site_title: Wedding belles
summary: The traditional Peranakan wedding ceremony, also known as a Baba wedding, is a laborious and time-consuming affair that can last up to 12 days. The ceremony, based on Chinese tradition, involves various rituals, including the Cheu Thau coming of age ceremony, serenades, and teasing the bride to make her laugh. The finale is the dua belas hari, where the marriage is confirmed and approved. However, these lavish weddings are on the decline, and their loss is felt, as they often ended with "happily ever after."

site_title: Hand crafting
summary: The Supermama Porcelain and Craft Festival 2017 is returning with a bigger second edition, featuring Japanese porcelain producers and furniture pieces. The event will take place at Blk 47 and Blk 7 from Sep 29 to Oct 1, showcasing quality materials and craftsmanship. Visitors can explore the festival, attend exhibitions, and shop for unique porcelain pieces, including slightly flawed items at discounted prices.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: STI 7.23 points weaker on Friday; down one point for the week
summary: The Singapore stock market saw a week of volatility, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending 7.23 points weaker at 3,219.91 on Friday. Factors contributing to the decline included a weaker industrial production report and a speech by US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen, which suggested a possible December interest rate hike. However, the market recovered slightly on Thursday and Friday. Analysts remain bullish on the market, with some predicting a potential tie-up between ComfortDelGro and Uber to boost its stock performance.

site_title: Old Zouk site up for sale as housing-commercial plot
summary: The former Zouk nightclub site at Jiak Kim Street in Singapore is up for sale by public tender after a developer committed to a bid of at least $689.35 million. The 1.35-hectare site, zoned for residential use with a commercial component, will be developed into a 36-storey mixed-use building with 525 housing units. The tender period is expected to last six weeks, with analysts predicting strong interest from developers due to the site's prime location and favorable market conditions.

site_title: Singapore scales up floating solar PV ambitions
summary: Singapore's national water agency, PUB, is exploring the installation of 50 MWp and 6.7 MWp floating solar PV systems in Tengeh and Upper Peirce reservoirs, respectively. The systems, which could power 12,500 homes, are expected to have minimal environmental impact and will be subject to comprehensive environmental studies. This move aims to increase Singapore's adoption of solar power, with the government setting a target of 1 GWp by 2020.

site_title: Two Japanese sushi chains plan merger as they set their sights on overseas expansion
summary: Japanese conveyor-belt sushi chains Genki Sushi Co and Sushiro Global Holdings Ltd are merging, with Genki's parent firm buying a one-third stake in Sushiro for around 38 billion yen. The deal aims to expand their presence overseas as the domestic market matures. Despite rising wages and competition, the firms see opportunities in international markets, with Genki already expanding abroad and Sushiro planning to go public. The merger is expected to boost sales and increase the number of outlets, helping the firms stay competitive in a slowing domestic market.

site_title: Royal plus
summary: Royal Pavilion at the Park Regis hotel has introduced a new chef, Chai Ngen Kin, who offers solid dim sum staples with a twist, including grilled siew mai with teriyaki sauce and addictive deep-fried burdock chips. The char siew 'snow buns' are particularly praised, rivaling Tim Ho Wan's version. The restaurant appeals to both classic and modern palates, offering reworked dishes like 'orh nee' as a charcoal 'briquette' crispy fritter of sweet yam.

site_title: World traveller
summary: NOMOS Glashütte has collaborated with The Hour Glass to create 50 limited edition NOMOS Red Dot watches based on the worldtimer Zürich Weltzeit, featuring a world map and the ability to display time in multiple time zones. The watches come in two colors: classic white and salmon, with 35 available with the classic dial and 15 with the new salmon dial. The watches feature the in-house DUW 5201 calibre.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Kmart being sued over banana suit
summary: Kmart is being sued by costume maker Silvertop Associates Inc, Rasta Imposta, over copyright and trade dress infringement for selling a banana costume similar to the company's copyrighted design. The lawsuit claims Kmart's costume is a direct replication of Rasta Imposta's Banana Design, which the company licenses and considers one of its most important costumes. The case highlights the lucrative business of Halloween costumes, with Americans expected to spend $9.1 billion on Halloween-related items this year.

site_title: Consumer spending barely increases in August
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.1% in August, slightly below expectations, due to the effects of Hurricane Harvey, which impacted car sales and reduced demand for utilities. Annual inflation rose at its slowest pace since late 2015, at 1.3%, and the economy's growth in the third quarter is expected to be dented, with Hurricane Irma also affecting the economy. However, economists predict a pick-up in output in the fourth quarter as communities rebuild.

site_title: Bank of Singapore golfers to return in 2018
summary: The Bank of Singapore golf team has committed to participating in the Business Times Corporate Golf League in 2018, marking their fifth consecutive year in the event. Team captain Kenny Chia expressed the team's enjoyment in the experience, citing the opportunity to bond with golfers from other companies.

site_title: Fashion world shaken by #NoFreePhotos row
summary: Photographers in the fashion industry have formed an unofficial union to combat the use of their street style images without crediting them. Over 40 photographers have threatened to shame brands and influencers who use their images without permission, citing the "work for free" culture in the multi-billion dollar industry. Influencers and bloggers often promote fashion labels' products on social media without giving credit to the photographers who took the images. This move aims to change the way images are used and valued in the fashion world.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shunt higher before weekend
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose ahead of the weekend, despite a softer showing on Wall Street, as investors remained cautious due to weak US inflation data and uncertainty over the European Central Bank's bond-buying plans. The London market was boosted by rising oil prices and a softer pound, while Asian equities mostly climbed after US President Trump unveiled proposals to cut corporate taxes. Despite these gains, analysts remain in "wait-and-see mode" and will be watching for confirmation of the eurozone's economic strength and corporate earnings in the third quarter.

site_title: Sept market value of S'pore stocks dips as broad market slides
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a decline for the third consecutive month in September, with a 0.7% drop in the total market capitalization of SGX-listed companies to S$978.4 million.

site_title: Grab pumps US$15m into autonomous vehicle startup
summary: Grab invests US$15 million in autonomous vehicle startup Drive.ai, deepening its efforts in autonomous vehicles and potentially paving the way for autonomous ridesharing in Singapore. Drive.ai's driverless technology could be deployed in Singapore, further solidifying Grab's presence in the global land transport space.

site_title: Formula One: Malaysia track given all-clear after freak crash
summary: Formula One inspectors have cleared the Sepang circuit in Malaysia after a loose drain caused a tyre explosion during practice for the Malaysian Grand Prix. Romain Grosjean's Haas was struck at high speed after a drain grille popped up on turn nine, causing a shock. Inspectors inspected and reinforced the drain covers, giving the circuit the all-clear.

site_title: Catalan separatists determined to hold independence vote
summary: Catalan separatists have taken over dozens of schools in Barcelona to hold an independence referendum banned by Madrid. The referendum, scheduled for Sunday, aims to determine the region's future. Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont has declared that the referendum is "within reach" despite police efforts to stop it. The move is seen as a defiant act by separatists, who claim the right to self-determination. The outcome of the referendum is uncertain, with Spanish authorities threatening to take legal action.

site_title: Chinese money seeping into world's housing markets
summary: Chinese buyers continue to drive up housing prices worldwide despite Beijing's crackdown on currency outflows. The authorities' efforts to stem capital outflows have prompted buyers to seek cheaper homes in smaller cities, making down payments more manageable. As a result, Chinese buyers are increasingly looking for properties in cities like Florida and Texas, and are spending up to $612,000 for US homes and $612,000 for UK properties. The trend is expected to continue, putting upward pressure on prices and stoking concern among locals.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC's CEO Helen Wong is retiring and Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named as her successor. Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: A stellar tradition
summary: The Audi Tradition building in Germany is a repository of the brand's historic models, featuring a collection of rare and exclusive vehicles, including vintage motorcycles, tiny roadsters, vans, and luxurious limousines. The building, unlike the modern Audi Museum, is utilitarian in design and houses the essence of Audi's automotive heritage. Audi historian Thomas Erdmann guides visitors through the collection, sharing stories and details about each model, including the iconic Audi Quattro coupe and the exceptionally rare Audi Group S prototype. The collection showcases Audi's rich motorsport heritage and its legacy in the automotive industry.

site_title: The end of Germany's centrism
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a tax reform plan, including a 20% corporate tax cut. This move is part of a grand plan for tax reform, although the specifics were not new. Trump also threatened "devastating" force against North Korea.

images.alt_text: While German Chancellor Angela Merkel's party the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) won the most seats, the key point is that the centrist coalition that has long ruled Germany is no longer in place.

site_title: Greece hopes to resolve Hellenikon project obstacles
summary: Greece hopes to resolve the Hellenikon project obstacles by the end of the year, despite ongoing delays due to disagreements with archaeologists over the environmental and cultural impact of a 99-year lease deal. The 620-hectare wasteland site, once Athens airport, is set to be turned into one of Europe's biggest coastal resorts with an 8 billion euro investment. The project's fate will be decided by the culture minister after the archaeological council's recommendations are taken into account, with Greece aiming to issue a decree for the project to proceed by the end of the year.

site_title: Lyft IPO expected to compound Uber's troubles
summary: Lyft is preparing to go public as early as next year, capitalizing on Uber's self-inflicted damage. The ride-hailing firm, valued at $7.5 billion, would gain fresh capital to expand into more cities and gain riders and drivers. With Uber facing scandals, executive flight, and firings, Lyft sees an opportunity to close the valuation gap between the two firms. Despite being relatively small, Lyft is growing faster and losing less money than Uber, and additional capital would help it take advantage of Uber's woes.

site_title: Mortgage rates, applications stall as US housing market stumbles
summary: US mortgage rates stalled at 3.83% for 30-year fixed rates and 3.13% for 15-year fixed rates, despite weak housing data. Pending home sales fell 2.6% and existing sales dropped 1.7% in August, with new home sales also declining 1.7%. Home prices rose 5.9% in July, putting upward pressure on mortgage rates. Investors anticipate a rate hike in December, but experts disagree on the direction of mortgage rates, with some predicting a fall or stability.

site_title: WeWork sees 'huge opportunity' for growth in Asia
summary: WeWork, a US-based co-working startup valued at over $20 billion, is seeking growth in Asia and has acquired Singapore-based Spacemob. The company aims to build an entrepreneurial ecosystem in Singapore, expanding its presence to 165 locations in 53 cities worldwide. With over 150,000 members, WeWork plans to capitalize on the growing demand for flexible office spaces in the region. The move is part of WeWork's strategy to establish itself as a major player in the Asian market.

site_title: Hurrah at the Yarra for Sean Lee
summary: A 13-year-old Singaporean golfer, Sean Lee, finished runner-up in the Under-14 boys' event at the Victoria Junior Masters in Melbourne, boosting the success of the Singapore Golf Association's (SGA) Junior Camp. The programme has seen an overall improvement in standards among junior golfers, with many parents and children enjoying the training camps and competitions, providing a break from school schedules. This achievement is a significant fillip for the programme, demonstrating its potential to produce talented golfers.

site_title: Chinese manufacturing accelerates for second straight month
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded for a second consecutive month in September, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) reaching 52.4, its fastest pace since 2012. The growth was driven by improving demand at home and overseas, as well as a booming high-tech industry. However, an independent indicator, Caixin, reported a lower reading of 51, citing outstanding price pressure as a drag on companies' profitability. China's economy has grown at 6.9% in the first and second quarters, but analysts warn that the country's huge debt load could weigh on growth.

site_title: TV for our times
summary: The Emmys have confirmed The Handmaid's Tale as the best TV drama of the year, with Elizabeth Moss being named the queen of the small screen. Based on Margaret Atwood's classic novel, the show tells a terrifying tale of a dystopian America where fertile women are turned into concubines. The show's success has led to a resurgence in Atwood's novel, which has re-entered bestseller lists worldwide, drawing parallels with the current political climate under Trump.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Cap seen for any upside in property stocks
summary: Analysts expect a residential price recovery in Singapore, but some see limited growth headroom for developers' share prices due to valuations already factored in. A recent report from Daiwa Capital Markets suggests that developers with meaningful landbanks still have undemanding valuations ahead of the market recovery.

site_title: Anger grows over Puerto Rico relief effort
summary: US President Donald Trump's response to the Puerto Rico hurricane relief effort has come under fire, with growing criticism from officials and residents. Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz of San Juan accused the administration of downplaying the severity of the disaster, while Acting Homeland Security Secretary Elaine Duke later apologized for her earlier "good news story" comments. Trump defended the response, saying it's been "catastrophic" and that a massive federal mobilization is underway. Despite efforts to deliver aid, only 4.5% of the population has electricity, and 50% of residents have running water.

site_title: Commonwealth Games-UK govt confirms Birmingham 2022 bid
summary: The UK government has confirmed Birmingham as the sole bidder for the 2022 Commonwealth Games, with a bid submission set for Saturday. The city will receive full official backing, with the government covering 75% of the estimated £750 million budget. Birmingham City Council will contribute 25% to the cost. The games are expected to showcase Britain to the world and leave a strong sports legacy, with a focus on maximum value for money for taxpayers. The Commonwealth Games Federation is set to announce a new host by the end of the year.

site_title: Lereno Bio-Chem lines up a third RTO target as second attempt falls through
summary: Lereno Bio-Chem, a cash company, has secured a third reverse takeover (RTO) target after its second attempt with Kenyalang Property Development fell through. It has signed a new agreement with Knit Textile and Apparel, with Lim Siau Hing @ Lim Kim Hoe proposing to acquire Knit for S$26.4 million via new shares. This deal, if successful, would be Lereno's third RTO attempt, following a planned acquisition of Majubina Projects. Under the agreement, Lim will hold approximately 80.2% of the enlarged issued share capital of Lereno Bio-Chem.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Africa's little red dot
summary: Rwanda, a small land-locked nation in Africa, has been compared to Singapore due to its cleanliness, greenery, and safety. The country has made significant strides in recovery and growth since the genocide in 1994. Rwanda's government has taken inspiration from Singapore's model, with President Paul Kagame's administration implementing various initiatives to promote economic development and business-friendly policies. Several Singaporeans have set up business ventures in Rwanda, including poultry farms, logistics services, and food processing companies. The country's business climate is seen as promising, with Rwanda's Vision 2050 development plan modeled after Singapore's. Despite challenges, Rwanda's unique combination of peace, calm, and natural beauty makes it an attractive destination for entrepreneurs and expats, with many considering it a "second Singapore" in Africa.

site_title: Sunpower unit acquires steam outfit in China
summary: Sunpower Group has entered into a cooperative agreement to acquire at least 70% equity in a Chinese outfit supplying steam, heat, and electricity. The Chinese outfit, with a registered capital of 10 million yuan, will relocate and build new facilities in Xintai Economic Development Zone. Sunpower will fund the acquisition using its internal resources and net proceeds from convertible bonds. The deal is expected to contribute to the expansion of Sunpower's green investments business.

site_title: EU warns 'miracles' needed for Brexit progress
summary: The European Union warned that the UK needs a "miracle" to make progress in Brexit talks by the end of October, as EU leaders discussed post-Brexit reform plans. European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker said there would be "no sufficient progress" unless significant breakthroughs occur, citing a lack of progress on the UK's exit bill, Northern Ireland, and EU citizens' rights. British Prime Minister Theresa May insisted there had been "very good progress" on EU expatriates' rights, but EU leaders remain skeptical about meeting the October deadline for the next phase of Brexit talks.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: GuocoLand received a record-breaking S$1.62 billion bid for its leasehold mixed-use site in Beach Road, with a top bid of S$1,706 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The bid is expected to result in a blended average breakeven of around S$2,750-2,800 psf, with a potential 20-30% price increase for the office component and 5-10% for the residential component. GuocoLand's analysts maintain a BUY rating with an unchanged target price of S$2.80.

site_title: Austria moves to ban the burqa
summary: Austria has implemented new restrictions banning the wearing of the full Islamic veil and other face-covering items in public places and buildings, effective Sunday. Exemptions include clown disguises, medical masks, and scarves in cold weather. The move aims to ensure social cohesion and is part of a package of integration measures, including an "integration contract" and language courses. Violations may result in fines of up to 150 euros. The legislation was introduced by the outgoing government ahead of elections, where the anti-immigration Freedom Party is expected to perform well.

site_title: US consumer spending barely rises; core inflation moderates
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in August, matching economists' expectations, as Hurricane Harvey impacted auto sales and mild temperatures reduced utility demand. This moderation in economic growth suggests the third quarter may see slower growth. The core inflation rate, which is the Federal Reserve's preferred measure, slowed to 1.3% after advancing 1.4% in July, the smallest year-on-year increase since 2015.

site_title: Banks assess loan exposure as Qatar crisis deepens
summary: Qatari banks and financial institutions in neighboring countries are assessing their exposure to each other as the crisis deepens, with lenders reviewing existing loans and considering selling loans in the secondary market. The crisis began when Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt imposed travel and trade restrictions on Qatar, accusing it of backing terrorism. Qatar's economy has been under pressure, with the country injecting $38.5 billion into its economy to cushion the impact. Banks are seeking to balance their exposure and consider asset swaps or mandatory repayment if illegality clauses are triggered.

site_title: Trump to visit Asia in November, North Korea in spotlight
summary: US President Donald Trump will visit Asia in November, stopping in Japan, South Korea, China, Vietnam, and the Philippines. His trip, which includes attending two major summits, aims to address the North Korea nuclear threat. Trump will be joined by his wife Melania, and his attendance at the Manila summit had been in doubt due to concerns about Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's anti-American stance. The visit is expected to focus on economic cooperation and regional security, with Trump seeking to build relationships with Asian leaders and address pressing issues, including North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: Winding-up petition presented against Swing Media Technology Group
summary: A winding-up petition has been presented against Swing Media Technology Group Limited to the High Court of Hong Kong after the company failed to make a US$2 million payment within three weeks. The petition, filed on July 13, 2017, will be heard on November 15. The company's bank accounts have been suspended, and it has requested updates on any material developments. This follows a statutory demand issued to the company and its subsidiaries, requesting payment of US$2 million and HK$39 million.

site_title: Motivation? It's all in your head
summary: Helle Bundgaard, founder of Motivation Factor, spoke on sustained motivation, emphasizing a Hierarchy of Motivation with four tiers: energy, needs, talents, and purpose. People settle in ruts due to complexity and feeling powerless, leading to demotivation. To stay motivated, identify energy drainers, unmet needs, and utilize talents, and make discipline a habit to reach goals. Ultimately, individual responsibility is key to motivation, and while motivational talks can be helpful, action is necessary for lasting change.

site_title: French jewel thieves jailed, despite perfect crime
summary: A Paris court sentenced three jewel thieves to jail terms despite their "perfect crime" in 2016, when they stole $50 million from a De Beers store. The thieves had attempted to repeat the heist a year later, but were caught. The court distinguished between the two crimes, defining a successful robbery as one without the use of weapons. The thieves were handed prison sentences for their second attempt, highlighting the authorities' determination to bring them to justice.

site_title: IBF launches mobile learning app to train new capabilities in finance
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore (IBF) has launched Learn@IBF, a mobile learning app aimed at training finance professionals on emerging capabilities such as data science, innovation, and digital communication. The app will feature content from industry specialists and partners, including Amazon and IBM, to address topics like new technologies and risk management in a digital world. The app is part of IBF's efforts to support the finance industry's development of new skills and capabilities.

site_title: Low water, lock repairs send US river freights soaring
summary: US river freight rates surged to a three-year high due to low water levels and back-ups at ageing locks on the Mississippi River system, affecting grain shipments just as farmers need to ramp up deliveries of corn and soybeans. Shippers are loading barges with reduced capacity, increasing the need for more barges, while buyers at Gulf terminals scramble for supplies amid a growing back-up of bulk cargo ships. River levels are expected to drop further, threatening sales as rival South American exporters leave the stage.

site_title: Trump interviews four for Fed chair job, to decide in 2-3 weeks
summary: US President Donald Trump is narrowing down his search for a new Federal Reserve (Fed) chairman, meeting with four candidates including former Governor Kevin Warsh, Jerome Powell, and Stanford University economist John Taylor. Trump promised a decision within two to three weeks, with speculation that Warsh is the front-runner due to his hawkish stance on monetary policy. Trump had previously considered reappointing Janet Yellen, who expires as chair in February, but has since shifted his focus to the other candidates.

site_title: S'pore, Latin-American and Caribbean businesses in tie-ups
summary: Singapore and Latin America & the Caribbean businesses are exploring opportunities in technology and education. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran noted that Singapore-LAC economic relations have deepened. The 12th edition of the International Enterprise (IE) Singapore's Latin-Asia Business Forum (LABF) aims to increase trade and investment between the two regions.

images.alt_text: Mr S Iswaran notes that there are more than 200 Singapore companies with 400 points of presence across the LAC region.

site_title: Trump's health secretary resigns amid private-jet scandal
summary: Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price resigned amid controversy over his use of private and military jets at taxpayer expense, with over 2 dozen private flights and military trips costing over $1 million. Price cited a "privilege to serve" in his resignation letter, while President Trump said he was "not happy" with Price's conduct. Price's departure may distract from administration priorities, and his successor will face decisions on the Affordable Care Act, which Price's agency had slashed advertising funding for.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit records on tech lift
summary: US stocks hit records on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq advancing to new highs, driven by gains in technology stocks. The technology sector rose 0.75%, its fourth straight day of gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.11%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.37% and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.66%. The major indexes closed the quarter with solid gains, with the S&P and Dow recording eight straight quarters of gains.

site_title: Stock markets always rise over the long term
summary: Stock markets always rise over the long term due to fundamental factors such as population growth and rising standard of living, which drive consumption and business earnings. As long as there is a growing demand for goods and services, businesses collectively will do well and stock markets will rise. Investing in a broadly diversified portfolio of stocks over 10 years can generate significant returns, with index-based portfolios achieving 9.01% and 9.86% annualized returns between 2016 and 2017. Staying invested and avoiding market fluctuations can lead to long-term success.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Bayer finds a nifty time machine for big Covestro trade
summary: Bayer AG has sold a 7% stake in Covestro AG, taking its stake to below 25% for a price of 1 billion euros. The sale is permissible due to an existing lock-up preventing further share sales until mid-December, allowing Bayer to retain "economic exposure" and potentially receive more cash if the stock price increases before the lock-up expires. The deal allows Bayer to de-consolidate Covestro ahead of its 2017 annual results, which should appear cleaner.

site_title: Former Uber CEO names two directors without consulting board
summary: Former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick named two new directors, Ursula Burns and John Thain, without consulting the board or new leader Dara Khosrowshahi, sparking a battle for control of the company. Uber challenged the appointments, calling them a surprise, as Benchmark, Uber's largest shareholder, sues Kalanick for fraud and seeks to relinquish his control of three board seats. Kalanick defends the move, saying it's essential for proper deliberation, and remains supportive of Khosrowshahi ahead of a planned vote on Uber's governance structure.

site_title: Lereno Bio-Chem shoots for third RTO attempt as second one falls through
summary: Lereno Bio-Chem, a cash company, has successfully inked a new reverse takeover (RTO) pact with Knit Textile and Apparel, its third attempt after its previous deal with Kenyalang Property Development fell through. The new deal, valued at S$26.4 million, will see Lereno Bio-Chem acquire Knit, a private company with an issued and paid-up share capital of S$2. The deal is conditional on shareholder approval and will see Mr. Lim, the owner of Knit, holding approximately 80.2% of Lereno Bio-Chem's enlarged issued share capital.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: The property market - is it a-turnin'?
summary: Analysts predict Singapore's private housing sector may see the first increase in property prices after 15 quarters of decline, with forecasts ranging from 0.1% to 10-15% growth over the next 12-15 months. Morgan Stanley expects a 0.8% quarter-on-quarter rise, while OCBC Investment Research believes the bottom has been reached and prices may surge another 20% if foreigners re-enter the market. However, some analysts, such as Ku Swee Yong, remain cautious, citing a weak job market, slow population growth, and stagnant bank valuations.

site_title: Straits Trading unit buys into Tokyo residential property
summary: Straits Trading's real estate arm, Straits Real Estate (SRE), acquired a 98.5% stake in a Tokyo residential property for 448 million yen (S$5.41 million). The property, located in Nerima-ku, has 96 apartments with a 99% occupancy rate. The acquisition is part of SRE's strategy to redeploy capital into higher-yielding opportunities, with minimal impact on Straits Trading's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Google is said to retool user security in wake of political hack
summary: Google is launching the Advanced Protection Program, a service that will enhance online account security by blocking third-party access to user data. The program, set to begin in October, will provide physical security keys to protect accounts such as email and Google Drive. The move comes after high-profile hacks, including the 2016 Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta. The service will be marketed to corporate executives, politicians, and others with heightened security concerns, offering an alternative to two-factor authentication. Google plans to continuously update the program to protect user data.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish Friday mixed, STI flat for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) finished Friday at 3,219.91, flat for the week after losing 7.23 points. The session was mixed, with 215 rises and 184 falls in turnover. Expectations of a US rate hike and big tax cuts were major market forces.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.3% to 7,340.82 points, and the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. Mining and healthcare stocks drove gains, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: After winning Trump's ear, Boeing gets victory in trade row
summary: Boeing has secured a victory in the trade row with the Trump administration, with the US imposing larger duties on Bombardier's jet than Boeing had requested. This comes after Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg established a direct channel with President Trump, who initially scolded the company on Twitter. Boeing's shares have risen 63% this year, making it the best performer on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The company is now pushing forward with a case against Bombardier, seeking to counter the Canadian company's government support.

site_title: 60 years on, WP continues to thrive and renew its ranks: Sylvia Lim
summary: Workers' Party chairman Sylvia Lim expressed confidence in the party's "healthy breed" of younger leaders and members, who will take over leadership roles. The party has thrived despite 60 years of challenges, including lawsuits and financial difficulties. The party has purchased a new 1,200 sq ft headquarters, marking a significant milestone in its history. The move is seen as a "firm foundation" for the party's future, with a 99-year lease remaining. The party will celebrate its 60th anniversary with an 80-table dinner and the launch of a documentary and commemorative book.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 2.48 points to 1,755.58, with a trading volume of 2 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion.

site_title: Singapore SMEs wary about prospects over next 6 months
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are becoming increasingly pessimistic about their business prospects over the next six months, with all sectors except retail/F&B expecting a decline in profit performance. The SBF-DP SME Index fell 0.3 points to 50.6, indicating a cautious outlook. Construction/engineering and commerce/trading sectors are the most pessimistic, with scores of 49.9 and 4.80, respectively. SMEs attribute their pessimism to a muted economy, high input costs, and competition, with many expecting weaker earnings or even losses.

site_title: Spanish pride
summary: Manolo Blahnik collaborates with Castaner, a Spanish family-owned business, on a capsule collection of espadrilles. The collection, comprising three models in six colors, combines traditional craftsmanship with modern luxury. Blahnik aims to preserve traditional shoemaking techniques, while Castañer values the art of handmade espadrilles. The collection is available exclusively at the Castaner boutique and prices start from S$490 for flats to S$690 for heels, reflecting the brand's commitment to timeless classics and contemporary authenticity.

site_title: Chinese border trading hub struggles with housing glut as N.Korea ties fray
summary: China's border city of Dandong is struggling with a housing glut, with over 4 million sq m of unsold inventory, despite falling inventories in other parts of the country. The glut is attributed to international sanctions on North Korea, which has led to a decline in trade and tourism, resulting in lower property prices. The city's New Zone development, expected to boost trade and tourism, remains unfinished and idle due to the sanctions. With 28.8 months to work through its inventory, Dandong faces a long period of unsold housing, affecting homeowners and investors.

site_title: TT Int'l seeking legal advice on appointment of receivers for Big Box
summary: TT International, a Singapore-based consumer electronics retailer, has received a notice of appointment of receivers for its 51%-owned subsidiary Big Box Pte Ltd. The appointment was made by Ernst & Young Solutions LLP on behalf of OCBC as security trustee for the lenders under the BBPL facility. TT International is seeking legal advice on the matter and has a moratorium in place until February 11, 2018, to restrict creditors from taking further action. The company is restructured under a scheme of arrangement since April 2010 and is in talks with lenders to obtain funding to refinance and repay debt.

site_title: Near-term outlook for China okay but credit excesses pose risks
summary: China's near-term outlook appears positive, with companies reporting a sharp profit upturn of 18% in the second quarter, driven by rising sales and improving margins. The banking sector has also seen improved earnings growth, with asset quality of bank loans declining. However, concerns remain about China's debt build-up and credit excesses, which may pose risks to economic growth in the medium term. Investors are looking forward to reforms to open up the economy and shift focus to domestic consumption, which could drive growth in a sustainable manner.

site_title: Take investment-related aphorisms with lots of salt
summary: Investors often rely on unproven investment aphorisms, such as the notion that individual bonds are safer than bond funds due to interest-rate risk. However, this strategy merely trades one risk for another, as holding individual bonds to maturity can result in losses due to inflation. Other market-related arguments, including the idea that low volume rallies spell trouble for stocks and that margin debt indicates euphoria, are also based on flawed logic. A more nuanced approach is needed to understand the relationship between bond performance and interest rates, and to make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close slightly lower as yen picks up
summary: Tokyo stocks closed slightly lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.03% and the Topix index down 0.08%. The decline was attributed to a gradual pick-up in the yen exchange rate affecting exporters.

site_title: Institutional noteholders weigh in on Nam Cheong scheme
summary: Malaysian banks RHB and CIMB have emerged as significant institutional investors in Nam Cheong's medium-term notes, weighing in on the company's scheme of arrangement (SA) for debt restructuring under Singapore's updated debt restructuring regime. The banks, among seven lenders to Nam Cheong's subsidiaries, have more at stake if the debt revamp goes awry. Nam Cheong has proposed a debt-to-equity swap and immediate conversion of debts into shares, sparking debate among noteholders on the fairness of the terms.

site_title: Extending your childhood - one brick at a time
summary: A lifelong passion for Lego bricks is shared by author Michelle Quah, who collects Lego Creator Expert sets that number in the thousands. These sets, designed for adults, allow her to relive childhood dreams of building iconic structures and vehicles. Like Ed Sheeran, who invested in Lego sets as a child, Quah finds solace in these sets, which transport her back to her childhood and foster creativity and joy. Rare and discontinued sets can also appreciate in value over time, making them a worthwhile investment.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: ST Aero injects capital into aircraft leasing unit
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm, ST Aerospace, has injected US$10.5 million into ST Aerospace Resources, a 50% stake in Keystone Holdings, to expand its aircraft leasing business. This brings the total share capital contribution to about US$20 million, with no expected impact on ST Engineering's financials.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia's PNB looks to sell two British properties
summary: Malaysia's Permodalan Nasional Bhd (PNB) is considering selling two commercial properties in London, 1 Silk Street and 90 High Holborn, after they matured. PNB bought the properties in 2012 for £350 million and £140 million, respectively. The sale could suggest a redeployment of funds to Malaysia, as PNB has another three commercial properties in Britain and one in Australia. The move comes amid strong demand for British real estate, following the Malaysian state-owned funds' entry into the market in 2010-2013.

site_title: Hanwell acquires property in Osaka for 575 million yen
summary: Hanwell Holdings acquired a 5-storey building in Osaka, Japan for 575 million yen (S$6.9 million). The property, strategically located in Dotonbori, will serve as a stepping stone for the company's food business expansion in Japan. The acquisition will be funded by internal resources, with payment to be made upon completion of certain milestones. Hanwell aims to redeploy capital into potentially higher return real estate opportunities.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Australia shares close up but fall for fifth straight month; NZ firm
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,681.6, but fell for the fifth straight month, losing 0.7% this quarter. Materials and consumer staples led gains, while healthcare and industrial stocks also rose. New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.2%, marking a ninth straight month of gains. Despite uncertainty over the Australian government, investors appear unfazed, with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand reporting a solid economy and foreign buying interest in the local market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post first monthly loss this year
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day higher, but posted a 1.5% monthly loss in September, marking the first monthly loss this year. The Hang Seng index rose 0.5% to 27,554.30, reducing this year's gain to 25%. Investors are awaiting China's 19th Communist Party Congress and third-quarter economic data, amid concerns over US monetary tightening and China's economic slowdown. The market's upward momentum may be slowing, with investors watching for signs of China's economic recovery and US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in August rose 0.3% from July, driven by higher loans to financial institutions. A residential site at Jiak Kim Street is up for public tender, while a 99-year private housing site along West Coast Vale is available for application. Singapore is investing in Latin America and the Caribbean, and struggling retailer TT International has received a notice of appointment of receivers for its subsidiary Big Box. Keppel's BrasFELS shipyard delivered its fifth FPSO project, and ST Aerospace injected capital into its aircraft leasing unit.

site_title: Man City striker Aguero injured in Dutch car crash
summary: Manchester City striker Sergio Aguero sustained injuries in a car crash in the Netherlands on Thursday and will be assessed by club doctors upon his return to Britain on Friday. The 29-year-old was driving a taxi when it hit a lamp post, and three people were transferred to hospital for observation. Aguero is set to return to Manchester ahead of the weekend's Premier League fixtures, including City's match against Chelsea on Saturday. The severity of his injuries is not specified.

images.alt_text: Manchester City's Argentine striker Sergio Aguero "sustained injuries" in a car crash in the Netherlands and is returning to Britain to be checked ahead of the weekend's Premier League fixtures, the club said Friday.

site_title: New Uber CEO to meet London transport boss next Tuesday
summary: Uber's new CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, will meet with London Transport Commissioner Mike Brown next Tuesday to discuss the decision to strip Uber's licence in London due to concerns over reporting serious crimes and driver background checks. The licence is set to expire on Saturday. Khosrowshahi aims to "work with London to make things right" following the decision, made by Transport for London on September 22.

site_title: China's bitcoin market alive and well as traders defy crackdown
summary: China's bitcoin market remains active despite a crackdown by regulators. Weeks after Beijing banned fundraising through token launches and shut some exchanges, traders have turned to peer-to-peer marketplaces and encrypted apps to buy and sell bitcoin. The price of bitcoin in China now trades at a discount to overseas exchanges, creating an arbitrage opportunity for investors. Industry insiders say the market is unlikely to be eliminated, with many users anonymous and difficult to track.

site_title: Euro-area inflation stuck too low as ECB debates stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank is awaiting a sustainable pickup in euro-area inflation, which remains below its target of 2% due to strong growth and weak price gains. Consumer prices increased 1.5% annually in September, unchanged from August, and core price growth weakened to 1.1%. The ECB will decide on October 26 whether to start tapering bond purchases, which could impact the euro's value and import costs. Bank of France Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau urged the ECB to be "pragmatic" in reducing bond purchases, citing strong domestic demand as offsetting the euro's appreciation.

site_title: Formula One: China extends F1 deal for three more years
summary: China has extended its Formula One Grand Prix deal for three more years, with the Shanghai Grand Prix scheduled to continue through at least 2027. The event, which debuted in 2004, will now take place a week later next year, on April 15, swapping places with the Bahrain race. The change is made to avoid conflicting with China's Qingming national holiday.

site_title: Audi A5 Cabriolet review: A soft top with lots of booty
summary: Audi's new A5 Cabriolet boasts a stunning design, with a soft top and curvaceous lines that evoke a sense of luxury and beauty. However, the cabin's clean layout and lack of character may deter some, while the steering feels vague and the handling lacks precision. Despite this, the convertible transforms into a comfortable cruiser when its roof is down, making it a desirable choice for those who value style over driving dynamics. With seating for four adults and a spacious boot, the A5 Cabriolet is a practical option, but its rivals from BMW and Mercedes-Benz may offer better driving experiences.

site_title: Vietnam ex-banker sentenced to death in fraud saga
summary: A Vietnamese former banking executive, Nguyen Xuan Son, was sentenced to death for embezzlement, abuse of power, and economic mismanagement in a massive fraud case. His co-accused, Ha Van Tham, was jailed for life. The trial, which targeted 51 bankers and businessmen, was part of Vietnam's anti-corruption sweep. The sentences were handed down as the country struggles with corruption, ranking high among Asian nations. The scandal led to the demise of Ocean Bank and highlighted the banking sector's issues with dodgy loans and favoritism.

site_title: How to build a US$60m art trove while staying within your means
summary: Heinz and Ruthe Eppler, a couple who started collecting modern art in the late 1970s, are set to sell their art trove at Christie's for over $60 million. The collection, which includes works by Picasso, de Kooning, and Kline, was assembled over several decades with the advice of a museum curator. Unlike megacollectors who store art in private museums, the Epplers bought works to fill their homes, with a focus on abstract expressionism. The collection, which includes a Kline painting that sold for $20 million in 1985, is expected to fetch a total of over $60 million, with some pieces selling for as much as $6 million.

images.alt_text: Light Mechanic (1960) by Franz Kline, estimated at US$20 million, is the star of the Eppler collection at the Christie's auction in November. The Epplers paid US$900,000 - a steep price in 1985 - for this 8-foot-tall canvas by the master of muscular black strokes on white ground.

site_title: Japan Post to invest funds from future group share sales for growth - CEO
summary: Japan Post Holdings plans to use proceeds from future share sales of its financial units for growth measures, including acquisitions, rather than returning money to shareholders. CEO Masatsugu Nagato stated that the company will focus on investments, citing a lack of clear growth prospects for the postal business. Japan Post's parcel delivery business has seen a sharp rise in volume, but labor shortages are pushing up costs. The company's dividend yield is 3.7%, attracting investors, but it aims to lure more investors with its growth plans.

site_title: UK PM Theresa May defends Uber on same day she attacks Boeing
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May defended Uber on the same day she criticized Boeing, citing jobs in Belfast and Northern Ireland. May expressed concerns over Boeing's case against Bombardier, which threatens workers, and contrasted it with Uber's safety issues. However, her defense of Uber has raised eyebrows, as she has previously attacked footloose companies and flouting rules. The move is seen as a possible attempt to discredit London Mayor Sadiq Khan, who has been a vocal critic of Uber, ahead of the next election.

site_title: West Coast housing site available for application on reserve list
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released the sales conditions for a 99-year private housing site along West Coast Vale, making it available for application on the reserve list of the second-half 2017 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. The 1.959-hectare site, which can potentially yield up to 730 private homes, is located near existing condominiums and major transportation links. This is the first time the site has been made available for application, following its placement on the reserve list.

site_title: Tea and Tiananmen: Inside China's new censorship machine
summary: China's online censorship efforts have intensified, with hundreds of young censors working for Beijing ByteDance Technology Co, the parent company of popular news feed app Toutiao. The censors review and remove content deemed counter to Communist Party doctrine, including references to President Xi Jinping and the Tiananmen protests. The government has been tightening control over online content ahead of a Communist Party congress, where Xi is expected to bolster his leadership. The censorship efforts have been met with criticism and concern, with some describing it as a "chilling effect" on free speech.

site_title: Formula One: Verstappen sets pace in rain-hit Malaysia practice
summary: Max Verstappen set the pace in the rain-hit first practice session for the Malaysian Grand Prix, completing 11 laps and posting a 1min 48.962sec lap time. Daniel Ricciardo was 0.757sec behind, while Fernando Alonso secured third place with a strong final lap. Lewis Hamilton struggled in the conditions, finishing sixth, and championship rival Sebastian Vettel was fifth. Rookie Pierre Gasly impressed with the ninth-fastest time, completing 14 laps in his Toro Rosso.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won recover as investors square positions ahead of long holiday
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.9% on Friday, recovering from recent losses, as investors squared their positions ahead of a long holiday break. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,394.47 points, up 0.2% for the week and 1.3% for the month. The won also rose 0.3% to 1,145.4 to the dollar, snapping a four-day selling streak by foreign investors. The market will close from October 2-9 due to national holiday break.

site_title: London house prices fall for first time in 8 years
summary: London house prices have fallen for the first time in 8 years, with a 0.6% annual decline in September, according to Nationwide. This marks the weakest performing region in the UK since 2005. Nationally, house prices rose 2% year-on-year in September, the slowest pace in over four years. Pressure on household incomes due to inflation and slow wage growth is cited as the main reason for the slowdown. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates, but Nationwide believes a modest rise will have a small impact.

site_title: Singapore investments in Latin America, the Caribbean still growing
summary: Singapore's investments in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) continue to grow, reaching a compounded annual growth rate of 9% over a five-year period. The region's economy is recovering from a slowdown, with Singapore's stock of direct investments valued at S$18.1 billion in 2016. New sectors such as technology and education are emerging as opportunities for Singapore businesses, with companies like CrimsonLogic and Educare expanding operations into the region. The government encourages closer collaboration to tap into new markets and growth sectors, positioning Singapore as a key player in LAC trade and investment.

site_title: Making time for the ladies
summary: Patek Philippe, a 178-year-old Swiss luxury watch brand, has been designing watches for women since 1839, with three sold to Madame Goscinska in its first year. The brand has consistently catered to women, offering a wide range of complications, including chronograph, annual calendar, moon phase, and perpetual calendar timepieces. Patek Philippe's women's timepieces are designed around the movement, with attention to detail and beauty, and are often more accurate than men's timepieces. The brand's commitment to women's timepieces has been recognized by its head of creation, Sandrine Stern, and the company's president, Thierry Stern.

images.alt_text: (1) The ladies' Annual Calendar Moon Phases launched in 2006.
(2) A modern woman's Minute Repeater watch unveiled in 2016.
(3) A woman's Travel Time watch launched in 2007.
(4) The latest Perpetual Calendar Moon Phase watch launched in 2017.
(5) A ladies' World Time watch launched to celebrate Patek Philippe's 175th anniversary in 2014.

site_title: As Brexit talks drag, EU is said to see Davis as an obstacle
summary: European officials view UK Brexit negotiator David Davis as an obstacle in Brexit talks, with EU chief Michel Barnier welcoming a "new dynamic" despite limited progress. Davis declared that the UK would only settle its financial obligations if a trade deal is struck, contradicting Prime Minister Theresa May's offer to honor the UK's financial obligations. The fourth round of negotiations ended with trade talks potentially being put off for months, and the EU is considering bringing forward talks on the transitional arrangement.

site_title: Oil mixed but set for weekly gain
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Friday but set for a weekly gain as investors believe efforts to cut a global glut are working and demand outlook is improving. US crude fell 4 cents to $51.52 a barrel, heading for a fourth consecutive weekly gain and a 9% advance this month.

site_title: Disgraced US football star OJ Simpson to be released from prison
summary: OJ Simpson, the former NFL star and actor, is set to be released from prison as early as Monday after serving nine years for armed robbery. Simpson, 70, was granted parole in July and plans to relocate to Florida, where he will play golf and be around friends and family. He was found not guilty in 1995 of murdering his ex-wife and a male companion, but was convicted in 2008 for armed robbery and sentenced to nine years. Simpson's release comes after a nearly eight-hour documentary about his murder trial won the Oscar for best documentary, and a TV mini-series about the case won nine Emmy awards.

site_title: Why neighbourhood toy stores boom while Toys R Us goes bust
summary: Toys R Us filed for bankruptcy due to $7.9 billion in debt, largely stemming from a 2005 leveraged buyout. In contrast, independent toy stores like Barstons Child's Play in Washington DC have seen a revival, with annual sales climbing 3% and revenue in the millions. These stores offer unique experiences, curated selections, and personalized service, appealing to parents seeking more than just online shopping. Experts say independent toy stores have an advantage over online retailers, allowing children to play and explore in-store, creating a memorable experience.

site_title: VW takes new 2.5b euros hit over diesel emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen has added 2.5 billion euros to its provisions related to the diesel emissions scandal, increasing the total cost to around 20 billion euros. The increase is due to a more complex and time-consuming buyback/retrofit program for 2.0l TDI vehicles in North America. The company has recalled around 11 million vehicles worldwide since admitting to manipulating emissions tests two years ago, with 8.5 million in Europe. Volkswagen's shares dropped 3.1% following the statement, with some traders questioning the sustainability of the company's settlements.

site_title: Singapore August bank lending up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in August rose 0.3% from July, reaching S$634.4 billion, driven by higher loans to financial institutions. This marks a 5.1% increase from the same period last year. Loans denominated in Asian currencies also rose 0.3% to S$569.1 billion.

site_title: Angry Birds maker Rovio's shares in high-flying debut
summary: Rovio Entertainment, the maker of Angry Birds, made its stock market debut with its shares trading at 12.11 euros, a 5.3% increase from the IPO price. Analysts note that the high valuation is based on the company's historical profit growth, and Rovio needs to maintain its performance to justify the market valuation of 950 million euros. The IPO was multiple times oversubscribed, indicating initial demand, but experts are cautious, expecting the company to continue delivering good performance.

site_title: UK annual GDP growth revised down for Q2, July services weak
summary: The UK economy recorded its weakest year-on-year growth since 2013 in Q2, with gross domestic product growth slowing to 1.5% from 1.8% in the first quarter. The services sector, which accounts for 80% of the economy, contracted in July, showing a possible loss of momentum ahead of the Bank of England's first interest rate hike in a decade. The current account deficit widened to 4.6% in Q2, and consumer confidence figures showed a slight increase despite rising pessimism about household finances.

site_title: Lehman, Citi settle US$2b financial crisis-era dispute
summary: Citigroup and the estate of Lehman Brothers have settled a long-standing dispute over $2.1 billion, with Citigroup agreeing to return $1.74 billion. The dispute dated back to the 2008 financial crisis and involved claims over derivatives trades. The settlement resolves a key question about derivatives-trading practices and will benefit Lehman's unsecured creditors. The agreement came 40 days into a trial in New York that shed light on the frenzied weekend before Lehman's bankruptcy filing.

site_title: Yuan set for 1st monthly loss since April
summary: China's yuan fell 0.3% against the US dollar, set for its first monthly loss since April, due to weaker central bank fixings and strong US dollar demand. The yuan's year-to-date gains against the greenback have been shaved to around 4% from 7.5% earlier this month, amid concerns over export competitiveness. Authorities are believed to have applied the brakes on the currency's rapid rise.

site_title: Twitter reveals Russia-backed ads ahead of US election
summary: Twitter revealed nearly 2,000 Russian-backed ads were placed on its platform in 2016, ahead of the US presidential election, with RT spending $274,000 on ads that may have influenced the election. The company shared data with congressional investigators and removed tweets that attempted to suppress voting rights. The news comes after Facebook acknowledged foreign entities linked to Russia paid to promote political messages, potentially violating US election laws. Twitter's presentation was criticized as "deeply disappointing" and "inadequate" by Democratic Senator Mark Warner.

site_title: US will need immigrants for jobs created by Trump tax reform
summary: US President Donald Trump's tax reform plan is expected to create jobs, but the labor market is extremely tight, making it difficult for native-born workers to fill the positions. According to Jonas Prising, head of Manpower, immigration will be necessary to support job growth, as the labor force participation rate is near a 40-year low. This contradicts Trump's plan to reduce immigration, which includes building a wall on the border with Mexico. The US will need to rely on immigrants to fill the gap, raising questions about the compatibility of these policies.

site_title: Thai Aug factory output rises 3.74% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's annual industrial output rose 3.74% in August, beating forecasts, driven by stronger production of cars, rubber, and electronics. This marks the second consecutive month of growth, with exports jumping 13.2% and capacity utilisation at 62.46%. The Bank of Thailand raised its 2017 economic growth forecast to 3.8% due to these positive indicators.

site_title: Notre-Dame needs a makeover, and hopes you can help
summary: The Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris is in dire need of a major makeover due to extensive deterioration. Experts say the 850-year-old Gothic structure has reached a tipping point, requiring urgent restoration work estimated to cost 150 million euros. The cathedral's iconic features, such as flying buttresses and gargoyles, are suffering from pollution, rainwater erosion, and structural damage. A newly created foundation aims to raise funds in the US, capitalizing on the architectural patriotism of the French and the francophilia of US donors. The French state has pledged to double its annual upkeep, but a complete renovation is estimated to require nearly $110 million.

site_title: A whole new bam!
summary: BAM! has undergone a revamp to become an omakase-only restaurant, featuring Japanese ingredients and Spanish influences. Menus range from four courses at S$98++ to eight courses at S$188++ with sake-pairings available at additional S$58++ and S$98++. Chef Pepe Moncayo's dishes include cold somen with sudachi lime and Kyoho grapes, and a "gazpachuelo" with tuna noten, sago, and tobiko.

site_title: Gold inches lower, on track for worst month this year
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,284.28 per ounce, on track for a 2.8% decline in September, the largest monthly drop this year. The US dollar's strength, driven by a tax plan and Federal Reserve policy, contributed to the decline. Gold is also sensitive to rising US interest rates, which boost the dollar and increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Sunmoon add shine to competition
summary: Team Sunmoon dominated the 2017 Business Times Corporate Golf League competition with three consecutive victories from 2012 to 2014 and a title win in 2016. However, they slipped to third place in the Open Category this year, finishing three points behind Team Boustead and Tat Hong - The Crane Boomers, who tied for the top spot with a better score in the final leg. Team Sunmoon's star players, including captain Tan Teck Lee and Lee Tien Beng, contributed to the team's success, but their poor performance in the final round cost them the title.

site_title: Aston Martin's ultimate toy for your superyacht - a submarine
summary: Aston Martin unveiled Project Neptune, a three-person submarine designed for superyachts, at the Monaco Yacht Show. The submersible, dubbed Neptune, features silver, blade-like pontoons and an acrylic cabin for underwater views. Priced around $4 million, it's expected to be available in about a year. The collaboration between Aston Martin Consulting and Triton Submarines aims to cater to high-net-worth individuals seeking unique experiences beyond luxury cars, with a limited annual production of 12 units.

images.alt_text: Designed as an accessory for superyachts, it's the smallest, lightest three-person sub in production. Oh, and it costs about US$4 million.

"Those superyacht people, what they want to experience is changing. It's no longer about just having a launch or having your tender. It's about having some other way of entertaining your guests." Aston Martin's chief creative officer Marek Reichman, on high-net-worth individuals' penchant for boating, which is why the company started to look beyond building cars

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.08 points to 1,757.98. The index saw a trading volume of 109.66 million lots worth RM37.39 million, with 111 gainers and 81 losers.

site_title: Home additions
summary: The Maison&Objet Paris show featured innovative home decor items from various brands. Big Blue's resin stone replicas of ocean elements and Qeeboo's quirky furniture designs, such as the Ribbon Chair and Killer umbrella, were showcased. AP Collection's stuffed toy chairs and Kitchibe's understated stone-like diffusers were also highlighted. Other notable brands included Kristina Dam's sculptural minimalism, Bump's minimalist glass vessels, and Tiny Miracles' handmade paper products. Industry+ showcased its Take A Seat collection, featuring Wimbledon-inspired chairs. These brands offer unique and functional designs for the modern home.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Cheryl Gan
summary: Singapore entrepreneur Cheryl Gan, 40, rebranded her aromatherapy business Mt Sapola as HYSSES, with a new logo and website, after 10 years of operation in the country. The move aims to expand internationally, with London as the first European market target. Gan credits her mentor, Low Cheong Yew, founder of Home-Fix, for advising her on business decisions. As a working mother of four, Gan balances her career and family life, prioritizing her children's education and values over business success.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Cheryl Gan

site_title: EU ambassador urges China to match anti-protectionism talk with reform
summary: The European Union's ambassador to China, Hans Dietmar Schweisgut, has urged China to match its anti-protectionism talk with reforms, citing the country's restrictive regulations on foreign investment. China has expressed concern over the EU's proposed investment screening mechanism, but Schweisgut argued that China's own restrictions on foreign investment in European industries are "unreasonable." EU investment in China is decreasing, and the EU hopes China's upcoming Communist Party Congress will speed up market reforms. Schweisgut warned that China's failure to match its rhetoric with reforms would be a concern for European investors.

site_title: Has Apple finally made a dud iPhone?
summary: Apple's latest iPhone release has generated concerns that it may not be as successful as previous models. Shares of Apple and suppliers have fallen, with some analysts predicting lower pre-orders. The lack of significant upgrades and mixed reviews may be contributing to the decline.

site_title: Making food out of thin air
summary: Companies Calysta in California and String Bio in Bengaluru have developed technology to turn methane into protein, which can be used in animal feed and potentially human consumption. Bacteria are fed a liquid containing methane, sparking a fermentation process that releases protein into the water, which is then dried into a brown powder. The goal is to alleviate the strain on agricultural land and oceans as the global population grows, and to provide a sustainable food source for emerging economies. The companies aim to scale up their technology, with Calysta planning to start operating in 2019 and String Bio seeking funding to commercialize its product.

site_title: Japan imports of US frozen beef drop by a quarter after tariff hike
summary: Japan's imports of US frozen beef dropped by 26% in August to 4,317 tonnes, following a 50% tariff hike in July. However, US chilled beef imports surged 54% to 18,038 tonnes, boosting overall US beef shipments by 20%. Frozen beef imports from Australia rose 30% to 15,010 tonnes, as buyers sought alternatives. Overall, US beef imports were up by around 20% in August, despite the tariff increase.

site_title: Australia shares up slightly on support from materials; NZ gain
summary: Australian shares rose 0.11% to 5,676.4, driven by gains in material stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, which rose 1.3% and 1.6%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also edged higher, up 0.118%, led by healthcare and information technology stocks. The market is awaiting fresh catalysts, with investors focusing on economic data and company earnings.

site_title: Asia's challenges and prospects for the next decade
summary: Asia's economic prospects for the next decade are influenced by its diverse dimensions, including India's insular economy and China's strong independent economy. Despite favourable global conditions, including low interest rates, Asia's growth rates remain driven by underlying factors. However, risks persist due to unpriced monetary policy tightening and abundant liquidity, which could trigger downturns in Asia. The region's long-term growth prospects remain favourable, with 5 of the top 8 growth economies in the next decade located in Asia.

site_title: US office vacancy rate remains flat in third quarter: Reis
summary: The US office vacancy rate remained flat at 16.1% in the third quarter, according to Reis research firm. Asking and effective rents rose 0.3% from the second quarter, driven by net absorption of 5.4 million square feet and new construction of 6.5 million square feet. The vacancy rate could stay flat due to occupancy growth matching new completions, limiting rent growth. The tightest markets were New York City (8.6%) and Washington, DC (9.3%).

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won up; hope for respite from N Korea woes before holidays
summary: South Korean stocks rose slightly on Friday, gaining 0.5% as investors look ahead to the third-quarter earnings season and the upcoming national holidays. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,385.70 points, up from a 0.7% loss for the week. The benchmark has declined nearly 2% since September 19 amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula. The won also edged up to 1,146.0 on the US dollar. Investors are hopeful for a respite from the recent volatility before the holidays.

site_title: Old Zouk site up for public tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has accepted a developer's application to put up a 1.35-hectare site in Jiak Kim Street, the former Zouk nightclub, for sale by public tender. The site, zoned for residential with commercial use, has a minimum committed price of S$689.35 million and will be released for sale in two to three weeks. The tender period is expected to be six weeks, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 51,234 square meters and a maximum building height of 36 storeys.

site_title: Hong Kong private home prices climb to fresh highs in August
summary: Hong Kong private home prices reached a fresh peak in August, marking the 10th consecutive month of gains and the 17th month of increases. Prices rose 0.44% in August, up 18% from a year earlier. The city's new leader, Carrie Lam, aims to address the issue through increasing land and primary housing supply. However, analysts suggest that high stamp duties have effectively locked up the secondary housing market, limiting supply and fueling price growth. This trend is expected to continue, making home ownership a distant dream for many in the city.

site_title: Asia: Markets up after Trump tax plan, China trade data eyed
summary: US President Donald Trump's tax cut plans boosted Asian markets, with Shanghai up 0.4% and South Korea's benchmark index gaining 0.6%. However, Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 0.3% due to a stronger yen. Analysts expect the tax bill to face tough passage through Congress, and investors are monitoring Chinese manufacturing data. The yen's weakness may be short-lived, with Hideyuki Ishiguro predicting its impact on Japanese stocks will slow.

site_title: Japan economic data boost PM Shinzo Abe ahead of election
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe received a boost ahead of the election with positive economic data. Factory output grew 2.1% in August, the longest winning streak in over a decade, while household spending increased and the unemployment rate hit a two-decade low. This recovery is seen as crucial for Japan's exit from deflation. Abe's campaign is heavily focused on the health of the world's third-largest economy, which will play a major role in the election.

site_title: AusGroup to convert some S$5.3m of outstanding debt into new shares
summary: AusGroup, an oilfield services firm, has accepted 6.79% of its S$5.3 million outstanding debt from note holders, exchanging it for new shares. This results in reduced annual interest payments of approximately S$500,000. AusGroup will issue 91.6 million new shares to the participating note holders, representing 6.48% of its issued share capital. The exchange offer closed on Thursday, with the settlement scheduled for Friday.

site_title: Sunseap unit launching pilot hire purchase plan for solar panels
summary: Sunseap Group, a clean energy provider, will launch a pilot hire purchase scheme for solar panels in October. The scheme allows clients to pay up to five-year instalments for residential and commercial clients, with set-up costs included. The plan aims to make solar energy more accessible to those who prefer not to pay a large upfront sum. Solar panels can save 20-30% on electricity bills, depending on usage habits and system size. The scheme is available for 20 landed property owners and SMEs who are not existing customers.

site_title: Vietnam's economy expands at faster pace in third quarter
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded at a faster pace in the third quarter, with a 7.46% growth in GDP from the previous year. This is a significant improvement from the 6.28% growth in the previous quarter and 6.41% for the nine-month period. The strong growth eases pressure on the government and central bank to implement additional stimulus measures, targeting a 6.7% economic expansion this year. The central bank has already taken steps to ease monetary policy, cutting its benchmark interest rate for the first time in three years in July.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen picks up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to a gradual pick-up in the yen exchange rate. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.13% to 20,337.21, while the Topix index fell 0.16% to 1,673.58. The yen's rise affected exporters, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Trump health secretary to repay cost of private jet travel
summary: US Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price promised to repay $52,000 for his seats on private charter flights, amid scrutiny from Congress over expensive air travel by Trump administration officials. Price stated he will write a personal check to the US Treasury, citing that taxpayers won't pay for his seat. This move comes as expensive air travel by Trump administration officials drew sharp criticism.

site_title: EU leaders look to digital future
summary: EU leaders are set to discuss the bloc's digital future at a summit in Tallinn, with French President Emmanuel Macron seeking to persuade sceptical counterparts to overhaul tax rules on Silicon Valley giants. Macron's proposal aims to increase tax revenue from tech companies, part of a broader vision to revive the European project hurt by Brexit, populism, and the migration crisis. The EU leaders' focus on the digital future comes as the bloc navigates economic and social challenges, with a potential overhaul of tax rules seen as a key step towards a more sustainable and prosperous digital economy.

site_title: Fear of volcanic eruption on Bali forces nearly 135,000 to flee to shelters
summary: Nearly 135,000 people on Bali's Indonesian island have evacuated their homes due to warnings of a potential Mount Agung volcano eruption. The volcano's alert status was raised to the highest level last week, prompting villagers to flee to makeshift shelters. Many are concerned about the 12 km exclusion zone and potential disruption to their livelihoods. Officials are working to relocate around 30,000 cattle within the danger zone. The evacuation comes after a 1963 eruption that killed over 1,000 people, and is the latest in a series of eruptions in Indonesia, which has nearly 130 active volcanoes.

site_title: Nobel's shining stars who lost their lustre
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, a 1991 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has faced criticism for her handling of the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar, with many calling for her prize to be withdrawn. Her supporters argue she lacks authority to rein in the military, but an online petition and several prominent laureates, including Desmond Tutu and the Dalai Lama, have urged her to take action. This is not an isolated case, as other Nobel stars, such as former US President Barack Obama and Lech Walesa, have also seen their "lustre fade" due to controversies and perceived failures.

site_title: Deutsche Bank rating cut by Fitch on lack of revenue recovery
summary: Deutsche Bank's long-term credit grade was cut one level by Fitch Ratings to BBB+ due to the lender's struggles with revenue recovery. The bank will take "some time" to reach earnings targets, and Fitch expects necessary restructuring costs to continue eroding net income. The downgrade follows the bank's weakest quarterly revenue in 3 1/2 years and a third strategic overhaul in as many years. Fitch also notes that Deutsche Bank has further to go to complete its business restructuring compared to other global universal banks.

site_title: TT International receives notice of appointment of receivers for Big Box
summary: TT International, a struggling consumer electronics retailer, received a notice of appointment of receivers for its 51%-owned subsidiary, Big Box Pte Ltd. Joint receivers Ee Meng Yen Angela and Aaron Loh Cheng Lee were appointed by OCBC as security trustee for the lenders. TT International is seeking legal advice and continues to discuss refinancing options with lenders to refinance and repay BBPL's liabilities. The company's warehouse retail scheme business remains unaffected, and efforts to pursue refinancing options continue.

site_title: Singapore shares open down on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened lower on Friday, retreating 4.25 points or 0.1% to 3,222.89. Despite US stocks closing modestly higher overnight, investors remained cautious due to tariff uncertainty. Gainers outnumbered losers 84 to 50, with ASTI being the most actively traded counter. Other Asian markets, including Japan's Topix, South Korea's Kospi, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng, also saw changes.

site_title: US dollar rally sputters on profit-taking, quarter-end positioning
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.23% against a basket of currencies, snapping a three-day winning streak, as investors took profits ahead of the end of the quarter.
