The US dollar index is still up about 1% this week, following a strong rally on Wednesday after President Trump proposed a tax overhaul. The decline is attributed to quarter-end positioning and lack of direction, with traders awaiting the release of the non-farm payrolls report for clues on the next interest rate hike.

site_title: Seesaw US-China ties on an upswing as Trump plans trip
summary: US-China relations appear to be improving as the two nations work together to address the North Korea nuclear stand-off. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is in Beijing for talks with senior Chinese leaders, discussing preparations for a planned Donald Trump visit to the region. The US hopes that China's cooperation will help convince North Korea's leader to tone down his rhetoric and halt nuclear and missile tests. The two nations have recently imposed new sanctions on North Korea, and China has taken additional actions to restrict its trade with the country.

site_title: Keppel's BrasFELS shipyard delivers its 5th FPSO project for MODEC
summary: Keppel's BrasFELS shipyard has delivered its fifth Floating Production Storage and Offloading (FPSO) vessel, the Cidade de Campos dos Goytacazes MV29, to MODEC Offshore Production Systems. The FPSO, with a production capacity of 150,000 barrels of oil per day, was completed safely, on time, and within budget. BrasFELS' ninth FPSO project for Brazil, it demonstrates the company's commitment to supporting the country's oil and gas industry. The vessel will be deployed in the Tartaruga Verde and Tartaruga Mestiça Fields in the Campos Basin, off the coast of Rio de Janeiro.

site_title: OCBC prices 500m euro covered bonds, says transaction well-received
summary: OCBC Bank priced 500 million euros in fixed-rate covered bonds due 2022 at a 0.25% annual interest rate, receiving a strong order book more than three times covered. The transaction, part of the bank's US$10 billion global covered bond programme, will be rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Fitch, and the net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. The bonds are expected to be issued on October 5 and listed on the Singapore Exchange on October 6.

site_title: South Korea's Aug factory output up for 2nd month, underpins economic recovery
summary: South Korea's factory output expanded for the second consecutive month in August, rising 0.4% seasonally adjusted, driven by gains in semiconductor production. The increase follows a 1.7% jump in July. Semiconductor manufacturing output rose 12.4% and electronic components 4.4% from July, while car manufacturing fell 4% and transportation equipment output declined 18.5%. The economy is expected to remain solid, with exports driving growth, despite a weakening construction sector.

site_title: Japan's Aug industrial output rises 2.1% month-on-month
summary: Japan's industrial output increased 2.1% in August from the previous month, surpassing the median estimate of 1.9%. This follows a 0.8% decline in July. Manufacturers predict a 1.9% decline in September and a 3.5% increase in October.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koh Brothers Eco, Aspen, Thakral Corp, Keppel Corp
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include Koh Brothers Eco securing a S$520 million contract with PUB for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) Phase 2 project, Aspen entering into a sale and purchase agreement for 22,954 square meters of freehold land for RM66.71 million, Thakral Corp acquiring two properties in Australia for A$20 million, and Keppel Offshore & Marine delivering its fifth Floating Production Storage and Offloading (FPSO) vessel to MODEC. These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Aspen to fork out RM66.7m for Kajang land
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings has entered into a sale and purchase agreement for 22,954 sqm of freehold land in Kajang, Malaysia for RM66.71 million. The land, approved for residential and commercial developments, will be paid for in 10% deposit and the balance within seven months. This deal follows the cancellation of a previous agreement with Aspen Vision Realty for two plots of land in Semenyih, Malaysia, where Tropicana Kajang Hill will refund a RM1 million deposit.

site_title: Greek economy's recovery to strengthen: ECB's Stournaras
summary: Greek economy is expected to recover from a deep recession, with growth projected to pick up in the next two years. Bank of Greece Governor Yannis Stournaras predicts 1.7% GDP growth in 2017, increasing to 2.4% in 2018 and 2.7% in 2019, driven by rising investment, consumption, and exports. Stournaras urged a speedy conclusion of a bailout review to avoid uncertainty, citing the assumption that Greece's reforms and privatisations programme will be implemented consistently.

site_title: Apple sees sharp increase in US national security requests
summary: Apple has received more than four times as many national-security related requests from the US government in the first half of 2017 compared to the same period in 2016. The company received 13,250-13,499 NSLs and FISA requests affecting 9,000-9,249 users, up from 2,750-2,999 requests affecting 2,000-2,249 users in 2016.

images.alt_text: Apple has received more than four times as many national-security related requests from the US government in the first half of this year versus a year ago, according to a company report on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.12% in early trade on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index edging down to 27,388.78. Chinese shares remained unchanged ahead of manufacturing data. The Shanghai Composite Index was 0.02% higher, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.09%. The slight decline in Hong Kong stocks follows a week-long national holiday in China.

site_title: Ikea buys on-demand help startup TaskRabbit
summary: Ikea acquired TaskRabbit, a US-based on-demand help startup, in a deal to expand its services and tap into the online sharing economy. TaskRabbit provides freelance labor for various tasks, and Ikea plans to offer these services to customers after the acquisition. The deal is expected to result in a broader range of services and increased earnings for TaskRabbit's freelance workers. Financial terms were not disclosed, and TaskRabbit will continue to operate independently.

site_title: Tax cuts to help most in middle-class, not all: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic adviser Gary Cohn defended the proposed tax overhaul, stating it aims to benefit middle-class Americans but acknowledges not everyone will see a tax cut due to the complexity of local jurisdictions and financial situations. The plan involves cutting corporate tax rates, reducing income tax brackets, and eliminating the alternative minimum tax. Critics argue the cuts will mainly benefit the wealthy, while economists question whether tax cuts can pay for themselves and sustain high growth rates.

site_title: UOL associate to buy Nanak Mansions for S$201m
summary: UOL associate Secure Venture Development has won the tender to purchase the freehold property of Nanak Mansions at S$201.08 million, with a price of S$1,429 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) inclusive of development charge. The 18,185 sq m site, comprising 36 maisonettes, is expected to be re-developed and completed within three months.

site_title: Street hawkers pave the way to Indonesia's first e-commerce IPO
summary: PT Kioson Komersial Indonesia, an Indonesian e-commerce startup, will list on the stock market on October 3 after raising 45 billion rupiah (S$4.54 million). The company connects 19,000 merchants in 300 cities with consumers, providing a gauge of confidence in Indonesia's burgeoning startup industry. This is the first Indonesian e-commerce startup to go public, indicating investors' appetite for tech companies from Southeast Asia's largest economy.

site_title: Better for Hong Kong to overhaul its main board than to have a third board
summary: Hong Kong's main stock exchange may not need a third board to attract technology companies, as ZhongAn's successful trading debut undermines the proposal. The exchange plans a new venue with two segments, but existing tweaks may suffice. This suggests that the city is well-positioned to win new listings, rather than requiring a new board with looser listing terms.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up and cling to 10-week high, H&M disappoints
summary: European shares rose 0.1% to a 10-week high, driven by optimism over US President Donald Trump's tax cut plan, despite concerns of its implementation difficulty. The STOXX 600 index clung to the gains, with a mix of sectors including mining and healthcare. Analysts expressed skepticism about the plan's passage, citing potential hurdles in Congress.

site_title: Brexit progress but trade talks 'weeks or months' away
summary: Britain and the EU have made progress in Brexit divorce negotiations, with Prime Minister Theresa May's speech in Florence creating a "new dynamic" for the discussions. However, EU negotiator Michel Barnier warned that trade talks may be months away, citing a need for more progress on divorce arrangements. EU leaders will decide in October whether there has been sufficient progress on three key issues, with the clock ticking to reach a final deal before Britain's March 2019 exit. Despite optimism from British counterpart David Davis, the talks remain stalled.

site_title: After long silence, IS says chief calls on jihadists to 'resist'
summary: ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has released a recording, calling on jihadists in Syria and Iraq to "resist" their enemies, including the US, Russia, and Iran. The recording, which has been verified by the US, is Baghdadi's first in nearly a year and appears to confirm his survival. He urged his followers to target media centers and pursue their "jihad" against the "infidels". Despite losses in Iraq and Syria, the US warns that the global threat posed by ISIS has not diminished, and Baghdadi's group has claimed responsibility for deadly attacks worldwide.

site_title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus announces she has breast cancer
summary: Julia Louis-Dreyfus, 56, announces on Twitter that she has been diagnosed with breast cancer. The actress, known for her roles in Veep and Seinfeld, shared her diagnosis with 750,000 followers, expressing gratitude for her supportive friends and insurance. She also used the opportunity to advocate for universal healthcare and cancer research, stating "not all women are so lucky." The news comes after Louis-Dreyfus won her sixth consecutive Emmy for comedy acting just weeks prior.

site_title: BOJ member called for ramping up stimulus in Sept
summary: A Bank of Japan policymaker, Goushi Kataoka, called for expanding monetary stimulus in September, citing the need to boost inflation to the BOJ's 2% target. Most board members agreed maintaining current stimulus was appropriate due to time constraints. Kataoka's views on aggressive easing may create divisions within the nine-member board, particularly Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. The BOJ kept monetary policy steady, maintaining its short-term interest rate target at minus 0.1% and a pledge to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero percent. A potential proposal to expand stimulus could be discussed at the next rate review on October 30-31.

site_title: Australian jihadist, on trial in Turkey, 'regrets joining IS'
summary: An Australian jihadist, Neil Prakash, is on trial in Turkey for joining Islamic State (IS) in Syria. Prakash, who was detained last year, expressed regret for his involvement with the organization after seeing its "true face." His trial, held via video link, is being held in the Kilis region due to security concerns in Gaziantep. Prakash faces charges related to his involvement with IS, but the trial's outcome is not yet clear.

site_title: Keen contest expected for captain's post
summary: Singapore Island Country Club members are set for a closely contested election for club captain, with incumbent Andrew Lim facing off against general committee member Ivan Chua. Lim, 68, emphasizes continuity and course improvements, while Chua, 46, prioritizes raising overall golf standards and regaining the club's elite reputation. The election, which has now closed, will determine the next leader of the club.

site_title: Oil slips 1% as extends pullback from 2015 peaks
summary: Oil prices slipped 1% on Thursday as tensions in northern Iraq following the Kurdistan region's vote in favor of independence spurred fresh supply concerns. Crude prices rose sharply in the last two weeks but are near overbought levels. US crude fell 58 cents to $51.56 a barrel, while Brent dropped 49 cents to $57.41 a barrel. Analysts expect a pullback in prices due to reduced demand from Hurricane Harvey's impact, with some predicting a modest selloff.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Thursday, further backing off from 2015 peaks hit earlier in the week as tension around northern Iraq following the Kurdistan region's vote in favour of independence spurred fresh supply concerns.

site_title: Customer needs, new providers to drive change in banking
summary: Traditional banking players face increased pressure from customers and new providers to innovate, with the fastest movers achieving competitive disruption. New entrants into banking and payment services, unencumbered by legacy systems, are shifting the goal posts. To remain relevant, banks must focus on customers and understand their needs, modernizing products, processes, and customer touchpoints. Technology, such as automation and data analytics, is key to shaping the banking landscape, while regulators must balance innovation with stability, transparency, and customer protection.

site_title: Japan's inflation, labour demand and factory output signal solid economic recovery
summary: Japan's core inflation rose 0.7% in August, exceeding expectations, and industrial output increased more than expected, bolstering optimism about the country's economic recovery. Labour demand remains strong, its highest in over 40 years. However, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's snap election call raises uncertainty about economic policy, and concerns about the Bank of Japan's monetary policy persist, with one board member advocating for expanded stimulus.

site_title: Between a wok and an Ard place
summary: Restaurant Ards, a modern Asian restaurant in Singapore, offers a progressive and cosmopolitan dining experience. Chefs Ace Tan and David Lee have developed a unique cuisine by combining traditional Asian recipes with modern techniques. The 15-course tasting menu, priced at S$188, showcases inventive dishes such as deep-fried Japanese peanut shells and Hokkaido oysters, as well as familiar flavors like egg tarts and mother's chicken soup. While the menu has its hits and misses, the restaurant's emphasis on originality and creativity is promising. Rating: 7.

site_title: Prime office rents to jump 15.8% over three years: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's prime office rents are expected to rise 15.8% over the next three years, driven by demand exceeding supply. According to Knight Frank, the market has turned a corner, with two consecutive quarters of improvement in rents. The technology sector is a key driver of leasing activities, with tenants benefiting from increased space efficiency and investment interest in offices. Despite cheaper business park spaces, some technology companies will remain in the CBD due to client and vendor locations.

site_title: Omron opens automation centre to study AI and robotics
summary: Omron has opened its ninth global innovation centre in Singapore, a S$13.5 million investment in robotics capabilities, focusing on AI, IoT, and robotics technologies in manufacturing. The 8,500 sq ft facility is the largest in the Asia-Pacific and features a robotics laboratory, reconfigurable production line, and IoT-based manufacturing plant. The centre aims to demonstrate smart manufacturing and bring the future to present-day customers, with plans to increase skilled positions and train local talent.

site_title: What price would you pay to slay a monster?
summary: The Man with the Iron Heart is a World War II drama film about the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich, a high-ranking Nazi official and architect of the Holocaust. The film follows Heydrich's rise to power and his eventual killing by Czech Resistance members. The movie portrays the men who carried out the assassination as quiet patriots, leaving viewers to ponder the moral implications of their actions. The film's portrayal of the incident and its consequences is significant, with uncomfortable modern-day parallels to right-wing extremism.

site_title: Q2 GDP revised higher; hurricanes slow Q3 growth momentum
summary: The US economy grew at a 3.1% annual rate in the second quarter, the fastest pace in over two years, with inventory investment and consumer spending driving the growth. However, hurricanes Harvey and Irma are expected to slow down Q3 growth momentum. Labor market remains strong, but job growth may be impacted by the storms. The economy is expected to grow 2.1% in the first half of 2017, below President Trump's 3% target.

site_title: Financial Forensic Accounting Qualification to launch in March 2018
summary: Singapore is set to launch the first financial forensic accounting qualification in South-east Asia in March 2018 to combat the growing complexity of financial crimes. The qualification, offered by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA), will cover topics such as forensic accounting methodology and data analytics. The program is open to professionals from various fields, including accounting, finance, law enforcement, and financial crime compliance and investigation. The move aims to develop a talent pool to tackle cybercrimes and money laundering in the region, following high-profile cases of asset misappropriation and corruption-related financial fraud.

site_title: Etihad banks on new chief to steer it out of turbulence
summary: Etihad Airways appoints Tony Douglas as its new group chief executive, replacing James Hogan, who implemented an expansion strategy that resulted in significant losses. The airline's equity stakes in Alitalia, Air Berlin, Jet Airways, and Virgin Australia contributed to these losses. Douglas, who joins from the UK's Ministry of Defence, aims to steer the airline out of turbulence and stabilize its operations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Govt to bring forward another S$700m of construction jobs
summary: The Singapore government plans to bring forward S$700 million in construction projects to support local SME contractors, in addition to S$700 million already announced for 2017 and 2018. This brings the total amount to S$1.4 billion. The move aims to alleviate the difficulties faced by the construction sector.

site_title: Jazz's gentle giant sings for a better tomorrow
summary: Gregory Porter, a two-time Grammy winner, is set to perform his first headlining show in Singapore on Friday. The jazz singer-songwriter believes music can heal the world and hopes his new record, Nat King Cole & Me, will bring peace and positivity to listeners. Porter, who has overcome a difficult childhood without his father, has chosen to record a tribute to his musical hero Nat King Cole to establish himself as a singer-songwriter and share life lessons and wisdom through his music.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Take a leaf out of Library Board's book
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) in Singapore successfully implemented a winning innovation strategy, bridging the gap between strategy and execution. The organization's visionary leadership, culture of innovation, and user-centric service delivery enabled it to innovate and adapt to changing trends. NLB's strategic approach included asking the right questions, decisively following up on steps, and leveraging boundary-spanning collaboration, service co-creation, and geospatial analytics. The board's mission, "We make knowledge come alive, spark imagination and create possibilities," served as a guiding force, and its innovation objectives were reflected in various masterplans. NLB's success demonstrates the importance of effective strategic leadership and a strong focus on innovation in achieving organizational goals.

site_title: Abe dissolves parliament; kicks off 'difficult' election battle
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dissolved parliament on Thursday, starting a national election campaign. He faces a challenge from Tokyo's popular governor, who is considered a formidable opponent. The move comes after a difficult period for Abe's government. The dissolution marks the beginning of a national election, where Abe's leadership and policies will be scrutinized.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe and his party's lawmakers including Taro Aso and Toshihiro Nikai pledge to win in the upcoming lower house election at their party headquarters in Tokyo on Thursday.

site_title: Global software glitch hits airports, airlines
summary: A global software glitch affected airports and airlines, including Changi Airport and Singapore Airlines, causing delays worldwide. The issue was with the Altea software program, which was temporarily down, according to Amadeus. The outage was reportedly resolved, and major carriers were not significantly impacted.

site_title: US: S&P 500 edges to record as markets eye Trump tax plan
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the S&P 500 edging to a new record, as investors reacted to President Trump's tax plan outline. The plan, which would cut the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20%, was seen as a positive development after initial enthusiasm. However, analysts noted that the proposal still faces a long way to go before becoming law. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Private trades value Spotify at US$16b; firm still suffering huge losses
summary: Spotify is valued at around $16 billion in private trades, with some estimates suggesting it could reach $20 billion when it goes public in the first or second quarter of next year. The company's strong demand for shares and rising subscription numbers are driving the valuation, which could be worth at least four times its 2016 sales. Despite its significant losses, Spotify's rapid growth in paying users and increasing revenues raise hopes that it can eventually turn profitable.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Geo Energy Resources' subsidiary secured a US$1.2 billion note offering, more than three times oversubscribed, with a 8% coupon rate. Cosco Shipping International secured two contracts to build pulp vessels and bulk carriers. Thakral Corp acquired two Australian properties through a joint-venture, while Astrea III Class A-1 bonds received a one-notch upgrade to their credit rating.

site_title: Chinese airliner's test sparks delivery concerns
summary: China's C-919 passenger jet completed its second test flight, with a 166-minute flight time that was more than double its maiden flight. The delay and shorter flight time have raised concerns over meeting its 2020 delivery target, with some analysts calling it "extraordinary" that the aircraft didn't fly sooner. The C-919, China's first domestically developed passenger jet, has faced lengthy delays and regulatory certification issues, limiting sales to the domestic market.

site_title: Lots of horn-tooting but little headway despite Trump pushing carmakers
summary: US carmakers have invested $5.5 billion in new American factories this year, falling short of the decade's average of $10.2 billion. Despite President Trump's threats to heavily tax imported cars, investments remain sluggish. Industry sales are slowing, with General Motors and Ford cutting shifts or scheduling time off at plants. The lack of significant investments highlights the challenges faced by the US automotive sector, particularly in the face of global competition and trade tensions.

site_title: Chinese online insurer ZhongAn up 18% in HK debut
summary: ZhongAn, a Chinese online insurer, made its Hong Kong debut, jumping 18% in its $1.5 billion initial public offering, marking the biggest ever IPO by a financial technology firm in Asia. The successful listing boosts Hong Kong's hopes of luring Chinese technology startups away from New York, with Alibaba affiliate Ant Financial and peer-to-peer lending platform Lufax also considering IPOs in the city. The deal demonstrates Hong Kong's ability to attract tech firms, with investors seeking diversification opportunities, and could pave the way for future listings from prominent fintech companies.

images.alt_text: ZhongAn chairman Ou Yaping (centre) and chief executive Jeffrey Chen on Thursday. Mr Chen says: "We've invited partners and many companies that are interested to list in Hong Kong to join the (celebration) party. They became interested after they saw ZhongAn's example,"

site_title: India's richest state, Maharashtra, undergoing major makeover
summary: Maharashtra, India's richest state, is undergoing a major makeover under the leadership of Devendra Fadnavis. The government has implemented reforms to boost infrastructure, ease business regulations, and revive the farm sector. Key initiatives include reducing the number of approvals needed to start an industry, streamlining land acquisition processes, and launching a massive infrastructure drive. As a result, foreign direct investment has surged, with Maharashtra accounting for 51% of India's total FDI in 2016/17, a threefold increase from 2012/13. The state's economic growth has also improved, with a 9.4% GDP expansion in 2016/17, outpacing India's overall growth.

site_title: New 'deplorables' might just push old order forward
summary: In Germany's recent election, Chancellor Angela Merkel secured a fourth term, marking a shift towards "political normality" after years of a monolithic party system. The new parliament features four smaller parties, including the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD), which won a significant number of votes. The AfD's "Germany first" narrative reflects similar radical demands seen in other European parties, such as the Freedom Caucus in the US House of Representatives. Merkel faces challenges in forming a coalition, but experts believe ignoring the AfD is not an option, and that the party's internal divisions may help push Germany and Europe towards a more normal and forward-looking narrative.

site_title: Mundane tasks take on new meanings
summary: Tan Pin Pin's documentary "In Time To Come" premiered at Visions du Réel in Switzerland and has since played at international festivals. Shot over four years, the film captures everyday life in Singapore with continuous takes and no narrative, aiming to "look at Singapore through the prism of its everyday rituals." Tan hopes viewers will engage with the film's experimental nature, providing time for interpretation and autonomy. The film centers around the opening and sealing of time capsules, leaving cultural significance open to audience interpretation.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
"So much of mainstream cinema today feels like a roller-coaster ride. You are just pulled along by the story, didactic sound design, and visuals." - Tan Pin Pin.

site_title: Contenders for post of president include a suspended member
summary: Singapore Island Country Club's annual general meeting will focus on two hot-button issues: contest eligibility and a member's court injunction that allowed him to stand for election despite a disciplinary hearing. Veteran member Goh Ho Wee, suspended for breaching the code of conduct, has been cleared to stand in the five-way presidential election, sparking grumbles about its constitutionality. The new general committee will have to address these issues, amidst the club facing challenges such as losing the Sime course and uncertainty over the Bukit course.

site_title: DBS ties up with Chubb to bolster insurance offerings
summary: DBS Bank has entered into a 15-year regional distribution partnership agreement with Chubb to bolster its insurance offerings in five markets: Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Indonesia, and China. DBS will distribute Chubb's insurance products, including home, contents, and personal accident insurance, as well as general insurance products for small and medium-sized enterprises. The partnership combines DBS' Asian banking franchise with Chubb's global general insurance capability, offering customers unrivaled experience and convenience in purchasing general insurance. The agreement will take effect in early 2018 and roll out progressively through the year.

site_title: London skyscrapers draw highest rents in Europe despite Brexit
summary: London's skyscrapers continue to hold the highest office rents in Europe, despite Brexit uncertainty, with prime rents reaching US$110 per square foot. The UK capital remains a sought-after business hub, with steady office space take-up and overseas groups buying prominent skyscrapers. Knight Frank's report indicates London's resilience and popularity, with firms willing to pay more for office space due to its status as an international hub.

site_title: Bids for Florence Regency come in below independent valuation
summary: Florence Regency, a 336-unit HUDC estate in Hougang, Singapore, received three bids for collective sale, but the top bidder's offer was below the independent valuation of S$629 million. As a result, the valuation became the new minimum price, and marketing agent JLL is going back to interested parties to consider offers at or above this price. The estate has a balance lease term of 71 years and could potentially support over 1,100 apartment units, with an estimated land cost of S$842 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buys Auckland office tower for NZ$63m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired NZI Centre in Auckland, New Zealand for NZ$63 million (S$61.7 million), excluding taxes. The commercial office building has a net lettable area of 9,446 square metres and is fully leased to IAG New Zealand until 2036. Roxy-Pacific believes the property presents a prime investment opportunity with stable rental income potential. The acquisition is subject to certain conditions, including the head landlord's written consent.

site_title: A treat for cats and dogs at PAW-sitive
summary: PAW-sitive: Interactive Art For Pets exhibition opens at the School of Arts in Singapore, featuring 10 commissioned artworks for dogs and cats created by local artists. The exhibition aims to excite and engage pets, with artworks designed to cater to their characteristics. Organized by Silversky Pte Ltd, the event seeks to help pets and their owners bond and connect. The exhibition runs from this weekend, marking Silversky's 10-year presence in Singapore.

site_title: Global IPOs in first 9 months outstrip 2016's full-year tally
summary: Global initial public offerings (IPOs) in the first 9 months of 2017 surpassed the total for the full year of 2016, with 1,156 listings raising $126.9 billion. Asia-Pacific led the charge, accounting for 65% of global IPOs and nearly half of global capital raised. Mainland China exchanges hosted the most IPOs, followed by Hong Kong, Australia, Japan, and South Korea. Singapore's NetLink NBN Trust's $1.7 billion IPO in July was the largest in six years, highlighting the demand for high-quality IPOs.

site_title: APAC Realty surges above IPO price on its debut day
summary: APAC Realty Ltd, a real estate player operating under the ERA brand, made a successful debut on the Singapore Exchange, with its shares surging 11.5 Singapore cents to close at S$0.76 on the first day of trading. The IPO marked ERA's return to the Singapore Exchange after a 5-year hiatus. The company received strong interest for its IPO, with 3,035 valid applications for the public offering and aggregate indications of interest for over 597.6 million placement shares.

site_title: Strong investment performance lifts global wealth
summary: Global wealth of high net worth individuals (HNWIs) expanded 8.2% in 2016, driven by strong investment performance, with wealth managed by wealth managers appreciating 24.3% globally and 33% in the Asia-Pacific. However, Singapore's HNWIs reported a relatively muted investment performance, contributing to the region's negative net promoter score. The Asia-Pacific remains the world's largest HNWI market, with 5.5 million HNWIs holding US$18.8 trillion in wealth. More than half of HNWIs are open to becoming clients of BigTech firms, and clients value hybrid service models combining digital tools with human interaction.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Facebook, Google, Twitter asked to testify on Russian meddling
summary: US lawmakers have asked Facebook, Google, and Twitter to testify on Russian meddling in the 2016 US election. The Senate Intelligence Committee has scheduled public hearings with Facebook and Google executives on November 1, while the House Intelligence Committee will hold an open hearing with unnamed tech companies in October. Lawmakers are seeking information on how Russia used online tools and platforms to sow discord and influence the election. Facebook has revealed that suspected Russian trolls purchased over $100,000 worth of divisive ads on its platform.

site_title: Trump's tax cuts 'likely to produce short sugar-high of job growth'
summary: US President Donald Trump's corporate tax cuts are expected to produce short-term job growth, but may not sustain it, according to economist Alan Viard. The tax cuts, aimed at firms spending heavily on new equipment, could lead to a "sugar high" effect, resulting in a quick burst of growth that then dwindles. This contradicts Trump's and Republican leaders' desire for sustained job growth.

site_title: China sets new-energy vehicle sales quota for carmakers; rule starts from 2019
summary: China has mandated automakers to sell a minimum of 10% new-energy vehicles in 2019 and 12% in 2020, as part of the government's efforts to phase out fossil-fuel powered vehicles. The policy applies to companies producing or importing over 30,000 traditional vehicles annually, requiring them to buy credits or face fines. The goal is to reduce dependence on oil imports and cut carbon emissions, with China aiming to cap emissions by 2030. This rule joins the UK and France in setting a timeline for the elimination of fossil-fuel vehicles.

site_title: Mr Big defies the odds on supergroup's new album
summary: Mr. Big's drummer Pat Torpey, diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease three years ago, continues to tour with the iconic '90s hard rockers, performing a handful of songs in Singapore in October. Despite his condition, Torpey remains committed to music, citing it as the greatest therapy. The band's latest album, Defying Gravity, was recorded "live" in six days and features the original lineup, including Eric Martin, Paul Gilbert, and Billy Sheehan. The album's lyrics reflect the band's perseverance and triumph over challenges, with Torpey serving as a huge inspiration to those facing similar afflictions.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
(From left) Pat Torpey, Eric Martin, Billy Sheehan and Paul Gilbert, of Mr Big, will be performing at Kallang Theatre on Oct 15.

site_title: Museums give peek into secret world of Yves Saint Laurent
summary: Yves Saint Laurent's legacy is being celebrated through two new museums, one in Paris and another in Marrakesh, Morocco, which open weeks after his partner and business partner Pierre Berge's death. The Paris museum features Saint Laurent's studio, where he designed iconic pieces like "Le Smoking" and showcases his creative process, while the Marrakesh museum will house a larger collection of his work. The museums aim to decode the mysteries of the private fashion designer who revolutionized women's fashion and gave them power.

site_title: South Korea to offer tax help, loans to firms hit by China's reprisals
summary: South Korea plans to offer tax and loan concessions to companies affected by China's reprisals, including deferment of corporate income and value-added taxes for up to nine months. The measures aim to help firms hit by declining sales of South Korean cars in China and boycotts of South Korean goods. The government also plans to boost domestic tourism and increase funds at policy banks to support car part makers and suppliers. The move is seen as a limited response to China's tactics, with economists saying it's difficult to resolve the issue by removing the Thaad system.

site_title: Free outdoor fashion concert at ION
summary: ION Orchard is hosting a free outdoor fashion concert on Friday, featuring South Korean celebrity Yook Sung-jae from the K-pop boy band BtoB, as well as a fashion show with 24 models showcasing the latest Autumn/Winter collections. The event, part of the shopping mall's 8th anniversary celebrations, will begin at 7pm and be streamed live on the building's exterior screens. The concert aims to align with the mall's trendy and fashion-forward identity, capitalizing on the popularity of K-pop.

site_title: ExxonMobil bets on Brazil, buys 10 oil blocks in auction
summary: ExxonMobil significantly expanded its presence in Brazil by winning 10 oil blocks in the country's 14th round of bidding, fetching a record 3.8 billion reais (S$1.62 billion). The US company won six blocks in consortium with Petrobras, two blocks to operate alone, and two in the Sergipe-Alagoas basin. This marked a surprise after a lacklustre oil price performance and dwindling cash for investments. The auction was seen as a test of market-friendly reforms under President Michel Temer, with ExxonMobil's record bids helping Brazil achieve the record take.

site_title: Euro-area confidence rises more than forecast to decade high
summary: Euro-area economic confidence surged to a decade high in September, exceeding economists' forecasts with an index of 113. This positive reading, well above the median estimate of 112, provides a boost to European Central Bank policy makers as they consider the future of their bond-buying program.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' firm UOB Kay Hian maintains a bullish stance on SATS, citing its superior scale in catering and ground handling, as well as its ability to prevail in a pricing war. SATS handles 144,000 flights versus Dnata's 40,000, and its investment in automation is expected to drive operating leverage. The firm also expects cargo yields to improve, positively impacting SATS' earnings. Despite a 4.6% year-to-date decline in SATS' stock price, UOB Kay Hian remains optimistic, citing Changi's data points and cost control as key positives.

site_title: Early momentum fades, STI ends lower
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 14 points to 3,250 due to early morning buying, but declined 9.01 points to 3,227.14 by the end of the day, after Dow futures fell into the red. This was partly due to the US market's reaction to the Trump administration's tax reform plans, which include a 20% corporate tax rate. The highest weekly turnover so far was 2.1 billion units worth S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Beach Road shaping up to be a Quek and Kwek playground
summary: GuocoLand and its Hong Kong-listed parent Guoco Group have won a bid for a two-hectare Beach Road commercial site in Singapore, with a top offer of S$1.622 billion, or S$1,706.30 per square foot per plot ratio. The bid surpasses previous offers from other developers, including CDL and IOI Properties, and is seen as a bullish sign for the Singapore office market, which has been experiencing a recovery. The project is expected to include office, residential, and retail components, and will complement existing developments in the area.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: After 'multi-crisis', Europe faces battle on four fronts
summary: Europe is facing a "battle on four fronts" following a season of continuous political upsets, including Brexit, the ongoing euro crisis, and challenges from "illiberal democracy" in Hungary and Poland. The European Commission's first vice-president, Frans Timmermans, described the state of Europe as a "multi-crisis" last year, citing geopolitical risks from US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. With Germany's election over, it is now time for Europe to take action to address these challenges and respond to the upheavals created by the recent votes.

site_title: In Time To Come is a time capsule
summary: Tan Pin Pin, a renowned Singaporean documentary filmmaker, has released her latest film "In Time To Come," a 62-minute time capsule exploring the nation's urban topography through everyday moments and public rituals. The documentary features footage shot over four years, with a focus on ambient sounds and a deliberate obliqueness of purpose. It marks Tan's most experimental work to date, raising questions about national identity and the society of the future. The film has received a mainstream cineplex release and has been praised for its observational intelligence and subversive humor.

site_title: Australia faces coal squeeze despite being energy powerhouse
summary: Australia is facing a coal squeeze, threatening power supply disruptions during peak summer demand. Despite being a global energy powerhouse, the country is struggling to find enough supply for its own use, with power price spikes and gas shortages affecting businesses and homes. Coal inventories at major electricity providers have dwindled, and the closure of the Hazelwood coal-fired power plant has increased pressure on remaining generators. The country's reliance on coal for 76% of its power generation and high demand for domestic customers have driven miners to sell lower-quality coal to international customers, exacerbating the issue.

site_title: A treat for the senses in BT Weekend
summary: A Singaporean magazine, BT Weekend, explores Rwanda's unexpected similarities to Singapore, including hipster food clusters and home decor trends. The magazine also delves into unusual topics such as synaesthesia, sustained motivation, and Lego culture. Additionally, it reviews the Audi A4 cabriolet and features articles on sustainable living, financial literacy, and corporate purpose.

site_title: Dollar pauses after recent rebound; euro and yen struggle on
summary: The US dollar consolidated its gains after reaching a one-month high against a basket of currencies, driven by rising US Treasury yields and hawkish rhetoric from the Federal Reserve. The dollar has gained 1.2% against the basket, despite a divided US Congress and uncertainty over tax reforms. The euro and yen struggled, while a snap election in Japan and German inflation data influenced currency movements.

site_title: Changi Airport issues manual boarding passes for airlines including SIA, Qantas due to technical glitch
summary: Changi Airport experienced technical issues with check-in systems for airlines including Singapore Airlines and Qantas, causing longer wait times for passengers. The issue was resolved, but the airport issued manual boarding passes for affected flights. The cause of the technical glitch was not specified.

site_title: US fast-food staff stuck in low-paying jobs because of hidden clauses
summary: Fast-food franchises, including major chains like Burger King, Carl's Jr, and Pizza Hut, have clauses in their contracts that prohibit franchisees from hiring workers from other franchises, effectively keeping employees tied to one location. This practice, hidden in lengthy contracts signed by franchisees, limits worker mobility and can contribute to wage stagnation. The clauses, which were found in over 70,000 restaurants, or a quarter of the fast-food outlets in the US, were deemed "ubiquitous" and aimed to limit competition and turnover. The clauses have been challenged in lawsuits, with McDonald's recently removing the language from its contract, although the decision's timing may be coincidental.

site_title: General Re targets world- beating India market
summary: General Re, a unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc, aims to dominate India's reinsurance market by expanding into health and life insurance, and exploring opportunities in property and casualty cover. The company plans to capitalize on the market's rapid growth. CEO Venkatesh Chakravarty expressed confidence in General Re's ability to achieve its goals in the rapidly growing Indian market.

site_title: Yingluck left Dubai on Sept 11 for UK: sources
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra left Dubai on September 11 for London, according to a source in the UAE. She had been in Dubai to avoid being jailed over a rice subsidy scheme that lost billions of dollars. This follows a statement from Thailand's military junta leader, who said Shinawatra had fled to Dubai three months prior.

site_title: Angry Birds maker Rovio valued at 896m euros in IPO
summary: Finnish mobile games and animation studio Rovio Entertainment priced its initial public offering (IPO) at 11.50 euros per share, valuing the company at 896 million euros. The IPO raised 30 million euros, with major owners receiving approximately 458 million euros. Rovio's successful Angry Birds franchise is expected to contribute to the company's growth and market presence.

site_title: UK business, unions ally to urge Brexit citizenship deal
summary: Britain's leading business and union bodies jointly urged the government and EU to guarantee citizenship rights for four million expatriate European and British citizens after Brexit takes place in March 2019. The CBI and TUC said a clear guarantee of the right to remain was needed within weeks, citing concerns about job opportunities and public services. EU citizens face uncertainty due to the need for a permanent residency card, which costs £160 and can only be obtained by filling out an 80-page form. The issue has become a stumbling block in bilateral talks over Britain's divorce.

site_title: Electronics transformation map can make all manufacturing in Singapore Industry 4.0 ready
summary: Singapore's Electronics Industry Transformation Map (ITM) aims to prepare the sector for Industry 4.0 by 2020, with a target of S$22.2 billion in manufacturing value-add and 2,100 new jobs. The ITM will focus on improving manufacturing efficiency and adopting advanced technologies, with a goal of making 100% of manufacturing plants in Singapore best-in-class globally. The electronics cluster, which employs 70,000 workers, is seen as crucial to Singapore's growth and competitiveness, with the ITM aiming to drive innovation and reskilling of the workforce.

site_title: Architecture, food tell a lot about culture and society
summary: Archifest 2017, an annual architecture festival in Singapore, explores the intersection of architecture and culture through various events, including edible dioramas, a bake-off, photography workshops, and guided tours. The festival aims to bring people together through food and architecture, showcasing their artistic and technical aspects. By highlighting the relationship between food and architecture, the event seeks to empower the public to participate in shaping their built environment, promoting a sense of community and cultural understanding.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Powering the Smart City vision through the use of visual analytics
summary: Singapore is embracing the "smart city" vision by leveraging data analytics to improve urban planning, public services, and citizen engagement. The government has invested in ICT and data analytics to extract insights from various information sources, enabling strategic decision-making and performance management. The city-state's reputation for efficient management is a result of its proactive approach to innovation and collaboration with stakeholders. Key initiatives include the use of geospatial technology, predictive systems, and data analytics to understand urban planning implications and optimize infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Singapore's reputation as one of Asia's best-managed cities is the result of a constant proactive effort by the authorities to stay ahead of the curve, managing the demands of population growth against a constant factor of space constraint.

site_title: Jackie Chan out of place in The Foreigner
summary: The Foreigner, a vigilante fantasy cum political drama starring Pierce Brosnan and Jackie Chan, received a mixed review. The film, set in post-Troubles London, follows Irish Deputy Minister Liam Hennessy as he investigates a London bombing, while Chan's character Quan Ngoc Minh seeks revenge for his daughter's death. The movie's action scenes are notable, but the story is marred by inconsistencies and a lack of coherence, making Chan's character feel out of place. The film's director, Martin Campbell, has experience in action genres, but the movie's script and tone fall short of expectations.

images.alt_text: Chan's character, Quan, is a rehash of Liam Neeson in the Taken trilogy.

site_title: Koh Brothers unit makes tunnelling debut with S$520m PUB job
summary: Koh Brothers unit, KBCE, has secured a S$520 million contract with PUB for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) Phase 2 project, marking its first foray into tunnelling. The joint venture with Penta-Ocean Construction Co Ltd will design and construct 10.1 km of tunnels, shafts, and other features. The contract lifts Koh Brothers Eco's order book to S$878.9 million. This win follows a previous contract for the Circle Line 6 (CCL6) project, and the company is exploring overseas markets to build up its tunnelling expertise.

site_title: Playboy founder Hugh Hefner dies at age 91
summary: Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy magazine, died at his home on September 28, 2017, at the age of 91. He was known as the "prophet of pop hedonism" and helped usher in the 1960s sexual revolution with his magazine. Hefner peacefully passed away, leaving behind a business empire built around his libertine lifestyle.

site_title: Toddler shoots playmates at Michigan daycare
summary: Two toddlers, aged three, were hospitalized in critical condition after being accidentally shot with a loaded gun at a daycare in Dearborn, Michigan. The child, who was caring for the toddlers, accessed a loaded gun at a private home that functioned as a daycare, firing one or two shots. The incident highlights the risk of children being injured by unsecured firearms, with nearly 1,300 children dying and 5,790 being treated for gunshot wounds annually in the US. An investigation is ongoing, and charges are possible.

site_title: UN visit to Myanmar's Rakhine state thwarted by 'bad weather'
summary: A UN visit to Myanmar's Rakhine state was postponed due to bad weather, thwarting efforts to assess the humanitarian situation and allegations of widespread abuses against Rohingya Muslims. The visit was part of UN efforts to provide humanitarian aid to over 480,000 Rohingya who fled violence in late August. The UN has urged Myanmar to allow access to northern Rakhine state, but the government has controlled access, leading to concerns about the situation on the ground. The UN Security Council is set to meet on the crisis later Thursday.

site_title: Asia's first YOTEL opens in Singapore
summary: YOTEL, a global chain of microhotels, has opened its first property in Asia, YOTEL Singapore, with 30 floors and 610 rooms in Orchard Road. The hotel offers compact luxury and innovative services, with room rates starting from S$164++. The company has received a US$250 million investment from Starwood Capital Group, which aims to expand YOTEL globally, particularly in Europe, North America, and Asia. YOTEL plans to open its fifth YOTELAIR at Jewel Changi Airport next year, as part of its international expansion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 6.18 points to 1,758.06 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 2.305 billion lots worth RM2.188 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 506 to 328.

site_title: Toshiba inks 2t yen deal to sell chip arm to Bain consortium
summary: Toshiba has signed a final agreement to sell its flash memory chip business to a Bain consortium for approximately 2 trillion yen ($24.1 billion), following months of negotiations. The consortium includes major technology players such as Apple, Dell, and SK Hynix, with Toshiba maintaining a stake. The deal is a significant step towards completing the sale and marks a major shift for the Japanese electronics company.

site_title: Mencast, FEG seek cash from asset deals
summary: Two Singapore listed offshore and marine (O&M) companies, Mencast Holdings and Falcon Energy Group (FEG), are seeking cash through asset deals amid a protracted industry downturn. Mencast is in exploratory discussions over the divestment of its assets, while FEG plans to complete a sale and leaseback by October 2. Both companies have faced significant financial challenges due to the collapse in oil prices in 2014, resulting in net losses in Q2 FY17 for Mencast and Q4 FY17 for FEG. The companies have also relied on financing from the Singapore dollar medium-term notes market.

site_title: US revises growth up a notch for second quarter
summary: The US economy grew at an annual rate of 3.1% in the second quarter, surpassing President Donald Trump's three percent target. The revised estimate, released by the Commerce Department, was driven by increased spending by state and local governments, farms, and consumer spending on services. However, sluggish housing sales weighed on the result, with home buying slowing by 7.3% in the second quarter. The growth rate is the fastest in more than two years, but still falls short of the three percent target.

site_title: Singapore home prices seen reversing after a long downward trend
summary: Singapore's property market is seen reversing its long downward trend, with analysts predicting a recovery. OCBC Investment Research notes that the Urban Redevelopment Authority's third-quarter price index is poised to rebound, marking the end of the bear market. Analysts cite improved sales volumes, increased price expectations from developers, and robust macroeconomic conditions as reasons for their view. Forecasts suggest Singapore home prices will be flat in 2017 and appreciate by 3-8% in 2018. Other analysts, including Morgan Stanley and UOB Kay Hian, also predict a recovery in the property sector.

site_title: Senegalese music start-ups race to be West Africa's Spotify
summary: Senegalese start-ups are racing to create a West African version of Spotify, capitalizing on the growing demand for online music platforms in the region. Despite a lack of credit cards, entrepreneurs like MusikBi and Deedo are developing platforms that allow users to purchase songs via text message and pay with phone credit or cash transfers. The market is seen as untapped, with many West Africans downloading music illegally online due to a lack of access to digital platforms. With the support of investors and mobile operators, the sector is expected to grow, with analysts predicting that users are willing to pay for convenience and attractive services.

site_title: ECB should slow asset purchases, but keep policy loose: Villeroy
summary: The European Central Bank's Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau suggests the ECB should slow its asset purchases while maintaining accommodative monetary policy. This decision aims to balance economic growth with inflation, which remains below the 2% target. Villeroy emphasizes the need for a pragmatic approach to reducing asset purchases and keeping interest rates low until inflation shows a lasting increase. The ECB's 2.3 trillion euro bond-buying program may be reduced, with policymakers agreeing to take a decision on its future this month.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after economic data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 0.08% to 22,322.84, the S&P 500 losing 0.10% to 2,504.29, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 0.25% to 6,437.00. This decline came after data showed a rise in weekly jobless claims and a potential slowdown in third-quarter GDP growth due to the impact of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma.

site_title: DBS enters into 15-year tie-up with insurer Chubb
summary: DBS Bank has entered into a 15-year partnership with Chubb, covering five markets in Asia, to distribute Chubb's home, contents, and general insurance products. The agreement, set to take effect in early 2018, aims to combine DBS' Asian banking franchise with Chubb's general insurance capabilities, targeting SMEs and personal insurance products. This partnership will roll out progressively through 2018.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises US$12.5b from dollar bond offering
summary: Saudi Arabia raised $12.5 billion from its second dollar bond sale this year, bolstering its finances amid an economic overhaul. The government sold $3 billion of long five-year notes, $5 billion of the 10-year tranche, and $4.5 billion of the 30-year offering, with investors submitting about $40 billion in bids. The sale comes as the kingdom seeks to bridge a budget deficit forecast at 7.7% of economic output this year, with yields on existing bonds rising on Wednesday to 3.47% as of 6:33pm in London.

site_title: Mencast in talks for asset divestment
summary: Mencast, an offshore services provider, is in early-stage exploratory discussions with unnamed parties over the divestment of its assets. The company clarified that no definitive agreement has been signed, and shares rose 17.7% before a trading halt. Mencast requested the halt to be lifted after responding to a query from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: UOL associate to buy Nanak Mansions for S$201.08m
summary: UOL Group's associate, Secure Venture Development, has won a tender to purchase the freehold property Nanak Mansions for S$201.08 million. The 10,185 sqm site, with a gross plot ratio of 1.4, is earmarked for residential development. Secure Venture Development, a 50:50 joint-venture between UOL Venture Investments and Kheng Leong Co, will pay 90% of the purchase consideration upon legal completion, with the remaining 10% paid within seven business days. The deal will also include acquiring a private road adjacent to the property.

site_title: Merkel urged by German economists to cut taxes in her next term
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's next government should consider tax cuts to boost growth, economists say. The country's leading research organizations, including the Institute for the World Economy, have urged Merkel to lower social-security taxes and income-tax cuts for lower earners. With more budget surpluses on the horizon, the next government should focus on growth-oriented policies, including improving the compatibility of family and work, and better integrating migrants. The forecasted GDP growth in Germany is expected to increase to 2% next year and 1.8% in 2019.

site_title: Govt bringing forward another S$700m of construction projects to help SME contractors
summary: The Singapore government is bringing forward S$700 million in construction projects to support local SME contractors, in addition to S$700 million announced earlier, totaling S$1.4 billion. These smaller projects, such as upgrading neighbourhood facilities, will benefit SME contractors and are expected to be launched over the next 1-2 years. The government will closely monitor the industry and adjust project pace if necessary, aiming to help the sector during a difficult time.

site_title: North Korean firms in China ordered to close by January
summary: China has ordered North Korean companies in the country to shut down by January, following UN sanctions imposed after Pyongyang's sixth nuclear test. The 120-day closure deadline begins from September 11, as China applies a limit on refined petroleum exports to North Korea starting October 1 and bans textile exports. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will visit Beijing for talks on North Korean nuclear tensions, trade issues, and President Donald Trump's planned trip to China in November.

site_title: Soilbuild to bolster procurement unit equity by S$8.5m
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has bolstered the equity of its wholly-owned subsidiary SB Procurement Pte Ltd by S$8.5 million, bringing the total equity injection to S$15 million. The additional investment, funded by internal resources, will enable SB Procurement to meet the minimum paid-up share capital requirement for an A1 grading by the Building and Construction Authority of Singapore, allowing it to tender for public construction projects of unlimited contract sum.

site_title: BlackBerry Q2 profit rises on back of software sales
summary: BlackBerry posted a rise in Q2 adjusted profit to US$29 million, or 5 US cents a share, driven by record software sales. Revenue fell to US$249 million, down from US$352 million a year ago. The company's software business reached a record high, contributing to the profit increase. BlackBerry stopped manufacturing smartphones last year to focus on software, and the results show its shift towards software sales is paying off.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buys NZ office tower for NZ$63m
summary: Real estate developer Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired NZI Centre in Auckland, New Zealand for NZ$63 million (S$61.7 million). The commercial office building is fully leased to IAG New Zealand until 2036.

site_title: Protesters in Hong Kong demand full democracy on "Occupy" anniversary
summary: Hundreds of protesters in Hong Kong gathered outside government headquarters, demanding full democracy on the third anniversary of the 2014 pro-democracy movement. The protesters, carrying yellow umbrellas, spoke out against China's suppression of civil liberties. The 2014 protests, which blocked major roads for nearly three months, were considered a bold challenge to China's Communist Party rulers. The demonstrators called for greater democracy and freedom, echoing the spirit of the 2014 movement.

site_title: May warns Boeing its relationship with the UK is being undermined by Bombardier row
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May criticized Boeing for its behavior in a dispute with Canadian rival Bombardier, which has put 4,200 jobs at risk in Northern Ireland. May said Boeing's actions undermine its relationship with Britain and that she will work with Canada's government to stress the importance of Bombardier to the region. May also warned of the risk of "creeping protectionism" in the global economy, citing Boeing's complaint against Canada's subsidy of Bombardier as an example.

site_title: GuocoLand, Guoco Group tie-up highest bidder for Beach Rd site at S$1.622b
summary: GuocoLand and Guoco Group submitted the highest bid of S$1.622 billion for a 99-year leasehold commercial site at Beach Road, surpassing other bidders including Kingsford Hurray Development and OUE. The site, which can be developed into a maximum 950,592 sq ft, must include at least 665,424 sq ft for office use. The successful bid marks the top price for the site, which was first made available in 2014 and was initially expected to fetch S$1.138 billion.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: May defends UK economic model in olive branch to business
summary: Theresa May defended the UK's economic model as "the greatest agent of collective human progress" in a speech marking 20 years of Bank of England independence. She emphasized the need for balanced spending and debt control, warning that unfunded borrowing and higher taxation would harm the economy. This comes as Labour's Jeremy Corbyn proposes state intervention and nationalization of utilities, with estimates of £312 billion in pledges. May's speech is part of her efforts to reassure businesses and contrast with Labour's approach.

site_title: JY Pillay sworn in as CPA chairman
summary: JY Pillay, 83, was sworn in as chairman of the Council of Presidential Advisers (CPA) in Singapore on September 28, 2017, marking his re-appointment following the start of a new presidential term. The ceremony was attended by President Halimah Yacob, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon. Pillay has held the position since 2005.

images.alt_text: Mr Pillay (second from left) being sworn in as the chairman of the Council of Presidential Advisers on Thursday.

site_title: Bids for Florence Regency come below independent valuation
summary: Florence Regency, a HUDC estate in Hougang, received three bids for collective sale but the top bidder's price of S$600 million was below its independent valuation of S$629 million. The valuation became the new minimum price for the estate, preventing the award of the tender to the top bidder.

site_title: Formula One: Rookie Gasly heard of debut by text message
summary: Formula One rookie Pierre Gasly was unexpectedly told he would make his Toro Rosso debut at the Malaysian Grand Prix via a text message on Monday. Gasly, the 2016 GP2 champion, replaced Daniil Kvyat and will drive alongside Carlos Sainz for at least the next two races. Gasly hopes to earn a full-time seat for 2018, but is focusing on the current weekend, trying to learn as quickly as possible. Sainz expressed confidence in Gasly's ability to adapt quickly.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker as push on banks fizzles out
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day 9.01 points weaker at 3,227.14, despite a morning push driven by a Wall Street bounce on hopes of tax reform plans. The Straits Times Index initially rose 14 points to an intraday high of 3,250 before losing momentum. Turnover was 2.1 billion units worth S$1.3 billion, the highest for the week. The advance-decline score was 184-212.

site_title: Strong returns lift high net worth individuals' wealth globally
summary: High net worth individuals (HNWI) globally saw a 8.2% wealth expansion in 2016, driven by strong investment performance, with the average global wealth managed by wealth managers rising 24.3%. The Asia-Pacific region, despite a slower growth rate, remains the world's largest HNWI market, with an estimated US$18.8 trillion in wealth, followed by North America with US$45.2 trillion. The region's market growth was hindered by sharp equity market declines in Japan and China.

site_title: Progress on Brexit, but not enough to open trade talk
summary: The European Union and Britain made progress in divorce talks, but not enough to move forward with discussions on a post-Brexit free trade deal. EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier praised a "new dynamic" created by concessions made by Prime Minister Theresa May, but said further work is needed. Key areas of disagreement include citizens' rights and Britain's financial commitments. The two sides agreed on the direct effect of the withdrawal treaty guaranteeing EU citizens' rights in British law, but disagree on pursuing grievances at the EU's court. Talks will resume on October 9.

site_title: Koh Brothers Eco's JV firm secures S$520m contract for maiden tunnelling project
summary: Koh Brothers Eco's joint venture firm has secured a S$520 million contract from PUB for the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) Phase 2 project, marking KBCE's maiden tunnelling project. KBCE and its partner Penta-Ocean will design and construct 10.1km tunnels and other features. The project is KBCE's first large-scale infrastructure project, with CEO Paul Shin expressing optimism for future growth and strengthened order book.

site_title: Cosco Shipping Int'l secures two shipbuilding contracts
summary: Cosco Shipping International has secured two shipbuilding contracts, worth 222 million yuan, to build two multi-purpose pulp vessels and four bulk carriers. The vessels are scheduled for delivery between 2019 and 2020, with the bulk carriers set to be delivered between 2019 and 2020. The contracts are not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Uber launches in new Southeast Asian markets amid push for government blessing
summary: Uber launched operations in Cambodia and Myanmar, securing regulatory approval in the process, amid a push for government blessings in Southeast Asia. The company faces increased government scrutiny, including a US Department of Justice investigation into bribery laws, and recently ended operations in Quebec due to new regulations. Despite this, Uber plans to launch a petition in Thailand to allow its services to operate legally. Regional rival Grab continues to grow its presence in Southeast Asia, with Toyota joining its funding drive.

site_title: Temasek-linked PE bond earns one-notch upgrade from S&P
summary: Temasek-linked private-equity bond Astrea III's Class A-1 notes received a one-notch upgrade to "A+ (sf)" from Standard & Poor's due to a reserve account balance of over $180.4 million and timely interest payments. The upgrade reflects the unique Astrea platform's ability to provide regular income and risk mitigation. The bond series, launched in 2016, is backed by cash flows from 34 underlying private equity funds, offering investors diversification and regular income.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares firm on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, driven by a cheaper yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.47% and the Topix index rose 0.71% following President Donald Trump's plan to slash corporate tax. The moves tracked gains on US stocks, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Thakral Corp's JV GemLife acquires 2 more Australia properties for retirement housing
summary: Thakral Corp's joint venture GemLife has acquired two Australian properties for retirement housing, committing A$20 million to develop them into resort-style homes. The properties, in Victoria and New South Wales, will have 199 and 170 homes, respectively, when completed. This brings the total number of homes under GemLife to over 1,000, with development costs funded by senior debt, capital, and home sales proceeds.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Abu Dhabi state fund Mubadala swings to 1H profit
summary: Abu Dhabi's state-owned Mubadala Investment Company reported a net profit of 4.2 billion dirhams (S$1.5 billion) for the first half of 2017, its first combined financials after merging with IPIC earlier this year. The company's total comprehensive income was 6.8 billion dirhams, compared to a loss of 5.4 billion dirhams in the same period last year. Mubadala's CFO cited prudent cost management and monetizing mature assets as factors contributing to the improved financial performance.

site_title: Hong Kong set to see strong rebound in mainland tours for Golden Week
summary: Hong Kong is expected to see a significant rebound in tour groups from mainland China during the Golden Week holiday, with estimated daily increases of up to 40% compared to last year. This is attributed to a decline in travel to Japan, Korea, and Taiwan due to China's discouragement of tourism to these countries. The rebound is expected to boost Hong Kong's retailers, with shares of jewelers and apparel retailers rising ahead of the holiday. This growth comes after a two-year slump in tourism, with Hong Kong Tourism Board recording a 2.4% rise in tourist arrivals in July.

site_title: China's final Q2 current account surplus at US$50.9b: FX regulator
summary: China reported a final Q2 current account surplus of US$50.9 billion, down from a preliminary surplus of US$52.9 billion. The capital and financial account deficit for the April-June period was US$400 million, down from a preliminary deficit of US$52.9 billion. China's first-half current account surplus stood at US$69.3 billion, while the capital and financial account deficit was US$38.9 billion. This marks a slight decrease in China's current account surplus, indicating potential pressure on policymakers to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Carney: BOE can't be expected to nullify Brexit hit to economy
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that the BOE cannot nullify the economic hit from Brexit, but its monetary policy can influence how the impact is distributed between job losses and price rises. Britain's economic prosperity will depend on the final EU divorce arrangements and government fiscal policies.

site_title: Seoul: Won skids to 11-week low as foreign selling intensifies
summary: The South Korean won fell to an 11-week low, reaching 1,149.1 to the US dollar, due to increased foreign selling of local shares and government bonds as the US dollar rises. Foreign investors sold 3 trillion won worth of South Korean treasury bonds and 136.6 billion won worth of Korean shares, but the benchmark Kospi index remained unchanged. Finance officials attribute the selloff to profit-taking or portfolio adjustments, unrelated to escalating tensions over North Korea.

site_title: A long-term future in an uncertain world
summary: The Global Investment Council (GIC) hosted its annual thought leadership event, GIC Insights, on September 15, 2017, where 110 global business leaders discussed long-term issues. The panel on "A Long-Term Future in an Uncertain World" focused on the future of business and investment in a changing global landscape. The event aimed to explore potential challenges and opportunities, including the role of Asia in the next decade, artificial intelligence, and its impact on traditional industries. The discussion highlighted the need for adaptability and innovation in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: Price cuts to clear summer stock fray H&M margins
summary: H&M reported a 20% fall in quarterly profit to 5.02 billion Swedish crowns, due to summer discounts hurting margins and slowing sales. The company attributed the decline to increased competition and young shoppers moving online. Despite a 4.6% drop in shares, H&M sees potential to achieve lower inventory levels in the future and plans a net increase of 385 stores for the year. The company's gross margin shrunk to 51.4% from 54.0%, and inventories rose 8% at the end of the quarter.

site_title: Hanging cow at Australia restaurant sparks controversy
summary: An Australian pizzeria, Etica, in Adelaide has sparked controversy by hanging a taxidermied dairy cow from its ceiling to highlight the industrialization of the farming industry. The owners, passionate about animal welfare, claim the display aims to educate patrons about the origins of the food they serve. However, the move has been criticized on social media for cruelty, with many questioning the ethics of displaying a dead animal. The owners defend their decision, stating they want to raise awareness about the treatment of animals in the farming industry.

site_title: Macron's EU vision faces reality check at Estonia dinner
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to present his vision for a more integrated European Union to fellow leaders at an informal dinner in Estonia, but faces cautious resistance to his calls for a pooling of national budgets and deeper monetary union. Eastern European leaders may caution about the risk of new cleavages, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel is unlikely to commit to significant financial burden-sharing due to her own domestic coalition talks. The dinner aims to streamline debate and focus on concrete objectives, amid a backdrop of Brexit negotiations and the bloc's post-2019 slump.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron can expound his ambitious new vision for the European Union when he meets his fellow EU leaders over dinner in Estonia on Thursday, but is likely to receive only a cautious hearing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GuocoLand tops bids for a 99-year leasehold commercial site on Beach Road with a bid of S$1.622 billion, or S$1,706 per square foot per plot ratio. The country saw its largest IPO listing in six years in Q3 2017, while home prices are expected to rebound for the first time in four years. Starbucks extended its agreement with Maxim's Caterers to grow in Singapore, and a subsidiary of Koh Brothers Eco secured a S$520 million contract for a maiden tunnelling project.

site_title: Starbucks extends agreement with Maxim's Caterers to grow in Singapore
summary: Starbucks has entered into an agreement with Maxim's Caterers Limited to license fully Starbucks operations in Singapore. The move aligns with Starbucks' growth agenda and accelerates its expansion in the market. Maxim's Caterers, a leading restaurant operator in Asia, will operate and develop Starbucks stores in Singapore, where the company has a presence since 1996 with over 130 stores. The partnership will leverage Maxim's expertise and the Starbucks brand to welcome Singaporean customers and earn their trust.

site_title: Toshiba signs 2t yen deal to sell chip unit to Bain Capital
summary: Toshiba has formally signed a deal to sell its memory chip business to a consortium led by US investor Bain Capital for around $18 billion. The sale is crucial to keeping the struggling Japanese conglomerate afloat, with the chip unit accounting for a quarter of Toshiba's total annual revenue. The deal caps a months-long saga that included heated courtroom battles and rival bids, and aims to complete the sale by March. Toshiba narrowly avoided delisting this year, and the sale is seen as key to its survival as it recovers from multi-billion-dollar losses at its US nuclear operation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down despite Wall St gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, despite a strong lead from Wall Street, as investors brushed off US President Donald Trump's plans to slash taxes and ramp up the US economy. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.80%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding US trade policies, despite a fresh record for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Kuroda: Japan's economic expansion broadening
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that Japan's economic expansion is broadening and likely to be sustainable, despite inflation remaining below the 2% target. Kuroda reiterated the BOJ's commitment to its massive stimulus program. He noted that despite economic growth, prices continue to hover on a weak note. This suggests the BOJ will maintain its current stimulus efforts to support the economy.

site_title: SIA, Lufthansa JV partnership to kick off from Oct 1
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) and Lufthansa Group will launch a joint venture (JV) on October 1, covering flights between Singapore, Australia, and Germany, Switzerland, Austria, and Belgium. Passengers will have access to wider travel itineraries and fares, and existing Star Alliance arrangements will be enhanced. The two carriers have expanded capacity between Singapore and Germany and Switzerland since 2015 and have increased codeshare ties to over 130 city pairs. Flights operated by SIA, Lufthansa, and SWISS between Singapore and European cities will be included in a revenue-sharing agreement.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Etihad appoints new group CEO to lead turnaround
summary: Etihad appoints Tony Douglas as new group CEO in January 2018, replacing James Hogan.
