Douglas, a former UK Ministry of Defence official, aims to lead the airline group's turnaround after significant losses due to expansion strategy and slower travel demand. The airline group, the third-largest in the Gulf trio, is seeking to recover from losses on equity stakes in Alitalia, Air Berlin, and Virgin Australia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Mencast calls for trading halt after price surge, query from SGX
summary: MENCAST Holdings requested a trading halt for its shares on September 28, 2017, following a 17.7% surge in its stock price to 19.3 Singapore cents. The surge triggered a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Modi's $2.5b power plan may stumble on ailing buyers
summary: India's plan to electrify all households by December 2018 faces challenges as state-run power retailers continue to lose money selling electricity below cost. The federal government will spend $3.38 billion to provide electricity connections, but convincing states to allow profitable power tariffs will be Prime Minister Narendra Modi's biggest challenge. States must allow operational autonomy and timely payment of subsidies for the plan to succeed, and losses are expected to decrease over the next few years, with the government taking over 50% of retailer losses by 2021.

site_title: Australia: shares end up on Wall St boost; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.11% to close at 5,670.4, tracking US stock gains on hopes for a US tax-reduction plan. Financial stocks climbed 0.4%, with the "Big Four" banks adding 0.2-0.6% each. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.002% due to concerns over a lower growth outlook and interest rates remaining at record lows.

site_title: Europe: Equities clamber higher at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, driven by US President Donald Trump's market-friendly tax cut plans. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1%, while the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 added 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. The rally was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with investors remaining positive despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slide to multi-week lows on N Korea risks
summary: South Korea's won fell to a seven-week low, reaching 1,146.2 won per US dollar, amid concerns over North Korea's potential provocations, particularly around the anniversary of its communist party's founding and China's Communist Party Congress. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also slid 0.2% to its weakest level since September 15. Investors are taking precautions before the Chuseok break, expecting US rate hikes and uncertainty over North Korea's actions.

site_title: Australia: Shares firm on Wall St, Trump tax plan; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.11% to 5,670.6, supported by gains on Wall Street on hopes of a US tax-reduction plan. New Zealand shares remained flat. The S&P/ASX 200 index was boosted by industrial commodities like copper, with copper closing higher after five consecutive days of losses. Financial stocks and utilities led the gains, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose marginally due to a lower growth outlook.

site_title: Broker's take: Singapore home prices to rebound for first time in 4 years
summary: OCBC Investment Research expects Singapore home prices to rebound for the first time in four years, according to their third-quarter price index forecast. The analysts cite improved market conditions, including strengthened sales volumes and take-up rates in the primary housing market, and increased price expectations from developers and home sellers in the secondary market. They predict flat prices in 2017 and a 3-8% appreciation in 2018, maintaining their "overweight" rating for the property sector with top picks being City Developments, UOL Group, and Wheelock Properties.

site_title: Singapore sees largest IPO listing in 6 years in Q3 2017: EY
summary: Singapore's mainboard saw the largest IPO in six years in Q3 2017, with NetLink NBN Trust raising US$1.7 billion. This was the second-largest global listing that quarter, and the company's IPO was over-subscribed by 100%. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had a total of 13 IPOs in the first nine months of 2017, a slight decline from the previous year. The Asia-Pacific region dominated global IPO markets in Q3 2017, accounting for 65% of global listings and 49% of capital raised.

site_title: Playboy creator Hugh Hefner dies at age 91
summary: Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy magazine, died at his home near Los Angeles at the age of 91. He passed away from natural causes, and his death was announced by Playboy Enterprises Inc. Hefner was known for creating a media and entertainment giant that advertised itself as a symbol of the sexual revolution. He was a successful entrepreneur, publishing the first issue of Playboy in 1953, and lived a life that was often compared to a romantic movie, featuring himself as a sophisticated host.

site_title: India says work on GE's locomotive factory on track
summary: India's railways minister Piyush Goyal said the construction of a diesel locomotive factory by US firm General Electric is on track, despite concerns over changes to the contract. GE had won a $2.6 billion contract to supply 1,000 diesel locomotives, but the railways ministry recently suggested making electric engines instead to save costs. The ministry claims the change won't undermine the 'Make in India' initiative, which aims to boost domestic manufacturing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 1.64 points to 1,765.88. The index saw 80.25 million lots traded worth RM14.66 million, with 106 gainers outnumbering 48 losers.

site_title: Indonesia hopes investors will snap up "komodo bonds" to fund infrastructure
summary: Indonesia is set to issue "komodo bonds" to raise funds for infrastructure projects. The bonds, denominated in rupiah, are being issued by four state firms with President Joko Widodo's approval. The term "komodo bonds" was chosen, rather than local food, and is named after the Komodo dragon found in eastern Indonesia. This move aims to attract investors and raise funds for the country's infrastructure development.

site_title: Acceptances push unconditional offer for Mary Chia past 90% mark
summary: Suki Sushi, controlled by Lee Boon Leng, has acquired about 90.1% of Mary Chia Holdings, surpassing the 90% threshold required by the Singapore Exchange. As a result, trading in the shares may be suspended and/or the company may be delisted unless a public float of at least 10% is restored within three months or longer. Suki Sushi intends to maintain the company's listing status and plans to take necessary steps to restore the public float.

site_title: Asia's first YOTEL opening in the heart of Singapore
summary: YOTEL, a microhotel chain, has opened its first location in Asia in Singapore, located at 366 Orchard Road. The 610-room hotel features smartly designed "cabins" with adjustable beds, technowalls, and smart TVs. Inspired by Japanese capsule hotels and British Airways' first class lounge, YOTEL aims to provide guests with "everything they need and nothing they don't." The hotel's CEO, Hubert Viriot, believes the innovative style of hospitality will suit Singapore's lifestyle, with a second location set to open at Jewel Changi Airport in 2018.

site_title: Thai junta leader confirms fugitive former PM Yingluck is in Dubai
summary: Thai junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha confirmed fugitive former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra is in Dubai, having fled the country last month to avoid a 5-year prison sentence over a rice subsidy scheme. The court found Yingluck guilty and sentenced her in absentia. Thailand will pursue her through diplomatic channels and police cooperation with Interpol. The Supreme Court had delayed judgment after Yingluck failed to appear, citing her absence from the country. Yingluck's brother, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, lives in self-imposed exile in Dubai.

site_title: China Q4 quota awards show total 2017 oil products exports to be cut 19%
summary: China has allocated 1.644 million tonnes of oil product export quotas for the fourth quarter to state-owned oil majors CNPC and Sinopec, resulting in a 19% cut in total 2017 oil exports to 37.4 million tonnes. This move is part of Beijing's drive to cut pollution, following a record volume of quotas issued last year that wasn't fully utilized. The cuts may cap crude processing rates in China as refiners struggle with a fuel supply glut.

site_title: 'Flatliners' resurrects Hollywood's afterlife fixation
summary: The Hollywood film "Flatliners" reimagines the concept of an afterlife, where a group of medical students experiment with near-death experiences to prove the existence of an afterlife. The 2017 reboot, directed by Niels Arden Oplev, features a new cast, including Ellen Page and Kevin Bacon, and incorporates modern medical technology to create a more realistic portrayal of the experience. The film also explores themes of American culture's obsession with success and the consequences of one's actions.

images.alt_text: The latest take on the hereafter is "Flatliners," a reboot of the 1990 cult classic about student physicians shocking themselves to the other side and back - with a young new cast and a masters degree in medical authenticity.

site_title: Australia job vacancies surge to record high in August quarter
summary: Australia's job vacancies reached a record high of 203,700 in the June-August quarter, up 6% from the previous quarter and 15.4% from the same period in 2016. Private sector vacancies climbed 6.1% to 183,700, while public sector vacancies rose 5.3% to 20,000, the highest since 1989. Analysts value the vacancies series as a reliable leading indicator of labor demand and turning points in employment growth, supporting official employment figures for a surge in hiring this year.

site_title: South Korea to offer tax help, loans to firms hit by China trade curbs
summary: South Korea plans to offer tax and loan concessions to firms affected by China's trade sanctions, which were imposed in response to Seoul's deployment of a missile shield. The government will allow duty-free retailers to defer corporate income and value-added taxes for up to nine months, and provide cheap loans to auto-component makers hit by declining sales of South Korean cars in China. The measures aim to compensate for losses suffered by the tourism and auto sectors, which have been impacted by Beijing's boycotts.

site_title: Gov Koike's new party gains traction ahead of general election-polls
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's new conservative party, the Party of Hope, is gaining traction ahead of Japan's general election on October 22. Media polls show 18% of voters plan to vote for Koike's party, while 29% support Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party. Koike, a former LDP lawmaker, has upended the outlook with her pro-reform and conservative stance, which has drawn support from the main opposition Democratic Party. Koike wants to freeze the national sales tax and abandon nuclear power, staking out different policy positions from Abe's government.

site_title: Toyota, Mazda set up venture to develop electric cars
summary: Toyota and Mazda are forming a joint venture to develop electric cars, with Toyota holding an 90% stake in the company. The venture, called the EV Common Architecture Spirit Co Ltd, will produce a range of electric vehicles, including minivehicles, passenger cars, SUVs, and light trucks. Mazda and Denso will each hold a 5% stake in the company. This move aims to help the Japanese automakers catch up with global rivals in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: US dollar steady near 1-month high, supported by US fiscal hopes
summary: The US dollar traded near a one-month high against a basket of currencies due to hopes for US fiscal reforms, with President Donald Trump's proposed tax overhaul sparking optimism. The US dollar index reached a high of 93.607, its strongest level since August 23, and has gained about 1.3% so far this week. The euro held steady, while the New Zealand dollar slipped after the central bank kept interest rates unchanged. The US dollar's bounce is seen as stabilizing, but not a strong rebound, and the near-term focus will be on US data releases.

site_title: Japan's lower house of parliament dissolved, paving way for snap vote
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dissolved parliament, paving the way for a snap election on October 22. Abe faces a challenge from Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike, who has launched the "Party of Hope" with an influx of lawmakers. Koike is not running for a seat in parliament but is focusing on governing Tokyo ahead of the 2020 Olympics. Abe seeks a fresh mandate for his hardline stance on North Korea and a new tax plan. The election is seen as a test of Abe's popularity and his ability to unify the opposition against him.

site_title: Audrey Hepburn's personal memorabilia auction tops £4.6m
summary: Audrey Hepburn's personal memorabilia auctioned for £4,635,500 (S$8.4 million) at Christie's in London, exceeding US$6 million. The 10-hour sale featured items from the screen icon's collection, including a world record-breaking script for the 1961 film "Breakfast at Tiffany's". Christie's head of sale and director, Adrian Hume-Sayer, expressed delight at the "overwhelming response" to the auction.

site_title: Sanofi, Regeneron's eczema drug dupilumab gets European Union nod
summary: The European Commission has approved Regeneron Pharmaceuticals and Sanofi's dupilumab, sold as Dupixent, for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis. The approval follows the US FDA's approval in March. Dupilumab is designed to inhibit two key proteins driving the disease and is expected to generate annual sales of 4.7 billion euros by 2023. Sanofi plans to submit an application for dupilumab in asthma by the end of the year, while Regeneron and Sanofi's shares have declined after recent trial data and sales performance fell short of investor expectations.

site_title: China says intellectual property rights crackdown not reaction to other countries' probes
summary: China's commerce ministry stated its intellectual property rights crackdown is not a reaction to probes by other countries, but rather a proactive effort to protect intellectual property rights. The ministry emphasized the importance of protection of intellectual property rights and took steps to combat business secret theft and counterfeit goods. This move comes amid global scrutiny of China's IP protection, but the ministry asserts its actions are independent of external probes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street following President Donald Trump's tax plan and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.64% to 20,396.88, while the Topix index increased 0.65% to 1,675.21.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up after Trump unveils tax plan
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday morning following a rally on Wall Street after US President Donald Trump unveiled long-awaited tax plans. The Hang Seng Index edged up 0.07%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 1.43%. The rally was seen as a positive reaction to Trump's tax plan, extending the previous day's gains.

site_title: Tech executives to testify at US Congress' Russia hearings
summary: US Congress to hear from Facebook, Google, and Twitter executives on Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 US election. The Senate Intelligence Committee has requested testimony from the tech companies on November 1, while the House Intelligence Committee plans an open hearing. The goal is to understand how Russia used online tools and platforms to influence the election. Lawmakers are seeking information about the influence of social networks, amid concerns about fake news and possible collusion between Trump associates and Russia. Moscow denies any interference.

site_title: South Korea expects more North Korea provocations mid-October
summary: South Korea expects North Korea to increase provocative actions around October 10 and 18, coinciding with the anniversary of the founding of North Korea's communist party and China's Communist Party Congress. The move comes amid escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula due to North Korea's nuclear and missile development program. South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has expressed concerns about the possibility of accidental incidents sparking military conflict, while the US has threatened military and diplomatic options. China's opposition to North Korea's actions is also expected to increase during the Congress.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Roxy-Pacific, APAC Realty, shopper360
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has denied demolishing a historic facade without City of Sydney Council approval, claiming it has worked closely with the council to retain or rebuild original building elements. APAC Realty will debut on the Singapore bourse, receiving 13.4 times oversubscription for its initial public offering. shopper360 signed a non-binding agreement to incorporate a joint venture company in Myanmar for marketing services.

site_title: Banks plan counterattack as Apple Pay readies Nordic market grab
summary: Danske Bank's digital-pay subsidiary, MobilePay, is urging Nordic banks to form a single payments platform to counter Apple Pay and Samsung Pay's entry into the region. The move comes as the European payments directive, set to take effect in January, will require banks to provide rivals with access to account information, potentially weakening their grip on customer data. MobilePay aims to protect banks' role in the payment value chain, while Apple Pay prepares to launch in Denmark, Sweden, and Finland by the end of the year.

site_title: Canada's Bombardier eyes options after blows to rail, aero units
summary: Bombardier Inc faces increased pressure after the US imposed preliminary anti-subsidy duties on its jet sales, and Germany's Siemens AG merged its rail business with Alstom instead of partnering with Bombardier. Despite these setbacks, Bombardier is pursuing talks with China for jet sales, and a potential European jet order, which may help its turnaround plan. The company has a $33 billion train order backlog and is in a stronger position than in 2015, when it considered bankruptcy. Bombardier is aiming to sell its first CSeries jet in China, with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau set to visit the country in December.

site_title: Hot stock: APAC Realty rises above IPO price on debut day
summary: APAC Realty Ltd, a real estate player operating under the ERA brand, made a successful debut on the Singapore Exchange with its IPO. The stock rose to an intra-day high of S$0.775, 11.5 cents above its IPO price of S$0.66 per share. Over 39.3 million shares were traded, and the stock closed at S$0.76, 10 cents higher than its IPO price. The company received strong interest for its IPO, with 3,035 valid applications for the public offering and 597.6 million placement shares subscribed.

site_title: Museums give peek into secret world of Yves Saint Laurent
summary: Yves Saint Laurent's innermost secrets are being revealed through new museums and publications. The first of two museums dedicated to his memory opened in Paris, showcasing his life and work. New books and documentaries, including one on his erotic drawings, aim to decode the mysteries of the painfully shy designer who revolutionized women's fashion. This follows the death of his partner and business partner, Pierre Berge, just weeks ago. Saint Laurent's private world is slowly being uncovered, offering a glimpse into the life of a fashion legend.

site_title: Australia dollar near 6-week lows; kiwi ticks higher as NZ rates on hold
summary: The Australian dollar has fallen near six-week lows at US$0.7846, down 1.3% for the week, as the US dollar and Treasury yields rise amid expectations of a US tax cut boost to economic growth and inflation. The New Zealand dollar has also ticked higher at US$0.7226, despite the Reserve Bank of New Zealand keeping interest rates unchanged. Economists expect a possible rate hike in New Zealand later this year if wages and fiscal policy improve.

site_title: US slashes number of refugees it is ready to resettle
summary: The US has reduced its refugee resettlement goal to 45,000 over the next year, down from 84,995 in 2016, and is on track to accept around 50,000 this year. The decision, made by President Donald Trump, is part of a broader effort to tighten security procedures and vetting processes for new arrivals. Refugee advocates and UN agencies have condemned the move, citing the need for increased resettlement opportunities for vulnerable displaced people, including widows with children, the elderly, and the disabled.

site_title: Trump looking 'very closely' at firing health secretary over use of private jets
summary: President Donald Trump is considering firing Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price due to his use of private jets for taxpayer-funded flights. Price is facing two investigations into his travel, which has cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Trump has expressed displeasure with Price's performance, particularly on repealing and replacing Obamacare. The White House has refused to defend Price's travel, and a House committee has launched an inquiry into the use of government planes by senior administration officials.

site_title: Zuckerberg argues back after Trump tweets about Facebook bias
summary: Mark Zuckerberg responded to President Trump's accusation of bias on Facebook, saying both sides criticize the platform for ideas and content they dislike. Zuckerberg acknowledged that Facebook encouraged more people to engage politically and vote, while also conceding that the platform had "problematic ads." He also apologized for his earlier dismissal of the idea that misinformation on Facebook could have influenced the US presidential election. Zuckerberg stated that Facebook will defend against nation-states spreading misinformation and subverting elections.

site_title: Despite Brexit, London skyscrapers draw highest rents in Europe
summary: London remains Europe's top destination for office space, with prime rents in skyscrapers exceeding $110 per square foot, nearly double those in Paris and Frankfurt. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the capital's steady office space take-up has attracted overseas buyers, including for iconic buildings like the "Cheesegrater" and "Walkie Talkie." Knight Frank's report suggests London's resilience and popularity as a business location, with firms willing to pay more for office space due to its status as an international hub.

site_title: New Zealand keeps cash rate at record lows
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank kept the official cash rate at a record low of 1.75% amid moderate inflation and healthy economic growth. Annual inflation was 1.7% in the year to June 30, forecast to reach 2.0% in the long term. Economic growth was 2.7% in the 12 months to June, tracking at around 3% for over a year. The bank's stance is expected to remain accommodative for a considerable period, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Airbnb enters restaurant reservation business
summary: Airbnb has entered the restaurant reservation business, partnering with Resy to offer table reservations at 700 restaurants in 16 US cities. The partnership aims to provide travelers with a memorable dining experience before their stay. Airbnb executive Joe Zadeh stated that the company is not looking to dominate the restaurant market, but rather focus on partnering with high-quality establishments that travelers should visit. The deal is a minority investment by Resy, and financial details were not disclosed.

site_title: Most US voters think Trump not fit to be president: poll
summary: A majority of US voters, 56%, believe Donald Trump is not fit to serve as president, according to a Quinnipiac University poll. Only 36% approve of Trump's job performance, and 69% think he should stop tweeting. The poll found significant party and racial divisions, with 94% of Democrats and 4% of Republicans saying Trump is unfit. Trump's job approval numbers have hovered between 33% and 40% in recent Quinnipiac polls.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 8.15 points or 0.3% to 3,244.3. The gains followed overnight US stocks, with financials and tech stocks leading the pack. About 44.6 million shares worth S$102.2 million were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 78 to 30.

site_title: US senators announce deal on self-driving car legislation
summary: US Senators John Thune and Gary Peters announced a bipartisan deal on legislation to ease hurdles for self-driving cars. The bill would allow federal regulators to approve their use if deemed safe, barring states from blocking autonomous vehicles. Commercial trucks above 10,000 pounds would be excluded. Automakers can sell up to 25,000 vehicles in the first year, with safety assessment reports required, but no pre-market approval needed. The bill aims to speed deployment of self-driving cars, potentially saving lives and creating new jobs, with the goal of beginning deployment around 2020.

site_title: Trump and Republicans roll out tax reform plan
summary: US President Donald Trump's Republican Party unveiled a tax reform plan, aiming to cut the corporate tax rate from 35% to 20% and abolish the inheritance tax. The plan also seeks to simplify the tax code and encourage firms to bring back profits from abroad. However, Democrats criticized the proposal as favoring the wealthy, and its funding mechanism was not clarified. The plan's passage remains uncertain, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer warning that it could add $5-7 trillion to the federal deficit.

site_title: Ryanair lurches deeper into cancellations crisis
summary: Ryanair has cancelled more flights, affecting 400,000 customers and doubling the original number of passengers impacted by the airline's crisis since mid-September. The cancellations, affecting 34 routes, will eliminate all risk of further flight cancellations until early 2018. Ryanair plans to operate 25 fewer aircraft during its European winter schedule and will roll out seat sales for winter 2017. The airline has also dropped its bid for Italy's Alitalia and is facing enforcement action from Britain's Civil Aviation Authority for failing to provide proper information to customers.

site_title: Britain talks new trade deals with Peru, Ecuador and Colombia
summary: Britain is in talks with Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia to form new trade deals based on their existing agreements with the European Union, following the country's Brexit. The talks aim to establish independent trading arrangements and capitalize on the UK's post-Brexit opportunities for free trade. Britain's trade with South American countries totaled £12.4 billion in 2015, and officials hope to strengthen ties with these nations after the UK leaves the EU.

site_title: Geo Energy unit's US$300m notes offering more than 3 times oversubscribed
summary: Geo Energy Resources Limited's US$300 million notes offering was more than three times oversubscribed, with a total order book of over US$1.2 billion. The fixed-rate senior notes have a 8% coupon rate and are due in 2022. The net proceeds will be used for debt repayment, working capital, and corporate purposes. The notes are rated B2 by Moody's and B by Standard and Poor's. They will be issued by Geo Coal International Pte Ltd on October 4 and listed on the Singapore Exchange on October 5.

site_title: Amazon beefs up Echo line-up and Alexa skills
summary: Amazon introduced new home assistant devices powered by Alexa, including a redesigned Echo speaker with improved sound and a free voice call feature. The company also announced Alexa integration into BMW and Mini cars by mid-2018. Additionally, Amazon released the Echo Spot with a circular screen and a new Fire TV device capable of streaming 4K video. The updates aim to fortify Amazon's hardware lineup ahead of the holiday shopping season, competing with Google and other digital assistants.

site_title: Canada blasts Boeing, warns US jobs at stake in Bombardier trade row
summary: Canada strongly criticized the US Commerce Department's announcement to impose 220% anti-dumping duties on Bombardier's CSeries jetliners, warning that US jobs could be at stake. The move is seen as protectionist and aimed at eliminating Bombardier's aircraft from the US market. Canada and the UK have threatened to boycott Boeing, which is seeking to sell fighter jets to Canada and helicopters to Britain. The duties are expected to impact the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement and could lead to retaliatory measures, with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau vowing to fight for good Canadian jobs.

site_title: Brent slips from 2015 peaks, US crude up on inventory draw
summary: Oil prices saw a shift on Wednesday, with Brent slipping 1% to $57.90 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 0.5% to $52.14. A 1.8 million-barrel draw in US crude inventories supported oil prices, while refiners came back online after Hurricane Harvey. However, petrol stocks rose, and diesel stocks fell short of expectations. The dollar's strength also impacted the market. Oil prices remain influenced by output curbs by OPEC and concerns about US production growth.

site_title: Finance has become the tail that wags the dog
summary: The US financial system has become detached from its core purpose, prioritizing profits over serving society. Over the past decade, financial scandals, regulatory battles, and complexity have numbed the public to the debate, despite the need for a safer system. The largest banks now focus on trading and enriching the wealthy, with only 15% of their funds going to new business investment, rather than the 80% of assets owned by the top 20% of the population. This model is disconnected from Adam Smith's vision of finance as a helpmeet to other businesses, fueling the wealth gap and hindering growth.

site_title: Brazil holds record oil field auctions
summary: Brazil's National Petroleum Agency held a record-breaking oil auction, selling 37 exploration blocks for over $1 billion in Rio de Janeiro. The auction, an early test of President Michel Temer's policies, fetched $1.2 billion, exceeding expectations. The sales were part of a series of nine auctions aimed at attracting foreign investors and boosting the economy, with total sales expected to reach $80 billion by 2019. The auctions also included the sale of operating licenses for four hydroelectric facilities for $3.8 billion.

site_title: 78% of CPF investors beat risk-free 2.5% returns
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board reported that 78% of CPF investors, or 441,000 members, outperformed the 2.5% guaranteed annual interest rate in fiscal year 2016, with 12% incurring losses. The CPF Board tweaked its method for tracking performance, excluding members with no investments and factoring in unrealized gains. This change aims to better reflect members' total investment portfolio performance. The board also introduced a cumulative series of profit or losses to reflect longer-term performance, but data for past years may not be comparable.

site_title: Rise in bike-sharing across Asia leads to drop in petrol consumption growth
summary: A growing bike-sharing industry across Asia has led to a decline in petrol consumption growth, with millions of consumers using phone apps to rent bikes for short trips, reducing car use and trips by motor vehicles. In China alone, over 16 million bikes have been put into service, with more than 100 million registered riders, eating into petrol demand growth expected to stagnate by 2025. Industry estimates and government reports suggest that bike-sharing boosts public transport utilization, contributing to the decline in petrol consumption.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as Trump unveils tax cut
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as President Donald Trump unveiled a long-awaited tax plan, with financial and technology shares gaining. The plan slashes the corporate rate to 20% from 35% and offers tax relief for companies to bring earnings back to the US. The policy is expected to undergo significant changes as it moves through Congress.

site_title: No obvious signs of torture on American held by North Korea: coroner
summary: An Ohio coroner stated that American student Otto Warmbier, who died after being released from North Korea, displayed no obvious signs of torture. The coroner attributed Warmbier's death to brain damage caused by lack of oxygen, but couldn't determine the cause. This contradicts claims by Warmbier's parents and President Donald Trump that he was tortured by the North Korean regime, who had convicted him of trying to steal a propaganda poster. The coroner emphasized that physical evidence of torture was not found, and the truth behind Warmbier's death may never be known.

images.alt_text: Otto Warmbier, the American student who died days after being released from North Korea in a coma, displayed no obvious signs of torture, an Ohio medical examiner said on Wednesday.

site_title: How to drive off in a BlueSG electric car
summary: BlueSG, a Singapore-based electric car-sharing service, is set to launch in December. To drive a BlueSG car, users must have a valid driving license and credit card, choose a package, and confirm the transaction. Members can pick up and drop off cars using their membership card, which also unlocks and charges the vehicle. Parking spaces can be reserved in advance. Users will receive an SMS confirmation after parking and charging the car. BlueSG's customer service is available 24/7.

site_title: Sterling hits 10-week high amid surge in UK retail sales growth
summary: Sterling reached a 10-week high against the euro due to British retail sales growth hitting a two-year peak, bolstering bets on a Bank of England rate hike in November. The pound also rose against the dollar after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that gradual rate hikes are necessary, while sterling fell as the dollar reached a five-week high. Despite this, sterling strengthened to its strongest level since July 17 against the euro, before trading flat at 87.67 pence.

site_title: Property market on verge of turning
summary: Singapore's property market is poised for a turning point, with strong buying momentum and sales of new private homes surpassing 2016's full-year level. Unsold units are estimated to clear in one-and-a-half years, and residential prices and rents are moderating. The revival of en bloc sales and limited government land supply may support demand. The office sector is also showing signs of improvement, with premium office rents rising and net demand for space increasing. However, caution is advised due to uncertainties in economic conditions and future employment.

site_title: BNP: S'pore home prices have bottomed, HK's still 'crazy'
summary: Singapore home prices have reached a bottom and will rebound, driven by "very significant" income growth, according to BNP Paribas SA. Home prices are expected to rise 10-15% over the next 12-15 months, attracting foreign buyers, particularly from China. In contrast, Hong Kong's housing market is expected to remain "crazy" with prices defying gravity, but no property bubble is predicted. Affordability in Singapore has improved, with the house price-to-income ratio declining to 10 times, while in Hong Kong it has risen to 15 times.

site_title: Raffles Education proposes placement of up to 95m new ordinary shares
summary: Raffles Education Corporation has entered into a placement agreement to issue up to 95 million new ordinary shares at S$0.30 each, with the gross proceeds estimated to be up to S$28.5 million. The net proceeds will be used for loan repayment and general working capital purposes. This will increase the total number of issued shares to up to 1.06 billion shares, excluding treasury shares.

site_title: Equifax tries to turn the page by replacing CEO
summary: Equifax's CEO, Richard F Smith, will retire after weeks of mounting public and legal pressure following the massive data breach that compromised the personal information of US adults. The company's board, citing damage from the breach, retroactively classified Smith as having been fired for cause, potentially requiring him to forgo or repay compensation. Paulino do Rego Barros Jr. will replace Smith on an interim basis, and the company is conducting a search for a permanent CEO. The move comes as lawmakers push for tougher oversight of the industry, and critics argue that management changes alone are insufficient to address concerns.

site_title: Macron government cuts wealth taxes in its first budget
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's government unveiled its first annual budget, cutting wealth taxes and slashing social security spending by 5.5 billion euros. The budget includes 7 billion euros in tax cuts, with high-paid finance workers facing lower taxes, and aims to boost purchasing power for low-paid workers and those caring for disabled children. The government also plans to trim France's deficit to 2.6% of GDP by 2018, as Macron seeks to earn credibility with European leaders and encourage investors to fund companies in France.

site_title: Syngenta to pay more than US$1.4b in corn settlement: sources
summary: Syngenta has agreed to pay over $1.4 billion to US farmers in a settlement related to the marketing of genetically modified corn seeds, resolving all US litigation. The deal, announced in a Minnesota class-action trial, affects over 100,000 farmers who claimed the company misled them about Chinese approval for its seeds, leading to depressed corn prices. The settlement is nearly equal to Syngenta's 2016 revenue and resolves a lawsuit that could have resulted in a $3 billion resolution.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Civmec has secured several contracts by Jemena Northern Gas Pipeline Pty Ltd for a project near Tennent Creek in Australia, including camp set-up and SMPEI installation works. Global Logistic Properties is shifting investments from Qingdao and Tianjin to Chongqing and Shenyang. VALUEMAX Group has entered a share purchase agreement to acquire Sengkang Pawnshop for over S$3.58 million.

site_title: Tide turns for executive condos
summary: The Singapore executive condominium (EC) market is expected to face a shortage of units in 2019 and 2020 due to a reduction in supply and an increase in demand. The oversupply of EC units in the market, which peaked at 4,007 units in 2016, has declined to 928 units as of August 2017. In contrast, EC sales have been increasing, with 2,550 and 3,999 units sold in 2015 and 2016, respectively. The shortage is attributed to the 15-month waiting rule for EC developers, which has led to a pent-up supply of units.

site_title: FDA selects 9 tech firms for product pre-clearance
summary: The FDA has selected 9 tech firms, including Apple, Fitbit, and Samsung, for a pilot program called Pre-Cert for Software Pilot, allowing them to get products pre-cleared for quality and safety without going through the standard approval process. The program aims to modernize the regulatory framework and speed up innovation in digital health. Companies participating will undergo audits of their software and facilities to ensure quality standards, with pre-certification potentially leading to a less stringent approval process or no FDA approval at all.

site_title: Microsoft CEO says tech's progress on gender equality 'good, but not sufficient'
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella stated that the tech industry has made progress on gender equality, but it's "good, but not sufficient" with more women working in Silicon Valley. Nadella acknowledged past mistakes, including suggesting women shouldn't push for pay raises, and emphasized the need for equal opportunity and recognition for women in tech. He also discussed the importance of immigration and competition, highlighting how immigrants have contributed to Microsoft's success.

site_title: Cheers, catcalls as Saudi ends ban on women driving
summary: Saudi Arabia has lifted its ban on women driving, allowing millions of women to take to the roads for the first time. The move, announced on September 27, 2017, was met with widespread celebration and relief among women, who had been restricted from driving since 1957. Many women took to the streets, calling it a "freedom day." The change has been hailed as a significant step towards equality and women's rights in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: New blood and old masters keep qipao dressmaking alive
summary: In Taiwan, a handful of tailors specialize in handmade qipao dressmaking, a traditional garment originating from China. Despite its popularity in the 1920s and 1970s, the qipao has largely fallen out of favor due to mass production and growing anti-China sentiment. However, a new generation of dressmakers, such as Lin Chin-te and Hung Chu-tsu, are working to preserve the craft and adapt it to modern life. With the rise of social media, clients like Lee Wei-fan are seeking traditional Asian styles, and a qipao club has been established to promote the dress as a daily wardrobe staple.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese qipao maker Lin Chin-te (right) working with students at his studio in Taipei. Mr Lin is worried that dressmakers will no longer learn his skills and takes on apprentices to pass down his knowhow.

site_title: Audi springs surprise lucky draw prize worth S$24,000
summary: Audi Singapore's general manager, Jeff Mannering, surprised the attendees of the Business Times Corporate Golf League by announcing a $24,000 lucky draw prize, which was originally intended for a hole-in-one Audi A5 car. The winner, Tanah Merah Country Club member Yeo Su-Lynn, was given the opportunity to drive Audi models in Germany with business class flights for two. Yeo, a regular participant in local events, described the prize as the biggest she had ever won.

site_title: Singapore's non-resident population falls by 1.6%, first drop in 14 years
summary: Singapore's non-resident population fell by 1.6% to 1.65 million, the first drop in 14 years, mainly due to a decline in Work Permit holders. The total population grew by 0.1% to 5.61 million, the slowest rate of growth since 2003. The citizen population continued to age, with the median age rising to 41.3 and the old-age support ratio falling to 4.4. Citizen births remained stable, while the permanent resident population remained stable at 527,000.

site_title: China money markets calm ahead of health check, holidays
summary: China's money markets remain calm ahead of a quarterly health check of banks and a National Day holiday, with benchmark repo rates rising 11.5 basis points to 3.92% and a seven-day repo rate increasing 60 basis points to 3.44%. Despite increased demand for cash, the central bank has refrained from injecting funds into the market, citing fiscal expenditure to counter maturing reverse repos. Economists attribute the market calm to increased government spending and the upcoming Communist Party Congress, where President Xi Jinping aims to strengthen his leadership.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific rebuts reports that it demolished historic facade in Sydney
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a Singapore-based property and hospitality group, has denied reports that it demolished a historic facade in Sydney's Potts Point without approval. The company claims that the City of Sydney Council had no issues with the removal of dilapidated timber and unstable masonry structures as instructed by the project's structural engineer. Roxy-Pacific is working with the council to reinstate the wall and faces a fine for carrying out works without development consent.

site_title: Europe: Banks drive stocks to 10-week high as "Trumpflation" hopes return
summary: European stocks reached a 10-week high on Wednesday, driven by a tax overhaul plan backed by President Donald Trump and a falling euro. Banks led the gains, with Banco Sabadell and Caixabank rising 6.9% and 4.4%, respectively. Mergers and acquisitions also fueled the market, with Alstom and Siemens shares rising 4.6% and 1.2%. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.4%, its highest level since July 20, as investors bet on "Trumpflation" and fiscal stimulus in the US.

site_title: UK Brexit bill set to grow as EU liabilities swell
summary: The UK Brexit bill may increase as EU liabilities grow, with pension costs rising 5% in 2016. The EU's liabilities increased by 4% and the UK is expected to pay a larger share of these costs. This could enrage parts of the UK government, adding to the already contentious pension costs. The Brexit bill remains a contentious issue, with the UK and EU officials negotiating the terms of Britain's divorce settlement.

site_title: Siemens to merge rail operations with French rival Alstom
summary: Siemens and Alstom, two European rail giants, agreed to merge their businesses in a deal aimed at countering competition from China. Siemens will transfer its rail business to Alstom, gaining a 50% stake in the new entity, Siemens Alstom. The combined company will have sales of 15.3 billion euros and will remain based in the Paris area. The deal is expected to close by the end of 2018 and will create a European transportation giant. The merger is seen as a strategic move to strengthen competition in the global rail market.

images.alt_text: Years of bitter rivalry between Alstom and Siemens created animosity in the past so a deal between them was unexpected until last week, when Bloomberg reported talks.

site_title: Tuas Power, ST Marine secure Jurong Island desalination project
summary: A consortium of Tuas Power and ST Marine, the marine arm of ST Engineering, has been selected by PUB to design, build, own, and operate a desalination plant on Jurong Island. The plant, Singapore's fifth, is expected to start operations in 2020 and will add 137,000 cubic meters of water a day to Singapore's water supply. The consortium offered the most competitive tariff among the three bidders, with a first-year price of S$0.91 per cubic meter.

site_title: Asia ex-Japan financial assets rise 15%: Allianz
summary: Asia's financial assets, excluding Japan, rose 15% in 2017, more than double the global average of 7.1%. Singapore topped the rankings per capita, with 125,645 euros per inhabitant, while China drove growth with a 17.9% increase. However, debt growth accelerated to 17% in Asia ex-Japan, pushing the debt ratio to 46.3%. The report also highlights a need for countries to develop financial systems and access to services to improve long-term savings and address the growing old-age dependency ratio.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Gold's durability in Asia driving global demand
summary: Global demand for gold is driven by its popularity as a portfolio diversifier, inflation and currency hedge, and safe haven asset. Central banks, particularly emerging markets, have been actively buying gold, with China and Russia being the most aggressive purchasers. However, gold still constitutes a small percentage of their total reserves compared to advanced economies. Private-sector demand in Asia, particularly in China and India, is also high, driven by cultural affinity and hedging against inflation and uncertainties. The rise of cryptocurrencies may reduce the allure for gold, but it is a more trusted asset and has a larger market size.

images.alt_text: Major policy changes and structural issues in Asian economies can potentially impact global gold demand.

site_title: Singapore's competitiveness: The good, the bad and the ugly
summary: Singapore's competitiveness slipped to third in the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Index, down from second place for five consecutive years. Despite ranking high in areas such as higher education and goods market efficiency, the country lags behind in innovation and business sophistication. Weak spots include restrictive labor regulations and a market size pillar ranking 35 out of 137 countries. However, Singapore is taking steps to address these issues, including forming a Committee on the Future Economy and pushing for digital economy initiatives.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Getting businesses on board SGSecure a timely move
summary: Singapore's business leaders rank "terrorist attacks" as their top concern, with 12,000 executives across 136 countries citing cyberattacks, asset bubbles, and data fraud as secondary risks. The country's high level of terror threat, fueled by the rise of ISIS in South-east Asia, has prompted the SGSecure movement to encourage businesses to prepare for a crisis. A new handbook, the SGSecure Guide for Workplaces, provides guidance on how companies can protect workers, protect the workplace, and build contingency plans.

site_title: Trump's plan calls for slashing taxes on businesses and wealthy
summary: US President Donald Trump unveiled a sweeping Republican tax overhaul plan that would slash taxes on businesses and the wealthy, but lacks details on how to fund the cuts without increasing the federal deficit. The plan would lower corporate income tax rates, cut taxes for "pass-through" businesses, and reduce the top individual tax rate. Despite concerns about the potential economic impact, some Republicans in Congress support the plan, which could be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: Four agreements inked to lift Singapore-Hungary economic ties
summary: Singapore and Hungary have signed four Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) to boost economic ties. The agreements cover trade, investment, technology, and training between businesses and trade promotion agencies in both countries. The MOUs were signed in the presence of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang, with the aim of deepening and broadening trade and investment relations. Trade between Singapore and Hungary reached S$1.14 billion in 2016, with Singapore companies already present in Hungary. The agreements are seen as a step towards increasing economic cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Yellen's hawkish speech gives banks a lift
summary: The Straits Times Index jumped 24.11 points to 3,236.15 on Wednesday, driven by large rebounds in the three banks, DBS, Nomura, and Mandarin Oriental. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's hawkish speech hinted at a December rate hike, boosting market confidence. DBS rose 1.8%, while Mandarin Oriental fell 28% after shelving hotel sale plans. Goldman Sachs upgraded SGX to "Buy" and State Street Global Exchange's Global Investor Confidence Index decreased, revealing diverging paths in investor confidence.

site_title: Billionaire Burkle sued by hotel partner over alleged 'coup'
summary: Billionaire Ron Burkle is being sued by his hotel development partner Andrew Zobler over allegations of trying to stage a coup to oust Zobler from the chief executive post of their boutique hotel venture, Sydell Group. Burkle allegedly sought to replace Zobler and install his own hand-picked CEO, threatening to "go thermonuclear" if he tried to get in the way. The lawsuit claims Burkle wants to use the company for his own benefit, occupying a luxury suite without paying and refusing to consent to favorable terms for his own stake in the underlying property.

site_title: S'pore has more US investments than China-Japan combined
summary: US multinational corporations have invested more in Singapore than in China and Japan combined, with a cumulative book value of US$846.68 billion in 2016, according to the US Department of Commerce. The majority of US investments in Singapore are in holding companies, manufacturing, and finance, with a significant presence in the electronics and manufacturing sectors. Reinvestment of earnings was the primary driver of growth in US investments in Singapore and China, with Singapore's manufacturing sector seeing a decline to second place to China in 2016.

site_title: Citibank and golf are natural partners
summary: Citibank's golf team finished sixth in the Business Times Corporate Golf League, despite strong performances in the third and fourth legs. The team, led by captain Chris Chew, suffered from tactical blunders in the final rounds, resulting in disappointing scores. Chew attributed the setback to the younger players not raising their game. Citibank has a long history of supporting the golf league and charity events, and the bank's team is known for their fun-loving and competitive spirit. The team will look to bounce back in future competitions.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental shares dive as Excelsior sale shelved
summary: Mandarin Oriental International has decided not to sell its Hong Kong hotel, The Excelsior, after a dissatisfactory tender process. The company's executive vice president, Richard Baker, stated that none of the proposals met their expectations, and they will continue to review options, including redevelopment into a commercial building. The decision is expected to be positive for business, and the hotel will continue to operate as usual. However, property market forces in Hong Kong may push the company to redevelop the site into office or retail space, following a common trend in the city.

site_title: Prospects of landed homes looking bright as sentiment improves
summary: The Singapore landed property market is showing signs of improvement, with demand picking up and prices stabilizing. Despite 15 consecutive quarters of price decline, the non-landed segment has started to stabilize, while landed volumes have seen a steady rise on the back of improving sentiments. The market is approaching an inflection point, with buyers lured back to the market as prices become more compelling. Long-term growth prospects remain underpinned by low existing and incoming supply, with demand expected to rise over the long term.

site_title: STT Connect gets highest certification for multi-tier cloud security standard
summary: STT Connect, a cloud enablement company, has achieved the highest certification for multi-tier cloud security standard, MTCS SS 584 at Level 3, the highest certification level. This certification meets the stringent cloud security requirements for enterprises handling high-impact information, such as medical and financial records. STT Connect has also received the ISO27001 certification, the international standard for information security management systems. This milestone puts the company on par with global cloud giants like Google and Amazon Web Services in terms of cloud security.

site_title: Luxury condos - developers banking on local demand
summary: Foreigners' buying interest in Singapore's luxury condos is uncertain, with recent demand from foreigners possibly unsustainable. Transactions in the Core Central Region (CCR) have been declining, with the share of foreigners in new and secondary sales falling from 48% in 2011 to 44% in 2016 and 2017. The removal of the Financial Investor Scheme (FIS) in 2012 and exogenous policy measures, such as China's foreign exchange controls, are believed to have contributed to this decline. Chinese buyers, who have seen a sharp rise in demand, are expected to decrease unless policy changes are made.

site_title: Singapore's electric car-sharing programme kicks off in December
summary: Singapore's electric car-sharing programme, BlueSG, will launch in December with 80 cars and 30 charging stations. The 10-year contract was awarded by the Land Transport Authority and Economic Development Board. The programme aims to roll out 1,000 electric cars and 500 charging stations by 2020, with 400 charging points available for public use. BlueSG, a subsidiary of the Bollore Group, has made Singapore its Asia-Pacific headquarters with 30 staff and plans to create 250 jobs by 2021.

site_title: Just 3% of a huge China US dollar bond bought by non-Asians
summary: China's largest US dollar bond sale, valued at $7.25 billion, saw 70% of purchases come from Chinese buyers, with 27% from the rest of Asia. The sale, priced just hours after China's sovereign rating was cut, demonstrates the dominance of local demand in Asia's booming offshore debt market. The market has seen record issuance of US$221 billion of US dollar bonds this year, with the pool of liquidity in Asia approaching US$1 trillion. This growth is driven by increasing regional ownership, with over 70% of Asian US dollar bonds taken up by Asian investors.

site_title: CBD office rents set to rise
summary: Office rental growth in Singapore's CBD is poised for recovery, driven by four factors: business confidence, growing demand from co-working and technology sectors, a dwindling business park supply, and a widening rental gap with Hong Kong. Major deals, such as Facebook's lease for 320,000 sq ft, and Microsoft's lease for 125,000 sq ft, have boosted occupancy rates. The net office absorption in the Downtown Core submarket increased to 409,000 sq ft in the first half of 2017, and the total Grade A CBD vacancy rate rose less than one percentage point.

site_title: Property technology: disruptor or enabler?
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizes the need for the country to become a "smart nation" through technology. The real estate industry is seeing a significant impact from "proptech" (property technology), which includes software, hardware, and blockchain. Proptech 2.0, the latest wave of technology advancement, is driven by increased venture capital investment, with $3 billion projected for 2017. Proptech software and hardware are changing the industry, offering virtual services, data analytics, and virtual tours. However, traditional third-party service providers, such as property agents, are being challenged by these new technologies. The winners in the industry will be those who can fill the gaps technology cannot and maximize opportunities.

site_title: Househunt September 2017
summary: Singapore's prime property market is facing increased competition with the Q3 wave of condo launches, which will test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. US mortgage rates have begun to climb after five weeks of declines. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Meanwhile, WeWork has secured new tenants at its 21 Collyer Quay, Suntec City location, filling more space post-bankruptcy. These developments indicate a shift in the global property market, with increasing competition and changing consumer demand.

site_title: HDB resale market abuzz with activity
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore has seen increased activity, with 6,001 transactions concluded in the second quarter of 2017, the highest number since Q3 2012. This is attributed to the attractive features of resale properties, including almost-zero cash downpayment and increased housing grants for first-time buyers. However, some newly married couples are opting for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats due to shorter waiting times, affordable prices, and more chances of securing a unit. Prices of resale properties are expected to be muted, with low growth of -1 to 2% by the end of 2017, while private properties are expected to increase by 10% in 2018.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) expands its investment mandate to include overseas income-producing real estate primary for data-center use, targeting gateway cities in Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the US. The new mandate will be effective from Oct 26, with the potential to form up to 20% of aggregate asset under management. KSH Holdings reported the start of the 10th Chinese National Youth Rock Climbing Championship at its Sino-Singapore Health City development project in China. OCBC Investment Research maintains a Hold target for KSH Holdings, citing a recent bonus share issuance.

site_title: When a cluttered counter obstructed cashless payments
summary: A Singaporean woman attempted to pay for a S$10 purchase using Apple Pay at a pharmacy, but was unable to do so due to a misplaced card reader. The issue was resolved when a colleague discovered the correct terminal, hidden under a pile of cartons. The incident highlights two deterrents to Singapore's cashless society: merchant confusion about e-payment solutions and the lack of a unified POS terminal, exacerbated by limited space on checkout counters.

images.alt_text: With only a S$100 note in my wallet and not wanting to deal with change, I decided to go with Apple Pay.

site_title: Higher land bids may fuel market recovery
summary: Higher land bids in Singapore's government land sales (GLS) programme in H1 2017 have reinforced the bullish outlook for the residential property market. The record number of bids and high prices for land parcels zoned for residential use have driven optimism. However, concerns remain about the disconnect between the market's optimism and Singapore's economic growth, which is expected to be between 1-3% in 2017. Despite this, the increasing number of taxpayers with annual incomes above $100,000 and the declining inventory of unsold homes suggest rising affluence and a potential for sustained growth.

site_title: Geo Energy relaunching US$ denominated bonds due 2022
summary: Geo Energy Resources Limited, an Indonesian coal mining group, is relaunching a US$ denominated bond offering due 2022 after cancelling it in July 2017 due to unfavourable market conditions. The fixed rate senior notes will be used to refinance the group's capital structure, repay advances, and fund potential coal mining asset acquisitions. Market conditions have improved, with the US Federal Reserve keeping interest rates steady, prompting Geo Energy to proceed with the offering. JP Morgan, Deutsche Bank, and other banks have been mandated as joint bookrunners and lead managers.

site_title: Decentralisation still a key long-term strategy
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority has called for public feedback on a master plan proposal for Jurong Lake District, aiming to transform it into Singapore's second Central Business District. Decentralisation remains a key long-term strategy, despite some firms locating in the CBD, as the gap between CBD and decentralised rents is expected to expand, offering more incentives for decentralisation.

site_title: Shaping business parks, mixed-use clusters for Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore aims to cater to Industry 4.0 companies with adaptive and high-specification industrial space. The government has been proactive in providing incentives and assistance to attract high-value industries, including aerospace, electronics, and biologics. Business parks, such as the Jurong Innovation District, offer integrated communities for businesses to collaborate and leverage synergies. Specialized industrial parks, like MedTech Park, provide tailored infrastructure for specific trades. The government also supports tech entrepreneurship through startup spaces and co-working platforms, with a focus on innovation and flexibility. This will enable companies to adapt to changing demands and needs in the Industry 4.0 era.

site_title: Customer satisfaction rises in transport sector
summary: Customer satisfaction in Singapore's transport sector rose in the second quarter, driven by gains in taxi services, public buses, and budget airlines. The overall land transport sector scored 67.8 points, up nearly one point from last year, with taxi services and public buses seeing increases in customer satisfaction levels. However, the MRT system sub-sector saw a decline of 1.6 points due to disruptions. Budget airlines, particularly Scoot, also saw improvements, with Scoot's score rising 3.61 points to 71.8 points.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesia's Freeport victory sets tone for foreign miners
summary: Indonesia secured a major victory in its negotiations with US giant Freeport-McMoRan Inc. over the Grasberg mine, one of the world's largest gold and copper mines. The framework agreement, reached in August, requires Freeport to cut its majority ownership from over 90% to below 50% in favor of Indonesian owners. The deal also includes measures such as increasing revenues to Indonesia, building a smelter, and investing up to $20 billion in the mine by 2031. The agreement is seen as a significant win for President Joko Widodo and a step towards wresting back control of mines from foreign companies.

site_title: Bombardier hits turbulence as US slaps duties on C Series jet
summary: The US Commerce Department imposed 220% import duties on Bombardier's C Series jet, citing improper subsidies, after a complaint from Boeing. This move threatens to upend Bombardier's planned deliveries to Delta Air Lines, which ordered 75 jets worth over $5 billion. The decision adds pressure on Bombardier CEO Alain Bellemare, who is trying to turn the company around after the C Series came in over budget and late. The US penalties could be reversed if the International Trade Commission determines Boeing wasn't injured by Bombardier's jet program.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages posts third annual loss of S$1.7m
summary: Global Yellow Pages reported its third consecutive annual net loss of S$1.7 million for FY17, down from S$12.4 million in FY16. Revenue increased by 6.3% to S$27.1 million. The company also reported an adjusted net profit of S$2.7 million. Global Yellow Pages was placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to its low trading price.

site_title: Venezuela craft brewers rare bright spot in crisis economy
summary: Venezuela's craft brewers, such as Social Club, are a rare bright spot in the country's economic crisis. Despite high prices, demand for their beer regularly outstrips supply, with most sold on weekends. The craft beer market is small but growing, with around 30 commercial breweries operating, and some have even won international brewing contests. However, challenges persist, including high costs due to imported ingredients and currency fluctuations, and winning over consumers accustomed to milder flavors.

site_title: Merkel welcomes 'a lot of material' from Macron on EU reform
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel welcomes French President Emmanuel Macron's EU reform speech, calling it "a lot of material" for debate. Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert says Berlin shares Macron's view that the EU needs reforms, particularly in areas such as defense, immigration, and social policy. However, Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) may block Macron's plan for a joint eurozone budget, with senior CDU member Eckhardt Rehberg arguing that existing funds can be used more effectively. Merkel's coalition government talks are expected to begin in mid-October.

site_title: Once worth US$3b, Taiwan's Kuomintang party now short of cash
summary: Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang party, once worth $3 billion, is struggling financially due to a government investigation. The party is seeking donations to pay its 300 staff members, with monthly personnel costs of NT$30 million (S$1.34 million). This is a significant decline from its former wealth, resulting from decades in power and subsequent losses. The party's financial woes come after losing control of the presidency and legislature last year.

site_title: Coming home to a shipping container
summary: A shipping container home has been built on a hillside in New York, featuring an expansive living room, kitchen, and small bathroom. The container's bright orange Corten steel exterior is visible in some areas, but the interior resembles a traditional timber-framed home. The unusual structure, two hours northwest of New York City, offers stunning views of the Catskill Mountains.

site_title: Twitter to let some users break 140-character limit in trial
summary: Twitter is introducing a trial with a 280-character limit for tweets, allowing users to send longer messages. The test, which includes all languages except Japanese, Korean, and Chinese, aims to encourage more engaging conversations and help the platform become a destination for live events and discussions. The change is part of Twitter's efforts to revitalize user growth and advertising revenue, which have been declining. The test is seen as a potential solution to the platform's struggles, with analysts noting that the 140-character limit was created for small displays and is no longer necessary.

site_title: Prada, Ferragamo unfashionably late to luxury industry's rebound
summary: Luxury fashion brands Prada, Ferragamo, and Tod's are struggling to rebound from a multi-year slowdown, with sales declining and profits falling. Italian rivals Gucci and Fendi, owned by French conglomerates LVMH and Kering, are leading the industry's upswing. Prada, Ferragamo, and Tod's are trying to catch up by investing in e-commerce and revamping their digital strategies, but analysts warn that smaller companies may struggle to keep pace with faster-growing rivals. Shares of the struggling brands have fallen significantly in the past six months.

site_title: GLP moves investment in Qingdao, Tianjin, to assets in Chongqing, Shenyang
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has shifted an investment in Qingdao and Tianjin to assets in Chongqing and Shenyang. Indirect subsidiaries CLH and China Kunpeng Infrastructure sold 30% stakes in Hangzhou Transfar for 162.5 million yuan, acquiring 40% interest in Hangzhou Puxin Logistics Facilities Co, which owns Chongqing and Shenyang Transfar Logistics Bases. The transactions are expected to have no material impact on GLP's net tangible asset and earnings per share in the year ending March 2018.

site_title: US: Wall Street pares gains after Trump outlines tax plan
summary: US stocks pared gains after President Donald Trump's administration outlined a tax plan that includes slashing corporate tax rates to 20%, a new 25% tax rate for pass-through businesses, and a reduced top income tax rate to 35%. The plan aims to pay for tax cuts without expanding the federal deficit, but investors remain cautious, awaiting details on bipartisan support. Despite this, major indexes rose, with the Dow up 0.06% and the Nasdaq Composite up 0.5%.

site_title: US dollar climbs on hopes of fiscal reforms
summary: The US dollar rose half a percent against a broad basket of currencies on Wednesday, driven by optimism over US fiscal reforms and hawkish comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen. Futures markets indicate a 70% likelihood of a US rate hike by December, compared to less than 20% previously. The Trump administration's potential tax plan could boost the dollar if it leads to sustained 3% US growth. Investors are scrambling to cover short dollar bets, with bearish positions against the dollar at their highest since January 2013.

site_title: Many recipes but Singapore's cashless appetite still not sated
summary: Singapore's cashless society is hindered by too many e-payment players, with competition improving user experience but lacking standardization. The market is saturated with DBS PayLah!, GrabPay, Liquid Pay, NetsPay, and RazerPay, with new players entering the scene. Observers suggest that Singapore needs a standardized Quick Response (QR) code or Point-of-Sale (POS) terminal to achieve a seamless cashless experience, rather than relying on multiple e-wallets.

site_title: Increasing agility as a matter of urgency
summary: The world is rapidly changing due to globalisation, digitalisation, and increasing attention on sustainability, making business environments more challenging. The lifespan of successful companies is declining, with Innosight predicting an average lifespan of 14 years by 2026. To stay relevant, companies must adopt agile organisational structures and empower their teams, fostering an entrepreneurial culture with autonomy and authority to drive changes. This requires investing in promising startups and leveraging their expertise in new technologies and business models, while also investing in digital training and upskilling for employees to navigate the digital world.

site_title: Nike declines after athletic giant gives bleak US outlook
summary: Nike shares declined after the company reported a bleak outlook for its US operations, with North American sales expected to decline again this quarter. The slump is attributed to a three percent dip in the region last quarter and a decline in Converse business. However, Nike's international sales, particularly in China, helped the company post a profit that topped estimates. The company's reliance on overseas growth is expected to continue.

site_title: Scoot key for SIA group if long-haul, low-cost movement takes off
summary: Norwegian will launch direct budget flights from London to Singapore, starting with four weekly services, on Thursday, entering a market dominated by Singapore Airlines (SIA) and British Airways. The move is seen as a threat to SIA's long-haul network, particularly its low-cost arm Scoot. Norwegian's entry could effectively double the number of airlines serving the direct Singapore-London route. Analysts predict potential expansion to other European hubs, posing a challenge to SIA and other airlines operating in the long-haul, low-cost sector.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore needs to reinvent retail scene
summary: Singapore's retail scene faces challenges as other Asian cities, such as Kuala Lumpur, Beijing, and Shanghai, catch up. Despite positive retail sales data, weak sentiment persists due to global economic and political uncertainties. However, Singapore's tourism industry remains a key pillar, supporting the retail sector. According to a study by Knight Frank, Hong Kong and Singapore are the top two retail destinations in Asia, but Singapore needs to reinvent its retail scene to strengthen its position. The city-state can capitalize on its strengths, uniqueness, and experiential factor, such as Jewel Changi Airport and Funan DigitaLife Mall, to attract tourists and retailers.

site_title: Trump's Le Cirque fundraiser pulls in US$5m for GOP
summary: US President Donald Trump helped raise an estimated $5 million for Republicans at a private fundraiser at New York's Le Cirque restaurant. The event, attended by around 150 people, including billionaires and real-estate tycoons, featured a private roundtable with the president and raised tickets ranging from $35,000 to $100,000. The fundraiser comes as Republicans gear up for the 2018 midterm elections, with Trump's tax plan expected to be unveiled soon.

site_title: UBS offices in Germany searched amid client tax fraud probe
summary: Prosecutors in Germany conducted searches at UBS offices in connection with an investigation into suspected tax fraud by around 2,000 clients. The searches involved around 130 investigators and are part of a broader probe into tax evasion cases across Europe. UBS has cooperated with authorities and previously settled a similar investigation in 2014 by paying 302 million euros. The Swiss bank has been involved in numerous tax evasion cases to help governments track hidden cash.

site_title: US Commerce Secretary warns of 'lopsided' trade relationship with China
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross warned of a "lopsided" trade relationship with China, calling for a dramatic shift in the countries' trade dynamics. During a visit to Beijing, Ross expressed concerns over the imbalance of trade and investment relations, intellectual property protection, and tariffs. He also criticized China's "Made in China 2025" policy, which aims to make the country self-sufficient in high-tech industries by 2025. Ross aims to narrow the US-China trade deficit by increasing US exports to China and promoting fair market access for US companies.

site_title: UBS chairman not concerned about weakened Merkel
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber says German Chancellor Angela Merkel's slim majority after federal elections will lead to more inward-looking policies, but he's not concerned. Merkel is struggling to form a coalition government. Weber believes this will result in France taking the lead in international collaboration, offsetting Merkel's weakened stance.

site_title: A luxury building boom is transforming Montreal
summary: A luxury building boom is transforming Montreal, driven by an increase in businesses and luxury hotels. The Four Seasons Hotel and Private Residences Montreal, a $200 million project, is part of the city's revitalization. After years of political instability, Montreal has stabilized, attracting businesses and leisure visitors, including Facebook's AI research lab and Google's similar facility. New office space, luxury hotels, and amenities have emerged, with the Golden Square Mile seeing a surge in visitors, reaching 11.2 million tourists by the end of 2017.

site_title: Declout appoints liquidator for Netipay
summary: Declout appoints Chiang Kar Fong Dorothy as liquidator for Netipay Pte Ltd, a dormant subsidiary since Jan 1, 2015, as part of its voluntary winding-up proceedings. Netipay was owned by Declout through its wholly-owned subsidiary Corous360. The liquidation process commenced on Wednesday, following a trading close announcement.

site_title: More CPF investors beat guranteed risk-free returns in fiscal 2016
summary: In fiscal 2016, 78% of CPF investors in Singapore outperformed the guaranteed 2.5% interest rate, with 441,000 members achieving profits larger than 2.5%. This marked an improvement from the previous year, when only 27% of investors made such profits. The CPF Board has revised its methodology to better reflect members' total investment portfolio performance, excluding those with no investments and factoring in unrealized gains. The changes aim to provide a more accurate representation of members' long-term investment performance.

site_title: Getting Indonesia's slowing economy back on track
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is facing challenges in reshaping his country's economy, which has been slowing down. Despite his initial popularity and ability to consolidate power, his electability will depend on the economy's trajectory. Widodo's government must navigate vested interests and a business environment that has been hostile to new policies. His ratings in popularity polls indicate he could win a second term, but the economy's performance will be crucial in determining his success.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 1.35 points lower at 1,764.24 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 2.209 billion lots worth RM2.156 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 401 to 376.

site_title: ValueMax offers S$3.58m for Sengkang Pawnshop
summary: VALUEMAX Group has entered into a share purchase agreement to acquire Sengkang Pawnshop Pte Ltd for S$3.58 million, with the target becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary. The acquisition is in line with ValueMax's expansion strategy and aims to provide an additional revenue stream. The completion of the acquisition is conditional upon approval from the Registrar of Pawnbrokers.

site_title: Trump's plan calls for slashing taxes on businesses, the wealthy
