The initiative comes as the International Maritime Organization sets a 0.5% global sulphur cap on marine fuels, set to take effect in 2020, and plans to lower carbon emissions for shipping. The trial is part of Singapore's efforts to provide cleaner alternative sources of fuel to the global shipping industry.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO's focus is on 38 leased planes in Air Berlin battle
summary: Lufthansa CEO Thomas Klautau expressed interest in acquiring up to 80 planes from Air Berlin, with a focus on securing the 38 planes the airline leases. A creditor committee is set to discuss offers for Air Berlin, which filed for insolvency in August after Etihad withdrew funding. Lufthansa is competing with other airlines, including easyJet and Condor, for Air Berlin's Niki short-haul business.

site_title: Citigroup upbeat on commodities over the rest of the year
summary: Citigroup expects commodities to perform strongly for the rest of 2017, driven by gains in metals such as aluminum and oil. The bank attributes the growth to China's push for metals and bulks, stronger yuan, and environmental policies. Citigroup forecasts Brent oil to reach $58 a barrel by the end of 2017 and $54 in 2018, with West Texas Intermediate expected to reach $50 next year. The bank's bullish stance on commodities has been consistent, with predictions of a "sterling performance" for raw materials.

site_title: EU oversight plan draws fire from financial firms and consumers alike
summary: The European Union has proposed a plan to strengthen its oversight of financial firms, but it has drawn criticism from industry and consumer groups. The plan aims to end national supervision of some financial industries and increase controls over foreign firms, but critics argue it could hurt businesses, particularly those based in the UK and US. Consumer groups say the EU's proposed approach is too timid, while industry groups see it as a form of protectionism. The EU's vice president has defended the plan, stating that it will allow for greater intervention in national markets to protect savers.

site_title: IMF says Macron reforms crucial for French growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that French President Emmanuel Macron's reforms are crucial for boosting the country's growth. The IMF projects 1.6% growth in France's GDP this year and 1.8% in 2018, but warned that implementation of the reform agenda will be the key challenge. The reforms, which include labor market and fiscal overhaul, are necessary to reduce unemployment and improve competitiveness. However, protests against the labor code overhaul have hindered progress, and the IMF has recommended measures to tackle France's high long-term structural unemployment.

site_title: Money talks and talent walks in Google's HTC buy
summary: Google has agreed to buy part of HTC Corp's engineering and design teams for $1.1 billion, taking on 2,000 employees who worked on the Pixel phone. This move aims to bolster Google's nascent hardware business and showcase the best features of the Android software. The acquisition is part of Google's efforts to expand its capabilities in hardware design and engineering.

site_title: S&P cuts China's credit rating, citing increasing economic, financial risks
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded China's long-term sovereign credit rating to A+ from AA-, citing increasing economic and financial risks due to rapid credit growth. The downgrade follows Moody's Investors Service's similar demotion in May and comes ahead of a key Communist Party Congress. S&P sees credit growth remaining high, increasing financial risks in the next two to three years. The stable outlook suggests efforts by the government to reduce corporate leverage could stabilize financial risks in the medium-term.

site_title: Cracks showing in The Glass Castle
summary: A film adaptation of Jeannette Walls' memoir "The Glass Castle" tells the story of her dysfunctional family, featuring a charismatic but irresponsible father and a pathetically deluded mother. The clan's nomadic lifestyle and lack of basic necessities lead to neglect and abuse of the children. The film follows Jeannette's journey from her teenage years to adulthood, as she confronts her past and reconciles with her parents at their deathbed. Despite its commendable performances and unsparing detailing of the family's misery, the film's redemptive tone is seen as sentimental and betraying the true horror of the story.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end flat
summary: Hong Kong shares ended flat on Thursday, with the Hang Seng index falling 0.1% to 28,110.33 points, as a stronger dollar and revived expectations of a US rate hike countered gains in financial and consumer stocks. The Federal Reserve announced it would start shrinking its balance sheet next month and signal one more rate hike later this year.

site_title: Del Monte unit to sell vegetable business to McCall Farms for US$55 million
summary: Del Monte Foods' US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods (DMF), has agreed to sell its Sager Creek vegetable business to McCall Farms for US$55 million. The Sager Creek business produces specialty vegetables for the food service and retail markets, and will cease operations at one production facility in Siloam Springs, Arkansas, with DMF continuing to serve customers until early 2018. The sale allows DMF to focus on its core business and innovation, according to Chief Operating Officer David Meyers.

site_title: ASL Marine on track with partial notes redemption
summary: ASL Marine Holdings reported it is on track to meet a mandatory partial principal redemption of S$1.25 million of outstanding notes, with the redemption set to occur on October 2, 2017. This is in addition to an earlier announcement of a separate redemption of S$2.5 million for the Series 6 notes issued. The company's pledge to deliver on the partial principal redemptions was made in exchange for securing consent to extend the maturity of the two tranches of notes from noteholders.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open, London flat
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index climbing 0.3% to 12,601.95 points and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.3% to 5,259.02 points. London's FTSE 100 index remained flat. The increases were driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. The rally came despite ongoing US interest rate concerns and uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Tat Hong says in ongoing talks on potential transactions, appoints adviser
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane specialist, halted trading after its shares surged 5.195% due to potential transaction discussions. The company appointed Rippledot Capital Advisers as its financial adviser and stated that discussions are ongoing with no certainty of a transaction. Tat Hong reported a net loss of S$5.086 million in the first fiscal quarter, but remains cautiously optimistic about the improving market and economic outlook in Australia and China.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Global trade 'rebounds strongly' in first half of 2017: WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has upgraded its forecast for global trade growth in 2017 to 3.6%, up from 2.4%, due to stronger-than-expected demand for merchandise in Asia and North America. This represents a substantial improvement from the 1.3% increase in 2016. The growth is attributed to a rebound in trade, which had been sluggish in 2016.

site_title: Volvo rolls out compact SUV in latest upmarket shift under Geely
summary: Volvo has launched its first compact SUV, the XC40, as part of its efforts to shift its line-up to more upmarket models under Chinese ownership. The XC40, produced in Belgium, competes with Audi Q3, BMW X1, and Mercedes GLA, and is expected to appeal to city dwellers seeking a high driving position, practicality, and stylish looks. Volvo aims to sell around 100,000 units next year, which would edge the company closer to its medium-term sales target of 800,000 cars.

site_title: US tech giants in EU sights as tax clampdown takes shape
summary: The European Commission is proposing new tax rules for digital companies, including US tech giants, to increase revenue for the EU. The current tax system was designed for traditional economies and doesn't capture companies' activities based on intangible assets and data. EU finance ministers previously discussed adapting tax policy to address global tech companies, which pay a 10.1% average tax rate compared to 23.3% for traditional firms. The commission is considering various options to tax digital companies, aiming to close the tax gap and ensure fair contribution to public coffers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SINGAPORE'S GIC-backed JV to acquire Sheraton Grande Tokyo Bay Hotel for US$909.1m. Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) buys Asia Square Tower 2 for S$2.09b, making it Singapore's second largest office tower sale. AIA Group buys Australian insurer for S$4.1b. Darco and InfraCo Asia team up on S$50m water treatment projects in Vietnam. Tat Hong Holdings is in talks on potential transactions. The Land Transport Authority forms a new unit to implement the KL-Singapore High Speed Rail project.

site_title: Advertising ghosts reappear in Sydney as buildings come down
summary: Historic advertisements are reappearing on Sydney buildings as they are demolished, offering a glimpse into the city's past. Old banners from Australian brands, including Peters Ice Cream and Shell Oil, dating back to the 19th and early-20th centuries, are being uncovered. The re-emergence of these advertisements serves as a reminder of Sydney's history and evolution over time, with Sydney historian Lisa Murray stating that it's a "nice to sometimes be reminded of our history and reflect on how they change over time."

site_title: Eurozone growth gaining momentum but inflation subdued: ECB Bulletin
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) stated that Eurozone economic growth is gaining momentum, with a decline in unemployment rates, but inflation remains subdued. The firming of the euro poses a risk to inflation, requiring continued monitoring. The ECB left its monetary policy unchanged but signaled a possible "recalibration" in the next month, indicating a potential reduction in stimulus. Despite strong growth, labor market slack remains elevated in many eurozone markets.

site_title: Tracie Pang brings Tony-winning musical to local stage
summary: Tracie Pang's theatre company Pangdemonium brings the Tony-winning musical "Fun Home" to the local stage, adapting the 2006 graphic memoir by Alison Bechdel. The show, which won five Tony awards in 2015, tells the coming-of-age story of a young woman discovering the secrets of her eccentric father. Despite its dark themes, the musical is a heart-wrenching and joyful story of self-acceptance and empowerment. The production, which features child actors and a R18 rating, aims to stimulate audiences to think outside their comfort zones and challenge their perspectives.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The acclaimed musical Fun Home promises an unusual night at the theatre, with a cast led by Nikki Muller (centre).

"I want to get something out of the theatre experience that is much more than just 'easy' entertainment. I want to be stimulated to think outside of my comfort zone, and to be provoked to feel a little uncomfortable..." - Tracie Pang.

site_title: BOJ masters yield curve but inflation failure draws critics
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy unchanged, keeping the 10-year bond yield around zero percent, despite failing to spur inflation and criticism from former officials. The economy is experiencing its longest expansion since 2006, but inflation remains stuck at 0.5%, just a quarter of the BOJ's two percent target. The central bank's yield-curve control policy has been successful in managing spending, but its impact on inflation is questioned, with investors expecting annual inflation to average just 0.31% over the next five years.

site_title: Motor racing: Mexican F1 track undamaged by quake, race to go ahead
summary: Mexican F1 track undamaged by 7.1 magnitude earthquake, with the Formula One Mexican Grand Prix scheduled to go ahead on October 29. The Hermanos Rodriguez circuit in Mexico City has been inspected twice and deemed safe, with organizers and officials expressing no concern about facilities. The government-backed event is expected to attract 135,000 spectators, including 30% foreigners, and will proceed as planned despite the devastating earthquake that killed over 200 people and left 52 buildings collapsed.

site_title: India considering 500b rupee stimulus spending in 2017/18 - govt sources
summary: India's government is considering loosening its fiscal deficit target to spend an additional 500 billion rupees (S$10.5 billion) in the 2017/18 financial year to revive economic growth, which hit a three-year low of 5.7% in the second quarter. The plan aims to boost economic growth, which Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the government was looking to lift. The move is still to be made public.

site_title: Builders doubt NZ election will resolve housing crunch
summary: New Zealand builders doubt the country's upcoming election will resolve the housing crunch, despite promises from both the National Party and Labour to address the issue. The housing shortage, driven by record immigration, has led to a 50-60% increase in national housing prices and almost doubling in Auckland, with 14,000 new homes needed annually for three decades to accommodate the population growth. Builders cite a labour shortage and infrastructure constraints as major obstacles to resolving the issue, with no clear solution in sight regardless of the party's victory.

site_title: Biggest cocoa growers seek larger slice of chocolate profits
summary: West Africa's top cocoa-growing nations, Ghana and Ivory Coast, aim to increase their share of chocolate profits by processing more cocoa themselves. The two countries, accounting for 60% of global cocoa output, earned only 5.5% of the $100 billion value chain in 2015. Ghanaian President Nana Akufo-Addo proposes joint efforts to market cocoa better and develop new markets, with Ivory Coast aiming to process 50% of its cocoa by 2020. The goal is to become competitive in producing higher-end products to increase value extraction from the raw material.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed slightly higher on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen, which lifted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.18%, while the Topix index inched up 0.05%. Toshiba's memory chip business sale for $18 billion, however, weighed on the market, with the company's stock retreating. Despite this, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: ERA Realty to relist as APAC Realty; IPO at 66 Singapore cents per share
summary: ERA Realty Network, Singapore's second-largest property agency, is relisting as APAC Realty and launching an initial public offering (IPO) at 66 Singapore cents per share. The company aims to channel more resources into its Asia-Pacific network post-listing. CEO Jack Chua plans to boost the network, ahead of a perceived property upcycle.

site_title: GIC-backed JV to buy Sheraton Grande Tokyo Bay Hotel for US$909.1m
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will acquire the Sheraton Grande Tokyo Bay Hotel through a joint venture with Invincible Investment Corporation for approximately $909.1 million. GIC will own a 51% majority stake in the 1,016-room hotel, built in 1988 and adjacent to Tokyo Disney Resort. The acquisition is seen as a long-term investment opportunity, with GIC confident in the continued growth and demand in Japan. The partnership aims to enhance the hotel and support its growth, marking GIC's continued investment in Japan for over 20 years.

site_title: Hot stock: Tat Hong halts trading after share price surged more than 5%
summary: Trading in Tat Hong Holdings was halted after the company's share price surged over 5% to S$0.405 per share. The crane specialist reported a net loss of S$5.086 million in its fiscal first quarter, despite a 1% revenue growth to S$118.329 million. Tat Hong expressed cautious optimism about the improving market and economic outlook, particularly in Australia and China, where it expects to continue its fleet rationalisation activities and capitalize on its strong presence.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Thai activists ordered to pay US$16m for occupying airports
summary: Thirteen Thai activists from the People's Alliance for Democracy were ordered to pay US$16 million in compensation for occupying Bangkok's two main international airports in 2008. The protesters, who shut down the airports for over a week, disrupted hundreds of flights and stranded hundreds of thousands of travelers. The Supreme Court ruled that the activists must pay the money, plus interest, to the Airports of Thailand operator.

site_title: New Zealand calls in navy to beat jet fuel shortage before vote
summary: New Zealand's government has deployed a navy vessel to ferry diesel fuel around the country amid a days-long fuel shortage that has disrupted air travel in Auckland ahead of the national election. The ship will transport up to 4.8 million litres of diesel to support industry efforts to provide jet fuel to the crisis-hit airport. The shortage has cancelled over 120 flights, with the government and industry taking measures to contain the crisis, including fuel rationing and military assistance. The ruling National Party is battling with the Labour Party to form the next government.

site_title: Japanese brewer Asahi ready to spend "billions of dollars" on acquisitions
summary: Asahi Group Holdings Ltd is prepared to spend "billions of dollars" on acquisitions, following its recent US$11 billion purchase of European beer brands from Anheuser-Busch InBev NV. President Akiyoshi Koji prioritizes "bolt-on" acquisitions to boost European businesses, but declined to comment on specific targets. The company is also studying Vietnam's plan to sell a majority stake in beer makers Sabeco and Habeco, as it assesses potential opportunities in the attractive Asian growth market.

site_title: Merkel's party dips in poll but still way ahead before Sunday vote
summary: Angela Merkel's conservative party dropped one percentage point in a poll released Thursday, three days before the German election, with her main opponent, the Social Democrats, remaining unchanged at 22%. The far-right Alternative for Germany rose to 10%, while the Greens and pro-business parties remained at 8% and 9% respectively. The poll also showed 34% of voters are undecided or non-voters, a higher rate than the last election four years ago. Merkel's party is still expected to win a fourth term, but the result may be less certain than initially thought.

site_title: China may let insurance funds take part in firms' debt-to-equity swaps
summary: China is considering allowing insurance funds to participate in debt-to-equity swaps of distressed firms, with the goal of stabilizing the financial market. Insurance regulator Jia Biao also supports mixed ownership reforms in state-owned firms and plans to increase supervision of insurance funds. These moves aim to improve the financial stability of the country's economy, which is expected to slow down. The regulator's decisions are part of efforts to address the challenges posed by the country's economic slowdown.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares inch down on Fed decision; Samsung at record high
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% to 1,132.7 won per US dollar due to the Federal Reserve's decision to trim its portfolio and signal another rate hike by year-end. However, Seoul stocks rose, with Samsung Electronics reaching a record high of 2,640,000 won and SK Hynix closing 3% higher. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) ended 0.2% lower at 2,406.50 points.

site_title: China hits back at US over trade, says unilateralism is "unprecedented challenge"
summary: China responded to US criticism of its trade practices, calling unilateralism an unprecedented challenge to global trade. Commerce Minister Gao Feng stated that foreign and domestic firms are treated equally, and foreign firms should not have concerns about investing in China. The US has launched trade investigations under WTO statutes, citing China's intellectual property practices as a threat to the global trading system. China hopes the European Union will maintain an open market, and both sides aim to promote free trade and liberalize global investment.

site_title: Apple shares slip on smartwatch reviews
summary: Apple shares declined 1.68% on Wednesday following mixed reviews of its latest smartwatch, the Apple Watch Series 3, which struggled to connect to mobile networks. The smartwatch's ability to make calls and use functions without a smartphone was also questioned. Additionally, pre-orders for the iPhone 8 models lagged behind those of the previous generation, possibly due to interest in the upcoming iPhone X model. Apple's stock ended the day at $156.07.

site_title: Certis CISCO's unit to provide cyber security for Google Cloud Platform
summary: Singapore-based managed security services provider Quann has become a Google Cloud Platform Services Partner, offering cyber security services such as security architecture assessments, data penetration testing, and incident response management. Quann will also collaborate with Google on cyber security threat analytics using Google's analytics engine and technologies. This partnership aims to address the growing concern of security in the Asia-Pacific region as businesses move towards digitalization.

site_title: Changi Airport sees 7% rise in passenger movements in August
summary: Changi Airport reported a 7.0% increase in passenger movements to 5.27 million in August 2017, driven by growth in air travel to South Asia, Africa, and the Americas. Strong performance was seen in routes to India, China, and Malaysia. Airfreight throughput rose 10.7% to 180,590 tonnes, while aircraft movements increased 4.9% to 31,750 landings and takeoffs.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia's RBA head says rates will more likely go up than down
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe stated that interest rates in the country are more likely to rise than fall, despite staying at record lows due to weak inflation. Lowe said it's difficult to see inflation reaching 2.5% anytime soon, indicating that rates will remain low for some time.

site_title: Opening of reconstructed OCBC building in Xiamen a symbol of enduring ties between S'pore and China: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat marked the opening of a reconstructed OCBC building in Xiamen as a symbol of the enduring ties between Singapore and China. The bank has a long history in China, opening before the country became a key global investment destination. The China-Singapore relationship, established 35 years ago, has stood the test of time, similar to OCBC's presence in China.

site_title: eSports battle for a knockout at Tokyo game show
summary: Top eSports players competed in Tokyo's game show, marking eSports' first time taking center stage at the annual event. The show drew 250,000 mostly male visitors and featured games like Street Fighter V and virtual reality operators. eSports champions can earn millions in prize money, with the sport expected to become a full medal sport at the 2022 Asian Games. Industry insiders believe the event could boost eSports in Japan, where operating restrictions have held back growth, and the sport may eventually gain Olympic status.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip in first few minutes
summary: Hong Kong shares opened lower on Thursday, September 21, 2017, after the Federal Reserve announced plans to wind down crisis-era stimulus and hinted at another interest rate hike next month. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.13%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.04%. This move followed a global trend of lower stock markets amid uncertainty over US-China trade relations.

site_title: Australia shares end at 7.5 month low; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest in over seven months, falling 0.9% to 5,655.4, due to the US Federal Reserve's suggestion of a third interest hike in December and rising global interest rates. Material stocks, such as BHP Billiton and Newcrest Mining, were heavily weighted on the index. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.3% to 7,795.41, driven by a decline in the construction sector.

site_title: Malaysia arrests seven suspected of involvement with Abu Sayyaf militant group
summary: Malaysia has arrested seven suspected members of the Abu Sayyaf militant group, who worked as security guards in Kuala Lumpur and surrounding areas. The suspects, all Philippine men, are believed to have been involved in activities with the group, which has pledged loyalty to Islamic State. The arrests were made based on information received after authorities thwarted a plan to stage an attack at the Southeast Asian Games in Kuala Lumpur. This brings the total number of suspected Abu Sayyaf links in Malaysia to over 300 since 2013.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed, yen falls as Fed, BOJ decide
summary: Asian stocks were mixed, with the yen falling to a two-month low as the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan announced diverging monetary policies. The US dollar extended gains against major peers, while Japan's Topix index pared gains. The US central bank set an October start for shrinking its balance sheet and maintained a forecast for another rate increase this year, while the BOJ kept its monetary stimulus unchanged. Oil prices held above $50 a barrel, while gold and base metals tumbled.

site_title: Citigroup hails outlook for commodities over rest of year
summary: Citigroup expects a strong performance for commodities, particularly metals, in the remainder of 2017, driven by gains in aluminum and a stronger yuan in China. Oil is also forecast to end the year on a high, with Brent trading at US$58 a barrel in the fourth quarter and US$54 in 2018. The bank attributes this optimism to supply-demand fundamentals trending in-line with its expectations and falling oil inventories.

site_title: Landmark EU, Canada trade deal enters into force
summary: A landmark free trade deal between the European Union and Canada, known as the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (Ceta), entered into force on September 21, 2017, despite opposition from activists concerned about environmental and health impacts. The EU hailed the deal as one of its most ambitious, setting a new standard for future deals, and observers see it as a model for future ties between Britain and the EU after Brexit. The pact eliminates customs duties on 98% of products, affecting 510 million European consumers and 35 million Canadians.

site_title: Local brands vague about palm oil usage, among other issues: WWF report
summary: A World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) report found that two-thirds of local brands in Singapore are vague about their palm oil usage, with nearly eight in ten not sourcing sustainable palm oil. Only three local brands have public commitments on palm oil use, compared to 80% of global brands. The report highlights obstacles such as cost and capacity issues, but notes that sustainable palm oil options are available at a minimal price increase. WWF-Singapore has launched a campaign to demonstrate consumer demand for sustainable palm oil, with several brands committing to source sustainable palm oil.

site_title: New Zealand election too close to call
summary: New Zealand is heading to the polls in a closely contested election, with conservative Prime Minister Bill English battling charismatic young rival Jacinda Ardern. The election is expected to be the closest since 2005, with opinion polls swinging wildly between the two leaders. Ardern's Labour party has seen a significant 20-point popularity boost, and she is bidding to become the youngest prime minister since 1856. The outcome is uncertain, with Winston Peters, leader of New Zealand First, waiting in the wings to potentially play kingmaker.

site_title: HKD's not so boring now as options top US$100b
summary: Hong Kong's dollar is experiencing its highest level of swings in six months, with notional options value reaching $103 billion. The currency's volatility has increased due to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's surprise cash-draining measures and interest-rate expectations in the US. Despite the pegged exchange rate, forecasters predict volatility will remain high, with the currency forecast to weaken further.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip after Fed's decision; tech shares rally
summary: The South Korean won fell to a one-week low, dropping 0.4% to 1,132.6 against the US dollar, following the Federal Reserve's decision to reduce its portfolio and signal a possible rate hike by year-end. Seoul shares slipped 0.2% to 2,408.54 points, with tech shares rallying despite foreign investors selling Kospi shares. Gains for Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix were driven by expectations of quarterly earnings exceeding forecasts, while robust exports data lifted investor sentiment.

site_title: Darco, InfraCo Asia team up for S$50m water treatment projects in Vietnam
summary: Darco Water Technologies and InfraCo Asia Development have partnered for S$50 million municipal water treatment projects in Vietnam. The 50-year concession projects will provide up to 62,000 cubic meters of water for 500,000 residents. This marks Darco's first DBOO model in Vietnam, shifting to asset ownership for overseas growth. The first project in Ben Tre province will begin construction in Q4 2017, with the others starting in 2018.

site_title: New protests as France set to enshrine labour reforms
summary: French unions stage new protests Thursday against a planned overhaul of the country's labour code, which President Emmanuel Macron is expected to sign into law. The protests, called by the CGT and Solidaires unions, object to new powers given to employers and changes to firing staff costs. Despite opposition, Macron's government believes it has the upper hand and that the protest movement has been weakening for years, with some critics viewing the method as authoritarian. The reforms aim to boost competitiveness and reduce unemployment, but public opinion is divided.

site_title: New Zealand election surprise may shake Australia's stock market
summary: New Zealand is set to hold a surprise election, which may impact Australia's stock market due to significant revenue exposure between the two countries. About 43% of Australian companies in the S&P/ASX 200 benchmark derive revenue from New Zealand, including big four banks. A Labour Party victory, which could alter migration, taxation, and housing policies, may hurt home prices in New Zealand and have implications for Australian politics. A weaker New Zealand dollar could also negatively affect Australian bank profits.

site_title: Tencent enters old-school finance with stake in China's CICC
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social media firm, has invested HK$2.9 billion (S$500.3 million) in CICC International Capital Corp., a move to expand its wealth management business. The investment will allow CICC to utilize big data and financial technology, while Tencent gains a 5% stake in the investment bank. The partnership aims to provide personalized and diversified wealth management products and services to customers. This move marks Tencent's entry into traditional finance, as the company seeks to displace Ant Financial's dominance in mobile payments and money management.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social media firm, is entering the traditional finance industry by investing in CICC International Capital Corp., a move that may help the investment bank's expansion in wealth management.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars give ground to US dollar, jump on yen
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar, while surging yields at home boosted the currencies' value against the yen and Swiss franc. The Australian dollar retreated to US$0.8010, and the kiwi eased to US$0.7333, after the US Federal Reserve stuck with plans to hike rates in December. Strong yields on Australian and New Zealand bonds made the currencies attractive to carry trade investors, with the Aussie reaching a near two-year high against the yen and the kiwi surging to 82.50 yen.

site_title: QBE prices US$300m fixed rate senior notes due 2023
summary: QBE Insurance Group priced a US$300 million fixed rate senior note due 2023, maturing May 25, 2023, with a 3% annual interest rate. The notes are expected to be rated A- by Standard & Poor's. Settlement and issue are scheduled for September 25, 2017.

site_title: CCT to buy Asia Square Tower 2 for S$2.09b
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) is buying Asia Square Tower 2 from BlackRock Asia Property Fund III L.P. for S$2.09 billion, or S$2,689 per square foot, making it Singapore's second-largest office tower sale in history. The 46-storey building, which includes The Westin Singapore and a retail podium, is being acquired by CCT, excluding hotel premises owned by a third party. This sale is BlackRock's fourth property sale in Singapore since 2015, following the sale of Asia Square Tower 1 for S$3.4 billion to Qatar Investment Authority in 2022.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: BOJ set to keep monetary spigot open, political risk looms
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its ultra-low interest rates, as an improving economy has not yet led to inflation near its 2% target. Premier Shinzo Abe's decision to call a snap election may delay fiscal reform, putting pressure on the BOJ to continue stimulus. Analysts predict this could lead to greater tension between the government and central bank, potentially limiting the BOJ's ability to scale back stimulus. The BOJ's decision is expected to reassure markets, but the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, OCBC, CCT, Raffles Education
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is assessing options after reports of a possible stake sale in its Malaysian unit. OCBC shares may benefit from this as Great Eastern contributes 15% to OCBC's earnings. CCT halted trading pending announcements, while Raffles Education's chairman has been approached about selling his shares. No agreement has been reached, and discussions have ceased.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.63 points to 1,774.21 on Thursday, driven by gains over 132 stocks while 103 lost value. Total trading volume was 300.85 million lots worth RM127.54 million.

site_title: GE to sell corporate jets in cost-cutting move
summary: General Electric plans to sell its corporate jets as part of a cost-cutting effort to reduce US$2 billion in expenses by the end of 2018. The move comes amid sluggish activity in key industrial divisions, including oil and gas and power, which has pressured the company's earnings outlook. GE will use charter companies as needed and plans to sell its fleet of jets and helicopters. The company's shares have fallen 23% since January.

site_title: Ex-Barclays CEO Jenkins bags £34m for his fintech startup
summary: Barclays ex-CEO Antony Jenkins has secured £34 million in funding for his fintech startup, 10X Future Technologies. The Series A round, led by Ping An Insurance and Oliver Wyman, is 17 times larger than the median of other fintech startups. Jenkins' firm aims to help traditional financial companies redesign their IT systems and products using digital tools. He expects the funding to aid expansion in key markets, including Asia, and follows his previous efforts to promote fintech at Barclays.

site_title: Australia shares hit 3-week low after Fed; NZ down
summary: Australian shares hit a three-week low after the US Federal Reserve signaled it expects one more interest rate hike by the end of the year, despite low inflation. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.8010, and the S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.9% to 5,657.2. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 0.6% to 7,773.18, with construction firm Fletcher Building being the biggest drag. The Fed's comments also raised pressure on markets, with asset prices expected to come down as interest rates rise.

site_title: US embassy employee kidnapped, freed, in Venezuela: police
summary: A US embassy employee, Kerbin Barazarte, a 28-year-old security guard, was kidnapped in Venezuela two days earlier, with kidnappers demanding a $30,000 ransom. He was released unharmed and without payment on Wednesday. The kidnappers, unknown, targeted Barazarte while he was patrolling in a van near the embassy. A colleague managed to evade the kidnappers. The incident highlights the rise in kidnappings in Venezuela, with the country experiencing a significant increase in such crimes over the last few years.

site_title: As Nicaragua joins Paris Accord, Trump left alone with Syria
summary: Nicaragua is set to join the Paris climate accord, leaving the US and Syria as the only two nations refusing to support the landmark deal. Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega announced plans to sign the agreement "soon." This move comes after Trump's decision to pull the US from the accord in June, citing restrictions on US companies. The US and Syria are now the only two countries to opt out of the 2015 agreement aimed at combating global warming.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen eases after Fed decision
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday as the yen weakened against the dollar following the US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.80% to 20,472.56, while the Topix index gained 0.70% to 1,679.54. The move was seen as a boost to exporters, who benefit from a weaker yen. The decision also kept the door open for a potential December interest rate hike, which had investors cautious about the market's outlook.

site_title: China Hongxing Sports' ex-CEO makes S$20.5m offer to buy company's subsidiaries
summary: China Hongxing Sports Limited's former CEO, Denis Wu Rongzhao, has made a S$20.5 million offer to acquire the company's operating subsidiaries through his investment firm, Jiayao Investments Limited. The proposed deal involves disposing off all businesses in China held under Profitstart Group Limited.

site_title: SGX to 'invest strategically' to boost fixed income business
summary: SGX, the Singapore Exchange, plans to "invest strategically" to boost its fixed income business, according to CEO Loh Boon Chye. This move is aimed at increasing distribution in overseas offices and investing in growth opportunities. The fixed income and foreign exchange asset classes are key to this strategy, with SGX seeking to market foreign exchange as a complementary risk hedging or margin offsetting instrument. The exchange currently offers 21 currency futures contracts.

site_title: US dollar rises as Fed hints at December rate hike
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-month high versus the yen, reaching 112.51 yen, as the Federal Reserve hinted at a potential rate hike in December, sparking a 73% chance of a rate increase according to futures markets. The Fed also announced it will begin reducing its $4.5 trillion balance sheet in October. Despite inflation remaining below its 2% goal, the market sees the Fed as more hawkish than anticipated, causing the euro to slide and emerging market currencies to fluctuate.

site_title: Japan PM says time for North Korea dialogue is over
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared the time for dialogue with North Korea over, citing the regime's nuclear and missile tests. Abe supported US President Donald Trump's warning that "all options" are on the table, including military action. Abe and other world leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lofven, expressed concern over Trump's bellicose tone, urging dialogue and sanctions instead. Abe called for pressure, not dialogue, to address North Korea's nuclear ambitions, which he said pose a threat to global credibility.

site_title: Surging onion, egg, squid costs spice up Asian inflation outlook
summary: Asian countries are experiencing surging food prices, with onions, eggs, and squid seeing significant increases. However, experts believe these price spikes are transitory and not indicative of a broader inflation breakout. Despite this, some countries, such as South Korea and India, are seeing higher inflation rates, while others, like Indonesia and Taiwan, are experiencing declining food costs. Monetary authorities in the region are not expected to raise interest rates, and economists predict that inflation will accelerate due to a strong demand pick-up and accommodative financial conditions.

site_title: China may relax rules for foreign EV makers, say officials
summary: China is discussing a plan to relax rules for foreign electric vehicle (EV) makers, allowing them to set up wholly owned businesses in free trade zones. The move, potentially in place by next year, would be a significant departure from the existing joint venture rule, giving companies like Tesla the opportunity to establish fully owned manufacturing operations in China. The plan is part of China's broader efforts to open up the new-energy manufacturing sector to foreign investors, following a notice from the State Council in August.

site_title: No need to renegotiate Iran nuclear deal: EU
summary: EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini stated there's no need to renegotiate the Iranian nuclear deal, saying it's "delivering" despite US demands. Mogherini's comments came after a meeting with US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif. US President Donald Trump had previously called the deal "an embarrassment" and expressed plans to re-evaluate it, but Mogherini warned against re-opening the deal at a time of global nuclear threats, including North Korea. The deal has been ratified by six world powers, including Britain, France, Russia, China, and Germany.

site_title: Management fight erupts at Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' China factory
summary: A physical assault occurred at Shanghai Turbo Enterprises' China factory, targeting the new management team of a subsidiary. Former executive director Liu Ming's associates allegedly attacked Raymond Lim, an independent non-executive director, and four others with plastic batons. The incident is linked to a legal case against Liu, who is accused of assault. The victims suffered injuries, including bruises, bleeding, and bone fractures. The case has been reported to local authorities and the Singapore Consulate-General in Shanghai.

site_title: Fed to shrink assets next month, boost rates by year end
summary: The Federal Reserve announced plans to shrink its $4.5 trillion balance sheet in October, starting with a monthly reduction of $10 billion, and to raise interest rates by year-end. Despite concerns about the impact of hurricanes on the economy, the Fed expects steady growth and low unemployment to sustain inflation around its 2% goal. The decision is the third major policy step by Chair Janet Yellen, who will step down in the final year of her term.

site_title: Global dairy prices rise at second auction in a row
summary: Global dairy prices rose for the second consecutive auction, with the Global Dairy Trade Price Index climbing 0.9% to an average selling price of US$3,368 per tonne. This follows a strong three-month rally, with whole milk powder and butter performing well, rising 0.6% and 1.2% respectively. Analysts predict further price increases due to bad weather in New Zealand, the world's largest dairy exporter, which is expected to hamper supply and push prices higher in coming months.

site_title: Great Eastern weighs options on Malaysian unit's stake sale
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is assessing options to sell a minority stake in its Malaysian unit, Great Eastern Life Assurance (Malaysia) Berhad, to comply with foreign ownership requirements in Malaysia. The insurer has not confirmed any agreement and advises shareholders that the assessment is preliminary. The move follows reports on Wednesday.

site_title: Spain's central government takes control of Catalonia's finances to block referendum
summary: Spain's central government has taken control of Catalonia's finances to block an independence referendum, limiting the region's autonomy. The move prevents funds from being used for the referendum and may impact thousands of public workers' salaries. Catalonia's Vice-President, Oriol Junqueras, described the measure as "unprecedented" and "total irresponsibility."

site_title: Oil up 2% despite US crude build; set for best 3rd quarter since 2004
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 1.9% to $56.20 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 1.9% to $50.41 a barrel. Despite a 4.6 million-barrel increase in US crude inventories, the market is expected to see its largest third-quarter gain in 13 years, with prices on track for a nearly 16% rise this quarter. OPEC and its partners are considering extending or deepening output cuts, and a meeting is scheduled for Friday to discuss the pact's progress.

site_title: Google likely to buy stake in Taiwan smartphone maker HTC: report
summary: Google is reportedly set to buy a stake in Taiwan-based smartphone maker HTC, gaining control of its smartphone design unit. The deal would bolster Google's challenge to market leaders Apple and Samsung, allowing it to integrate smartphone hardware and its Android operating software more seamlessly. This would be Google's first foray into hardware since acquiring Motorola in 2012. The announcement could come later in the day, pending an official statement from Google.

site_title: M&A, Spain turmoil liven up Europe stocks
summary: Europe's stock markets saw a mixed session on Wednesday, with Spanish stocks falling 0.8% amid political turmoil and police arrests in Catalonia. However, deal-making and M&A activity lifted some stocks, including Thyssenkrupp's 2% rise after a steel merger with Tata Steel. Banks also saw gains, with Commerzbank rallying 2.4% after reports of a potential merger with UniCredit. The Stoxx 600 ended flat, and investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook.

site_title: Once "kittens" in cyber spy world, Iran gains prowess: security experts
summary: Iran's cyber-spying prowess has significantly increased, with hackers linked to the Iranian government targeting Saudi and Western aerospace and petrochemical firms, according to a report by security firm FireEye. The group, dubbed APT33, has been linked to attacks since 2013, seeking to steal aviation and military secrets. The US Treasury Department has also added two Iran-based hacking networks and eight individuals to a US sanctions list, accusing them of cyber-enabled attacks on the US financial system. Experts describe rising maturity and professionalism in Iran's cyber-espionage capabilities, with the country now ranking with China and Russia in terms of frequency of attacks.

site_title: US Fed's Yellen says has not met with Trump to discuss status
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated she has not met with President Donald Trump to discuss her status as Fed chair. Her four-year term expires in February, and she intends to serve out her term. Despite Trump's support for her, Yellen has not commented on her future. The Fed may face an empty board with four seats vacant until Trump's nominee Randall Quarles is confirmed by Congress. Yellen expressed confidence in Fed officials' ability to carry out their responsibilities and hopes for additional nominations to fill vacant seats.

site_title: US: Wall St closes slightly higher after Fed policy decisions
summary: The US stock market closed slightly higher on Wednesday, adding to its string of closing records, after the Federal Reserve signaled another interest rate hike by year-end and disclosed its plan to reduce its balance sheet. The Fed left interest rates unchanged but announced it would begin cutting its balance sheet in October, with a plan to cut up to $10 billion in monthly Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities holdings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.19% to end at a record close, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reached fresh records.

site_title: Tillerson, Zarif in first meeting with partners on Iran nuclear deal
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson met with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif at the United Nations, discussing the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. The meeting aimed to reassure European partners backing the deal, amid President Donald Trump's threat to scrap it. Trump is set to report to Congress on whether Iran is upholding its side of the accord by October 15. The US has lifted sanctions in exchange for Iran's nuclear concessions, but Trump has called the deal "an embarrassment" for the US.

site_title: Pavilion Energy, Uniper of Germany to share LNG storage capacity
summary: Pavilion Energy and Uniper of Germany have signed a two-year agreement allowing each other to use their respective LNG storage capacity at terminals in Singapore, the UK, and Germany. The deal strengthens Pavilion's reach to UK and continental Europe gas markets, while giving Uniper access to Asian markets. The agreement follows Pavilion's recent storage and reload deal with Singapore LNG Corporation. Both companies plan to cooperate further in energy trading and exploring new markets together.

site_title: China's short-term bonds could be next risk target
summary: China's riskiest borrowers are selling large amounts of short-term dollar debt, sparking concerns of a potential crackdown by authorities. Seventeen firms have priced $4.3 billion of under-the-radar debt due in less than a year, with most issuers being unrated or in the single B credit space. The National Development and Reform Commission is likely to curb this issuance, citing concerns over credit quality and leverage levels. A redemption wave is expected mid-next year, with many of these bonds coming due in the next few months, potentially leading to higher costs for issuers.

site_title: Russia's nuclear giant joins race to supply lithium for electric cars
summary: Russia's state-owned nuclear corporation Rosatom Corp plans to start mining and trading lithium, a key component in electric vehicle batteries, as the demand for electric cars grows. Following a collapse in uranium prices, Rosatom aims to accumulate the entire integrated line of lithium products, including batteries and cooperation with car producers. The company's strong balance sheet allows it to invest in new products, and it has already opened a trading company in Switzerland to start trading lithium and other metals. Rosatom plans to get 30% of its revenue from non-nuclear businesses by 2030.

site_title: Football legends to duke it out on Nov 11
summary: The Battle of the Masters football event in Singapore, set for November 11, will feature former players from the Singapore national team, Liverpool, and Arsenal in a 40-minute round-robin match. The event, sponsored by American Express CapitaCard, marks the first time the company has joined the Masters Football Asia series. The Singapore Masters team includes players such as Fandi Ahmad and Aleksandar Duric, while the Liverpool and Arsenal teams boast notable players like David James and Robert Pires. The match will be played at the 55,000-seater National Stadium in Kallang.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand Limited announced that its wholly owned subsidiaries, C31 Ventures Fund 1 Pte Ltd and C31VF1-065C Pte Ltd, have increased their issued and paid-up share capital through an allotment of redeemable preference shares. The subsidiaries will use the proceeds to fund working capital and investment activities. The share increase was done for cash consideration and has increased their capital to about S$11.2 million and S$8.4 million respectively.

site_title: Eu Realty puts up 2 South Bridge Rd shophouses for sale
summary: Eu Realty, a subsidiary of Eu Yan Sang International, has listed two shophouses along South Bridge Road for sale, with an asking price of S$28.5 million (S$2,842 per sq ft). The two shophouses, spanning three levels and an attic, are located in the heart of Chinatown and are currently home to a TCM clinic. The property's sale will not affect the adjacent four shophouses, which are also owned by Eu Realty and will remain in operation. The property presents an attractive investment opportunity due to its prime location and limited supply in the conservation shophouse market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: CPF - there's a silver lining in the silver tsunami
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) saw a 10% increase in total balances to S$328.9 billion in 2016, with an average balance of S$87,000, more than doubling from S$43,000 in 2007. The number of active CPF members rose 0.8% to 2 million, while those aged 55 and above reached 1.2 million, with many choosing to top-up their retirement accounts and withdraw less. The CPF's wealth growth has outpaced its member base, with women closing the gap in CPF balances, though they still lag behind men.

site_title: Assets in Singapore family offices close to global average
summary: Singapore's ultra-rich families have nearly twice as much assets managed by family offices (FOs) as their counterparts in the Asia Pacific, with an average assets under management (AUM) of US$857 million. Singapore FOs also lead the region in succession planning, with 67% of families in the process of developing a plan, compared to 29% in Hong Kong. Additionally, Singapore FOs are keen on private investments, including private equity and co-investment deals, and impact investing, with 29% of families having an exposure.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: China car brands pull up at Frankfurt fair
summary: Chinese car brands showcased their electric vehicles at the Frankfurt car show, aiming to increase their presence in Europe. Taiwanese company Thunder Power unveiled a high-end electric SUV, while Borgward, a German-Chinese manufacturer, showcased a limited-edition SUV and a sporty Isabella concept car. Other Chinese brands, WEY and Chery, also made their debuts, highlighting their ambitions to tap into Europe's booming 4x4 market. Industry experts see this move as a way for Chinese manufacturers to gain international recognition and cachet back home.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp, Tata Steel merge Europe operations
summary: Thyssenkrupp and Tata Steel have agreed to merge their European steel operations in a preliminary deal, creating the continent's second-largest steelmaker after ArcelorMittal. The deal will not involve any cash and will instead be funded by debt and liabilities. The companies aim to consolidate operations to address overcapacity in the European steel market, which faces cheap imports from China. Annual synergies are expected to be 400-600 million euros, with up to 4,000 job cuts. The joint venture, Thyssenkrupp Tata Steel, will be headquartered in Amsterdam and will ease Tata Steel's debt burden.

site_title: Why Australia may be 'woefully unprepared' for flu season
summary: Australia is experiencing a historically high number of flu cases, with over 166,000 reported cases and at least 72 fatalities, prompting concerns about the country's preparedness. A low vaccination rate, particularly among children, has been cited as a contributing factor, with less than 10% of kids receiving flu shots. Experts attribute the issue to a "she'll be right" attitude towards the flu, as well as inadequate messaging about the importance of vaccination. The Australian government's focus on high-risk groups has been criticized for not being clear enough in its messaging.

site_title: Two property listings portals battle over alleged copyright infringement
summary: PropertyGuru, a leading Singapore property listings portal, has sued 99.co, its rival, over alleged copyright infringement. The trial, which began on September 20, 2017, centers on the use of Xpressor, a digital app allowing property agents to post listings across multiple platforms. PropertyGuru claims 99.co reproduced its content, including photographs with its watermark, without permission, and encouraged agents to breach its rules by using Xpressor. 99.co denies the claims and has filed a counterclaim for "groundless threats" of copyright infringement.

site_title: Swissco lands US$28.5m offer for offshore support vessel business
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, has secured a US$28.5 million offer from Asian Strategic Turnaround Ventures Pte Ltd for its offshore support vessel business. The deal, involving the sale of shares and 26 vessels, is the first of its kind for an O&M entity undergoing judicial management. The fund house will also acquire Swissco's stakes in two Malaysian-incorporated companies and provide a US$4 million loan to discharge mortgages. The transaction is expected to result in a net loss of US$12.7 million and is subject to court and shareholder approvals.

site_title: Used-car dealer taps fintech for one-stop ease
summary: Orchard Credit, a used-car dealership, has introduced a fintech solution to provide a hassle-free one-stop service for buyers. The showroom allows customers to make an online deposit to reserve a car and submit a car loan application with e-signature directly to nine banks. This move aims to reduce paperwork and increase productivity, catering to the demand for used cars due to shrinking COE quotas and rising car prices.

site_title: Jurong Port, Oiltanking launch venture for new petrochemical terminal
summary: Singapore's Jurong Port and Oiltanking launched their joint venture, Jurong Port Tank Terminals (JPTT), for a new liquid bulk terminal. The terminal aims to solidify Singapore's position as Asia's regional petrochemical hub, providing 480,000 cubic meters of storage capacity and supporting energy and commodity companies. The terminal is expected to enter operation in phases starting from 2019, following the awarding of construction work to Rotary Engineering and Antara Koh in the earlier part of the year.

images.alt_text: Juring Port and Oiltanking commemorated the official launch of their joint venture, Jurong Port Tank Terminals (JPTT), on Wednesday.

site_title: 'Uber of banking' sparks radical changes across industries
summary: Fintech is transforming various industries globally, including banking, trading, and insurance, with digital solutions such as robo-advisory, blockchain, and QR payment mechanisms. The global fintech financing activity has increased significantly, with a notable rise in the Asia-Pacific region. Fintech is expected to have a profound impact on the global financial industry, potentially leading to the "Fourth Industrial Revolution". To benefit from this revolution, Singapore businesses must adapt to the changes and adopt a more holistic approach to innovation, including leveraging technology, collaborating with investors, and upskilling their workforce.

site_title: Edgy talent razes the runways in a rebounding market
summary: Fashion week in Milan kicked off with Gucci's strong show, marking the brand's first collection since announcing a ban on ultra-thin models. Luxury groups LVMH and Kering also signed on to the ban following scandals in the industry. Expect a colorful and eclectic mix of designs from various brands, including Paul Surridge's maiden collection for Roberto Cavalli and the Meier duo's first designs for Jil Sander. Sales in the luxury market are rebounding, with Gucci seeing its sales grow at its fastest pace in 20 years, but other brands, like Prada, struggle to regain momentum.

site_title: A decaying Washington waterfront returns to life
summary: The Wharf waterfront project in Washington D.C. is set to reopen on October 12, after a $2.5 billion investment. The 10-year project aims to revitalize a struggling waterfront along the Potomac River, featuring a 1.6-km cobblestone promenade, public piers, office buildings, and residential units. The project drew inspiration from European waterfronts and incorporated local businesses, with a focus on authenticity. The Wharf will also include a cistern system to collect and recycle rainwater, addressing concerns about extreme flooding. The project's completion reflects lessons learned from similar developments across the US and abroad.

site_title: Two-pronged battle plan to keep electronics sector fighting fit
summary: Singapore's Industry Minister S Iswaran unveiled the Electronics Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to transform the sector, focusing on new growth markets and high-value component investments. The aim is to achieve a manufacturing value-add of S$22.2 billion and introduce 2,100 new jobs by 2020. The ITM includes a pipeline of local talent, upgrading industry associations, and a new Skills Framework for Electronics. The government also launched a new professional conversion program for Electronics Engineers and Assistants, and will continue to attract high-value activities, including investments from companies like ams AG and Soitec.

site_title: US 'muddling through' in search of a doctrine
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is struggling to develop a coherent foreign policy doctrine, despite his campaign promise to challenge the status quo. Unlike previous presidents, who introduced doctrines in response to the Cold War, Trump's "America First" approach lacks a clear grand strategy. Instead, he is muddling through, adapting to a complex international system, and reversing campaign promises. This approach is similar to that of his predecessors, Bill Clinton, George W Bush, and Barack Obama, who also failed to develop a coherent doctrine. The lack of a clear doctrine is due to the opposition from political and economic elites, as well as the difficulty of finding a replacement for the US's global hegemonic role.

site_title: Carrots and variety a good way to improve market regulations
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Regulation arm is exploring "regulatory carrots" to encourage companies to improve corporate governance standards. CEO Tan Boon Gin suggests that well-behaved companies with a good track record could receive fast-tracked approval for corporate actions or be exempt from scrutiny. This approach aims to move beyond a one-size-fits-all regulatory framework, recognizing the variance in companies and their circumstances. The goal is to create a more discerning and efficient regime, leveraging rules as incentives rather than just deterrents.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is reportedly exploring the sale of its Malaysian operations, with a potential sale price of up to US$1 billion. The move comes as Bank Negara Malaysia considers stricter enforcement of the 70% foreign ownership cap on insurers, introduced in 2009. The exact timeline and negotiations are unclear, but the sale would mark a significant shift in the company's operations.

site_title: The next UK-German monetary struggle is brewing
summary: The UK and Germany are embroiled in a monetary struggle as Britain's exit from the EU looms. Germany, the main EU budgetary contributor, is seeking a bridging deal with the UK to prevent a funding shortage. However, the UK's proposed payment of £10 billion per year over three years is opposed by influential Conservative backbenchers and ministers. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's relationship with UK Prime Minister Theresa May is crucial, and her government's willingness to comply with a deal is uncertain. The UK's exit in April 2019 poses a risk of a "cliff edge" departure, with negotiations on a future relationship yet to begin.

site_title: Uber reviews Asia dealings amid US criminal probe
summary: Uber is under scrutiny from the US Justice Department amid a federal probe into potential overseas bribery. The company is reviewing its Asia operations, including dealings in China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and South Korea, following reports of suspicious activities. Uber notified US officials about payments made by staff in Indonesia and is cooperating with investigators. The probe is also looking into a corporate donation to a Malaysian government-backed entrepreneur hub, raising questions about potential quid pro quo arrangements.

site_title: Bain consortium bags Toshiba chip business in hard-fought win
summary: Toshiba has selected a US$22 billion Bain-led consortium, including SK Hynix, Apple, and Dell, to buy its prized memory chip unit, after a hard-fought auction. The decision comes as rival Western Digital Corp has initiated legal action, arguing that no deal can proceed without its consent due to its joint venture partnership. The Bain-led group aims to settle the dispute through arbitration before investing in the business. Toshiba's board decision is seen as a last-minute twist, with the company under pressure to clinch a deal by the end of the financial year to avoid delisting and plug a huge hole in its finances.

site_title: BOE's Carney has 200b reasons to fret about consumer debt
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is concerned about rising consumer debt, with household credit growing five times faster than earnings. Unsecured debt reached £202 billion in July, the highest since 2008, and regulators are reviewing the resilience of banks to a sharp jump in defaults. The Financial Policy Committee is set to publish a statement on September 25, which may include recommendations for action, including interest rate hikes, to address the issue.

site_title: Facebook to be called to testify before Senate panel on Russian meddling
summary: The US Senate Intelligence Committee plans to hold a public hearing to examine Russia's use of social media to influence the 2016 US presidential election. Facebook Inc will be called to testify, along with Twitter Inc, and is expected to provide details on its handling of political ad spending by a Russian group. The hearing may also cover other social media companies. Facebook has cooperated with investigators, but chairman Richard Burr expressed concerns about the company's transparency. The probe, led by special counsel Robert Mueller, aims to determine links between Russia's activity and President Donald Trump's campaign.

site_title: Last chance to win a car
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League is set to conclude with a final leg at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden course, where a gleaming Audi A5 Sportback is on display as the grand prize. To win the car, golfers must sink an ace, with Team Audi Sport members including managing director Jeff Mannering and low handicappers Raju Arivazagan and Lim Joo Seng having a chance. The event's focus is on corporate entertainment, with other prizes including a luxury villa stay and golf equipment.

site_title: Bitcoin chief Roger Ver sees the digital currency splitting again
summary: Roger Ver, CEO of Bitcoin.com, predicts Bitcoin will split again in November due to scaling issues. The split, which occurred in August, led to the creation of Bitcoin Cash, which Ver believes is more in line with the original vision of Bitcoin. If the split happens, it could create another version of the cryptocurrency and further scatter capital and resources. Ver has moved some funds into Bitcoin Cash and expects prices to rally, despite China's crackdown on cryptocurrency trading.

site_title: Poh Tiong Choon CEO launches S$1.30-a-share offer for firm
summary: Poh Tiong Choon Logistics CEO launches a S$1.30-per-share offer to privatize and delist the company, valued at S$275.5 million. The offer, led by chairman Poh Choon Ann, has obtained irrevocable undertakings from 66.7% shareholders to accept the deal. The company aims to save on expenses related to listed status and focus on business operations. The offer represents a 32.5% premium to the one-month VWAP per share and a 58.1% premium to the 12-month VWAP per share.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix extension sparks positive buzz online: report
summary: A four-year Formula 1 extension by Singapore until 2021 has sparked positive buzz online, with 75% of Singaporeans reacting positively to the news. Meltwater analyzed online posts and found Ferrari led social media chatter, followed by Lewis Hamilton and Mercedes. Title sponsor Singapore Airlines was the most talked-about brand, with 85% positive sentiment. The event has attracted over 450,000 visitors and generated an estimated S$1.4 billion in tourism spend.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US Carlyle Group exits Australian mining services play Coates Hire
summary: US private equity firm Carlyle Group is selling its 53.3% stake in Australian mining services provider Coates Hire to Seven Group Holdings for A$517 million. Seven Group will assume Coates's A$1 billion net debt and integrate the business into its industrial services division. The deal is expected to boost Seven's underlying earnings per share by 15% and underlying pre-tax profit to A$415 million. Carlyle's exit marks its departure from the Australian mining services sector amid improved conditions, although plans to list Coates remained unfulfilled.

site_title: Oxley rules out bidding for UEL despite owning 14% stake
summary: OXLEY Holdings' CEO Ching Chiat Kwong has reiterated that the company has no plans to make a bid for United Engineers (UEL), despite owning a 14.1% stake in the company. The stake was accumulated in the last few months, following a failed offer by Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Yanlord Group. Oxley's acquisition is deemed an investment, driven by the company's desire for high dividends and a well-run operation. The ongoing general offer does not prevent Oxley from making open-market purchases in UEL.

site_title: Asti hotly traded on news of unit disposal talks
summary: Asti Holdings shares surged 12.5% on Wednesday after the company announced it has entered into non-binding talks with China Fortune-Tech Capital Co to divest its wholly owned subsidiary STI Group. The semiconductor equipment maker expects the deal to be worth between S$105 million and S$115 million. The deal is expected to provide Asti with a robust balance sheet, allowing its business units to explore opportunities and achieve accelerated growth. The shares opened at S$0.09 and hit a record high of S$0.104 within 15 minutes.

site_title: Is China's debt driving it to a financial crisis?
summary: China's debt has reached alarming levels, with IMF estimates suggesting it will reach almost 300% of GDP by 2022. The country's high corporate leverage and money supply to GDP ratio pose significant risks, including a financial crisis. Despite government assurances, experts warn that deleveraging will be painful and hinder long-term growth. The government's priorities remain focused on GDP growth, and efforts to address the issue have been limited, with some experts likening China's situation to Japan's in the 1990s.

site_title: Pent-up demand greets new Rolls-Royce Phantom
summary: A dozen Rolls-Royce Phantom VIII limousine bookings have been received in Singapore, with deliveries expected to start in the first quarter of 2018. The car, which replaces the previous-generation Phantom, has a starting price of S$1,788,888 before options and COE, but orders typically average S$2.0 million to S$2.2 million on the road. Global demand is strong, with the car sold out for 2018, and the company attributes the bookings to pent-up demand for the new model, which has been 14 years in the making.

site_title: Cubans get back on their bikes
summary: Cuba is witnessing a resurgence in the use of bicycles as a mode of transportation, driven by demand from tourists and Cubans frustrated with poor public transportation. The humble bicycle, once associated with economic crisis, is making a comeback in cities like Cardenas, where it was the preferred way to get around in the 1990s. Modern bike shops are emerging to meet this demand, and customization is common, with many Cubans modifying their bikes to carry extra passengers or even lawnmower engines. Despite its benefits, cycling in Cuba remains a challenge due to inadequate bike paths and motorist education.

site_title: Great Eastern's 3-year 2.05% endowment plan selling well
summary: Great Eastern's 3-year single premium endowment plan, offering a 2.05% guaranteed payout, is selling well. The plan, launched last week, provides coverage against death and disability, with a single premium ranging from S$10,000 to S$500,000. The guaranteed yearly payout can be withdrawn annually or accumulated for a lump sum at the end of three years. The plan's take-up rate is "very good," exceeding expectations, according to Great Eastern head of group brand and communications Tan Seck Geok.

site_title: Harder to get into the hottest oil trader parties in S'pore
summary: The world's top independent oil trader, Vitol Group, is shifting its annual social highlight to more exclusive events due to renovations at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore, which previously hosted the industry's biggest parties. Companies like Vitol, BP, and S-Oil Corp are opting for smaller, private gatherings reserved for top clients, focusing on exclusivity and wooing counterparties in Asia, the largest oil market. This strategy allows firms to save money and concentrate on key clients, as the industry becomes leaner and more focused on its core operations.

site_title: The Duck that lays the Golden egg
summary: The Golden Duck, a Singaporean company, has successfully introduced Salted Egg Yolk flavored potato chips, capitalizing on the flavor trend. Co-founders Chris Hwang and Jonathen Shen launched the product in 2015, despite facing initial doubts and staff shortages. The company has since expanded to over 450 locations in Singapore and Hong Kong, with distributors in the Philippines. Despite challenges, The Golden Duck has become the leading player in the market, selling out within the first six hours of operations. The company continues to grow, with plans to focus on existing markets and expand its product line.

site_title: President Xi, PM Lee hail 'new historical chapter' in bilateral ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met in Beijing, discussing new areas of cooperation in financial, judicial, and legal matters, as well as defense. They reaffirmed the deep and strong friendship between their countries and expressed hope for further progress in bilateral ties. The leaders also discussed the Belt and Road Initiative, regional developments, and the potential of the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative. They agreed to strengthen mechanisms and mechanisms to bring relations to the next level, and welcomed Chinese companies to bid on the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail project.

site_title: UK, France, Italy leaders in push for faster removal of extremist content
summary: UK, France, and Italy leaders urge social media companies to remove "terrorist content" within 1-2 hours of its appearance, citing the short time frame when material is spread. British Prime Minister Theresa May, French President Emmanuel Macron, and Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni will meet with Twitter, Facebook, Microsoft, and Google to push for faster action. The European Union has threatened legislation if companies don't step up efforts to police online content. The move comes after a series of militant attacks, with Twitter removing 299,649 accounts for promoting terrorism in the first half of the year.

site_title: Swiss Takeover Board asks China's HNA to clarify ownership
summary: The Swiss Takeover Board has asked China's HNA Group to clarify its ownership structure by October 3 due to apparent discrepancies since its $1.5 billion takeover of Swiss aviation services company Gategroup. HNA, which has been criticized for its showy overseas ventures, has recently shaken up its shareholding structure with a new charitable foundation. The board pointed out discrepancies between HNA's prospectus and recent statements by the group's top leadership, prompting the request for clarification.

site_title: Modi faces sluggish job creation; opposition's criticism increases
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces criticism over the country's sluggish job creation, with a 30-40% reduction in manufacturing jobs predicted. The opposition, led by Rahul Gandhi, is intensifying its criticism ahead of 2019 elections. Modi's allies, including Subramanian Swamy, have also expressed concerns about the economy heading for a "major depression." The jobs market has been impacted by demonetization and the implementation of a goods and services tax, with many workers lacking the skills required for the services sector.

site_title: Airbus woos China with first wide-body jet facility outside Europe - in Tianjin
summary: Airbus has inaugurated its first wide-body jet facility outside Europe in Tianjin, China, as part of its efforts to tap into the country's massive aviation market. The $200 million completion centre will produce A330 aircraft, with the goal of rolling out two planes per month. The facility is seen as a strategic move to build relationships with China and gain access to the country's $1.1 trillion aircraft market over the next two decades. Airbus and Boeing are also investing in other facilities in China to manufacture aircraft parts and supply components.

site_title: Trump to pay his legal bills with campaign funds
summary: President Donald Trump will use campaign funds to pay his personal legal bills related to Russia investigations. The first payments have been made to Trump lawyers John Dowd and Jay Sekulow, using donations from the campaign and Republican National Committee. The use of campaign funds for personal defense is likely a valid expense as long as it's related to campaign activities. Trump's personal legal bills could reach beyond $1 million, but his campaign has $22.6 million in cash on hand and the RNC has $45.8 million.

site_title: More misses than hits in the latest volume of Clinton's memoirs
summary: Hillary Clinton's new memoir, "What Happened," has received criticism for its perceived lack of self-awareness and defensiveness, with Clinton attributing her 2016 loss to external factors rather than acknowledging her own mistakes. The book's tone is seen as dismissive of her internal party rival Bernie Sanders and the Democratic Party's failure to adapt to changing voter needs. Clinton's refusal to acknowledge the role of big money in politics and her own party's ties to wealthy donors are also criticized. The book is seen as unlikely to resonate with non-believers and may be perceived as a launchpad for another presidential campaign.

site_title: GE shares fall on possible sale of Malaysian stake
