summary: OCBC shares edged up, while Great Eastern's shares lost 19 cents following reports that the insurer is selling its stake in its Malaysian unit for US$1 billion. DBS Group Research said OCBC shareholders could benefit from the sale, maintaining its "buy" call and target price of S$12.80. The sale comes as insurers in Malaysia face a deadline to reduce foreign ownership to 70% by June 2018.

site_title: Cautious session ahead of FOMC meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index ended 7.88 points weaker at 3,218.07 on Wednesday, tracking Dow futures and Hong Kong. Trading volume was low, with 1.9 billion units worth S$824 million traded, the lowest since August 28. Analysts from Macquarie, Bank of Singapore, and Deutsche Bank expressed cautious views on the market ahead of the FOMC meeting, citing potential tightening of monetary policy and higher financial market volatility.

site_title: RBA sees slack in job market, at ease with inflation outlook
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) believes the labour market has "plenty of spare capacity," limiting wage growth and inflation for the time being. Despite jobs surging in August, the unemployment rate remained static at 5.6% due to more people seeking work. RBA head of economics Luci Ellis stated there is still "fair bit of slack" in the labour market, which needs to edge down to around 5% for the economy to run full throttle. The RBA is comfortable with its inflation forecast, aiming for the 2-3% target band by next year, but notes record-high household debt as a potential risk.

site_title: Sprint, T-Mobile said to be discussing terms to bring merger closer
summary: Sprint and T-Mobile are in preliminary talks for a stock-for-stock merger, with Deutsche Telekom set to have control. The deal would create a No. 3 wireless carrier in the US, with T-Mobile executives leading the combined company. SoftBank, which owns Sprint, favors the deal due to potential savings and its desire to create a stronger US player. However, regulatory approval would take at least a year, and the deal faces challenges, including a lack of framework for structuring the merger and differing views on the future of the industry.

site_title: Drug-resistant infections a global health emergency, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared antibiotic-resistant infections a global health emergency, citing a lack of new treatments for deadly bacteria such as tuberculosis. The report warns that resistance to antibiotics is inevitable but has been accelerated by misuse, leading to longer illness and treatment. Only 8 out of 51 new drugs in development are deemed valuable, and more than $800 million annually is needed to fund research into drug-resistant TB. The WHO emphasizes responsible antibiotic use and calls for increased investment in research and development.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde warns US won't meet growth targets amid slow reforms
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warned that the US will likely fall short of its 3% annual economic growth target unless it accelerates promised policy changes, including tax reform. The International Monetary Fund cut its US growth forecast to 2.1% due to slow reforms. Lagarde expressed support for tax reform and stated that the US economy's low unemployment rate and other factors make a 3% growth rate unrealistic. The IMF's revised growth forecasts will be published in mid-October.

site_title: Small car COE rebounds on strong demand
summary: The Singapore small car Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium has rebounded, rising to S$42,902 after a S$6,901 increase in the second bidding exercise of September. This marks a significant jump from a seven-year low of S$36,001. Demand for Cat A COEs surged, with bookings triple the usual number and nearly twice as many bids as available COEs. The COE premium is expected to remain at this level for the next two rounds before the new quota is announced in November 2017.

images.alt_text: The small car certificate of entitlement (COE) premium bounced back up after most distributors reported robust bookings following the almost S$7,000 plunge two weeks ago.

site_title: US dollar heads towards 2½-year lows
summary: The US dollar is edging towards 2½-year lows due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike and balance sheet cuts. Investors await clues from the Fed's policy meeting on Wednesday, with a weakening dollar attributed to "less hawkish" Fed members. The dollar has fallen 11% this year, largely due to the receding "Trumpflation trade" expectations, while the kiwi dollar rose to a 1½-month high after a poll showed a strong lead for New Zealand's ruling National Party.

site_title: Latest Moxy hotel is a throwback to the past
summary: Moxy Hotels, a design-driven hospitality brand, is set to debut its 15th property, Moxy Times Square, in New York City. The 612-room hotel, owned by Lightstone, is designed to be affordable, with rooms starting at $139, a bargain by NYC standards. The property features communal areas, including a lobby with leather couches and Instagram-worthy art installations, as well as five restaurants and bars. The hotel's ethos is a throwback to the past, offering a unique blend of upscale touches and wallet-friendly prices.

images.alt_text: One of the 19 "crashpads" at the 612-room Moxy Times Square hotel. The property is the 15th of the Moxy Hotels, Marriott International's design-driven hospitality brand.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker as caution reigns ahead of FOMC meeting
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day 7.88 points weaker at 3,218.07 due to caution ahead of the FOMC meeting on Thursday, with trading volume at its lowest since August 28 at 1.9 billion units worth S$824 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Wednesday, down 3.08 points to 1,773.58. Losers outnumbered gainers 476 to 377, with a total volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion.

site_title: Olam issues unsecured notes and close to 8 million additional warrants
summary: Olam International Limited is issuing $96.5 million in 0.9825% fixed rate senior unsecured notes due 2022 through a private placement. The notes will be issued under the company's $5 billion Euro Medium Term Note Programme and will mature on September 27, 2022. The company has also announced that it will issue approximately 8 million additional warrants.

site_title: Temasek invests in electric scooter maker Gogoro
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte has invested $300 million in Gogoro Inc, an electric scooter maker, alongside other investors such as Generation Investment Management and Sumitomo Corp. The investment brings Gogoro's valuation to approximately $800 million and will be used for expansion and research and development. Founded in 2011, Gogoro plans to expand into more cities, particularly in South-east Asia, where it has a strong presence in Taiwan.

site_title: US:Wall St opens little changed
summary: Wall Street opened little changed on Wednesday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's conclusion of its two-day meeting for indications of a third interest rate hike this year. The S&P 500 edged up to another record level, with eight of 11 major S&P sectors higher, led by a 0.50% gain in the energy index. The Fed is likely to keep interest rates unchanged and start unwinding its $4.2 trillion bond holdings. The central bank's decision will be closely watched for views on inflation, with a December rate hike now seen as more likely than 50% earlier this week.

site_title: Toshiba seals US$18b deal to sell chip unit to Bain Capital group
summary: Toshiba has agreed to sell its semiconductor business to a group led by US private equity firm Bain Capital LP for approximately $18 billion. The deal is a key step in keeping the struggling Japanese conglomerate listed on the Tokyo exchange. The decision was made at a board meeting earlier in the day, after Toshiba had previously led toward an agreement with its US joint venture partner Western Digital Corp.

site_title: EU, Canada launch free trade agreement while Britain eyes own deal
summary: The European Union and Canada have launched a free trade agreement, CETA, which will abolish 98% of customs duties and open up public tenders. The agreement, eight years in the making, marks a success for the EU after its credibility was damaged by Britain's 2016 vote to leave the block. Britain is expected to create its own free trade agreement with Canada, which took five years to negotiate. The agreement is seen as a reminder to Britain of the work it will take to replace its trade alliances when it leaves the EU.

site_title: Hurricane Maria lashes Puerto Rico with force not seen in 'modern history'
summary: Hurricane Maria made landfall on Puerto Rico as the strongest storm in over 80 years, bringing powerful winds of over 160 mph and causing widespread destruction. The Category 4 hurricane has already left death and devastation across the Caribbean, with at least two deaths reported in the French island of Guadeloupe. Puerto Rico was spared the full force of Hurricane Irma earlier this month, but Maria's approach has knocked out power for about 1 million people and weakened the island's hurricane defenses.

site_title: Abe's snap election bid could either bruise or bolster
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to call a snap general election in an attempt to bolster his hold on power, similar to Britain's Theresa May after the Brexit vote. However, opposition forces may capitalize on his opportunism, potentially bruising his chances. This move comes at a crucial moment, with Abe seeking to address Japan's economic and security challenges. The outcome of the election is uncertain, and Abe's bid may not yield the desired results, potentially weakening his position.

site_title: Bank bailout hits Russia as B&N asks central bank for aid
summary: Russia's B&N Bank, the country's 12th biggest lender by assets, has sought a bailout from the central bank amid financial struggles. The central bank is in talks with B&N's owners about the request, with a decision expected soon. This comes three weeks after another leading Russian bank, Otkritie, was rescued with a potential $6.9 billion bailout. Insiders believe the problems are contained to a few mid-sized private banks and the risk of a wider crisis is small. The central bank may provide B&N with extra capital from a newly-created Banking Sector Consolidation Fund.

site_title: CapitaLand's wholly owned subsidiaries increase issued and paid-up share capital
summary: CapitaLand's wholly owned subsidiaries, C31 Ventures Fund 1 Pte Ltd and C31VF1-065C Pte Ltd, have increased their issued and paid-up share capital by allotting additional redeemable preference shares for cash consideration. The subsidiaries received S$3 million each, with proceeds to be used for general working capital and investment activities. The share increases do not impact the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2017 financial year.

site_title: Fortum plans 8.05b euros bid for EON fossil-fuel arm Uniper
summary: Fortum Oyj plans to offer 8.05 billion euros for EON SE's legacy fossil fuel and trading business, Uniper SE, amid European power sector consolidation. Fortum is in talks with EON to acquire its remaining 47% stake in Uniper. The proposed deal reflects the shift towards renewable energy, making traditional coal and gas plants less profitable. If agreed, Fortum will make a voluntary takeover offer of 22 euros per share to Uniper investors. The offer represents a 4.5% premium to Uniper's closing price, following speculation of a potential takeover.

site_title: Zara-owner Inditex's H1 gross margin eroded by strong euro
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a 9% higher profit of 2.29 billion euros in the first half of 2017, driven by a 9% increase in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda). However, the company's gross margin eroded due to the stronger euro, slightly missing forecasts. Despite this, Inditex's business model of responding to catwalk trends has allowed it to consistently outperform rivals. Sales at constant currency terms increased by 12% in the first seven weeks of the second half, driven by strong autumn/winter collections.

site_title: Luxottica, Essilor offer no merger concessions to EU regulators
summary: Luxottica and Essilor, the companies behind a proposed 46 billion euro merger, have failed to offer concessions to EU regulators, increasing the likelihood of a lengthy investigation into the deal. The European Commission requires companies to make concessions if they are to be considered in the approval process. The companies had until September 19 to address the commission's concerns, but a filing on the commission's website shows they have not made any concessions. This decision may lead to a prolonged investigation into the merger.

site_title: Yoko Ono won't let it be, forces "John Lemon" drink to re-brand
summary: Yoko Ono forced a Polish beverage company to re-brand its "John Lemon" drink to "On Lemon" after threatening legal action due to trademark infringement. The company agreed to the change after receiving warnings from Ono's lawyers, who cited potential costs of up to 5,000 euros per day. The move comes after Ono heard about the drink's name, prompting her to take action to protect her late husband John Lennon's trademark.

site_title: Saudi plans US$2.7b entertainment firm as Kingdom opens up
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund is launching a US$2.7 billion entertainment firm to reduce the country's reliance on oil. The company, with an initial capitalization of 10 billion riyals, aims to serve 50 million visitors annually and create 22,000 local jobs by 2030. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan includes boosting entertainment options to diversify revenue sources and improve quality of life in the conservative kingdom. The new firm will expand entertainment offerings to international standards, with early plans including building an entertainment complex.

site_title: European steel getting the deals it craved for years
summary: European steel companies have secured a major deal, with Tata Steel Ltd and Thyssenkrupp AG agreeing to merge their European steel businesses. The combined company, Thyssenkrupp Tata Steel, will control about half of Europe's steel industry, aiming to reduce excess supply and support prices. The move is expected to create a clear No 2 producer in the region, behind ArcelorMittal, which recently acquired Italy's Ilva steel plant. The deal is seen as a solution to the industry's oversupply problem, with potential benefits including greater pricing discipline and corporate cost savings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's electronics sector is set to achieve a manufacturing value-add of S$22.2 billion and create 2,100 new jobs by 2020, as the electronics industry transformation map (ITM) kicked off. The small car COE premium rebounded after a S$7,000 plunge two weeks ago. A consortium led by Poh Tiong Choon Logistics is making an offer to takeover the firm at S$1.30 a share. Temasek Holdings Pte led a US$300 million investment in electric scooter-maker GOGORO Inc.

site_title: Singapore's small car COE rebounds on strong demand
summary: Singapore's small car COE premium rebounded after a two-week slump, rising to S$42,902 in the second September bidding exercise. Category A saw a S$6,901 increase, while categories B, C, and D also rose. The rebound follows a S$6,899 drop in the first exercise, a seven-year low. These increases are attributed to strong demand from distributors, who reported robust bookings following the initial plunge.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares at 28-month highs as China metal shares rally
summary: Hong Kong shares reached 28-month highs, with the Hang Seng index rising 0.3% to 28,127.80 points. Chinese metal producers' shares also rallied, contributing to the gains. However, caution ahead of a US Federal Reserve policy decision, which is expected to keep rates unchanged but may start reducing massive bond holdings, capped broader market gains.

site_title: Yuan firms as corporates take profits on US dollar ahead of Fed decision
summary: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Wednesday as companies sold dollars to take profits ahead of a Federal Reserve policy decision. The yuan opened at 6.5755 per US dollar and traded at 6.5675, 185 pips firmer than the previous close. The Fed is expected to announce reducing its balance sheet and keep interest rates on hold, but investors will watch for hints on future rate hikes. The yuan's gains were supported by US dollar selling by traders and corporate clients.

site_title: Hindus fleeing Myanmar violence hope for shelter in Modi's India
summary: Hundreds of Hindus fleeing violence in Myanmar are seeking shelter in India, particularly in the Hindu-majority state of Modi's government. Nearly 500 Hindus are housed in a chicken farm in Bangladesh, fearing deportation to Myanmar or staying in mostly Muslim Bangladesh. India's government has made it easier for minorities from Bangladesh and Pakistan to gain citizenship, but has declined to comment on the Hindu refugees' hopes. The Vishwa Hindu Parishad, close to Modi's ruling party, is pushing for a new policy allowing Hindus from Myanmar and Bangladesh to seek asylum in India.

site_title: Diageo says Indian highway liquor ban to hurt sales
summary: Diageo, the maker of Johnnie Walker whiskey and Smirnoff vodka, expects its first-half sales growth to suffer due to the timing of Chinese New Year and the Indian highway liquor ban. The ban, implemented in April, restricts liquor outlets within 500 meters of national and state highways, affecting Diageo's sales in India, its largest market in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite concerns, Diageo stands by its sales growth target of mid single digits and an improvement in its organic operating margin.

site_title: Croesus Retail Asset Management increases shareholdings in subsidiaries
summary: Croesus Retail Asset Management, trustee manager of Croesus Retail Trust (CRT), has increased its shareholdings in subsidiaries Apple 1 TMK Holdings Pte Ltd and Apple 2 TMK Holdings Pte Ltd. The company subscribed for additional shares worth 500 million yen (S$3 million) to fund capital expenditure and financing the construction of a new building. This move aims to enhance assets and is not expected to impact CRT's net tangible asset value or distribution per unit for the current financial year. The subscriptions were funded through a four-year term loan facility with Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges up, stocks down as foreign investors take profits
summary: The South Korean won edged up 0.3% to 1,128.3 won per US dollar, but the cautious market mood was maintained due to uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's September policy meeting. Foreign investors sold off local equities, cutting 188.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares, causing the Korea Composite Stock Price Index to close 0.2% down at 2,412.20 points.

site_title: Commonwealth Games-2022 deadline looms with Birmingham in box seat
summary: Birmingham is in pole position to host the 2022 Commonwealth Games, with the UK government backing the bid. The city's preferred option over Liverpool, Birmingham's submission deadline is September 30. Kuala Lumpur and Victoria, also in the running, face challenges due to lack of government support. Australia has expressed interest in hosting the Games but will only submit a formal bid if an alternative host cannot be found. The Commonwealth Games Federation will review submissions before making a final decision by the end of the year.

site_title: US existing home sales fall to 12-month low
summary: US existing home sales fell to a 12-month low in August, decreasing 1.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.35 million units. The decline was attributed to Hurricane Harvey's impact on Houston and a shortage of properties on the market. This marks the lowest level since August 2016. July's sales pace remained at 5.44 million units, unchanged. The drop in sales pace is a concern for the housing market.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp and Tata to create Europe's 2nd largest steelmaker
summary: Thyssenkrupp and Tata Steel have signed a memorandum of understanding to merge their European steel businesses, creating the region's second-largest steelmaker. The joint venture, Thyssenkrupp Tata Steel, will be equally owned and aims to achieve annual synergies of 400-600 million euros. The deal is expected to be finalized in early 2018 and will result in the loss of around 4,000 jobs. The companies expect to save costs through capacity utilization, sales, and research and development.

site_title: Eurozone catches up with US as global growth gets more in sync: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has reported that the global economy is expected to grow at 3.5% this year and 3.7% next year, with the eurozone catching up with the US. The eurozone's growth rate has been revised up to 2.1%, matching the US, while France and Italy have driven this brighter outlook. The OECD also recommended that the US Federal Reserve stick to gradually raising interest rates and the European Central Bank trim its asset purchases before phasing out negative interest rates.

site_title: Trump's fiery UN address redefines US role in the world
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a fiery UN address, redefining America's role in the world. He emphasized a "Trump doctrine" prioritizing the nation state, rejecting globalism and multilateralism. Trump used the term "sovereignty" 21 times, reflecting a shift away from global institutions and towards a more isolationist approach. However, critics argue that his words do not match his actions, with Trump having ripped up trade pacts and not yet left the Paris climate accord. The speech has left allies bewildered and raised questions about the coherence of Trump's foreign policy.

site_title: Average assets in Singapore family offices nearly double those in Asia-Pacific
summary: Singapore family offices have nearly doubled their average assets under management to US$857 million, surpassing the Asia-Pacific average of US$445 million, according to the Global Family Office Report 2017. This represents a significant increase in investment performance, with Singapore FOs registering a 6.6% return in 2016, compared to a 7% global average. Asian FOs are increasingly focusing on private investments and impact investing, with 67% of Singapore FOs in the process of developing a succession plan, ahead of the regional average.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Jurong Port, Oiltanking launch joint venture for new petrochemical terminal
summary: Jurong Port and Oiltanking launched a joint venture, Jurong Port Tank Terminals (JPTT), to develop and operate a new liquid bulk terminal in Singapore. The terminal will be supported by four jetties and operational in phases from 2019. The joint venture aims to bolster trading and storage of petrochemical products in Singapore, meeting the demand for supporting infrastructure emerging from petrochemical product flows into South-east Asia. The terminal will connect via pipelines to Jurong Island, enhancing Jurong Port's strategic vision of becoming a world-class multipurpose port operator.

site_title: UK retail sales surge in August, likely to boost BOE rate hike bets
summary: UK retail sales surged 1% in August, beating economists' forecasts, and rose 2.4% year-over-year, boosting bets on a November interest rate hike. The data, which smoothed out monthly volatility, showed a 1.2% growth rate over the three months to August, despite inflation pressures. Retail sales growth was driven by non-essential purchases and online sales, while food purchases declined. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in November if the economy and inflation pressures strengthen as expected.

site_title: Surging bond yields underpin Aussie dollar; kiwi near 1-month high
summary: The Australian dollar held above 80 cents due to rising government bond yields, which reached their highest since late 2015. Higher yields have supported the Aussie dollar, while analysts at ANZ and National Australia Bank predict the Reserve Bank of Australia will hike rates by 50 basis points in 2018. The New Zealand dollar rose to a one-month high, while investors await the Federal Reserve's meeting on Thursday, anticipating a possible rate hike.

site_title: Asia tanker rates hit multi-month high as vessels divert to US, Mexico
summary: Asia's oil tanker rates have surged to a multi-month high due to vessels diverting to ship fuel to the US and Mexico after Hurricane Harvey. Rates for Long-Range 1 tankers reached 143 World Scale points, while Medium-Range tankers jumped 38% to 203 points. The shortage of vessels has been compounded by traders holding fuel on expectations of tighter supply and improved demand in the fourth quarter, with some tankers being used as temporary storage for gasoil.

site_title: Swissco judicial managers get US$28.5m offer from white knight investor
summary: Swissco Holdings' court-appointed judicial managers have accepted a US$28.5 million offer from Asian Strategic Turnaround Ventures Pte Ltd to sell shares in three Swissco-related entities and 26 vessels. The deal involves the acquisition of Swissco Offshore Pte Ltd and Singapore Marine (SM) Logistics, with a US$4 million loan to discharge mortgages. The transaction, subject to conditions, is expected to result in a US$12.7 million net loss from disposal based on the assets' aggregate net book value as of December 31, 2016.

site_title: Opec has success at last, but oil revival may be short-lived
summary: OPEC's production cuts, led by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Russia, have been successful in clearing a global oil glut, with crude prices rebounding to a three-month high and fuel inventories shrinking. However, the strategy may be short-lived as US shale oil continues to thrive and seasonal demand wanes, potentially leading to a surplus in 2018. OPEC officials are considering extending the production cuts by at least three months to avoid oversupplying the market again, but deeper cuts may be necessary to achieve long-term goals.

site_title: Poh Tiong Choon chairman makes S$1.30/shr takeover offer
summary: A consortium led by Poh Tiong Choon Logistics' chairman, Poh Choon Ann, is making a S$1.30/shr takeover offer, valuing the company at S$275.5 million. The offer has obtained irrevocable undertakings from 66.7% of owners, and if accepted, Poh Tiong Choon will be privatised and delisted from the Singapore Exchange. The offer price represents a 32.5% premium to the 1-month volume weighted average price per share. The company's low trading volume and challenging business environment are cited as reasons for the offer.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia shares trim losses to end slightly lower; NZ up
summary: Australian shares closed marginally lower on Wednesday, falling 0.1% to 5,709.10, after early losses were trimmed by gains in health care and industrial stocks. Commonwealth Bank rose, while Westpac and ANZ Banking Group fell. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise the cash rate by 50 basis points in 2018, according to ANZ, which may impact the housing market. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.7% to a one-week closing high.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip before Fed
summary: Europe's main stock markets dipped at the start of trading on Wednesday, influenced by the Federal Reserve's expected announcement to end its economic stimulus program. London's FTSE 100 index fell a few points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also declined 0.1%. The US stock market, however, continued its upward trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty and divided Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Football: Giggs and Scholes no-show angers India fans
summary: Manchester United legends Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes have angered Indian fans by failing to participate in a futsal tournament in Bangalore, despite billing themselves as star attractions. The pair, 42 and 43 years old respectively, were initially "tired" upon arrival and did not appear in the first game, sparking outrage among fans who paid up to $156 for tickets. The event, which also features former stars Ronaldinho and Hernan Crespo, will continue in Dubai next week.

site_title: UK businesses least confident about outlook since Brexit
summary: Confidence among UK small businesses and employers has fallen to its lowest level since the Brexit vote, according to two surveys. Rising labor costs, taxation, and rent are key concerns, while exporters are more optimistic due to the pound's decline. The UK economy expanded 0.3% in the second quarter, below the average of Group of Seven nations, and inflation has risen to almost 3%. The Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned of labor shortages and inflationary pressures due to Brexit, echoing concerns from the Recruitment and Employment Confederation.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares flat, Nintendo jumps on Switch console hopes
summary: Tokyo shares remained flat on Wednesday, ending at 20,310.46, after reaching a two-year high. However, Nintendo surged 1.7% on expectations of strong sales for its Switch console. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.05% and the Topix index rose 0.04%. The gains were driven by hopes for Nintendo's console, but the overall market remained stable.

site_title: New Zealand fuel shortage disrupts air travel just days before poll
summary: A fuel shortage crisis in New Zealand has disrupted air travel, with over 100 flights cancelled and many more delayed, just days before a national election. The crisis is due to damage to a pipeline carrying jet fuel to Auckland airport. The government has set up a commission and called in the military to help truck in fuel supplies. Despite initial concerns, economists say the direct economic impact is relatively minor, but the international reputation of the country could be affected.

site_title: Ambani's Jio free model gets boost as India cuts connection fees
summary: India's Telecom Regulatory Authority has cut interconnection fees for telecom operators, benefiting Reliance Jio's free data and voice services. The reduction, starting Oct 1, is expected to boost Jio's earnings by 76% by March 2019, according to Morgan Stanley analysts. The move is seen as a blow to rival Bharti Airtel, Vodafone India, and Idea Cellular, which have blamed Jio's free services for their declining growth. Jio's shares rose 4%, while Bharti Airtel and Idea fell 6.3% and 7.6%, respectively.

site_title: Great Eastern to sell stake in Malaysian ops for US$1b: report
summary: Great Eastern Holdings Ltd plans to sell its stake in Malaysian operations for US$1 billion, citing a June 2018 deadline requiring 30% local ownership. Foreign insurers Prudential and Tokio Marine also plan to sell close to a third of their Malaysian units, potentially raising US$3 billion. Malaysian institutional funds, such as the Employees Provident Fund, are reportedly potential buyers. The sales aim to comply with the local ownership requirement and increase local participation in the industry.

site_title: Hot stock: ASTI shares up 22.5% amid advanced talks to divest STI Group
summary: ASTI Holdings shares rose 22.5% on Wednesday following an announcement that a Chinese company, China Fortune-Tech Capital Co, is in advanced talks to acquire its wholly owned subsidiary STI Group. The technology group aims to strengthen its balance sheet and explore other opportunities. Negotiations for the potential S$105-115 million deal are ongoing.

site_title: Amazon working on 'smart glasses' as its first wearable device
summary: Amazon is reportedly working on its first wearable device, a pair of "smart glasses" that will allow users to summon its digital assistant Alexa at any time. The device features a bone-conduction audio system, enabling users to hear Alexa without wearing headphones. This move comes after Alphabet Inc reintroduced its Google Glass headset earlier this year. Amazon has not commented on the report.

site_title: Toshiba selects Bain group as buyer of its memory chip business: sources
summary: Toshiba has selected Bain Capital's group as the buyer of its prized memory chip business, worth around $22 billion. The decision was made by Toshiba's board and will be announced later on Wednesday. The auction process has been marked by revised bids, changing alliances, and legal wrangling from chip joint venture partner Western Digital, which still has concerns over its stake in the business. Toshiba needs to clinch a deal by the end of the financial year to avoid delisting and financial issues.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, ST Engineering, UEL
summary: Keppel Corp, ST Engineering, and United Engineers Limited (UEL) saw significant developments. Keppel Land bought a prime site in Jakarta to build a luxury apartment tower, while ST Engineering's Corporate Venture Capital unit invested in Janus Technologies Inc. UEL's takeover offer lapsed due to insufficient takers, and several independent directors stepped down.

site_title: Great Eastern's 3-year 2.05% endowment plan selling well: company official
summary: Great Eastern's three-year 2.05% endowment plan is selling well, according to a company official. The plan, which provides coverage against death and total and permanent disability, offers a guaranteed payout of 2.05% per annum. The minimum and maximum single premium is S$10,000 to S$500,000, respectively. The plan's take-up rate is higher than expected, and customers can enjoy straight-through application with no medical underwriting. This is a higher guaranteed return compared to a similar five-year plan launched in 2015.

site_title: UK property slowdown continues as prices fall for 5th month
summary: UK house prices fell 0.2% in August, marking the fifth consecutive monthly decline, with the annual gain weakening to its weakest since 2012. The average price dropped to £297,398, down 2.1% from the previous year. The slowdown is attributed to the impact of Brexit and inflation, as well as payback from years of rapid price gains. Regions like the east of England are closing the gap with traditionally strong performers like the south-east, driven by first-time buyers seeking more affordable housing.

site_title: Magnitude 6.1 earthquake strikes south of New Zealand: USGS
summary: A magnitude 6.1 earthquake struck the remote Southern Ocean south of New Zealand on September 20, 2017, at a shallow depth of 10 km west of the sub-Antarctic Auckland Island. The USGS reported no tsunami warnings were issued.

site_title: Maersk sells oil tankers to owner, opening door to Mitsui
summary: A.P. Moller-Maersk has agreed to sell its oil tanker division to its controlling shareholder for $1.71 billion, paving the way for a potential partnership with Japan's Mitsui & Co. The sale, expected to close by next month, will not impact Maersk's financial guidance for 2017 and will be used to reduce debt. This follows the company's restructuring efforts to focus on transport and logistics, which included the sale of its oil and gas business to Total last month for $7.45 billion.

site_title: Malaysia's August inflation rate picks up to 3.7% y-o-y, just above forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index in August rose 3.7% from a year earlier, just above the forecasted 3.6% inflation rate. Fuel costs, with a 11.7% year-on-year increase, drove inflation, while food and non-alcoholic beverages also rose 4.3%. This marks an eight-year high of 5.1% in March. The central bank has set a 2017 inflation target of 3-4%.

site_title: LNG growth to propel oil and gas industry's carbon emissions: Wood Mackenzie
summary: LNG growth is expected to propel oil and gas industry's carbon emissions, with emissions from LNG production forecast to grow by 43% by 2025, surpassing the 22% increase in supply. The process of liquefying natural gas, which cools it to minus 160 degrees Celsius, is highly energy-intensive and emission-intensive. The world's top oil and gas companies, including ExxonMobil and Royal Dutch Shell, are under pressure to reduce emissions, with investors focusing on capping heat-trapping gas emissions and limiting methane emissions.

site_title: Broker's take: Stake sale in Great Eastern's Malaysia ops may unlock 'small value' for OCBC shareholders
summary: DBS Group research reported that a potential stake sale in Great Eastern's Malaysian operations may unlock "small value" for OCBC shareholders. Great Eastern is planning to sell a stake worth US$1 billion to meet Malaysian central bank requirements. The sale is expected to have minimal impact on OCBC's earnings, but will benefit both Great Eastern and OCBC's shareholders. DBS maintains its "buy" call with a target price of S$12.80.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO faces board grilling
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan faces a grilling from the bank's board amid growing investor frustration over the speed of his turnaround plans. Two years into his job, Cryan is expected to update the board on progress on integrating Postbank and planning for Brexit, with the bank's share price stabilizing but revenue still declining. Investors are calling for progress, warning that the bank will lose credibility if it doesn't see results, while Cryan signals a return to risk-taking to drive growth.

site_title: Australia shares slip on financials; NZ edges up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,699.9, their lowest in a week, as financials and materials stocks declined. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points in 2018, according to ANZ. This may impact the housing market, which is heavily leveraged. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% to 7,782.07, driven by gains in Auckland International Airport and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corporation.

site_title: Buffett calls pessimists about United States 'out of their mind'
summary: Warren Buffett expressed optimism about the United States' long-term prospects, despite growing global uncertainty. He stated that pessimists about the country's future are "out of their mind." This sentiment was shared during an event celebrating the 100th anniversary of Forbes magazine. Buffett's comments suggest that he remains confident in the US economy's ability to adapt and thrive over time.

site_title: Merkel's potato soup, beer and nudism: When Germany's election got weird
summary: Germany's general election, held on September 24, 2017, saw Chancellor Angela Merkel win her fourth term. The election was marked by unusual events, including a press conference where Merkel revealed her recipe for potato soup and her favorite foods and hobbies. Other candidates, such as Christian Lindner and Gregor Gysi, also shared personal anecdotes, including Lindner's weight loss and Gysi's nostalgia for nudism. Satirical parties like Die Partei and The Urban also made headlines with their outlandish promises and campaigns.

site_title: US Fed to announce stimulus drawdown, let rates stand
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady and announce the end of its post-financial crisis economic stimulus program during a two-day policy meeting on Wednesday. The Fed will also release its quarterly forecasts and assess recent trends in inflation, which has been low despite a recent spike. Policymakers are divided on the timing of future rate hikes, with some citing financial market risks and others focusing on inflation. Market odds for at least one rate increase by December are around 60%.

site_title: Microsoft promotes Xbox chief in sign games are big deal again
summary: Microsoft has promoted Xbox chief Phil Spencer to executive vice president, placing him on Satya Nadella's senior leadership team, highlighting the renewed importance of gaming at the company. This change comes after Nadella redefined gaming as a significant "other business" in 2014, after earlier considering exiting the gaming sector due to poor Xbox One sales and investor pressure. Since then, Spencer has stabilized Xbox sales, which reached $9 billion last year, and successfully integrated Minecraft into Microsoft's portfolio.

site_title: MAS sets up cyber security advisory panel
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a cyber security advisory panel to enhance the cyber resilience of Singapore's financial sector. The 11-member panel, comprising global cyber security thought leaders, will provide MAS with global perspectives on evolving technologies and cyber threats. The panel's members include experts from top financial institutions and cybersecurity firms. The inaugural meeting is scheduled for October 2017. The MAS aims to ensure Singapore's financial sector remains dynamic and secure in an increasingly digital world.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Zara-owner Inditex H1 gross margin eroded by strong euro
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a 9% rise in first-half profit to 1.37 billion euros, but its gross margin slipped due to the stronger euro. The company's Ebitda rose 9% to 2.29 billion euros. Despite a slightly missed forecast, sales at constant currency terms increased by 12% in the first seven weeks of the second half. The company's business model of responding to catwalk trends has allowed it to outperform rivals like H&M. The euro's fluctuation affects Inditex's results, making up more than half of its sales in non-euro currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, following a third consecutive record close on Wall Street, amid anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17% to 28,099.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.14% to 3,352.18.

site_title: Merkel's problem: Booming German economy is so 20th century
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's steady economy is a boon for her re-election bid, but underlying issues such as outdated broadband and education infrastructure threaten Germany's 21st-century competitiveness. Despite a low jobless rate, Merkel's government faces criticism for neglecting public investment and failing to catch up on digital benchmarks. Germany's strong economy, driven by high-productivity workers and a "social-market economy," is also facing challenges from protectionism and a shrinking population. Merkel's opponents promise a better digital future, but it remains unclear how much funding will be available for fiber-optic networks.

site_title: Major Australia terror attack 'inevitable'
summary: Australian authorities warn that a major terror attack is "inevitable" due to the threat posed by homegrown extremism. Assistant Commissioner Mark Murdoch stated that despite efforts to prevent attacks, "anything can happen at any time." The country has prevented 13 terror attacks in the past few years, but authorities remain concerned about the risk of attackers not on their radar. Concrete barriers have been installed in Sydney to counter vehicle attacks, and the national terror alert level remains at "probable," indicating a credible threat of a terrorist attack.

site_title: Airbus opens China A330 plant amid market push
summary: Airbus has opened its Chinese completion plant for A330 jets in Tianjin, marking a significant expansion into the world's fastest-growing aviation market. The plant, a joint venture between Airbus and Chinese companies, aims to boost demand for the firm's profitable but ageing wide-body jets. The first A330 jet delivered from the plant was handed over to Tianjin Airlines, marking a major milestone in Airbus' efforts to increase its presence in China. The centre was agreed upon during a 2014 visit by President Xi Jinping to France.

site_title: Temasek leads US$300m investment in electric scooter maker
summary: Gogoro Inc, an electric scooter maker backed by Panasonic, raised US$300 million from Singapore's Temasek Holdings Pte and other investors for expansion and R&D. The new funding brings the company's valuation to about US$800 million. Gogoro plans to use the investment to expand into more cities, following successful sales of over 30,000 scooters and the launch of scooter-sharing services in cities like Berlin and Paris. The investment is part of a growing trend in the sharing of electric vehicles in cities.

site_title: Online reactions to Singapore Grand Prix renewal largely positive: Meltwater
summary: The four-year renewal of the Singapore Grand Prix was well-received online by the majority of Singaporeans, with 76% of reactions to the last-minute deal being positive. Meltwater analyzed online reactions on forums, Twitter, and Instagram, finding Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel and Lewis Hamilton to be the top drivers, with 37% and 36% of social media chatter, respectively. The deal was seen as a positive for the city-state, generating record levels of interest on social media.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Meltwater analysed online reactions in the lead-up and during the F1 weekend between Sept 13-18 and found that 76 per cent of reactions to the last-minute deal were positive.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks tentative waiting for Fed; Trump's comments eyed
summary: South Korea's won and shares were subdued on Wednesday as investors waited for the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, despite US President Donald Trump's strong comments on North Korea. Trump's remarks, which included a threat to "totally destroy" North Korea, were seen as a factor in holding down the won. Analysts believe the cautious mood was due to uncertainty surrounding the Fed's decision. The won and shares were expected to wait for the Fed's outcome before making any significant moves.

site_title: ECB stimulus is finally reaching the whole eurozone
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus is finally reaching the entire eurozone, marking a significant step towards a sustained recovery. The transmission of ECB interest rates to business loans in southern European countries, such as Greece and Portugal, had been severed in 2013, but has now been restored. The ECB's targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) and quantitative easing have helped to lower lending costs to businesses, with over 80% of the overall amount taken up by periphery banks. This improvement in lending rates is seen as a crucial step towards a sustained economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Here's a sign the euro-area economy is on stronger footing. According to economist Benn Steil, it's the simple fact that monetary policy is actually working again.

site_title: Electronics manufacturing roadmap eyes 2,100 new jobs, S$22b in value-add by 2020: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's electronics sector aims to create 2,100 new jobs and achieve a manufacturing value-add of S$22.2 billion by 2020, driven by growth in mobile devices and emerging areas like autonomous vehicles, AI, and healthcare. The Electronics Industry Transformation Map (ITM) sets a two-pronged strategy: diversifying into new opportunities and transforming current manufacturing. To support this, the Skills Framework for Electronics was launched, identifying emerging skills and competencies for the sector.

site_title: Asia: Investors move cautiously as Fed decision approaches
summary: Asian markets are moving cautiously ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with investors wary of potential rate hikes. Despite a record-breaking third day on Wall Street, dealers are cashing in recent gains and sitting tight. The US dollar remains flat, while the Mexican peso fell 0.3% after a deadly earthquake. The US-North Korea stand-off has intensified, with Trump warning Pyongyang of "total destruction" if its nuclear ambitions are not curbed. Policymakers are expected to maintain current interest rates, with the main focus on the post-meeting statement and comments from Chair Janet Yellen.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.03 points lower at 1,776.63 on Wednesday, with 40.38 million lots traded worth RM17.51 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 55.

site_title: Fischer Tech's takeover offer scheme is fair, says independent financial adviser
summary: Fischer Tech's takeover offer by Platinum Equity at S$3.02 a share in cash is deemed fair and reasonable by its appointed independent financial adviser, Provenance Capital Pte Ltd. The adviser advised the directors to recommend shareholders vote in favour of the scheme, citing publicly available information and information provided by the directors. The opinion does not reflect future financial projections.

site_title: China's Xi demands "strong hands" to maintain stability ahead of Congress
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has emphasized the importance of maintaining stability, urging security officials to use "strong hands" to ensure the Communist Party's rule is not challenged. This comes ahead of the key Congress of the ruling party. Xi also stressed the importance of development and stability being dealt with simultaneously.

site_title: Third suspect arrested over London train attack: police
summary: British police arrested a 25-year-old man in Newport, Wales, on Tuesday as the third suspect in the bombing of a London Underground train that injured 30 people last week. The arrest follows a search at an address in Newport, according to the Metropolitan Police. This development brings the total number of suspects to three, as police continue their investigation into the attack.

site_title: US dollar falls as traders await possible move on Fed bond purchases
summary: The US dollar fell against a basket of currencies on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on shrinking its $4.2 trillion in bond holdings. Analysts expect the Fed to announce a lowering of monthly bond purchases starting in October, with some speculating a possible rate increase in December. The dollar's weakness is partly due to uncertainty over the Fed's move, which could cast doubt on a December rate hike.

site_title: Uber is said to review Asia dealings amid US criminal probe
summary: Uber is reviewing its Asia operations amid a US federal probe into potential overseas bribery, following reports of suspicious transactions in countries such as China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and South Korea. The company notified US officials about payments made by staff in Indonesia and is working with law firm O'Melveny & Myers to examine records and interview employees. Uber has cooperated with investigators but declined to comment further, amid mounting legal troubles that have led to the departure of several top executives.

site_title: GIC-led Greystar completes Monogram purchase for total transaction value of US$4.4b
summary: GIC's PERPETUAL-LIFE fund, through Greystar Growth & Income Fund, completed the acquisition of Monogram for US$4.4 billion. Monogram owns and operates high-quality apartment communities in select US coastal markets, with 48 multifamily communities and 13,438 apartment homes. The acquisition aligns with Greystar's long-term strategy and provides a valuable seed portfolio.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks take a breather after hitting two-year high
summary: Tokyo shares paused after reaching a two-year high on Tuesday. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.01% to 20,301.88, while the broader Topix index declined 0.12% to 1,665.91. This follows a day of gains as investors took a breather after a strong session.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 7.36 points to 3,218.59 at 9:05am. About 124 million shares worth S$73 million changed hands, with Blumont being the most actively traded stock. This marks a reversal of the 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which saw the index rise 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Quarterly reporting: the debate rages on
summary: Singapore is set to review its quarterly reporting requirements, with some arguing it should be left to shareholders to decide whether to continue the practice. Veteran investor Ang Hao Yao suggests a re-vote every 2-3 years, with restrictions on major shareholders with insider information. Others argue that quarterly reporting remains crucial for investors to make informed decisions. The debate highlights the ongoing debate on the importance and necessity of quarterly reporting in the region.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Pavilion Energy to gain access to UK and Rotterdam LNG terminals after deal with Uniper
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-owned company, has secured access to liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals in Rotterdam and the UK through an option swap agreement with Uniper. This deal allows Pavilion to access Gate LNG Terminal in Rotterdam and Grain LNG Terminal in the UK, while granting Uniper access to Singapore LNG Corporation's tank capacity. The agreement is expected to enhance Pavilion's LNG portfolio and create optimization opportunities, as Europe's demand for LNG is expected to grow in its efforts to reduce reliance on pipe gas.

site_title: Telecom stocks rally in quiet European markets on M&A talk
summary: European telecom stocks rose as much as 0.9% on Tuesday after CNBC reported that US wireless carriers T-Mobile US Inc and Sprint Corp were in active merger talks, with Deutsche Telekom being the biggest gainer. The sector's performance was a rare bright spot in quiet European markets, where investors awaited the outcome of a Federal Reserve meeting. Analysts said a recovery of telecom stocks was long overdue and recommended taking positions as any rally could be swift.

site_title: Indonesia to trace and tax assets kept hidden during amnesty
summary: Indonesia's government has issued new regulations to trace and tax assets kept hidden during a nine-month tax amnesty program. Despite 972,000 taxpayers declaring assets worth $495.58 billion, the government found discrepancies between declared and actual holdings, with 24% held offshore. The new regulations aim to tax undeclared assets, with a 30% final income tax rate for individuals, 25% for companies, and 12.5% for special cases, and will be enforced starting July 1, 2019.

site_title: A-Plus doesn't come easy for this homegrown firm
summary: A-Plus Automation, a Singapore-based homegrown firm, has successfully carved a niche in the materials management industry through its tough journey. Founded in 1979, the company started trading motors and components before expanding into automated materials handling systems for manufacturing and logistic companies in South-east Asia. A-Plus has built a reputation with big-name clients, including DHL Express Singapore and Kraft Foods Indonesia, and designs, manufactures, and installs automated systems for the food and e-commerce sectors.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to unblock internet calling apps
summary: Saudi Arabia is lifting its ban on internet calling applications, including WhatsApp and Skype, allowing voice and video calls to be widely available to users. The move aims to improve business confidence and reduce operational costs, as the kingdom transitions into a post-oil era. The decision comes after criticism over censorship, following the blocking of Al Jazeera from Snapchat's app at the request of Saudi authorities. The government defends its actions, citing concerns over extremism, while human rights groups have criticized the move as an assault on freedom of expression.

site_title: Qatar emir again urges dialogue, Trump says dispute to be resolved quickly
summary: Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani urged "unconditional dialogue" to resolve a crisis with four Arab states, including Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Egypt, and Bahrain, which cut diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in June. US President Donald Trump expressed confidence that the dispute would be resolved "pretty quickly." The crisis stems from Qatar's alleged support for regional foe Iran and Islamists, with Kuwait mediating and the US taking a more active role in trying to resolve the issue.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets in talks with Burwill over final prepayment of A$4.375m
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets (AMA) is in talks with Burwill Holdings Ltd over the final prepayment of A$4.375 million, due on September 15, 2017, under a lithium concentrate offtake agreement. The Australian miner has received A$8.125 million from Burwill to date, with the total prepayment amounting to A$12.5 million. The outcome of the discussion is uncertain, and AMA will update when there are material developments. The agreement is for the supply of lithium concentrate from AMA's Bald Hill Project in Western Australia for an initial five-year term.

site_title: ASTI enters term sheet to divest units to China-based firm
summary: ASTI Holdings, a Singapore-listed technology group, has entered a non-binding term sheet with China Fortune-Tech Capital Co (CFTC) to divest its STI Group, which designs and manufactures semiconductor equipment, for S$105-115 million. The deal aims to strengthen ASTI's balance sheet and enable it to explore other opportunities. Negotiations are ongoing, with a two-month exclusivity period for CFTC to complete due diligence. The move follows ASTI's current financial struggles, including a six-month loss of S$3.59 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US: Wall St edges higher; US Fed meeting in focus
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday, logging closing records, with financial stocks providing the biggest boost ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 39.45 points, or 0.18%, to a record close. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also hit new highs. Investors are closely watching the Fed's decision on reducing its balance sheet and potential interest rate hikes in December.

site_title: SGX carrots for good compliance? One idea mooted is fast-track approval
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) CEO Tan Boon Gin suggests using "carrots" to encourage companies to improve their corporate governance, potentially offering fast-tracked approval for compliant companies. Industry players welcome the idea, citing the importance of time-to-market in the volatile business environment. However, implementation details, such as criteria for fast-tracking, are yet to be determined, and concerns about fairness and transparency arise.

site_title: Britain's young shoulder burden of housing crisis, while older reap profits: study
summary: Britain's young families are shouldering a significant burden due to the country's housing crisis, spending nearly a quarter of their income on housing costs. In contrast, older homeowners are reaping profits from the shortage. A 50-year analysis by the Resolution Foundation found that millennials are half as likely to own their homes as their parents and spend 6% more on housing. The crisis has drained living standards of millennials, while enriching older generations, with average house prices more than doubling in the past two decades.

site_title: Japan exports surge at fastest in nearly 4 years on global demand
summary: Japan's exports surged 18.1% in August, the fastest pace in nearly four years, driven by strong demand for cars and electronics. This marks a ninth consecutive month of expansion and exceeds the median estimate of a 14.7% annual rise. The country's trade balance turned into a surplus of 113.6 billion yen, with exports to China and the US increasing significantly. The strong export growth is seen as supporting healthy economic growth, but the Bank of Japan is expected to keep monetary policy on hold due to low inflation.

site_title: Oil edges off recent high ahead US stock data, Opec meet
summary: Oil prices retreated from near five-month highs ahead of a meeting between key oil producers on supply cuts. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is discussing options for extending its 1.8-million barrel-per-day supply cut deal. US oil futures remained in a tight range, closing between US$49 and US$50 a barrel. Brent crude futures settled down 34 cents at US$55.14 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell 43 cents to US$49.48.

site_title: Mexico quake death toll rises to 65: official
summary: A 7.1-magnitude earthquake struck Mexico, killing at least 65 people, with the hardest hit being the state of Morelos, which reported 42 deaths. Puebla and Mexico state also experienced significant loss of life. The quake, which occurred on Tuesday, has raised concerns about the country's disaster preparedness.

site_title: PM Lee, Premier Li reaffirm long-standing S'pore-China ties
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reaffirmed the long-standing friendship between Singapore and China during a 3-day official visit to China. They discussed economic cooperation, the Belt and Road Initiative, and regional developments, while also expressing concern over the Korean Peninsula tensions. Premier Li accepted an invitation to visit Singapore, and the two leaders agreed to promote stronger Asean-China cooperation during their respective chairmanships.

site_title: Bayer, Viking make record bet on agricultural tech
summary: Bayer AG has joined forces with hedge fund Viking Global Investors to invest $100 million in a new agricultural technology venture, the largest ever in the sector. The venture aims to reduce farm nitrogen fertilizer waste, focusing on gene modification and mimicking genomes of nitrogen-providing crops. Bayer's CEO Axel Bouchon stated that the large investment allows the companies to focus on the challenge of nitrogen waste over the next four to five years, citing the need for "big tools" to tackle the issue.

site_title: Britain to promise 20 billion euros in Brexit bill: FT
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to promise a Brexit divorce bill of at least 20 billion euros (S$32 billion) when she delivers a speech in Florence on Friday. The offer is part of the UK's financial obligations to the European Union when it leaves the bloc, currently set for March 29, 2019. This figure is lower than Brussels' preliminary evaluation of 60-100 billion euros. The UK has yet to put forward a definitive figure, with the government previously stating it would challenge the EU's proposed amount.

site_title: Mobile, cashless payments will drive new economy
summary: Stripe SEA head Piruze Sabuncu emphasizes mobile and cashless payments as the backbone of the new economy. Businesses can benefit from mobile payments by offering more services, improving user experience, and leveraging data to optimize services. A cashless society can provide valuable insights into consumer behavior, allowing businesses to make informed decisions. However, user experience is a key factor in adopting cashless payments, and friction in the process can deter consumers. Sabuncu notes that mobile payments can increase reach, making services available globally.

site_title: Britain suspends Myanmar military training
summary: Britain has suspended its military training courses for the Myanmar military due to the ongoing ethnic violence in Rakhine state. The decision comes after deadly attacks on police posts by Muslim minority Rohingya militants on August 25. London expressed "deep concern" over human rights abuses and will not resume the courses unless an "acceptable resolution" to the crisis is reached. The suspension follows communal violence in western Rakhine state, where thousands of Rohingya have fled.

site_title: Equifax suffered hack earlier than disclosed
summary: Equifax, a 118-year-old credit reporting agency, suffered a major breach of its computer systems in March, nearly five months before publicly disclosing the incident in September 2017. The breach was not related to the hack that exposed 143 million US consumers' personal and financial data. Equifax hired security firm Mandiant on both occasions, with the first breach possibly going unnoticed until July 29. The revelation complicates efforts to explain a series of unusual stock sales by Equifax executives, potentially leading to charges of insider trading. Investigations and lawsuits are underway, seeking answers about how the breach occurred and why executives sold shares before the public disclosure.

site_title: Disruption in the boardroom
summary: Singaporean boards face increasing pressure from shareholders, technology, and a changing business landscape. To succeed, they must reinvent themselves, focusing on core objectives of good corporate governance, such as building trust, creating long-term value, and ensuring sustainable growth. Embedding a strong ethical culture is crucial, with a "walk-the-talk" approach and clear policies and practices. Boards must navigate challenges like disruption, cybersecurity, and quarterly reporting, while maintaining transparency and accountability. Independent directors play a key role in safeguarding shareholders' interests and providing diverse perspectives. To address corporate failures, companies must be vigilant and assess their corporate integrity, ethics, and accountability.

site_title: Chartered accountants body develops sustainability reporting guide
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) has developed a sustainability reporting implementation roadmap to aid new adopters in starting their sustainability reporting journey. The roadmap provides practical guidance on the implementation process and key considerations for the company's first sustainability report. This move aims to support Singaporean companies in adopting sustainability reporting standards.

site_title: CSA to set up academy, signs training MOU
summary: The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with ISACA to enhance Singapore's cybersecurity capabilities and workforce. The collaboration will use ISACA-developed training, assessment tools, and certification to bolster professional knowledge and performance in governance, risk, and compliance roles. The CSA will also establish a new academy to train cybersecurity professionals, with US-based cybersecurity firm FireEye as its first industry partner. The move aims to address the global shortage of one million cybersecurity professionals and develop a vibrant cybersecurity ecosystem in Singapore.

site_title: Wall St bond gurus may be wrong about QE unwind
summary: Wall Street bond experts believe the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing (QE) unwind will lead to rising US Treasury yields. However, historical data suggests this may not be the case. During each QE cycle, yields rose when the Fed bought and fell when it stopped, contradicting expectations based on supply and demand. This has occurred despite the Fed accumulating $4.5 trillion in debt and becoming the largest holder of Treasuries.

site_title: Insurers go from grudge to nudge with the help of real-time tech
summary: Insurers are shifting from a "grudge" to a "nudge" approach, using real-time technology to encourage safer behavior and reduce payouts. Investment in "insurtech" has surged to over $400 million in Europe, with the UK leading the way, as companies explore blockchain, big data, and artificial intelligence to mitigate risk. Regulators warn of risks, including data security and social exclusion, but insurers argue that technology can promote less risky behavior, such as safer driving and exercise habits.

site_title: US Reits headed here can only be a good thing
summary: Singapore is poised to welcome its second US real estate investment trust (Reit), KBS-Keppel Capital Reit, which will list on the Singapore Exchange. The Reit, managed by KBS Realty and Keppel Capital, will offer an estimated 7% investment yield, despite its portfolio consisting mainly of office assets in suburban US markets. The listing is seen as a positive signal for Singapore's Reit market, which has struggled with limited listings this year. The partnership between KBS Realty and Keppel Capital is expected to bring credibility to future Reit listings by foreign firms, offering yield-loving investors a new option for Reits with overseas assets.

site_title: New weapons to counter cybersecurity threats
summary: Artificial intelligence and machine learning are being developed to counter cybersecurity threats. Symantec, the largest cybersecurity company, uses these technologies to analyze over 10 trillion security events per year. Machine learning focuses on threat detection, anomaly detection, and user behavior analysis, while AI has yet to make a big impact on cybersecurity. New tools using machine learning and AI can detect unknown malware, anomalies, and potential threats, making security analysts more productive. The goal is to build intelligence security systems that can learn faster than threats and predict new attacks, providing a force multiplier for cybersecurity centers.

site_title: Raising the bar on Singapore's corporate governance
summary: Singapore's corporate governance is being re-evaluated following recent corporate debacles. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering requiring boards to publish internal audit reports detailing lapses and proposed actions. This move aims to increase accountability and transparency, following a "gentrification" of corporate governance in the Singapore market. Foreign corporations listed in Singapore face Singapore laws on mismanagement and fraud, but enforcement remains a challenge if perpetrators are outside Singapore's jurisdiction. The proposed change seeks to strengthen the culture of corporate governance in the country's listed companies.

site_title: Weak wage growth has Aussies stuck in debt trap
summary: Australia's average weekly household income has grown by a mere A$27 since 2008, with wages growth remaining stagnant. Despite a strong labour market, households are trapped in debt due to stagnant wages and rising housing costs. A Reserve Bank of Australia interest-rate increase is unlikely, and the economy is expected to continue growing, but at a slower pace than other major countries. The labour market's spare capacity remains a concern, and wage growth is expected to take time to improve.

site_title: STI pulls back as Fed ponders tightening
summary: The Straits Times Index dropped 15.9 points to 3,225.95 on Tuesday, following subdued trading due to caution ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting. The index was weighed down by banks, Jardine stocks, Singtel, and ComfortDelGro, with ComfortDelGro falling S$0.06 to S$2.01. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research and UOB-Kay Hian, expect the Fed to announce plans to unwind its balance sheet and tighten monetary conditions, potentially affecting emerging markets.

site_title: Chinese skiers cool off at world's largest indoor ski park
summary: China's world's largest indoor ski park, the Ice and Snow Park in Harbin, has opened, marking the country's ambitions to become a winter sports powerhouse ahead of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. The 80,000-square-meter facility features six runs, including the longest 500-meter slope, and offers affordable skiing options, with a day pass costing 488 yuan ($100). The park is expected to boost China's skiing population, which currently numbers six million, with the government aiming to increase the number to 300 million by 2030.

site_title: China boosts purchases of US Treasuries in July
summary: China increased its purchases of US Treasuries for the sixth consecutive month in July, with its holdings rising to $1.17 trillion, making it the largest non-US holder. The Chinese yuan's appreciation against the US dollar this year has reduced the need for China to sell its US debt, and foreign investors sold $490 million in Treasuries in July, after purchasing $19.7 billion in June. Global central banks increased their US Treasury holdings to $6.25 trillion in July.

site_title: Good time for investors to take stock
summary: Financial markets are experiencing a period of relative calm, with most risk indicators at benign levels. A continued move towards reflation, with stronger growth and modestly higher inflation, remains a likely economic scenario, with a 35% probability. However, market expectations of inflation are lower, increasing the likelihood of a muddle-through environment, with a 40% probability. Investors can benefit from a diversified income-seeking strategy combining equity, fixed income, and hybrid assets, which is expected to deliver a 4-5% yield alongside positive total returns.

site_title: Utilities line up to profit from 'slowest trainwreck' in history
summary: Europe's largest utilities, Enel and EON, predict that only companies with diverse portfolios and resources can compete against subsidy-free renewable energy projects. The cost of electricity from offshore wind farms is expected to drop by 71% over the next two decades, making solar and renewable energy more competitive. This trend is expected to lead to consolidation in the market, with only "good performers" able to make a profit. Companies must adapt to new challenges from upstart wind and solar newcomers to remain competitive.

site_title: Dollar hits 8-week high against yen as Fed meets
summary: The dollar reached an 8-week high against the yen as the US Federal Reserve met, with investors anticipating potentially hawkish statements. The Swiss franc hit a multi-year low against the euro, and safe-haven currencies like the yen and franc are expected to remain under pressure as long as the US maintains a diplomatic approach to the North Korean crisis. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates on hold but may start paring its balance sheet, with investors watching for hints on future rate hikes.

site_title: Hackers compromised free CCleaner software
summary: Hackers compromised the free CCleaner software, a computer performance optimization tool, potentially affecting over 2 million users. The malicious program was inserted into legitimate CCleaner software, which is downloaded 5 million times a week. Researchers discovered the attack, which included remote administration tools, in August, and Piriform's parent company Avast uncovered the issue on September 12. A new, uncompromised version of CCleaner was released, and users are advised to download the updated software to avoid potential control of their devices.

site_title: Paying Homage to the elderly in Singapore
summary: Gillian Tee, a Singaporean entrepreneur, founded Homage, a start-up providing in-home care services for the elderly, in 2016. The business aims to offer holistic care, including medication management, personal care, and rehabilitation services, to help seniors live with dignity and independence at home. With over 300 carefully-screened professionals and 30,000 hours of caregiving provided, Homage has grown significantly since its inception. Tee's goal is to differentiate her business from traditional home care agencies using technology and provide a more personalized experience for seniors and their families.

site_title: China's small and weak developers may be hurt by 250b yuan bond puts
summary: China's small and weak property developers face a significant threat from 250 billion yuan (S$51 billion) of bond put options set to mature in 2018, which investors can force them to repay early. Rising interest rates and tightening funding conditions have pushed local bonds to high yields, making early repayment more likely. This could lead to financial pressure on lower-rated developers, with some analysts warning of increased liquidity strains.

site_title: Car-mad Germany cool towards tech gizmos of driverless cars
summary: Germany's car enthusiasts remain skeptical about self-driving cars, despite prominent displays at the IAA international auto show in Frankfurt. Visitors can test drive a specially created car on a track, but most Germans are hesitant to adopt the technology. The country's car culture and emphasis on manual driving may hinder widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles.

images.alt_text: An Audi AG Elaine electric concept autonomous car at the 67th IAA (International Motor Show). Germans largely believe that driving has to be enjoyable, and that automated cars take this away.

site_title: Rewarding good governance
summary: The Bursa Malaysia has introduced a "Green Lane Policy" to reward top-listed companies that practice good corporate governance and disclosure practices. The policy grants privileges, such as faster issuance of circulars to shareholders, to these companies, aiming to recognize and encourage good governance. This approach balances regulatory "sticks" with "carrots" or incentives, similar to the US "Well-Known Seasoned Issuer" program, which allows companies to register securities without paying registration fees for timely reporting. The policy will be reviewed periodically and may expand to include more companies.

site_title: Sunseap bags S$75m investment from listed Thai utility Banpu
summary: Singapore's Sunseap Group secured an S$75 million investment from Thai utility Banpu Public Company Limited, valuing the group at S$300 million. The investment will be used for solar projects across Asia, leveraging Banpu's networks and expertise. The partnership highlights the growing momentum in the alternative energy market, driven by technological advancements, price parity, and consumer support. Sunseap plans to tap Banpu's resources and expertise, while Banpu aims to capture a new era in the energy industry through its "Banpu Greener and Smarter" strategy.

site_title: Canadian PM threatens to halt Boeing F-18 deal over Bombardier dispute
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has threatened to halt a $5.23 billion deal to buy Boeing F-18 fighter jets due to the company's pursuit of a trade challenge against Montreal-based Bombardier Inc. over its commercial aircraft. Trudeau stated that Canada won't do business with Boeing while the company pursues the challenge, citing concerns over the impact on Canadian aerospace workers. Both Trudeau and UK Prime Minister Theresa May have pressed the US to drop the challenge, which is currently being investigated by the US Commerce Department.

site_title: Ryanair scrambles to contain damage from cancellation fiasco
summary: Ryanair has scrambled to contain damage from scrapping hundreds of flights until the end of October, affecting 400,000 passengers. The airline will compensate passengers and apologize for the mismanagement, which stemmed from scheduling too many pilots for vacation. Ryanair expects a 25 million euro profit hit from refunds and compensation. The company will also hire additional crew, including signing bonuses and poaching from insolvent airlines, to prevent future issues.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A takeover offer for United Engineers Limited (UEL) lapsed due to insufficient takers, with Yanlord Perennial Investment securing 34.8% of the ordinary shares.
