Cisco signed a MOU with ST Electronics to provide managed detection and response security services. Loyz Energy proposed a name change and entered into a binding agreement for a new joint venture. Spackman Entertainment acquired a 10% equity interest in NSY Group Pte Ltd, and Rowsley appointed Credit Suisse as its financial adviser for a proposed acquisition of Sasteria Pte Ltd.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage Public Company's target price is set at S$1.07, unchanged, despite a 2.2% drop in stock price to S$0.91. The company's forecast remains unchanged due to the relatively muted excise tax increase. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's rating is downgraded to Hold due to a tenant's arrears and potential impact on future income streams. OCBC Investment Research downgrades CGSI to Hold, citing slowing earnings growth in H2.

images.alt_text: Thailand announced new excise taxes, which roughly translate to 1-5 per cent of average selling price (ASP), effective Sept 16.

site_title: Egypt plays down poppy seed spat threatening wheat supply
summary: Egypt has eased a dispute over poppy seeds in wheat cargoes, authorizing the unloading of two shipments held up at its Safaga port. The issue arose from confusion over red and pink poppy flowers, with some traders concerned they could be used to produce narcotics. Egyptian officials have assured the public that non-toxic poppies are common in Europe and cannot be used for narcotics. The move aims to avoid a potential boycott and disruption to food supplies, which are already strained due to high inflation and rising prices.

site_title: French Connection's profit falls as store closures hit sales
summary: French Connection Group, a British fashion retailer, reported a drop in profit for the half-year due to store closures and increased competition from fast-fashion rivals. Gross profit fell to £31.1 million, down from £38.1 million year ago, and revenue decreased to £68.1 million. The company closed 7 stores in the last 12 months, reducing trading space by 10.2%. Despite this, revenue at its wholesale operation rose 7.2%. French Connection aims to return to profitability through strategic store openings and management changes.

site_title: Keppel Land buying prime site in Jakarta CBD for 586b rupiah
summary: Keppel Land is acquiring a prime site in Jakarta's central business district for 586 billion rupiah (S$60 million) to build a luxury apartment tower. The site, adjacent to International Financial Centre Jakarta, will yield about 400 luxury apartments and has a total development cost of S$170 million. The transaction is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year. The luxury tower is expected to meet the needs of a growing expatriate and local business community in the city center.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Google shuffles top policy team amid ongoing antitrust cases
summary: Google has shuffled its top policy team amid ongoing antitrust cases, including a record $2.7 billion fine from the EU for abusing its market position. Caroline Atkinson, who headed global policy efforts, is stepping aside and will focus on external-facing work, while Leslie Miller, a Google policy director, will manage the team on an interim basis. The move comes as Google faces rising regulatory scrutiny in the US, including calls for tougher competition enforcement, with a Senate antitrust subcommittee introducing legislation to modernize antitrust enforcement.

site_title: Malaysia angling for tax revenue from foreign digital-services firms
summary: Malaysia plans to amend tax laws to require foreign digital-services companies operating in the country to pay taxes, despite the challenges posed by the internet's borderless nature. The move aims to boost revenue collection by "a couple of billions of ringgit" and could be implemented when Parliament convenes next month. However, experts warn that identifying and taxing these companies could be difficult, and a global effort would be needed to implement such a tax. The government's goal is to collect RM42 billion from GST this year, with the amendment potentially affecting companies like Airbnb and overseas dating sites.

site_title: ST Telemedia unit begins construction of sixth Singapore data centre
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) has begun construction on its sixth data centre in Singapore, STT Defu 2, which is expected to be completed in the second half of 2018. The 150,000 sq ft, Tier 3-standard facility will be connected to other STT GDC properties in Singapore, offering customers network connectivity options. The construction starts as the company rapidly expands capacity globally, with over 50 data centres worldwide.

site_title: S'pore, China establish framework for resolving Belt and Road disputes
summary: Singapore and China have established a framework to help businesses resolve cross-border disputes related to the Belt and Road Initiative. The two countries signed a Memorandum of Understanding, allowing the Singapore International Mediation Centre and the Mediation Center of the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade to jointly serve companies in both countries and other BRI markets. This move aims to build trust and confidence among governments, investors, and people through a rule-based, neutral, and stable framework.

site_title: Buying a home? Compare building quality scores on BCA website
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has launched a new tool allowing homebuyers to compare the quality of workmanship of developers and their projects. The "Search for Quality Housing" function on the BCA website compiles building quality scores from the Construction Quality Assessment System (Conquas) and Quality Mark. This will enable buyers to make more informed decisions, particularly for uncompleted projects, by comparing scores of developers and contractors. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong encouraged developers to publish these scores in their sales documents for greater transparency.

site_title: Dividend sanctity takes a hit in Australia, world's top yielding market
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest phone company, has ended its 20-year run of steady dividends, citing the need to invest in new technology. This move could undermine Australia's reputation as a dividend-heavy stock market. Other companies, such as Santos Ltd and TPG Telecom Ltd, have also announced dividend freezes or cuts, citing rising capital expenditure. The decision may lead to investors seeking alternative income sources, potentially favoring mining stocks.

site_title: US may have to 'totally destroy' North Korea, warns Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump warned at the UN that the US will "totally destroy" North Korea unless it backs down from its nuclear challenge, calling its leader a "rocket man" on a "suicide mission." Trump also denounced governments in Syria, Iran, and Venezuela, urging UN member states to work together to isolate the Kim government. He emphasized that the US will defend its interests, but also seeks a world order based on strong, sovereign nations.

site_title: Disrupting the stock exchange
summary: A US entrepreneur, Eric Ries, has launched the Long-Term Stock Exchange (LTSE), aiming to disrupt the stock exchange system. The exchange, backed by venture-capital investors, will have voting rights for investors based on the length of time they own shares, new disclosure policies, and a rewrite of compensation schemes to focus on long-term goals. This is part of a growing effort to fix the broken US public stock markets, which have seen a decline in companies going public and a rise in employee turnover due to the IPO process.

site_title: BT journalists win SIAS top and special awards
summary: The Securities Investors' Association of Singapore (SIAS) honored journalists from The Business Times (BT) and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) at the Investors' Choice Awards 2017. BT reporters Jamie Lee and Claire Huang won top awards for financial journalism, including Financial Journalist of the Year and Special Awards, respectively. The awards recognize their investigative reporting on fintech firms, healthcare costs, and insurance, shedding light on industry issues and consumer concerns. SPH also won the Singapore Corporate Governance Award, solidifying its commitment to transparency and corporate governance.

THEY GIVE YOU NEWS YOU CAN USE: Correspondents of The Business Times Claire Huang (left) and Jamie Lee being honoured on Tuesday night for their work, with awards presented by the Singapore Investors Association Singapore (SIAS).

site_title: Billionaire Leong said to buy London building for £250m
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Angela Leong has purchased a 174,000 square foot building in London's Aldwych district for approximately £250 million. The building, which has been leased to tenants including WeWork Cos and the ROKA restaurant, was sold by Rowan Asset Management and GI Partners LLC. Leong, married to casino magnate Stanley Ho, has a net worth of $3.7 billion and has invested heavily in London's commercial real estate market following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Ageing populations pose challenges but present business opportunities for Asia: Deloitte
summary: Deloitte's report highlights Asia's rapidly ageing population as a significant business opportunity, with the number of people over 65 expected to grow from 365 million in 2017 to over 1 billion by the mid-21st century. This demographic shift is expected to drive growth in healthcare and related sectors, as well as private sector opportunities in asset management, insurance, and financial services. Countries such as Singapore, China, Vietnam, and Australia will experience slower economic growth due to ageing populations, but will also see increased demand for healthcare and related services.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Global markets in for some shocks as a result of monetary tapering
summary: Global markets are bracing for potential shocks as central banks consider tapering their monetary stimulus. The US Federal Reserve, Bank of England, and Bank of Canada are expected to reduce their balance sheets and raise interest rates, while the European Central Bank will decide on its own monetary stimulus phase-out. This tightening of monetary policy could lead to higher interest rates, impacting corporate debt, emerging markets, and exchange rates. Experts warn that global markets are unprepared for these changes, which could lead to significant financial instability.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us files for bankruptcy protection in US
summary: Toys "R" Us Inc has filed for bankruptcy protection in the US, citing over $5 billion in long-term debt. However, its Asian joint venture, Toys "R" Us (Asia), remains unaffected and is reportedly expanding, with plans to open new stores in China, Hong Kong, and other markets. The company's Asian operations are financially independent from its US parent, and President Andre Javes stated that the Asian business is "very focused on delivering full-year results" despite the US parent's financial struggles.

site_title: Rowsley appoints Credit Suisse (Singapore) as financial adviser in proposed acquisition
summary: Rowsley Limited has appointed Credit Suisse (Singapore) as its financial adviser in the proposed acquisition of Sasteria Pte Ltd. The acquisition is valued at up to S$1.9 billion. Rowsley has advised shareholders to exercise caution and refrain from taking any action that may be prejudicial to their interests. The company is preparing and negotiating the terms of the definitive agreements, with no certainty on the transactions being proceeded with or on the indicative terms previously announced.

site_title: Taking steps for disclosure regime to work in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has taken steps to improve its disclosure regime, with a focus on corporate governance and sustainability reporting. The exchange has introduced a "comply or explain" approach for sustainability reporting, allowing companies to tailor their reports to their individual needs. To encourage better corporate governance, SGX has also increased scrutiny of companies with poorer governance records, and is exploring ways to reward good governance, such as fast-tracking applications. Additionally, SGX is considering revising its quarterly reporting requirements to reduce short-termism. The exchange aims to balance the needs of retail and institutional investors in its regulatory approach.

site_title: Exceeding its own sustainability targets
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property giant, has exceeded its own sustainability targets, cutting carbon emissions intensity by 26% and water intensity by 22% from 2008 levels. The company has also won several awards, including a sustainability award and an excellence award for shareholder communications. Its sustainability efforts are recognized internationally and regionally, and it has been a longest-standing Singapore company recognized in the Dow Jones Sustainability Index. CapitaLand attributes its success to its discipline of setting green building rating targets, energy and water consumption targets, and monitoring indicators to save costs.

images.alt_text: At the launch of CapitaLand Hope Foundation's Kids' Food Fund 2013. CapitaLand CCO Mr Tan (far left) who is also executive director of the group's philanthropic arm looking on as the junior chefs do their thing. CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan (right) and staff volunteer Joey Ng lending a helping hand to another `apprentice'.

site_title: IPC soars, fuelled by proposed hotel, robot firm deals
summary: Shares in IPC Corporation surged 71% on Tuesday after the company signed a non-binding heads of agreement to sell a hotel for S$41 million and acquire a 51% stake in a robot development company for US$5.1 million. The acquisition will be the company's first foray into artificial intelligence, with plans to expand into data centers, digital technologies, and services. The stock closed at S$0.525, up 40% from its intra-day low.

site_title: Having women as directors has clear advantages
summary: In Asia's largest public companies, women hold just one in eight board seats, despite intentions to tackle gender diversity. Many women are in senior management positions, but this hasn't translated to board level. Outdated perceptions and traditional corporate norms may be contributing factors, as well as the fact that women often take breaks to raise families, resulting in men gaining more experience and networking opportunities. Research shows that gender-diverse boards perform better financially, and increasing women's representation on boards can help tackle gender discrimination and provide female role models.

site_title: S Korean cosmetics giant revamps products to target S-E Asia
summary: South Korea's cosmetics giant Amorepacific is revamping its products to target Muslim women and darker-skinned individuals in Southeast Asia, following business losses due to political tension with China. The company aims to triple its sales in the region, which generated 3% of its revenue last year. Amorepacific has developed new products to compensate for humidity, darker skin, and Muslim women's needs, including lighter, washable makeup and darker foundation shades. The company plans to open 150 new stores and invest in a production facility in Malaysia to meet its 2020 revenue target.

site_title: UN should ensure that it is not dominated by China
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi recently praised the country's human rights record, claiming the Chinese people have the most say in their own human rights situation. However, experts argue that the Chinese government restricts NGOs and ordinary citizens from participating in UN human rights discussions. The UN human rights expert Philip Alston's 2016 report on China's human rights situation was heavily influenced by government restrictions, and human rights lawyer Jiang Tianyong's disappearance after cooperating with Alston has raised concerns. Human Rights Watch reports that China is taking extreme measures to control criticism of its human rights record, including harassing activists and blocking NGOs from being accredited. The UN must ensure it is not dominated by China, particularly in human rights discussions.

site_title: BT reporters win SIAS's top and special journalism awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) journalists Jamie Lee and Claire Huang won top and special awards for financial journalism at the SIAS Investors' Choice Awards 2017. Jamie Lee won the top award for her reporting on digital disruption in banking and finance, while Claire Huang received a special award for shedding light on healthcare costs and insurance. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) won five awards, including the Singapore Corporate Governance Award, and CapitaLand took the top corporate governance award for big cap companies.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Something old, something new from SIAS
summary: The Securities Investors' Association of Singapore (SIAS) has established itself as a platform for bondholders, providing assistance to hundreds of distressed bond investors since 2016. Founded by David Gerald, SIAS offers a powerful voice for bond investors and connects them with issuers facing hardship. The organization also empowers bondholders to set up steering committees to push their interest agenda. SIAS plans to be funded by regulators and has proposed more teeth to represent disgruntled shareholders in court through class action.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Buzzwords from a shipping talk fest
summary: The London International Shipping Week highlighted two key concerns: "zero-emission vessels" and "autonomous shipping". Industry leaders discussed reducing carbon dioxide emissions and the potential for unmanned ships, but experts cautioned that implementing these changes will be complex and require significant investment. Research suggests that zero-emission ships could significantly penetrate global shipping markets by 2030, while the International Chamber of Shipping emphasized the need for gradual progress towards autonomous vessels, prioritizing the human factor.

site_title: Scientists a step closer to colouring butterflies' wings
summary: Scientists have made a breakthrough in understanding the genetics behind butterfly wing patterns, using the CRISPR-Cas gene-editing technique. Two teams of biologists have successfully deleted genes controlling the appearance of butterfly wings, revealing their roles in determining color and pattern. The findings suggest that genes like optix, which controls all color in a butterfly's wing, and WntA, which influences wing patterning, can evolve different roles in different species, offering insights into the evolution of species and the 3D structure of the body.

site_title: Google offers to auction off shopping ad spots to rivals
summary: Google has proposed to auction off shopping ad spots to rivals as part of an effort to stave off EU antitrust fines. The proposal, submitted to the European Commission, would allow competitors to bid for spots in Google's shopping section, but critics say it's inadequate. EU regulators have fined Google a record 2.4 billion euros for favoring its own service, and could impose millions more in fines if it fails to treat rivals equally. The proposal has been met with criticism from competitors, who say it doesn't address the issues set out by EU regulators.

site_title: German bank hands £45m to UK online lender amid Brexit
summary: A German bank, Varengold Bank AG, has provided £45 million in annual funding for loans to small businesses arranged by UK online lender MarketInvoice. The deal, which comes a month after a similar agreement with Dutch insurer Aegon, shows professional investors are willing to invest in peer-to-peer lending despite Brexit uncertainty. MarketInvoice is generating 60% of its funding from institutions, with a net return of 9% this year and historic default rates at around 4.7%. The online lender is now the fourth biggest in the UK, arranging £1.5 billion in loans.

site_title: Be prepared for more cyber attacks
summary: Business leaders should prepare for more cyber attacks due to the widespread use of mobile devices, cloud, and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. A recent report by Symantec found a two-fold increase in attempted attacks against IoT devices in 2016, with default passwords being the biggest security weakness. Email malware rates also jumped from one in 220 emails in 2015 to one in 131 emails in 2016. The report warns that businesses must take steps to secure critical assets and prevent data loss, as attackers are making considerable profits from these kinds of attacks.

site_title: Volvo cars said to double US plant investment to US$1b
summary: Volvo Cars plans to double its investment in its US factory near Charleston, South Carolina, to $1 billion, supporting an additional 1,900 jobs. The expansion aims to support 800,000 global light-vehicle sales by 2020. The investment will go toward building a second production line, which won't delay the start of S60 sedan production late next year. Volvo is rapidly expanding its product lineup and manufacturing base under Chinese ownership, following a $1.8 billion investment in 2016.

site_title: Salesforce to launch US$50m artificial intelligence fund
summary: Salesforce is launching a $50 million fund to invest in start-ups employing artificial intelligence, aiming to attract more developers to build AI apps that work with its products. This move follows a surge in venture capital investment in AI start-ups, projected to surpass $10.8 billion in 2017. The new fund will build on Salesforce's existing commitment to AI, expanding its 'Einstein' technology and providing more AI-centric solutions to customers.

site_title: Coffee rivals square off in Italy ahead of Starbucks invasion
summary: Italy's coffee giants, Lavazza and illycaffe, are opening flagship stores in Milan ahead of Starbucks' arrival next year. The luxury cafes, near the La Scala opera house, aim to showcase high-quality espresso and gourmet food, sparking competition in the city's upscale coffee market. Industry experts believe the openings are a response to Starbucks' expansion plans, while Lavazza and illycaffe deny this, focusing on boosting brand visibility and offering exclusive experiences.

site_title: When CFOs are more than number crunchers
summary: A growing number of CFOs are recognizing their potential to create more value for their companies by shifting their focus from routine tasks to strategic planning and decision-making. However, many struggle to align their energies with company priorities, citing challenges such as saving costs and improving efficiency. To overcome these obstacles, CFOs must adopt an "owner mindset" and prioritize strategic initiatives. By understanding their industry, company strategy, and organizational needs, CFOs can identify areas for improvement and develop a roadmap for change. With unwavering support from top management, CFOs can transform their finance departments into strategic partners, driving business growth and value creation.

images.alt_text: The nearly 100 CFOs interviewed by Bain & Company in 2015 readily admitted that they were struggling to align their energies to strategic priorities. The survey found that 41 per cent of them would like to spend more time in strategic planning.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau says talks on Bombardier dispute will continue
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that talks with the US on a Bombardier dispute will continue, regardless of a potential US trade court ruling. Trudeau accused Boeing of trying to put thousands of aerospace employees out of work by selling the CSeries airliner at unfairly low prices. He emphasized that his government will push back against Boeing's claims.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher ahead of Fed meet
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Dow hitting a record high, ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 31.18 points, or 0.14%, to 22,362.53. The meeting is expected to roll out a plan to pare the central bank's bond holdings.

site_title: ASTI Holdings enters into term sheet to divest STI Group
summary: ASTI Holdings has entered into a non-binding term sheet with China Fortune-Tech Capital Co (CFTC) to divest the STI Group for between S$105 million and S$115 million. The STI Group, comprising five subsidiaries, designs and manufactures semiconductor equipment. Negotiations are ongoing, with the deal pending further discussion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: ST Engineering unit invests in cyber security business
summary: ST Engineering's Corporate Venture Capital unit invested US$5.8 million in Janus Technologies, an endpoint cyber security provider, in a Series B round. This investment will support Janus Technologies' organic growth through ST Engineering's established business networks and channels. The move is part of ST Engineering's strategy to invest in cutting-edge technologies, including cyber security, robotics, and data analytics, to create long-term value and growth.

site_title: Giorgio Armani says successor need not be Italian
summary: Giorgio Armani, 83, has stated that his fashion brand's successor doesn't necessarily need to be Italian. He mentioned his nieces, nephew, and long-time assistant as potential successors, but also emphasized the importance of someone being visible and photographed. Armani believes a younger, fresher face would be better, drawing inspiration from French fashion designers of the 1970s-1980s. He has already created a foundation to safeguard the company's future and plans to showcase his collection in London's fashion week.

site_title: Ascott eyes nearly 4,700 units in Malaysia by 2023
summary: The Ascott Limited plans to increase its Malaysia portfolio to 4,692 serviced residences by 2023, up from about 1,700 units across eight properties. The operator aims to add an average of 500 units annually over the next six years, driven by strong demand from corporate and leisure travelers in Malaysia, where average occupancy rates are over 70%. This expansion will bring the total units across 19 residences.

site_title: Merkel looks to make history with fourth win
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is seeking a fourth consecutive election victory, aiming to cement her status as Europe's most influential leader. Merkel's popularity is at 60%, driven by low unemployment and a contented electorate. Her right-of-centre CDU is expected to win, but the exact balance of power in the new Bundestag is unclear. A fourth term would make Merkel the longest-serving Chancellor in German history, surpassing Helmut Kohl and Konrad Adenauer. The outcome will influence Brexit negotiations and EU integration, with possible implications for Germany's influence within the EU and its relations with France and the UK.

site_title: Bridging the gap in sustainability
summary: Investors increasingly prioritize sustainability issues, with over US$70 trillion in assets under management committed to the UN principles of responsible investing. Despite this, many corporate executives underestimate the importance of sustainability, with only 60% of publicly traded company managers acknowledging its material importance in investment decisions. To bridge this gap, companies should adopt a phased approach to sustainability reporting, tailoring their approach to their unique attributes and engaging stakeholders through various media channels. By proposing targets and viewing sustainability as an opportunity for competitive edge, companies can effectively bridge the gap between sustainability leadership and business results.

site_title: China places great importance on ties with Singapore: Premier Li Keqiang
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang emphasized the importance of bilateral ties with Singapore, citing mutual respect and equal footing as the foundation for a beneficial relationship. He made the statement during a meeting with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The relationship has been built over 35 years, even before diplomatic ties were established.

site_title: BOE's Carney says UK rate hike looms in Brexit-hobbled economy
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warns that the UK economy is at risk of overheating due to Brexit, which has slowed growth but reduced the economy's potential. The BOE may need to raise interest rates soon, contradicting the Bank's previous dovish stance. Carney cites inflation accelerating to almost 3% and economic growth slowing in the first half of the year as reasons for the potential rate hike. The BOE expects price growth to remain above its 2% goal and may soon need to lift its benchmark rate from a record-low 0.25%.

site_title: Brazil drugmaker Blau in talks with banks for IPO -sources
summary: Brazilian pharmaceutical company Blau Farmacêutica SA is in talks with banks to go public through an initial public offering (IPO) aimed at raising funds for expansion across Latin America. Blau has discussed underwriting roles with several banks, including Itaú Unibanco, Banco Safra, and Morgan Stanley, but no timetable has been set. The IPO follows a surge in pharmaceutical deals in the region, with 21 mergers and acquisitions and two IPOs raising almost $1 billion in the past year. Blau has nearly 20 plants and exports medicines to several countries.

site_title: China central bank backs mortgage rate hikes in capital
summary: China's central bank has backed mortgage rate hikes in the Beijing market, stating that rates 5-10% higher than the benchmark lending rate have become a "mainstream phenomenon." The move aligns with the central bank's policy direction. This decision comes as some banks in the Beijing market have begun increasing lending rates on mortgage loans. The central bank's backing suggests that the bank is supportive of the trend, which could have implications for the country's property market.

site_title: Strong growth gives flexibility on interest rates, says Bank Negara Malaysia chief
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim Muhammad, said strong economic growth and manageable inflation give the bank more flexibility in setting interest rates. The overnight policy rate remains unchanged at 3% despite an eight-year high inflation rate of 5.1% in March. The bank expects the inflation rate to ease to 3.6% next year, and the direction of global oil prices will be a key factor in determining the inflation outlook. This flexibility allows the bank to promote growth while managing inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down on profit-taking
summary: Hong Kong shares fell on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.38% to 28,051.41, due to profit-taking after a strong rally. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Traders await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the week, while investors in Singapore and Europe showed resilience.

site_title: Beijing, Shanghai shut down bitcoin exchanges: media
summary: Beijing and Shanghai regulators have ordered local cryptocurrency exchanges to shut down, in the latest blow to China's virtual money market. The Beijing-based regulator required exchanges to submit a plan for winding down operations by September 20, while Shanghai's exchanges were closed last week. The international value of bitcoin has plummeted amid speculation of the shutdown, trading at $3,969. China's central bank had previously banned initial coin offerings and warned that cryptocurrencies are used in criminal activities, leading to the shutdown of two major platforms, BTCC and OKCoin.

site_title: Ford to tie up with India's Mahindra, eyes access to huge market
summary: Ford Motor has partnered with India's Mahindra Group for three years to boost its presence in the country's growing auto market. The alliance will focus on electric vehicles and sourcing, giving Ford access to Mahindra's affordable electric car technology. In return, Mahindra will gain access to new designs and markets. The partnership aims to help Ford overcome its less than 3% market share in India and capitalize on the industry's shift towards greener transport. The move is seen as a strategic tie-up to survive in the rapidly changing sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7 points lower at 1,776.66 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 2.011 billion lots worth RM 1.921 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 517 to 337.

site_title: Loyz Energy proposes change in name of company to CWX Global Limited
summary: Loyz Energy Limited announced plans to change its name to CWX Global Limited, pending shareholder approval. The name change aims to better represent the company's new corporate identity and business strategy. The application to reserve the name CWX Global Limited was approved by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore on September 15, 2017. The name change will be subject to a special resolution at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: CDL has its eye on a triple bottom line
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has adopted a "triple bottom line" approach, focusing on financial, ethical, and environmental performance. The Singapore-listed developer has integrated sustainability into its business operations for over two decades, with initiatives such as enhanced corporate governance, shareholder engagement, and sustainability reporting. CDL has received recognition for its efforts, including runner-up for the Singapore Corporate Governance Award and Sustainability Award. The company's sustainability blueprint, CDL Future Value 2030, sets long-term ESG targets, including green building and environmental stewardship, in line with Singapore's Green Building Masterplan.

images.alt_text: South Beach, CDL's joint venture mega mixed-use development on Beach Road, is a sustainable development with its distinctive microclimatic wave-like canopy which acts as an environmental filter.

site_title: Billionaire Leong is said to buy £250m London office
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Angela Leong has purchased a historic 174,000 square-foot building in London's Aldwych district for approximately £250 million, according to sources. The building, which has been leased to tenants including WeWork Cos and the ROKA restaurant, is the latest in a series of high-profile purchases by Hong Kong investors in London's commercial real estate market, following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Keppel Land buys prime site in Jakarta's CBD to build luxury apartment tower
summary: Keppel Land has acquired a prime site in Jakarta's central business district through a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement with Bank Central Asia for 586 billion rupiah (S$60 million). The site will be developed into a luxury apartment tower with approximately 400 units, estimated to cost S$170 million. The project is part of Keppel Land's plans to expand its presence in the Indonesian market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's electronics manufacturing sector is a job market bright spot, according to NTUC leader Patrick Tay. The Singapore International Mediation Centre signed a MOU with China's Mediation Center to support businesses in cross-border disputes under the Belt and Road Initiative. Keppel Land acquired a prime site in Jakarta to build a luxury apartment tower. Asia will be home to 60% of the world's over 65s by 2030, according to Deloitte's Voice of Asia report. Cisco signed an MOU with ST Electronics to provide cybersecurity services to the Singapore government.

site_title: Spackman acquires 10% of Korean dessert cafe chain in Singapore
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group Limited has acquired a 10% equity interest in NSY Group Pte Ltd, the owner of the Korean dessert cafe chain Nunsongyee in Singapore, for S$137,755 in cash. The acquisition is seen as an investment opportunity to leverage the group's presence in Korean entertainment and create additional value. Spackman plans to collaborate with Nunsongyee, associating its brand with celebrities represented by its associated company, Spackman Media Group. The deal is not expected to impact the group's earnings per share and net asset value.

site_title: ECB may keep open option to prolong bond-buying again in 2018 - sources
summary: European Central Bank policymakers are divided on setting a definitive end-date for their bond-buying program, with 'hawks' from richer northern countries pushing to wind down the 2.3 trillion euro program and 'doves' seeking to reduce its monthly pace. The strong euro's dampening effect on inflation is a major point of contention. The ECB may consider a compromise solution or delay the decision until December, raising the likelihood of prolonging the program again in 2018. No decision has been made, and the debate remains open.

site_title: Bayer says needs more time for Monsanto deal approval
summary: Bayer, a German drugs and pesticides group, has extended the deadline for its planned $66 billion takeover of US seeds group Monsanto to January 22, from its initial end-of-2017 target. The European Commission had been scrutinizing the deal due to concerns over competition in pesticide and seeds markets, including the use of glyphosate and licensing of cotton-seed technology. The company now expects the deal to close in early 2018.

site_title: ECB economics head creates new hub for policy makers' forecasts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has established a new hub, the Forecasting and Policy Modelling Division, under the direction of Frank Smets, its Director General for Economics. This division will focus on projections that underpin the institution's policy making. The move expands a revamp of the ECB's economics staff, which has been split into two halves, one for economic developments and one for monetary policy. The division will report directly to Smets and will provide input into the ECB's quarterly macroeconomic projections, which aim to achieve average inflation just below 2% in the medium term.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker ahead of US FOMC meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 15.9 points to 3,225.95 on Tuesday, influenced by cautious trading ahead of the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting. The quiet session saw 184 rises and 227 falls, excluding warrants, with turnover amounting to 1.6 billion units worth S$1.04 billion. The meeting, which ends on Wednesday, is expected to announce plans to unwind the US$4.2 trillion balance sheet, despite no interest rate hike anticipated.

site_title: Apple revamps its money-making App Store
summary: Apple has revamped its App Store in iOS 11, introducing changes to satisfy app developers and add augmented reality apps. The redesigned store gives developers more space for images and text, making it easier to find apps. Games are expected to make up 75% of App Store revenue, with in-app purchases driving most of that revenue. The new system also includes screen recording, which may help AR apps spread and go viral. The changes are part of iOS 11, released ahead of the iPhone 8 and iPhone X, which will start shipping on Friday and November 3, respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks waver despite steel rally; won extends losses
summary: South Korean shares ended slightly weaker on Tuesday, despite strong gains in steel and carmakers, due to foreign investors' cautious stance ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy decision. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 0.1% lower at 2,416.05 points, with the won extending its losses 0.4% to 1,131.3 to the US dollar. Foreign investors trimmed their portfolios by 143.7 billion won, taking profits from the Kospi's previous day gain.

site_title: Cisco inks MOU with ST Electronics to provide cybersecurity services
summary: Cisco has signed a memorandum of understanding with Singapore Technologies Electronics Limited (ST Electronics) to provide managed detection and response security services to the Singapore government and enterprises. The integrated platform, called ST Electronics-Cisco MDRSS, combines Cisco's security solutions with ST Electronics' managed security services, delivering full-time, proactive threat monitoring and management. The collaboration aims to address Singapore's cybersecurity challenges, including a shortage of cybersecurity professionals, to support the country's Smart Nation vision.

site_title: Eurozone current account surplus widens in July
summary: The eurozone's current account surplus widened to 25.1 billion euros in July, despite a narrowing balance from goods trade. This marks a slight increase from June's 22.8 billion euros. The annualized surplus remains on a downward trend, narrowing to 3% of GDP from 3.5% in 2016. The European Central Bank expects the surplus to ease to 2.9% of GDP this year and hover around 2.5% over the next two years.

site_title: Japan commercial land prices rise for first time in 10 years -govt survey
summary: Japan's commercial land prices rose for the first time in 10 years, increasing 0.5% in the year to July 1, according to a government survey. The recovery is driven by a boom in tourism, boosting demand for new hotels and retail outlets. Residential and overall land prices, however, remain down for a 26th consecutive year, falling 0.6% and 0.3% respectively. The increases were led by cities outside Tokyo, with Kyoto and Osaka accounting for the 10 largest gains. The survey's director attributed the momentum for recovery to actual demand.

site_title: Iraq says Opec mulls deeper, longer oil cuts to end-2018
summary: Iraqi Oil Minister Jabbar al-Luaibi stated that OPEC producers are considering deeper and longer oil cuts to end 2018, with some suggesting a 1% reduction and others proposing extending the current 1.8 million barrel reduction. Benchmark Brent crude has slid 2% this year, and while OPEC's output cuts are seen as effective, non-OPEC compliance is lower. Iraq is exceeding its targeted reduction by cutting 270,000 barrels a day, and oil demand is expected to increase in the coming two to three years.

site_title: Quiet energy revolution underway in Japan as dozens of towns go off the grid
summary: A quiet energy revolution is underway in Japan as dozens of towns aim to go off the grid, adopting micro-grids and decentralized renewable power generation. The city of Higashi Matsushima, which lost 1,100 people in the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, is leading the effort with a self-sustaining system capable of producing 25% of its electricity. The Japanese government's "National Resilience Program" is providing funding for this shift, with the goal of reducing municipalities' dependence on large power plants and creating more local autonomy in energy generation.

site_title: New Zealand's fuel shortage hits more flights and petrol stations
summary: New Zealand's fuel shortage, caused by a damaged pipeline to Auckland Airport, has led to the cancellation of 39 flights, including 13 international ones, and halted high-octane gasoline sales at 13 fuel stations in Auckland. The crisis has disrupted air travel, with flights to and from Auckland diverted to airports in Australia and Pacific islands. The government has deployed the military to transport fuel supplies, and airlines have restricted ticket sales and cargo. The pipeline is expected to return to 70% capacity by September 24-26, but the fuel shortage has raised concerns about infrastructure failures ahead of the national election.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei soars 2% to close at two-year high
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.96% to close at 20,299.38, its highest level in over two years, driven by a weaker yen lifting exporters. The broader Topix index also rose 1.77% to end at 1,667.88. The gains followed a weaker yen, which boosted exporters. The Nikkei surpassed the psychologically important 20,000 mark.

site_title: Gem Diamonds recovers 115-carat diamond from Letseng mine
summary: Gem Diamonds recovered a 115-carat diamond from its Letseng mine in Lesotho, the company's third significant find from the mine this year. The discovery follows five other diamonds over 100 carats recovered in 2017. The mine, owned 70% by Gem Diamonds, is known for exceptional Type II diamonds. The recovery comes amid weaker demand from China and the US, and a decline in average diamond prices.

site_title: Indonesia to trace and tax assets kept hidden during amnesty
summary: Indonesia's government has introduced new regulations to trace and tax assets kept hidden during the nine-month tax amnesty that ended in March. Around 972,000 taxpayers joined the amnesty, with 24% of declared assets held offshore, mostly in Singapore. The government will treat undeclared assets as untaxed income, subjecting them to a 30% final income tax rate for individuals and 25% for companies. The estimated value of undeclared assets has not been made public, and tax authorities will receive data on assets kept in jurisdictions that sign the OECD's Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information in Tax Matters.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge down with all eyes on the Fed
summary: European shares edged down on Tuesday, following overnight caution from Asia, as traders await the Federal Reserve's plans to unwind its US$4.2 trillion portfolio. The pan-European STOXX index fell 0.2% despite financials rising 0.2% and HSBC gaining 1%. Ocado, a British online grocer, plummeted 5.3% after reporting increased short-term costs. The European banking index and healthcare stocks were among the few sectors in positive territory. The focus is now on the Fed's plans, with investors divided on its future moves.

site_title: Asia will be home to 60% of world's over 65s by 2030: Deloitte
summary: Asia will account for 60% of the world's over 65 population by 2030, with the number growing from 365 million in 2017 to over 520 million in 2027, according to Deloitte's Voice of Asia report. This aging population is expected to create significant business opportunities in Asia, particularly in industries that cater to the needs of seniors.

site_title: British regulator ends probe into KPMG audit of lender HBOS
summary: Britain's Financial Reporting Council closed its investigation into KPMG's audit of lender HBOS, finding the firm's work did not significantly fall short of audit standards. The probe centered on the signing off of HBOS's 2007 accounts, which KPMG endorsed as prepared on a going concern basis. The FRC deemed KPMG's conduct satisfactory, allowing the investigation to close.

site_title: 1-Microsoft's Hotmail, Outlook.com services back up after outage
summary: Microsoft's free email services Outlook.com and Hotmail experienced a 12-hour outage across Europe on Monday, affecting users in Western Europe and Britain. The issue was caused by an overload of server capacity due to its internet traffic load-balancing system. The outage was resolved, and services are now back online, with no apparent increase in user traffic. No other major Microsoft online services were affected.

site_title: Hamza bin Laden: the heir to Al-Qaeda?
summary: Al-Qaeda has released a photo montage marking the 16th anniversary of 9/11, featuring the face of Osama bin Laden and his son Hamza, 28, referred to as the "crown prince of jihad." Analysts believe Hamza may try to unify global jihadists, taking advantage of the Islamic State's military weakness. Former FBI agent Ali Soufan suggests Hamza is being groomed for a leadership role, with his messages repeating those of his father and gaining credibility among jihadist circles.

site_title: Thai utility Banpu Public Company Limited invests S$75m in Sunseap
summary: Thai utility Banpu Public Company Limited invests S$75m in Singapore-based clean energy provider Sunseap Group, increasing its equity value to S$300m. The investment will be used for solar projects across Asia. The two companies plan to leverage each other's networks to grow in the alternative energy market. Sunseap has a pipeline of projects in multiple countries, including Cambodia, India, and Vietnam. This marks Sunseap's first strategic investor from Thailand.

site_title: KL-Singapore High Speed Rail project seeking ticketing, fare collection expertise
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project is seeking expertise in ticketing and fare collection. MyHSR Corporation Sdn Bhd and the Land Transport Authority of Singapore invited companies to share the latest ticketing technology to develop a robust TFC approach. The discussion will take place in Kuala Lumpur on Oct 9-10, 2017, and inputs will be considered when structuring the ticketing and fare collection ecosystem. Interested parties can visit the MyHSR Corp website or the LTA website for more details.

site_title: Australia shares pulled under by property stocks; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended slightly lower, down 0.1% to 5,713.6, due to a selloff in real estate stocks, including a 2.2% drop in Goodman Group and 2.1% in Westfield Corp. The Reserve Bank of Australia's September meeting minutes highlighted rising household debt and a strong local dollar. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.1% to 7,764.53, driven by a 5.5% gain in Synlait Milk after its full-year net profit climbed 12%.

site_title: Australia shares edge up buoyed by financials; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose on Tuesday, driven by financials and record highs on Wall Street ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. The Fed is expected to take steps towards policy normalization and unwind its US$4.2 trillion portfolio. Telecom stocks and large-capped material stocks also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Japan's Abe to pledge something for all generations in snap election: source
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to pledge to spend on education and child care, while maintaining a tough stance on North Korea and revising the pacifist constitution in his upcoming snap election. Abe is considering calling the election on September 28 to take advantage of his improved ratings and the opposition's disarray. He aims to create a "social security system for all generations" using some of the revenue from a planned 10% sales tax increase, which could invest in education and decrease government debt.

site_title: Suu Kyi appeals to global community over Rohingya crisis
summary: Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi appealed to the global community for support in addressing the Rohingya refugee crisis, which the UN has described as "ethnic cleansing." Suu Kyi urged outsiders to help her nation unite across religious and ethnic lines and offered a pathway back to Myanmar for some Rohingya refugees. In a televised speech, she acknowledged the suffering of all displaced groups, but her efforts to address the crisis have been criticized for failing to speak up publicly for the stateless Rohingya or urge restraint from the military.

site_title: Group of 6 firms to provide DDoS mitigation services to Singapore government agencies
summary: A consortium of six companies, including Toffs Technologies and Embrio Enterprises, has been awarded a three-year contract to provide DDoS mitigation services to Singapore government agencies. The services will be used to protect government websites from volumetric bot attacks, ensure website availability, and improve performance. The contract is valued in the multimillion-dollar range, with the goal of improving the security and reliability of government online services. The consortium's multi-CDN strategy will distribute traffic across multiple networks to prevent disruptions.

site_title: Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants develops sustainability reporting guide
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) has developed a sustainability reporting implementation roadmap to aid early-stage adopters in their sustainability reporting journey. The roadmap provides practical guidance and key considerations for the first sustainability report. ISCA CEO Lee Fook Chiew emphasized the importance of integrating sustainability into business strategies, operations, and processes. This comes as Singapore Exchange requires listed companies to produce a sustainability report starting from the financial year ending December 31, 2017.

site_title: Data governance a central strategic resource
summary: Data governance has become a central strategic resource for organizations in the digital era, with 61% of respondents acknowledging that their companies' decision-making is only somewhat or rarely data-driven. Effective data governance requires senior management sponsorship, technology systems, and a cultural shift among employees. Key steps to improve data governance include breaking the journey into small phases, engaging with the business from the early stages, and leveraging tools and management support. A data-driven organization culture is also essential for successful implementation, as poor governance can lead to productivity decline and cybersecurity risks.

site_title: 'Car nation' Germany distrustful of driverless vehicles
summary: Germany's "car nation" remains skeptical about driverless vehicles, with only 26% of Germans willing to ride in an autonomous car and 18% owning one, according to a recent survey. Despite carmakers showcasing self-driving cars at the IAA auto show, many Germans view driving as a pleasurable experience and are hesitant to trust technology. Industry experts believe it will take time for the technology to gain acceptance, but acknowledge the potential for autonomous driving to save lives and increase efficiency.

site_title: Tencent, Guangzhou Auto agree to collaborate on internet-connected cars
summary: Tencent Holdings and Guangzhou Automobile Group have agreed to collaborate on internet-connected cars, developing self-driving cars and artificial intelligence-aided driving. The partnership aims to tap into mobile payments, social networking, and big data expertise. Tencent will provide cloud services and technical support, while Guangzhou Auto will explore investments in areas such as auto-related e-commerce and new energy cars. Shares in Guangzhou Auto surged 5% after the announcement, while Tencent gained nearly 1% to a record high, marking Tencent's entry into the auto sector after Alibaba's joint venture with SAIC Motor and Baidu's self-driving car development.

site_title: Pound forecasters catch up with rally as BOE boosts bulls
summary: The pound has seen a significant rally this month, with a nearly 3% gain, as the Bank of England signaled its intention to withdraw stimulus "over the coming months". Analysts are revising their forecasts, with HSBC, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group increasing their estimates for the currency. The market now prices a 73% chance of a rate hike in November, and some strategists expect further strength, with the pound potentially ending 2017 at $1.40. However, risks remain, including economic data weaknesses and Brexit negotiations.

site_title: New Zealand's fuel shortage hits more flights and petrol stations
summary: A fuel shortage in New Zealand has forced 28 flights to be cancelled, including six international flights, due to a damaged pipeline to Auckland Airport. The shortage has caused widespread disruption to air travel and has raised concerns about the spread of the crisis. Petrol stations in Auckland have cut high-octane fuel for high-end cars, and the government has been criticized for what is deemed an infrastructure failure. The pipeline is expected to return to 70% capacity by September 24-26, but disruptions to air travel may continue for up to 10 days.

site_title: KPMG, McKinsey feel the heat as graft scandal hits South Africa
summary: A graft scandal in South Africa has implicated global companies KPMG, McKinsey & Co, and SAP, as well as politicians and the Gupta family, who are friends of President Jacob Zuma. The scandal centers on allegations of looting taxpayer funds and undue influence over the state. Eight KPMG executives have quit, while Bell Pottinger has collapsed and McKinsey has suspended staff. Despite numerous allegations, no one has been arrested or prosecuted. The scandal has damaged the reputation of the state, presidency, and ruling African National Congress, and calls for investigations and penalties against implicated companies are growing.

site_title: Japan deploys missile defence to northern island: official
summary: Japan has deployed an additional PAC-3 missile defence system on its northern island of Hokkaido, following North Korea's sixth nuclear test and two missile launches over the island. The move aims to boost security amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has urged the international community to pressure North Korea, while the UN Security Council will hold a ministerial-level meeting to enforce sanctions on the North Korean regime.

site_title: Singapore, China ink MOU to help businesses resolve disputes under Belt and Road Initiative
summary: Singapore and China have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to support businesses resolving disputes under China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). The MOU was signed by representatives from the Singapore International Mediation Centre and the Mediation Center of the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade. The agreement aims to facilitate cross-border commercial transactions and provide assistance to businesses involved in the BRI.

site_title: Toyota offers souped-up Prius as part of high-performance line
summary: Toyota has introduced a high-performance series, "GR," featuring souped-up versions of its Prius plug-in hybrid and Vitz subcompact, among others. The series aims to revitalize the company's image, following President Akio Toyoda's efforts to make the brand more exciting. The GR series, named after GAZOO Racing, a newly established in-house company, will expand globally and include a concept for an all-new Supra at the Tokyo Motor Show. This move aims to increase the brand's appeal and compete with luxury brands, as part of Toyota's broader efforts to reinvigorate its image.

site_title: Bangladesh PM says expects no help from Trump on refugees fleeing Myanmar
summary: Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina stated she expects no help from US President Donald Trump on refugees fleeing Myanmar, as he has expressed skepticism about refugees. Over 410,000 Rohingya Muslims have fled to Bangladesh, escaping ethnic cleansing in Myanmar. Hasina wants to see international pressure on Myanmar to allow the Rohingya to return, but Trump's stance on refugees is clear, with the US already declaring it will not allow any refugees.

site_title: Wages rising just A$3 a year has Aussies snared in debt trap
summary: Australia's stagnant wages, despite a slight increase, have led to a debt trap for over a quarter of the population, with households owing three times their income. Low wage growth and high debt levels pose a challenge to consumption, accounting for more than half of the country's GDP. The Reserve Bank of Australia has acknowledged risks from growth in housing debt, but a rate increase is unlikely. Economic growth is expected to slow, with the labor market's spare capacity remaining elevated, and the workforce's casualization lacking bargaining power.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Tuesday, building on previous day's gains, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.14% to 28,200.54. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, driven by the record performance on Wall Street. The gains come as traders brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Japan must keep fiscal discipline if sales tax revenue used for other purposes: Aso
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso warned the government must maintain fiscal discipline if it plans to use the revenue from a 2019 sales tax hike for other purposes, such as education and child care programs. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering calling a snap election, which could impact policy decisions. Using less tax revenue to pay down debt may raise concerns about fiscal discipline, and economists question the timing of the election. Aso emphasized the need for fiscal discipline, regardless of the election plans.

site_title: Singapore electronics manufacturing sector a bright spot for jobs, says NTUC leader
summary: Singapore's electronics manufacturing sector is a job creator, employing 68,000 workers, according to NTUC leader Patrick Tay. The sector will require skilled engineers and technicians with knowledge of advanced technologies like AI, Big Data, and the Internet of Things. The upcoming Industry Transformation Map aims to leverage Singapore's status as a world-class electronics hub. Tay emphasized the need for workers to be adaptable and continuously learn to remain engaged, employed, and employable in the face of technological changes.

site_title: Tokyo Steel says to raise product prices for second month
summary: Tokyo Steel Manufacturing, Japan's top electric-arc furnace steelmaker, will raise its product prices for a second month in October due to higher overseas prices and a tight domestic market. The price increase will range from 3.3 to 5.1% across all products, with steel bars and U-shaped steel-sheet piles expected to see the largest price hikes. The move is closely watched by Asian rivals and reflects the company's efforts to maintain profitability in a competitive market.

site_title: Hong Kong leader demands end of independence talk, warns ties with Beijing at risk
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, has urged an end to independence debates, warning that ties with Beijing are at risk. The calls, which have moved into the mainstream, violate the Basic Law, a constitutional document that enshrines Hong Kong's freedoms. Chinese leaders, including President Xi Jinping, have warned that independence discussions are a red line that cannot be crossed. Lam said the issue is harming the city's relationship with Beijing and must stop. The controversy has sparked criticism from Chinese state media and a joint statement from Hong Kong university heads condemning the recent "abuses" of freedom of expression.

site_title: Castlery plugs a gap in furniture industry
summary: Castlery Pte Ltd, co-founded by Declan Ee, has successfully launched an e-commerce designer furniture business. The company aims to provide great quality furniture at affordable prices, addressing the frustration of customers who wanted to buy designer furniture but couldn't afford it. With its online platform, Castlery offers a wide range of stylish and affordable furniture options, filling a gap in the Singapore furniture industry.

site_title: Tata Sons boosting stake in Jaguar Land Rover owner: source
summary: Tata Sons, India's largest conglomerate, is purchasing up to 20 billion rupees (S$420 million) worth of Tata Motors shares, aiming to boost its stake in the Jaguar Land Rover owner to 35.7%. The deal, managed by Citigroup Inc, offers shares for up to 421.56 rupees apiece, a 4% premium to the stock's last close. This move aims to protect Tata Group companies from potential takeover threats and is part of a broader strategy to increase its ownership in key businesses. The purchase will also give Tata Sons greater control over Tata Motors.

site_title: Google shuffles top policy team amid ongoing EU antitrust row
summary: Google has shuffled its top policy team amid ongoing EU antitrust row. Caroline Atkinson, the global policy chief, is stepping down and will focus on external-facing work, while Leslie Miller will manage the team on an interim basis. This change comes as Google negotiates EU antitrust terms following a record $2.7 billion fine and faces increasing regulatory scrutiny in the US. The move is part of a broader effort to address growing criticism from both conservative and liberal lawmakers, who are calling for tougher competition enforcement.

site_title: Goldman Sachs names new chairman for Asia Pacific: memo
summary: Goldman Sachs has named Ken Hitchner as its new chairman and CEO in Asia Pacific, excluding Japan. Hitchner, who joined the bank in 1991, replaces Mark Schwartz, who retired after 27 years. James Paradise and Todd Leland will co-lead the bank in Asia Pacific. The appointments were announced in an internal memo.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group has named veteran banker Ken Hitchner as its new chairman and chief executive officer in Asia Pacific excluding Japan, according to an internal memo seen by Reuters on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.83 points to 3,249.68. The gain followed Wall Street's record highs and the US dollar's snap back from a two-day drop. About 55 million shares changed hands, with Blumont being the most actively traded stock. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 44, as investors seemed relaxed about the prospect of the Federal Reserve unwinding stimulus.

site_title: Clogged drain? Could mean toilet is flush with cash
summary: Prosecutors in Geneva, Switzerland, are investigating two Spanish women who tried to flush approximately $162,000 in 500 euro notes down toilets in three restaurants and an office of UBS bank. The incident, which occurred in May, was reported after the restaurants complained of clogged toilets. The women reportedly used scissors to cut the notes and attempted to destroy them. The investigation will focus on whether the cash was connected to any illegal activity, but destroying bank notes is not a crime in Switzerland. The suspects have already compensated the businesses for plumbing repairs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.80 points to 1,782.86. Volume reached 29.19 million lots worth RM11.68 million, with 99 gainers and 51 losers.

site_title: Olympics: No room for Australia, NZ in Asian Games says OCA chief
summary: The OCA President, Sheikh Ahmad Al Fahad Al Sabah, stated that there is no room for athletes from Australia and New Zealand in the Asian Games due to the event's large size, exceeding 15,000 athletes and officials. The Asian Games, set to take place in Indonesia and China, will be the second-largest after the Summer Olympics. Despite previous attempts and backing from China, Sheikh Ahmad ruled out inclusion of Oceania nations, suggesting the Asian Beach Games or Indoor Games as alternatives.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei tops 20,000 as exporters rise on weak yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index reached a six-week high of 20,132.75, surpassing 20,000 for the first time, driven by a weak yen and Wall Street's new record close. The broader Topix index also rose 1.01%, as exporters benefited from the currency's decline. This marks the first time the Nikkei has topped 20,000 since early August.

site_title: Protesters back on St Louis streets after violence, arrests
summary: Protests in St Louis, Missouri, continued for the fourth consecutive day amid outrage over the acquittal of a white former police officer in the shooting death of a black man. Dozens marched peacefully, but a large crowd gathered outside the city justice centre, where police reported no arrests or incidents. The violence, which included broken windows and property damage, led to the cancellations of several cultural events, including concerts by U2 and Ed Sheeran. The police union is taking donations for officers working long shifts, and the American Civil Liberties Union criticized the police response, citing excessive force and unlawful behavior.

site_title: France leads push to urge Trump to save Iran deal
summary: France has urged US President Donald Trump to save the Iran nuclear deal, warning that scrapping it could lead to a regional arms race. The deal, signed in 2015, limits Iran's uranium enrichment, but its limits are set to expire in 2025 under "sunset clauses." France's Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said that maintaining the agreement is crucial to prevent a proliferation spiral and urged Trump to reconsider. France and other world powers, including Britain, Germany, China, and Russia, continue to see the deal as the best way to prevent Iran from building a bomb.

site_title: Hurricane Maria bears down on battered Caribbean
summary: Hurricane Maria strengthened into a Category Five storm, packing 257 km/h winds, as it bore down on the Caribbean island of Dominica. The storm also threatened the Leeward Islands, including Martinique, Puerto Rico, and the US and British Virgin islands, with dangerous storm surges, destructive waves, flash floods, and mudslides. The US National Hurricane Center warned of potentially catastrophic conditions, forcing residents to evacuate in powerful winds and lashing rain.

site_title: Europe: Shares flirt with six-week high as Portugal shines
summary: European shares rose to a six-week high, driven by Portugal's investment grade rating and a rally in Lisbon blue chips. The Stoxx index ended 0.3% higher, with bank stocks contributing the most to the gain. Global economic recovery and easing monetary policy uncertainty also boosted the region's equities. Despite geopolitical tensions, investors remain optimistic, with JPMorgan expecting financials to outperform the market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, IPC, Rowsley
summary: Sembcorp Marine signed a letter of intent with SeaOne Caribbean LLC for the design and construction of the first compressed gas liquid (CGL) carriers in Singapore. IPC Corporation Limited has signed non-binding agreements to sell its Grand Nest Hotel Zhuhai and acquire a 51% equity interest in Beijing iJourney Technology Development Co. Rowsley Limited appointed a new CEO, Tan Wee Tuck, who will focus on growth, innovation, and renewing the leadership of its design and engineering business. IPC resumes trading today.

site_title: Trump warns Venezuela is 'collapsing'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Venezuela is "collapsing" under the rule of President Nicolas Maduro, suggesting the US may take additional steps to restore democracy. Trump stated that the Venezuelan people are starving and their country is collapsing, and that the US is prepared to take further action, including a possible military option if necessary. The US has already imposed sanctions on Venezuela, and Trump's comments were made during a meeting with Latin American allies at the United Nations General Assembly.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump warned on Monday that Venezuela is "collapsing," suggesting the United States may take additional steps to restore democracy.

site_title: US state grants US$3b in tax incentives to Foxconn
summary: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker signed a bill granting US$3 billion in tax incentives to Foxconn, a Taiwan electronics giant, to build a manufacturing plant in the state. The deal, worth up to US$10 billion, promises at least 3,000 new jobs and possibly 13,000. This is the highest US government subsidy for a foreign company, according to fact-checking website PolitiFact. The tax subsidies will be spread out over 15 years, with Walker calling it "transformational" and a benefit for the state for generations to come.

site_title: Trump campaign adviser was wiretapped under secret court orders: CNN
summary: US investigators wiretapped former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort under secret court orders before and after the 2016 election, according to CNN. The New York Times reported that prosecutors planned to indict him. Manafort was one of President Donald Trump's closest campaign advisers, who are now being investigated by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. The FBI resumed surveillance on Manafort in 2016 after initially discontinuing it due to lack of evidence. The wiretapping continued into 2017, including conversations between Manafort and Trump after he became president, but it's unclear if Trump was picked up on the surveillance.

site_title: Global oil prices slip, but remain near recent highs
summary: Global crude oil prices slipped slightly, settling at $55.48 a barrel for Brent crude futures and $49.91 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures. Prices remained near multi-month highs as traders awaited potential stockpile builds. Oil refineries in the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean restarted after hurricanes, increasing demand. US shale production is expected to rise in October, with output from the Bakken and Eagle Ford formations also increasing. Speculators raised their net long positions in Brent futures, while hedge funds cut their bullish bets on US crude futures.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles as Chinese Exchange says it will halt trading
summary: Bitcoin fell for a fifth day, its longest losing streak in over a year, after China's largest online exchange, BTC China, announced it would stop trading by the end of the month due to a government crackdown on cryptocurrencies. The decision comes after China's regulators outlawed initial coin offerings. Since September 7, Bitcoin has slumped about 21% amid increased scrutiny of the cryptocurrency.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us files for bankruptcy protection; Asian operations not part of filing
summary: Toys 'R' Us, the largest US toy store chain, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, casting doubt on the future of its 1,600 stores and 64,000 employees. The company received a $3 billion debtor-in-possession financing commitment to ensure payment for holiday shipments. Operations outside the US and Canada, including Asian licensed stores, are not part of the bankruptcy proceedings. The company aims to restructure its $5 billion debt and work with investors to address financial constraints.

site_title: Braddell View hops onto en bloc bandwagon
summary: Braddell View, Singapore's largest HUDC estate, is launching its en bloc sale process, with an extraordinary general meeting set for October 10. Owners aim to sell the 918-unit estate for at least S$2 billion, surpassing previous en bloc deals. Market analysts predict the en bloc up cycle is still in its early stages, with property prices expected to rise by 5-10% next year. The en bloc fever is expected to continue until the end of next year, with 12,000 new private homes potentially generated from collective sales.

site_title: All eyes on Suu Kyi as Myanmar leader breaks silence on Rohingya crisis
summary: Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi is set to break her silence on the Rohingya crisis in a televised speech, amid global pressure and criticism for her near-silence on the violence. Over 410,000 Rohingya have been displaced, and the UN has accused the country's army of ethnic cleansing. Suu Kyi faces a delicate task of balancing international expectations with the views of her country's Buddhist majority, which rejects the Rohingya's existence. The speech is seen as a crucial moment for her to address the crisis and prevent a rollback on democratic gains.

site_title: SembMarine inks LOI with US firm to deliver S'pore's first CGL carriers
summary: SembMarine, a Singapore-based shipbuilding yard, has signed a letter of intent with US firm SeaOne Caribbean LLC to deliver Singapore's first compressed gas liquid (CGL) carriers. The potential contract, worth at least two large CGL carriers, could mark a breakthrough for SembMarine into the newbuild market for gas liquid carriers. The project, which aims to reduce emissions, is on track for a final investment decision by November and could be finalized by the year-end, with the design incorporating proprietary ship component ideas from LMG Marine.

site_title: Fed wants end to crisis-era measures to be as dull as possible
summary: The US Federal Reserve, led by Chair Janet Yellen, plans to announce a plan to trim its US$4.5 trillion assets to US$3 trillion, marking the end of crisis-era measures. The plan, set to start in October, aims to gradually stop buying bonds, allowing the Fed's holdings to shrink over several years. The goal is to minimize market fluctuations, unlike past shifts which caused wild swings.

site_title: Uber goes on rare legal offensive, suing Dentsu unit for fraud
summary: Uber is suing Fetch Media Ltd, a unit of Dentsu Inc, for click fraud, alleging the firm improperly billed Uber for "fake" online ads and took credit for app downloads it didn't generate. Uber claims Fetch over-billed by $82.5 million and refused to pay $7 million it owed. The lawsuit seeks at least $40 million in damages and marks a rare move by Uber, which usually defends itself in court. The issue highlights the growing problem of online advertising fraud, with Fetch acknowledging the challenge and working to combat it with research firm Forensiq's help.

site_title: Too-close-to-call Kiwi election spooks financial markets
summary: New Zealand's election is too close to call, with the ruling National Party and main opposition Labour Party neck-and-neck in opinion polls. Financial markets are spooked by the uncertainty, with the kiwi dollar dropping whenever Labour appears ahead. Investors are pricing a Labour victory as a negative event, despite Labour's promise of steady finances and investment in social areas. The outcome will likely lead to a period of uncertainty and potential policy concessions, with smaller parties potentially holding the key to forming a government.

site_title: Room for further growth in taxman's tally
summary: Singaporeans paid S$47 billion in taxes over the 12-month period ended March 31, 2017, representing a 5% growth in tax collection. The growth came from increased collection of personal income tax, Goods and Services Tax, stamp duty, and withholding tax. This increase is attributed to the cessation of a one-off personal tax rebate, an increase in wealthy individuals, and growing value-added jobs. The tax authorities' efforts to investigate and identify defaulters also contributed to the growth, with a 10,626 non-compliant cases uncovered in the 2016/17 period. The government may consider leveraging technology to simplify tax administration and support the corporate sector to drive further growth.

site_title: Nafta talks moving at 'warp speed', US trade rep says
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said negotiations on revamping the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) are moving at a "warp speed" but the outcome remains uncertain. The third round of talks is set to begin Saturday in Canada, with officials eager to conclude the talks due to time pressures and the impact on businesses. Lighthizer emphasized the need to reduce bilateral trade deficits, a goal that may be difficult to achieve in trade talks. He also expressed concerns about China's intellectual property policies, calling them an "unprecedented" threat to the world trading system.

site_title: US: Wall St clings to records, helped by banks; tech falters
