summary: US stocks ended slightly higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.15% to 2,503.87, as financial stocks rose ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average clocked a record close for the fifth day in a row. Technology stocks, however, lost ground, with big tech companies such as Microsoft and Alphabet falling 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively, after Amazon announced plans to charge businesses in one-second increments for server use. The Fed meeting starts Tuesday, with investors awaiting details on the central bank's plans to unwind its $4.2 trillion portfolio.

site_title: Burberry has tartan plaid in the bag
summary: Burberry, a luxury fashion brand, is focusing on growth in handbags under new CEO Marco Gobbetti, who aims to revive the brand's turnaround. The company showcased reversible tote bags with tartan plaid at its Paris runway show, highlighting its trademark pattern. Burberry has already generated £1 billion in accessories sales, and the brand plans to expand into footwear and other categories. The company is seeking to elevate its luxury image, particularly in Asia, and is making progress in selling items at its own stores at a higher price.

site_title: Lufthansa and EasyJet bidding for Air Berlin after Etihad bails out
summary: Lufthansa and EasyJet have submitted binding bids for Air Berlin, following Etihad Airways' withdrawal as an investor. The German airline's administrators received proposals from "several" suitors, including Lufthansa and EasyJet, as well as Thomas Cook's German Condor unit. The deadline for bids was met, and the companies will now negotiate the sale of the carrier. The outcome will determine the future of Air Berlin, which had attempted to turn around its operations after failing to gain traction. The bidding process is expected to conclude soon.

site_title: US dollar edges higher versus yen ahead of Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar rose to a 7-week high against the yen on Monday, driven by rising US Treasury yields ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The dollar-yen pair increased 0.51% to 111.4 yen, with investors expecting a potential rate hike. The Fed's meeting is seen as a key event for interest rate decisions, with US yields rising as traders anticipate a more hawkish stance. The dollar's rise also follows a pickup in US consumer prices and easing concerns about North Korean missile tests.

site_title: Property trust seeks to raise up to 927m euros in S'pore IPO
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cereit), a property trust sponsored by Australia's Cromwell Property Group, launched an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore with a potential raise of up to €927 million (S$1.5 billion). The base offering consists of up to 1.296 billion units priced at 0.55-0.57 euros each, with a forecast dividend yield of up to 7.7% per annum. The IPO will be priced on September 21 and debut on the Singapore stock exchange on September 28.

site_title: Singapore-China ties will advance with the times: PM
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the advancement of Singapore-China ties during a recent visit to China, citing the need for both countries to adapt to changing times. The partnership has evolved over the past three decades, with Singapore focusing on projects that align with China's development priorities. A memorandum of understanding signed in May aims to deepen collaboration on China's Belt and Road Initiative, with Singapore offering its financial and transportation expertise. Lee stressed the importance of mutual learning and cooperation, particularly in areas like technology and sustainable development.

site_title: Market recoups half of fortnight's losses
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 32.29 points to 3,241.85 on Monday, recovering half of its losses over the previous two weeks. The banking sector contributed the most to the index's recovery, with gains in local lenders adding 19 points. Turnover was low at 1.7 billion units worth S$1.07 billion.

site_title: Meat the professionals
summary: Indoguna, a Singaporean premium meats purveyor, began in 1993 as a B2B business, serving high-end hotels and restaurants. The company has since expanded to include various premium food products and house brands, such as Ocean Gems and Carne Meats. Indoguna's products cater to a growing appetite for premium seafood and halal dim sum.

site_title: Slack gets slice of SoftBank's US$100b tech bounty
summary: Slack Technologies has closed a US$250 million funding round led by SoftBank's Vision Fund, valuing the startup at US$5.1 billion. The funding, part of the US$100 billion raised by SoftBank's Vision Fund this year, will provide operational flexibility for the company. Slack has over 9 million weekly active users and 6 million daily active users, and will use the funds to compete with Microsoft's Teams and Atlassian's HipChat service for corporate customers.

site_title: New York joins pitch for Amazon's new HQ
summary: New York City is pitching to become the location for Amazon's proposed second headquarters, highlighting its diverse workforce, university system, and big-city living. The city notes that Google, with 5,000 employees in Manhattan, demonstrates that West Coast tech can thrive in the Big Apple. Despite being one of the country's most expensive housing markets, New York is confident its unique industry presence and economic opportunities will attract Amazon. The city's bid aims to overcome its major drawback and secure the headquarters.

site_title: Smart lab for S'pore's aerospace industry to fly higher
summary: Singapore has established a smart manufacturing joint lab with Rolls-Royce and Singapore Aero Engine Services Private Limited (SAESL) to develop next-generation aerospace manufacturing and maintenance capabilities. The $60 million project aims to enhance productivity, save costs, and boost competitiveness in the industry. The lab will deploy 120 existing staff and collaborate with other A*Star institutes to adopt latest technologies, enabling small and medium enterprises to join the global manufacturing supply chain and drive economic growth.

site_title: Creative centre for smells and tastes opens in Science Park
summary: Firmenich, the world's largest privately-owned fragrance and flavour company, has opened its Global Perfumery Creative Centre in Singapore's Science Park, investing S$13 million in the state-of-the-art facility. The 3,500 sq m centre offers capabilities in perfume creation and technology innovation, and employs about 300 people, including 27 perfumers worldwide. Firmenich has a direct presence in over 100 markets and has been in Singapore since 1974, with plans to continue investing in the country as a strategic growth hub for Asia and the world.

site_title: Brazil's economy needs your prayers: minister
summary: Brazil's Economy Minister Henrique Meirelles has appealed for divine intervention due to the country's severe recession. The minister, who is a devout Catholic, recorded a video seeking prayers from the Brazilian public. Despite the economic struggles, there are signs of improvement, including positive economic growth and decreasing unemployment. The Sao Paulo stock market reached its fifth record high in six days, rising 0.31% to 75,990 points. Meirelles' appeal for prayers comes as Brazil's economy has taken a battering, with the deepest recession on record lasting two years.

site_title: S$25m for 'bold measures' to nurture innovation in Singapore
summary: The Singapore government has committed over S$25 million to nurture innovation in Singapore through various initiatives. The measures include an S$16 million boost to the cybersecurity sector, a S$1 million program called Pollinate to foster collaborative innovation, and an S$8 million National Lean LaunchPad program to support inventors and entrepreneurs. Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of people with vision, passion, and drive in creating positive change and commercializing innovative technologies.

site_title: GM to recall 2.5m vehicles in China over Takata airbag fears
summary: General Motors will recall over 2.5 million vehicles in China due to concerns about potentially faulty Takata airbags, which have been linked to 16 deaths and scores of injuries globally. The recall, starting next month, will include Chevrolet and Buick cars and replace the faulty airbags for free. This is part of a larger issue affecting 37 manufacturers and over 20 million vehicles in China, with Volkswagen also recalling 4.86 million vehicles. The recall comes as Japanese car parts giant Takata faces bankruptcy and has been linked to numerous airbag-related incidents.

site_title: All eyes on Nam Cheong's revamp
summary: Malaysian shipbuilder Nam Cheong proposes a restructuring plan, marking the first test-case under Singapore's nascent restructuring sector. The company faces a challenging task convincing bondholders that its projections are realistic and that it's not unfairly treating them. This development comes as the offshore and marine sector continues to face difficulties. The outcome of Nam Cheong's restructuring will be closely watched, with Marco Polo Marine also undergoing similar proceedings under the new regime.

site_title: Taking stock three years after oil rout
summary: Oil prices are expected to remain rangebound between US$45 and US$60 for at least a year, with conventional oil producers locked in a battle for market share against US shale producers. Smaller Singapore offshore and marine (O&M) firms may face severe cash flow problems and huge writedowns due to the downturn. Analysts point to production from Opec, shale activity, demand growth, and global inventories as key factors influencing the oil price trend. The industry is expected to take two to three years to balance out, with smaller firms likely to struggle and potentially face bankruptcy.

site_title: IEA sees risk of volatile oil prices on weak upstream investment
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns of a risk of volatile oil prices due to a lack of new investment in oil production, which may lead to tighter crude supply and unstable prices. The worldwide spare production capacity will shrink without further investment, according to Neil Atkinson, head of the IEA's oil markets and industry division. Despite expected slow demand growth over the next five years, the IEA cautions that a decrease in upstream investment could lead to oil price instability.

site_title: How Singapore SMEs should prepare for EU general data protection regulation
summary: Singapore SMEs must prepare for the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) coming into force on May 25, 2018, which will protect EU citizens' and residents' privacy and data. The regulation applies to all organizations collecting and processing personal data of EU citizens and residents, regardless of location. This change will impact Singaporean SMEs with EU clients and requires them to adhere to the GDPR regulation in about 10 months.

site_title: Global funds eye China bond market as it opens up
summary: China's bond market is gradually opening up to foreign investors, with significant potential to impact the global economy. The country aims to increase international capital inflows, improve corporate governance, and strengthen its balance sheet. However, hurdles include currency convertibility, capital controls, lack of transparency, rising defaults, and a different legal system. Analysts predict potential inflows of $3 trillion by 2025, with Citigroup estimating that foreign holdings may exceed $1 trillion this year. Despite challenges, the market is becoming increasingly attractive to investors, with foreign participants doubling in two years.

site_title: Future not bright for the right, nor for left
summary: A recent surge in right-wing populism in Western countries, exemplified by Donald Trump's victory in the US and Brexit in the UK, is overstated. The narrow margins of victory and failure of key right-wing leaders, such as Marine Le Pen and Geert Wilders, suggest a more nuanced political landscape. Younger voters, particularly millennials, tend to be more liberal on social-cultural issues, while older voters are more conservative. The future of politics is complicated, with neither side poised for a smashing victory in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Political parties still have to win the support of the middle-aged members of the middle class who remain committed to mostly centrist positions.

site_title: Is investment really booming?
summary: US companies are dedicating less of their investment spending to technology and software, despite e-commerce growth and increased reliance on Internet-based ordering. This "IT consumerisation" trend, where employees use personal devices for work, is disguising investment as consumer spending. As a result, economic data may be inaccurate, and investors may be missing key parts of the story. This phenomenon is due to the antiquated philosophy underlying economic data, which fails to account for changes in technology and work habits.

site_title: Singapore to train officers in Asean to combat cyber threats in region
summary: Singapore is allocating S$1.5 million over three years to train technical officers from Asean member states in cybersecurity, aiming to boost the region's readiness to combat cyber threats. The initiative, part of the Asean Cyber Capacity Programme, will focus on incident detection, threat containment, and forensics. The move comes as cyber crimes know no geographical boundaries, and Singapore calls for greater coordination among member states on cybersecurity policy building. The country also signed a memorandum of understanding with Japan to strengthen cybersecurity cooperation and is set to introduce a Cyber Security Bill requiring mandatory reporting of cybersecurity breaches.

site_title: Office spaces outside CBD 'need to work harder'
summary: The rental gap between central business district (CBD) office space and those outside the district in Singapore has narrowed to 54% in Q2 2017, down from 64% in Q1 2015. CBD office rents have declined 21.5% over the same period. Market watchers say CBD tenants may consider moving to city-fringe locations to save on costs, but a tight labor market has made it more competitive for companies to attract and retain talent. Decentralized office building owners must differentiate on building design and amenities to attract tenants, with some developers positioning their projects as progressive office spaces with health and wellness features.

site_title: Dollar at 8-week high vs yen as traders eye Fed
summary: The dollar reached an eight-week high against the yen, rising 0.5% to 111.43 yen, due to a rise in US Treasury yields and expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike by year-end. The Fed's September meeting is expected to announce a plan to shrink its balance sheet, but rates are likely to remain unchanged. Markets are pricing in a 50% chance of a rate hike by the end of the year, up from 40% last week.

images.alt_text: The dollar hit an eight-week high against the yen on Monday, supported by a rise in US Treasury yields, as traders eyed a Federal Reserve meeting starting the next day for clues on whether interest rates could rise again by year-end.

site_title: August's NODX surge signals strong Q3 economic growth
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 17% year-over-year in August, the strongest expansion in six months, driven by electronics and non-electronics exports. This growth is expected to point to vigorous third-quarter economic growth, with economists predicting GDP growth of 3.5-4.0% in the third quarter. However, some private-sector economists caution that the tech cycle may soon run out of steam, and a slowdown in China's economy may pose risks to NODX's rise.

site_title: Startup uses airbags to protect humans working with robots
summary: A German startup, Cobotect GmbH, has developed airbags to protect humans working with robots, aiming to improve safety in automated factories. The airbags cushion potentially hazardous parts and prevent workers from getting hurt. The concept is already being tested and has gained interest from carmakers like Volkswagen. Increased safety would enable robots to work more efficiently and at a faster pace near humans, reducing the risk of accidents and fatalities, which are becoming increasingly common in industrial automation.

site_title: Baidu hires Weibo's chief financial officer
summary: Baidu Inc has hired Herman Yu, Weibo Corp's former chief financial officer, as its new chief financial officer, marking a leadership shift towards artificial intelligence. Yu joins Baidu at a time of its focus on AI, following a string of regulatory investigations that hit profits. Jennifer Li, who will step down as CFO, will become a senior adviser to Baidu's top management. The move aims to drive growth and recovery for the Chinese search engine giant.

site_title: China's home price growth cools further in August
summary: China's new home prices rose in August at the slowest pace in seven months, with some cities experiencing a decline or leveling off, due to government cooling measures. This signals a more stable and less frothy housing market, which is a key driver of economic growth. The news is seen as a positive development for the Communist Party ahead of a key meeting next month.

site_title: Excess diesel emissions 'may be linked to 5,000 deaths in Europe per year'
summary: A study published in Europe suggests that excess diesel emissions may be linked to 5,000 deaths per year, similar to the "Dieselgate" scandal in 2015. The emissions, from cars rigged to appear eco-friendly, contribute to air pollution. This finding is in line with previous assessments. The study highlights the ongoing impact of the scandal on public health.

images.alt_text: There are more than 100 million diesel cars in Europe today, twice as many as in the rest of the world together.

site_title: Time to overhaul key personnel at non-performing sports associations
summary: Singapore's SportSG is considering a major overhaul of key personnel at non-performing sports associations, including football and athletics. The move comes after a dismal showing at the South East Asian Games, with Singapore's football team exiting early and athletics team failing to win any gold medals. SportSG's CEO, Lim Teck Yin, has suggested reducing funding for the two sports, but critics argue this will only exacerbate the problem. Instead, SportSG should focus on finding dedicated and experienced leaders to take charge of the troubled associations.

site_title: Giorgio Armani says successor need not be Italian
summary: Fashion designer Giorgio Armani has stated that his brand's image may benefit if he selects a non-Italian successor when he retires. Armani, 83, has not explicitly named a potential successor but has mentioned his nieces and nephew, as well as long-time assistant Pantaleo Dell'Orco, who could carry on his work. Armani emphasized the importance of a visible heir, but acknowledged that a non-Italian candidate could be suitable, citing French designers from the 1970s and 1980s as examples.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to seek bids for 1,600 km railway from Red Sea to Persian Gulf
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to seek bids for a 1,600 km railway from the Red Sea to the Persian Gulf, aiming to reduce its dependence on oil and improve shipping efficiency. The project, dubbed the Land Bridge line, will cut journey time from five days to three days and connect Riyadh and Jeddah. Contract tenders will be issued at the end of 2017 or early 2018, with a budget of 52 billion riyals allocated to infrastructure and transportation. The project is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify its economy.

site_title: Najib taps Muhammad Taib to take Selangor amid scepticism
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced the return of former Selangor mentri besar Muhammad Muhammad Taib to Umno, sparking skepticism over the move's effectiveness. The 72-year-old Taib has been absent from politics for 20 years, and many question his ability to lead Umno to retake Selangor from the opposition Pakatan Harapan. Analysts see the move as a PR stunt, and voters in the state are increasingly demanding good governance, placing Najib in a tight spot due to his alleged involvement in the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Rolling Stone hopes to gather new moss
summary: Jann Wenner, founder of Rolling Stone, is selling his controlling stake in the magazine. Despite financial struggles and costly missteps, Wenner hopes to remain employed. The publication, which defined cool culture for baby boomers, has been impacted by industry headwinds. Wenner started the magazine from a San Francisco loft in 1967 and produced iconic covers that inspired a song. The sale is a response to the publishing industry's financial toll.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: IPC Corporation has signed non-binding agreements to sell its hotel in Zhuhai for approximately $41 million and acquire a 51% stake in a robotics company for $5.1 million. Pavillon Holdings has signed a conditional deal to buy properties in Malaysia for $16.7 million. The Trendlines Group has partnered with Haier Group to invest in medical-tech and agricultural-tech startups. Rowsley has appointed a new CEO, Tan Wee Tuck, and made new appointments. Sunpower Group has secured deals to build a cogeneration facility and clinch a contract with Zhejiang Petrochemical.

site_title: Why Asian markets seem blind to the North's missiles
summary: Asian financial markets appear apathetic to North Korea's missile threats, with Japanese analysts better grasping the geopolitical risks. Despite the mounting danger, yen appreciation is seen as a "haven currency" due to its perceived safety, reflecting a "mindless" approach to portfolio investment by automated systems. Analysts warn that the current calm may be a "phoney peace," with the threat of conflict in North-east Asia still a significant risk. Markets are prioritizing monetary policy over geopolitical concerns, with the US Federal Reserve expected to lead a tightening of central bank bond buying, potentially weakening the yen.

site_title: EU, China step up climate fight amid signs of Trump softening
summary: The European Union and China are intensifying their efforts to combat climate change as the US considers re-engaging in the Paris Agreement. EU officials, including Frans Timmermans, are pushing for a low-carbon economy and reducing fossil fuel dependency. China is also accelerating its fight against air pollution, with plans for a nationwide cap-and-trade program. US officials, including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, have hinted at a potential reversal of the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, citing the need for cooperation on clean energy technologies.

site_title: Gaw Capital poised to buy PoMo in Selegie
summary: Gaw Capital Partners, a Hong Kong-based private equity real estate group, is in exclusive due diligence for a potential S$350 million sale of PoMo, a nine-storey office and retail development in Selegie Road, Singapore. The transaction involves a 51:49 joint-venture company between Enviro-Hub Holdings Ltd and BS Capital, with a balance lease term of 64.5 years. PoMo has a gross floor area of 235,000 sq ft, with 110,000 sq ft of offices and 70,000 sq ft of retail space, both fully and partially leased, respectively.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Silicon Valley makes rare bet on silicon with startup Barefoot
summary: Barefoot Networks Inc., a Silicon Valley startup, has secured $155 million in funding from top investors, including venture capitalists and major tech giants. The company is developing customisable chips for data transmission between computers, a segment that has seen declining interest in recent years. With a focus on resolving limitations in switches, Barefoot's chip contains 11 billion transistors and can be programmed using software. The startup aims to break into a $50 billion industry, with a seasoned executive from Google and Qualcomm at the helm, and is seen as a potential supplier by Cisco Systems.

site_title: Abe says he will decide on snap election after US trip
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced plans to decide on a snap election after his US trip, with a possible vote on Oct 22 or 29. This move could capitalize on opposition disarray and growing support for Abe's handling of the North Korea crisis. Abe's approval ratings have recovered following scandals, with over two-thirds of Japanese voters approving of his strong stance on North Korea. The Democratic Party, the main opposition, appears weak, and Abe's Liberal Democratic Party is leading in polls, potentially benefiting from the crisis.

images.alt_text: Calling an early election will allow Mr Abe to seize on opposition disarray and growing support for his handling of the North Korea crisis.

site_title: Emmys laud women's roles on TV and Baldwin's scathing spoofs of Trump
summary: The 69th Emmy Awards honored TV shows with women-centric storylines, with The Handmaid's Tale and Veep taking top prizes. Saturday Night Live won the most Emmys, thanks to its satirical sketches of Donald Trump. Alec Baldwin won Comedy Supporting Actor for his Trump impersonations. Julia Louis-Dreyfus won her sixth consecutive Emmy for Veep, while Elisabeth Moss won Best Drama Actress for The Handmaid's Tale. HBO's Big Little Lies won eight Emmys, including Best Series, and Sterling K Brown won Best Dramatic Actor for This Is Us.

site_title: Diversity in Singapore's manufacturing portfolio provides stable, sustainable growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing industry has a diverse portfolio, contributing 20% to the country's GDP. The sector experienced stable, sustainable growth from 2006 to 2015, with a 25% increase in value-added and 2.9% productivity growth. The electronics sector has shown long-term stability despite its cyclical nature, with a 4.9% compound annual growth rate. The government aims to take manufacturing to the next level through Advanced Manufacturing, with a focus on workforce adjustments to benefit Singaporeans.

site_title: Maximising profit and purpose go hand in hand
summary: A corporate culture is essential for delivering long-term sustainable performance, according to speakers at the 8th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2017. Chairman of the UK's Financial Reporting Council, Winfried Bischoff, emphasized that a healthy culture brings enhanced integrity, confidence, and trust. To establish a good culture, companies must define their purpose and values, align them with strategy, and prioritize diversity and succession planning. A top-down approach, where the board sets standards and observes behavior, is also crucial. Experts noted that a strong culture can be measured through conduct and outcomes, such as health and safety reports and employee turnover.

site_title: UN Security Council must revisit Rohingya issue
summary: The UN Security Council's response to the Rohingya crisis is deemed inadequate, with a mere statement expressing "concern" and calling for "immediate" steps to end the violence. Despite the plight of 400,000 refugees in Bangladesh, the council failed to take decisive action, instead being swayed by China's interests in Myanmar. The UN Secretary General described the situation as "ethnic cleansing," but Beijing's backing of Myanmar's military has hindered efforts to alleviate the crisis. The Security Council must revisit the issue and consider sanctions on Myanmar's generals, businesses, and bankers to stop the atrocity.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to seek bidders for 1,000-mile Red Sea-Gulf railway
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to bid out contracts for a 1,000-mile Red Sea-Gulf railway by the end of 2017 or early 2018, aiming to reduce the economy's dependence on oil and improve shipping times. The project, dubbed the Land Bridge line, will shave three days off current shipping times and enhance links to Riyadh and Jeddah, the nation's two biggest cities. The cost and exact route will depend on the chosen location and engineering companies will be involved in the bidding process.

site_title: Tackle the migration problem and its myths
summary: A solution to the migration challenge requires focusing on spurring development in migrants' home countries, particularly in Africa, to reduce pressure on recipient countries. The debate on immigration tends to boil down to three positions: benefiting the economy, preventing immigration, or accepting skilled migrants. However, accepting only skilled migrants does not address the root cause of migration pressures. Investing in Africa to boost economic growth, improve infrastructure, and increase access to markets can help reduce migration flows. The public sector can help by taking enabling steps, providing risk-pooling measures, and institution-building to attract private investment and critical skills.

images.alt_text: More rapid economic growth in Africa would, over time, greatly reduce the pressure of immigration that Europe faces.

site_title: ZhongAn to widen product range after HK IPO
summary: ZhongAn Online Property and Casualty Insurance Co Ltd, China's first internet-only insurer, plans to expand its product range after going public in Hong Kong. The company, founded by Alibaba and Tencent executives, aims to add life insurance and healthcare products to its policies. ZhongAn will also offer its technology to insurers worldwide, with Japan's SoftBank Group Corp investing around $550 million as a cornerstone investor. The company plans to use new funds to bolster its capital base and cope with a 70% surge in gross written premiums, and aims to further develop its insurance products and technology sales.

site_title: Big Oil cleaning up its act with cuts to greenhouse gas pollution
summary: Big Oil companies are reducing their greenhouse gas emissions, with 62 of the world's 100 largest companies cutting emissions annually between 2010 and 2015, resulting in a 12% decline, according to a report from Bloomberg New Energy Finance. The trend reflects growing pressure from shareholders, investor groups, and civil society, indicating a shift in the corporate world towards environmental responsibility.

site_title: Electric London cabs spur reopening of Welsh aluminium plant
summary: Norwegian aluminium components producer Sapa is reopening a Welsh plant to supply materials for the UK's first electric vehicle factory, producing London black cabs. The factory, which will produce 148 components, will invest £9.6 million and employ 130 workers. The move is seen as a boost to Britain's economy amid Brexit concerns. Sapa's decision follows a trend of carmakers mass-producing electric vehicles, driven by government emissions crackdowns, falling battery costs, and increasing electric car range.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singaporean brokers provide analysis on three companies: DBS Group Holdings, SATS, and Raffles Medical Group. DBS is upgraded to "accumulate" with a target price of S$21.45, citing its high loan-to-deposit ratio and competitive edge. SATS is maintained as "hold" with a target price of S$5.05, despite strong visitor arrivals and traffic statistics at Changi Airport. Raffles Medical Group's share price is upgraded to "add" with a target price of S$1.21, driven by its home-field advantage in China despite growing pains for new hospitals. Analysts expect positive loan rate and volume dynamics for DBS in H2 2017.

site_title: Google launches digital payments service for India
summary: Google has launched Tez, a digital payments service for India, to compete in the country's growing market. Tez is compatible with the Unified Payments Interface, allowing users to pay directly from their accounts and transfer money without sharing personal details. The service joins existing digital payment platforms, with an estimated growth to US$500 billion by 2020. Google's move aims to tap into India's billion-plus potential users, following the country's push for digital transactions after the government banned high-value bank notes last November.

site_title: Bahrain 'snubbing Qatari investors' in record bond sale
summary: Bahrain refused to process bids by Qatari investors for its $3 billion bond sale due to cutting ties with the gas-rich Gulf state in June. The decision, made by the Bahraini government, resulted in Doha-based companies not receiving allocations for the US$15 billion bond sale. This move comes amid regional political tensions and concerns of a widening standoff between Qatar and other Gulf economies. Bahrain's fiscal deficit reached 15% of economic output last year, and Moody's Investors Service cut the country's rating to B1 in July.

site_title: 18 NZ flights cancelled after fuel pipeline bursts
summary: A pipeline burst at Auckland airport's fuel supply has led to the cancellation of 18 flights and added stops for long-haul services, affecting 2,000 customers daily. The government has deployed a naval tanker to deliver fuel, and the damaged section needs to be replaced before fuel can be delivered to the airport, estimated to take until early next week. The leak resulted in the loss of 70,000 litres of jet fuel, and Refining NZ has recovered all the fuel. The disruption comes ahead of New Zealand's general election on September 23.

site_title: TEE Land buying Upper Thomson residential site for S$25.74m
summary: TEE Land acquired a 24,069.16 sq ft freehold site in Upper Thomson for S$25.74m, representing about S$931 per square foot. The site is zoned for residential use and can be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment project with up to 31 units. Owners of the six townhouses will receive between S$4.2 million and S$4.3 million each, depending on their strata area. The collective sale was concluded after a tender exercise that closed on September 15.

site_title: Audi takes lead in automated driving, but others wary to follow
summary: Audi has taken a lead in automated driving with its A8 model, which can drive itself under certain conditions, change lanes, and intervene at the sound of an alarm. The A8 is a level three autonomous vehicle, surpassing Tesla and General Motors' level two features. However, rivals are cautious due to ongoing legal and regulatory uncertainties surrounding the technology. Audi's move puts it ahead of competitors, but others are hesitant to follow, citing concerns about regulatory clarity and public acceptance.

site_title: Strong rebound expected for small car COE premium
summary: Singapore's small car COE premium is expected to rebound, with prices potentially rising by up to S$7,000 from the current S$36,001, following a sharp two-week drop. The previous week's low of S$36,001 was the lowest in seven years, attracting crowds to auto showrooms. However, some distributors believe the premium may not exceed last week's level, and a return to pre-drop levels is unlikely.

images.alt_text: Nicholas Wong, general manager of authorised Honda distributor Kah Motor, said his showrooms were "very packed'' with buyers after the COE result and are "still packing'' them in.

site_title: EU warns Ryanair on cancellation reimbursement, compensation
summary: The European Commission warned Ryanair to comply with EU passenger rights, including reimbursement and compensation, for its planned cancellations of between 40-50 flights per day until October. Passengers have the right to reimbursement if not warned two weeks in advance. The Commission emphasizes that airlines must respect European rules, and Ryanair must comply with these regulations despite operational decisions.

site_title: China Environmental Resources says it will incur less losses this fiscal year
summary: China Environmental Resources Group reported it expects to incur less losses this fiscal year due to higher gross profit from financial services, interest income, and lower administrative expenses. The company attributed this to cost-tightening measures and increased income from asset sales. This marks a decrease in losses compared to the previous year.

site_title: Euro crisis over, Portugal's investment grade comeback cuts bond yields
summary: Portugal regained its investment grade credit rating after 5.5 years, with Standard & Poor's upgrading its rating to BBB- from BB+ in a surprise move. The upgrade led to a sharp drop in the country's 10-year bond yield, falling to 2.51%, its lowest level since January 2016. This move is expected to attract more portfolio investment and boost the country's bond market, with Portuguese stocks also outperforming their peers. The upgrade is seen as a positive sign for Portugal's economic recovery and efforts to lower its budget deficit.

site_title: US:Wall St hits new record highs as financials, industrials gain
summary: Wall Street hit new record highs on Monday, driven by industrials and financials stocks, as tensions eased on the Korean peninsula and investors focused on the Federal Reserve's meeting. Caterpillar's 1.8% rise led the Dow, while Nvidia's 3.6% increase lifted the S&P and Nasdaq. The Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates, but investors will monitor Chair Janet Yellen's views on inflation readings and plans to unwind its $4.2 trillion portfolio.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO faces board grilling on turnaround progress
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan is facing a board grilling on the progress of his turnaround plans, two years into his role. The bank's share price has stabilized but revenue remains declining, putting pressure on Cryan. He is expected to brief the board on integrating Postbank and plans for Brexit, as well as an overhaul of the investment bank. Cryan aims to focus on Germany and has signaled a return to risk-taking, but investors are skeptical, citing the bank's limited options for growth. A successful turnaround is seen as crucial for the bank's credibility.

site_title: China to amend party constitution at October congress
summary: China's ruling Communist Party is expected to amend its constitution at a key party congress next month, with President Xi Jinping aiming to enshrine his guiding ideological doctrine in the charter. The draft amendment, to be discussed at the congress, would include "major theoretical viewpoints and major strategic thought" and is seen as a key measure of Xi's power. If approved, Xi's name could be "crowned" in the constitution, elevating him to the level of previous leaders like Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping.

site_title: Tevez's US$850,000-a-week pay symbol of Chinese largesse
summary: Carlos Tevez, once the world's best-paid footballer, now languishes in China's Super League after a disappointing stint with Shanghai Shenhua. The 33-year-old Argentine star reportedly earns $850,000 a week but has struggled with injury and form. Despite a brief improvement in his attitude, Tevez's performance remains inconsistent, and fans have largely lost interest. With the season ending in November, it's likely that Shenhua will cut their losses and let him go, ending a short-lived and unsuccessful chapter in Tevez's career.

images.alt_text: Chinese fans and media have an unflattering nickname for Tevez: Very Homesick Boy, a play on how his name is pronounced in Chinese and a nod to problems he has had throughout his career settling anywhere.

site_title: Tee Land to buy six plots of land at Seraya Crescent for S$25.7m
summary: Tee Land has entered into six option-to-purchase agreements to acquire freehold interest in six plots of land at Seraya Crescent in Singapore for S$25.74 million. The plots have a total land area of 2,236 sq m, and plans are to build a block of residential apartments. The proposed acquisition is subject to legal due diligence and expected to be completed by January 2018.

site_title: IPC announces hotel disposal, purchase of stake in robot development company
summary: IPC Corporation has signed non-binding agreements to sell its Grand nest HOTEL zhuhai to Xinyuan (China) Real Estate for approximately 200 million yuan (S$41 million) and acquire a 51% stake in Beijing iJourney Technology Development Co for US$5.1 million. The hotel sale is subject to regulatory approvals, while the robot development company acquisition is expected to be completed through the issuance of new shares. The deals are part of IPC's "One Belt One Net" initiative, focusing on data centers, digital technologies, and services.

site_title: Sunpower announces two China deals worth 543 million yuan
summary: Sunpower Group announced two deals in China worth 543 million yuan, totaling 490 million yuan for a cogeneration facility in Xinjiang Circular Economy Demonstration Park and 53 million yuan for a heat exchanger contract with Zhejiang Petrochemical. The facility will provide steam to companies operating in the Demonstration Park, while the heat exchanger contract is part of Zhejiang Petrochemical's refinery and chemical integration project. The projects are expected to have a positive impact on Sunpower's FY2018 financial results.

site_title: Kushner Cos acquires NJ apartment complex for US$190m
summary: Kushner Cos has acquired the 1,032-unit Quail Ridge Apartments in Central New Jersey for $190 million, a deal that reflects the firm's strategy of pursuing significant value investments. The 52-acre Plainsboro property was previously sold by Angelo Gordon & Co in 2007 to help finance a $1.8 billion purchase of a Manhattan office tower. The acquisition marks a shift in Kushner Cos.'s focus from New York to its home state of New Jersey, following a decade-long expansion into the city.

site_title: Singapore-China relations will continue advancing with the times, says PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's relationship with China will continue to evolve, advancing with the times. Over the past three decades, the Singapore-China partnership at the government level has undergone significant changes, reflecting China's rapid transformation. Lee emphasized the importance of this partnership, which has been instrumental in Singapore's development.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher thanks to robust NODX, jump in Dow futures
summary: Singapore stocks rose 32.29 points to 3,241.85 on Monday, driven by a 60-point gain in Dow futures, a 27-month high in the Hang Seng, and strong NODX numbers. The banking sector contributed the most to the rebound, with local banks adding 19 points. Turnover was lower than the previous Friday, with 1.7 billion units traded for S$1.07 billion.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine signs LOI for first pair of CGL vessels
summary: Sembcorp Marine's shipbuilding unit has signed a letter of intent (LOI) with SeaOne Caribbean LLC for the design and construction of the company's first pair of compressed gas liquid (CGL) carriers. The project, valued at an undisclosed amount, is part of SeaOne's Caribbean Fuels Supply Project and is expected to be finalized by November, with a potential 30-year export permit already secured by SeaOne from the US Department of Energy.

site_title: Rowsley appoints new CEO, renews leadership team
summary: Rowsley appoints Tan Wee Tuck as new CEO, focusing on growth, innovation, and renewing the leadership of its design and engineering business. Lai Huen Poh becomes senior managing director, overseeing revenue and design/engineering business. Lee Kut Cheung and Ng Eng Kiong take on senior director roles at RSP and Squire Mech, respectively. Albert Hong and Chang Meng Teng retire as non-executive chairs, and Liu Thai Ker leaves RSP to pursue personal interests. Rowsley also plans to expand into healthcare, with further management announcements to be made.

site_title: North Korea vows to complete nuke program after latest missile
summary: North Korea has vowed to complete its nuclear program despite UN sanctions, following the successful launch of an intermediate-range ballistic missile that flew over Japan. Leader Kim Jong Un claims his program is nearly complete and aims to achieve "equilibrium of real force" with the US to prevent military action. The missile test, North Korea's second over Japan in months, was aimed at "calming down the belligerence of the US" and was personally guided by Kim. The UN Security Council has tightened sanctions, with China urging the US to cease threats against North Korea and resolve the crisis.

site_title: Trendlines collaborates with China's Haier to develop medtech, agritech startups
summary: Trendlines, an Israel-based incubator, has partnered with China's Haier to develop medical and agricultural technology startups. The partnership will jointly invest in and develop new medtech and agritech solutions. This is part of Trendlines' expanded partnership network, which aims to bring together global companies to drive innovation in these sectors.

site_title: China expresses concern over EU push to curb foreign takeovers
summary: China expressed concern over the European Commission's proposal to limit its ability to buy European companies in strategic industries, citing potential interference in its business operations. The proposal, presented by European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker, aims to give EU members a tool to intervene in foreign direct investments by state-controlled or state-financed enterprises. China views this as a threat to its economic interests and has called for a more balanced approach to regulating foreign investment.

site_title: Australia shares gain on Wall Street; NZ slightly up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, led by financial stocks, to snap a three-session decline streak. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,726.8, with the "Big Four" banks gaining 0.9-1.1%. National Australia Bank hit a four-week high. This follows Wall Street's record highs on Friday, despite US-EU trade talks and Trump's new threats.

site_title: Braddell View jumping on en bloc bandwagon
summary: Braddell View, Singapore's largest HUDC estate, is planning to join the en bloc sales bandwagon. The 918-unit estate is holding an EGM on Oct 10 to form a collective sales committee, kicking off the process. This move comes after the estate's privatization in March. The decision is seen as a response to the growing trend of en bloc sales in Singapore's private housing market, with the goal of maximizing the sale price of the estate.

site_title: Spackman unit wins camera equipment deal for Netflix's Korean production
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's wholly owned subsidiary, Frame Pictures, has secured a 320 million won (S$379,000) contract to supply camera equipment for Netflix's first Korean original production, Love Alarm. This is Frame Pictures' 14th project for 2017, following a similar deal for the film Deceptive Murder. The production, based on a webtoon, is set to premiere exclusively on Netflix in 2018. The contract is expected to contribute positively to Spackman's FY2017 results.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise to 6-week high led by Portugal
summary: European shares rose to a six-week high on Monday, driven by gains in financial and industrial stocks. Portugal's stocks surged after the country returned to an investment grade rating, boosting its bonds. The pan-European STOXX index rose 0.6%, with utilities EDF and Fortum leading the gain. However, Ryanair fell 2.7% after announcing plans to cancel flights. The gains were supported by gains in Asia overnight and marked a strong session for European markets.

site_title: Slack gets slice of SoftBank's US$100b tech bounty
summary: Slack Technologies Inc. raised US$250 million in funding led by SoftBank's US$100 billion Vision Fund, valuing the company at US$5.1 billion. The funding will support operational flexibility, with Slack still holding US$591 million in previously raised funds. With this investment, Slack expands its workplace messaging services to more languages, competing with Microsoft's Teams and Atlassian's HipChat. The company boasts over 9 million weekly active users and US$200 million in revenue from subscriptions.

site_title: Taipei: Stock exchange index rises to the most in 27 years
summary: Taiwan's stock exchange index reached its highest level in 27 years, closing at 10,631.57, a 0.48% increase. The last time the index reached this level was on April 4, 1990. The surge comes despite global market uncertainty, with investors seemingly optimistic about the market's prospects. The Taiwan SE Weighted Index surpassed its previous record on Monday, marking a significant milestone for the Taiwanese stock market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.27% on Monday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street's record close last Friday. The Hang Seng Index ended at 28,159.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains come ahead of the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy meeting, with traders tracking the US market's performance. The rally follows a 0.4% gain in Singapore's STI on Thursday, despite concerns over US-China trade tensions and split Fed views.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.67 points to 1,783.66. Volume reached 1.609 billion lots worth RM1.992 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 457 to 406.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports surged 17% in August, exceeding July's 7.6% gain. A joint lab was launched to develop smart technologies for the aerospace industry, and Singapore set aside $1.5 million to build cybersecurity capability. The country's corporate governance will be driven by purpose, value, and culture, according to the UK Financial Reporting Council chair. Meanwhile, Braddell View is planning to join the en bloc bandwagon, and Singapore's relations with China will continue to advance, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: Malaysia scraps beer festival following Islamists' objections
summary: Malaysian authorities scrapped the annual "Better Beer Festival 2017" after an Islamist party objected to the event, citing concerns over its "Western" and un-Islamic nature. The festival, planned for October, would have featured craft beers from 11 countries and attracted around 6,000 attendees. The decision was made due to "political sensitivity" surrounding the event, according to Kuala Lumpur City Hall. The event's cancellation was seen as a victory for Islamist groups, who have long protested against Western-style events and festivals in Muslim-majority Malaysia.

site_title: Gates Foundation to invest up to US$40m in UK immunotherapy firm Immunocore
summary: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is investing up to $40 million in UK-based biotech firm Immunocore to support the development of immunotherapies for infectious diseases, including tuberculosis and HIV. Immunocore has previously focused on cancer treatments, but this investment will extend its work into infectious diseases. The partnership aims to find and develop new treatments for these diseases.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks closes at 6-week high as tech shares rally; won gains
summary: South Korean shares closed at a six-week high, with the Kospi index rising 1.35% to 2,418.21 points, driven by tech shares rallying on expectations of robust third-quarter earnings. Samsung Electronics jumped 4.13% to a record high, while SK Hynix gained 3.24%. The won also gained 0.45% against the US dollar. Foreign investors purchased a net 214.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares, easing concerns about North Korea risks.

site_title: Airbnb, Paris rental agents to register from Oct 2
summary: Paris authorities will require landlords renting through Airbnb and other online platforms to register starting October 2. The measure aims to curb a housing shortage and enforce rental controls, including a 120-day annual limit. Owners must obtain a registration number to list their properties, with a two-month deadline to comply. This follows Paris's imposition of a tourist tax and increased rental controls, which have led to fines for unlawful landlords.

site_title: Abe says he'll decide on snap Japan election after US trip
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced he will decide on calling a snap election after his return from a US trip, confirming reports that he is considering an early election. Abe intends to dissolve parliament on September 28 and hold an election on October 22, potentially capitalizing on opposition disarray and support for his handling of the North Korea crisis. His approval ratings have recovered following a series of scandals, and opposition parties appear weakened, with the Democratic Party resigning several members.

site_title: Australia shares close higher; NZ inches down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,720.6, snapping a three-session losing streak, driven by Wall Street's all-time highs and gains in financial, material, and energy stocks. The benchmark fell 0.8% on Friday. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index declined 0.1% for its fifth straight session. The Fed's meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday is expected to mark another step towards policy normalisation.

site_title: Google joins mobile payments race in cash-reliant India
summary: Google has launched Tez, a digital payments service in India, to compete with existing services like Paytm Payments Bank and One MobiKwik Systems. Tez is compatible with the Indian government-backed Unified Payments Interface, allowing users to make transactions and transfer money without sharing personal details. The move aims to tap into India's growing digital payments sector, which is estimated to reach $500 billion by 2020. Tez supports multiple languages and is available for download on iPhones and Android devices, joining other players like Facebook's WhatsApp and homegrown messaging service Hike.

images.alt_text: Alphabet's Google introduced a digital payments service specifically designed for India as competition heats up for the country's billion-plus potential users.

site_title: Sting, Costello to salute Leonard Cohen year after death
summary: Top musicians Sting, Elvis Costello, and Philip Glass will pay tribute to Leonard Cohen with a concert in Montreal, his native city, on November 6. The event, benefiting Canadian arts groups, will be attended by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Cohen's son Adam, also a musician, gave his blessing for the public event, saying it fulfills his father's wish to gather in Montreal. The concert will feature a diverse lineup of performers, including k d lang, Feist, Lana Del Rey, and Damien Rice, honoring Cohen's legacy as a songwriter and poet.

site_title: Taiwan shipping firm Evergreen Marine's stock slides as China bet wanes
summary: Taiwanese shipping firm Evergreen Marine's stock has plummeted 17% in September after its shares surged 39% last month, driven by bets on rising demand from China. The company's volatility is the highest in eight years, deterring less long-term investors. Despite this, analysts predict a 10% gain in shares over the next 12 months, citing strong quarterly earnings.

site_title: Inflation slump to hit in early 2018: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) forecasts that eurozone inflation will slump to 0.9% in the first quarter of 2018, significantly lower than its target of just below 2%. Inflation is expected to return to an upward path by the second half of 2018, barring unexpected price developments. The ECB's quantitative easing program, which includes monthly purchases of government and corporate debt, is expected to end, but interest rates are likely to remain low.

site_title: Asia: Markets track New York rally ahead of next Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday following a record finish on Wall Street, driven by expectations of the Federal Reserve's next policy meeting. Despite hurricanes Harvey and Irma's economic impact, investors await the Fed's decision on borrowing costs and crisis-era bond-buying stimulus. The US central bank is expected to keep borrowing costs on hold, but will review plans to cut back stimulus and interest rate signals.

site_title: Late summer rains, private food supplies limit impact of North Korea drought
summary: North Korea is unlikely to face acute food shortages this year due to late summer rains and the growth of privately produced crops. The country's crop yields are expected to be similar to last year, according to US Department of Agriculture satellite images. Private food markets have overtaken the state-run Public Distribution System as the primary distributor of food, and experts warn that official reports may not accurately reflect the situation due to the country's command economy. The UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) had previously warned of a severe drought, but the recent rains have alleviated dry conditions.

site_title: China says will prevent risks from excessively rapid growth in overseas investments
summary: China's insurance regulator announced plans to prevent risks from excessive overseas investments, strengthening supervision and urging insurance companies to conduct self-checks on property investments. The regulator will also monitor peer-to-peer lending and internet finance risks affecting the insurance industry.

site_title: Big Oil becomes greener with cuts to greenhouse gas pollution: report
summary: Big Oil companies are reducing their greenhouse gas pollution, with 62 of the world's 100 largest companies cutting emissions annually between 2010 and 2015, resulting in a 12% decline. The five largest oil companies - Exxon, Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron, BP, and Total - collectively reduced pollution by 13% during this period. This trend is attributed to growing pressure from shareholders, investors, and civil society for more transparency and emissions reduction targets, with companies such as BP cutting emissions by 25.5%.

site_title: 'Frothy' assets spark concerns as cash floods India markets
summary: India's equities and bonds have surged despite weak economic growth, driven by a surge in local flows after last year's cash ban and buoyant global markets. Authorities, including the Reserve Bank of India, are expressing concerns over "frothy and bubbly" valuations, warning of a potential correction. The strengthening rupee also raises concerns about calibration of large inflows. As a result, strategists are advising caution, with some predicting a slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: Singapore earmarks S$1.5m to build cybersecurity capability
summary: Singapore has allocated S$1.5 million over three years to build cybersecurity capabilities in the Asean region through the Asean Cyber Capacity Building Programme. The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore will collaborate with Information Systems Audit and Control Association and partner with companies to train professionals in cybersecurity job roles. The Tech Skills Accelerator initiative will also provide training opportunities for up to 18 candidates from Asean member states, focusing on security operations centre operations and management.

site_title: UK businesses call for three-year Brexit transitional deal
summary: UK businesses, including BT and Centrica, are calling for a three-year Brexit transitional deal to protect jobs in Britain and Europe. Over 100 companies employing 1 million people in the UK and EU have signed a letter, urging the government to plan for a 'no deal' scenario. The Confederation of British Industry says a transitional deal is crucial for collective prosperity, but Brussels has stated that talks on the UK's future trading relationship with the EU can only begin after "sufficient progress" is made on the terms of departure.

site_title: New Zealand military called in after pipeline leak hits air travel
summary: New Zealand's defense force has been called in to assist with fuel distribution after a burst oil pipeline triggered a 70% jet fuel shortage, causing flight cancellations and disruptions. Air New Zealand has cancelled 18 flights, while airlines are exploring alternative refueling options. The disruption is expected to last for about a week, affecting thousands of airline passengers. The pipeline damage also raised concerns about a potential fuel shortage for motorists in New Zealand's largest city.

site_title: A*Star, Rolls-Royce and Singapore Aero Engine Services launch S$60m lab to develop smart technologies
summary: A*Star, Rolls-Royce, and Singapore Aero Engine Services have launched a S$60m lab to develop smart technologies for the aerospace industry. The five-year collaboration aims to create next-generation manufacturing and maintenance capabilities using advanced processes, automation, and digital technologies. Singapore is a key aviation hub in Asia, with the local aerospace industry valued at over S$8 billion, 85% of which comes from maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) activities. The joint lab will foster innovation and co-development to benefit Singapore's future economy, aligning with the country's Future of Manufacturing strategy.

site_title: Chinese man investigated for cutting 'noisy' dogs' vocal cords
summary: A Chinese man, surnamed Zeng, is being investigated for running an unlicensed street clinic that cut the vocal cords of dogs to reduce their barking. The clinic, which operated in Chengdu, Sichuan province, used anaesthetised dogs and allegedly did not properly clean instruments between uses. Zeng charged between 50 yuan to 80 yuan per dog. Authorities have ordered the clinic to shut down, citing that Zeng was not licensed to operate on animals, and the practice is considered animal cruelty.

site_title: Trump pushes UN reform as world leaders gather for crisis talks
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to address the United Nations on Monday, focusing on UN reform amidst a week of intense diplomacy. With about 130 world leaders in attendance, Trump's "America First" agenda has raised concerns among allies and foes. Trump previously disparaged the UN, calling it a "club," and will lay out his views on reforming the organization. The gathering is dominated by worries about North Korea, Iran, and Myanmar, with Trump's address expected to be closely watched.

site_title: Football: 'Overweight' Tevez symbol of Chinese largesse
summary: Carlos Tevez, the best-paid footballer at the time, has become a symbol of Chinese football's largesse after a short stint with Shanghai Shenhua. The 33-year-old Argentine forward was heavily criticized for his indifferent form and struggles to settle in China. Despite his high weekly salary of $850,000, Tevez has failed to impress on the pitch and has been plagued by injuries. His departure from the team is now imminent, with fans and coaches alike expecting him to leave before the season ends in November.

site_title: Purpose, value, culture drive corporate governance: UK Financial Reporting Council chair
summary: UK Financial Reporting Council chair Winfried Bischoff emphasized that purpose, value, and corporate culture are key drivers of effective corporate governance. A healthy culture is essential for delivering long-term performance, integrity, and trust, while a poor culture is a significant business risk. Bischoff also highlighted the importance of diversity and succession planning in maintaining ongoing success, stating that a board must strike a balance of skills and experience among senior executives and non-executive directors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up after Wall Street record
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.59%, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained unchanged. The move comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the week. In contrast, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally, and US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales flat in August
summary: Australian new vehicle sales remained unchanged in August at 99,564, following a 2.4% drop in July. Sales of passenger vehicles and sports utilities declined, but commercial vehicle sales surged 7.2% to an all-time peak of 23,834. This increase in commercial sales suggests business investment may boost economic growth in the month.

site_title: Chinese online insurer ZhongAn starts US$1.5b Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese online insurer ZhongAn Online P&C Insurance launched a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) worth up to $1.5 billion, with Japan's SoftBank Group as the sole cornerstone investor. The company plans to use the funds to strengthen its capital base and support business growth. The IPO, which aims to raise 199.3 million new shares at HK$53.70 to HK$59.70 apiece, would add to the $9.3 billion of first-time share sales in Hong Kong this year, amid a rally in the city's benchmark Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Gold slips to two-week low ahead of Fed meet
summary: Gold prices dropped to a two-week low ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting, where monetary policy tightening is expected. The dollar strengthened, and equities rallied, contributing to the decline. Spot gold fell 0.2% to $1,317.00 an ounce, while US gold futures dropped 0.3% to $1,321.10 an ounce. Analysts attribute the decline to investors' focus on potential rate hikes by the Fed, which increases the metal's opportunity cost. The Fed meeting, starting Tuesday, is expected to announce balance sheet reduction and "normalise" monetary policy.

site_title: Giant sea snail plan to rescue Barrier Reef
summary: Australian researchers are breeding the Pacific triton sea snail, also known as the giant triton, to help control crown-of-thorns starfish, a major pest threatening the Great Barrier Reef. The snails, which can grow up to half a meter, prey on the starfish using scent, and their presence can deter the starfish from areas where they are present. A trial to breed thousands of the snails is underway, with the goal of deploying them to prevent starfish aggregations and help reduce coral loss.

images.alt_text: A giant starfish-eating snail could be unleashed to help save the Great Barrier Reef, officials said Monday, with a trial underway to breed thousands of the rare species.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reach 6-week peak as tech shares rally; Samsung hits record
summary: South Korean shares reached a six-week peak on Monday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 1.1% at 2,411.78 points. Tech shares, particularly Samsung, drove the rally, with the company hitting a record high at 2,590,000 won. Concerns about North Korea risks eased, and analysts attributed the rebound to a brighter outlook for tech sector quarterly earnings and rising DRAM prices. Foreign investors also purchased 58.8 billion Korean won of Kospi shares, bolstering the index.

site_title: China's yuan inches up after last week's biggest slide since November
summary: China's yuan edged up against the US dollar on Monday, following the central bank's firmer midpoint fix. The People's Bank of China set the yuan midpoint rate at 6.5419 per US dollar, four pips firmer than the previous rate. In the spot market, the yuan opened at 6.5510 and was changing hands at 6.5480, 20 pips firmer than the previous close but 0.09% weaker than the midpoint. This is China's first positive move against the US dollar since November.

site_title: DBS names Mark Troutman as new group head of sales for global transaction services
summary: DBS Bank appointed Mark Troutman as group head of sales for its Global Transaction Services (GTS) unit, succeeding John Laurens. Troutman, with 25 years of experience in cash management and trade finance, previously led corporate sales at HSBC. GTS income grew 14% year-over-year in the first half of 2017, and DBS aims to drive revenue growth through this unit.

site_title: AUD, NZD advance on yen as yields attract
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the Japanese yen, driven by rising bond yields in Australia and New Zealand. The Australian dollar gained 0.3% to US$0.8028, while the New Zealand dollar surged 0.5% to US$0.7325. Rising yields in Australia, which have climbed 20 basis points in seven sessions, have increased the Aussie's rate advantage over the yen. The moves are seen as a response to investor demand for higher-yielding currencies, particularly in light of the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) decision to refrain from raising interest rates this year.

site_title: China JV to recall over 2.5m vehicles over airbags: watchdog
summary: General Motors and its Chinese joint venture, Shanghai GM, will recall over 2.5 million vehicles in China due to faulty airbag inflators produced by Takata Corp. The recall includes 13,492 imported Saab and Opel vehicles and more than 2.51 million Chevrolet and Buick cars. This is part of a global recall of over 20 million vehicles linked to at least 16 deaths and 180 injuries globally. The recall follows similar actions by Volkswagen AG and other manufacturers.

site_title: 5,000 'Dieselgate' deaths in Europe per year: study
summary: A study published in Europe suggests that emissions from rigged diesel cars may be responsible for 5,000 air pollution deaths per year. This finding aligns with previous assessments related to the "Dieselgate" scandal, where Volkswagen admitted to cheating on emissions tests in 2015. Several other carmakers have also been under suspicion, and the study's numbers are in line with previous estimates.

site_title: Thai junta and Muslim separatists trade blame over peace steps
summary: Thailand's junta and a Malay Muslim separatist faction, Mara Patani, have blamed each other for a delay in setting up a 'safety zone' as a confidence-building measure towards ending a decades-old insurgency. Talks ended without a full agreement, leading to bombings that killed soldiers and policemen. The junta's chief negotiator said the insurgents were not ready for the zone, while Mara Patani claimed the Thai side had not addressed necessary details. A safety zone, jointly administered by both sides, is hoped to be set up within three to six months.

site_title: Hot Stock: ComfortDelGro stock falls after losing tender to rival SMRT
summary: ComfortDelGro's stock fell after losing the tender to operate the Thomson-East Coast (TEL) line to rival SMRT. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) stated that ComfortDelgro's bid was 30% higher than SMRT's offer. ComfortDelGro's stock dropped 5 Singapore cents to close at S$2.07, with OCBC Investment Research downgrading its rating and fair value estimate due to the loss of a significant growth catalyst.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.99 points to 1,783.34, with a trading volume of 71.38 million lots worth RM16.14 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.8% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 24.98 points to 3,234.54. About 84 million shares worth S$102 million changed hands, with Blumont being the most actively traded stock. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 39, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Oil markets firm on rising refinery demand, falling US rig count
summary: Oil markets remained near multi-month highs due to rising refinery demand and falling US rig count. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures were at $49.89 a barrel, while Brent crude futures were at $55.67 a barrel. Refineries in the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean began restarting after being shut due to hurricanes Harvey and Irma. The US rig count fell to 749, the fewest since June, as signs of stalling growth in the US shale industry emerged.

site_title: Angry Birds co-founder among Finnish delegation's Singapore trip
summary: A Finnish delegation, led by Helsinki's Mayor Jan Vapaavuori and including Angry Birds co-founder Peter Vesterbacka, is visiting Singapore from September 18 to 21. The "Designing Better Life" trip aims to seal at least seven deals and promote digital innovation and regional headquarters opportunities in Finland for Singapore companies. This visit comes ahead of Finland's centennial celebrations and comprehensive economic reforms to improve the business environment and attract foreign investors. The trip also aims to build on existing trade ties, with Finland's exports to Singapore totaling S$298 million last year.

site_title: UK house price growth at slowest since 2012 as London slumps
summary: UK house prices grew at their slowest annual pace in over five years, increasing 1.1% from last year, according to Rightmove. This decline is attributed to a slump in London, with asking prices dropping for the first time in September in four years. The autumn season typically sees price increases, but this year's decline marks a departure from the trend.

site_title: ISR Capital invests S$2.68m in Straits Hi-Rel
summary: ISR Capital's subsidiary, Infiniti Advantage, invests up to S$2.68 million in Straits Hi-Rel, a private company focused on high reliability engineering services. The investment, made in four stages, represents a 25% equity stake. Straits Hi-Rel will be structured as a Hi-Rel Technology Centre based in Singapore, aiming to expand into the high reliability engineering services business.

site_title: China drugmaker Fosun to buy smaller stake in India's Gland Pharma to avoid government veto
summary: Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group Co will purchase a 74% stake in India's Gland Pharma Ltd for $1.1 billion, avoiding a government review that may have blocked the deal. The reduced stake will allow the Chinese firm to gain access to Gland's generic injectable medicines and facilities approved for US sale. This deal follows similar efforts by Chinese drugmakers to expand into the US market, with Valeant Pharmaceuticals selling its Dendreon unit to Sanpower Group Co for $820 million in June. The deal is set to complete by October 3.

site_title: Australian moguls lose court challenge to CBS's planned buyout of Ten Network
summary: Australian media moguls Lachlan Murdoch and Bruce Gordon have lost a court challenge to CBS Corp's planned buyout of Ten Network Holdings. The deal, valued at A$201.1 million, will be put to a creditor vote on Tuesday. A judge dismissed arguments that CBS's biggest creditor should be barred from voting on its own bid, allowing the deal to proceed. The decision allows the CBS deal to move forward despite the media moguls' revised offer, which has not been disclosed.

site_title: Federal rate hike remains uncertain after Harvey, Irma
summary: The Federal Reserve is likely to leave interest rates unchanged after the two-day policy meeting this week, amid uncertainty from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. Despite a temporary increase in inflation due to the storms, economists expect the underlying trend of inflation to remain below the 2% target. The Fed is also set to announce a plan to reduce its multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings, which will be a gradual tightening of monetary policy.

site_title: With protest-hit St Louis on edge, U2 and Sheeran cancel gigs
summary: US city St Louis remains on edge after a second night of violent protests over the acquittal of a former police officer in the shooting death of a black man. Rock giants U2 and Ed Sheeran canceled their scheduled concerts due to security concerns. The protests, which began after the acquittal of former officer Jason Stockley, turned violent, with protesters breaking windows and hurling debris at police and media. At least seven arrests were made, and 10 officers were injured in clashes with protesters. The city is still reeling from the 2014 killing of Michael Brown in the suburb of Ferguson, heightening racial tensions.

site_title: UK households squeezed again, BoE might make it worse: survey
summary: British households are experiencing the tightest squeeze on their finances in three years, according to a survey. The Bank of England's signal to raise interest rates is expected to worsen the situation. The Household Finance Index fell to 42.8 in September from 43.4 in August, its lowest average reading since 2014. This is the third consecutive quarter of decline, with the UK economy shrinking for the second month, providing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Trump's eldest son will testify publicly on Russia: senator
summary: Donald Trump Jr will testify publicly before a congressional committee on Russia's meddling in the 2016 presidential campaign. The committee, led by Senator Dianne Feinstein, wants to know about Trump Jr's contacts with Russians, particularly a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower with Natalia Veselnitskaya. This will be the first public testimony by a member of President Trump's inner circle, following previous behind-the-door testimony by Trump Jr and Jared Kushner. The lawmakers aim to determine if there was any collusion with Moscow.

site_title: US dollar clings near 7-week high vs yen; sterling stands tall
summary: The US dollar held near a seven-week high against the yen, supported by rising US Treasury yields and growing expectations for a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December. The euro remained below a 2-1/2 year high, while sterling stood firm after a strong rally last week, driven by bets on a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of England. The yen's recent drop against other currencies has supported the US dollar, with trading expected to be thinner than usual due to Japanese markets being closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Dirty truth behind US oil pipeline growth
summary: A US fund manager, David Capobianco, is launching WaterBridge Resources LLC to manage wastewater from oil wells, a growing problem for oil producers as US crude output surges. The company aims to build pipelines to dispose of wastewater, potentially reducing costs from $1.50 to $2.50 per barrel to $1 per barrel. With oil production forecast to reach 10 million barrels a day, 30-50 million barrels of dirty water will be produced daily, enough to fill the Empire State Building eight times a day.

site_title: Sean Spicer wheels into Emmy Awards spotlight
summary: Former White House press secretary Sean Spicer made a surprise appearance at the Emmy Awards, wheeling onto the stage on a podium that resembled the one he used at the White House. Spicer, who served as Trump's first press secretary, appeared to poke fun at host Stephen Colbert's jabs at Trump's tweeting habits. McCarthy, who won an Emmy for her SNL sketch about Spicer, laughed and shook her head. The appearance marked Spicer's first major public appearance since leaving the White House this summer, sparking speculation about his next career move.

images.alt_text: A beaming Spicer, donning a suit and bow tie, walked on stage wheeling in a podium that looked like the one he used to stand behind while addressing journalists at the White House, except it had 'The Emmys Hollywood' written on it.

site_title: Air NZ cancels flights, says 2,000 disrupted as oil pipeline shuts
summary: Air New Zealand canceled 7 flights out of Auckland, affecting approximately 2,000 passengers, due to a shutdown of the New Zealand Refining Company's fuel pipeline.
