The pipeline leak resulted in a fuel supply issue, prompting airlines to refuel at alternative airports. The airline's shares declined 2.5% in early trading, while the refinery's shares fell 2.4%. The fuel supply issue is unlikely to impact Air New Zealand's fiscal-year 2018 results, and the pipeline's operational status is yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Hurricane Maria threatens weary Caribbean with more destruction
summary: Hurricane Maria, a powerful storm, is threatening the Caribbean islands with destruction. As of Sunday, the storm had strengthened into a hurricane with 75 miles per hour winds and is expected to intensify before hitting the Leeward Islands on Monday night. Maximum sustained winds are forecast to accelerate to 120 miles per hour within 72 hours, affecting the British and US Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. The storm is moving west-northwest and has already prompted hurricane warnings for several islands, with tropical storm warnings in effect for others.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports surge 17% in August
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports surged 17% in August, more than doubling the 7.6% gain in July. Shipments to top markets, including China, Hong Kong, and South Korea, contributed to the increase. Electronic exports rose 21.7%, while non-electronic exports increased 15%. Total trade expanded 15.6% to S$82.3 billion, marking the 10th straight monthly gain.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 17.0 per cent year on year in August, more than doubled the 7.6 per cent gain in July, trade promotion agency International Enterprise Singapore reported on Monday morning.

site_title: Qatar agrees to buy 24 jet fighters from the UK
summary: Qatar has signed an agreement to buy 24 Typhoon fighter jets from the UK, marking the country's second major defence deal amid its diplomatic dispute with neighbours. The deal was announced after a lengthy negotiating period, following a similar purchase of F-15 jets from the US. The agreement comes as Qatar seeks to strengthen its defence capabilities amid the ongoing crisis with Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, the UAE, and Egypt. The UK's defence secretary Michael Fallon described the deal as an "important moment" in the defence relationship between the two countries.

site_title: Hedge funds bet on fuels over crude as hurricane trade persists
summary: Hedge funds are betting heavily on fuel prices, with bets on gasoline and diesel surging for three straight weeks, the most bullish in years. This trend is largely due to the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, which damaged the US refining industry. However, West Texas Intermediate crude prices are being viewed skeptically, with many investors expecting prices to stabilize. The persistent uncertainty surrounding US crude prices has led to a shift in focus towards fuels, as hedge funds seek to capitalize on expected price increases.

site_title: Trump steps onto world stage with maiden UN speech
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered his maiden address to the United Nations, a highly anticipated event with global attention. Trump's 30-minute speech aimed to make a lasting impression, unlike past leaders who relied on dramatic gestures. The speech is part of a week-long series of remarks by world leaders vying to make their mark on the global stage. Trump's appearance marked a significant moment in his presidency, with potential implications for international relations, markets, and polls.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pavillon Holdings, ISR Capital, mm2 Asia
summary: Pavillon Holdings, ISR Capital, and mm2 Asia saw new developments that may impact trading. Pavillon Holdings' subsidiary entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement for commercial properties in Malaysia, with 70 million new shares to be issued. ISR Capital invested up to S$2.68 million in Straits Hi-Rel, gaining a 25% stake. mm2 Asia acquired 13 Lotus Fivestar Cinemas, increasing its screen count to 133 and paying RM98 million.

site_title: Former Malaysia minister returns to support Najib government
summary: Former Malaysian minister Muhammad Muhammad Taib, known as Mat Taib, has returned to the ruling party, the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), after shifting allegiance to the opposition. The move is seen as a boost to Prime Minister Najib Razak's government ahead of an expected election, which must be held by August 2018. UMNO is touting Mat Taib's return as a sign the opposition can't deliver on its promises, particularly to the ethnic Malay majority.

site_title: Hugh Hendry shuts Eclectica hedge fund, blames macro model
summary: Hugh Hendry, founder of Eclectica hedge fund, has shut down his firm after a 15-year run amid mounting losses. He blamed the macro model for failing to produce sufficient returns to cover costs and keep investors satisfied. Hendry cited the high risks taken by peers to justify their existence and play catch-up with markets on a roll. The decision comes as the macro hedge funds have been struggling to keep up with the market's momentum.

site_title: US warns North Korea will be 'destroyed' if threats continue
summary: The US has warned North Korea that it will be "destroyed" if it continues to pursue its "reckless" nuclear and ballistic missile drive. US President Donald Trump will address the UN General Assembly on Tuesday, and he has pledged "stronger pressure" on North Korea with his Japanese and South Korean counterparts. The UN Security Council has imposed new sanctions, but their impact depends on China and Russia's implementation. US Ambassador Nikki Haley has emphasized that the US will take military action if diplomacy fails, and has asserted that "none of us want war."

site_title: Pavillon Holdings unit to buy Johor Bahru properties for RM52m
summary: Pavillon Holdings' subsidiary Fengchi Real Estate Sdn Bhd has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 107 lots in a commercial complex and adjoining vacant lands in Johor Bahru, Malaysia for RM52 million. The deal, worth S$16.7 million, involves issuing 70 million new shares as part payment. Pavillon Holdings will acquire the properties from Hock Der Holdings Sdn Bhd and Ascent Asia Sdn Bhd, with the proposed acquisition expected to be completed in the near future.

site_title: BlackGold, China Huadian, PLN units to team up on Riau project
summary: BLACKGOLD Natural Resources has formed a consortium with China Huadian Engineering, PT Samantaka Batubara, PT Pembangkitan Jawa-Bali, and PT PLN Batubara to develop the Riau-1 coal-fired power project in Indonesia. The heads of agreement were signed on September 15, with the consortium expected to establish a joint venture company and enter into a power purchase agreement with PLN if the project is awarded. The successful award of the project would mark a significant development for the consortium, with the Riau-1 project expected to contribute to Indonesia's energy needs.

site_title: China home prices rise 0.2% in August from July
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.2% in August from July, slowing from a 0.4% gain in July, as policymakers battle to rein in an overheated market. This marks a slowdown from the 1.5% increase in August 2016. Despite regulatory efforts, analysts expect the sector to lose momentum over the rest of the year due to policy tightening and financial deleveraging. New home prices rose 8.3% in August versus a year ago, with regulators intensifying their crackdown on property speculation in more than 45 major cities.

site_title: Bomb scare forces BA flight evacuation in Paris
summary: A British Airways flight from Paris to London was evacuated due to a bomb scare on Sunday. A woman in her 50s claimed the plane was going to explode, prompting authorities to take her into custody. After a psychiatrist determined she was suffering from impaired judgment, she was released. The flight, BA303, was cleared for take-off after bomb disposal experts and sniffer dogs searched the aircraft and passengers underwent individual searches by armed officers. The flight departed four hours late.

site_title: Hong Kong gearing up for digital payments
summary: Hong Kong is transitioning to digital payments, with many businesses accepting QR code payments linked to Chinese bank accounts. In contrast, commuters in Hong Kong still rely on cash in taxis. This shift reflects the city's efforts to modernize its payment systems.

site_title: Bike-sharing firm gears up for next cycle
summary: oBike, a Singapore-based bicycle-sharing company, is planning to expand its fleet size and develop a next-generation product, dubbed a "game-changer" in the market. The company is considering integrating blockchain technology to ease operational cash flow. oBike chairman Shi Yi declined to provide further details, but noted that the main difference between bikes with gears and those without gears is this feature. The company aims to differentiate itself from competitors and capitalize on emerging trends in the bike-sharing industry.

site_title: Zombie firms on the march as rate hikes near: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warns that a rise in interest rates could turn into a nightmare for investors, as zombie firms – companies with interest expenses exceeding earnings – pose a risk to GDP growth. The BIS notes that ultra-low interest rates have allowed these firms to operate, but higher rates could lead to debt service payments and default risk, creating challenges for corporates and economic growth. The share of zombie firms has risen sharply in the eurozone and Britain, with 10% in the eurozone and 16% in the US, according to the BIS report.

site_title: Testing time ahead due to Fed meeting, N Korea
summary: US stocks are poised for a test this week, with the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Thursday expected to influence market sentiment. Despite North Korea's missile firing over Japan, US equities remain relatively unaffected, with the S&P 500 index nearing 2,500. The Fed's decision on interest rates and balance sheet normalization will be closely watched, with possible rate changes expected in 2018. Markets are also awaiting economic data from Asia, including inflation figures from Malaysia and trade updates from Japan and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Powerful wind storm kills eight in Romania
summary: A powerful wind storm in Romania killed eight people and injured dozens more, with gusts reaching nearly 100km/h. The storm, considered rare in intensity and unexpected, was caused by an abnormal accumulation of hot air that stagnated in the atmosphere. Most victims were outside when the winds swept in, with one man hit by a falling tree and two children in critical condition. The storm caused widespread damage, including trees and roofs being torn off, and left 67 people injured. Authorities were caught off guard, with many saying they were not warned about the storm's severity.

site_title: Tillerson to meet Russia's Lavrov ahead of UN assembly
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is set to meet Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in New York on Sunday ahead of the UN General Assembly, amid strained ties between the two countries. The meeting comes as diplomatic relations between Washington and Moscow reach a historic low due to tit-for-tat cuts to each other's diplomatic missions. The meeting is expected to be a crucial moment in the deteriorating relationship.

site_title: Lurid lawsuit against Silicon Valley startup Upload barely dents its image
summary: A former employee, Elizabeth Scott, has settled a lawsuit against Silicon Valley startup Upload, alleging a "rampant sexual behavior and focus" in the office, including a "kink room" and unwanted advances from colleagues. The lawsuit claimed a hostile work environment and was settled for a modest sum. Despite the allegations, Upload's CEO and president were not forced to resign, and investors did not pull their money. The incident is part of a broader trend of sexual harassment in the tech industry, with other companies facing similar allegations.

site_title: Toronto condos buck Canada housing crunch, but prices seen cooling
summary: Toronto's condo market continues to defy expectations, with prices rising 21% in a year despite a slump in detached home prices. The market's relative affordability compared to single-family homes has fueled the boom, but recent rate hikes and rent controls may cool prices by 2018. Despite this, the condo market is expected to remain strong, driven by a lack of land for detached houses and a low vacancy rate, which has fueled bidding wars among renters.

site_title: TA Corp warrants have time on their side
summary: TA Corporation's warrants, set to expire in May 2022, offer a leveraged play on a potential property market recovery. The warrants have a gearing of 16.25 and a conversion premium of 14%. Despite the company reporting a loss of S$10.9 million in the first half of 2017, revenue rose 22% to S$107.8 million, indicating promise of better days ahead. The warrants' exercise price of S$0.28 is below the current share price, making them an attractive option for traders and investors looking to capitalize on a potential recovery.

site_title: How big business got Brazil hooked on junk food
summary: Big business, particularly multinational food companies like Nestle, is contributing to Brazil's growing health problems by aggressively expanding their presence in the country, making processed and sugary foods widely available. The expansion has led to a significant increase in obesity rates, with nearly 20% of the population now obese, and Type 2 diabetes cases rising by 300,000 annually. Critics argue that the industry's influence has stymied public health efforts, and that the focus on convenience and affordability has come at the cost of nutritional value.

images.alt_text: Of the 800 products that Nestlé says are available through its vendors, Ms da Silva (with her daughter) says her customers are mostly interested in only about two dozen of them, virtually all sugar- sweetened items such as Kit-Kats.

site_title: Britain lowers threat level after second arrest over London attack
summary: Britain lowered its terrorism threat level from critical to severe on Sunday, days after a bombing on a London Underground train injured 30 people. The attack, claimed by the Islamic State group, was the fifth in six months, resulting in 35 deaths. Two men, aged 18 and 21, were arrested in connection with the bombing, and police are investigating how the 21-year-old was radicalized. The government says it has no evidence to suggest the IS claim of responsibility, and soldiers will return to their original positions at key sites in the coming days.

site_title: Missile launch depresses market
summary: North Korea's recent missile launch has depressed the market, particularly the Straits Times Index (STI), which had been experiencing bullish momentum since 2017. The STI's Relative Strength Index (RSI) had reached an overbought level in July, indicating a high possibility of a deeper correction. Historical data shows that 11 out of 14 RSI overbought signals have resulted in significant reversals, with an average correction of -7.7% and the largest drawdown being 23% in 2000. The STI is currently at risk of breaking below its 3,189 support area, which could lead to a more severe correction.

site_title: Juggalos on the mall? Just another weekend of Washington protests
summary: Thousands of Juggalos, supporters of the rap-metal duo Insane Clown Posse, gathered at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington to protest their classification as a criminal gang by the FBI. The event was part of a larger day of protests, including rallies against white supremacy, Russia's election interference, and President Trump's tax returns. Despite the potentially combustible mix, clashes were limited, and the city continued with its usual business. The Juggalos were classified as a gang after self-proclaimed members committed crimes, and the American Civil Liberties Union is appealing the decision.

site_title: High Court fixes Oct 13 for Swiber hearing
summary: The Singapore High Court has scheduled a hearing on October 13 for Swiber Holdings' judicial managers to seek directions on third-party securities. The court had previously granted judicial management to Swiber Holdings and its unit in October last year due to financial distress. Over 10 creditors, including DBS, have not objected to the judicial management. This comes after several Singapore offshore companies, including Swissco Holdings and Ezra Holdings, have sought court protection amid the global oil slump.

site_title: Coffee deals brewing as hipsters drink up
summary: Nestle's acquisition of a majority stake in California-based coffee chain Blue Bottle highlights the trend of big companies seeking exposure to premium brands driven by millennials. Industry experts predict more deals in the fragmented coffee market, which offers richer profit margins than mainstream packaged food and drink. Nestle's move is seen as evidence of the company's efforts to reconnect with consumers, particularly young ones, and tap into emerging trends such as cold brew and single-origin beans. The deal may also help Nestle innovate more quickly and expand its presence in the high-end coffee market.

site_title: Work of healing that is solid as a rock
summary: A 33-year-old Albanian immigrant, Uliks Gryka, creates an enigmatic series of rock stacks along New York's Hudson River, balancing them without wires or adhesives. The stacks, resembling a procession towards the George Washington Bridge, change in size, shape, and number daily, and are constantly reassembled by Gryka after being knocked over by vandals. Gryka, who has no art training, draws inspiration from mythological figures and environmental artists, and sees the rocks as having unique personalities. His work has become a popular spot for hikers and cyclists, with some comparing it to a modern-day cairn or a public art installation.

site_title: Good governance impacts sustainability and value
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 8th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2017, themed "Purpose, Values & Culture - How Does it Drive Governance?", from September 18 to 22, 2017. The week-long program features a Statement of Support by corporates to uphold and advance good corporate governance standards, signed by 122 companies. Key corporate leaders emphasize the importance of good governance in driving sustainability and value, highlighting the need for integrity, transparency, and accountability in business practices.

site_title: Break down silos to manage cyber risks
summary: Cybersecurity experts emphasize the need for companies to break down silos and come together to develop a cybersecurity strategy that addresses the entire organization, rather than just individual departments. With the increasing interconnectedness of technology and economies, cybersecurity has become a major business risk, impacting company operations, financial statements, and brand reputation. Experts recommend a holistic approach, including risk assessment, investment in robust cybersecurity measures, and a focus on building digital trust. A risk-based approach, addressing vulnerable elements such as staff, and a multi-layered strategy comprising prevention, protection, detection, mitigation, response, and recovery are also key to managing cyber threats effectively.

site_title: Bulls to continue run but on borrowed time
summary: US stocks reached new records last week, despite concerns over Hurricane Irma, North Korea's missile test, and inflation data. The rally may continue unless the Federal Reserve, North Korea, or the Trump administration's tax plans produce a shock. Insurers rebounded after the storm's most devastating effects were concentrated on small Caribbean islands. Investors remain optimistic, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Equity strategists keep plugging US banks despite poor performance
summary: US bank shares are experiencing their poorest year relative to the market since 2011, with financial shares having the third-worst performance among 11 S&P 500 Index groups in 2017. Despite this, 9 out of 10 equity strategists surveyed by Bloomberg recommend buying bank shares, citing potential benefits from regulatory changes, tax cuts, and increased buybacks. They believe the rally is coming, not reliant on the Fed tightening, and that banks offer a valuation discount.

site_title: Give US better terms or we'll leave Paris Accord, says White House
summary: The White House has denied European suggestions it is softening its stance on the Paris climate accord, insisting the US will withdraw unless it can re-enter on more favorable terms. The US will not renegotiate the agreement but will review terms for engagement. Environment ministers from 30 countries met in Montreal to discuss the accord, with Canada, China, and the EU reaffirming their commitments. The US observer at the summit stated the US would try to review terms for engagement, but the White House maintains its position.

site_title: Quake, blackout, breakdowns cripple Mexico's refinery capacity
summary: A power failure hit Mexico's Cadereyta refinery, crippling its capacity. The refinery, which accounts for 48% of Pemex's capacity, lost power for several hours and some units were knocked offline. This follows the strongest earthquake in over a century, which shut the nation's biggest refinery, and maintenance curbs at other facilities. As a result, Mexico is boosting fuel imports, and the shortage is expected to increase pressure on an already tight market, particularly with US refineries recovering from Hurricane Harvey. Pemex's Salina Cruz refinery may take two to three weeks to return online.

site_title: Bedrock of sustainable growth
summary: Business leaders from various industries emphasize the importance of building a culture of good governance for sustainable growth and long-term success. They attribute this to strong leadership, core values, and transparency, which are essential for maintaining accountability and trust with stakeholders. Companies such as CA Technologies, NTUC FairPrice, PwC Singapore, and others, have implemented governance frameworks that promote integrity, compliance, and responsible business practices. By prioritizing good governance, these organizations foster a culture of authenticity, fairness, and transparency, ultimately driving sustainable performance and stakeholder trust.

site_title: Cyber resilience - step by step
summary: A step-by-step approach to cyber resilience is crucial for organizations, according to a Singapore Management University study. CEOs should discuss their cybersecurity approach with their CISO to ensure it aligns with strategic priorities and protects vital business data. Key questions to consider include: how does cybersecurity fit into the organization's overall strategy, what data is most vulnerable, and how can the organization mitigate potential threats. Effective cybersecurity measures can help protect business success and prevent costly data breaches.

site_title: Dishing out second chances
summary: Chef Raymond Khoo, owner of The Peranakan restaurant in Singapore, employs mostly elderly staff, including 71-year-old chef Shirley Tay and 66-year-old chef Carol Ee, to promote cultural heritage and give people a second chance. Khoo also helps ex-convicts, their wives, and spouses of ex-convicts with jobs, providing flexible timing to accommodate their needs. His initiatives, such as the Saturday@Lengkok Bahru program, offer free meals and services to elderly residents, creating a positive working culture and opportunities for staff to interact with people from different walks of life.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Hamilton triumphs as things get wet and wild
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the 10th Singapore Grand Prix, his third victory at the circuit, after a dramatic crash eliminated early leaders Sebastian Vettel and Max Verstappen. The rain-soaked race saw Vettel blast off from pole position, but a collision with Kimi Raikkonen and Fernando Alonso led to their retirements. Hamilton, starting fifth, built a commanding lead and crossed the finish line four seconds ahead of Daniel Ricciardo, securing his 263 points and a 28-point lead over Vettel in the drivers' championship.

site_title: Abe poised to hold snap polls: reports
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may hold a snap general election next month, capitalizing on opposition disarray and growing support for his handling of the North Korea crisis. The move comes after a recovery in public support following a series of scandals. Abe's decision could be influenced by a recent spate of scandals and his efforts to capitalize on the opposition's disarray.

site_title: Electric rickshaws, buses to spur India's green drive
summary: India plans to roll out nearly 100,000 battery-powered buses and autorickshaws in the coming weeks, aiming to make new vehicle sales all-electric by 2030. The move is part of India's efforts to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and combat pollution. This ambitious plan is in line with India's goal to become a global leader in electric vehicles, following China's lead. The initiative is expected to have a significant impact on the country's transportation sector and its efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Not bound by neat and tidy definition of a foreign player
summary: China Construction (South Pacific) Development Co Pte Ltd, a 25-year-old Singapore-based firm, challenges the notion that all Chinese companies operating in Singapore are "foreign players" due to its local staff and suppliers. Vice-chairman Li Xiao Qian argues that each firm has its unique management style and that the definition of a Chinese company is becoming increasingly blurred. Despite criticisms of Chinese contractors undercutting competitors, Li denies these claims, citing the need for qualified workers and the global sourcing of materials.

site_title: Mexico's new airport grounded by debts, delays, disaster
summary: Mexico's new international airport, set to handle 68 million passengers by 2020, is facing significant delays and setbacks, including a late rail line, delayed runway construction, and a contractor's bankruptcy. The project's ambitious timeline and hefty price tag of $13 billion make it a high-stakes gamble for President Enrique Pena Nieto's legacy. Left-leaning candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has vowed to scrap the project, citing concerns over corruption and cost. The airport's operators claim they will meet the 2020 deadline, but experts warn of potential geological and financial risks.

site_title: GM sells millions of cars in China, but hardly any electric ones
summary: GM sells millions of cars in China annually, but only a handful of electric vehicles. Despite CEO Mary Barra's commitment to electrify its China fleet, the company has opted to wait for government requirements, passing on a shortcut taken by rivals VW and Ford. GM aims to cut CO2 emissions by 28% by 2020 and offer electrified options in most models by 2025, with plans to reach 150,000 electric vehicle sales in China by 2020 and 500,000 by 2025.

site_title: Merkel powers on, but not as a feminist
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is poised to re-elect as the most powerful woman in the world, but her approach to power has been deliberately understated, avoiding feminist labels and focusing on her competence. Unlike Hillary Clinton, who faced a misogynistic backlash, Merkel's strategy seems to have been effective in her success. Merkel has cultivated a neutral public persona, eschewing attention to her appearance and instead emphasizing her work ethic and decisiveness. This approach has allowed her to navigate the male-dominated world of politics and maintain her popularity among voters.

images.alt_text: Mrs Merkel has cultivated a resolutely boring public persona, easing her ascent to lead a nation that long held conservative attitudes towards women.

site_title: Venture joins STI Reserve List; CEO Wong Ngit Liong ups stake to 7.1%
summary: Venture Corp joins the Straits Times Index Reserve List after CEO Wong Ngit Liong acquired 400,000 shares, increasing his stake to 7.1%. Other notable transactions include Frencken Group chairman Gooi Soon Chai increasing his stake to 23.07%, Accrelist executive chairman Terence Tea Yeok Kian building his stake to 22.29%, and Aberdeen Asset Management acquiring 8,311,700 shares of Raffles Medical Group, increasing its stake to 6.17%. The STI marginally declined by 0.2% over the five sessions, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for 2017 to 15.1%.

site_title: F1's new drive could help give Singapore Grand Prix a boost
summary: Formula 1's new direction under Liberty Media, led by CEO Chase Carey, aims to boost the Singapore Grand Prix with digital platforms, new technologies, and tweaked rules to make the sport more competitive and accessible. The 10-year-old event has attracted over 450,000 visitors and generated an estimated $1.4 billion in tourism spend, with a significant portion of revenue coming from local businesses. With F1's renewed focus on winning new fans and engaging existing ones, the Singapore Grand Prix may see an increase in attendance and revenue, potentially benefiting local businesses and the city-state's reputation.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan's rural petrol stations get new lease on life
summary: Japan is reopening rural petrol stations that closed due to declining demand, with local governments and elderly residents taking an active role in keeping them operational. The country's petrol station numbers have halved since 1995, leaving many remote areas far from filling stations. The central government is budgeting tens of millions of dollars a year to support refurbishment efforts, and some stations are being repurposed as shops, cafes, and launderettes, offering essential services to elderly residents.

site_title: The Wolf of Wall Street producer settles US suit linked to Malaysian fund
summary: Red Granite Pictures, the movie company co-founded by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's stepson Riza Aziz, has settled a US civil lawsuit to seize assets allegedly bought with money stolen from the Malaysian state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The settlement, reached without revealing the sum, resolves claims that the 2013 film "The Wolf of Wall Street" was financed using stolen 1MDB funds. This is part of the US Justice Department's kleptocracy asset recovery initiative, seeking to seize $1.7 billion in assets linked to the scandal.

site_title: Wildfires in US getting wilder and nearer to urban areas
summary: Wildfires in the US West have become increasingly severe and close to urban areas, with extreme fire behavior making them difficult to predict and fight. As of mid-September, 8.3 million acres have been burned, with thousands forced to evacuate due to 23 active fires in four states. The proximity of fires to population centers, combined with changes in forest management and shifting climate patterns, have contributed to the worsening situation. The 2017 season has been marked by sudden explosions in fire size, with some fires jumping several miles across rivers, and has raised concerns about the long-term impact on the region.

images.alt_text: Maggie Rose, her dog, Butch, and items she has readied if she must evacuate due to the wildfire in the Columbia Gorge, in Troutdale, Oregon, a suburb of Portland, on Sept 12.

site_title: Toshiba aims to finalise chips deal with Bain-led group by Sept 20
summary: Toshiba aims to finalize its chip deal with a Bain-led group by September 20, despite opposition from Western Digital. The Bain group, which includes Western Digital competitors, will provide around $3 billion in capital, with Apple Inc backing the bid. The deal would give Bain control of Toshiba's 18% stake in the chip business, narrowing Western Digital's options and making pricing negotiations tougher. Toshiba's board may not reach a final deal this week, with the issue to be revisited the following week.

site_title: Racing beats
summary: The 2017 Singapore Grand Prix features an off-track concert line-up with various music genres, including Duran Duran, Ariana Grande, The Chainsmokers, Seal, and Calvin Harris. The event runs from September 15 to 17, with multiple stages hosting performances by local and international artists.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Mexico-US trade would survive any Nafta rupture: Mexico foreign minister
summary: Mexico's foreign minister, Luis Videgaray, says US-Mexico trade would not end if NAFTA is terminated, with tariffs averaging 3% and governed by World Trade Organization rules. The US is seeking a five-year sunset provision to renegotiate the 23-year-old trade pact, but Videgaray considers it unnecessary. Mexico is doubling down on its open trade model and is exploring new markets, including the European Union. Despite tensions, the two countries share concerns on issues like drug trafficking and defense cooperation.

site_title: Funding talks at Uber, Lyft throw up tangle of alliances
summary: Uber is nearing a deal with SoftBank to receive billions of dollars in funding, potentially valuing the company at nearly $70 billion. SoftBank, a major investor in Didi Chuxing, Uber's largest former foe, is also a major investor in Lyft, Uber's biggest American rival. Lyft has held talks to raise funding from Alphabet, Uber's largest shareholder, further complicating the situation. The funding could aid Uber's expansion efforts, but also comes with demands such as a discounted share price and two seats on Uber's board of directors.

site_title: Euro zone enlargement call sparks backlash in Germany
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's re-election bid in Germany has sparked backlash over European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker's call for non-eurozone countries to quickly adopt the single currency. Juncker's statement was misinterpreted in Germany, where some politicians fear it would be lenient in assessing readiness for the euro, potentially fueling support for populist parties. EU officials clarified that countries must meet economic and governance criteria, and that some countries like Bulgaria already meet many standards for entry, including Romania and Bulgaria.

site_title: Florida's 'vulnerable' homes survive storm with light damage
summary: Hurricane Irma caused widespread damage to Florida's mobile homes, but surprisingly, most of them survived with minimal damage. The rapid loss of strength of the hurricane, combined with stricter construction and installation standards, contributed to the resilience of the homes. Many homes suffered damage to carports, screened porches, and awnings, but only a few had significant roof damage. Officials estimate that around 10% of homes in some communities suffered significant damage, with only a handful of homes appearing to have been destroyed or heavily damaged.

site_title: China's Zhongwang, Aleris extend merger deadline amid smuggling claims
summary: China's Zhongwang and Aleris extend their merger deadline to September 29 amid reports of smuggling allegations made by the US Department of Justice against Chinese aluminium tycoon Liu Zhongtian. The extension comes despite 27 US senators urging the Treasury to reject the sale in June, citing a "strategic misstep." The US Department of Justice filed a complaint against Zhongwang's affiliate, Perfectus Aluminum Inc, of evading US$1.5 billion in tariffs by illegally importing aluminium into the US.

site_title: F1 turning to tech to thrill fans, millennials
summary: Formula 1 is leveraging digital technologies to bring the sport closer to fans, particularly millennials, who prefer immersive experiences. The sport is exploring virtual reality, augmented reality, Internet-of-Things, and artificial intelligence to create a more engaging experience. New cameras, sounds, and graphics will be introduced, allowing viewers to feel like they are part of the action. The goal is to make the sport more accessible and appealing to a younger fan base, with a focus on short-form content and mobile platforms.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US law on online sales tax poised for court review
summary: The US Supreme Court is poised for a review of a South Dakota law requiring online retailers to collect sales tax, following a ruling by the state's Supreme Court that companies selling over $100,000 worth of goods in the state cannot be forced to collect taxes. The decision could have significant implications for states and local governments, potentially generating billions in revenue. Online retailers such as Overstock, Wayfair, and NewEgg are challenging the law, with some arguing that it is unconstitutional and others predicting that the Supreme Court will rule in their favor, upholding the 1992 decision in Quill Corp v North Dakota.

site_title: Facebook, Google limit robo systems that allowed racist ads
summary: Facebook and Google have limited their automated ad systems to prevent racist and offensive ads from being displayed. Facebook shut off a key self-service ad tool after finding ads targeting users by self-reported education or employer with offensive content. Google stopped its main Search ad system from suggesting offensive phrases for targeting. The moves come after several news organizations showed they could buy ads based on racist and antisemitic terms, highlighting the need for more human monitoring.

site_title: Bacon fans take heart as wholesale pork belly prices plummet
summary: US retail prices of bacon are expected to ease soon, following record-high wholesale prices of pork bellies in July, which reached over $200 per hundredweight due to strong consumer demand and tight supply. However, prices should begin to drop as the supply chain adjusts. This news is a relief for bacon fans, who saw prices surge to record highs this summer.

site_title: Don't ignore signs of vulnerability in financial system: BIS
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) has warned that the financial system is vulnerable to an unexpected rise in inflation followed by a sudden increase in interest rates. Despite increased bank capital, the BIS notes signs of increased risk-taking, including narrow credit spreads, increased carry trade activity, and high margin debt levels. Equity valuations are also considered "stretched," with bond yields near historical lows. The BIS cautions that these signals indicate a "risk-on" phase, which could lead to a financial crash similar to the 2008 crisis.

site_title: Property agents face prospect of tech takeover
summary: Established property listing firms in Singapore, such as SRX Property, PropertyGuru, and 99.co, say technology will complement real estate agents' services, not replace them. However, startups like Ohmyhome, HugProperty, and Averspace are developing innovative platforms that could potentially cut out the middleman entirely, using automation, data science, and machine learning. These startups aim to put more power in the hands of individual buyers, renters, and sellers, and some have reported strong revenue streams and healthy transaction volumes in their first year of business.

site_title: GM's Cruise aims to open self-driving tests to public; timing unclear
summary: General Motors' self-driving unit Cruise Automation plans to open an internal ride-hailing service to people outside the company, testing its autonomous technology with the public. The service, called Cruise Anywhere, currently uses GM software and is limited to San Francisco employees. Regulatory approval is needed before a public launch, and the timing is unclear. The move is part of GM's efforts to adapt to a potential shift in the car industry from individual ownership to transportation as a service. Cruise will test its cars in urban environments such as San Francisco, New York, and Seattle.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co's self-driving unit, Cruise Automation, is working to open an internal ride-hailing service to people outside the company, aiming to join a small group of autonomous vehicle developers testing their technology with the public.

site_title: North Korea seeks 'equilibrium' with US, says nuclear capability nearly complete
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong-Un vowed to complete the country's nuclear program, stating it had "nearly reached the terminal." The country successfully launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile over Japan, prompting international condemnation and a UN Security Council condemnation as "highly provocative." The US has scheduled talks with Japan and South Korea to address the crisis, while Russia and China have appealed for talks to resolve tensions. Analysts say achieving a military balance with the US is unrealistic for North Korea, and the country is expected to be capable of operating nuclear missiles as deterrence within three to five years.

site_title: Attendance up for this year's Singapore Grand Prix
summary: Singapore Grand Prix ticket sales increased 19% year-over-year to 260,400 spectators, surpassing the event's 10-year average. This marks a significant improvement from the 2016 event, which saw a 15% decline in attendance due to economic concerns and the Zika outbreak.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China Construction eyes regional role
summary: China Construction (South Pacific) Development Co Pte Ltd (CCDC), one of Singapore's top revenue earners, aims to expand its regional presence by tendering for more infrastructure contracts and private residential development projects. The company, a subsidiary of China State Construction Engineering Co (CSCEC), has clocked S$1 billion of new contracts annually and has built public housing, schools, and private homes in Singapore. CCDC hopes to secure construction contracts in markets such as Malaysia and Indonesia, and is diversifying into infrastructure projects to ensure sustainable volumes and increase revenue and profit.

images.alt_text: This year has become more challenging amid dwindling contracts from the private sector and intense competition squeezing out margins, says Mr Li. The company is thus eyeing more infrastructure work.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us mulls bankruptcy filing: WSJ
summary: Toys 'R' Us may file for bankruptcy in the coming weeks due to pressure from suppliers who are demanding cash payments on delivery, according to the Wall Street Journal. The company is considering Chapter 11 protection in the US Bankruptcy Court in Richmond, Virginia, amid its approximately $5 billion in debt. This move comes as consumers increasingly shop online and avoid brick-and-mortar stores, with more than a dozen significant retail bankruptcies this year.

site_title: Oil and chemical spills from Hurricane Harvey big, but dwarfed by Katrina
summary: Hurricane Harvey caused significant oil and chemical spills in Texas, with over 22,000 barrels of oil, refined fuels, and chemicals spilled across the state. While these spills rank among the worst environmental mishaps in the US, they pale in comparison to the 190,000 barrels spilled in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina in 2005. The spills, which also included millions of cubic feet of natural gas and toxic substances, were largely contained and expected to be cleaned up within a few weeks.

site_title: Jailed mogul's Wu-Tang Clan album goes for US$1 million
summary: A unique copy of the Wu-Tang Clan's album "Once Upon a Time in Shaolin" sold for over $1 million in an eBay auction, despite the seller, Martin Shkreli, being jailed. The album, valued at $2 million by the Wu-Tang Clan, was sold by Shkreli after he threatened Hillary Clinton. The buyer's identity remains unknown, and the authenticity of the album has raised questions, with some speculating it may be a fake. The music will not be made available to the buyer until 2103, as decreed by the Wu-Tang Clan.

site_title: Manhunt underway after London Underground bomb attack
summary: A bomb detonated on a packed London Underground train during the morning rush hour, injuring at least 29 people in the fifth terror attack in six months in the UK. The device, believed to be an improvised explosive device, was on a frozen food bag from the budget supermarket chain Lidl and had a timer but failed to detonate fully. The attack occurred at Parsons Green station in west London, and police launched a manhunt. The device was described as a "wall of fire" and caused significant burns to passengers. The UK's Metropolitan Police dismissed speculation on the device's maker, and US President Donald Trump was rebuked by Prime Minister Theresa May for his unhelpful speculation.

site_title: Exxon restarting Beaumont, Texas refinery after Harvey
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp has restarted its 362,300 barrel per day Beaumont, Texas refinery, approximately three weeks after it was shut down due to Tropical Storm Harvey. The company has begun operating two crude distillation units, with the 110,000 bpd Crude A CDU restarting first and the 240,000 bpd CDU following later. The refinery's coking unit and other units are still offline, but Exxon is working to bring them online. The restart marks the first time the refinery has operated since Harvey caused flooding on August 30.

site_title: China rebuffs US demand to cut off oil exports to North Korea
summary: China rebuffed US demands to cut off oil exports to North Korea, stating it would implement all UN Security Council resolutions and any further steps needed UN consensus. China's Ambassador to the US, Cui Tiankai, said the US should tone down its rhetoric and come to the negotiating table, not China. The US had demanded China use its oil exports to dissuade North Korea from pursuing nuclear weapons.

site_title: Veteran actor Harry Dean Stanton dies at 91
summary: Veteran actor Harry Dean Stanton died on September 15, 2017, at the age of 91, from natural causes. Stanton appeared in over 70 films and TV shows, including "Repo Man," "Paris, Texas," and "Twin Peaks." Known for his distinctive look and ability to convey emotion through minimal acting, Stanton worked with notable directors such as Lynch, Coppola, and Scorsese. He is remembered for his memorable roles, including a nearly silent portrayal in "Paris, Texas," which earned him an Oscar nomination. Stanton's legacy as a character actor and musician continues to be celebrated.

site_title: A new moon
summary: Designers in Singapore have creatively repurposed traditional mooncake boxes into unique planters, lanterns, tea boxes, and even piggy banks, reflecting the Mid-Autumn Festival's themes of the moon and family time. Inspired by the legend of Chang'e, designers have transformed the boxes into mini gardens, decorative lanterns, and storage spaces, offering an innovative way to appreciate the moon and preserve memories. These innovative designs blend functionality with artistic expression, celebrating the cultural significance of the Mid-Autumn Festival.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Bubble race
summary: The Pan Pacific Singapore is hosting a Bubble Lift Race, where guests can participate by guessing the fastest time to reach the 22nd floor on the hotel's iconic indoor bubble lifts. The winner will receive a prize, and guests can also enjoy a special brunch and 'Supercharged' cocktails. For more information, visit pacificmarketplace.sg.

site_title: Venezuela publishes oil prices in Chinese currency to shun US dollar
summary: Venezuela published oil and fuel prices in Chinese yuan to circumvent US dollar sanctions, echoing President Nicolas Maduro's plan to "free the country from the tyranny of the dollar." This move comes after the US imposed sanctions on Venezuela, citing allegations of undermining democracy. The global oil industry primarily uses the US dollar for pricing, making this a significant shift for the country.

site_title: Portugal looks to attract new investors after S&P rating upgrade
summary: Portugal's credit rating was upgraded to investment grade by S&P Global Ratings, allowing a broader range of investors to hold the country's debt, potentially leading to lower borrowing costs for the government and corporations. The upgrade follows a forecast increase in economic growth and a narrowing budget deficit. This development is seen as a positive step for the minority Socialist government, led by Prime Minister Antonio Costa, as it aims to reverse measures introduced during the bailout program and cut its deficit to 1.5% of GDP in 2017.

site_title: China's Ant is said to be renewing US review of MoneyGram sale
summary: Ant Financial, a Chinese affiliate of Alibaba Group, is reportedly resubmitting its bid to acquire MoneyGram International Inc for $1.2 billion after failing to secure US approval. The deal's fate is uncertain amid heightened tensions between the US and China, with the Trump administration scrutinizing Chinese takeovers of American businesses. Ant Financial faces a second 75-day review period before the US Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS) makes a decision, which could impact the deal's closure by the end of the year.

site_title: Ryanair to cancel up to 50 flights per day 'to improve punctuality'
summary: Ryanair will cancel 40-50 flights per day until October 31 to improve its on-time flight ratio, which has fallen below 80% in September. The cancellations, starting immediately, will affect approximately 285,000 journeys. Passengers will be offered a refund or an alternative flight, and a waived 40-euro surcharge to change flights. The airline attributes the disruptions to air traffic control strikes, weather, and crew leave.

site_title: Old people power: Japan's rural elderly reverse gas station closures
summary: In Japan, a rural gas station in Hokkaido has been reopened after four years of closure due to declining sales. This is part of a nationwide trend, with the number of gas stations halving from a 1995 peak to 31,000. The decline is attributed to Japan's waning population and lower new car sales, with oil demand dropping by nearly a third since 2000. The reopening is seen as a success for the local community, highlighting the "old people power" of rural residents who took initiative to save their gas station.

site_title: On vacation? Don't apologise in your out-of-office reply
summary: A media mogul has introduced an email tool allowing workers to disconnect from work during vacation by sending automated replies and deleting emails. The tool shifts the onus from workers to senders to follow up after vacation. This concept challenges the common practice of expecting workers to be constantly available and responsive, even on break. While the idea may not be practical for everyone, it highlights the need to respect individuals' personal time and set boundaries.

site_title: California court reinstates foie gras ban
summary: A US court in California has reinstated a 2004 ban on foie gras, a French delicacy made by force-feeding ducks and geese, after a previous ruling was overturned in 2015. The ban, which imposed a fine of $1,000 on restaurants selling the product, was hailed by animal rights organizations but criticized by chefs and food groups. The decision is set to be appealed, but if not, it will become law. The ban's reinstatement was welcomed by Peta, which described foie gras production as "torture."

site_title: Shy billionaire sets sights on New York's Plaza Hotel
summary: Shy billionaire Ben Ashkenazy has expanded his real estate portfolio, acquiring the Plaza Hotel in New York. Ashkenazy's company, which manages a $12 billion portfolio, now owns some of the US's most iconic buildings. Despite being a relatively unknown figure in the real estate world, Ashkenazy has built a significant collection of properties over the past three decades. His latest acquisition further solidifies his position as a prominent player in the industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Ashkenazy also is eyeing more of the famed Plaza Hotel (above) in New York, once owned by US President Donald Trump. His company acquired a minority stake in May that includes some rights to buy the building.

site_title: Iceland PM calls for snap election after government falls
summary: Iceland's Prime Minister Bjarni Benediktsson has called for a snap election in November after a party quit the coalition government due to his father's involvement in seeking a clean record for a convicted paedophile. This is the second snap election in less than a year, following the 2016 general elections. Benediktsson expressed disappointment, stating they are "in the same place" as after the previous elections. The election will likely be held in November, with the current government set to dissolve.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Bjarni Benediktsson said he preferred the election to be held in November, just over a year after the last snap vote which was triggered by the Panama Papers scandal.

site_title: When phones tell the future
summary: Apple unveiled its latest iPhones, including the iPhone X, which features a more expansive screen, facial recognition, and augmented reality capabilities. The new technology is expected to revolutionize daily life, enabling features such as unlocking phones with facial recognition and paying with it, as well as layering digital elements over the real world. As AR and facial recognition become more prevalent, concerns arise about personal privacy, commercial boundaries, and law enforcement, highlighting the need for policymakers and companies to address the consequences of this emerging technology.

site_title: After new North Korea missile test, US says has military options
summary: The US has signaled its patience for diplomacy with North Korea is wearing thin after the country's second missile test in under a month. The UN Security Council condemned the "highly provocative" launch, which flew over Japan and into the Pacific Ocean. The US has military options to deal with North Korea, but no immediate action is expected. The UN council had previously imposed sanctions on North Korea in response to a nuclear bomb test, and has stepped up measures to limit its textile exports and crude oil imports. Diplomatic efforts remain stalled.

site_title: F1 to rev up Singapore's events calendar till 2021
summary: Singapore has extended its contract with Formula 1 to remain a venue until 2021, securing the iconic night race for four more years. The deal, sealed after negotiations, will see the cost of organizing the race decrease to S$135 million annually, with the government funding 60% and the race organizer covering the remaining balance. The extension aims to maintain the appeal of future editions and capitalize on the sport's growing popularity in Asia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hurricane Jose could threaten New York next week: NHC
summary: Hurricane Jose, a Category 1 hurricane, may threaten New York City and other East Coast areas by next week, according to the National Hurricane Center. The storm, about 1,029 kilometers southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, strengthened as it churned through the Atlantic Ocean. Its path could put it near New Jersey and New York by Wednesday morning, potentially disrupting oil refineries and vessels along the Atlantic seaboard. An 18% chance of tropical storm-force winds in New York City is predicted, with forecasters uncertain about its exact impact.

images.alt_text: Hurricane Jose may threaten New York City and other areas of the East Coast by next week, according to a National Hurricane Center advisory.

site_title: Credit Suisse takes US$79.5m charge on MassMutual settlement
summary: Credit Suisse has settled lawsuits with Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co over the sale of mortgage-backed securities, taking a US$79.5 million charge in the third quarter. The settlement resolves two lawsuits and relates to 19 residential mortgage-backed securities sold before the financial crisis. This marks the lender's latest settlement, following agreements with the US Department of Justice and the National Credit Union Administration. The move aims to refocus the firm on wealth management and put an end to outstanding legal issues.

site_title: Asia is core to Indosuez Wealth Management: CEO
summary: Indosuez Wealth Management, the private banking arm of Credit Agricole, has set Asia as a core market, with a focus on Singapore and Hong Kong. The company aims to develop its private banking business organically, with plans to hire 400 staff by year-end, including 150 in Singapore. Indosuez offers private equity investment services, providing diversification to clients, and has allocated over €1 billion to clients in private equity last year. The company seeks to be "human size" and offer personalized service, rather than competing with larger banks.

site_title: Facebook opens AI lab in Canada, with Trudeau on hand
summary: Facebook has opened its first artificial intelligence lab in Canada, located at McGill University in Montreal. The lab is led by Joelle Pineau, a specialist in AI, and aims to drive research in the field. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attended the launch, praising the impact of AI research on Canada's prosperity. The lab's focus is on advancing AI study, with Pineau expressing hopes that Facebook's investment will lead to more research collaborations.

site_title: About 1.5 million, mostly in Florida, without power in Irma's wake
summary: Hurricane Irma has left approximately 1.5 million homes and businesses in Florida and Georgia without power, including 46 nursing homes. The storm, which ranked as a Category 4 hurricane, has caused at least 84 fatalities, with 33 in Florida and eight in Georgia and the Carolinas. The deaths at a nursing home in Hollywood Hills, where residents were exposed to heat without air conditioning, have sparked outrage and calls for increased measures to prevent such tragedies. Florida's healthcare agency has ordered the nursing home to be suspended from the state Medicaid program.

site_title: China's stocks leave bonds in the dust as debt war simmers
summary: China's stocks continue to outperform corporate bonds, with the Shanghai Composite Index on track for its best three months in almost two years. The yield gap between stocks and bonds is at its narrowest since 2015, driven by investors' expectations of economic momentum and earnings growth. Central bank efforts to curb credit growth are mainly affecting the bond market, while stocks are more focused on fundamentals. Authorities' deleveraging campaign is expected to continue, but the economy is showing resilience, with corporate earnings improving.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip led by banks at end of strong week
summary: European stocks declined 0.3% on Friday, led by banks, while export-oriented stocks fell 1.1% amid a stronger pound. Despite this, the region's equities posted their strongest week in two months, driven by attractive valuations and solid growth. Key sectors like utilities and healthcare rose, while miners and banks fell. The decline was softened by a Bank of England policymaker's suggestion of possible rate increases, and investors continue to seek value in European equities.

site_title: Equifax says CIO, chief security officer to exit after hack
summary: Equifax Inc. has announced that its chief information officer (CIO) and chief security officer (CSO) are retiring immediately amid a cyberattack that exposed data on 143 million Americans. The company had previously stated that hackers exploited a software vulnerability, and it hired a cybersecurity firm to review the incident. The move comes as lawmakers and regulators threaten to boost oversight of the industry, and the Federal Trade Commission has launched a probe. The company's CEO has apologized to those affected, and a group of state attorneys general has called for Equifax to stop selling credit-monitoring services.

site_title: Have no fear, Google Wifi is here
summary: Google Wifi was launched in Singapore on August 30, 2016, as part of Google's Internet-of-Things strategy. The product, consisting of a node and a power adapter, offers a powerful and easy-to-manage network for homes. The sleek design aims to fit seamlessly into any home environment, replacing traditional large and boxy routers. Google Wifi was initially met with buzz and excitement upon its launch, marking a significant step in bringing Google's technology into homes.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P end at new records, brushing off North Korea, weak data
summary: US stocks ended the week on a high note, with the Dow and S&P reaching new records despite weak economic data and a North Korea missile launch. Investors brushed off concerns, citing a desire to avoid market disruptions. Economist Joel Naroff noted that investors were focused on pushing prices higher. The rally came despite a US economic data release showing a big impact from Hurricane Irma and an attack on the London subway.

site_title: Motor racing: Red Bull and Renault brush off engine 'speculation'
summary: Renault and Red Bull have dismissed reports that they will end their engine partnership after the upcoming season, calling the rumors "speculation." The pair won four consecutive titles together, but the relationship has been strained since the introduction of the 1.6-liter V6 turbo hybrid power unit in 2014. Despite Renault's less competitive engines, the partnership was saved when Red Bull failed to find an alternative supplier. The teams are expected to continue their partnership.

site_title: Roche focuses on diagnostics to help cut healthcare costs
summary: Roche Diagnostics is investing 450 million Swiss francs in a manufacturing plant in Suzhou, China, to strengthen its global manufacturing network and produce reagents for cancer, metabolic, and infectious diseases. The company aims to cut healthcare costs by enabling patients to avoid unnecessary hospital treatment and reducing treatment duration. Diagnostics influence over 60% of medical treatment decisions, but receives only 2% of healthcare funding worldwide. Roche Diagnostics' expansion in Asia-Pacific aims to shape best practices and reduce costs in emerging markets.

site_title: Credit Agricole sizing up opportunity for growth in Asia, says deputy CEO
summary: Credit Agricole, France's second-largest bank, is considering expanding its presence in Asia to tap the region's growth potential. The lender has opened a representative office in Indonesia and plans to hire 15-20 bankers annually in Asia. Credit Agricole's private bank has already expanded into Asia through the purchase of Credit Industriel et Commercial's private-banking operations in Hong Kong and Singapore. The bank's deputy CEO, Xavier Musca, expressed "genuine interest" in Asia for opportunities that European banks can offer, with the region being a "very important saving pool."

site_title: Developers' private-home sales so far this year shoot past 2016's full-year figure
summary: Private home sales in Singapore have exceeded 2016's full-year figure, with 8,391 units sold between January and August, a 60.3% increase from the same period last year. This surpasses the average annual sales of 7,576 units from 2014 to 2016. Developers expect sales to continue, with estimates ranging from 12,000 to 16,000 units by the end of 2017, driven by buyers seeking to purchase at market trough prices before potential price increases.

images.alt_text: Developers' private home sales in the first eight months of this year have already surpassed that made in the whole of last year - with buying fervour in the market having been unrestrained even in August, which coincided with the lunar Hungry Ghost Festival.

site_title: Gillman turns five
summary: Gillman Barracks, a high-end art cluster, is celebrating its fifth anniversary with an Art After Dark party on September 22. The event will feature live performances, new exhibitions, and pop-up food and beverage stalls. Galleries will stay open late, showcasing works by Angki Purbandono, Chen Wen Hsi, and Fyerool Darma. Admission is free.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Keppel T&T unit invests US$10m in US data centre startup
summary: Keppel T&T's unit, Keppel Data Centres, has invested US$10 million in US data centre startup Nautilus Data Technologies Inc's Series C preferred stock funding, representing 24.1% of the total issued shares. The investment aims to support Nautilus' commercial data centre deployment and benefits from its patented water-cooling technology, reducing electricity usage by 80%. This strategic investment will allow Keppel Data Centres to benefit from innovative and sustainable data centre technology.

site_title: Peter Teo
summary: Peter Teo, co-founder of PS.Cafe, discusses the challenges and successes of opening a new cafe location in Singapore. Despite a delayed opening due to renovation issues, Teo attributes the cafe's longevity to timing, luck, and working with the right people. PS.Cafe is known for its truffle fries and burgers, and its success can be attributed to consistency and constant evolution. The cafe has expanded to multiple locations, including a new outlet at One Fullerton and a second outlet at Raffles City, which is set to open by year-end. Teo shares his approach to selecting locations, which prioritizes finding spots that people want to escape to, and his advice for those considering opening a cafe.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Golden Energy to reduce share capital by US$401.2m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources plans to reduce its share capital by US$401.2 million to write off accumulated losses of the same amount. This move will not affect net tangible assets, earnings per share, or gearing level. The company will cancel share capital, but the number of issued shares and shareholder ownership will remain unchanged. The capital reduction aims to rationalize the balance sheet and facilitate future equity-related fund raising exercises.

site_title: STI ends week of relatively quiet trading 19 points lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week 19 points lower, or 0.6%, at 3,209.56. The decline was attributed to the sudden downgrade of three Singapore banks due to increasing expectations of delayed US interest rate hikes, as well as geopolitical tensions following North Korea's missile test over Japan. The STI fell 11.39 points, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC experiencing significant losses.

site_title: DBS training programme, pact with M'sia to boost S'pore fintech industry
summary: Singapore's fintech industry received a boost with the announcement of a DBS training programme and a cooperation agreement between the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Securities Commission Malaysia (SC). The programme, in partnership with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), will train over 85 young professionals in agile development, DevOps, and data analytics. The collaboration aims to foster closer cooperation on fintech and innovation in financial services between Singapore and Malaysia, and considers joint innovation projects leveraging blockchain and distributed ledgers.

images.alt_text: To build fintech talents, DBS has partnered IMDA to create the first fintech training programme under TechSkills Accelerator. It will train more than 85 young professionals.

site_title: Rohingya in Pakistan still living in despair
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya Muslims, stateless and desperate, live in poverty-stricken slums in Karachi, Pakistan. Many have fled Myanmar's violence, with an estimated 500,000 Rohingya already living in Pakistan. Despite condemnation from Pakistan, residents face routine harassment by police, including denial of ID cards, jobs, and access to hospitals. Residents demand more aid, food, and pressure on the Myanmar government, while some have been forced to pretend to be Bengalis to avoid persecution.

site_title: Everyday beauty
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has launched a new bracelet and ring from its iconic Perlée collection, designed for everyday wear. The pieces feature hand-polished yellow gold beads and an invisible hinge, showcasing the brand's 100-year tradition of excellence. The Perlée Circles of Gold bracelet is priced at $11,500, while the ring costs $3,650. The collection's minimalist and modern designs are part of the growing trend of layering jewelry, catering to those with high disposable incomes who want stylish, high-quality pieces for daily wear.

site_title: Not wet but wow
summary: Lewis Hamilton leads the drivers' championship with a three-point lead over Sebastian Vettel, having dominated the Italian Grand Prix at Monza two weeks ago. The Singapore Grand Prix will be a challenging and hot event, with an average lap speed of 172 kmh and a bumpy circuit. Hamilton has struggled in the past, with three DNFs in Singapore Grands Prix, while Vettel has consistently performed well, with a four-time win record. The outcome of the championship will be determined in the next seven races, with the event taking place in Singapore on Sunday night.

site_title: Heading into the final stretch
summary: The BT Corporate Golf League enters its final leg at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden course on Friday. Team SunMoon leads the Open Category table with a tight finish expected, as Tat Hong - The Crane Boomers and Team Citi chase closely. In Category A, Gayatri and Team Boss are separated by only a point, setting up a close finish. The tournament concludes the BT Corporate Golf League, marking the end of the golf season.

site_title: Downtrend in US fixed mortgage rates halted
summary: US fixed mortgage rates held steady this week, with the 30-year fixed-rate average remaining at 3.78% and the 15-year fixed-rate average at 3.08%. Long-term bond yields rose sharply, which may signal an upcoming increase in mortgage rates. Over 2/3 of mortgage rate experts surveyed by Bankrate.com predict rates will climb in the coming week. Despite natural disasters, mortgage applications increased 9.9% last week, with refinancing activity up 9% and purchase activity up 11%.

site_title: North Korea puts Guam in range with latest missile test over Japan
summary: North Korea launched an intermediate-range missile over Japan, reaching Guam in range, amid heightened tensions following the UN's approval of harsher sanctions against Kim Jong Un's regime. The missile travelled 3,700km, exceeding the 3,400km distance from Pyongyang to Guam. Investors largely ignored the launch, focusing on interest rate moves instead. The US and its allies condemned the test, with US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson calling for China and Russia to take action against North Korea.

site_title: Citibank and Mercer (Singapore) among finalists of FinTech Awards
summary: Citibank and Mercer (Singapore) are among the 30 finalists for the FinTech Awards, to be presented at the Singapore FinTech Festival in November. The awards recognize innovative financial-technology solutions implemented by fintech start-ups, financial institutions, and technology companies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PwC will select up to 10 winners from the finalists. The festival, in its second edition, aims to bring together startups, investors, banks, researchers, and corporates to promote the growth and evolution of the Singapore FinTech ecosystem.

site_title: In tune with nature
summary: A contemporary tropical home in Singapore, designed by RT + Q Architects, has been shortlisted for the World Architecture Festival's House - Completed Buildings category. The "House with Shadows" features extensive landscaping, including three distinct green spaces, and is situated between two other homes owned by the same family. The design concept revolves around garden spaces, addressing tropical living issues like cross-ventilation and natural light. The owners, low-key doctors, chose to live in the middle house, allowing them to dictate the look of the neighboring homes. The house's unique blend of traditional and modern elements has received praise from the architects and owners.

site_title: Cashflow planning in the digital era
summary: A growing trend of online shopping can lead to overspending, making cashflow planning crucial. The convenience of e-commerce can result in impulse purchases, with many consumers overspending to hit minimum purchase amounts for free delivery and extra savings. To combat this, cashflow planning involves tracking daily expenses, setting targets for spending habits, and trimming unnecessary expenses. Regular reviews of expenditure are essential to ensure financial stability. By implementing a three-step cashflow planning process, individuals can better manage their finances and achieve their savings goals.

site_title: This trader is betting millions on 'false peace'
summary: Trader Christopher Cole's hedge fund Artemis Capital is betting against a market reversal, taking the opposite side of investors who expect a flare-up of volatility in the months ahead. Cole draws parallels to the 1987 stock market crash, when investors were lulled into believing that volatility would not erupt. Despite the current low VIX gauge, Cole believes fear is increasing, setting him up for a potential profit if the market does experience a downturn. This long-running and profitable trade has been a successful bet against chaos in the financial markets.

site_title: Telcos unveil iPhone 8 pricing; Singtel joins unlimited data trend
summary: Telcos in Singapore have announced prices for the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus, ranging from free to S$935 for the iPhone 8 Plus with contract. Singtel has also launched mobile plans with unlimited local data, talk time, and SMSes, while M1 offers an unlimited data plan with a 12-month contract for S$98 a month. Meanwhile, Circles.Life will offer instalment payment plans for the latest Apple smartphones.

site_title: Cult classic
summary: The Projector is celebrating the 25th anniversary of Quentin Tarantino's directorial debut "Reservoir Dogs" with a one-off screening of the 1992 heist thriller. The film, starring Harvey Keitel and Michael Madsen, has been hailed as "the greatest independent film of all time" by Empire magazine. The screening will take place at The Projector's Green Room on September 16 at 9pm, with tickets available.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: How to know you're being tricked by Russian propaganda
summary: The European Union's East Stratcom Task Force has compiled a database of Russian propaganda, but fact-checking efforts have been ineffective in countering the spread of disinformation. The task force is funded by taxpayers, but a simpler approach is to adopt techniques such as checking the source of information and being aware of one's own biases. Russian propaganda outlets often use emotional appeals and half-truths, rather than relying on fact-based reporting. By following links to original sources and considering the reputation of the source, individuals can effectively resist Russian propaganda without needing expensive counter-propaganda efforts.

site_title: Food stars
summary: Resorts World Sentosa and Savour Events are hosting The Great Food Festival (TGFF) from Sept 21 to 24, featuring international chefs and RWS celebrity chefs. The festival includes segments such as the Star Chef Arena, Rollin' Sweet Times, and collaborative dinners titled the Connoisseur Collection. Tickets are available at www.tgff.com.sg.

site_title: Turn back the clock
summary: Two new treatments, HIFU SygmaLift and Enlighten Gold, aim to restore a youthful glow to men and women. HIFU SygmaLift uses ultrasound energy to stimulate collagen production, tighten skin, and reduce fat around the chin and jawline. Enlighten Gold, a high-tech laser platform, targets fine lines, wrinkles, and skin laxity with ultrafast laser pulses. Both treatments are painless, have no downtime, and produce visible results after 40 days. Recommended courses of three treatments and maintenance sessions are advised for optimal results.

site_title: Some Like It Hot
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng Ltd, a Singapore-based food and beverage manufacturer, began as a family-owned business in 1938. The company faced challenges during the Japanese Occupation, but sustained production and expanded after the war. By the 1950s, Yeo Hiap Seng had set up a second factory in Bukit Timah, producing around 224,000 bottles of sauce each month. The company's early success was due in part to the damage sustained by its factory during the Occupation, which allowed it to maintain its stockpile of soya sauce ingredients.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental receives bids for Excelsior hotel in HK
summary: Mandarin Oriental International Limited has received proposals from potential buyers to acquire The Excelsior hotel in Hong Kong. The company did not provide further details on the proposals. This move will form the basis for further consideration of the company's strategic options.

site_title: How Hollywood is killing Hollywood
summary: Hollywood executives blame Rotten Tomatoes, a review-aggregation site, for declining ratings and box office woes, despite a study finding no correlation between negative scores and box office totals. In reality, the median Rotten Tomatoes score is increasing, and audiences and critics' scores are aligning. The real issue may be that audiences are bored with CGI-heavy efforts, leading to diminishing box office returns. The study's findings suggest that Rotten Tomatoes is not the primary cause of Hollywood's problems.

site_title: Say halo to better health
summary: Krishna Bagaria, an asthma sufferer, discovered halotherapy, a salt therapy treatment, in Germany and later opened a centre in Singapore, Breathya, offering relief to respiratory and skin conditions. After two sessions, Bagaria no longer needed an inhaler. The therapy involves clients sitting in a salt-filled room, breathing in micro particles of medical-grade salt vapour, which is believed to reduce inflammation, clear airways, and restore overall well-being. While it's not suitable for everyone, including those with certain health conditions, Breathya has seen dozens of clients experience relief from various conditions.

site_title: Ezion Holdings to hold second informal meetings with securities holders
summary: Ezion Holdings Limited will hold a second informal meeting with securities holders on October 2 to discuss the company's S$1.5 billion Multicurrency Debt Issuance Programme. The meeting will focus on providing updates on the refinancing proposal with lenders and presenting the proposal to holders of various series of notes and subordinated securities. The meetings will be facilitated by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore).

site_title: Art for ants
summary: South African painter Lorraine Loots is showcasing 100 miniature artworks, including five original pieces depicting Singaporean historical and cultural landmarks, at K+ Curatorial Space in Scotts Square. The exhibit, #ANTSinSINGAPORE, runs until October 29. Loots aims to share her art with ants, believing that small is beautiful. The miniatures will also be on sale, offering a unique memento for visitors.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
