site_title: London subway bomb blast a terrorist incident: police
summary: A homemade bomb exploded in a London subway carriage during rush-hour, injuring 22 commuters. The blast, described as a terrorist incident, came from an improvised explosive device with a timer, indicating some bomb-making knowledge was used. Authorities identified one suspect, and security measures were tightened across London's mass transit network. Prime Minister Theresa May called a special meeting of the anti-terror Cobra committee, and the incident is being investigated by police and MI5.

site_title: Independent financial adviser appointed after Esteel Enterprise makes mandatory general offer for BRC Asia
summary: An independent financial adviser, RHT Capital Pte Ltd, has been appointed to advise the independent directors of BRC Asia Limited following a mandatory general offer by Esteel Enterprise Pte Ltd to acquire the company at S$0.925 per share. Esteel Enterprise, owned by You Zhenhua's Advance Venture Investments Limited (80.1%) and Liu Bin's Toptip Holding (19.9%), purchased a 43.77% stake in BRC Asia last week. The company's directors will consider the independent adviser's advice and the offeror's intentions before making a recommendation to shareholders.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust's (CRCT) target price is raised to S$1.59 from S$1.55 due to its sponsor's offline-and-online strategy and potential replication across its portfolio. Ellipsiz Limited is expected to return S$0.83/share after selling its probe card business for US$65 million. AEM Holdings' restructuring efforts and co-development of a high-margin test handler for Customer I are expected to drive profitability.

site_title: Sun Hung Kai Properties sees sales slowing after record year
summary: Sun Hung Kai Properties, Hong Kong's most valuable developer, posted a 29% jump in full-year contracted sales value to a record HK$52.4 billion. Despite this, the company expects sales to slow in the current year, with a target of HK$36 billion for the 2017-18 fiscal year. The company attributes the slowdown to the government's restrictive measures in the residential market, particularly in the secondary market. The company's underlying profit rose 7.4% to HK$25.97 billion.

site_title: Canadian home resales rose in August after 4 declines
summary: Canadian home resales rose 1.3% in August after four straight declines, according to the Canadian Real Estate Association. Sales increased 14.3% in Toronto, but forecasts for 2017 and 2018 sales and prices were lowered due to tax and rule changes announced in April. Despite this, home prices rose 11.2% from last year. The rebound in sales is uncertain, and only time will tell if it marks the start of a rebound.

site_title: Young Turks
summary: In Hong Kong, a new generation of chefs is challenging traditional notions of seniority and continuity in the culinary world. Young chefs, such as Quincey Tang, Chef May Chow, Chan Kei Ying, and Jayson Tang, are taking leading positions in the industry and pushing the boundaries of Cantonese cuisine. These chefs, who have been influenced by international culinary trends and techniques, are creating innovative dishes that blend traditional flavors with modern twists. They are also promoting awareness of the finesse inherent in Cantonese cuisine and advocating for the importance of using high-quality ingredients and traditional techniques. With their unique perspectives and skills, these young chefs are redefining the culinary landscape in Hong Kong and beyond.

site_title: Hurricane Irma shakes Havana's crumbling buildings
summary: Hurricane Irma has caused widespread destruction in Havana, Cuba's historic center, with 7 people killed and over 4,400 cases of damage reported. The city's crumbling buildings, exacerbated by a 57-year US trade embargo, have accelerated the city's decline. Residents fear the storm will worsen the housing deficit, which has risen to nearly 900,000 units nationwide, with Havana facing a shortage of over 200,000 homes. The government faces criticism for its handling of the crisis, with many residents expressing frustration over the lack of action to address the city's long-standing housing problems.

site_title: International Healthway Corporation proposes change of name
summary: International Healthway Corporation Limited has proposed a name change to OUE Lippo Healthcare Limited, set to be decided by shareholders at an extraordinary general meeting on October 9. The company will hold a circular for shareholders to review the proposal. The name change is aimed at aligning the company's identity with its business focus on healthcare.

site_title: Go west
summary: The hit musical West Side Story returns to the stage at Marina Bay Sands, running at Mastercard Theatres until Sept 30. Inspired by Romeo & Juliet, the show tells the story of two star-crossed lovers from rival street gangs who meet a tragic end. The classic music composed by Leonard Bernstein and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim continues to captivate audiences, with iconic songs such as Maria, Tonight, and America. Tickets are available through Sistic and at the box office.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: SMRT Trains wins tender to run Thomson-East Coast Line
summary: SMRT Trains won a tender to operate the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) in Singapore for an initial nine-year period. The 43 km long line, set to open in stages from 2019, will feature 31 stations and seven interchange stations linking it to existing MRT lines. The contract aims to enhance connectivity between the north, central, and eastern parts of Singapore and strengthen the rail network's resilience.

site_title: Industrial output, retail sales take a hit from Harvey's fury
summary: US industrial output fell 0.9% in August, the first decline since January, due to Hurricane Harvey's impact on oil, gas, and chemical plants. Retail sales also dipped 0.2%, with economists expecting a 0.1% increase. The decline was attributed to storm effects, with mining output falling 0.8% and consumer goods output dropping 0.7%. Despite this, motor vehicle production rose 2.2% and retail sales increased 3.2% year-over-year, suggesting underlying strength in domestic demand.

site_title: Nam Cheong subsidiary grants Option to Purchase to dispose of Paya Lebar property
summary: Nam Cheong Offshore Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Nam Cheong Limited, has granted an Option to Purchase to third-party purchasers to dispose of its Paya Lebar property in Singapore for S$4.5 million. The disposal will be used to settle outstanding debt under a credit facility granted by DBS Bank. This is the second disposal by Nam Cheong in two weeks, following the sale of office lots at Suntec Tower Three for S$25 million on September 8. The disposal does not require shareholder approval.

site_title: Ice gems
summary: Graff Diamonds, a luxury jeweller known for its rare and brilliant cut diamonds, has opened its first store in Singapore at ION Orchard. Founded in 1960 by Laurence Graff, the brand now boasts over 50 stores worldwide and has a royal clientele. The new 2,330 sq.ft store offers exclusive pieces and a VIP room, marking the first in Southeast Asia. CEO Francois Graff expressed excitement about the project, citing Singapore's importance in Graff's history and its appeal to discerning clients. The store is the latest addition to the brand's global retail presence.

site_title: Monster blob menaces London's East End sewers
summary: A massive 250m-long, 140-tonne "fatberg" has been discovered in London's East End sewers, threatening the city's underground infrastructure. The rock-solid mass of fat, disposable wipes, diapers, and other waste has been named the Whitechapel fatberg. An 8-member team will spend three weeks clearing the blockage, working all day. The discovery highlights the growing issue of sewer waste and the need for better waste management practices to prevent such incidents in the future.

site_title: SMRT bags Thomson-East Coast Line tender
summary: SMRT Trains has won the tender to operate the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) in Singapore for an initial nine-year period, beating SBS Transit in both quality and price. SMRT Trains quoted a total service fee of S$1.7 billion, 30% lower than SBS Transit's price. The TEL operator was chosen after a two-envelope process, with SMRT Trains receiving a higher quality score due to its commitment to predictive maintenance and staff development. The contract will enhance connectivity between Singapore's north, central, and eastern parts and strengthen the resilience of the rail network.

images.alt_text: The 43 km TEL, Singapore's most complex rail project to date, has 31 stations with seven interchange stations linking it to all five existing MRT lines. It opens in stages from 2019, enhancing connectivity between the north, central and eastern parts of Singapore.

site_title: US industrial output, sapped by Harvey, falls for first time since January
summary: US industrial output fell 0.9% in August, the first decline since January, due to Hurricane Harvey's impact on oil, gas, and chemical plants along the Gulf Coast and a cool summer in the east. The decline was attributed to 0.75 percentage points, primarily from storm effects, and was expected by economists despite a 0.1% increase forecasted. Other sectors, such as consumer goods and motor vehicles, also contributed to the decline, with utilization of factory capacity falling to 76.1%.

site_title: Golden Energy to carry out capital reduction exercise to write off US$401.2m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources plans to carry out a capital reduction exercise to write off US$401.2 million in losses, mainly due to impairment losses and doubtful debts. The move aims to rationalize the company's balance sheet and facilitate future equity-related fund raising exercises. As a result, the group will cancel share capital by the same amount.

site_title: Air Berlin says it received several offers for its assets
summary: Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, has received several offers for its assets following its insolvency filing last month. The airline's major shareholder Etihad withdrew funding due to years of losses. A final decision on buyers is due on September 25, four days after Germany's national election. This decision will determine the fate of Air Berlin's assets, which will be assessed by the carrier.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental receives bids for The Excelsior in Hong Kong, shares surge on Friday
summary: Mandarin Oriental International Limited has received proposals to acquire The Excelsior hotel in Hong Kong. The company's shares surged 20.8% to US$2.56 on Friday, likely due to speculation about a potential deal. No further details were provided, and the company will consider the proposals further.

site_title: US retail sales post biggest drop in six months
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.2% in August, the largest decline in six months, due to the impact of Hurricane Harvey on motor vehicle purchases. Despite a 3.2% year-on-year increase, core retail sales excluding automobiles and other discretionary items dropped 0.2%. The weak sales report may not affect expectations for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in December, but suggests moderation in consumer spending in the third quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong proposes creation of securities listing policy panel
summary: Hong Kong regulators proposed the creation of a securities listing policy panel to improve transparency and governance for investors. The panel, set up outside the Securities and Futures Commission and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd, will discuss listing policies and initiate centralised discussions. The move follows investor criticism of possible conflicts of interest in the current framework, where HKEX acts as both market operator and regulator. The proposed changes aim to address these concerns and enhance the listing process for initial public offerings (IPOs).

site_title: Superfast, but not super furious
summary: The Ferrari 812 Superfast, priced at S$1.42m, is a grand tourer that lives up to its name, but its impressive acceleration is not the only factor that sets it apart. The car boasts a 12-cylinder engine displacing 6.5 liters, producing 800 horsepower, and a new four-wheel-steering system, which enhances its handling and stability. The 812 Superfast accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 2.9 seconds and 0-200 km/h in 7.9 seconds, making it a formidable competitor on the track. Its agility and controlled aggression in corners make it a delightful driving experience.

site_title: Cooking up diversity
summary: A writer reflects on the struggle of homemaking and cooking, using the analogy of conquering broccoli as a symbol of mastering control and finding comfort in the kitchen. The writer argues that the kitchen is a space where women can find empowerment and pride, despite societal pressures and stereotypes. They note that the pursuit of perfection in cooking is often tied to the expectation of domesticity, and that women who choose to prioritize other skills or interests should be celebrated. The writer concludes that embracing imperfection and finding joy in imperfect cooking is essential to resisting the anxiety and judgment that often accompany homemaking.

images.alt_text: It seems the challenge of gender diversity today is to resist embarrassing women for their choices, and accept that women will do just fine with different skills and priorities.

site_title: Using his head, heart and guts to lead
summary: Beyonics CEO Scott D Smith has won the Asia Pacific Entrepreneurship Award 2017, citing the significance of leadership and teamwork in business success. Smith attributes his company's growth to surrounding himself with good people and emphasizes the importance of taking care of employees. He believes that leaders must possess a strong head, heart, and guts to make decisions and overcome obstacles, and that life is 80% attitude. Beyonics plans to invest in three mega-campuses and expand its operations in the region, aiming for 25% growth across its core segments.

site_title: Excelpoint boss builds success on trust
summary: Excelpoint Technology Ltd's founder and Group CEO Albert Phuay was named Entrepreneur of the Year Award 2017 for Electrical & Electronics Industry. Phuay attributed the award to the trust he built over 30 years, which helped him get started and grow his business. The award serves as a reminder to continuously adapt and innovate to remain competitive and add value for stakeholders.

site_title: Renault-Nissan to launch 12 zero-emission models
summary: Renault-Nissan plans to launch 12 zero-emission models over the next six years, targeting 20% of sales to be electrified by 2022, with projected car sales of 14 million units. The alliance aims to double synergy savings to 10 billion euros and equip dozens of models with driverless technology. Chairman Carlos Ghosn stated his intention to carry out the plan for as long as it makes sense, with the goal of increasing annual revenues to around $240 billion.

site_title: Update: Terrorist blast injures 22 during London's subway's rush hour
summary: At least 22 people were injured when a suspected terrorist set off an improvised explosive device on a London subway train during morning rush hour, the fifth attack in the UK this year. The device, possibly with a timer, failed to detonate fully and caused a stampede at Parsons Green station. Police identified one suspect and appealed for photos and information. The incident comes amid a "severe" terror threat level, with terrorism-related arrests rising 68% over the past year. Prime Minister Theresa May and US President Donald Trump offered support and vowed to bring the perpetrator to justice.

site_title: Australia shares end down, but post 1st weekly gain in four; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares ended down 0.8% on Friday, despite a weekly gain of 0.4% for the first time in four weeks. Weak steel and iron ore prices weighed on material stocks, while banks fell on profit-taking. Iron ore futures fell due to anticipated slower demand, while North Korea's missile launch triggered buying of safe-haven assets like gold. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.7%, marking a third week of losses.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix extends Formula 1 until 2021
summary: Singapore has extended its Formula 1 presence until 2021, with the Singapore Grand Prix remaining on the calendar for four years. Ticket sales for this year's event are up 19% compared to the previous year, with overseas spectators generating an average of S$150 million in tourism receipts annually. The event, organized by the government and Singapore GP, marks its 10th edition.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Philippine conglomerate Ayala to invest in green vehicles
summary: Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp plans to invest US$150 million in car manufacturing, capitalizing on the shift towards green vehicles. The company aims to participate in China's Belt and Road initiative and partner with Chinese counterparts for infrastructure projects. Ayala's expansion into the sector is driven by the global trend towards zero-emission vehicles, with countries like China, the UK, and France planning to ban fossil-fuel powered cars in the coming years. The investment is part of Ayala's broader strategy to diversify its businesses and tap into emerging markets.

site_title: US:Wall St unmoved by economic data, N. Korea missile test
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Friday, holding near record highs despite North Korea's latest missile test and weaker-than-expected economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.81 points, or 0.13%, to 22,232.29, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also edged higher. Investors await the Federal Reserve's meeting on September 19-20 to gauge interest rate policy, with odds of a December rate hike increasing after a strong consumer prices report.

site_title: China green car pivot will need state support, GM chief says
summary: China's push for new-energy vehicles (NEVs) will require government backing to win over consumers, according to General Motors Co CEO Mary Barra. China aims for at least a fifth of auto sales to be electric or hybrid by 2025, but carmakers worry about meeting quotas due to planned subsidies being rolled back. GM plans to introduce 10 new NEVs in China by 2020 and invest heavily in electrification. Barra emphasized the need for joint effort between the government and automakers to build consumer acceptance of NEVs.

site_title: Reserves top US$400b in boost to India safety buffer
summary: India's foreign-exchange reserves reached a record US$400.7 billion, surpassing the US$400 billion mark for the first time. The strong reserves are seen as a buffer against potential US stimulus reduction, which could impact the rupee. Analysts predict a slowdown in portfolio inflows and a potential increase in India's current account deficit to 1.4% of GDP in 2018. The Reserve Bank of India has been intervening to absorb excess funds and keep inflation under control.

site_title: Fortescue chief Nev Power to step down in 2018
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd announced that CEO Nev Power will step down in 2018 after nearly seven years in the post. The company has "great confidence" in internal and external candidates to continue its legacy, with CFO Elizabeth Gaines and director of operations Greg Lilleyman considered as top contenders. The news led to a decline in Fortescue shares, which plummeted 4.1% to A$5.57. The company's profits more than doubled in the full year on higher iron ore prices.

site_title: Trump's generals look to provide a steady hand
summary: US President Donald Trump's generals, including Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, and National Security Adviser HR McMaster, are working to impose order and discipline in the White House. They have cleaned up crises and prevented the North Korean nuclear standoff from escalating. The generals' influence has reassured some allies but raised eyebrows among others, with some questioning whether military men are suited for civilian jobs. While they can't control Trump's rhetoric, they can slow things down and moderate his instincts, according to experts.

site_title: Bitcoin falls as chinese exchange says it will halt trading
summary: Bitcoin fell for a fifth day, the longest losing streak in over a year, after China's largest online exchange, BTC China, announced it would halt trading by the end of the month due to a government crackdown on cryptocurrencies. The decision comes after Chinese regulators outlawed initial coin offerings and plans to ban trading of bitcoin and other virtual currencies on domestic exchanges. The move has led to a 27% slump in the cryptocurrency since September 7, despite its four-fold rise this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore extended its Formula 1 racing contract until 2021, with ticket sales up 19% for this year's event. Housing developers sold 1,581 private units and ECs in August, up 98% year-over-year. SINGTEL launched mobile plans with unlimited data, talktime, and SMS, while SMRT Trains won a contract to run the Thomson-East Coast Line. The LTA also awarded UBS a warning on the Singapore and Hong Kong housing market due to policy risks. DBS and IMDA collaborated on a fintech training program, and Keppel T&T invested in a data center startup.

site_title: Airbus still in mix for Malaysia A330Neo deal after Boeing order
summary: Malaysia Airlines is still considering purchasing Airbus' A330neo wide-body jet after placing an order for Boeing's 787. The carrier's CEO, Peter Bellew, said the A330neo would be a "super plane" and is in talks with Airbus for a deal. The order could take until this month, with a price of $255 million or $291 million before discounts. Malaysia Airlines needs up to 30 aircraft, with 15 replacing older planes and the rest for expansion, to meet its long-haul fleet renewal requirements. Talks are also underway for second-hand A330s to meet near-term needs.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won recoup losses, shrug off North's latest missile launch
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded to a five-week high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing 0.4% higher at 2,386.07 points, driven by a recouped won. Investors largely shrugged off North Korea's latest missile launch, which had triggered a brief market pullback. The won recovered 0.1% from Thursday's close, while offshore investors sold 92.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares. This marks the Kospi's biggest weekly gain since late May.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.960 points to 1,786.330. Volume reached 2.146 billion lots worth RM2.693 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 509 to 369.

site_title: ECB to announce in Oct plans to reduce QE; buy bonds through June 2018: Reuters poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to announce a six-month extension of its asset purchase program in October, but with a reduction in monthly purchases from 60 billion euros to 40 billion euros, starting from January 2018, according to a Reuters poll. This move is seen as a response to the eurozone's strong economic performance since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares ignore N.Korea missile
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained largely unchanged on Friday, ignoring another North Korea missile firing. The Hang Seng index rose 0.1%, while the China Enterprises Index fell 0.3%. The week saw a 0.5% gain for the HSI and a 0.7% decline for the HSCE. Investors seemed to shrug off the North Korea tensions, with China's weak August investment data also affecting raw material shares.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop at open
summary: Europe's stock markets declined at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.3% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also losing 0.1%. The declines followed a five-day rally in Singapore stocks. US markets, however, edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth seen up slightly from Q2: central bank official
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects its third-quarter GDP growth to slightly improve to 5.1-5.2%, driven by improving private consumption. This follows a 5.01% growth in the second quarter. The bank's benchmark rate cut in August is expected to take two to three quarters to materialize, primarily affecting 2018 GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore Aug exports seen up for 4th straight month, led by electronics: poll
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports are expected to rise 11.8% in August, marking a fourth consecutive month of growth, driven by strong demand for electronics. This follows a 8.5% increase in July. The growth is attributed to an improvement in global demand, particularly for electronics products and components. This is seen as a positive sign for the economy, which grew faster than initially estimated in the second quarter, suggesting a broader and more balanced recovery.

site_title: UK police investigate reports of blast on London underground train
summary: UK police are investigating a reported blast on a London underground train at Parsons Green station in West London. The incident left multiple passengers with facial burns and others injured in a stampede. Six ambulances, fire engines, and a helicopter were on the scene. Britain has experienced four terrorist attacks this year, killing 36 people. The investigation is ongoing, with police initially releasing few details and assuring they would provide accurate information once verified.

site_title: Harvard University withdraws fellowship invitation to Chelsea Manning
summary: Harvard University withdrew a fellowship invitation to Chelsea Manning, a convicted US Army soldier who leaked classified data, after two top intelligence experts distanced themselves due to the invite. CIA Director Mike Pompeo canceled a speaking engagement and former CIA Deputy Director Michael Morell resigned as a senior fellow over the decision. Manning was released from prison in May and stated she was honored to be disinvited, calling the university's move under CIA pressure a positive step. The fellowship invitation to speak at the university still stands.

site_title: Tata feud with Mistry deepens with plan to change holding firm
summary: The Tata Group has moved to change the legal status of its holding company, Tata Sons, to a private limited entity, which would restrict the Mistry family's ability to sell their stake to external investors. This move is seen as a deepening of the feud between the two families, following the ousting of Cyrus Mistry as chairman of the group last year. Shareholders will vote on the proposal on September 21, with the Mistry family set to vote against it.

site_title: Formula One: Red Bull boss slams 'frustrating' hybrids as Renault split looms
summary: Red Bull boss Christian Horner criticized Renault's hybrid engines, calling them "frustrating" and stating they've "always fallen short." Speculation grows about Renault potentially ending its partnership with Red Bull after next season, but Horner downplays these reports, saying they're "purely speculation" for now.

site_title: Knife-wielding man attacks Paris soldier, no injuries: police
summary: A knife-wielding man attacked a soldier on patrol in central Paris's Chatelet metro station on Friday, but the soldier quickly subdued the attacker without causing any injuries. The attacker made a reference to Allah and was not previously known to police. This incident comes amid France's high alert status following a string of terror attacks since January 2015, with French defense minister Florence Parly praising the professionalism and efficiency of the Sentinelle soldiers in their mission to protect. The attacker was arrested, but no further details on their intentions were released.

site_title: Abe: Japan can 'never tolerate' North Korea's 'provocative' acts
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that Japan cannot tolerate North Korea's "dangerous provocative actions" after a missile launch over Japan, threatening world peace. The launch, which flew over Hokkaido, prompted the UN Security Council to hold an emergency meeting. Abe emphasized the need for a clear message from the international community to North Korea, following recent nuclear tests. The incident further ratchets up tensions between Japan and North Korea.

site_title: JD.com, Thai retailer Central Group form US$500m e-commerce JV
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce company, has formed a US$500 million joint venture with Thai retailer Central Group to expand its presence in Southeast Asia. The venture will focus on e-commerce and financial technology, with each company contributing US$250 million. The partnership aims to compete with Alibaba Group and Amazon in the region, particularly in services like quick delivery in Singapore. The joint venture will help JD.com boost its overseas business and take on rivals in the Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Taiwan jails Chinese grad student for recruiting spies
summary: A Chinese graduate, Zhou Hongxu, was jailed for one year and two months for recruiting spies for Beijing while studying in Taiwan. Zhou, who graduated from National Chengchi University in 2016, was found guilty of violating the National Security Act after attempting to recruit a Taiwanese government official with a promise of $10,000. The sentence comes amid tense cross-strait relations, following a trial of a Taiwanese democracy activist who was held incommunicado since March.

site_title: Australia shares lower on material, financial stocks; NZ extends losses
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Friday due to a decline in metal prices, particularly copper, and a drop in financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track to end the week higher after three weeks of losses. In other news, North Korea fired a missile over Japan, and New Zealand's benchmark index shed 0.5% for its fourth consecutive day of losses, with home sales falling sharply and manufacturing activity picking up pace.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish lower after North Korean missile test
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.39 points to 3,209.56, closing at 0.6% lower for the week, following North Korea's missile test. The three local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also declined, with DBS dropping S$0.29 to S$20.06 and OCBC losing S$0.05 to S$10.95. The losses cut 9.4 points off the STI, with turnover reaching a week high of S$1.7 billion. The decline comes after weak economic numbers from China and a downgrade of the three local banks.

site_title: Japan scrutinises regional banks' fund buying as risks rise
summary: Japan's regional banks are under scrutiny for their aggressive buying of investment trusts, which cover various assets including stocks and real estate, to boost returns in a low-interest-rate environment. Regulators have expressed concerns that some lenders lack the necessary knowledge and structure to handle these products, which could pose credit risks. The Financial Services Agency has instructed lenders to strengthen their risk management and draw up exit plans for investments that are hard to sell.

site_title: Singapore developers move 1,581 new private homes, ECs in Aug, up 98% y-o-y
summary: Singapore developers sold 1,581 new private homes and executive condominiums (ECs) in August, a 98% surge from the previous year. This includes 1,241 private residential units and 340 ECs. Le Quest, a mixed development in Bukit Batok, was the top-selling project, with 286 units sold at a median price of S$1,309 per square foot. The developer is holding back the second phase of its sales launch, anticipating a possible upturn in the property market.

site_title: ECB concerned about bank efforts to avoid regulation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is concerned that banks in post-Brexit Europe are exploiting loopholes to avoid stricter regulation. ECB supervisor Daniele Nouy warned that banks may shift operations to countries with laxer regulations, set up shadow banking activities, or create local businesses to evade thorough checks. This "regulatory arbitrage" poses a significant risk to the banking sector, economy, and society, and is particularly concerning given the UK's departure from the EU. The ECB is urging policymakers to address this issue to maintain stability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher despite North Korea rocket launch
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday despite North Korea's launch of a second missile over Japan in less than a month. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.52% and the Topix index increased 0.42%. Investors remained calm, possibly due to a focus on other market news, such as the US stocks reaching fresh records. The launch did not seem to have a significant impact on the markets, with traders instead focusing on other economic indicators and global events.

site_title: Mazda to make all models hybrid, electric by early 2030s
summary: Mazda plans to transition all its models to electric-based vehicles by the early 2030s, including petrol hybrids, according to a Japanese media report. The company will use electric motors in all models by then, with some hybrid models already available. Mazda has partnered with Toyota to develop electric powertrain technologies, and has introduced an ultra-efficient petrol engine that will be incorporated into its cars from 2019. This move follows other automakers such as Nissan and Volvo, which are also shifting towards electrification.

site_title: Horrific fire in Malaysia sparks outrage over unregulated religious schools
summary: A horrific fire at an Islamic boarding school in Malaysia killed 23 teenage boys, with many trapped behind barred windows. The fire, which occurred at a "tahfiz" school, was the worst in 20 years and sparked outrage over inadequate regulation of the unregulated religious schools. Authorities claim a short circuit caused the fire, but family members and religious leaders blame the school's design and lack of safety measures. The incident is the latest in a series of safety issues at such schools, which have been criticized for poor regulation and training.

site_title: MAS, Securities Commission Malaysia inks agreement on fintech, innovation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Securities Commission Malaysia (SC) have signed a cooperation agreement to foster fintech and innovation in financial services between the two countries. The agreement establishes a strategic framework to support fintech firms and promote joint innovation projects, including those leveraging blockchain and distributed ledgers. The move aims to create new opportunities for fintech firms to venture into each other's markets and nurture a vibrant regional fintech ecosystem in Asean.

site_title: Chocolate fries help McDonald's Japan CEO overcome scandals
summary: McDonald's Japan CEO Sarah Casanova overcame scandals in 2014 that included expired chicken, a human tooth in fries, and a child injured by a plastic shard. Sales plummeted, and the company was on the verge of closing hundreds of restaurants. However, Casanova revamped the menu, added local flavors, and listened to customer feedback. She introduced measures to ensure food safety and introduced QR codes to track food origins. The company's stock closed at an all-time high in September, and same-store sales climbed for the 21st consecutive month. McDonald's Japan is now the largest overseas footprint for the company, with about 2,900 stores in Japan.

site_title: US dollar firmer vs yen, shrugs off North Korea missile launch
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen on Friday, recovering from earlier losses due to North Korea's missile launch over Japan. The dollar rose 0.1% to 110.37 yen, reversing a low of 109.55 yen earlier in the day. Despite Japan's proximity to North Korea, the yen remains a safe-haven currency. Market participants expect the overall market reaction to the missile launch to be short-lived, and the dollar is expected to hold firm against the yen due to rising US interest rate expectations and a strong US consumer inflation data.

site_title: All eyes on Trump as world leaders gather at UN
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to address the United Nations General Assembly, with world leaders gathering to discuss global crises such as the nuclear crisis with North Korea, the Iran nuclear deal, and Myanmar's military crackdown against Rohingya Muslims. Trump's "America-First" policy is expected to be a key focus, with diplomats watching for signs of a shift on climate change. French President Emmanuel Macron is also expected to deliver an address championing multilateralism, and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres will meet with North Korea's Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho to discuss the nuclear crisis.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars cold shouldered as others talk of rate hikes
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are experiencing losses as markets anticipate higher interest rates in the US and UK. The Australian dollar has fallen 0.7% for the week, reaching a low of US$0.7992, after the US Federal Reserve reignited the risk of a December rate hike due to firm inflation figures. There is no expectation of near-term rate hikes in Australia.

site_title: Big Data provides backing for Norway's exit from stimulus binge
summary: Norway's central bank is preparing for an interest rate decision, with data from the Financial News Index suggesting the economy is expanding above average. The index, developed by a team of researchers, uses Big Data analysis to gauge the economy based on articles from local financial media. This approach has shown to be a better predictor of recession than traditional market indicators. Consumer confidence has also been rising steadily since the start of the year, providing further evidence of the economy's improvement. The central bank's decision is expected to be influenced by this data, potentially marking the start of normalizing monetary policy after years of record stimulus.

site_title: DBS, IMDA to create first fintech training programme under TeSA initiative
summary: DBS Bank and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) have collaborated to create the first fintech training programme under the TechSkills Accelerator (TeSA) initiative. The programme, training over 85 young professionals, focuses on agile development, DevOps, information security, and data analytics for the financial services sector. This partnership marks DBS as the first bank to partner IMDA under TeSA's Company Led Training (CLT) programme, aiming to build a strong talent pool with fintech professionals to maintain Singapore's competitive edge as a leading Asian financial hub.

site_title: Seoul: Markets step back after latest North Korea missile launch
summary: South Korean markets experienced a slight pullback on Friday after North Korea launched a missile over northern Japan, with the won and Kospi index down 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Analysts attributed the muted reaction to the expectation of another test and the lack of threat to US territory. Despite this, shares of Lotte Shopping surged 9.6% after securing a new management deal for its Chinese supermarkets. Investors showed fatigue with North Korean sabre-rattling, with risk reversals steady and credit default swaps edging up.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte to sell China shops in face of boycott
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group plans to sell some of its Chinese stores due to Beijing's unofficial sanctions over the Thaad missile defense system. About 80% of Lotte Mart's 112 Chinese stores have been closed for over six months, costing the company hundreds of millions of dollars. The company has invested over 10 trillion won in its Chinese operations since 1994 and may lose 1 trillion won this year if the trend continues. Lotte has named Goldman Sachs as the lead manager to sell the stores, with talks underway with Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group.

site_title: Last call for bids on bankrupt Air Berlin
summary: Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, is holding a bidding war for its assets, including 8,500 employees, 140 aircraft, and landing slots, as the company teeters on the brink of bankruptcy. Bidders include Lufthansa and Austrian Niki Lauda, with offers due by 12:00 GMT. Management expects concrete decisions by September 25, potentially breaking down the airline amidst wildcat strikes by pilots. The outcome could determine the future of Germany's aviation industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.9 points to 1,784.27 on Friday, with volume reaching 52.67 million lots worth RM17.72 million. Gainers outpaced losers 93 to 64.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open after North Korea launch
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in the first few minutes of trade on Friday, easing 0.15% after North Korea launched a missile over Japan, potentially reviving geopolitical tensions. The Hang Seng Index dropped 40.60 points to 27,736.60, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The decline was attributed to the potential for increased tensions and uncertainty in the market.

site_title: Speeding safely
summary: Formula One driver Lewis Hamilton is focused on maintaining his lead in the championship standings at the upcoming weekend's race.

site_title: Yen steady after North Korea missile launch
summary: The yen remained steady against the US dollar following North Korea's missile launch, despite initial concerns over geopolitical risks. The yen rose to 109.55 yen per US dollar before paring losses, trading at 110.19 yen by the end of the day. Market participants expect the market reaction to be short-lived, with the US dollar likely to remain stable against the yen due to rising expectations of a US interest rate hike by year-end.

site_title: China Internet finance body suggests framework to support virtual currencies
summary: A senior executive at China's Internet finance association has suggested creating a framework to support the development of digital currencies, amid a crackdown on trading on virtual currencies like bitcoin. Li Lihui, a former Bank of China president, called for global regulators to collaborate on digital currencies. Chinese regulators have been cracking down on the cryptocurrency sector due to financial risks, with major exchange BTCChina stopping trading on September 30. This move has led to a significant decline in the value of bitcoin.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down after fresh North Korea missile launch
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday after North Korea's missile launch, with Seoul and Hong Kong experiencing significant drops. The launch, which traveled further than previous missiles, heightened concerns about the North's ability to strike the US mainland with an atomic bomb. However, analysts said the move was more of a provocation than an escalation, and markets were less startled. Meanwhile, the pound maintained its strength against the dollar after the Bank of England hinted at a potential interest rate hike next month.

site_title: Facebook-backed group to help fund 'Dreamer' application fees
summary: Facebook-backed group FWD.us is raising funds to help undocumented immigrants, known as Dreamers, reapply for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protects them from deportation. The $495 application fee is an "extraordinary expense" for many low-wage earners. FWD.us, co-founded by Mark Zuckerberg, is working with other lobby groups to raise money for The DACA Renewal Fund. The deadline for renewal applications is October 5.

site_title: Indonesia swings back to trade surplus in Aug
summary: Indonesia's external trade returned to a surplus in August, with exports rising 19.24% to $15.21 billion, led by growth in manufacturing and mining exports. The surplus was $1.72 billion, surpassing expectations. Imports increased 8.89% to $13.49 billion. This marks the largest surplus in over five years, after a trade deficit in July. The strong performance is attributed to a low base due to the Eid al-Fitr holidays in July 2016.

site_title: China's WeChat crackdown drives bitcoin devotees to Telegram
summary: China's WeChat is experiencing a mass exodus of users as part of a crackdown on bitcoin and cryptocurrency-related activities. WeChat administrators are now personally liable for content shared on their groups, prompting users to migrate to encrypted services like Telegram. Chinese bitcoin exchanges, such as OKCoin and Huobi, are also seeing a shift to services beyond the government's reach. This move is driven by the Chinese government's efforts to regulate and control cryptocurrency usage.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.3% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 10.14 points to 3,210.81, amid no major market-moving news. The most actively traded stock, Rowsley, fell 0.002 to 0.125. This is the first decline in five days, as investors await the release of GDP data.

site_title: London Fashion Week opens with boost from big brands
summary: London Fashion Week kicked off with a boost from big brands Emporio Armani and Tommy Hilfiger, who showcased their collections on the catwalk. The event aims to boost the status of London Fashion Week, which has been lacking big names in recent years. The British Fashion Council is working to support the trade in the UK, employing 880,000 people, and plans to launch an "industrial strategy for fashion" to address Brexit uncertainty. The event features 85 catwalk shows across the city, including Burberry's first collection since new president Marco Gobbetti took charge.

site_title: Jack Ma says Alibaba has to change mindset for global expansion
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., the e-commerce giant founded by Jack Ma, is shifting its focus to global expansion and department stores. The company, worth $458 billion, aims to move away from its asset-light approach and invest in heavy models to compete with Amazon and Tencent. Ma emphasized the need for a different mindset to tackle global challenges, including competition, data security, and cyber regulations. Alibaba plans to build a global e-commerce infrastructure, including logistics, cloud computing, and online payments, to facilitate cross-border trading and e-commerce.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel T&T, Oxley, Vard, Global Yellow Pages
summary: Keppel T&T invested US$10 million in data centre startup Nautilus Data Technologies, representing 24.1% of its issued shares. Oxley Holdings increased its issued and paid-up capital to S$4 million by issuing new shares. Vard Holdings secured a contract to design a cable lay vessel for a Japanese company, while Global Yellow Pages signed a conditional agreement to buy a plot of land in New Zealand for NZ$38 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher despite North Korea missile launch
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, defying concerns following North Korea's missile launch, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.21% and the Topix up 0.22%. Investors remained calm, and the rally was attributed to the absence of major market-moving news. The move was also seen as a reflection of the market's resilience to external factors.

site_title: New London underground markings anger seasoned commuters
summary: Seasoned London commuters are upset over new green platform markings at King's Cross station, which show the best position to quickly enter carriages. The markings, part of a trial to cut congestion during rush hour, render the expertise of long-time commuters useless. The system is currently only being trialled on the Victoria Line platforms, with Transport for London making no mention of expanding it. Commuters are taking to social media to express their frustration, with one tweeting that 20 years of personal knowledge are "rendered useless by some green paint."

site_title: Macy's to hire 80,000 workers for holidays, fewer than last year
summary: Macy's plans to hire 80,000 workers for the holiday season, a 3% decrease from last year. The company will increase its online staffing by 20% to 18,000 workers, focusing on distribution and warehouse support. This decision comes as Macy's struggles with weak sales and competition from online retailers. Total holiday hiring falls short of rival Target's 43% increase to 100,000 seasonal workers, highlighting the challenges facing the department store industry. Macy's has also been shutting stores and cutting jobs, with plans to close 100 stores by the end of the year.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust divests unit which holds CapitaMall Anzhen
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has completed the divestment of its entire equity interest in CapitaRetail Beijing Anzhen Real Estate Co, Ltd, resulting in the latter no longer being a wholly owned subsidiary. The divestment involves the unit holding CapitaMall Anzhen. The trustee-manager announced the completion in a Singapore Exchange filing on Friday.

site_title: Singtel upgrades mobile plans with unlimited talktime, SMS and data
summary: Singtel launched upgraded mobile plans with unlimited local data, talktime, and SMS in Singapore, starting Friday. The new plans, Singtel Combo 3, 6, and 12, offer an add-on of S$39.90/month for unlimited local data with DATA X INFINITY. This move aims to provide customers with flexibility and control over their mobile plans, following the success of previous DATA X add-ons.

site_title: Saviours or profiteers? Bangladesh fishermen rescue Rohingya, for a price
summary: In Bangladesh, thousands of Rohingya Muslims fleeing persecution in Myanmar are being rescued by informal fishing boat fleets, but at a steep cost. Refugees pay up to 10,000 taka (S$164) per adult to cross from Myanmar's coast to southern Bangladesh. Bangladeshi officials accuse fishermen of profiteering, and some have arrested or set fire to boats involved in the trade. However, fishermen claim it's a moral obligation to help fellow Muslims and that the money is part of a humanitarian act. Authorities are trying to crack down on human trafficking, but the crisis continues, with tens of thousands still waiting to cross into Bangladesh.

site_title: Trump says to visit China, Japan, South Korea in November
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to visit China, Japan, and South Korea in November, marking his first presidential trip to Asia. A US delegation will likely make the trip, with Trump possibly attending the APEC summit in Vietnam. Trump also expressed interest in attending the Asean regional summit in the Philippines, although the invitation was controversial.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Thursday announced he intends to visit China, Japan and South Korea later this year, a blockbuster maiden presidential visit to Asia.

site_title: Keppel T&T unit invests US$10m in data centre startup Nautilus Data Technologies
summary: Keppel T&T's unit, Keppel Data Centres, has invested US$10 million in data centre startup Nautilus Data Technologies as part of a Series C preferred stock funding. The investment represents 24.1% of Nautilus' total issued shares. Nautilus develops water-cooled data centres and is building its first commercial facility in Northern California. The investment aims to benefit from innovative and sustainable data centre technology with broader commercial application, according to Keppel Data Centres' CEO Wong Wai Meng.

site_title: Facebook removes advertiser ability to target 'Jew haters'
summary: Facebook has removed the ability for advertisers to target users who express interest in anti-Semitic categories, following an investigation by ProPublica. The company automatically populates interest categories based on user posts and had previously allowed advertisers to target users who self-reported their education and employers, including potentially discriminatory traits. Facebook said it has built new "guardrails" to prevent similar targeting in the future, citing its community standards that prohibit attacking people based on their protected characteristics. The company is considering removing the ability to target offensive self-reported profile traits in ad campaigns.

site_title: Brazil prosecutor charges President Temer with corruption
summary: Brazil's President Michel Temer was charged with obstruction of justice and leading a criminal group by Prosecutor General Rodrigo Janot's office, amid a corruption scandal. Temer, along with six allies, is accused of taking nearly $190 million in kickbacks for contracts at public companies like Petrobras. The charges must be accepted by the Supreme Court before being debated in the lower house, where Temer is likely to have enough support to avoid trial.

site_title: Trump says he 'likes' Fed chair Yellen
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he "likes" Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, indicating a possible extension of her term. Yellen's current four-year term expires in February. Trump also expressed confidence in the country's economic performance, crediting himself for the positive state of the economy. Despite rumors of potential replacement, Trump has not yet made a decision on Yellen's successor.

site_title: Oracle's profit, cloud growth forecasts drag down shares
summary: Oracle Corp forecasted adjusted profit of 64-68 cents per share for its second quarter, below Wall Street's estimates, and indicated slowing growth in its cloud business, leading to a 5% drop in shares. The company expects 39-43% growth in total cloud revenue, lower than the 51.4% growth in the previous quarter. Despite this, Oracle expects cloud bookings to grow, with co-CEO Mark Hurd stating strong or stronger growth than the previous quarter.

site_title: Oil at 5-month high on weak dollar, forecasts glut will recede
summary: Oil prices rose to a five-month high on Thursday, with Brent closing at $55.47 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $49.89 a barrel. The dollar's weakness and forecasted decline in global oil glut contributed to the increase. The International Energy Agency (IEA) revised up its 2017 global oil demand growth forecast, and Opec's production-cutting deal with non-member countries is helping to tackle a supply glut, favoring higher oil prices. Major producers are expected to keep output restricted, maintaining prices between $50 and $60.

site_title: Pound surges, FTSE falls on Bank of England decision
summary: The British pound surged to over $1.34 after the Bank of England hinted at an early interest rate hike, despite maintaining a record-low interest rate of 0.25%. The decision weighed on London's FTSE 100, which fell 1.1%. Global stocks were mixed, with US stocks edging to a record high, while Asian markets retreated due to weak Chinese economic data, including industrial and retail sales growth below expectations.

site_title: Nestle enters hipster coffee market with majority stake in Blue Bottle
summary: Nestle acquired a 68% majority stake in California-based Blue Bottle Coffee for around $425 million, marking the company's entry into the specialty coffee market. This deal follows Nestle's purchase of Sweet Earth meatless foods and comes as the company seeks to transform itself into a "nutrition, health and wellness" company. The move aims to tap into the growing US coffee market, which is expected to reach $4.4 billion by 2021, and compete with third-wave coffee chains like Starbucks and Intelligentsia.

site_title: Alphabet is said to consider Lyft investment of about US$1b
summary: Alphabet Inc is reportedly considering a $1 billion investment in Lyft Inc, according to sources familiar with the matter. The potential deal could come from Google or CapitalG, Alphabet's private-equity arm. This move would provide Lyft with the necessary funds to pursue aggressive growth strategies, including subsidies for drivers and discounts for riders. The investment would also ensure Lyft's independence, a priority for co-founder John Zimmer. The talks come as Uber faces self-inflicted scandals and probes, potentially benefiting Lyft's market share.

site_title: Europe: Oil, retailers help shares touch five-week high
summary: European stocks rose to a five-week high, driven by energy and retailer stocks, while US inflation data exceeded expectations, boosting sectors with high dollar exposure. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.1%, with oil and gas stocks up 0.9% and retailers reaching their best daily gains in five months. However, miners were the biggest weight, with shares in Rio Tinto, Glencore, and BHP Billiton declining. Analysts at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs say European stocks with high dollar exposure are undervalued and could benefit from a modest rise in the greenback.

site_title: UBS shuns Singapore, Hong Kong housing market on policy risks
summary: UBS has decided to avoid the Singapore and Hong Kong housing markets due to policy risks, according to Graham Mackie, head of real estate for Asia Pacific at UBS Asset Management. Mackie stated that the markets have historically been exposed to government intervention, making them unattractive to UBS. The move is a result of the threat of government curbs to tame prices in the region.

images.alt_text: The threat of government curbs to tame prices makes Singapore and Hong Kong residential property unattractive, the regional head of UBS Group AG's real-estate investment arm said.

site_title: New Google Pixel smartphone debut expected October 4
summary: Google is expected to unveil its second-generation Pixel smartphone on October 4, following the success of its first-generation model. The event, which will be held in San Francisco, comes ahead of Apple's release of the iPhone 8 and Samsung's new Galaxy Note. The pricing of the Pixel 2 is yet to be announced, but the original Pixel competes in the premium smartphone segment. The Google event will also follow the release of the iPhone X, which starts at $999 and will be available starting November 3.

site_title: More jobs ahead but growth likely to be subdued
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower expects higher labour demand in the second half of 2017, driven by steady economic growth at 2.5% for the year. However, some private-sector economists believe the recovery will be underwhelming. Despite this, the labour market has shown an uptick in the first half, with growth tipped to remain steady. The outlook suggests more jobs ahead, but subdued growth.

site_title: Trojan Women electrifies
summary: Director Ong Keng Sen's production of "Trojan Women" at the Singapore International Festival of Arts has been reimagined as a changgeuk (traditional Korean opera) with pansori music. The 2017 version features a minimalist set, sleek costumes, and stylized performances that convey the struggles of ordinary folk. Actress Nora Samosir plays Hecuba, while Kim Ji-Sook and Yi So-yeon portray Andromache and Cassandra, respectively. The production dispenses with traditional realism, instead focusing on raw emotions and austere staging. The fusion of Greek tragedy and Korean opera traditions has resulted in a seamless and enchanting production that has captivated audiences.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Apple's grand plan in Ireland held up by a forest
summary: US tech giant Apple's plan to build an 850-million-euro data centre in Ireland's Derrydonnell Forest is being held up by conservationists seeking to preserve the forest. The project, which would be the biggest private investment in western Ireland, has sparked concerns in the local economy. Apple's investment would bring much-needed jobs and revenue, but the protest is sending a negative message, according to campaigners. Irish officials have met with Apple executives, and the government is examining potential changes to the planning and legal system to support the investment.

site_title: China set for ethanol binge as Beijing pumps up renewable fuel drive
summary: China plans to roll out E10 petrol, containing 10% ethanol, across its massive car market by 2020, doubling its biofuels industry investment. Over 10 new ethanol plants are planned in the north-eastern corn belt, with most set to go online next year, adding 3 million tonnes of capacity. This move aims to clean up the environment and boost industrial demand for corn, while also addressing a 200 million-tonne stockpile. The plan could spur billions in investment and pose challenges for the oil industry.

site_title: North Korea fires missile from Pyongyang over Japan
summary: North Korea fired an unidentified missile eastward from Pyongyang, South Korea's capital, on September 14, 2017. The missile flew over Japan, prompting an urgent National Security Council meeting in South Korea. This launch comes a day after North Korea threatened to sink Japan and reduce the US to "ashes and darkness" for supporting new UN sanctions. The incident is the second missile launch from the Sunan district, which previously flew over Japan's Hokkaido island in August.

site_title: 'Cat bonds' investors may find themselves in deep water
summary: Investors in "cat bonds" - catastrophe bonds that insure against natural disasters - may face losses due to payouts from hurricane damage. Insurers are expected to report significant losses from hurricanes Harvey and Irma, putting the alternative reinsurance market to the test. As insurers seek more affordable options, cat bonds have grown in popularity in the US, but the recent losses could lead to financial strain for some investors.

site_title: Britain's Exchange Rate Mechanism crisis in 1992 was the first Brexit
summary: The article suggests that the 1992 Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) crisis in Britain was the first "Brexit" and a critical inflection point in the UK's European history. Britain's participation in the ERM, meant to stabilize the economy, ultimately led to its withdrawal from the mechanism, marking a return to the UK's traditional distance from the European core. The crisis was caused by Britain's inability to understand the changing nature of western European unity and its own role in it, as well as miscalculations by the British government, including Prime Minister John Major's failure to influence German monetary policies.

site_title: Expect self-driving lorries on the roads before taxis, says Waymo CEO
summary: Waymo CEO John Krafcik announced that the company is exploring self-driving lorries before taxis, citing a compelling use-case for goods transportation on highways. Waymo owns a single lorry being tested with self-driving software and sensors. Krafcik is pitching a per-mile business model to carmakers, offering a potential revenue stream over the lifetime of vehicles. Despite rivals' investments in autonomous technology, Krafcik believes some carmakers may partner with Waymo, with talks held with Honda Motor Co.

site_title: India plans larger oil auctions as Modi pursues import cuts
summary: India plans to auction larger areas with higher oil and natural gas reserves in the next round, aiming to cut rising crude oil imports. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to reduce the country's dependence on imported oil. The next auction will offer more substantial fields, with Atanu Chakraborty, head of oil regulator Directorate General of Hydrocarbons, stating that players can expect better fields. The goal is to increase domestic production and reduce imports, which have been rising due to increasing demand and lower domestic production.

site_title: Zenith CEO goes against the grain for greater gain
summary: Zenith CEO is revamping the company by shrinking its physical distribution network by up to 30% and revamping its website. This move is part of the company's efforts to adapt to the changing market and capitalize on the resurgence of mechanical movements in high-end watches. The company's CEO is taking a bold approach, echoing a past decision made by a foreman four decades ago when the company was on the brink of collapse, which ultimately helped the company survive and thrive.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings has raised its stake in United Engineers (UE) to 14.1% after buying 5.3 million shares at S$2.72 apiece. The purchase price is a 4.6% premium to the consortium's S$2.60 per share cash offer, which expires on September 19. Meanwhile, VARD Holdings Limited has secured a contract to design a cable lay vessel for Kokusai Cable Ship Co Ltd in Japan, with the vessel set to be delivered in 2019.

site_title: Julius Baer sees Asia making up a third of business
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer expects Asia to account for a third of its business in the next five years as it continues to hire staff to tap into the region's growing affluence. The bank currently generates 20-25% of its business from Asia, with net new money boosted by 6% in the first half of the year. Julius Baer plans to recruit more staff and expand its Asian operations, with its Asian assets under management expected to reach $100 billion by 2020.

site_title: US: Dow edges to record but tech selloff hits Nasdaq
summary: US stocks ended Thursday with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq pulled back from all-time peaks. The Dow rose 0.2% to 22,203.48, while the S&P 500 lost 0.1% and the Nasdaq shed 0.5%. Analysts attribute the shift to bets away from tech shares, with Apple, Facebook, and Google-parent Alphabet losing around 1%, while Boeing, United Technologies, and General Motors climbed at least 1%. Solid US economic data keeps alive the chances of a third Federal Reserve interest rate hike in 2017.

site_title: Trump blocks sale of US chipmaker Lattice to China firm
summary: US President Donald Trump blocked a $1.3 billion acquisition of US chipmaker Lattice Semiconductor Corp by a Chinese-backed private equity firm, Canyon Bridge Capital Partners. This move sends a signal to Beijing that Washington will oppose deals involving technologies with potential military applications. The deal was one of the largest attempted by a Chinese-backed firm in the US chip sector. Trump's decision highlights his administration's focus on national security and its opposition to Chinese investment in sensitive technologies.

site_title: SIFA 2017 says farewell
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2017, led by outgoing director Ong Keng Sen, closed on a strong note with record-high viewership of 218,000 and 85% ticket sales. The festival featured innovative and accessible art, including film commissions and community engagement events. Notable works include Lav Diaz's "Henrico's Farm" and W!ld Rice's "Hotel," which premiered in 2015 and will be shown again in Adelaide. New festival director Gaurav Kripalani is expected to bring his own programming to next year's festival, following Ong's legacy of innovative and challenging art.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Global Yellow Pages buys Auckland plot of land for NZ$38m
summary: Global Yellow Pages has signed a conditional agreement to buy a 21.9-hectare plot of land in Papakura, New Zealand, for NZ$38 million. The acquisition is part of the company's strategy to expand its core property business and pursue opportunities with good prospects for income and long-term growth. This is GYP's third purchase of real estate in New Zealand, following the acquisition of Pakuranga Plaza in 2015 and a plot of land at Queenstown in 2016. The land will be subdivided for sale and potentially developed into residential houses and commercial units.

site_title: China should rein in Kim for the sake of peace
summary: China should intervene to rein in North Korean leader Kim Jong-un due to the escalating nuclear threat. Unlike the US, China has the economic and diplomatic leverage to prevent a global catastrophe. China's inaction has emboldened Kim, who is threatening neighboring countries, including Singapore and Guam. If China fails to act, the consequences could be devastating, with the US and Russia potentially drawn into a devastating war. China must demonstrate its peaceful intentions and use its power for regional stability, rather than economic gain, to prevent a global crisis.

site_title: Bain bid for Toshiba unit: Apple 'chipping in US$3b'
summary: Apple is backing Bain Capital's bid for Toshiba's memory chips business with a US$3 billion investment, adding to support from Dell, Seagate, and SK Hynix. This deal may surpass Apple's largest acquisition, the US$3 billion purchase of Beats Electronics. Apple plans to take an equity stake alongside Bain, helping swing the deal away from Western Digital Corp, one of Apple's suppliers. The agreement aims to resolve a contentious battle for Toshiba's chips business, which the company needs to sell to avoid delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange by March.

site_title: Golden Agri launches oleochemical plant
summary: Golden Agri-Resources launched a 200 kilotonne-per-year oleochemicals plant in Indonesia, its first major downstream fatty alcohol facility, representing a 300 million euro investment. The plant is owned by a joint venture between Golden Agri and Spain-based Cepsa. The facility is expected to support the company's growth in the oleochemicals market.

site_title: Catastrophes are reminders of need for firm action on climate change
summary: Three powerful hurricanes in the Americas, including Harvey, Irma, and Jose, have raised concerns over the pace of global warming. Climate change exacerbates the severity of storms and flooding. The Paris agreement aims to slow global warming, but more action is needed. Urban planning and insurance are also key factors, with 70% of the world uninsured in 2016. Governments and urban planners must take urgent action to shore up flood protection structures and commit to reducing global warming to mitigate the toll of extreme weather events.

site_title: EL Devt's Lim family buys 2 GCBs for S$46.6m
summary: The Lim family, controlling Evan Lim & Co and EL Development, has purchased two Good Class Bungalows in Singapore for S$46.6 million. The properties, located in Chancery Lane and Ewart Park, were bought at S$1,202 psf and S$1,350 psf, respectively. The transactions were likely executed without caveats, indicating the buyers' desire for discretion.

images.alt_text: The two-storey Chancery Lane property is more than 30 years old and ripe for redevelopment.
The two-storey Ewart Park property has five en suite bedrooms and a pool as well as an open courtyard, garden landscaping and water features that create a resort feel.

site_title: M&A value in first 9 months highest since 2014
summary: M&A activity in Singapore reached a 9-month high of US$62.5 billion in the first nine months of 2017, with the value increasing 31.7% from the same period in 2016. The industrials sector accounted for the largest share, with a 35.6% market share worth US$22.3 billion. Credit Suisse took the lead in M&A advisory fees, with US$21.8 million in fees, followed by Morgan Stanley and UBS. Inbound M&A activity hit a record high in Q3, with US$19.3 billion in value, while outbound M&A activity decreased to US$3.1 billion.

site_title: Merkel on course for fourth term
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel appears set to win her fourth term in the upcoming elections, with her centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) party leading in polls. The Social Democratic Party (SPD), led by Martin Schultz, trails behind, and the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party is expected to enter Parliament for the first time, potentially taking 11% of the vote and 70 seats. The AfD's rise has sparked concerns about rising nationalism and anti-immigrant sentiment, with some commentators describing the campaign as "boring" and others as "disturbingly intense."

site_title: China's economy losing some steam with investment growth at 18-year low
summary: China's economy showed signs of slowing growth, with investment growth at an 18-year low of 7.8% in January-August. Factory output and retail sales also grew less than expected, with industrial output rising 6% in August, the weakest pace in nine months. However, a rebound in property sales and construction starts is expected to keep overall growth relatively robust, with economists predicting 6.8% growth in the third quarter. Despite a slowdown, China's economy remains on track to meet its full-year growth target of 6.5%.

site_title: SRX launches drone viewings for Singapore properties
summary: SRX Property has launched X-Drone, a drone viewing service for Singapore properties, allowing buyers to see properties from different elevations and view their surroundings. The service, which has full regulatory clearance from the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, is available for 10 high-end properties and aims to complement existing imaging features such as 360-degree photography and virtual reality technology. The service is expected to benefit buyers, developers, and agents, and is particularly useful for overseas buyers who can view properties from anywhere in the world.

site_title: Peter Cetera still going strong five decades later
summary: Peter Cetera, the 72-year-old ex-Chicago frontman, performed a solo concert at Resorts World Theatre, packing out the venue with a largely middle-aged crowd. The show featured hits from his five-decade career, including "Restless Heart," "Glory of Love," and "You're the Inspiration." Despite some age-related raspiness in his vocals, Cetera still delivered high-energy performances, including a bass guitar solo and a two-song encore. The concert was a testament to Cetera's enduring popularity as a soft-rock icon.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Amid cashless drive, no need to be shrill over shillings
summary: Singapore's cashless drive may raise concerns that children will lose the ability to save by hoarding coins, but this is unfounded. A mother's past experience of delaying spending to save 10 cents for a Coke illustrates the importance of saving. In reality, children can still save by delaying spending, and this practice can teach them the value of money. The cashless pursuit can also encourage responsible spending and financial literacy. With the right approach, the benefits of a cashless society can outweigh the potential drawbacks.

site_title: Optimism rises over EU's future, even as debate rages on
summary: European Commission President Jean Claude Juncker delivered a positive state-of-the-union address, citing improved eurozone growth, the rejection of far-right populists in France and the Netherlands, and the euro's recent highs against the pound. Juncker emphasized the need for the EU to capitalize on current positive sentiment, particularly in trade talks with Australia and New Zealand, and a potential enlargement project to the western Balkans. The EU faces five possible scenarios, including the status quo, a "Doing less more efficiently" scenario, and a more integrated future, with Juncker favoring the latter.

site_title: Chocolate industry killing Ivory Coast's forests, report warns
summary: A report by green group Mighty Earth warns that the chocolate industry is driving massive and illegal deforestation in Ivory Coast, resulting in the destruction of 90% of the country's protected areas. The industry's "laissez-faire approach to sourcing" has led to widespread deforestation, forcing protected species such as chimpanzees and elephants into smaller areas, making them vulnerable to poaching. The report also highlights the involvement of major chocolate brands, including Cargill, Olam, and Barry Callebaut, in the trade.

images.alt_text: A cocoa farmer in Ivory Coast. In several national parks and other protected areas, 90 per cent or more of the land mass has been converted to cocoa, said green group Mighty Earth.

site_title: China's SOE reform in slow lane as Party keeps its hands on the wheel
summary: China's state-owned enterprises (SOEs) remain inefficient and debt-ridden, four years after the government announced reforms aimed at increasing efficiency and reducing the state's role. Instead, SOEs have merged to become mega-companies focused on foreign industrial policies and spearheading investment in the One Belt One Road axis. The Communist Party maintains control, with President Xi Jinping stating the Party has the final say in SOE operations. Despite efforts to reform, observers say progress has been underwhelming, with SOEs continuing to receive cheap credit and prioritize political goals over business ones, stifling innovation and growth.

site_title: Playing games with a young woman's mind
summary: Darren Aronofsky's psychological thriller Mother! follows a young woman's descent into madness as her idyllic life with her husband is disrupted by a series of bizarre events. After a stranger arrives, the couple's world is turned upside down, and the young woman's fears and paranoia intensify. As the situation spirals out of control, Aronofsky employs delusional behavior and symbolism, but his overuse of these elements detracts from the film's impact. The result is a chaotic and overwhelming experience that drives the viewer to madness.

site_title: Winning ways and means
summary: A book titled "Differentiation: How to Win in a Disruptive Market" by Dr. Wilson Chew of PricewaterhouseCoopers aims to help companies cope with rapid change, technological innovation, and globalization to stay relevant and profitable. Chew seeks to provide strategies for firms to differentiate themselves in a rapidly changing business world.

site_title: Saudis said to prep for possible Aramco IPO delay to 2019
summary: Saudi Arabia is preparing contingency plans for a possible delay to the initial public offering (IPO) of state-owned oil company Saudi Aramco to 2019, rather than the initially planned second half of 2018. The government aims for a valuation of $2 trillion, which would raise $100 billion in the IPO. Decisions on foreign exchange and other preparatory work are still pending, with a possible announcement in late October. The delay is due to the complexity of the IPO and the company's advisers' ability to sell shares before the end of next year.

site_title: Kia Motors hires ex-BMW designer as head of styling
summary: Kia Motors has hired Pierre Leclercq, a former designer at BMW and Great Wall Motor, as its head of styling. The move aims to help the South Korean automaker reverse declining sales in China, its top market. Leclercq's experience designing SUVs for BMW and Great Wall Motors is expected to enhance Kia's SUV lineup. His appointment follows Hyundai's recruitment of Simon Loasby, former director of Volkswagen Group China, as its China design head. The changes are part of Kia's efforts to adapt to a market dominated by SUVs.

site_title: Engagement key to green building drive
summary: The Building and Construction Authority in Singapore is launching a green building drive to engage building occupants and tenants in reducing energy consumption and carbon emissions.
