Seventy-four stores have been closed by fire authorities over safety violations, while 13 others were shut down due to business difficulties. China has pressured South Korean businesses with boycotts and bans since Seoul deployed a US-made missile defense system last year, which Beijing claims can penetrate its territory. Lotte shares rose 0.7% following the announcement, with the company exploring alternative options, including selling or downsizing its Chinese operations.

site_title: A special kind of risk: financial records destroyed by fire
summary: A fire at Yamada Green Resources, a Fujian, China-based mushroom producer, destroyed financial documents and equipment, affecting fiscal 2017 and 2018 financial records. The company expects a delayed audit and has sought an extension to report its results until May 2018. This incident, along with previous fires and accounting irregularities, may lead to pain and loss for investors in Singapore-listed China stocks, which are trading at a low price-earnings multiple due to perceived elevated risk.

site_title: Europe: Insurers lead shares higher as Irma, Korea worries ease
summary: European shares rose 1% on Monday as insurers benefited from a drop in Hurricane Irma's estimated cost and North Korea's founding day celebrations without major missile tests. The STOXX 600 index jumped 2.1%, with reinsurers Hannover Re and Beazley leading the gain. Banks also rose 1.5%, while AstraZeneca offset a lung cancer setback with a 2.1% gain. The pan-European insurance index posted its best performance since April, and Europe's shares are now up for the week.

site_title: Trials for cashless commutes to widen
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore is extending a trial for MasterCard users to pay for public transport fares, which has seen over 100,000 users make 60,000 transactions daily. The trial will be extended for another six months, and LTA will also test mobile payment modes such as Android Pay, Apple Pay, and Samsung Pay starting in 2018. The goal is to achieve a fully cashless public transport system by 2020, with the aim of reducing costs and increasing convenience for commuters.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US: Stocks rally after Irma, S&P 500 ends at record
summary: US stocks rallied on Monday, with the S&P 500 finishing at a record high of 2,488.09, up 1.1% from the previous close. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.2% to 22,057.61, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.1% to 6,432.26. The rally followed Hurricane Irma, which caused less damage than initially feared, lifting investor sentiment and supporting stock prices. The record close marked the seventh time the S&P 500 has reached an all-time high this year.

site_title: On 9/11 anniversary, Al-Qaeda rebounding as a threat: experts
summary: Al-Qaeda is experiencing a resurgence in the Middle East, particularly in Syria, 16 years after the 9/11 attacks. Experts say Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), a Sunni group that controls the northern Syrian city of Idlib, is a rebranding of Al-Qaeda positioning itself as more moderate to attract new recruits. Former White House counterterrorism director Joshua Geltzer described Al-Qaeda's largest global affiliate as "worrisome." The group's resurgence poses a threat to global security, with ISIS currently being the preeminent terrorist threat.

site_title: Europe sheds its Brexit baggage; aims for bold new relaunch
summary: The European Union is poised for a renewed push for integration and cooperation following the Brexit vote. EU President Jean-Claude Juncker will deliver a State of the Union speech, focusing on free-trade pacts with Australia and New Zealand, as well as deeper euro-area banking integration. The EU aims to counterbalance the US's protectionist tilt and demonstrate its global market-opening clout. Juncker's plans come as British Prime Minister Theresa May struggles to secure leverage in Brexit talks, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel prepares for a fourth term. The EU sees this as an opportunity to strengthen its institutions and promote stability in a challenging global environment.

site_title: Linked firms vying for same public contracts
summary: Linked firms vying for same public contracts in Singapore are allowed under government procurement rules, as long as there is no collusion or tender rigging. Data shows four cases of connected companies bidding for the same jobs, including services procured by the Land Transport Authority, Ministry of Education, and Nanyang Polytechnic. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) emphasizes that companies with common directors or owners are considered distinct suppliers, evaluated based on their own merits. However, some opine that the current rules may need to be reviewed to prevent "gaming" and ensure public confidence in the tender process.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint buys 4 business parks in UK
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has acquired four business parks in the UK for approximately £686 million (S$1.2 billion), marking the group's entry into the commercial and business park sector. The properties, totaling 4.9 million square feet, have an occupancy rate of 85% and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.9 years. The acquisition is part of the group's strategy to grow its overseas presence and recurring income sources. Frasers Property International has also entered into a conditional agreement to acquire a fifth business park, Maxis, Bracknell, subject to certain conditions.

site_title: Q4 business sentiment dips but industry watchers remain upbeat
summary: Business sentiment among Singapore companies eased in Q4 2017, with the Business Optimism Index falling to +2.60 percentage points from +3.58 in Q3. This marks a decline compared to the same period last year. Despite this, the index remains in positive territory, indicating optimism. The decline is attributed to a decrease in the overall business sentiment score, with a number above zero indicating optimism.

site_title: Homebuyers thwart India's quick fix for bad debt
summary: A Supreme Court halt has temporarily stopped the insolvency process for Jaypee Infratech Ltd, a major Indian developer, after hundreds of homebuyers sued, claiming they would lose their homes and compensation. The central bank had pushed Jaypee into insolvency court to resolve its $180 billion in bad debt, but the court's decision has raised concerns about the treatment of homeowners. The case is seen as a test of the central bank's push to clean up the nation's troubled debts, with thousands of other homeowners facing a national mandate to resolve their own debts.

site_title: Mental revolution of Indonesia bureaucracy still a work-in-progress
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has expressed frustration with the country's slow progress in implementing a "mental revolution" to overhaul its bureaucracy, which he initially promised during his 2014 election campaign. The government's inability to finalize a real estate investment trust backed by state-owned assets has been cited as a prime example of bureaucratic inefficiency. Despite efforts to streamline business permitting and introduce reforms, analysts warn that the government must address petty turf wars and corruption to attract foreign investment and rebuild the country's infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Petty turf wars and dysfunction stymie the overseas investment that World Bank has said needs to top 9 per cent a year if Mr Joko has any hope of starting to meaningfully rebuild Indonesia's woeful infrastructure before the end of the decade.

site_title: Belt-tightening in Britain cinches sales for Primark
summary: Associated British Foods (ABF) has raised its forecast for full-year results following Primark's strong performance, driven by a sharp fall in sterling and below-inflation pay increases. Primark's 2016-17 sales rose 13% at constant currency, with like-for-like sales up 4%. The company added 1.5 million square feet of selling space in 2016-17 and plans another 1.2 million in 2017-18. ABF also announced a £650m cash balance, with analysts praising the company's good momentum.

site_title: Detecting fetal problems with a blood test
summary: A blood test developed by iGene Diagnostics can detect fetal problems with a 95% reduction in unnecessary invasive procedures. The test, which analyzes amniotic fluid, carries a one percent chance of causing a miscarriage. High-risk pregnancies, often experienced by women over 35, are more likely to require amniocentesis, increasing the risk of complications. The test aims to reduce the need for invasive procedures, which can carry a one percent risk of miscarriage.

site_title: Veterans complete board of SGX regulatory unit
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed its board of regulators for the new independent unit, SGX Regulation (Regco), which will start operating on September 15. The final board members include Alan Shaw, former head of risk management and regulation, Jane Diplock AO, a seasoned securities regulator, and Ronny Tan, a Sentosa Development Corp board member. This marks the final step in the transition of Regco, which will oversee regulatory and compliance matters for the exchange.

site_title: Windfall gains from en-bloc fever are likely to be capped
summary: Singapore's en-bloc fever in the residential property market is intensifying, with 17 collective sale sites launched and a total of S$3.5 billion in deals concluded in the first eight months of 2017. The surge in en-bloc transactions is driven by a combination of supply and demand factors, including a conservative approach to land sales by the government and a rise in transaction volumes. However, analysts warn that windfall gains for property owners and developers are likely to be capped due to ongoing property cooling measures and rising interest rates, which may lead to tightened regulations and reduced land sales.

site_title: Govt-style online surveillance opens up profitable new market for Babel Street
summary: Babel Street, a start-up in Virginia, offers government-style surveillance services to private companies, including police departments and stadium managers. The company's web crawlers collect data from 40 online sources, including social media platforms, to monitor security threats and track individuals. Babel Street has partnered with government agencies, including the Department of Homeland Security, and has raised over $5 million in funding. The company aims to balance its business with privacy concerns, limiting access to law enforcement officers and adhering to strict standards.

site_title: What's the big deal about sustainability?
summary: Corporate leaders are increasingly demanding companies to prioritize sustainability, but many are slow to adopt the concept due to its perceived lack of understanding and the free-rider problem. A recent Singapore Governance and Transparency Index found that only 13.2% of listed companies publish annual sustainability reports, despite the mandate to do so next year. Embracing a holistic approach to sustainability, covering a wide range of stakeholders, can provide a clearer value proposition and is becoming an imminent imperative for companies.

site_title: Stamford Tyres net profit rises 24% for Q1
summary: Stamford Tyres Corporation reported a 24% increase in its Q1 net profit to S$1.9 million, driven by improved sales in Australia. Revenue rose 1.5% to S$58.9 million, with gross profit increasing 7.1% to S$15.7 million. The company attributed the growth to value-added activities at its retail chain and truck tyre centres. However, operating expenses rose 6.6% due to higher lease rentals and foreign exchange costs, and net cash flows decreased 16%. The group's CEO stated that the company will continue to optimize its product mix and manage costs to mitigate the impact of a challenging global economic environment.

site_title: Car giants shifting electric projects to China despite risks
summary: Global carmakers, including Volkswagen, General Motors, Renault-Nissan, and Ford Motor, are shifting electric car projects to China despite risks. The country's investments in car-charging stations and research are attracting the industry, with China set to be the hub for electric car research and development. This move is driven by Beijing's push for battery-powered vehicles, which is expected to help carmakers reach their goals faster. The shift is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on opportunities in the rapidly growing Chinese market.

site_title: Singapore top Asian investor in US after Japan, with US$73.6b of FDI
summary: Singapore has become the top Asian investor in the US, surpassing Japan, with a total foreign direct investment (FDI) of $73.6 billion as of 2016. The US Department of Commerce reports that Singapore's FDI in the US has grown at a compound annual growth rate of 36.9% from 2011 to 2016, making it one of the fastest-growing sources of FDI in the country. Despite initial slow growth, Singapore's investments have significantly increased over the years, with a significant presence in manufacturing, services, and financial institutions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CITIC Envirotech has invested $75 million in two hazardous waste treatment facilities in China. Sembcorp Marine won a $145 million contract for hull carry over works in Brazil. Hyflux was ordered to pay $16.1 million to Hydrochem following an arbitration dispute. Tee International formed a collaboration with Advancer Global for joint tenders in engineering and facility management services. Meanwhile, OCBC named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Ills of rising corporate debt will show when liquidity dries up
summary: A growing global debt crisis is expected to reveal itself as financial liquidity dries up, posing a risk to corporate America and emerging markets. The Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns that corporate debt in the US has reached record levels, with over $13.7 trillion, or 72% of GDP, and is approaching the previous peak of the 2008 global financial crisis. The IIF also notes that global debt has reached $217 trillion, or 325% of world GDP, with most of it located in the corporate sector. Rising interest rates and debt buildup in countries like China, Malaysia, and South Korea are causing concern among investors and analysts.

site_title: Bid for global insurer standard faces hurdles
summary: A global standard for insurers to compare their capital holdings has stalled due to a lack of agreement between the US and Europe. The International Capital Standard (ICS), intended to help investors and policyholders, has been in development since 2013 but faces hurdles. Industry officials blame the US and European Union's differing approaches, with the US favoring accounting rules and Europe using market prices. The lack of progress has sparked speculation that regulators may put the process on hold, and few believe a new capital rule would lead to significant hikes in requirements.

site_title: India's traffic is so bad it's changing the cars that people buy
summary: India's notorious traffic congestion is forcing consumers to upgrade to more expensive cars with automatic gears, as manual stick-shifts are becoming less desirable. This shift is driven by the lengthy commutes, with cars crawling at under five kilometers per hour due to traffic jams. As a result, more people are opting for pricier models, marking a significant change in the country's car-buying habits.

site_title: Amazon workers find new roles as robots take over the heavy lifting
summary: Amazon workers are being reassigned to roles that involve monitoring and maintaining robots, rather than physically handling tasks, as the company continues to automate its warehouses. The new jobs, which include babysitting robots and troubleshooting issues, are seen as mentally stimulating and less physically demanding. Despite concerns about job displacement, Amazon has found new roles for displaced workers and plans to continue hiring. The company's use of automation is seen as crucial for maintaining low costs and providing efficient customer service, with some experts crediting it with enabling two-day shipping.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's telecom sector reported lower earnings in Q2 CY17 due to weaker mobile performances. Competition is expected to intensify with TPG's entry, impacting StarHub and M1 more significantly. Analysts have adjusted their forecasts, cutting average revenue per user (ARPU) assumptions and projecting a 14-20% decline over the next five years. M1 was upgraded to "hold" from "sell" despite a lower fair value, while StarHub maintained a "sell" rating. In contrast, Singtel was upgraded to "buy" with a lower fair value due to its growing presence in the digital space.

site_title: Who're you calling 'fat'? The plus-sized embrace their curves
summary: Plus-size model Iskra Lawrence is promoting body positivity and challenging unattainable beauty standards in the fashion world. Lawrence, who averages a US size 10-12, was once told she was too fat to model, but now has signed with JAG Models and has starred in campaigns for American Eagle and Aerie lingerie. Her message of self-acceptance and health has resonated with millions, with over 30 million people in the US suffering from eating disorders. Other strong women, including singers Beyonce and Serena Williams, are also embracing their curves, contributing to a shift in the fashion industry's perception of beauty.

site_title: Shares of Felda Global Ventures climb on appointment of new chairman
summary: Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd shares rose 4.3% to RM1.71 after Azhar Abdul Hamid, a former Sime Darby executive, was appointed chairman, aiming to make the company competitive. His appointment follows a decline in fortunes since 2012, and the company's struggles have been a concern for Prime Minister Najib Razak ahead of the next general election. Azhar stated that getting FGV competitive would be his priority, and he reported for work on Monday.

site_title: Stanchart's take
summary: Businesses can innovate successfully with limited resources by adopting the 70-20-10 rule, allocating time and budgets to maximize opportunities and mitigate risks. This involves empowering teams to suggest enhancements, setting aside budgets for implementation, and fostering a culture of innovation and ownership. A highly engaged workforce is key to successful innovation, as it can catalyze colleagues towards excellence and drive innovative thinking. By challenging and empowering employees, businesses can innovate despite limited resources.

site_title: Tungsten soars after China curbs supply; West steels itself
summary: Tungsten prices have surged over 50% in the last two months due to China's supply curbs, with the European Union classifying it as a "critical" commodity. China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has issued an edict enforcing production quotas, and producers without quotas are being ordered to halt production. This move has raised concerns about the impact on the Western world's economy and defences, with the car industry being the biggest consumer of tungsten.

site_title: Trump and the art of dealing with Democrats
summary: President Trump's ability to work with Democrats in Congress was initially seen as a potential strength in his legislative agenda. His willingness to make deals and form coalitions across party lines was thought to be a key factor in his ability to get things done. However, the article suggests that this expectation may not be met, implying that Trump's relationship with Democrats will be more contentious than anticipated.

site_title: Trump marks 9/11 with warning to America's 'enemies'
summary: US President Donald Trump marked the 16th anniversary of 9/11 with a solemn warning to America's "enemies," saying "savage killers" will find no haven on earth. Trump observed a moment of silence at the White House, laid a wreath at the Pentagon, and delivered remarks, championing America's resilience and common bonds. He issued a stern warning to enemies, stating "America cannot be intimidated" and vowing to protect the nation from attacks.

site_title: Japan Post IPO turns to TV ads to draw retail investors
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co is set to launch a 1.4 trillion yen ($17 billion) public offering, primarily targeting retail investors, amid market anxiety over North Korea. The company's underwriters, including Daiwa Securities and Goldman Sachs, will use a TV advertising campaign to attract individual investors, who are expected to make up most of the shares sold. The IPO is seen as a bid to smooth the sale to retail investors and capitalize on the company's inclusion in the benchmark Nikkei 225 Stock Average.

site_title: Pricey tag dampens iPhone 8's appeal in China
summary: Apple is set to launch the iPhone 8 in China, but its high price tag, estimated to be over $1,000, may dampen its appeal. The phone's success is crucial for the company, which has seen its iPhone sales decline steadily in China over the past six quarters. Local rivals such as Huawei, Oppo, and Xiaomi have gained popularity, with the iPhone's share of China's smartphone shipments falling to 9% in January-June. Consumers are opting for cheaper models or waiting for a price drop, with credit sales on the rise.

site_title: STI drifts lower despite rallies elsewhere
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.05 points, despite a 120-point jump in Dow futures and strong sessions in Hong Kong and Europe, due to low turnover and no major announcements. Media and property firm Singapore Press Holdings lost 4.4% after a CIMB downgrade citing structural decline in core media earnings. Investors await the release of US jobless claims and manufacturing data, which may be impacted by Hurricane Harvey, and are also watching for gold prices, which have been bolstered by market complacency.

site_title: New Speaker pledges to be impartial and fair, but firm
summary: Singapore's new Speaker of Parliament, Tan Chuan-Jin, has pledged to be impartial and fair but firm in facilitating debate and producing better policies. In his first speech, he emphasized the need for mutual respect and adherence to parliamentary rules. Tan also highlighted the challenges of discerning information in today's era of "fake news" and encouraged lawmakers to engage beyond Parliament to tap collective wisdom. He urged the public to trust and respect Parliament, upholding its dignity and honor.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mr Tan told the House he expects its members to debate vigorously but to respect each other.

site_title: China clamps down on lending by trust companies
summary: China's trust companies, a key part of the country's vast shadow banking industry, are facing pressure to step up compliance and background checks amid concerns over their lending practices. A regulatory fine and a legal case against Shanghai International Trust and National Trust highlight the challenges of policing the industry. The trusts, which have a total of 20 trillion yuan in lending operations, employ complex structures to sidestep lending restrictions, making it difficult for regulators to detect illicit activities. The Chinese government aims to rein in the industry and curb corporate debt, but it will be tough to rein in the fast-growing and opaque trust companies.

site_title: 50 years on, Asean's potential still holds much to bank on
summary: ASEAN marks its 50th anniversary amidst rising protectionism and debates about globalization's impact. The region's pragmatic approach, based on non-interference and consensus, has allowed for economic growth, social and cultural development, and peace and security. Despite its urbanization rate of 48% compared to 80% for high-income countries, Asean's collective potential is greater than the sum of its parts, driven by its young population, emerging economic centers, and strategic location. To realize its potential, Asean needs to accelerate its integration, invest in infrastructure, and promote inclusive and sustainable growth, while managing the impact of technological changes and job displacement.

site_title: Pittsburgh to host America's largest urban farm
summary: The city of Pittsburgh will host the US's largest urban farm, the Hilltop Urban Farm, opening in 2019 on 9 hectares of farmland in a low-income housing area. The farm will feature a fruit orchard, youth farm, and skills-building program, aiming to bring fresh produce to underserved areas. This project embodies a trend in former manufacturing cities to transform into green gardens, as seen in other Rust Belt cities like Detroit and Cleveland. The farm is funded by foundations and will provide an alternative to the city's reliance on grants.

site_title: New British wind power deals cheaper than nuclear supplies
summary: Britain's power auction for new offshore wind projects awarded contracts at £74.75-£57.50 per megawatt hour, lower than the £92.50/MWh awarded to France's EDF in 2012 for the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant. The 11 renewable energy projects will deliver up to 3 gigawatts of new electricity generation capacity from 2021-2023, and the cost of producing electricity from wind farms has plummeted in recent years. This marks a breakthrough moment for offshore wind in the UK, with the largest project, Dong Energy's Hornsea 2, set to be the world's largest wind farm.

site_title: Economic cost of Harvey and Irma could hit US$290b
summary: US forecasters predict the combined economic cost of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma could reach $290 billion, equivalent to 1.5% of the US GDP. Harvey is expected to be the costliest weather disaster in US history at $190 billion, while Irma's damage is estimated at $100 billion. Insurers are relieved that predictions about Irma's damage were excessively dire, leading to a sharp increase in Wall Street stocks.

images.alt_text: A partially submerged car in a flooded area in Coconut Grove in Miami on Sunday. Irma shifted course to Florida's Gulf Coast over the weekend, sparing Miami a direct hit, but warnings of high waters from storm surges remained in place in south and central Florida

site_title: Land mafias and the battle for Karachi's booming real estate
summary: In Karachi, land mafias settle disputes through bribery, patronage, and sometimes deadly force, hindering efforts to resolve land title claims for the city's poor. Perween Rahman, head of the Orangi Pilot Project, was shot and killed in 2013 after rejecting a bribe attempt. This highlights the challenges in addressing land disputes in the city, where corruption and violence often prevail.

site_title: Delivering on what they believe in
summary: Family-run logistics firm HUB Distributors Services, founded in 1989, credits its staff loyalty and long-term relationships with customers for its success. With a strong family structure, the company has maintained a low turnover rate, with staff members forming close bonds with the owners, Alex Ea and his sons. The firm's dedication to its clients has resulted in a number of returning clients, including Japanese firms Lion Corporation and Meiji Seika. Despite revenue growth, HUB Distributors Services faces challenges, including a tough labor market and the threat of automation, which the company is addressing through digitalization and optimizing processes.

site_title: Darco wins its first landfill gas recovery, conversion project with consortium partners
summary: Darco Water Technologies Limited has secured its first landfill gas recovery and conversion project in Jati Barang Landfill, Semarang, Indonesia, worth 21.5 million Danish Krone (S$4.7 million). The consortium, comprising Darco Water Systems Sdn Bhd, Q2 A/S, and Pt Fitama Putri Mandiri, will equally share profits and complete the project by the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: Japan ups the steaks to pick 'Wagyu Olympics' winner
summary: Japan's "Wagyu Olympics" has concluded with over 500 cattle parading through a ring in Sendai, Japan, to compete for prizes in categories such as Best Beef Cattle and Most Fertile Cow. Breeders showcased their wagyu cattle, prized for luscious marbling, to win fame and high-paying prizes. The contest, which ended in Miyagi prefecture, saw fertility judged by the cow's shoulders, legs, and back, while beef quality was evaluated by fat marbling and leanness. The event aims to increase overseas demand for wagyu beef, currently Japan's top agricultural export.

site_title: Brexit besieges May at home and away, raising odds of a hard exit
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces increasing pressure on Brexit as her government prepares to submit the EU Withdrawal Bill for approval. The bill's passage is uncertain due to potential rebellions within her own party and stalled negotiations with the EU. The Brexit talks' third round made no decisive progress, and the UK's financial situation is becoming increasingly precarious, with the euro currency at eight-year highs against the pound. The October crunch point looms, raising concerns about the UK's ability to secure a smooth exit from the EU.

site_title: Dubai developers unveil mega projects despite downturn
summary: Dubai property developers unveiled multi-billion-dollar mega-projects despite a three-year market downturn, aiming to stimulate demand and boost economic growth. Exhibitors showcased high-end skyscrapers and "Floating Venice", a $680 million resort with underwater suites. The market has seen a 14% price drop since 2014, with Asteco predicting a recovery after Expo 2020, which is expected to generate 300,000 jobs by 2020. Experts believe increased government spending and diversification strategies will drive a comeback, but demand is expected to remain low until economic sentiment improves.

site_title: Minister warns of disorderly Brexit if withdrawal bill does not pass
summary: Britain's Brexit Minister David Davis warned that a vote against the EU withdrawal bill could lead to a chaotic exit from the European Union. The bill aims to copy and paste EU law into British legislation to ensure a smooth transition. The government is expected to win the vote, but it's a test of Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership. Failure to pass the bill would present a major problem for May, who relies on the support of a small Northern Irish party to govern.

site_title: Conspiracies, conservatives, climate and catastrophe
summary: Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh falsely accused weather scientists of inventing Hurricane Irma's threat for political reasons, echoing the Trump administration's reluctance to discuss climate change. This conspiracy theory is part of a broader pattern of climate change denial on the American right, with many influential figures rejecting scientific evidence and impugning the motives of scientists. The Trump administration is purging climate science and scientists, and a survey shows a steady decline in conservatives' trust in science since the 1970s, with scientists now leaning predominantly Democratic. This willful ignorance poses a significant threat to civilization.

site_title: Facebook fined 1.2 million euros by Spanish data watchdog
summary: Facebook has been fined 1.2 million euros by the Spanish data watchdog, AEPD, for collecting personal information from users without informing them how it would be used for advertising. The investigation found three cases of Facebook collecting details such as gender, religious beliefs, and browsing history without consent. Facebook plans to appeal the decision, stating users can choose what information to share, but the authority said the company's privacy policy was generic and unclear, and it did not obtain consent as required by law.

site_title: China's latest bond default raises red flags for investors
summary: China's Wuyang Construction Group Co defaulted on two bonds totaling 1.36 billion yuan (S$280 million) in August, sparking concerns among investors. The company failed to disclose previous loan defaults and provided inconsistent financial figures in its bond prospectus. This incident highlights the teething problems in China's developing domestic bond market, which is made more accessible to offshore investors via Hong Kong. The incident raises scrutiny on underwriters and the need for thorough credit research. Foreign investors, who hold only 1.5% of the market, are increasingly cautious due to the lack of transparency and risk control in the market.

site_title: Irma weakens to tropical storm -NHC
summary: Irma, a tropical storm, has weakened to 110 km/hr winds, 170 km north-northwest of Tampa, Florida. It is expected to further weaken to a tropical depression by Tuesday afternoon. Despite weakening, Irma is still producing wind gusts near hurricane force.

site_title: Embraer mulling return to China with passenger jet plant
summary: Embraer is considering building a commercial aircraft factory in China, with CEO Paulo Cesar de Souza e Silva stating the company will wait until 2019 to deliberate on the plan. The proposed plant would be the company's first overseas factory for passenger planes, following the shutdown of its private jet plant in China in 2016. This move would mark a shift in strategy for the Brazilian planemaker, which has been focusing on its E195-E2 aircraft production since then.

site_title: China deepens oil ties with Russia with deal for share of Rosneft
summary: China's state-owned energy company CEFC China Energy Co has agreed to buy a 14.16% stake in Russia's largest crude producer Rosneft PJSC for approximately $9 billion. The deal deepens energy ties between China and Russia, amid increasing tensions with the US. Rosneft will retain a prized access to millions of barrels of Russian oil exports. The deal marks a departure from traditional partnerships, as Beijing has relied on state-owned China National Petroleum Corp and China Petroleum & Chemical Corp in the past.

site_title: US: Tech, insurers lead Wall Street rally as Irma, N Korea fears ease
summary: Wall Street experienced a broad rally on Monday, led by technology and financial stocks, as Irma weakened to a tropical storm and North Korea did not conduct a nuclear test. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 172.84 points, or 0.79%, to 21,970.63, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reached new highs. The relief and easing of tensions boosted risk appetite, causing world stocks to climb to a record high and the dollar to edge higher.

site_title: UK government confident of winning vote on Brexit legislation
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's government is confident of winning a vote on Brexit legislation, a bill allowing the UK to sever ties with the EU. The bill is crucial for a smooth Brexit and faces opposition from lawmakers. Brexit minister David Davis warned that a vote against the bill could lead to a chaotic exit from the EU. The vote is expected later this week, with the government encouraging all MPs to support the bill.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, following a rally in Tokyo. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.5%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices rose 0.6% each. The rally was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Dollar bounces as risk appetite returns
summary: The US dollar edged higher on Monday after posting its largest weekly drop in two months, driven by a revival in risk appetite and investors cutting short bets against the greenback. Despite this, net short bets against the dollar remain near their highest levels since 2013, with expectations of Federal Reserve policy tightening fading. US inflation data this week is expected to show a slight increase, but not enough to prompt a rate hike. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 92.51, while the euro tumbled towards the day's lows.

site_title: China August vehicle sales up 5.3% y-o-y
summary: China's vehicle sales in August rose 5.3% year-over-year to 2.19 million, rebounding from weakness in April and May. This follows a 6.2% increase in July and 4.5% in June. The country's auto market continues to recover, with sales up from a 2.2% decrease in April and 0.1% decrease in May.

site_title: Insolvent Air Berlin scraps more long-haul flights
summary: Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, is scrapping long-haul flights to the Caribbean from Duesseldorf due to fleet reduction needs. The airline, which filed for bankruptcy last month, will end routes to destinations like Mexico and Cuba on September 25. Bidders, including Lufthansa and Condor, are lining up to acquire the airline's assets, with a decision possible as early as September 21. The airline's planes are being kept in the air thanks to a 150 million euro government loan until November.

site_title: Swiss Re expects prices to stabilise due to recent loss events
summary: Swiss Re expects insurance prices to stabilize after recent catastrophes, including Hurricane Harvey and flooding in Asia, due to the industry's financial backstop role. The Zurich-based reinsurer noted a "protection gap" between beneficial and purchased coverage, citing the recent disasters as evidence. CEO Christian Mumenthaler emphasized the gap's reality, stating that expensive disasters continue to underscore the issue.

site_title: Five dancers have got this cellist's Bach
summary: Cellist Jean-Guihen Queyras has collaborated with choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker on a new dance work, "Mitten wir im Leben sind," which premiered at the Ruhrtriennale festival and has traveled to over a dozen locations in Europe. The piece is set to Queyras' performances of Bach's six suites for solo cello, with the dancers reacting to the music and creating a unique, geometric choreography. The collaboration has led to a new understanding of the suites, with Queyras adapting his playing to De Keersmaeker's counterintuitive choreography, and the dancers responding to the music's harmonic structure.

site_title: Stamford Tyres posts 24% rise in Q1 profit
summary: STAMFORD Tyres Corporation reported a 24% increase in Q1 net profit to S$1.9 million, driven by improved sales in Australia. Earnings per share rose to 0.82 Singapore cents from 0.66 cents a year ago. Revenue increased 1.5% to S$58.9 million in the quarter.

site_title: Trek 2000 soars after shares emerge from trading suspension
summary: Trek 2000 International shares surged 31.7% after the company resumed trading after a 1.5-year suspension. The stock rose 5.4 cents to S$0.245, with over 3.3 million shares traded. The suspension was related to issues with sale transactions between subsidiaries and customers, which may have overstated sales and profits by US$1.85 million and US$272,615 respectively. Despite this, the company returned to profitability in 2016 and reported a 79% increase in net profit in the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Citic Envirotech invests 365m yuan in two waste facilities in Guangdong
summary: CITIC Envirotech Ltd has invested 365 million yuan (S$75.13 million) in two hazardous waste treatment facilities in Guangdong province, China. The investment was made through the acquisition of a 51% stake in two companies and expansion of a treatment facility. The funds will come from bank financing and the issuance of senior perpetual securities. The acquisition is expected to have no material effect on the company's financial results for the current year.

site_title: Airbnb sees 80% jump in visitors to Britain
summary: Airbnb reported an 80% surge in visitors to Britain in the last year, reaching 5.9 million and generating £3.46 billion for the economy. The growth is attributed to the weaker pound, with official figures showing tourism to Britain has been rising. London has the highest number of active listings, and Airbnb has introduced a rule to limit long-term rentals in the city. The platform has disrupted the travel accommodation market, but has also faced controversies over regulations and local accommodation availability.

site_title: Presidential election: only one certificate of eligibility issued
summary: Singapore's presidential election is on track for a walkover after the Presidential Elections Committee issued a certificate of eligibility to only one applicant, Halimah Yacob, a former speaker of parliament. This leaves the election without any opposition candidates, with the other two applicants from the Malay community and the private sector also being unsuccessful. The Elections Department will not disclose the reasons for the unsuccessful applicants' rejection.

site_title: Thai junta tells Japan investors US$45b development plan to go ahead
summary: The Thai junta has assured Japanese investors that a $45 billion development plan to redevelop the country's industrial east will proceed regardless of the outcome of upcoming elections. The plan, known as the Eastern Economic Corridor, aims to boost growth to 5% by 2020 and establish a manufacturing hub for electric vehicles. The junta, facing economic challenges, has emphasized the project's importance and its status as a long-term national strategy.

site_title: Hyflux's subsidiary awarded US$16.1m following arbitration
summary: Hyflux's subsidiary, Hydrochem, has been awarded US$16.1 million by a tribunal following an arbitration dispute with SEPCOIII Electric Power Construction Corporation over a desalination facility contract in Oman. The arbitration began after disputes arose from the contract dated August 28, 2009. The tribunal will separately determine interest and costs.

site_title: Singapore stocks close mixed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed at 3,228.51, down 0.05 points, with a low turnover of 1.4 billion units worth S$884.4 million. site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start the week with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Monday, following broader Asian gains, as concerns over the North Korean crisis decreased. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.04% to 27,955.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.33% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 0.80%. The rally was driven by better-than-forecast Chinese inflation data and easing concerns over US trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.840 points to 1,782.740 on Monday, driven by a higher volume of 2.730 billion lots worth RM2.162 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 527 to 350.

site_title: SGX RegCo appoints board members; starts operations on Sep 15
summary: SGX RegCo has appointed board members Alan Shaw, Jane Diplock AO, and Ronny Tan. The company will start operations on September 15, 2017. Shaw has experience in takeovers and risk management, while Diplock AO has served as an independent non-executive director of SGX since 2011. Tan's background is not specified. The new regulatory body will oversee Singapore's securities market.

site_title: Union Gas' H1 profit down 37%
summary: Union Gas reported a 37% drop in net profit to S$1.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2017, mainly due to a 588.4% increase in administrative expenses. Revenue rose 12.6% to S$19.8 million, driven by increased sales of bottled and liquefied petroleum gas, and diesel, but partially offset by a decline in compressed natural gas sales. The company's earnings per share fell to 0.87 Singapore cents from 1.38 Singapore cents a year ago.

site_title: Vard Holdings secures contract to build cruise vessel for Australia's Coral Expeditions
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a contract to build an expedition cruise vessel for Coral Expeditions of Australia, set to be delivered in the first quarter of 2019. The 93.5-meter vessel, designed by Vard Design, will accommodate 120 guests and features a ship environment for daily shore expeditions, lectures, and briefings. The contract marks a significant milestone for Vard Holdings and Coral Expeditions, with the vessel scheduled for delivery from Vard Vung Tau in Vietnam.

site_title: Smart Nation push is not about tech for tech's sake: Janil Puthucheary
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation initiative aims to improve lives through technology, not just for its own sake. Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary addressed concerns about the elderly being left out, stating that the focus is on people-centricity. A Digital Readiness Workgroup has been set up to propose strategies for public readiness by 2018, complementing existing initiatives like the Silver Infocomm Initiative. Key milestones include the launch of PayNow, a new instant fund-transfer system, and the introduction of a common QR code for merchants to accept e-payments. The government is also studying e-payment proposals and strengthening digital security measures to mitigate risks.

site_title: Sembmarine's Brazilian subsidiary wins US$145m contract
summary: SembCorp Marine's wholly-owned Brazilian subsidiary, Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz Ltda, won a US$145 million contract for hull carry-over works from the Tupi BV consortium, which is controlled by Petrobras. The contract, for the FPSO P-68 Tupi Project, is an additional work that will enable full integration of the FPSO P-8. The contract is expected to have no material impact on the company's financials for the current year.

site_title: Trump marks 9/11 with threat to 'savage killers'
summary: President Donald Trump marked the 16th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks by delivering remarks at the Pentagon, where 184 people died. Trump observed a moment of silence, laid a wreath, and issued a stern warning to "savage killers" who threaten the US, stating that America "cannot be intimidated" and will vanquish its enemies. Trump also commemorated the victims at Ground Zero in New York, where a minute's silence was observed at 8:46 am, the moment the first plane struck the World Trade Center.

site_title: Will Aramco deliver world record profit for IPO in 2018?
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, is expected to disclose its financials for the first time next year, potentially revealing a world record profit for its initial public offering (IPO) in 2018. The company's valuation of US$2 trillion is based on its oil reserves and valuation of US$7 to US$8 per barrel. However, analysts question the company's target valuation, citing the need for higher core earnings, which could be a global first. If Aramco achieves its target valuation, it would be a significant milestone, with some experts predicting profits of US$250 billion a year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks strengthen, gains capped by China worries
summary: South Korean shares ended at their highest in over a week, driven by gains in tech and chemical stocks. The Kospi index rose 0.7% to 2,359.08 points, boosted by electric and electronics shares. However, tensions between Seoul and Beijing over South Korea's US anti-missile defence system limited gains, with local cosmetics-related companies falling. Offshore investors sold a net 136.3 billion won of local equities, and the won extended its losses against the US dollar.

site_title: VW, Mercedes scramble to plug diesel gap after two-year crisis
summary: German automakers Volkswagen, Mercedes-Benz, and BMW are scrambling to recover from a two-year crisis following Volkswagen's diesel-emissions cheating scandal. With diesel demand slumping in Europe, the industry is shifting to electric cars to meet stricter emissions rules. Despite unveiling electric concepts at the Frankfurt Auto Show, the manufacturers face billions of euros in fines and tens of thousands of jobs at risk. The EU's fleet-average emissions limit of 95 grams of carbon dioxide per kilometer by 2021 is unlikely to be met, with estimates suggesting that all three German carmakers will exceed the limit, potentially exposing them to fines.

site_title: ECB nerves keep eurozone bond markets on back foot
summary: Borrowing costs in the eurozone rose on Monday as signs of the European Central Bank's (ECB) plan to exit its stimulus scheme weighed on sentiment. ECB board member Benoit Coeure stated that the bank's definition of 'medium-term' inflation target would be longer than usual, briefly pushing bond yields down. The ECB is expected to cut bond purchases, with options including reducing monthly purchases from 60 billion euros to 20 or 40 billion euros, sparking market unease and pushing German 10-year bond yields up one basis point.

site_title: Carillion shakes up management to lead recovery
summary: Carillion, a British construction services company, has announced changes to its management in an effort to stabilize its business. CFO Zafar Khan is stepping down, replaced by Emma Mercer, while Lee Watson has been appointed as chief transformation officer. These changes come amid a crisis for the company, which has warned on full-year profits due to payment problems and a deterioration in some contracts. Carillion's debt pile and pension obligations also pose significant challenges, and the company may need to raise at least £500 million.

site_title: AUD, NZD fall from highs as USD rebounds
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined from their peaks as the US dollar rebounded after North Korea avoided escalating tensions. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.8046, while the New Zealand dollar dropped 0.2% to US$0.7249. The US dollar's rebound was driven by relief that North Korea did not launch another missile, lifting the greenback from its lowest since January 2015. The decline in local currencies is attributed to expectations of strong employment data in Australia and general election jitters in New Zealand.

site_title: Li Ka Shing expands investments in electric vehicles
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka Shing has agreed to buy an indirect stake in Japanese electric car maker GLM, expanding his investments in the electric vehicle market. This investment comes as China pushes to phase out gasoline and diesel vehicles, driving demand for electric cars. Li's investment gets him a place in the higher-end EV market, targeting a segment dominated by Tesla. The investment also follows China's announcement of a deadline for automakers to end sales of fossil fuel-powered vehicles, set to heat up the EV market further.

site_title: Japan govt launches US$12b follow-up sale of Japan Post Holdings shares
summary: Japan's government plans to sell approximately $12 billion worth of shares in Japan Post Holdings Co Ltd, following a 2015 IPO that raised $12 billion. The sale comes amid declining mail delivery volume and ultra-low interest rates affecting Japan Post's financial units. Institutional investors are expected to struggle to attract demand due to the lack of a strong growth story. The sale, part of a broader $36 billion plan to raise funds for Japan's reconstruction efforts, will determine its price between September 25 and September 27.

site_title: UN warns Myanmar situation 'textbook example of ethnic cleansing'
summary: The UN human rights chief, Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, warned that Myanmar's treatment of the Rohingya minority amounts to "ethnic cleansing". The situation is described as a "textbook example" of ethnic cleansing, with reports of extrajudicial killings, burning of villages, and laying of landmines along the border. Over 294,000 Rohingya refugees have fled to Bangladesh, with tens of thousands more believed to be on the move. The UN calls for the Myanmar government to end its military operation and reverse severe discrimination against the Rohingya population, urging access to investigate the situation.

site_title: Blockade attempt to force Qatar into 'trusteeship': minister
summary: Qatar's foreign minister, Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani, condemned the "illegal siege" imposed by Saudi Arabia and its allies as a "state of trusteeship" aimed at controlling Qatar's foreign and domestic policies. The blockade, which began on June 5, has been described as a "clear violation of international laws." Al-Thani stated that Qatar cannot tolerate this situation, which he claims is not aimed at fighting terrorism, but rather to undermine Qatar's sovereignty and interfere in its domestic policy.

site_title: Goldman sees hurricanes curbing US growth, only for a quarter
summary: Goldman Sachs economists predict US economic growth will be curbed by hurricanes in the third quarter, with a 0.8 percentage point reduction, but will rebound in the fourth quarter and first half of next year, reaching 2.7% growth. The firm estimates a cumulative one percentage-point gain in the fourth quarter and first half of 2018. This prediction contrasts with Bank of America's forecast that Hurricane Harvey would reduce third-quarter GDP by 0.4 percentage point.

site_title: Hot Stock: SPH falls 3.7% on heavy trading
summary: SPH shares fell 3.7% on Monday, trading 10 cents lower at S$2.64 due to heavy trading, with over 9.5 million shares exchanged. The decline comes ahead of the company's full-year results in October, following a report that advertisements at flagship paper The Straits Times declined year-on-year in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on upbeat data, weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by upbeat Japanese data and a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.14% to 19,545.77, while the Topix index gained 1.17% to 1,612.26. site_title: LA protestors voice support for 'Dreamer' immigrants
summary: Thousands of Los Angeles residents protested US President Donald Trump's decision to rescind the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrival (DACA) program, which protected 800,000 young undocumented immigrants. Demonstrators chanted slogans opposing Trump's decision, calling for unity against racism. The program, initiated by former President Barack Obama, granted temporary legal status to eligible young immigrants. The protest was part of a growing nationwide movement to support 'Dreamer' immigrants, who face deportation.

site_title: Uber gives free rides to shelters in Hurricane Irma's path
summary: Uber and Lyft offered free rides to shelters in Tampa, Florida, as Hurricane Irma approached, providing a vital service to residents. The move aimed to burnish Uber's image, following criticism of surge pricing during times of crisis. Uber suspended its service in the Tampa Bay area, while Lyft also suspended rides. The free rides included trips to hospitals and were publicized by the city's Office of Emergency Management. The storm made landfall in the Florida Keys as a Category 4 storm, moving north along Florida's west coast.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Monday with a 0.76% gain, building on last week's positive finish. The Hang Seng Index rose 209.22 points to 27,877.69, driven by relief that North Korea did not fire another missile. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, with the latter increasing 0.14%. The gains come as traders brush off new US threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: Australian shares higher as investors hunt for yield, NZ extends gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by investors seeking yield in sectors such as finance, despite concerns over North Korea's nuclear test and Commonwealth Bank's money laundering allegations. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 36.483 points to 5,709.1, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.07%. Financial stocks and consumer staples led the gains, with Macquarie Group expecting higher first-half net profit. Commodity prices fell, dragging down mining giants BHP and Rio Tinto.

site_title: Australian PM Turnbull defends baby and beer photo
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull defended a photo of himself nursing a beer while holding his granddaughter, dismissing criticism as "craziness" from social media users. The image sparked ire, with some calling him "irresponsible" and "disgraceful". However, most comments on his Facebook page defended the photo as a tender family moment, with Turnbull saying "you've just got to be yourself". The backlash was largely dismissed by politicians, including opposition leader Bill Shorten, who tweeted it was "rubbish".

site_title: Aussie banks sitting on A$500b of 'liar loans', UBS says
summary: UBS estimates Australian banks hold A$500 billion in "liar loans," or mortgages based on inaccurate financial information. A survey of 907 Australians found only 67% of mortgage applicants stated their application was accurate, down from 72% the previous year. Common inaccuracies included overstating income and understating living expenses. Analysts warn that these findings suggest lenders may be overestimating borrowers' ability to repay loans, potentially leading to larger losses in a downturn.

site_title: China's yuan slips, rally pauses after relaxation of FX outflow curbs
summary: China's yuan slipped slightly on Monday after a brief rally, with the currency easing 0.05% to 6.5040 per US dollar. This move, along with the central bank's guidance to push the yuan higher for 11 consecutive sessions, led to a softer-than-expected fixing and a weaker-than-expected opening in the spot market. Economists believe the yuan's gains may lose steam as exporters face strain and the Chinese government prepares for a Communist Party gathering in October.

site_title: China mulls petrol car ban, boosting electric vehicles
summary: China is considering a ban on fossil fuel cars, potentially as early as 2040, to boost electric vehicle production and reduce pollution. The move follows similar plans by France and Britain. The policy is expected to be implemented "in the near future," according to the government.

The Dalai Lama's comments join a growing chorus of criticism from Nobel peace laureates, including the UN, highlighting the need for international action to address the crisis.

site_title: Australian banks may exit wealth management without being forced

site_title: Cape Town boom a bust for long-time tenants

summary: US-based weather forecaster AccuWeather estimated the economic cost of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma to be US$290 billion, equivalent to 1.5% of the US GDP. summary: Australian researchers claim a combination of new treatments can stop melanoma from spreading, effectively preventing its progression and saving lives. The results suggest that melanoma can be made a chronic rather than a terminal illness, bringing the disease closer to being eradicated.

summary: The Hong Kong dollar has seen its largest two-day jump in 19 months, driven by a tumble in the US dollar and investors unwinding short positions. site_title: US dollar stabilises after selloff; focus on North Korea, Hurricane Irma

site_title: Spicey skits bring an Emmy for Melissa McCarthy
summary: Melissa McCarthy won an Emmy for her spoofs of former White House spokesman Sean Spicer on "Saturday Night Live" as "Spicey." The show also received nominations for other cast members, including Alec Baldwin and Kate McKinnon, and won an Emmy for comedian Dave Chappelle's guest actor and host appearance.

site_title: China studying when to ban sales of traditional fuel cars
summary: China has begun studying when to ban the production and sale of traditional fuel cars, citing "turbulent times" for the industry. The country's Industry and Information Technology vice-minister, Xin Guobin, predicted that a ban could be implemented in the coming years, with the goal of making electric and plug-in hybrid cars account for at least 20% of sales by 2025. The move aims to combat air pollution and close the gap with global rivals.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump as investors hunt for bargains; North Korea fears recede
summary: South Korean stocks jumped 0.8% to their highest in over a week, driven by buying in tech shares and reduced concerns about North Korea. Market players believe the risks from North Korea have receded, but caution that it's too early to say the situation is fully resolved.

site_title: North Korea warns US of 'greatest pain' over fresh sanctions
summary: North Korea warned the US it would inflict "the greatest pain and suffering" if the UN Security Council votes on harsher sanctions following the country's sixth nuclear test. The US is calling for an oil embargo, asset freeze, and restrictions on textile exports and guest worker payments. North Korea's foreign ministry stated that if the US imposes the sanctions, the country will take "a series of actions" that will cause the US "the greatest pain and suffering it has ever gone through." The warning came amid escalating tensions over North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: The next oil major? Service firm Schlumberger bets big on production
summary: Schlumberger, the world's largest oilfield services company, is investing billions in its customers' oil and gas projects, gaining operational authority and potentially upending the service business model. The company has committed hundreds of millions to growing its production management division, which now generates $1.4 billion in revenue. Schlumberger's gamble could increase profits but also ramps up risk, as the company takes on more speculative projects and faces global oil price swings.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment for Q4 2017 moderates but still optimistic: poll
summary: Singapore business sentiment for Q4 2017 moderated to +2.60 percentage points, down from +3.58 in Q3, but remains optimistic. Expectations for net profits have decreased, while inventory levels contract. Sales volumes and employment levels are expected to expand, albeit at a slower pace. The manufacturing, services, and wholesale sectors are the most optimistic. A survey of 200 business owners and executives found a decrease in expectations for selling prices and new orders.

site_title: Stocks to watch: TEE International, Advancer Global, BRC Asia, HG Metal, Trek 2000
summary: Several companies made significant developments in the stock market. TEE International formed a collaboration with Advancer Global, while BRC Asia and HG Metal Manufacturing are set to be acquired by Esteel Enterprise at S$0.925 per share. Trek 2000 International will resume trading after a moratorium on trading by its senior and former management. These developments may impact trading of the companies' shares, and investors should stay informed about the latest news.

site_title: Victoria Beckham brings Play-Doh sparkle to New York
summary: Victoria Beckham unveiled her latest fashion collection in New York, featuring colors inspired by Play-Doh and sparkly slippers named after her daughter. The designer stated the new colors are "not too sweet" and "just the right amount." The collection marked a departure from her classic black aesthetic, showcasing her willingness to experiment and evolve her style.

site_title: TEE International forms tie-up with Advancer Global
summary: TEE International, a real estate and engineering group, has formed a collaboration with Advancer Global, a maid agency and facility management services arm. The partnership aims to explore joint tenders in contracts requiring mechanical and electrical engineering works and jointly invest in facilities management projects in the Asia-Pacific region. The move follows TEE International's failed attempt to buy out the company in August, with shares trading at S$0.205.

site_title: UN slams UK government over 'plague' of air pollution
summary: The UN has criticized the UK government for failing to address the "plague" of air pollution, which is linked to over 40,000 premature deaths annually. The report argues that inaction has violated the government's obligations to protect children. The criticism comes ahead of the Human Rights Council, which starts Monday.

site_title: Japan's banks must improve screening for card loans
summary: Japan's banks face scrutiny over excessive card loan lending, with outstanding loans reaching 5.7 trillion yen, a 70% increase from five years ago. The Financial Services Agency will conduct on-site inspections to assess banks' screening systems. Critics argue that banks' aggressive strategies and loopholes in regulations have led to a surge in unsecured card loans, which can quickly become unmanageable for borrowers. The agency aims to uncover problems and ensure banks thoroughly verify borrowers' repayment abilities.

site_title: Tennis: Wu warns world after first Chinese boys Slam title
summary: Chinese tennis player Wu Yibing won the US Open boys singles title, defeating Argentina's Axel Geller 6-4, 6-4. At 17, Wu became China's first boys Slam singles champion. He also won the US Open boys doubles title with partner Hsu Yu Hsiou, becoming the first all-Asian pair to do so. Wu attributed his success to hard work and dedication, saying "I think this is showing ourselves and showing the world Chinese boys can be good and better - and Chinese men."

site_title: With Trump meeting, Malaysia's PM seeks to put 1MDB scandal behind him
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is seeking to put the 1MDB scandal behind him as he prepares to meet with US President Donald Trump, where investigations into the state fund are ongoing. Najib has overseen the scandal, which is being investigated in at least six countries, including the US, where the Justice Department seeks to seize $1.7 billion in assets. Najib's government has launched an anti-corruption campaign, but critics say it ignores the elephant in the room, and the US meeting may affect investigations. Najib's general election must be called by mid-2018.

site_title: En-bloc fever is back
summary: En-bloc fever has taken hold in Singapore's residential property market, driven by growing optimism and developers' need to replenish their land banks. With the government's land sales program tapering off, developers are turning to collective sales, leading to increased demand for residential property. Experts predict a surge in short- to mid-term buying interest, with some forecasting a 10% rise in private home prices by end-2018. The en-bloc market is also expected to boost jobs in the property and construction sector, as well as contribute to economic growth.

site_title: Mourners sob, sift wreckage of huge Mexico quake
summary: A powerful 8.2-magnitude earthquake struck southern Mexico on Thursday, killing at least 65 people in the states of Oaxaca, Tabasco, and Chiapas. The quake, the country's biggest in a century, has left thousands homeless and without access to basic necessities like water and electricity. Families camped out in the streets, fearing aftershocks, while authorities scrambled to provide aid and clear the rubble. Rescuers searched for victims in remote areas, and the death toll is expected to rise as more bodies are discovered.

site_title: 'Do NOT shoot' at Irma, Florida sheriff warns after online prank
summary: Pasco County Sheriff's Office warned residents not to shoot at Hurricane Irma after an online prank promoting the idea went viral on social media. The prank, started as a joke, was meant to poke fun at the storm's unpredictable flight path, but many took it seriously, with some even suggesting using guns or flame-throwers to target the storm. The sheriff's office clarified the warning, stating "DO NOT shoot weapons at #Irma" and warning of dangerous side effects. The prank sparked criticism, with some calling the person who started it "stupid" and "stressing out" the public.

site_title: Buybacks rise, Oei Hong Leong increases Raffles Education stake
summary: Raffles Education Corporation's substantial shareholder Oei Hong Leong increased his stake in the company to 12.14% after acquiring 6,454,200 shares at S$0.1946 per share. The company reported a 13% fall in FY17 revenue to S$96.2 million, mainly due to the discontinuation of a joint venture college. Other notable share buybacks included S I2I, which bought back 7.06% of its shares, and UOB Kay Hian Holdings, which purchased 35,500 shares. The Straits Times Index declined 1.5% over four sessions, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for 2017 to 15.3%.

site_title: Private home prices to rise 10% by end-2018: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a 10% increase in private home prices by the end of 2018, reversing earlier forecasts of a decline. The firm attributes this change to the en-bloc trend, which could bring in S$13 billion in potential capital inflows. Analyst Wilson Ng also notes that unsold inventory has reached a record low, and households are re-entering the market with improved balance sheets. The firm's revised forecast is among the most bullish in the research circle, with prices expected to rise 2% in 2017 and 8% in 2018.

site_title: Aramco IPO process 'going ahead' even as Saudis redraw transformation plan
summary: Saudi Arabia's government says the Aramco IPO process is "well under way" despite redrawing its National Transformation Program to align with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Saudi Vision 2030. The kingdom plans to sell up to 5% of Aramco next year, which could be the world's largest IPO. The revised plan won't change key fiscal or energy targets but aims to match the Aramco IPO with the broader Saudi Vision 2030. A final report is due by the end of October.

site_title: Equifax's insurance likely to be inadequate against cyber breaches
summary: Equifax's insurance policy may be insufficient to cover the costs of a massive cyber breach that affected 143 million people, potentially leading to higher expenses. The company's policy is estimated to cover $100-150 million, but costs could be multiples higher. Equifax faces multiple investigations and a proposed class action lawsuit, and the company has acknowledged the limits of its insurance protection. The breach has resulted in the exposure of sensitive data, including Social Security numbers and driver's license information.

site_title: All eyes on N Korea moves, US debt-ceiling saga & dollar
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's defiant missile tests and US President Donald Trump's actions are influencing stock-market movements. Kim's missile tests have raised "geopolitical risk," but his track record suggests his belligerent overtures will likely amount to nothing. Meanwhile, Trump's debt-ceiling deal with Democrats has reversed recent rises in Treasury yields, but a new government shutdown deadline in December and a return to the debt ceiling in 2018 may impact stocks. The recent weakness in the US dollar may also provide support for the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Adnoc could list stake in fuel retail business by early 2018: sources
summary: Adnoc, Abu Dhabi National Oil Co, plans to list more than 10% of its fuel retail business by early 2018, and potentially one or two more businesses, as part of a major shake-up to make its energy assets more competitive and efficient.

site_title: Brexit fallout is driving UK firms to Nasdaq's Nordic market
summary: Nasdaq Nordic expects up to 15% of its initial public offerings and listings in 2018 to be made by companies outside the Nordic region, primarily from the UK, Ireland, Israel, Malta, and Germany, due to Brexit uncertainty. The market's head, Adam Kostyal, attributes the shift to the fact that "uncertainty is a listing's worst enemy." Nasdaq Nordic's First North offering, which allows smaller firms to raise capital without stricter rules, is becoming an attractive alternative to London's AIM market.

site_title: Russia urges talks to solve Gulf crisis
summary: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov urged Arab countries and Qatar to engage in direct talks to resolve the ongoing diplomatic dispute, calling for regional unity. Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, UAE, and Egypt severed ties with Qatar in June, accusing it of supporting terrorist groups. Russia supports mediation efforts led by Kuwait and the US, and Saudi Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir demands Qatar show seriousness in finding a solution. A breakthrough in the crisis is seen as crucial for regional stability, with Russia and Saudi Arabia discussing de-escalation zones in Syria.

site_title: Days of oil market's plastic fantasy may be numbered
summary: Kenya's ban on single-use plastic bags has sent a warning signal to the oil industry, particularly those reliant on petrochemicals, as the world shifts towards electric cars. The International Energy Agency predicts petrochemicals will drive crude sales for decades, but the rise of recycling and bans on plastic waste threatens this growth. With plastic waste estimated to surpass fish by weight in oceans by 2050, countries like India and England are introducing initiatives to curb plastic pollution, potentially harming the petrochemicals sector's need for oil-based feedstocks.

site_title: Bttrigtical reinvents water-in-oil detector
summary: Bttrigtical Pte Ltd has developed a water-in-oil detector that is more convenient and accurate than existing methods. The product is designed to detect water contamination in industrial oils, which can damage machinery components and cause costly failures. The detector has the potential to disrupt various industries, including oil and gas, petrochemical, and pharmaceutical. The company claims its test is not only more convenient but also far more accurate than existing methods, offering a solution to the problem of water contamination in industrial oils.

site_title: Hurricanes vs hikes - the storm before the calm?
summary: US stocks remained flat last week amid uncertainty from two catastrophic storms, Hurricane Irma and Hurricane Harvey. Irma, which caused widespread destruction in the Caribbean, threatened to knock power out for millions of Americans and disrupt supplies to the Florida Keys. Despite fears of a devastating impact, stocks may advance if Irma fails to live up to expectations and inflation remains in check. Analysts expect Harvey's impact to be felt soon, with the Commerce Department set to report retail sales for August, while the Federal Reserve may hold off on rate hikes due to low inflation.

site_title: Cigarettes, cash and cover-ups: A US agency's shady actions
summary: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) operated a secret account in Bristol, Virginia, for seven years, allowing agents to buy goods and services without Congressional oversight. The account, controlled by veteran agent Thomas Lesnak, was used to fund undercover operations, including purchasing luxury cars and electronics. Informants, including tobacco distributors Jason Carpenter and Christopher Small, were paid millions of dollars and received lavish rewards. The scheme, which began as a way to catch black-market cigarette dealers, transformed into a nearly untraceable slush fund that agents could tap. Despite thousands of pages of documents revealing the scheme, no one was ever prosecuted, and Congress was only notified recently.

site_title: Millions flee or hunker down as deadly Irma slams into Florida
summary: Hurricane Irma made landfall in Florida on Sunday with 130-mph winds, causing widespread destruction and prompting millions to evacuate. The storm's second landfall is predicted to occur overnight near Tampa, with storm surges reaching 5-10 feet in the Florida Keys and potentially 15 feet in south-western Florida. Over 6 million residents were ordered to evacuate, and at least 50,000 are staying in shelters. Officials warn of devastating winds, flooding, and tornadoes, with Governor Rick Scott urging residents to leave immediately. The storm is expected to bring destruction not seen in a generation.

images.alt_text: The Tampa skyline (above) is barely visible across Hillsborough Bay ahead of the arrival of Hurricane Irma on Sunday.
Conditions in South Beach (above). The National Weather Service said south-western Florida could see storm surges of up to 15 feet (4.5 meters) if peak surge happens during high tide.

site_title: Aussie govt, firm at odds over fate of coal-fired plant
summary: Australia's government is pushing AGL Energy Ltd to extend the life of its coal-fired Liddell power station beyond 2022, when the company plans to close it. Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg and Treasurer Scott Morrison emphasized the importance of maintaining base-load power and avoiding power blackouts, citing coal-fired stations as a reliable option. The government plans to discuss options with AGL CEO Andy Vesey, with Morrison stating he would be happy to assist in selling the plant to a responsible party.

images.alt_text: Canberra says coal-fired stations provide base-load power and would help avoid power blackouts in some states.

site_title: These are not the robots we were promised
summary: Smart speakers, such as Amazon Echo, Google Home, and Apple HomePod, are revolutionizing home automation with their ability to deliver news, traffic, and weather reports, as well as perform tasks like diagnosing ailments and reading bedtime stories. Despite their humanoid designs, they avoid the "uncanny valley" and are preferred over anthropomorphic robots. With over 35 million users in the US, smart speakers are expected to become a staple in 75% of US households by 2020, symbolizing our self-absorbed time and desire for comfort in a virtual world.

images.alt_text: Whether real or fictional, robots hold a mirror up to society. Some 35 million Americans now use diminutive, talking computers - more than twice the number of just a year ago, according to estimates by eMarketer.

site_title: Rohingya militants declare one-month ceasefire
summary: Rohingya militants, affiliated with the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army (ARSA), have declared a one-month ceasefire in Myanmar's Rakhine State, effective until October 9. The move aims to allow humanitarian aid to reach the battered region, where nearly 300,000 Rohingya refugees have fled to Bangladesh. The ceasefire is seen as a temporary measure to alleviate the humanitarian crisis, which has left thousands of displaced people stranded or without food for weeks. The UN has appealed for $77 million in aid to cope with the emergency, while rights monitors report widespread violence and arson targeting the Muslim population.

site_title: Citi golf event donates S$500k to ChildAid
summary: Citi's charity golf event has donated S$500,000 to ChildAid for the seventh consecutive year, bringing the total contribution to S$3.64 million since 2011. The funds support two charities, helping over 150,000 disadvantaged children with their education and daily needs. The 12th edition of ChildAid, co-organised by Citi and Singapore Press Holdings, will take place on Nov 24-25 at Resorts World Sentosa with a new look and format led by creative director Dick Lee.

site_title: Possible deluge of used cars ahead but impact uncertain
summary: Uber is selling off its estimated 15,000-strong fleet of private-hire cars in Singapore, with up to 3,000-4,000 cars potentially entering the used market. This could impact resale values, particularly with the collapse of the COE premium to a 7-year low. However, the high mileage on these cars may mitigate the effect, with some models depreciating by 30-35% due to excessive usage. Industry experts are uncertain about the impact on resale values and new car prices, with some suggesting that the private-hire cars' lower specifications may not affect the brand's residual value.
