images.alt_text: Private-hire cars lying idle at Big Box in Jurong East; some of the popular models in the Uber fleet are the Honda Vezel, Mazda3, Toyota Prius, Mitsubishi Attrage and Toyota Corolla Altis.
Private-hire cars lying idle at Big Box in Jurong East; some of the popular models in the Uber fleet are the Honda Vezel, Mazda3, Toyota Prius, Mitsubishi Attrage and Toyota Corolla Altis.

site_title: Clearing airport security with your finger and iris scans
summary: Clear, a company using fingerprints and iris scans to verify identity, has been expanding airport security services, allowing passengers to bypass the document-verification checkpoint and reducing wait times. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) oversees and tests Clear's technology, which is certified by the Department of Homeland Security. Clear has over 1 million subscribers and operates in 24 airports, offering discounted memberships for frequent travelers and their spouses. The company aims to expand its services to other areas, such as store purchases and pharmaceutical prescriptions, with its biometric technology.

site_title: Cambodian opposition party to boycott vote on leader
summary: Cambodia's opposition party, the Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP), will boycott a parliamentary vote to strip their leader, Kem Sokha, of immunity, instead demanding his release from jail. The vote is set for Monday, but the CNRP claims it is illegal. Kem Sokha, accused of treason, has been in jail since his arrest a week ago. The ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) is expected to pass the motion, which has been criticized by Western countries. The CNRP's boycott is seen as a response to the government's crackdown on critics ahead of next year's general election.

site_title: Dishing out healthy food for a cause
summary: Greendot, a vegetarian eatery in Singapore, aims to promote healthy eating by offering non-vegetarian customers options. Founded in 2011 by Fu Yong Hong and Justin Chou, the business caters to a diverse customer base, including women, who make up 70% of its clientele. Greendot's menu is tailored to meet specific nutritional needs, such as higher iron content for women. The company's mission is to educate people on the importance of healthy eating and sustainability, citing Eric Schmidt's prediction of a future shift towards plant-based proteins.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Bahrain tightens Islamic finance rules with mandatory external audit
summary: Bahrain's central bank has announced a move to tighten Islamic finance rules, requiring all Islamic banks to undergo independent, external audits to certify compliance with Muslim laws known as Syariah. The move aims to increase transparency and reduce conflicts of interest. The audits will be conducted annually, starting in 2020, and will not be made publicly available. This decision is expected to make Bahrain a strict jurisdiction for Islamic banking, potentially adding momentum to global pressure for more centralized regulation of the industry. The move is seen as an example for the region and global Islamic banking market.

site_title: Gold very likely to retest the 2016 high of US$1,375
summary: Gold is likely to retest the 2016 high of US$1,375 due to rising tensions in the Korean Peninsula, which has led to a surge in safe-haven assets. Gold has broken its eight-year downtrend and breached its long-term resistance line, signaling a secular uptrend. The gold-S&P 500 spread has also triggered a buy signal, indicating a potential major trend change. Historically, the spread has signaled extreme risk-off environments, leading to mean reversion and major trend changes in gold. A similar pattern occurred in 2001, leading to a 550% appreciation in gold over 10 years, and a retest of the 2016 high of US$1,375 is expected.

site_title: UOB, HSBC join mortgage war with 3-year fixed-rate packages
summary: Banks in Singapore have launched three-year fixed-rate home-loan packages, joining DBS Bank, which had previously been the only provider. UOB and HSBC have introduced 1.68% fixed-rate packages, while Bank of China (BOC) offers varying yearly rates. The move is seen as a response to the recent drop in interest rates and is expected to benefit homebuyers, who can now choose from more competitive fixed-rate options. The total number of private homes sold in Q2 2017 reached 6,905, a 32.7% increase from the previous quarter.

site_title: Starburst's warrants deserve another look
summary: Starburst Holdings' warrants fell 10% on low volume, despite the company's shares rising 0.005 to S$0.44. The warrants, with an exercise price of S$0.25, are "in-the-money" by S$0.19, offering a small conversion discount of 3.9%. Given the company's average gearing and long expiry date in June 2021, the warrant's interest lies in its potential for traders to exploit illiquid trading. UOB-Kay Hian maintains a "trading buy" on the stock, citing new 52-week highs and increased trading volume.

site_title: Tanzania planning to nationalise diamonds valued at US$29.5m
summary: Tanzania plans to nationalise diamonds valued at US$29.5 million, seized from Williamson Diamonds Ltd, which exports to Antwerp, Belgium. The government accuses the miner of under-declaring mineral exports, with a valuation discrepancy of US$14.798 million to US$29.5 million. The move is part of a crackdown on the mining sector, which accounts for 4% of Tanzania's GDP, following allegations of irregularities and under-declared exports.

site_title: Egypt throws grain market into tizzy after poppy seeds found in wheat
summary: Egypt is considering rejecting 59,000 tonnes of French wheat due to the presence of poppy seeds, its second cargo to be scrutinized, amid concerns over the country's import policy. The decision follows a similar rejection of a Romanian cargo last month, raising uncertainty over Egypt's grain market. The rejection would further strain ties with France and exacerbate the ongoing row over Egypt's import requirements, which have been a source of tension since 2015.

site_title: AIA's new firm 'luring hundreds of rival agents'
summary: AIA Financial Advisers, a new firm set up by AIA, has lured about 300 experienced insurance agents from rival Great Eastern, the largest migration in recent years. Many of the agents, including the Chuan group, are reportedly underperforming at Great Eastern. AIA's FA arm has received "strong interest" from a wide range of candidates, including its own tied agents and professionals from the financial industry. AIA's CEO, Tan Chuan How, defended the firm's recruitment practices, saying they prioritize rewarding agents fairly based on their qualifications and productivity.

site_title: Fuel tankers plot routes to steer clear of monster Atlantic storms
summary: Traders are shifting fuel tankers globally to avoid natural disasters, including hurricanes and earthquakes, disrupting commodity flows. Four natural disasters in the western hemisphere have forced traders to change plans daily, making it difficult to determine optimal tanker routes. Tankers are being diverted to alternative destinations, such as Canada and the US, to take advantage of arbitrage opportunities, despite higher costs. The US waiver of the Jones Act has eased fuel supply to Florida after Hurricane Irma.

site_title: Airlines' sky-high fares for Irma evacuees trigger outrage
summary: Airlines have faced criticism for charging high fares to evacuees fleeing Hurricane Irma. US Senators Richard Blumenthal and Edward Markey have written to Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, requesting an investigation into possible price gouging. The move comes after a viral tweet highlighted the issue, sparking outrage among those trying to escape the storm.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF idea still a little funky, experts say
summary: US regulators will likely wait until the underlying cryptocurrency market matures before approving exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that provide exposure to cryptocurrencies like bitcoin. Despite strong demand, regulators cite concerns over price volatility, cybersecurity risks, and regulatory uncertainty. The SEC has already deemed tokens from initial coin offerings (ICOs) to be securities, subject to disclosure laws and regulatory scrutiny. Experts say proper regulation is necessary to pave the way for cryptocurrency-based ETFs, with some issuers receiving interest from prospective investors.

site_title: Flood of migrants causing tensions within European Union
summary: The European Union is facing tensions over its refugee relocation policy as some Eastern European members, including Hungary, Slovakia, Poland, and the Czech Republic, oppose the policy and want to control migrants entering their countries. Despite the EU's strict ruling on free movement, the court has ruled that member states have no legal grounds to reject resettlements. The UK's desire for immigration controls, fueled by Brexit negotiations, is contributing to the tensions. The EU has spent billions of euros trying to reduce refugee and migrant numbers, but the issue remains unresolved, with EU migration commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos warning that non-compliant member states could face court action.

site_title: Blockchain developers face off over US$1b in digital cash
summary: Two blockchain developers, R3 and Ripple Labs, are battling over more than $1 billion in virtual-currency options in a dispute that may establish the leading player in providing new payment technologies to financial companies. R3 sued Ripple in Delaware, accusing it of reneging on an options agreement for Ripple's XRP digital currency, while Ripple filed a suit in California accusing R3 officials of duping them on other agreements. The dispute highlights a break between the two companies, which were once partners in developing blockchain technology for financial institutions.

site_title: Apple out to renew iPhone frenzy at age 10
summary: Apple is set to unveil its new iPhones, seeking to recapture the magic from its first release 10 years ago. The tech giant is looking to refresh its product line and services to stay competitive. The unveiling event, held at Apple's new campus in Silicon Valley, marks a new era for the company. The move aims to revitalize the brand and attract new customers, particularly among younger generations.

site_title: Transformation reverses AEM's fortunes
summary: AEM Holdings, a Singapore-based semiconductor test handler, has transformed its fortunes after a dark past, with the company reporting robust earnings results for the first half of 2017. Chairman Loke Wai San, a managing director of private-equity firm Novo Tellus Capital Partners, led the transformation by focusing on the equipment business and investing in engineering, R&D, and supply chain. The company has invested over S$10 million to S$15 million in headcount and capital expenditure over the past five years. AEM is now targeting acquisitions of promising technology companies to enhance its capabilities and expand its solution offerings.

images.alt_text: AEM chairman Loke Wai San is a managing director of the technology buyout fund behind the transformation of AEM.

site_title: More room for HK's Octopus to extend its tentacles
summary: Hong Kong's Octopus Card Limited, a 20-year-old joint venture of public transport operators, is poised to extend its dominance in the city's cashless payments market. With over 99% of users relying on the card for daily transactions, Octopus is the closest to establishing a unified e-payment system. Critics argue that the company should focus on developing simpler payment solutions, better transaction security, and fewer hardware requirements, rather than replicating existing ideas.

site_title: Hurricane Irma makes landfall in Cuba as massive storm: US forecasters
summary: Hurricane Irma made landfall in Cuba as a Category Five storm, bringing maximum sustained winds of 260 km/h. The storm had previously devastated Caribbean islands and posed a threat to the US state of Florida. With its eye 300 miles south-southeast of Miami, the storm's trajectory and speed are expected to have significant implications for the region.

site_title: Europe's bank regulators on hunt for risk specialists before Brexit
summary: Europe's bank regulators are competing to hire risk specialists to prepare for banks escaping Brexit, with Germany's financial regulator Bafin and the French and Irish central banks seeking dozens of new recruits. However, filling these positions is difficult due to limited budgets and high demand for risk specialists, who can earn up to 400,000 pounds per year. The European Central Bank is also seeking new staff, but may be able to keep pace with its annual budget of over 400 million euros.

site_title: Vietnam's floating market struggles to stay afloat
summary: Vietnam's floating Cai Rang market is struggling to stay afloat due to modernity and economic growth, with many vendors giving up their boats for better lives on land. Once a thriving market with 550 boats, it now has about 300, with vendors like Nguyen Van Ut, who relies on handouts from his children, unable to afford a life on shore. The local government is trying to preserve the market's culture and attract tourists, but its future remains uncertain.

site_title: CVC 'mulls over first Mid-East deal' in hunt for new markets
summary: CVC Capital Partners, Europe's largest private-equity firm, is considering its first investment in the Middle East as it seeks to expand into new markets. The company is exploring potential targets including Al Fakher Tobacco Trading and education companies in the UAE. CVC's push into the region is led by Istvan Szoke, who is attracted by the region's young and growing population. The firm is also studying other potential transactions in the Middle East, following a sharp drop in oil prices and its impact on local economies.

site_title: Starbucks tempts lunch, dinner market with its sushi burrito
summary: Starbucks has introduced the sushi burrito, a "classic California burrito with a twist," to its Mercato lunch menu in Chicago and Seattle. The dish features cooked chicken, pickled cabbage, and avocado, wrapped in sushi rice and seaweed. Despite previous attempts at selling meals, analysts say Starbucks faces challenges in convincing customers to linger for a meal, given its lack of in-store kitchens. Food sales account for around 20% of Starbucks' revenue, with breakfast items being a notable exception, but lunch and dinner sales growth has plateaued due to competition.

site_title: New breast cancer drug data a boost for Eli Lilly
summary: Eli Lilly's new breast cancer drug, abemaciclib, has shown a 46% reduction in disease progression when added to standard therapy, comparable to rival drugs from Pfizer and Novartis. In a study, 59% of patients experienced significant tumour shrinkage, and the median progression-free survival was 14.7 months. Experts say the drug's efficacy is comparable to existing treatments and its continuous administration may offer advantages. The company forecasts $1.8 billion in annual sales by 2023, with potential benefits seen in patients with challenging metastases.

site_title: Merkel hopeful EU dispute over refugee issue will soon end
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed optimism that a EU dispute over refugee distribution will soon be resolved after a court ruled that member states must take in a share of refugees. Merkel welcomed the court's decision, citing the need for solidarity in dealing with the migration crisis. A compromise is emerging, linking accepting refugees to payments from the EU, with potential incentives and penalties for underperforming countries. The EU's highest court dismissed complaints by Slovakia and Hungary over mandatory quotas introduced in 2015. Merkel sees a resolution as crucial for EU cohesion.

site_title: Russia makes u-turn on cryptocurrencies after backing from Putin
summary: Russia is drawing up rules to regulate initial coin offerings (ICOs) after President Vladimir Putin signaled his approval for digital currencies. The Finance Ministry plans to regulate cryptocurrencies like securities, reversing a previous proposal to punish people who use them with up to seven years in jail. This move comes after Putin gave his blessing for Russia to develop blockchain technology, which has attracted investors and lenders. China, on the other hand, has banned ICOs and closed domestic cryptocurrency trading platforms.

site_title: Riyadh sides with Moscow as Syrian rebels lose favour
summary: Saudi Arabia appears to be aligning with Russia's efforts to maintain President Bashar al-Assad's power in Syria. The Saudis hosted talks with Syrian opposition factions, seeking a settlement that would leave Assad in place, and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov recently visited Saudi Arabia for talks. This shift marks a significant blow to Syrian rebels, who have seen Assad regain control of much of the country. The Saudi government still maintains that its long-term goal is a new future for Syria without Assad, but the talks suggest a willingness to work with Russia to achieve this goal.

site_title: Najib's US trip may affect 1MDB probe: activists
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's upcoming visit to the US may impact the country's 1MDB probe, with critics warning that President Trump's invitation could hinder US investigations. Najib is facing scrutiny over his handling of the state fund, which is being investigated in six countries for money-laundering and misappropriation of funds. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission has arrested dozens of officials, but the probe appears to have shut down, with the attorney-general declaring the case closed in 2016. Najib's visit is seen as an attempt to burnish his credentials before the 2018 election, with critics accusing him of using repressive laws to stifle critics.

site_title: Ivan Chua a popular player of the round
summary: Ivan Chua, a 46-year-old single-handicapper, shot a 4-over 76 at Warren Golf and Country Club, securing the best individual stableford score of 39 points and being named FJ Player of the Round. Chua's team, Team SunMoon, is in pole position in the Open Category with 441 points, five ahead of Tat Hong - The Crane Boomers, after five of six legs. Chua expressed his excitement about the tournament, which he has played in for five years, and his team's goal to win the A Category and the top prize in the Open Category next season.

images.alt_text: Ivan Chua (centre), the FJ Player of the Round, after receiving his trophy from FJ representative Sally Chua (right). On the left is Business Times News Editor Ven Sreenivasan.

site_title: Family's ranch buy ends up with more land than New York City
summary: A New York City family, the Boeddekers, purchased a ranch in Steamboat Springs, Colorado, in 1991 for an estimated "tens of millions" of dollars. The 200,000-acre property, Cross Mountain Ranch, features mountains, forests, rivers, and pastures, and was initially valued at over 81,000 hectares. The family improved and expanded the property over 25 years, adding structures and amenities, and is now selling the ranch for $100 million. The property, which includes a wildlife preserve, is being marketed as a rare opportunity to own a piece of land comparable in size to New York City.

site_title: More than a million without power as Irma slams into Florida
summary: Hurricane Irma made landfall in Florida, knocking out power to over 1 million homes and businesses with 130-mph winds. The Category 4 hurricane threatened catastrophic flooding on the state's Gulf Coast, particularly cities like Tampa and St. Petersburg. At least one life was claimed in the state, and officials evacuated 6.3 million people, but some chose to ride out the storm. The storm caused billions of dollars in damage and follows record-setting flooding from Hurricane Harvey.

images.alt_text: The rough waters where the Miami River meets Biscayne Bay shows the full effects of Hurricane Irma strike in Miami, Florida.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips as Irma heads towards Florida
summary: Wall Street dipped on Friday as investors braced for potential damage from Hurricane Irma moving towards Florida. The S&P 500 ended slightly lower, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.07% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.59%. The decline was driven by a drop in big tech names like Apple and Facebook.

site_title: China's August CPI rises 1.8%, PPI up 6.3%, both above forecasts
summary: China's August consumer inflation rate rose 1.8% from a year earlier, surpassing forecasts, marking the first uptick in three months. Producer price inflation also accelerated, rising 6.3% from 5.5% in July, the first increase in six months. The data suggests China's economic growth may be slowing, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Pregnant woman's suicide roils China
summary: A pregnant Chinese woman, Ma Rongrong, died by jumping from a hospital window after being denied a C-section, a common procedure in China. Her family and doctors have blamed each other for the decision, sparking a national discussion on healthcare costs, patients' rights, and traditional family values. The incident has raised questions about the balance between individual autonomy and family pressures, with some arguing that China's strict one-child policy and emphasis on traditional values contribute to the tragedy.

site_title: Hurricane delivers windfall to lucky high-ground owners
summary: Hurricane Harvey has led to a sudden housing shortage in Houston, with prices and rents expected to rise. Homeowners who were spared from flooding can now command higher prices for their properties, with some selling at asking prices. The city's affordable housing shortage has created a competitive market, with out-of-state investors and developers swooping in to acquire damaged homes. Experts predict that the housing market will remain hot, with a potential 3-4% price increase in the next three years, benefiting those who were not affected by the storm.

site_title: King of cool vs king of bling at NY Fashion Week
summary: Alexander Wang and Philipp Plein clashed at New York Fashion Week, showcasing their distinct styles. Wang's show in Brooklyn featured a bohemian, affordable aesthetic, while Plein's event in Manhattan was an extravagant, flesh-and-titillation spectacle. Wang's models, including Kaia Gerber and Kendall Jenner, walked the runway to a luxury bus, whereas Plein's show featured burlesque performances, topless models, and a live performance by rapper Future. Both designers aimed to create buzz, but their approaches differed, highlighting the contrasting visions of "cool" and "bling."

site_title: BOE divided between economic growth and heading off inflation
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep its benchmark rate at a record-low 0.25% due to sluggish consumer spending growth, but two policy makers may push for a rate increase to combat inflation, which accelerated to 2.8% in July. Nurses and other public sector workers are protesting due to stagnant wages, with the Royal College of Nursing arguing their salaries have dropped 14% in real terms over the past seven years. The BOE faces a trade-off between supporting economic growth and heading off inflation, with Governor Mark Carney watching pay developments closely.

site_title: India's first all-woman crew on around-the-globe mission
summary: India's first all-woman crew embarked on a historic around-the-world mission, starting from Goa, on September 9, 2017. Led by Lieutenant Commander Vartika Joshi, the six naval officers will circumnavigate the globe, visiting Australia, New Zealand, the Falkland islands, and South Africa. The mission aims to promote women in the navy and inspire others in the country, backed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The crew prepared for the voyage since 2014 and will return to Goa in March 2018, showcasing India's capabilities and strengths globally.

site_title: China bitcoin exchanges awaiting clarification on closure report
summary: China's Bitcoin exchanges are awaiting clarification on a reported plan to be shut down, following a media report that China will close local crypto-currency exchanges. Despite a ban on "initial coin offerings" earlier this week, analysts say this is a temporary setback. Spokespeople from OK Coin and Huobi, two major exchanges, stated they have not received any notification from regulators. Reuters was unable to verify the report, and the Chinese government has yet to confirm the closure plans.

site_title: Britain makes more funding available to help expand broadband
summary: Britain has made £645 million available to expand broadband to more remote locations, following higher-than-expected take-up of services. The funding will support the rollout of superfast broadband to 4.5 million premises, with 94% of UK homes and businesses already connected. The government aims to reach 95% by the end of the year, with the surplus funding to be reinvested in the program.

site_title: Tory Burch finds English joy to soothe troubled times
summary: Tory Burch showcased a bold and colorful collection at New York Fashion Week, aiming to bring joy and escapism to troubled times. Inspired by late English interior designer David Hicks, the collection featured a modern take on traditional English garden style. Burch emphasized the importance of finding joy in life despite current events, stating that her designs are about "joy and happiness." Other designers, including Kate Spade and GCDS, also presented collections that reflected a more relaxed and playful aesthetic.

site_title: French minister calls out Trump on climate change as Irma wreaks havoc
summary: French Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot criticized US President Donald Trump's stance on climate change, stating that extreme weather conditions like Hurricane Irma, which is affecting Florida, are becoming the norm. Trump has called global warming a hoax, despite most scientists regarding it as an established fact. Hulot implied that Trump's stance may change as more Americans are affected by climate-related disasters, and that it will be driven by federal states, cities, and society rather than the president.

site_title: Rohingya rebels call one-month Myanmar ceasefire as exodus grows
summary: Rohingya militants in Myanmar declared a one-month ceasefire, but the government rejected the offer, saying it would not negotiate with "terrorists." Nearly 300,000 Rohingya refugees have fled to Bangladesh since August 25, when militants attacked Myanmar security forces, leading to a major military backlash. Bangladesh's foreign minister described the situation as "genocide" in Rakhine state, where tens of thousands of Rohingya are on the move without shelter, food, and water. The ceasefire, which ends on October 9, urged humanitarian aid delivery to all victims, regardless of background.

site_title: Uber acknowledges FBI probe into software tool
summary: Uber acknowledged a federal investigation into a software tool called "Hell" that allegedly interfered with rival ride-sharing operator Lyft. The tool, used to track drivers and create fake accounts, is no longer in use. Uber is cooperating with the investigation, which also resulted in a civil lawsuit filed by a Lyft driver being dismissed. This latest probe adds to Uber's woes, following the recent replacement of its top executive to address workplace culture issues.

site_title: Fire at ASL Marine's Batam shipyard kills five and injures one
summary: A fire at ASL Marine's shipyard in Batam, Indonesia on September 7, 2017, killed five people and injured one, with the cause of the fire currently under investigation. The fire occurred in a tanker being repaired at the dock and was confined to the pump room. Initial investigations suggest there was no explosion. ASL Marine is cooperating with authorities and has suspended work on the vessel until the cause is established.

site_title: Bain, SK Hynix group ups bid for Toshiba chip unit to 2.4t yen
summary: A consortium led by US private equity group Bain Capital and South Korea's SK Hynix has raised its offer for Toshiba's chip business to 2.4 trillion yen (S$29.66 billion), including a 200 billion yen investment in infrastructure. The offer surpasses the initial bid of around 1.94 trillion yen. Toshiba is seeking to sell the unit to cover billions of liabilities at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse. The consortium's proposal includes a 49.9% stake in the memory chip business, with Toshiba retaining 40% and Japanese firms holding 10.1%. Toshiba's board is set to meet on Wednesday to consider the offers.

site_title: New Cayenne: How Porsche is changing its gameplan
summary: Porsche unveiled the third-generation Cayenne SUV, balancing performance with environmentalism. The new model features a 3.0-litre, V6 turbocharged engine, delivering improved fuel efficiency and lower emissions. The Cayenne will likely discontinue diesel power and introduce plug-in hybrid variants, including a possible electric Cayenne Coupe. Porsche chairman Oliver Blume emphasized the company's commitment to electrification, citing a "surprising" benefit from its plug-in hybrid strategy.

site_title: Fine dining
summary: UnionPay International has launched the U Collection, a global dining privilege programme offering exclusive benefits to Platinum and Diamond cardholders. The programme includes reservations at over 80 highly-acclaimed restaurants, including two-Michelin-starred Restaurant Andre, and features perks such as complimentary wine and greetings from chefs or managers. Cardholders can make reservations by calling the UnionPay concierge hotline.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: New South Park game gets harder based on skin colour
summary: The makers of South Park have released a game, "South Park: The Fractured But Whole," which adjusts difficulty levels based on the skin color of the player's character. Journalists played a preview and uploaded a video to YouTube, showcasing the feature. The game allows players to customize their avatar's appearance, including skin color, before starting the game. The feature has sparked controversy and discussion about representation in gaming.

site_title: US Congress approves hurricane relief, debt ceiling hike
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a $15 billion hurricane relief package, raising the debt ceiling and funding the government until early December. The bill, which includes $7.85 billion for Hurricane Harvey relief, passed 316-90 with all 90 opposing Republicans. The Senate had already passed the measure, and President Trump is expected to sign it, extending US borrowing authority and freeing up emergency relief funding just as Hurricane Irma approaches Florida.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says it's Brexit, not BOE, moving UK assets most
summary: Goldman Sachs finds that Brexit matters more than the Bank of England's monetary policy in trading UK assets, with 10 Brexit-related news events accounting for 50% of sterling moves since the vote. The investment bank's strategists believe the market's response to Brexit politics extends beyond exchange rates to impact domestic demand and foreign investor confidence. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold until the end of 2018, despite a weakening pound. This cautious approach suggests a mildly hawkish direction for the central bank's communications.

site_title: Audi Q2 1.0 review: An Audi SUV for S$141k
summary: The Audi Q2 1.0 is a compact SUV priced at S$141,091, making it a budget-friendly option for young buyers. Despite its tiny 1.0-liter engine, the car offers a balance of fun and practicality, with a posh cabin and precise handling. The Q2 strikes a balance between Audi's prestige and mass-market affordability, making it a viable alternative to cheaper Audis like the A3 and A1 Sportback.

site_title: Ex-VP jailed 14 years for money laundering, cheating
summary: Former Singapore asset management vice-president Linda Lee was jailed for 14 years for money laundering and cheating, involving over S$10 million. Lee, 39, had colluded with several individuals to provide fake quotes for maintenance works, totaling more than S$5 million in personal gains. Several bank accounts, insurance policies, and luxury items were seized, with about S$2.1 million potentially recoverable. The court deemed Lee's offences serious and large, resulting in a severe sentence.

site_title: Lady Gaga says taking a break after fifth album tour
summary: Lady Gaga announced at a press conference that she plans to take a break after her current Joanne World Tour ends in mid-December. The 30-year-old music star stated she will rest and reflect on her decade-long career, citing chronic pain and the rigors of touring as reasons for her decision. She expressed her desire to slow down, heal, and continue creating without revealing specific plans.

images.alt_text: Lady Gaga said Friday she plans to take a break after her current Joanne World Tour ends in mid-December.

site_title: Timeless appeal
summary: The Cartier Tank watch turns 100, celebrating its timeless appeal and universal popularity. Introduced in 1917, the watch was designed by Louis Cartier to be both functional and elegant, pioneering the wristwatch concept and Art Deco style. Iconic wearers include Princess Diana, Madonna, and Rudolf Valentino, with the watch's minimalist design and iconic elements such as Roman numerals, chemins de fer, and brancards making it a symbol of understated style and elegance. The Cartier Tank has stood the test of time, remaining a popular choice for generations.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Football: Pele delighted by Neymar's PSG switch
summary: Brazilian legend Pele expressed his support for Neymar's move from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain, calling it an opportunity for his compatriot to "be the big star". Pele praised Neymar's skills, stating that he is one of the best in his position, but noted that he can't match Lionel Messi's organizational skills. Neymar joined PSG in a world-record transfer worth 222 million euros, leaving the shadow of his former Barcelona teammate. Pele believes Neymar will thrive in his new role and become the main star.

site_title: Superb playback that doesn't break the bank
summary: A high-end turntable, the EAT B-Sharp, offers superb playback at an affordable price, with features such as a high-tech suspension system and a carbon fibre alloy tonearm. This model is available for $1,990 and competes with more expensive alternatives. Meanwhile, jazz musician Christian Scott's album "Ruler Rebel" is set to make a mark, blending trap music, New Orleans jazz-funk, and Native American influences, and is part of his Centennial Trilogy series, which addresses societal issues affecting the African-American population.

site_title: A bad week for greenback as Singdollar rises to 15-month high
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has reached a 15-month high against the US dollar, trading at 1.3371, due to skepticism over further interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve and ongoing geo-political worries. The SGD has risen 8.2% year-to-date, while the US dollar has fallen almost every month since January. Safe-haven currencies such as the Japanese yen and Chinese yuan are also experiencing weakness. Market experts predict a possible technical rebound in USD/SGD, but some believe the USD's weakness is overdone and expect a continued rise in the SGD.

site_title: Mnuchin ripped by House GOP on sales job for debt limit deal
summary: Conservative House Republicans criticized Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin for his sales pitch for a debt limit deal, with some calling his comments "intellectually insulting" and "not one of my constituents." The deal, which includes a short-term extension of the federal debt limit, was passed by the House and Senate and now awaits President Donald Trump's signature. Republicans also mocked White House budget director Mick Mulvaney, who previously opposed the debt limit, for pleading with them to pass the measure. The bill provides hurricane relief and aid to flood victims in Texas and other parts of the Gulf coast.

site_title: PBOC is said to remove reserve rule for FX forwards trading
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to remove a reserve requirement for trading foreign currency forwards, effective September 11. This move aims to slow the pace of yuan appreciation, which has surged over 5% in the past three months. The current 20% reserve ratio will be lifted, making it easier for traders to buy US dollars, reducing pressure on the yuan. The decision is seen as a signal from the authorities that they are uncomfortable with the rapid appreciation and may intervene to prevent damage to exports.

site_title: Work-life balance
summary: Hotel Jen Beijing, operated by Shangri-La, offers a unique work-life balance experience with its 450-room property. The hotel features a co-working space, a brew-your-own beer pub, and a 24-hour gym that transforms into a club-like environment at night. Guests can enjoy spacious rooms with city views and take advantage of a Lifestyle Room Package from RMB1,388 per night, which includes unlimited access to the co-working space, beer tastings, and late check-out. The package is available until the end of December.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Now there's a fast Mercedes for everyone
summary: Mercedes-AMG, the high-performance division of Mercedes-Benz, is celebrating its 50th anniversary, showcasing its powerful cars with exceptional handling and speed. The brand's latest models, such as the E 63 S and C 43 4Matic, offer impressive performance at a lower price point, making them more accessible to enthusiasts. With a record-breaking year in 2016 and a growing fan base, AMG is expanding its product lineup to include less powerful but more affordable models, further increasing its appeal to driving enthusiasts.

site_title: Young Chinese immigrants fuelling HK's home shortage
summary: Young Chinese immigrants are exacerbating Hong Kong's housing shortage, with mainland graduates potentially boosting demand by 4,000 units per year. This compares to 25,500 private residential units completed in 2016. To address the issue, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has targeted mortgage borrowers with foreign income, while the government has pledged to offer subsidized flats to first-home buyers. The influx of young, affluent mainlanders, many of whom have parents willing to provide downpayments, is driving up housing prices and fueling the shortage.

site_title: Merkel warned that failure to hit climate goal may hurt Germany
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's climate goals for Germany may be at risk of being missed. Researchers at Agora Energiewende predict that Germany will reduce carbon dioxide emissions by about 30% by 2020, falling short of the 40% target set in 2012. This is despite a July survey showing that over seven out of 10 Germans are concerned about climate change. The Environment Ministry has rejected the forecast, estimating a 37% reduction in emissions. Merkel is seeking a fourth term as chancellor after this month's federal election, which has seen climate protection getting short shrift in campaigning.

site_title: Trading in Trek 2000 to resume on Sept 11
summary: Trek 2000 International shares will resume trading on September 11 after a moratorium, with CEO Henn Tan, former executive director Poo Teng Pin, and former CFO Gurcharan Singh agreeing to observe the moratorium. The company is undergoing a review by forensic accountant RSM Corporate Advisory into potential round-tripping transactions between 2008 and 2016. Preliminary calculations suggest $1.85 million in overstated sales and $272,615 in understated profits. The review will also examine other transactions and discrepancies.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US formally requests UN vote Monday on North Korea
summary: The US has formally requested a UN Security Council vote on Monday to impose new sanctions on North Korea, including an oil embargo and a ban on textiles. The proposed resolution also calls for an assets freeze on Kim Jong Un and an end to payments of North Korean guest workers. However, resistance from China and Russia may hinder the outcome. The US has presented the draft resolution to the council, but its fate remains uncertain.

site_title: Finnish your meal
summary: Finnish design house Marimekko collaborates with Equilibrium restaurant in Singapore to celebrate Finland's 100th anniversary. The restaurant offers two special menus combining Nordic and Mediterranean cuisine, featuring dishes like beetroot salad and cabbage rolls. Marimekko decorates the restaurant with its unique prints and home accessories, inspired by its new Home Fall/Winter 2017 collection. The collaboration is available for reservations at equilibrium.sg/marimekko.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand invests S$300m in Indonesia's largest economy, with its first integrated development, The Stature Jakarta, set to be completed in 2020. Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation is expected to benefit from datacentre demand with its DC development strategy. CWT Limited has accepted an offer from HNA Holding Group, with sufficient financial resources available to fund the acquisition. OCBC Research has upgraded its target price for CapitaLand and Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation.

site_title: Feeling giddy - should you be worried?
summary: Dizziness, vertigo, and imbalance can severely affect a person's quality of life, particularly in the elderly, who are at increased risk of falls. These conditions are caused by issues with the vestibular system, which coordinates balance and spatial orientation. Treatment options include specialized physiotherapy, oral medications, eardrum injections, and surgery, and may also involve addressing underlying cardiovascular or eye problems. A comprehensive check-up with an ENT specialist, cardiologist, and eye specialist is essential for proper diagnosis and treatment.

site_title: US job satisfaction is up, but still far off previous peaks
summary: US job satisfaction has increased to 50.8% for the first time in over a decade, according to a survey by the Conference Board. This uptick is attributed to an improved labor market in recovery mode for years. However, job satisfaction remains below pre-1987 and 1995 levels, with factors such as income inequality and the erosion of the social contract between workers and companies contributing to the decline. Experts speculate that satisfaction may not return to previous peaks, citing fundamental changes in the US workforce.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, is reviewing its financial position and capital structure with bank lenders to consider a consensual restructuring. The High Court has ordered the winding up of Sakae Holdings Ltd's associate company Gryphon Capital Management by consent, with appointed liquidators investigating the company's affairs. Chinese conglomerate HNA Holding Group has made a formal offer to privatize CWT Limited for S$1.4 billion. United Food Holdings' executive director and CEO, Wang Tingbao, has resigned, effective immediately.

site_title: Design cycle
summary: Lifestyle retailer Naiise is partnering with oBike Singapore for Design Circuit, a one-day cycling event on September 9. The event combines design and cycling, featuring a 2km trail with 10 pit stops, including design studios and lifestyle stores. The first 10 participants to complete the trail will receive a S$50 Naiise gift card. Tickets are priced from S$15 per person and can be purchased from Naiise's website. The event runs from 3pm to 9pm, providing a unique experience for participants.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Mercedes-AMG E 43 review: A twist in the tail
summary: The Mercedes-AMG E 43 Estate boasts a high-performance makeover, featuring a Formula One-inspired nano-coated engine, aggressive styling, and exceptional handling. With a 401-hp twin-turbo V6 engine, the E 43 accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 4.7 seconds and boasts a limited top speed of 250 km/h. Its refined interior and subtle performance cues cater to driving enthusiasts, offering a unique blend of power and subtlety.

site_title: Fosun's booster shot rejuvenates Club Med's growth plans
summary: Club Med is accelerating its expansion in China with plans to develop 20 resorts by 2021, following a financial booster shot from Chinese conglomerate Fosun Group. The group, owned by Franco-Chinese owners, will give a "total face-lift" to its holiday resort chain. This move aims to rejuvenate the company's growth plans in the Chinese market.

site_title: King of cashmere
summary: Brunello Cucinelli, founder of the luxury cashmere brand, found his fortune in the 1970s by spotting the potential of cashmere. He specialized in cashmere to enhance its quality and longevity, believing in the value of focusing on one product. Cucinelli's business is driven by an altruistic spirit, prioritizing human values and environmental sustainability. His company, now public, has grown while maintaining a unique approach, including a beautiful workspace and 100% locally sourced materials. Cucinelli defines luxury as high-quality craftsmanship and sustainability, inspiring other brands to follow his egalitarian model.

site_title: This time, it's different
summary: Financial markets ended August with a 0.1% decline in the MSCI AC World index, despite initial geopolitical concerns. Global bonds saw a 0.4% return, outperforming the simple benchmark. The portfolio delivered an 11.5% return, trailing the simple benchmark's 12.3%. The decision to be more defensive in fixed income and US equity products led to underperformance. Asian and emerging markets equity funds were the best performers, while developed markets and high yield space losses detracted from overall returns.

site_title: The future of retail
summary: Singapore's luxury retail sector is thriving, with malls such as The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands and ION Orchard experiencing significant growth. Despite the rise of online shopping, brick-and-mortar stores remain profitable due to the value of human interaction and personalized experiences. Technology can enhance the shopping experience, but it cannot replicate the benefits of in-store interactions. Retailers are adapting by incorporating technology into their marketing strategies, offering augmented reality experiences, and creating unique experiential elements in-store. Successful malls and retailers are "future-proofing" by investing in innovations in retail technology to stay ahead of the competition.

site_title: Apple-backed Foxconn Group eyeing Toshiba's chips business
summary: Foxconn Technology Group, backed by Apple, is making a last-ditch effort to acquire Toshiba's memory chips business for 2.1 trillion yen (S$26 billion). The bid faces rival offers from Bain Capital and KKR & Co, with Foxconn claiming "deal certainty" and promising to provide funds for Toshiba's R&D. Toshiba, however, is still negotiating with three groups and has faced opposition from the Japanese government due to Foxconn's close ties to China. The bid must be finalized by March to avoid Toshiba's delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Czech Catholic Church branches out into forestry
summary: The Czech Catholic Church, now the country's largest private landowner, is investing in the forestry industry to ensure its long-term financial future. The church received US$4 billion in compensation for its property seized under Communism, including 140,000 hectares of woodland. However, managing these holdings poses challenges, such as labor shortages and pressure to make profits. The church aims to operate sustainably, focusing on forests that will be profitable in decades to come. This business venture is seen as a way for the church to maintain its economic freedom and responsibility.

site_title: STI sheds 1.5% on North Korea and US debt ceiling worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.5% for the week due to concerns over North Korea's nuclear test and the US debt ceiling. However, US President Donald Trump's deal to raise the debt limit and fund the government through December 8 helped stabilize markets. The STI recorded a net gain of half a point on Friday, but ultimately ended the week with a loss. Banking stocks drove the market, with banks being the main index drivers.

site_title: Eight of the best ready to battle it out in Singapore
summary: The WTA Finals in Singapore is just 43 days away, with eight singles players competing for the US$7 million tournament. The top contenders include Garbine Muguruza, Simona Halep, and Elina Svitolina, who are vying for a spot in the top 8. Muguruza, the reigning Wimbledon champion, is the favorite to qualify after becoming the new world No 1. The other top players, including Venus Williams, Caroline Wozniacki, and Johanna Konta, also have a chance to make it to the tournament, but need to accumulate enough ranking points in the next six weeks.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: NY landlords who can't find buyers turn to borrowing instead
summary: Manhattan landlords are turning to borrowing to cash in on their properties as the commercial property market slows, with transactions in the first half of the year tumbling 50% from 2016. Investors are ploughing into real estate loans as an alternative to lower-yielding bonds, giving building owners another option to refinance instead of finding buyers. This trend is driven by a chasm between buyer offers and seller valuations, with debt markets booming while the sales market seeks price discovery.

site_title: When Trump put ice on Zuckerberg's glacier tour
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration curtailed a planned visit to Glacier National Park by Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, citing concerns over the "publicity" generated by the event. The visit aimed to raise awareness about climate change, but Trump officials, including Interior Press Secretary Heather Swift, questioned the use of government resources for a "celebrity's PR tour." The visit was eventually reduced to a two-hour, five-person delegation, including Zuckerberg's dog, Gracie, and was not promoted on the National Park Service's social media accounts.

site_title: Game over - not
summary: HBO releases a behind-the-scenes series, "The Game Revealed," offering insights into the filming of Season 7's biggest scenes from Game of Thrones. The seven-episode series is available on HBO Asia's Facebook page and HBO On Demand starting every Friday.

site_title: Wanted: North American city to house Amazon's second HQ
summary: Amazon is seeking proposals from North American cities to house its second US$5 billion headquarters, known as Amazon HQ2, which plans to hire up to 50,000 full-time workers. The company is focusing on metropolitan areas with over 1 million people and is considering factors such as tax incentives, workforce training, and business-friendly environments. Experts believe the decision is as much about politics as logistics, with Toronto and other cities potentially emerging as top contenders due to their business-friendly environments and ease of hiring foreign workers.

site_title: Cromwell Reit eyes 7.5-7.7% yield in 1.25b euro Singapore IPO
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is set to raise up to 1.25 billion euros through its euro-denominated IPO in Singapore, offering a yield of 7.5-7.7% based on a forecast distribution per unit of 4.23-4.27 euro cents in 2018. The Reit, which holds commercial, industrial, and retail properties in six European countries, aims to acquire its portfolio with proceeds from the IPO, sponsor, and cornerstone offerings. The IPO is targeted for September 21, with listing set for September 28.

site_title: Investors should hedge risks, be market-selective in Q4: DBS
summary: DBS has advised investors to hedge risks and be market-selective in Q4 due to escalating tensions over North Korea and accelerating US rate hikes. The bank's Asia equity strategy report notes Asian markets leave little room for tail risk events. Banking and property sectors are expected to drive Singapore's index performance.

site_title: Many Sides of Bukit Timah
summary: Bukit Timah, a central Singapore district, boasts a mix of natural beauty, historical significance, and nostalgic charm. The area is known for its high density of private property and expensive real estate, but also features unique attractions like the "Antique Row," a row of antique shops, and The Grandstand, a former racecourse turned family lifestyle destination. Other notable sites include the Former Ford Factory, a national monument that served as a Japanese surrender site during WWII, and the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, a primary rainforest reserve.

site_title: The fall/winter 2017 shopping list
summary: This fall/winter 2017 shopping list highlights 22 key fashion trends. Corduroy is making a comeback, while Granny cardigans get a new twist with embellishments. Velvet suits, retro bags, and talisman-inspired necklaces are also on the radar. Other notable trends include oversized hats, shell-inspired clothing, and luxurious denim. The season also sees a resurgence of double-breasted blazers, detachable sleeves, and luxury hoodies. To stay stylish, consider investing in key boots, baggy trousers, and statement accessories like feathers and check patterns.

site_title: Markets don't really care who the president is
summary: US economists Justin Wolfers and Eric Zitzewitz analyzed the stock market's reaction to the 2016 presidential election, predicting a 8-10% drop if Donald Trump won. However, the actual outcome saw a brief decline followed by a 1% recovery. Since Trump's presidency, US stocks have risen double digits with minimal volatility. The article contrasts this with the current market trends in Asia, where dollar asset diversification is expected to drive growth.

site_title: China's export growth slows in August but imports pick up
summary: China's export growth slowed to 5.5% year-over-year in August, below forecasts, due to weak global demand. However, imports increased 13.3% year-over-year, beating expectations, indicating a domestic pick-up. The strong import figures suggest a shift in China's growth model from exports to domestic consumption. Analysts attribute the surge in imports to higher industrial metal prices and domestic demand momentum. The data follows recent positive readings and a rise in China's foreign-exchange reserves, indicating a potential recalibration of the country's growth model.

images.alt_text: China's exports increased 5.5 per cent year on year in August, down from 7.2 per cent in July. Imports climbed 13.3 per cent last month, against July's 11 per cent.

site_title: Exodus of Rohingya to Bangladesh tops quarter of a million - UNHCR
summary: A surge of 270,000 Rohingya refugees has fled to Bangladesh over the past two weeks, surpassing the quarter of a million mark, according to the UNHCR. The refugees, many of whom are sick or wounded, have strained aid agencies and communities already helping hundreds of thousands displaced by violence in Myanmar. Satellite images show widespread destruction of Rohingya homes and civilian deaths in Myanmar, with fears of a humanitarian crisis unfolding in the north of Rakhine State. The international community has called for urgent action to address the situation, with several countries, including Malaysia and the US, proposing solutions to the crisis.

site_title: US:Wall Street opens lower as hurricane Irma powers toward Florida
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, September 8, 2017, due to concerns over hurricane Irma's impact on Florida. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.17%, the S&P 500 lost 0.19%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.12%. Investors were also assessing the financial impact of hurricane Harvey.

site_title: Fullerton unit secures private fund management licence in China
summary: Fullerton Fund Management's unit has secured a private fund management licence in China, enabling it to offer onshore investment products to institutional and high net worth investors. This is the first time an Asian fund has successfully registered as a private fund management company in China. Fullerton plans to further invest in its local office and grow its team, with assets under management of S$17 billion. The company aims to expand its presence in the regional asset management industry, particularly in China, which is seen as a long-term growth and investment potential.

site_title: Beijing backlanes
summary: Beijing's historic hutongs, narrow alleys that date back centuries, are facing gentrification as the Chinese government announces the shutdown of 2435 hutongs by 2019 and plans to remodel another 500 annually from 2014 to 2019. While some are being preserved, others are being transformed into modern business and technology hubs, sparking controversy and creativity among affected tenants. Despite gentrification, some businesses are embracing the changes, preserving traditional culture and charm, and others are adapting to the new era.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Vision of success
summary: Ermenegildo Zegna continues its alternative advertising approach with a new campaign "Defining Moments" featuring Hollywood legend Robert De Niro and choreographer Benjamin Millepied. The documentary-style campaign focuses on conversations about their life, career, and defining moments, without mentioning the brand or products. Zegna's CEO Gildo Zegna sees this direction as a way to meet customer expectations and remain competitive in a changing market. The campaign marks a shift towards a more personal and conversational approach to advertising, highlighting the brand's ability to tell a good story.

site_title: Romance under the stars
summary: Singapore Dance Theatre's annual outdoor dance event, Ballet Under The Stars, returns with a romantic edition featuring three classical dance excerpts: Coppélia Act III, Aurora's Wedding from Sleeping Beauty, and Don Quixote Act III. The event runs at Fort Canning Park until September 10, with tickets available from Sistic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Prada's first-half profits fall 18%
summary: Prada's first-half profits fell 18.4% due to declining sales in key markets such as the US, Europe, and Japan. The company's net profit for the first six months of 2017 was 115.7 million euros, down from 141.9 million euros a year earlier. Prada is trying to turn itself around by slimming down its retail network and offering more accessible products to compete with rising competition from new brands and established rivals.

site_title: Town & country
summary: Bienvenue, a Parisian hotel, features two distinct buildings with unique styles. The 32 Art Deco rooms in "Town" have smooth monochrome color palettes and handmade headboards, while the eight "Countryside" rooms have floral prints and daisy-shaped taps. The hotel's central courtyard features artist Julien Colombier's floor motif and serves as a highlight. Baker Anaïs Olmer offers signature wacky cakes at the ground-floor bar and restaurant.

site_title: Loyz Energy forms venture to get into fund management, investments, trading
summary: Loyz Energy Limited has formed a joint venture with Arctos Investments to diversify into fund management, investments, and trading. The venture, FIT Global, will be owned 40% by Loyz Energy and 60% by Arctos. Loyz Energy will contribute $1 million in cash, while Arctos will contribute its network and expertise. The company aims to augment its income and cash flows, and expects the new venture to diversify its revenue stream and reduce its dependence on oil and gas assets.

site_title: Keppel Group scores high in sustainable practices
summary: Keppel Group has achieved international recognition for its sustainability efforts, ranking in top indices for five consecutive years. Keppel Corporation is listed in the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices Asia Pacific Index, while Keppel Land topped the Global/Developer/Residential and Asia/Developer categories in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) 2017. Keppel Reit ranked second among listed office entities in Asia and third among 52 Asian listed companies. The company's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, praised the recognition, stating that sustainability is at the heart of Keppel's strategy and operations.

site_title: 'Window closing' for Americans to escape Hurricane Irma's fury
summary: Hurricane Irma, a Category 4 storm with winds of 240 km/h, is expected to make landfall in south Florida late on Saturday, posing a significant threat to the state and southeastern US. Over 1 million people are under mandatory evacuation orders, and officials warn of widespread power outages and potential devastation. The storm has already caused destruction in the Caribbean, killing at least 17 people, and is forecast to bring six-metre storm surges to the Florida Keys before moving northwards up the peninsula.

site_title: Bold start
summary: Two new Mod Asian restaurants have opened in Singapore, aiming to break new ground with their original dining concepts. Chef David Lee and Ace Tan's Restaurant Ards, set to open on September 15, will feature Asian-style dishes created from scratch, including Mum's Chicken Soup and The Seas of Asia. Meanwhile, Toh Kok Jin's Coalesce, opened four weeks ago, offers Singapore-centric cuisine combining elements from various cultures, such as Indian flavors with Australian fish. Ah Hua Kelong's Scaled by Ah Hua Kelong restaurant, launched two months ago, showcases fresh seafood cooked in simple yet flavorful ways, with dishes like Fresh Crispy Squid and Confit Seabass.

site_title: Volvo XC60 review: Not your dad's Volvo
summary: Volvo's new XC60 SUV offers a sleek appearance and packs features from the larger XC90 at a lower price. The mid-sized SUV faces competition from Audi Q5, BMW X3, and others, but its design and safety features set it apart. The XC60 boasts a comfortable ride, advanced technology, and a powerful engine, but its driving dynamics are not class-leading. The XC60 T6 R-Design model tested was found to be fast but vocal, with a disconnected feel in steering. It's not a driver's car, but excels in other areas, making it a suitable choice for those seeking an affordable and feature-packed SUV.

site_title: 'Hungry ghosts' not dampening GCB interest
summary: Good Class Bungalow (GCB) sales are seeing a surge in interest, despite the "hungry ghosts" month being traditionally quiet. KH Tan, a GCB agent, reports increased offers from Chinese citizens who have become Singaporeans and homegrown developers. Notably, Simon Israel recently sold his Caldecott Hill bungalow for S$25.6m to Dymon Asia Capital co-founder. The increased demand is attributed to the growing pool of eligible buyers in the GCB market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Objects of desire
summary: The Artling, an online art gallery, is hosting its third pop-up show featuring emerging artists under 40 from seven Asian countries, including Malaysia, South Korea, and China, at Artspace@Helutrans from Sept 8 to 17. The show highlights the international relevance of these artists, with participating galleries including FOST, Gajah Gallery, and Pearl Lam Galleries. This event aims to promote the work of promising Asian artists and their contributions to the global art scene.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Local brands, design talent set for boost from new initiatives
summary: Singapore is launching initiatives to boost local brands and retailers, who face a challenging retail environment. A design incubator, operated by Naiise, will open at Orchard Road next year, featuring over 60 local brands. The incubator will serve as a retail showcase and incubation space, supporting local talent in fashion, lifestyle products, and souvenirs.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US wholesale inventories revised higher in July
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.6% in July, matching the previous two months, driven by gains in auto and durable goods inventories. Auto inventories increased 0.2% and durable goods inventories rose 0.9%, with machinery and electrical equipment seeing significant increases. Sales at wholesalers slipped 0.1%, while motor vehicles sales declined 0.8%. The inventories-to-sales ratio for motor vehicles rose to 1.80 months, indicating a potential inventory glut.

site_title: Volvo Car to buy Luxe assets to boost digital services
summary: Volvo Car Group, owned by Geely, plans to acquire Luxe's assets to enhance its digital services. The deal will help Volvo advance its algorithms for routing, logistics, and arrival time predictions. This technology will aid in offering digital customer experiences, such as pick-up and drop-off services. The acquisition is expected to boost Volvo's digital capabilities and accelerate its customer experience offerings.

site_title: Dubai hotel owner, Viceroy group mired in multiple lawsuits
summary: The Viceroy Group, owner of a $1 billion luxury hotel in Dubai, is facing multiple lawsuits after firing its management company, Five Holdings, just three months after opening. The management company has threatened potential visitors with imprisonment, claiming the hotel owner is trying to scare them off. The incident has raised concerns about the hotel's reputation and occupancy rates.

site_title: UK manufacturing jumps, construction falls as quarter starts
summary: The UK economy started the third quarter with a mixed performance, with manufacturing output rising 0.5% in July for the first time this year, boosted by a strong rebound in car production. However, construction output fell 0.9% for a fourth consecutive month due to a plunge in new orders. The trade deficit remained at £2.9 billion, and the dominant services industry continues to lose momentum, despite weak pound boosting exports over the past year.

site_title: New Japanese robot dog sniffs out smelly feet
summary: A Japanese start-up, Next Technology, has developed a robot dog named Hana-chan that can sniff out smelly feet and provide an honest verdict. The robot dog, equipped with an odor detection sensor, can detect moderately whiffy toes and faint if the stink is particularly pungent. It also sprays air freshener to resolve the situation. The device is designed to address a common issue in Japan where removing shoes at home is a social norm. The robot dog will be sold for over $1,200 next year, with the goal of providing a discreet and honest solution to foot odor problems.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares closed lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 3.08 points to 1,779.90, down 0.17%. Trading volume reached 2.97 billion lots valued at RM2.27 billion.

site_title: Florida insurers tumbling on fears of hurricane Irma damage
summary: Florida insurers plummeted 14% on Thursday as Hurricane Irma continues to threaten Miami, with Universal Insurance Holdings Inc sinking the most. The insurers, including Heritage Insurance Holdings Inc, Federated National Holding Co, and HCI Group Inc, owe their market presence to past hurricane losses, which led national carriers to retreat from coastal regions. Reinsurance coverage is expected to help mitigate losses, but analysts warn the sell-off may be overdone. The US National Hurricane Center has posted hurricane watches for Florida and the Florida Keys, with Irma's chances of a direct hit increasing.

site_title: Temasek-backed startup Adyen targets Asian payments expansion
summary: Temasek-backed payments startup Adyen is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region, aiming to double its Singapore workforce to 70 in the next 12 months. The company plans to increase its revenue from 10% to 30% in the region, driven by the growing adoption of e-commerce and mobile devices. Adyen is targeting larger companies in the region, including Grab, and has unveiled infrastructure connecting businesses to Visa and MasterCard in Singapore. The company's expansion is part of a broader trend of payments tech providers betting on Southeast Asia's growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Pentagon's mysterious spacecraft punches above its weight
summary: The US Air Force has launched the X-37B, a mysterious space drone, on a 270-day mission to test emerging space technologies and demonstrate rapid space access. The X-37B, a reusable spacecraft, has spent nearly six years in orbit, and its primary objectives include carrying small satellites and testing experimental electronics. The launch marks the first time SpaceX has been chosen to launch for the Air Force, and comes as the Pentagon emphasizes the importance of defending space in the event of war. The mission's success highlights the growing significance of space in military operations.

site_title: Executive director and CEO of United Food Holdings resigns
summary: United Food Holdings' executive director and CEO Wang Tingbao has resigned, effective Friday. The board expressed gratitude for his "clear leadership, direction, and invaluable contributions" to the company. No reason for the resignation was provided.

site_title: Razer's first shave at cashless raises bumps
summary: Razer has proposed a cashless payment system in Singapore, aiming to advance the country to a cashless society within 18 months. The company has committed S$10 million in seed funding and plans to hire Singaporeans to join the e-payment startup. Razer's proposal focuses on building an open framework for interoperability among different payment systems, addressing the issue of closed-loop systems that hinder consumer convenience. The proposal has received support from e-commerce retailers and individuals, but critics argue that Razer's profit-first mindset may hinder progress in the cashless drive.

site_title: Singaporean named CEO at Goldman Sachs Singapore
summary: Goldman Sachs Singapore has promoted Jason Moo, 44, to CEO, succeeding Frederick Towfigh for four years. Moo, a 20-year veteran, will continue with the firm as a retired partner and advisory director. He previously held positions of head of market solutions group and head of alternative capital markets in Asia. Moo retains his role as regional manager for South-east Asia and Australia at Goldman Sachs Private Wealth Management.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a volatile week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.53% to close at 27,668.47. The gains came as bargain-buyers moved in, despite traders remaining cautious over the North Korea nuclear crisis. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw small gains.

site_title: Invest in Greece, you won't regret it - Greek PM says
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged French businesses to invest in Greece, promising they won't regret it. He said the country's economy could grow by over 2% after seven years of crisis, aiming to reduce unemployment and achieve financial independence by 2018. Tsipras emphasized Greece as an "opportunity" for investment, highlighting the country's potential for growth and stability.

site_title: Yingluck's escape convoy seen heading towards Cambodia: Thai junta
summary: A convoy believed to be carrying Thailand's fugitive former prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra was last spotted heading through a military checkpoint close to the border with Cambodia, according to the junta's deputy leader. Yingluck's disappearance on the day a court was due to deliver a verdict in her trial for criminal negligence has raised questions about the junta's awareness of her plans. Analysts and many Thais have found it hard to believe the junta was unaware of her flight, given the round-the-clock surveillance she frequently complained of.

site_title: Apple-backed billionaire makes case to buy Toshiba chip unit
summary: Terry Gou's Foxconn Technology Group is making a 2.1 trillion yen (S$26.1 billion) bid to acquire Toshiba Corp's memory chips business, beating out American buyout firms Bain Capital and KKR & Co. Foxconn has broad support from Apple, SoftBank Group Corp, and Sharp Corp, and is offering a stable supply of chips to Toshiba, ensuring continued demand for its products. Toshiba needs to raise the funds by March to repair its balance sheet and avoid delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Former VP sentenced to 14 years jail for money laundering and cheating: CPIB
summary: Former Vice-President Linda Lee of United Engineers Developments was sentenced to 14 years' imprisonment for money laundering and cheating. Investigations revealed she colluded with others to provide fictitious quotes for maintenance works, awarding them to her associates. The scheme resulted in approximately $4.977 million in illicit gains. Ng Shu Jun, Tan Aik Gee, Tan Kiam Boon, and Wong Weng Kong have also been charged in connection with the case.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Carmakers bemoan flip-flopping India, urge stable policies to foster investment
summary: Indian carmakers, including Volkswagen and Hyundai, are calling on the government to set clear and stable policies to foster investment. Recent rule changes, including a tax increase on luxury cars and sport utility vehicles, have left the industry scrambling. The government needs to create millions of new jobs each year, but frequent policy changes are expected to dampen growth. Analysts predict a 11% decline in domestic car sales growth in 2018, and the industry is urging a more predictable framework to set long-term strategies.

site_title: Irma powers toward Florida, leaving behind path of death, destruction
summary: Hurricane Irma, a powerful Atlantic storm, drove toward Florida on September 8, 2017, leaving a path of death and destruction. The storm killed 19 people and devastated the Caribbean, particularly the Turks and Caicos Islands. Irma was downgraded from a Category 5 to a Category 4, but still had winds of up to 240 km/h. The storm was about 724 km southeast of Miami, Florida, as it moved toward the US state.

site_title: New wave of leaders stepping up after the jailing of Hong Kong democracy activists
summary: A new wave of young leaders is stepping up in Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement following the jailing of prominent activists Joshua Wong, Nathan Law, and Alex Chow. Tens of thousands protested their sentences, and activists like Agnes Chow and Derek Lam are now taking center stage. They aim to keep the movement's message alive and improve connections at the grassroots level. Despite pessimism, activists like Lester Shum remain optimistic, citing the jailed activists' calm and determined attitude as a turning point for the democratic movement.

site_title: Gold hits 1-year peak as US dollar sags, North Korea concerns support
summary: Gold prices hit a 1-year peak, rising 0.4% to $1,352.91 per ounce, amid weaker-than-expected US jobs data and heightened tensions over North Korea. The US dollar sagged, falling 0.5% against a basket of major currencies, while long-dated Treasury yields reached 10-month lows. The move is attributed to safe-haven demand and concerns over North Korea's nuclear and missile threat.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit talks IPO at 0.55 to 0.57 euro per unit, targets Sept 28 listing
summary: Cromwell Property Group plans to raise up to 1.25 billion euros in a Singapore initial public offering of a European property real estate investment trust (Reit) by the end of September. The IPO price is set between 0.55 and 0.57 euro per unit, implying a yield-at-listing of 7.5 to 7.7%. The proceeds will be used to acquire a portfolio of 81 commercial, industrial, and retail properties in six European countries, with expected distributions of 4.23-4.27 euro cents per unit in 2018.

site_title: At least five die in Mexico quake; small tsunami triggered
summary: An earthquake of magnitude 8.1 struck off Mexico's southern coast, killing at least five people and triggering small tsunami waves. The epicenter was 87 km southwest of Pijijiapan in Chiapas state, with reports of damage limited in Mexico City. Three deaths were reported in Chiapas, and two in Tabasco. Widespread, hazardous tsunami waves were possible within three hours, but no threat was posed to Hawaii or American Samoa. Multiple aftershocks occurred, and some buildings were severely damaged in the south of the country.

site_title: India bars 'unruly' passengers from flying for 3 months to over 2 years
summary: India has introduced new norms barring unruly passengers from flying for a minimum of 3 months to over 2 years, depending on the severity of the behavior. The move follows a lawmaker's admission of assaulting an Air India official. The new rules categorize unruly behavior into three levels: verbal, physical, and life-threatening. The concept of the no-fly list is based on the safety of other passengers, crew, and the aircraft. The rules will apply to both domestic and foreign carriers, aiming to maintain safety and security on Indian flights.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) will participate in the LEAD+ programme to boost the retail sector's productivity. SPRING is exploring the incubation of local designers at department stores to access the overseas market. Cromwell European Reit is planning an IPO with a target listing on September 28, aiming to raise up to S$2 billion. The Singapore dollar reached a one-year high as the US dollar tumbled. A former United Engineers Developments executive was sentenced to 14 years in prison for money laundering and cheating.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% to 7,380.60 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.3% to 12,261.81 points, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.3% to 5,099.31 points. The decline was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks remained a focus.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars soar as greenback sinks
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged against the US dollar, with the Australian dollar reaching a 3-1/2-week high at 80 US cents and the New Zealand dollar reaching a two-week high at 73.31 US cents. This was driven by fading expectations of a US interest rate hike and the US dollar index slipping 0.6% to its lowest since January 2015. The moves were also influenced by global events, including a Mexico earthquake and concerns about hurricanes Irma and Harvey.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on strong yen, North Korea woes
summary: Tokyo stocks dropped 0.63% on Friday, led by a strong yen that hit a 10-month high against the dollar. Exporters were under pressure, and traders were cautious about a possible North Korean missile launch. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,274.82, down 121.70 points.

site_title: Australian shares fall as financials decline; NZ up
