summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,672.60, as financials declined following a banking regulator's plans to investigate Commonwealth Bank's corporate structure. The "Big Four" banks and material and energy stocks also fell. However, the gold index rose 0.8% as gold prices hit a fresh one-year high. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6% driven by industrial and consumer stocks.

site_title: Most South Koreans don't expect war with North; Trump highlights military option
summary: Most South Koreans do not expect a war with North Korea, according to a survey, with 58% believing there is no possibility of war. Despite North Korea's nuclear tests, including its sixth test, and US President Donald Trump's threat of military action, many South Koreans remain unconcerned. Trump has said all options are on the table, but senior administration members have hinted at a diplomatic solution. The US and South Korea are technically still at war with North Korea, and tensions remain high, with the US deploying a nuclear-powered carrier in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar surges most in 1-1/2 years, boosting developers
summary: The Hong Kong dollar surged 0.12% to HK$7.8037 against the US dollar, its biggest two-day gain in 1-1/2 years, boosting property developers. The currency's rebound was driven by the greenback's slide and traders unwinding short positions. The move also boosted stocks, with the Hang Seng Index rising 3% as developers such as Henderson Land Development Co and New World Development Co advanced. The surge is expected to be short-lived, with economists warning that the cash supply in Hong Kong remains flush.

site_title: SRA to embark on LEAD+ programme to help Singapore retail sector boost productivity
summary: The Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) will embark on the Local Enterprise and Association Development Plus (LEAD+) programme to boost the retail sector's productivity and competitiveness. The programme, announced at the Singapore Retail Industry Conference, includes an overseas study mission, a mobile portal, and enhanced features for the GoSpree merchant app. The goal is to enhance retailers' productivity, capabilities, and branding for improved business growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore stocks finish Friday mixed; STI down 1.5% for week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed Friday at 3,228.56, recording a net gain of 0.5 points, despite a 1.5% loss for the week. The STI was impacted by concerns over the US government's debt ceiling and North Korea's nuclear test, but stabilized after diplomatic channels were considered. The market's volatility continued as investors awaited GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australia shares drop as financials tumble, CBA woes persist; NZ market gains
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.4% on Friday, led by a decline in the financial and energy sectors, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia falling 0.7% due to ongoing money-laundering scandal woes. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,668.10. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6% as industrial and telecommunication stocks gained.

site_title: Singapore Cruise Centre partners PT Nongsa Terminal Bahari to promote Riau Islands tourism
summary: Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) has partnered with PT Nongsa Terminal Bahari (NTB) to promote tourism in Batam and the Riau Islands. The collaboration aims to increase passenger traffic at NTB's Nongsapura Ferry Terminal, promoting recent developments such as Infinite Studios and condotel The Scene. The two companies will also focus on enhancing safety, security, and customer service at the terminal, potentially serving as a model for other ferry terminals in the Riau Islands.

site_title: Taiwan's new premier vows to "build country", scrap investment hurdles
summary: Taiwan's new Premier William Lai vowed to build the country, expand the economy, and improve people's lives during his cabinet transition ceremony. Lai, formerly Tainan's mayor, aims to lure greater investment and push through reforms in areas like energy, labor, and pensions. The move comes as President Tsai Ing-Wen's approval ratings have fallen to below 30% due to public dissatisfaction with labor and pension reforms. Lai's cabinet will focus on pragmatic and steadfast solutions, with several new key appointments, including a new financial supervisory chief and vice-premier.

site_title: Bell Pottinger Asia separates from Bell Pottinger UK, relaunches as Klareco Communications
summary: Bell Pottinger Asia has formally separated from its UK counterpart and relaunched as Klareco Communications, a new ownership structure with a separate legal entity. The Asia business is solvent and will continue to serve clients, with CEO Ang Shih Huei and Mark Worthington stating it is "business as usual." This move comes as the UK business is expected to go into administration.

site_title: Euro presses higher against US dollar, Asia markets cautious
summary: The euro surged past US$1.20, its highest level since January 2015, after ECB boss Mario Draghi hinted at tapering the bank's stimulus program. The eurozone economy continued to improve in the second quarter, leading to increased bets on the ECB cutting back on its bond-buying scheme. The dollar was under pressure due to concerns over Hurricane Irma and US political uncertainty, with analysts predicting further declines. Markets remain cautious, with North Korea tensions still a concern.

site_title: Uber drivers' cars torched in South Africa clash
summary: In Johannesburg, South Africa, three cars were torched in a business district clash between Uber drivers and traditional cabbies. Two cars believed to belong to Uber drivers were set alight, while a fourth had its windows smashed. No injuries were reported. The incident is part of the ongoing rivalry between Uber and taxi drivers, who accuse Uber of stealing business and competing unfairly due to low fares.

site_title: US is said to target North Korea violators, with ZTE's help
summary: The US government is planning to seize assets from Chinese companies accused of laundering money for North Korea, using information from ZTE Corp's investigation. This is the third round of asset seizures by the Trump administration amid escalating tensions with China over North Korea's missile and nuclear tests. The actions are expected to coincide with new trade restrictions and a possible addition of Chinese entities to the US sanctions list. ZTE's cooperation has helped investigators identify and prioritize companies to target, with the US also considering adding more Chinese companies to the sanctions list.

site_title: US airlines scramble to evacuate residents ahead of Hurricane Irma
summary: US airlines scrambled to evacuate residents ahead of Hurricane Irma, adding flights out of south Florida airports but limiting availability. Airlines, including American, Delta, and United, increased flights, but many remained canceled or fully booked. The airlines faced accusations of price gouging, with some carriers capping fares at $99-$399. The Federal Aviation Administration held daily calls with airlines to discuss airport conditions, and Carnival Cruise Lines canceled several Caribbean cruises due to the storm.

site_title: Taxify halts London services after regulator questions licence
summary: Taxify, an Estonian taxi-hailing start-up, has temporarily halted operations in London after Transport for London (TfL) said the company failed to obtain a proper operating licence. TfL is investigating the company's activities and will take action where appropriate. Taxify had launched private hire taxi hailing services across London with 3,000 drivers and 30,000 customers. The company claims to charge lower commissions, aiming to make the ride-hailing market fairer for customers and drivers. Taxify is seeking to discuss the issue with TfL to resolve the matter.

site_title: China Aug exports rise 5.5%, imports up 13.3%
summary: China's August exports rose 5.5% from a year earlier, beating expectations, while imports grew 13.3%, resulting in a trade surplus of $41.99 billion, the lowest since May. This rebound in trade performance is attributed to strong domestic demand and abroad. The country's trade surplus narrowed from $46.73 billion in July, indicating a possible easing of pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Malaysia ready to provide temporary shelter for Rohingya fleeing violence
summary: Malaysia is prepared to provide temporary shelter for Rohingya Muslims fleeing violence in Myanmar, despite not signing the UN Refugee Convention. The country's coast guard will not turn away Rohingya refugees, and they will be housed in immigration detention centers. Over 160,000 Rohingya have fled to Bangladesh, and Malaysia expects more to arrive due to renewed violence. The country already hosts over 100,000 Rohingya refugees.

site_title: Trek 2000 International intends to resume trading on Sept 11, 9am
summary: Trek 2000 International Ltd, a Singaporean mainboard-listed company, plans to resume trading on September 11 at 9am. The company's CEO, Henn Tan, and former executive director Poo Teng Pin, as well as former CFO Gurcharan Singh, have agreed to a moratorium on trading their shares until a forensic report is released. The moratorium is related to a review of suspicious transactions and comes after RSM Corporate Advisory highlighted potential breaches of duties by the three individuals in July 2017.

site_title: Donald Trump Jr questioned by Senate investigators
summary: Senate investigators questioned Donald Trump Jr for over five hours, probing his possible connections to Russia during his father's 2016 presidential campaign. Trump Jr, 39, denied collusion and acknowledged attending a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower with a lawyer linked to the Kremlin. He stated he was skeptical of the meeting's claims and ultimately decided not to pursue further. The meeting was also attended by Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner and former campaign manager Paul Manafort.

site_title: Incubator for designers and other initiatives planned to rejuvenate Singapore retail scene
summary: Singapore is launching initiatives to rejuvenate its retail scene, including a Design Incubator and Retail Centre of Excellence, to support local designers and retailers. The incubator, set to open in 2018, will provide a platform for local brands to showcase their designs and access overseas markets. The Retail Centre of Excellence will conduct talent development and research programs to help the industry solve business challenges. The government is also working to enhance Orchard Road as a shopping and lifestyle destination through various plans, including pop-up and permanent activations and improved walkability.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singdollar rises to over a year's high as US dollar tumbles
summary: The Singapore dollar reached a one-year high of 1.3440 to the US dollar, up 0.6% from the previous day, amid fresh weakness in the US currency. This marks a 7% gain for the Singapore currency this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to a stronger yen and concerns over the North Korean crisis. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.34% to 19,331.52, while the Topix index dropped 0.13%. This follows a global trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Nam Cheong unit selling its Suntec office lots for S$25m
summary: Nam Cheong Limited's unit is selling its office lots at Suntec Tower Three for S$25 million to settle an outstanding credit facility with DBS Bank Limited. The sale, a loss on disposal, will be used to repay the debt secured by the Suntec property. The move is part of the company's restructuring efforts to preserve its value amid a severe global downturn in the oil and gas industry.

site_title: One big problem for Apple's iPhone is jaded Chinese consumers
summary: Apple's new iPhones, featuring vibrant full-screen displays and wireless charging, face a challenge in China's saturated market, where consumers can already find similar features on other devices from Huawei, Oppo, and Xiaomi. The country's largest mobile market has become accustomed to getting the latest technology, making it harder for Apple to convince jaded customers of the value of its software. Apple's new flagship is expected to cost around $1,000, but the company's Chinese rivals may appeal to price-sensitive buyers with features like dual SIM capabilities and advanced camera features, potentially drawing buyers away.

site_title: Mexico expels North Korean ambassador after nuclear test
summary: Mexico expelled North Korean Ambassador Kim Hyong Gil on September 7, 2017, after Pyongyang's sixth nuclear test, deeming it a "grave risk for peace" and a serious violation of international law. The Mexican government gave the ambassador 72 hours to leave the country. This move followed global condemnation and calls for stronger UN Security Council sanctions against North Korea, with the US presenting a draft resolution to impose an oil embargo and freeze assets on Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Wesco Engineering's ex-director sentenced to 2 weeks' jail, fine for assisting tax evasion
summary: Wesco Engineering's ex-director Kuah Pong Guan was sentenced to two weeks' jail and fined S$354,045.33 for assisting the company to evade tax by providing false information in income tax returns for two years. He failed to report 81 cash sales made to customers, pocketing the earnings for gambling and paying off creditors. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) takes a serious view of non-compliance and tax evasion, imposing severe penalties for those who wilfully evade tax.

site_title: Australia gun and explosives amnesty nets large cache
summary: Australian authorities have collected a large cache of explosives, gunpowder, and firearms under an amnesty, with over 146kg of explosives, 20kg of gunpowder, and thousands of detonators surrendered. The amnesty, introduced in March, has also seen 25,999 guns handed in, exceeding expectations. Authorities believe there are up to 260,000 illicit weapons on the streets, and the government is working to remove them to minimize the danger of extremist attacks and gangland shootings. The gun amnesty runs for another three weeks, with officials expressing confidence in the success of the initiative.

site_title: Trump offers to mediate in Qatar crisis
summary: US President Donald Trump offered to mediate the Qatar crisis, stating it could be solved "fairly easily." The crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, UAE, and Egypt cut ties with Qatar, accusing it of ties with Iran and Islamist groups. Qatar denies the claims and accuses the other countries of an attack on its sovereignty. Trump expressed support for Saudi Arabia but acknowledges the US has mixed signals on its policy to the Gulf crisis.

site_title: UK jobs boom sends new hire pay up by most in almost two years
summary: The UK jobs market experienced a hiring boom, with vacancies rising at the quickest rate in 28 months in August. Starting salaries increased by the most since October 2015, driven by a shortage of available workers. The availability of workers declined sharply, exacerbated by a fall in net migration from the European Union. Temporary worker pay rose at the steepest rate in 16 months, while there was a significant shortage of people to fill blue-collar roles. This news provides a rare piece of good news for UK employees, who have seen average wage growth lag behind price growth.

site_title: Oil prices rise on sharp drop in US production as hurricanes bite
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday as US crude production fell by almost 8% due to Hurricane Harvey's impact on the US Gulf coast, cutting demand for crude oil. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 12 cents to $49.21 barrel, while Brent crude futures increased 24 cents to $54.73 barrel. The US petroleum industry is expected to take weeks to return to full capacity, with traders citing harsh sea conditions and port closures in the Caribbean. Hurricane Irma is also heading for Florida, threatening further disruption to the industry.

site_title: Oil mixed, Brent rises as Irma casts shadow over Harvey recovery
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Thursday, with Brent rising to a 5-1/2 month high, while US crude slipped due to a bigger-than-expected crude stock build. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 4.6 million-barrel increase in US weekly crude stocks, with oil refinery utilisation rates at 79.7%, the lowest since 2010. Hurricane Irma's threat to crude shipments weighed on prices, while Hurricane Harvey's impact on the US oil industry was still visible.

site_title: BlackRock said to be in talks for Calpers' buyout business
summary: BlackRock is in talks with the California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers) to manage its $26.2 billion in private equity investments. Calpers is seeking to control fees and offset anemic returns, amid criticism over its private equity investing and fee disclosure. The talks are preliminary, with Calpers considering outsourcing its private equity business to BlackRock. This would be a significant win for BlackRock, expanding its alternatives business and increasing fee revenue.

site_title: Japan's Q2 economic growth revised down from stellar first reading
summary: Japan's second-quarter economic growth was revised down to 2.5% annualized, lower than the initial estimate of 4.0% growth. The country's GDP grew 0.6% in real terms, down from a preliminary 1.0% increase. Capital spending rose 0.5%, down from a preliminary 2.4% increase. Despite slower growth, analysts expect the economy to sustain a steady recovery due to robust global demand and a tightening job market, which may lead to higher wages.

site_title: Training, maintenance issues beset overseas US Navy ships
summary: The US Navy's foreign-based ships are facing training and maintenance issues, raising concerns about military readiness. A Government Accountability Office (GAO) review found that crews are overworked and undertrained, while vital maintenance is not being completed on time. Recent incidents, including the USS John S. McCain and USS Fitzgerald collisions, have resulted in sailor deaths and injuries. The GAO report found that 37% of warfare certifications for destroyer crews in Japan had expired, and the number of sailors lacking current training certifications has risen five-fold in two years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.18% to 27,571.59, following a turbulent week due to North Korea's nuclear test. Meanwhile, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices edged down 0.03% and 0.08% respectively. The gains come as investors cautiously returned to the market amid uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pacific Radiance, Loyz Energy, AVIC International Maritime, Sakae Holdings, Spackman Entertainment
summary: Singapore-listed companies Pacific Radiance and AVIC International Maritime have seen developments affecting their shares. Pacific Radiance is reviewing its financial position and capital structure with bank lenders for a consensual restructuring, while AVIC International Maritime completed the liquidation of AVIC International Ship Engineering Pte Ltd. Loyz Energy signed a joint venture agreement with Arctos Investments, Sakae Holdings had an associate company wound up by consent, and Spackman Entertainment formed a co-production partnership with Mongjakso Co Ltd to produce Korean dramas. These developments may impact trading of these shares.

site_title: China's yuan extends blistering 2017 rally to 7.5% after breaching key level
summary: China's yuan strengthened to a 7.5% year-to-date gain against the US dollar, breaking the 6.5 per US dollar level for the first time since May 2016. The currency's onshore spot rate surged to a 6.4478 high, its strongest level since December 2015, and finished the week up 1.54%, its best weekly gain since the yuan's revaluation in 2005. The People's Bank of China raised the official yuan midpoint for the 10th straight session, but the move was seen as weaker than expected, with some traders expecting a firmer rate.

site_title: Fullerton Fund Management unit receives private fund management licence in China
summary: Fullerton Fund Management's wholly foreign-owned enterprise unit, Fullerton Investment Management (Shanghai) Co Ltd, has received a private fund management licence in China, allowing it to offer onshore investment products to institutional and high net worth investors. This is the first time an Asian fund house has successfully registered its WFOE with the AMAC. Fullerton has an asset under management of S$17 billion and plans to further invest in its local office and grow its staff to cover various functions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.59 points to 1,782.39. The index saw 142.2 million lots traded worth RM37.9 million, with 140 gainers and 81 losers.

site_title: Oil-rich Norway struggles to beat its 'petroholism'
summary: Norway, rich from its oil reserves, struggles to reduce its dependence on the industry as it faces climate concerns and economic prudence. The Green Party has urged the government to end new oil exploration and phase out the entire oil industry within 15 years. Despite this, the ruling Conservatives and opposition Labour parties have rejected the ultimatum, citing the industry's importance to the economy. Norway's sovereign wealth fund, worth nearly $1 trillion, is seen as a potential solution, but alternatives to oil are difficult to find, sparking fierce opposition from environmental groups.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index moving up 0.96 point to 3,229.02. The US stocks ended little changed overnight, driven by media companies' slump offset by healthcare shares' gains. The most actively traded counter was M Development, while the market saw a slight edge to gainers over losers.

site_title: Pacific Radiance starts discussion with banks to review capital structure
summary: Pacific Radiance Limited, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, has begun discussions with bank lenders to review its capital structure amid debt refinancing or restructuring. The group narrowed its loss in the second quarter due to the absence of one-time impairment charges, but its bottom line remains affected by weaker offshore support services performance. The goal is to achieve a consensual restructuring of its borrowings.

site_title: A fashionable weekend with BT
summary: BTWeekend's Fall/Winter fashion report highlights must-buys for the season, while also exploring the evolution of luxury retailing and its staying power. The article touches on women in tech, featuring an inequality discussion, and reviews various products, including the European Audio Team B-Sharp Turntable and the Porsche Cayenne. Additionally, it covers emerging trends and businesses, such as mod-Asian restaurants and zero-waste initiatives.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as Hurricane Irma approaches
summary: US stocks finished nearly flat on Thursday as Hurricane Irma approached the US, following Hurricane Harvey's impact last week. Financial stocks, including banks, insurers, and media companies, were among the laggards. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained less than 0.1%. Insurer Travelers and reinsurance company Everest Re lost 1.6% and 6.8%, respectively. Media companies, including Disney and Comcast, also dropped due to weak profit forecasts and rising competition.

site_title: AVIC International Maritime completes liquidation of unit
summary: AVIC International Maritime Holdings Limited completed the liquidation of AVIC International Ship Engineering Pte Ltd on September 7, 2017. The move was part of an intragroup restructuring exercise to streamline corporate holdings and comply with a directive from the Chinese government requiring state-owned enterprises to reduce intermediary companies. AISE, an investment holding company with no material business operations, was dissolved as part of the restructuring.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE edges up but financials falter after ECB meeting
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index rose 0.6% on Thursday, despite financial stocks suffering losses, following the European central bank's reaffirmation of its ultra-easy policy stance. Banking stocks, such as HSBC and Barclays, fell 4.1% and 0.4-1.3% respectively. Imperial Brands led a rise in defensive, consumer-focused companies, while Bovis Homes surged 10% after reporting its half-year results. Analysts at Numis upgraded Bovis Homes to "buy" from "add", citing expected improvements in return on equity and dividend payments.

site_title: Loyz Energy inks MOU with Arctos Investments to diversify business
summary: Loyz Energy Limited has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Arctos Investments to form a joint venture company, FIT Global Pte Ltd, focusing on fund management, investments, and trading. Loyz Energy will contribute $1 million in cash for the incorporation of FIT, with the aim of diversifying its business beyond upstream energy exploration and production.

site_title: HNA unit makes formal offer for its takeover of CWT
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Holding Group made a formal offer to acquire Singapore-listed logistics firm CWT Limited for S$1.4 billion, with a general meeting seeking shareholders' approval. The offer price is S$2.33 in cash per share, to be made through HNA Belt And Road Investments (Singapore) Pte Ltd. Ernst & Young Corporate Finance Pte Ltd has been appointed as the independent financial adviser. A circular with the offer details and IFA advice will be sent to shareholders within 14 days. The deal, valued at S$1.4 billion, aims to privatize CWT.

site_title: Anti-terror chiefs want social media help with 'lone wolves'
summary: Top counter-terror chiefs from the US, Britain, Germany, and Canada emphasized the need for social media companies' assistance in detecting lone wolf threats. The officials stated that traditional intelligence methods are insufficient to uncover attacks by self-radicalized individuals, who often use social media to plan and execute attacks. The chiefs called for more proactive support from companies like Facebook and Google to scan users for potential threats, citing the challenge of encryption on the dark web as a hindrance to investigation.

site_title: US ousts Pakistani bank amid money laundering concerns
summary: US banking regulators ordered Pakistan's Habib Bank to close its New York office due to repeated failures to address concerns over possible terrorist financing and money laundering. Habib Bank, the country's largest private bank, was fined $225 million after failing to comply with oversight of potentially illegal transactions. The bank had facilitated transactions with Saudi private bank Al Rajhi Bank, which has links to al Qaeda, and failed to screen transactions for sanctioned countries. Habib Bank will surrender its license after meeting US banking officials' requirements.

site_title: GE tumbles on worries about its outlook
summary: General Electric's shares dropped 3.6% to $24.02 after JPMorgan Chase analysts expressed concerns about the company's outlook, citing weak activity in its key electricity and oil and gas businesses. Analysts now expect earnings to shrink to $1.15-$1.20 per share in 2018, down from $1.70, due to "continued risks" in the power business and a sluggish recovery in oil and gas. Aviation and healthcare remain strong, but are not enough to offset the other problems, with JPMorgan warning of a "clear downside to current expectations."

site_title: China's digital healthcare revolution gaining ground
summary: China's healthcare sector is undergoing a digital revolution driven by the country's growing middle class and increasing purchasing power of its digital native generation. The healthcare market is expected to reach $892 billion by 2018, with an average annual growth rate of 11.8%. However, there are significant supply shortages and market dynamics issues, prompting the government to develop digital health solutions. Tech giants such as Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent are investing heavily in digital healthcare, with over $1.5 billion in venture funding in 2016. Digital health services are becoming increasingly popular, with apps offering online diagnostic services, appointment booking, and personalized health advice, and are expected to transform the healthcare landscape.

site_title: Not all Burgundies are expensive
summary: Not all Burgundies are expensive, contrary to the common perception that they are stratospherically priced. The commune of Vosne-Romanee, home to famous names like Romanee-Conti and La Tache, offers lush and velvety Pinot Noir wines that can be found within a modest budget, excluding high-end Domaines. Negociant-domains like Maison Joseph Drouhin and Louis Jadot offer high-quality wines at affordable prices, making Burgundies accessible to a wider range of consumers. By exploring these options and understanding the importance of terroir, wine enthusiasts can discover great Pinot Noirs from other regions, such as Napa Valley and Australia's Margaret River.

site_title: Euro rises as ECB signals stimulus slowdown
summary: The euro surged to a nine-day high against the US dollar after the European Central Bank (ECB) indicated it was preparing to scale back its stimulus program. The dollar index fell 1.1% to its lowest since January 2015, while gold rose to a one-year peak. The ECB kept its growth and inflation outlooks unchanged, with ECB head Mario Draghi stating the bank would be ready to scale back stimulus by October. The euro rose 0.92% to $1.2025, while major world stock markets climbed.

site_title: HDB ties up with universities to boost productivity, design
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has signed two research and development agreements with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) worth S$10.7 million. The collaborations aim to boost HDB's construction productivity and design neighbourhoods to better meet residents' needs, utilizing smart solutions.

site_title: 143m affected in hack of US credit agency
summary: Equifax, a US credit reporting agency, confirmed a massive hack that potentially affected 143 million US customers, as well as some data for British and Canadian residents. The breach occurred from mid-May to July 2017, and hackers gained access to names, social security numbers, birth dates, addresses, and driver's license numbers. Credit card numbers were compromised for 209,000 US consumers, and credit dispute documents for 182,000 people. Equifax is offering free credit monitoring and identity theft protection to affected customers.

site_title: Konnichiwa, here are your groceries - and your order of hydrogen
summary: Japan's Hitachi Ltd and Marubeni Corp launch a pilot project to deliver hydrogen to homes in northern Japan, aiming to expand its use in rural areas where gas pipelines are unavailable. The project, funded by Japan's Ministry of the Environment, will use solar power to produce hydrogen and transport it in cartridges to be used in fuel cell systems. The goal is to serve 47% of households without city gas and 28 million members of cooperatives, with the potential to reduce reliance on LPG cylinders.

site_title: Two Singaporeans arrested for terror-linked activities
summary: Two Singaporeans, Imran Kassim, 34, and Shakirah Begam Abdul Wahab, 23, have been arrested under the Internal Security Act for terrorism-related activities. Imran, managing director of a logistics company, was detained for intending to join ISIS and planning to attack Singapore Armed Forces personnel, while Shakirah, an administrative assistant, was issued a restriction order for initiating and maintaining contact with foreign ISIS fighters. Their arrests come amid the country's highest terror threat levels in recent years.

site_title: Trump bypasses Republicans to strike deal
summary: US President Donald Trump struck a deal with Democratic congressional leaders to increase the debt limit and finance the government until mid-December, bypassing his own Republican allies. The agreement, which combined a debt ceiling increase and stopgap spending measure with relief aid to Texas and other areas devastated by Hurricane Harvey, was seen as a surprise move by Trump. The deal reflects a willingness by Trump to cross party lines, particularly on immigration, and sets up the prospect for an even bigger clash at the end of the year.

site_title: Swedish bank Nordea moves HQ to Finland where rules are easier
summary: Nordea Bank AB, a European banking giant, has announced plans to relocate its headquarters from Sweden to Finland, citing easier regulatory rules. The move is expected to save the bank up to $1.3 billion in regulatory costs over time. The decision puts the Nordic region's only global systemically important bank inside the eurozone, sparking concerns in Sweden about its ability to deal with financial crises. Finland has welcomed the move, while Swedish authorities warn of a "limited" impact on staffing and day-to-day operations.

site_title: Sale of Brooklyn housing complex raises potential conflict of interest for Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's 4% stake in Brooklyn's Starrett City housing complex, the largest federally subsidized development in the US, is set to be sold for over $850 million. The sale, which requires HUD and state housing approval, raises potential conflicts of interest for Trump and his family. Trump's share of the proceeds could be around $14 million, sparking concerns about the president's involvement in the deal. The sale is expected to close early next year and will provide stability for the complex's 15,000 residents.

site_title: Nam Cheong controlling shareholder to take up RM50m of rights shares
summary: Malaysian tycoon Tiong Su Kouk, controlling shareholder of Nam Cheong, has pledged to subscribe RM50 million (S$15.9 million) to a proposed rights issue, funding an option for noteholders to cash out their debt after a severe haircut. The funds will support Nam Cheong's debt restructuring plan, which includes converting unsecured debt into new shares. The company has defaulted on several payments, totaling US$424 million in debt, and has proposed a seven-year repayment plan with interest fixed at 4% per annum.

site_title: Aspen back in the black for Q2 on revenue surge
summary: Aspen Holdings, a Malaysia-based property development group, reported a net profit of RM13.4 million (S$4.28 million) for the second quarter, reversing a net loss from the previous year. Revenue surged 246.3% to RM70 million, driven by progress in ongoing projects. The company has total unbilled sales of RM1 billion and remains positive, benefiting from government initiatives to alleviate the shortage of affordable homes. Aspen's president and CEO, M Murly, expressed optimism for the company's future growth.

site_title: McDonald's Japan opening more stores in second half
summary: McDonald's Japan plans to open more restaurants than it will close in the second half of the year, marking a turnaround after years of shuttered stores due to food-contamination scandals. The company's CEO, Sarah Casanova, expects the trend of new stores to continue next year. This marks 21 consecutive months of same-store sales growth, underscoring the chain's recovery.

site_title: Euro near day's highs after ECB outcome
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reaffirmed its ultra-easy policy stance, keeping the door open to increasing bond purchases. This move lifted the euro, which rose 0.5% against the US dollar to $1.1974, its highest level in a day. Markets shifted focus to Mario Draghi's comments at a press conference, where he may discuss the currency's strength. The euro's gains also outpaced the US dollar, which fell 0.5% against a broad trade-weighted basket.

site_title: Mumbai residents refuse to leave unsafe buildings
summary: In Mumbai, thousands of residents live in crumbling buildings declared uninhabitable by housing authorities, but most refuse to leave due to lax laws and loopholes. The Husainee building collapse on August 31, 2017, killed 34 people, including a newborn baby, after it was declared unsafe six years earlier. Officials say they cannot force residents to evacuate due to a law requiring 70% tenant agreement for redevelopment, which residents often refuse. Despite identifying over 14,000 buildings in need of repair, the city struggles to enforce eviction and relocate residents to safer housing.

site_title: Fischer's exit makes Trump's choice for Fed chair even starker
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing a significant economic decision as Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen's term expires in February, with Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer's surprise exit making her reappointment uncertain. Trump has considered nominating Gary Cohn, his top economic adviser, for the job, but Fischer's departure makes continuity at the top of the Fed even starker. The Fed's leadership plays a crucial role in maintaining financial stability, and Trump's choice will impact the economy's key questions, including the link between unemployment and inflation.

site_title: Airlines scramble, traffic in tangle as Florida residents hurry out of Irma's way
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people fled south Florida ahead of Hurricane Irma, with airlines scrambling to accommodate demand. Despite added flights and waived change fees, hundreds of flights were cancelled on Wednesday. Airlines such as American and Delta warned passengers to check before leaving for the airport, while some reported exorbitant fares for flights out of affected areas. The storm, with maximum sustained winds near 298 kph, is expected to hit south Florida between Friday night and Monday, prompting mandatory evacuations and gridlock on roadways.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw conferred Asean Legacy Award
summary: Wee Cho Yaw, UOB chairman emeritus and adviser, has been conferred the Asean Legacy Award for Singapore at the 2017 Asean Business Awards. Recognized for his business achievements in the region, Wee has had a long association with Asean, serving as the first Singaporean to assume the presidency of the Asean Chamber of Commerce & Industry in 1979. His banking empire, UOB, has expanded into the region, with over 90% of its offices and branches now based in Asean.

site_title: Dialogue is the only option to defuse North Korea crisis
summary: The North Korea crisis is intensifying, with tensions on the Korean peninsula mounting. Former Japanese diplomat Hiroshi Tanaka suggests that the US may be willing to accept a North Korean strike on South Korea, as it does not pose an imminent threat to the US. This theory implies that the US might be willing to accept a reunified Korea on North Korea's terms, potentially leading to a mega-conflict. Experts emphasize the need for dialogue, but warn that if the situation persists, it could escalate into a major conflict, with the US potentially deploying nuclear weapons in Japan and South Korea.

site_title: F1 ticket sales rev up in final lap of current contract
summary: Formula 1 ticket sales for the Singapore Grand Prix are on track to exceed last year's, with 7 out of 10 ticket categories sold out. The event, which could be its final year if no extension deal is struck after the current contract expires in 2017, has seen a 15% increase in attendance since 2016. Despite the uncertainty, Singapore GP executive director Michael Roche highlighted the economic and branding benefits of hosting the event. The nation has seen significant revenue from tourism and economic spin-offs, but the cost of hosting the race remains high, with the government footing 60% of the bill.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan's cutesy kei cars hit bumpy road
summary: Japan's beloved kei cars, known for their tiny size and cute designs, are facing a decline in sales. Despite a peak of 2.27 million units in 2014, sales plummeted, and the market is expected to have a "bumpy road ahead." The cutesy box-shaped cars, which are a staple of the world's No 3 vehicle market, may struggle to regain their popularity. The reasons behind the decline are not explicitly stated, but the article implies that the market is experiencing a downturn.

site_title: Spackman to produce Korean TV dramas with Mongjakso
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group Ltd has partnered with Mongjakso Co Ltd to co-produce two Korean TV dramas, including actor So Ji Sub's next project, "The Game". The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing popularity of Korean entertainment in Southeast Asia. This move expands Spackman Entertainment's business portfolio and diversifies its revenue stream. The company has already acquired a 100% equity interest in Frame Pictures Co Ltd and owns Zip Cinema Co Ltd and Novus Mediacorp Co Ltd, further solidifying its presence in the Korean entertainment industry.

images.alt_text: Actor So Ji Sub will star in a Spackman-Mongjakso TV drama which is expected to be released in 2018.

site_title: Singapore's greatest hits reimagined
summary: Singapore's top classic songs have been reimagined by up-and-coming musicians for "The Great Singapore Replay" (TGSR) final showcase at Clarke Quay Central. The event features 10 young musicians performing their own original material and re-recorded versions of well-known local hits, including Dick Lee's "The Mad Chinaman" and "Shanty" by The Quests. The project was launched by Temasek Holdings and National Arts Council, aiming to bring together young and old through music and showcase local talent.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: When banks try to apply new tech to outdated ways
summary: Banks are struggling to adapt to the changing financial landscape, with many attempting to apply new technology to outdated business models. To prepare for the future, banks should first acknowledge the limitations of their legacy systems and stop protecting them at any cost. Second, they must adopt a bold, innovative approach, embracing technology as a step change rather than an incremental process. Finally, banks should focus on delivering value to their clients through technology, increasing efficiency ratios and challenging their value chain to become more efficient.

site_title: Naked products expose British consumers' worries about packaging waste
summary: A British cosmetics company, Lush, has launched an exhibition called the "Naked House" in London, showcasing products sold without packaging to raise awareness about environmentally sustainable consumer alternatives. The exhibition features a history of packaging waste, including banana skins, glass bottles, and metal tins, as well as eco-friendly alternatives. A survey found that 4 in 5 Britons are concerned about waste, with women more anxious than men. Similar initiatives are being implemented in other countries, with some introducing deposit return schemes and zero-waste supermarkets.

site_title: Facebook identifies fake accounts by Kremlin-linked firm
summary: Facebook has identified over $100,000 worth of divisive ads purchased by a Russian company linked to the Kremlin, which ran between June 2015 and May 2017. The ads, focused on hot-button issues such as race and gun control, were linked to 470 fake accounts and pages shut down by the company. This disclosure adds to evidence of Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election, with US intelligence agencies concluding the campaign was designed to damage Hillary Clinton and boost Donald Trump.

site_title: US debt ceiling doubts cap prices here
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a quiet trading session on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,228.06, down 4.41 points. The US stock market rose after President Trump and Democrats agreed on a three-month deal to raise the debt ceiling and pay for hurricane relief. However, analysts warn that the agreement is only a short-term solution and may distract from tax reform. The Reit sector showed mixed results, with some stocks rebounding, while others fell.

site_title: Changi Garden latest to hop on en bloc train
summary: The residents of Changi Garden in Singapore have agreed to put their nearly 40-year-old property up for collective sale by public tender, with an asking price of S$196 million. This is the 15th residential en bloc attempt this year, and 50-60 deals are reportedly underway. The property, comprising 60 apartments, 12 penthouses, and 12 shops, is expected to fetch S$1.69 million to S$1.79 million per apartment, and S$3.18 million to S$3.74 million for penthouse owners. The sale is seen as a momentum-driven opportunity, with attractive pricing, redevelopment potential, and a prime location.

site_title: Bank Negara FX losses a 'bitter lesson, but helped overcome Asian financial crisis'
summary: Former Bank Negara Malaysia adviser Nor Mohamed Yakcop testified before a royal commission of inquiry into the central bank's colossal foreign exchange losses in the 1990s, which exceeded RM32 billion. He attributed the losses to a combination of factors, including a focus on value preservation, profit optimization, and market expertise. Yakcop claimed that these policies helped Malaysia formulate strategies to defend against currency speculators during the Asian financial crisis, saving the nation billions of ringgit in losses. The commission also heard that the bank's reserve management became more active over time, with larger bets made to cover losses, but experts questioned the bank's risk management and oversight.

site_title: Razer delivers on proposal for universal e-payment system in Singapore
summary: Razer has submitted a proposal for a universal e-payment system in Singapore, committing $10 million in seed funding for its new solution, RazerPay. The proposal aims to develop an interoperable e-payment framework, which will be managed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Razer will also support existing e-payment solutions, such as Alipay, which has launched at Changi Airport with over 78 outlets available. The move is part of Singapore's push towards a cashless society within 18 months.

site_title: China bear loses his shorts betting against the yuan
summary: Hedge fund manager Mark Hart, who bet against the yuan, has lost his conviction after China successfully stabilized the currency's exchange rate. Hart's $240 million loss was due to his initial belief that China's leaders would let the yuan slide, but instead, the government took extreme measures to prop it up. The yuan has rallied over 6% in 2017 and is trading at its strongest level in over a year, making Hart's bet unsuccessful.

site_title: Questions on banking? Ask Citi's chatbot
summary: Citi Singapore has launched its chatbot, Citi Bot, on Facebook Messenger, allowing customers to ask common questions such as account balance and transaction summaries. The bot will be rolled out to the Asia-Pacific region in the coming months, with a commercial launch slated for the fourth quarter. The bank developed the bot in-house and leveraged technology from vendors, following a beta testing phase with 600 members of its Beta Testing Community. The Citi Bot aims to enhance the digital experience for customers, making banking more convenient and accessible.

site_title: A good annual report can help build trust
summary: The Best Annual Report Awards (Bara) recognizes companies that provide useful and relevant information through their annual reports, earning trust from stakeholders. This year's winners, including DBS Group Holdings and Tuan Sing Holdings, presented clear, concise, and coherent snapshots of their performance, environmental and social policies, and risk management strategies. The awards aim to promote transparency and accountability, and the judges are looking forward to seeing more companies adopt industry benchmarks, value-adding disclosures, and thoughtful discussions on internal controls in the future.

site_title: China's reliance on old growth drivers keeps slowdown at bay
summary: China's economy defied expectations for a slowdown, growing 6.9% in the first half of the year, driven by strong global demand for exports, a resilient property market, and government investment. Despite concerns about the economy's long-term trajectory due to reliance on old growth drivers, economists expect China's growth to accelerate for the first time in seven years, with a forecast of 6.8% this year. However, policymakers face pressure to push through reforms, particularly targeting state firms, to address issues such as credit build-up and uneven competition.

site_title: Stepping up its game in the halal business
summary: My Outlets Express, a Singapore-based halal industry player, is expanding globally while maintaining its presence in Singapore. The company aims to create a global halal hub, enabling halal food manufacturers and exporters to distribute their products through its value-chain channel. With a market value of US$2.77 trillion, the halal market is one of the world's fastest-growing markets. My Outlets has already opened three supermarkets in Japan and plans expansion in other Asian countries, with Singapore remaining its primary target market.

site_title: US:Wall St opens slightly higher
summary: Wall Street opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 14.69 points to 21,822.33. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record and the Nasdaq adding 9.86 points. The ECB reaffirmed its ultra-easy policy stance, while investors monitored Hurricane Irma's potential impact on Florida.

site_title: Policyholders' data in AXA's health portal breached
summary: AXA Singapore's health portal was hacked, compromising the personal data of 5,400 past and present policyholders, including email addresses, mobile numbers, and policy numbers. The insurer has apologized and secured its portal, with MAS and police investigating. No financial or health data was compromised, but the exposed information could be used for phishing attempts. AXA has notified affected customers and is reviewing its IT systems, with MAS urging the insurer to prioritize cyber security and adopt proactive measures to protect customer data.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific back in the black for Q1
summary: Del Monte Pacific Ltd has reversed its loss to report a net profit of US$740,000 for the first quarter of 2017, driven by strong sales in Asia. Revenue edged up 1.4% to US$473.8 million, with the S&W business in Asia contributing significantly. Despite lower sales in the US, the group increased its market share in several categories and aims to rationalize non-profitable businesses and focus on premium quality and healthy products.

site_title: Shell expects Aussie gas shortage to trigger LNG export curbs
summary: Australia's energy market operator, AEMO, is likely to declare a domestic gas shortage in the next two to four weeks, triggering export curbs. This comes as Shell Australia's chairwoman Zoe Yujnovich warned of a structural shortfall due to increased demand and limited supply. LNG exports from plants that draw more gas from local markets than they supply may be limited, affecting Queensland's three export projects. The shortage is expected to impact eastern states, with prices rising and some citizens facing tighter supply.

site_title: Best World won't be affected by China crackdown: COO
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based beauty products direct seller, remains on track to meet analyst targets for 2017, despite concerns over its China business. COO Huang Ban Chin said the company's China export revenue will continue to grow at a strong double-digit pace, and there has been no impact from a government crackdown on illegal pyramid selling schemes. The company expects to hit S$43 million in earnings, a 20-30% improvement from 2016, and its shares gained 4% to close at S$1.285.

site_title: Keppel O&M, Pavilion Gas to work with Indonesia's PLN
summary: Keppel Offshore and Marine Ltd (Keppel O&M) and Pavilion Gas are collaborating with Indonesia's state-owned electricity provider PLN to distribute liquefied natural gas (LNG) to remote islands and locations in West Indonesia. The partnership aims to bring cost savings and mutual benefits, with the companies combining their expertise to deliver LNG to floating and onshore terminals, where it will be regasified to generate electricity at PLN's power plants. This collaboration could result in cheaper LNG for Indonesia and enhance energy cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Dirty truths emerge over how P&G works
summary: Billionaire Nelson Peltz is pushing Procter & Gamble Co (P&G) to reorganize its business units, invest in smaller brands, and prioritize digital strategy. Peltz's Trian Fund Management owns $3.5 billion of P&G stock and wants the company to break up its "matrix" organizational structure into three autonomous units. P&G's CEO, David Taylor, opposes Peltz's plan, calling it a "serious brake" on the company's momentum. Peltz also recommends hiring more outside executives to break up P&G's insular culture and acquiring smaller, high-growth brands to compete with Amazon.

site_title: Macron's popularity drops but he is still ahead
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's popularity has declined to 41% in September, down 13 points from May, but he remains ahead of his opposition. Macron's economic plans, including labor market liberalization and business-friendly tax cuts, are expected to pass with the support of his National Assembly majority. His plans aim to revitalize France's economy and bring Germany on board for deeper European integration, despite a divided parliamentary opposition. Macron faces a challenge to win back angry voters before his re-election in 2022.

site_title: History reignited
summary: Two performances at the Singapore International Festival of Arts reignite apathy and spark change. "The Nature Museum" combines fact and fiction to highlight Singapore's vanishing natural landscape, while "Guilty Landscapes III" forces viewers to confront the horrors of war through real-time communication with a Syrian victim. Meanwhile, "My Lai" tells the story of a US soldier who intervened in a massacre, but some critics argue it elevates the soldier's role over the victims' experiences, raising questions about representation and purpose.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Central bankers are shifting the goalposts on responsibility
summary: Central bankers are deviating from their traditional focus on monetary policy to address external issues, such as growth, trade, and investment. However, this shift in focus is puzzling, given that they were made independent to prioritize price stability. The European Central Bank, in particular, has been facing a favorable economic environment, with low inflation and unemployment rates. Yet, it continues to advocate for unconventional monetary policy measures, including negative interest rates and quantitative easing, which seem unjustified by current market conditions. This trend is not unique to Europe, as other central banks, such as the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan, are also adopting similar approaches.

images.alt_text: Central bankers surely wish for a dynamic global economy. But that is not something that they can influence much.

site_title: Sushi bar with its heart in the right place
summary: Southpaw Bar & Sushi, located in Jalan Besar, Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its whisky pairing concept and omakase sets. The staff is friendly and engaging, introducing themselves and seeking feedback to improve. However, the food is straightforward and predictable, with a focus on sashimi and sushi. The giant oyster is a visually appealing centerpiece, but the Canadian rock oyster lacks elegance. The higher-priced sets offer more variety and quality, including a pleasant salmon carpaccio and fresh sashimi. Despite the food's limitations, the restaurant's heart is in the right place, making it a promising option for those seeking a casual dining experience.

images.alt_text: Sashimi that is decent in quality and fresh.
Salmon topped with herring roe.
Akagai sushi.
Southpaw's whisky selection.

site_title: Norway's giant wealth fund a piggy bank to be used prudently
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global, the world's largest sovereign wealth fund, holds nearly $1 trillion, accumulated since 1996. The fund invests in stocks, bonds, and real estate, and is managed by the Norwegian central bank to avoid destabilizing the economy. The fund's returns are strictly defined, and it is barred from investing in companies violating human rights or causing environmental damage. Despite oil revenues decreasing, the fund continues to grow, with 1.3% of the world's market capitalization and 2.3% in Europe.

site_title: Bravely exploring new musical territories
summary: Local indie band TypeWriter has released their new EP "What You're Feeling Is Not Enough", featuring a mix of emotions and musical styles. The five-track album marks a departure from their previous sound, with songs like "Everything is Classified" and "The Room Upstairs" showcasing a more experimental approach. The EP was shot in a disco-inspired style, with the band dressed as 1970s disco icons Village People for the music video. TypeWriter will perform a show on September 9 to launch the EP, which is available on Spotify and limited edition vinyl.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
From left: Alan Bok, Yee Chang Kang, Patrick Chng, Desmond Goh and Robin Chua of TypeWriter.

site_title: If you build it, the Dutch will pedal it
summary: In Utrecht, Netherlands, the world's largest bike parking garage has been unveiled, with 6,000 new spots filling quickly. The city aims to create thousands more bike parking spots and miles of bike paths to promote cycling, as residents have shown a strong demand for bike infrastructure. The Netherlands, a bike-friendly country, has seen a significant increase in cycling, with over 22 million bikes and a 11% growth in daily usage over the last decade. Cycling is estimated to save the country 19 billion euros annually, and studies have shown it can prevent 6,500 premature deaths each year, while reducing health, social, and other costs.

site_title: Ghosts and Spectres digs up the past
summary: A new film and video exhibition, "Ghosts and Spectres --Shadows of History," at NTU CCA Singapore explores the role of local myths, rituals, and oral histories in shaping historical narratives in post-war and Cold War Asia. Four Asian artists - Ho Tzu Nyen, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, Nguyen Trinh Thi, and Park Chan-kyong - examine their respective social and geopolitical contexts through complex, multi-layered video installations and films that blend fact and fiction. The exhibition critiques the omission of certain stories and the power dynamics in historical narratives.

site_title: China's cities face surging funding costs on default concerns
summary: China's cities and counties face surging borrowing costs due to concerns over landmark defaults by local government financing vehicles (LGFVs). Average financing costs have jumped, with yields for some borrowers surging the most in six years. Investors are gradually accepting that the government is reducing support for LGFVs, leading to increased debt costs. At least 40 LGFVs have announced plans to change their financing structures, fuelling concerns over default risks and systemic risk.

site_title: 10 years after the subprime crisis, have things really changed?
summary: The US subprime mortgage crisis, which began in 2007, has largely been forgotten 10 years after its start. The Dodd-Frank Act, passed in 2010, aimed to prevent similar crises, but its repeal and rollback of regulations could lead to banks resuming activities curbed since 2010. This could result in another crisis, as the US Federal Reserve's oversight may have contributed to the initial crisis. Despite the passage of time, concerns remain about the potential for another financial crisis, compounded by the lack of accountability for those responsible for the 2007 crisis.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.7% y-o-y in Aug: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore slipped 0.7% year-on-year in August, while transaction volumes rose 3% over the same period, according to SRX Property. Prices eased 0.2% in mature estates and 1.1% in non-mature estates. Experts attribute the increase in volumes to buyers rushing to seal deals before the Hungry Ghosts month, but expect gradual price growth due to strict loan curbs, with prices projected to be range-bound between -1% and +1% in 2017.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: India needs to find allies to tap cheap funds for clean coal - trade body
summary: India needs to partner with countries like the US, Japan, and Australia to access cheaper funding for cleaner coal technologies, as the country's reliance on coal is expected to increase to produce over half of its power by 2040. India's coal quality is lower than international standards, making it difficult to shift from imported coal. The government should explore using funds from the National Clean Energy Fund to develop domestic coal expertise, despite renewable energy's growing share in the energy mix.

site_title: Higher consumer spending underpins euro zone strong growth
summary: The euro zone economy grew 0.6% in the second quarter, driven by higher domestic demand and investment, despite slower export growth due to the strong euro. This is in line with previous estimates and market expectations. Consumer spending and investment accelerated the growth, while the euro's value against other currencies negatively impacted exports. The robust growth is a positive sign for the euro zone economy.

site_title: Mum's still the word for this director
summary: Local filmmaker Sam Loh premieres his latest telemovie, Kid Napped, on Friday, which centers around two mothers searching for their abducted child. The film is part of StarHub's Go Local productions and stars Maia Lee, Debbie Goh, and Allan Wu. Loh reveals that maternal themes have been a recurring theme in his work, including his upcoming erotic femme fatale revenge trilogy, which may also feature a central mother character. Loh praises Lee's standout performance in Kid Napped, saying her emotions were genuine and he hopes the film will showcase her in a new light.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: ECB needs to factor in inflation as it prepares to wind down stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) president, Mario Draghi, stated that the bank must consider the weakening of inflation due to the strong euro as it prepares to wind down its stimulus program. The ECB kept interest rates at record lows and maintained asset purchases at 60 billion euros per month until December. Inflation forecasts for 2019 were also trimmed, mainly due to the euro's 13% rally against the dollar. The decision reflects the ECB's dilemma in balancing robust growth with low inflation, with policymakers likely to make a decision on tapering stimulus this autumn.

site_title: Big US stores get in bed with online giants to bolster sales
summary: US retailers Kohl's and Home Depot have partnered with Amazon and Google, respectively, to bolster sales. Kohl's will offer Amazon products in its stores, while Home Depot will sell goods online through voice commands. The deals aim to drive traffic to brick-and-mortar locations and counter Amazon's e-commerce threat. Kohl's shares rose 4.9% after the announcement, while Home Depot's shares gained 2.4%. The partnerships highlight the growing importance of voice-controlled devices and online shopping.

site_title: Norway's election niggles give Big Oil the jitters
summary: Norway's upcoming election poses a threat to the country's oil industry, with several parties opposed to further exploration emerging as potential kingmakers. The Green Party, which wants to end exploration immediately, could become a key parliamentary force, and Labor, a historic supporter of the industry, may be forced to reconsider its stance. This could lead to reduced licence awards, fewer tax subsidies, and potentially jeopardize a program that allows loss-making companies to collect exploration expenses in cash, posing a significant blow to the industry.

site_title: Weeding out a Civil War snake in the Garden of Eden
summary: Sofia Coppola's 2017 film "The Beguiled" is a Southern Gothic psychological thriller set in a girls' boarding academy during the American Civil War. The story follows the arrival of a wounded Union Army deserter, Corporal John McBurney, played by Colin Farrell, who preys on the fantasies of the female students and staff. As the women, led by headmistress Miss Martha (Nicole Kidman), try to impress McBurney, they begin to turn against him, leading to shocking violence. Coppola's film explores themes of female desire, manipulation, and the consequences of violating the sheltered world of the academy.

site_title: Caper flick that is criminally fun
summary: Logan Lucky, a heist film directed by Steven Soderbergh, follows Jimmy Logan (Channing Tatum), a laid-off worker who enlists a crew of rednecks to steal money from a NASCAR track's vault. The plan involves a complex scheme, including a prison break and a network of pneumatic tubes. As the operation unfolds, complications arise, and FBI agent Sarah Grayson (Hilary Swank) investigates. The film, which features an ensemble cast, is a "tasty Soderbergh salad" with a feel-good caper storyline that's worth the price of admission.

site_title: Kendal Industrial Park has drawn US$475m in investments to date
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that the Kendal Industrial Park, a joint venture with Indonesia, has attracted US$475 million in investments and 32 confirmed tenants, creating potential jobs for up to 4,000 people. The park, which opened 10 months ago, will also feature a new polytechnic to train Indonesians for jobs supporting the investments. Lee highlighted the strong partnership between Singapore and Indonesia, citing 50 years of diplomatic relations and cooperation in areas such as trade, investment, and disaster management. The two leaders also agreed to negotiate a new bilateral investment treaty to further strengthen economic cooperation.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Japan's seniors develop yen for Reits to fight banks' paltry rates
summary: Japan's seniors are increasingly investing in real estate investment trusts (Reits) as banks offer low interest rates, with individuals accounting for net buyers for the first time in nearly seven years. Seniors in their 70s and 60s made up 45% and 17% of total J-REIT investments, respectively, in the year ended March. This trend is driven by Reits' stable returns, resilient to market fluctuations, and attractive dividend yields of 4.1%. The move is seen as a response to Japan's stagnant economy and low interest rates, with many seniors looking for alternative investment options.

site_title: India puts its boots on in battle with capricious weather
summary: India plans to enhance its weather prediction capabilities with the installation of two new supercomputers and a suite of new radars in a small geographical area, aiming to improve its ability to predict devastating rainfall. This comes after the heaviest rainfall since 2005 in Mumbai last week, which killed a dozen people and disrupted daily life. The move is expected to help authorities better prepare for and respond to extreme weather events.

site_title: ECB sticks to easy money as bond-buying squeeze nears
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its easy-money policy, keeping interest rates and its bond-buying program unchanged. The ECB's quantitative easing program, worth 60 billion euros per month, will continue until the end of December, with policymakers citing a stronger euro and sluggish inflation as reasons to prolong the program. Analysts expect the growth outlook to be upgraded, but inflation expectations are likely to undershoot the 2% target.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub's Fixed Enterprise Group showcased its capabilities through a sell-side day, with a revamped leadership and acquisition of Accel Systems & Technologies expected to strengthen growth. Sheng Siong Group sees potential for growth in the grocery market despite Amazon's entry, while Wilmar International's recent acquisitions may expand its offerings in bakery products and confectionery.

site_title: UK Brexit minister says "good prospect" of agreeing transitional deal with EU
summary: UK Brexit minister David Davis stated that there is a "good prospect" of agreeing a transitional deal with the EU before the UK leaves the bloc in March 2019. The EU has expressed openness to discussing a transition, and Davis believes this will be agreed upon by March 2019. However, the opposition Labour Party has expressed concerns and is seeking amendments to the bill to better protect workers' rights, which the government is unlikely to accept.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.500 points to 1,782.980 on Thursday, driven by a 533-317 gain-to-lose ratio. The index closed at RM2.413 billion in volume. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty due to US trade policies.

site_title: Bet on Indonesia's long-term growth, says business chief
summary: Singapore Business Federation chairman Teo Siong Seng emphasized Indonesia's long-term growth potential, citing positive GDP growth and government efforts to improve the investment environment. The country's economy expanded by 5% last year and is expected to grow 5.4% next year. Indonesia attracted $29 billion in foreign direct investment in 2016, with Singapore being the largest contributor. The two countries have a strong tourism industry, with 1.47 million Singaporeans visiting Indonesia last year. The Indonesian government is encouraging the development of 10 new cities as modelled after Bali, offering opportunities for Singapore businesses to tap into the country's growth.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China's tiger mums fuel online education boom
summary: China's online education market is booming, driven by "tiger mums" who invest in extra-curricular classes to prepare their children for a high-tech future. Millions of children are taking online classes for English, math, and sciences, with platforms like VIPKid and iTutorGroup expanding rapidly. The market is expected to double to $165 billion within five years, with traditional tutoring companies and online startups competing for market share. Chinese parents prioritize academic achievement, and online education offers flexibility and data analysis, leading to increased demand and investment.

site_title: Taking the cue from Tamil culture
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival is celebrating its 20th edition with the theme of "aram", a Tamil concept meaning "doing good to others" and "acting humanely and conscientiously". The festival features an aram conference exploring goodness and virtue, with panel discussions on intercultural dialogue, aram in conflict, and its relevance to youth. The Tamil community views aram as a core moral principle, and the festival aims to raise awareness and understanding of this concept, which underpins Tamil morality.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Spotify, Hulu to sell US$4.99 entertainment bundle for students
summary: Spotify and Hulu are launching a US$4.99 monthly bundle for US college and university students, offering music and video services at a discounted rate. The bundle includes Spotify's music streaming service and Hulu's ad-supported video service, with the companies splitting the subscription fee. This is the first time Spotify has packaged its music streaming service with another company's content. The move aims to attract young customers and retain existing users who may be lured by rival Apple Music.

site_title: Draghi says euro is important factor in future policy decisions
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the euro's strength could impact future policy decisions due to its effect on inflation, growth, and exports. The euro has gained 13% against the dollar this year, making exports less competitive and reducing costs of imports. The ECB lowered inflation projections, but lifted growth forecasts due to the euro zone's best growth run in a decade. Draghi emphasized the need to monitor the euro's volatility and its implications for the medium-term outlook for price stability.

site_title: China agrees more UN actions needed against North Korea after nuclear test
summary: China agreed the UN should take more action against North Korea after its nuclear test, while pushing for dialogue to resolve the crisis. The US wants the UN to impose sanctions, including an oil embargo and travel ban on leader Kim Jong Un. North Korea vowed to respond with "powerful counter measures" and accused the US of aiming to start a war. China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said any new actions should curb North Korea's nuclear and missile programmes while restarting dialogue.

site_title: Plenty of frights in IT - but its real-world violence scares the most
summary: The 2017 film "IT" directed by Andy Muschietti is a horror adaptation of Stephen King's 1986 novel. The story follows seven middle-school outcasts in 1988 Derry, Maine, as they investigate the disappearances of local kids by the shapeshifting monster Pennywise, played by Bill Skarsgard. The film's pacing is slow, but the cast's chemistry and Skarsgard's performance make it frightening, particularly in its portrayal of real-world violence. A sequel is planned, with the septet reunited 30 years later to face Pennywise again.

images.alt_text: Bill Skarsgard as Pennywise. The Swedish actor gets to unleash the killer clown's maniacal theatricality in IT.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: mm2 Entertainment, a subsidiary of mm2 Asia, will co-produce five films and multiple online films with two Chinese media companies, New Culture Media Hong Kong Ltd and 9i Film & Television Media Co Ltd, with a US$25 million investment. The partnership aims to capitalize on the popularity of online films in China. Meanwhile, TT International has been granted a temporary moratorium until February 11, 2018, to protect it from creditors. Noble Group's senior secured borrowing base revolving credit facility has been extended to January 15, 2018, to facilitate the sale of its global oil liquids business.

site_title: Liaoning is China's hotbed for shadow loans
summary: Liaoning, a northeastern Chinese province, has the highest concentration of shadow loans, accounting for 95% of regional bank lending in 2016. This is attributed to the province's slow economic growth. A study by UBS Group AG found this high concentration of shadow loans, which are unofficial loans not recorded on banks' balance sheets. This phenomenon is a concern for policymakers, as it may indicate financial instability and slow economic growth in the region.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment Group, Mongjakso to partner and produce So Ji Sub Drama
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group and Mongjakso Co Ltd have partnered to produce two TV dramas, including actor So Ji Sub's next project, "The Game", set for release in 2018. The partnership aims to tap into the growing popularity of Korean entertainment in South-east Asia. Spackman Entertainment, led by Charles Spackman, is expanding its business portfolio to diversify revenue streams. This move accelerates plans to enter the Korean drama series production business, leveraging Mongjakso's expertise in producing quality TV dramas.

site_title: 2 Singaporeans arrested under ISA for terrorism-related activities: MHA
summary: Two Singaporeans, Imran Kassim, 34, and Shakirah Begam Abdul Wahab, 23, were arrested under the Internal Security Act (ISA) in July for terrorism-related activities. Kassim was issued an Order of Detention for intending to undertake armed violence overseas, while Abdul Wahab was issued a Restriction Order for initiating and maintaining contact with foreign terrorist fighters. The Ministry of Home Affairs confirmed the arrests without providing further details.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down on lingering N. Korea fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.33% on September 7, 2017, due to lingering concerns over the North Korea nuclear crisis, despite positive leads from Wall Street and a deal by US President Donald Trump to avert a government shutdown. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,522.92, down 90.84 points.

site_title: Rickmers to continue ship management under new owners
summary: German shipping group Rickmers, which filed for insolvency in June, has found a solution to continue its ship management unit under new owners, Zeaborn Group and Bertram Rickmers. A consortium bought the division after winning a bidding process, with the goal of expanding and investing in the business. The deal is subject to approval by the German federal cartel office and follows an earlier restructuring plan that failed to win lender HSH Nordbank's approval. Rickmers, which employs 2,000 and has 114 ships, had doubled losses to 341 million euros in 2016.

site_title: Mixed response from Germany's call to stop Turkey's bid to join EU
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel calls for EU to stop Turkey's bid to join the bloc, drawing a mixed response from EU foreign ministers. Some, like Austria's Sebastian Kurz, support ending talks, while others, like Finland's Linas Linkevicius, argue against breaking off negotiations, citing the importance of maintaining contacts. French President Emmanuel Macron also emphasizes Turkey's value as a partner, despite concerns over President Tayyip Erdogan's human rights record. The EU is eager to preserve a deal that has stemmed migration from Turkey, but no formal decision is expected this year.

site_title: Hurricane Irma kills 8 on Caribbean island of Saint Martin
summary: Hurricane Irma has killed 8 people on the Caribbean island of Saint Martin, with 95% of the island destroyed. The storm has also devastated Barbuda, with 50% of residents homeless and 9 out of 10 buildings damaged. Irma's powerful winds have knocked out power on Saint Martin, Saint Barthelemy, and parts of Puerto Rico, with at least half of Puerto Rico's homes and businesses without power. The hurricane is expected to make landfall in Florida on Saturday or Sunday, becoming the second major hurricane to hit the US mainland in as many weeks.

site_title: China tightens regulation of religion to "block extremism"
