summary: China's cabinet has passed new rules to regulate religion, aiming to bolster national security and fight extremism. The rules, set to take effect on February 2, 2018, restrict faith practiced outside state-approved organizations and place new oversight on online discussions, gatherings, and fundraising. The regulations also increase fines for breaking the rules, with penalties ranging from 100,000 to 300,000 yuan. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to protect China's national security and prevent the spread of "extremist" ideology, while also promoting traditional faiths.

site_title: Japan, South Korea push Putin over Pyongyang sanctions
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Moon Jae In pushed for increased pressure on North Korea after its sixth and most powerful nuclear test, calling for immediate compliance with UN resolutions and abandonment of nuclear programs. The US, China, and EU are also demanding tougher sanctions, while Russia's Vladimir Putin insists diplomacy is the only solution. Despite mounting pressure, North Korea remains defiant, holding a mass celebration for its scientists involved in the nuclear test.

site_title: UK monthly house price growth hits 8-month high
summary: UK house prices rose 1.1% in August, the largest one-month increase since December, driven by strong employment growth and mortgage approvals. Annual growth accelerated to 2.6% from 2.1% in July. Despite this, wage growth concerns limit affordability. The Bank of England reported stronger-than-expected mortgage approvals in July, contradicting analyst expectations of a muted housing market outlook.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDB resale volume rose 9.6% month-over-month in August, while HDB prices increased 0.1%. Singapore-based social music startup BandLab acquired UK livestreaming service Chew.tv. Other news includes Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is back, darker than ever
summary: Rebel hacker Lisbeth Salander returns in the fifth book of the Millennium series, "The Girl Who Takes an Eye for an Eye", battling neo-Nazi prison gangs and honour killings while uncovering secrets about her troubled childhood. Author David Lagercrantz delves deeper into her mysterious past and adds more darkness to her character. The book draws inspiration from Sweden's issues, including a resurgent far-right movement and honour killings, which are fiercely debated topics in the country. The series, created by Stieg Larsson, has sold over 80 million copies worldwide.

site_title: McDonald's Japan adding stores as turnaround gains momentum
summary: McDonald's Japan is adding stores as it experiences a turnaround, with same-store sales climbing 21 consecutive months. The company plans to open 10 new stores in the second half of the year, while closing 7, resulting in a net addition of 3 stores for the year. This marks a significant shift after shuttering over 100 stores in 2015 due to food-contamination scandals. McDonald's Japan shares have gained 62% this year, outpacing the 30% gain for McDonald's globally, and CEO Sarah Casanova expects the trend of new store openings to continue next year.

site_title: Self-driving cars could have a long road to travel
summary: The US House of Representatives has approved the Self Drive Act, which aims to clear the path for self-driving cars nationwide by requiring consistent regulations across the 50 states. Industry trackers and analysts caution that technical challenges, legal, and liability issues will hinder the widespread adoption of self-driving cars. Despite major car makers' promises to have self-driving models in production by 2020, experts warn of a long road ahead, citing concerns over security, design complexity, and infrastructure.

site_title: China August FX reserves rise to US$3.092t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose to US$3.092 trillion in August, marking the seventh consecutive month of growth, but slightly less than market expectations. The reserves increased by US$10.5 billion, driven by tighter regulations and a weaker dollar. This is the first time reserves have climbed for seven months since June 2014, and represents the highest level since October last year. The yuan has appreciated 2% in August, recouping all 2016 losses.

site_title: Razer submits proposal for unified e-payment system
summary: Razer, a Singapore-based tech firm, has submitted a proposal for a unified e-payment system in the country, dubbed RazerPay. The proposal meets the two-week deadline set by Razer's CEO Tan Min-Liang. The system is designed in line with existing guidelines set by the Government, aiming to simplify e-payments in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed following Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended Thursday at 3,228.06, down 4.41 points, following a quiet trading session. The local market was influenced by a firm overnight Wall Street and a possible weak US market opening. Despite this, the index traded within a narrow band and closed with a 0.4% gain. The mixed session was attributed to a short-term US deal on the debt ceiling and hurricane relief, but observers warned that the problem would resurface soon. Turnover was S$1.14 billion, with an advance-decline score of 194-192, excluding warrants.

site_title: BMW gears up to mass produce electric cars by 2020
summary: BMW plans to mass produce electric cars by 2020 and will have 12 fully-electric models by 2025, with a range of up to 700 km. The move comes as traditional manufacturers face pressure to speed up development of zero-emission alternatives due to growing demand and global pollution concerns. BMW's investment in battery technology aims to bring down costs, which currently make up 30-50% of an electric vehicle's cost. The company's goal is to make electric cars competitive with combustion-engined equivalents by 2020-2030, with Europe potentially becoming a 100% pure battery electric vehicle market by 2035.

site_title: Gap closing hundreds of stores in shift toward Old Navy
summary: Gap Inc plans to refocus on Old Navy and Athleta brands, closing hundreds of stores that carry the Gap and Banana Republic names. The company aims to concentrate on e-commerce, value-priced products, and activewear, areas where its flagship brands have struggled. As part of the shift, Gap expects Old Navy's sales to exceed $10 billion and Athleta's to exceed $1 billion. The company will close 200 underperforming Gap and Banana Republic stores, while opening 270 new Old Navy and Athleta locations, sending shares up 7.4% on the announcement.

site_title: Australian retail loses its fizz, trade surplus shrinks
summary: Australia's retail sales remained flat in July, contradicting expectations of a 0.3% increase, due to stagnant wages and rising utility bills. The Reserve Bank of Australia fears ballooning debt in the property sector is hindering consumer spending. The country's trade surplus also narrowed unexpectedly to $460 million, with export earnings falling 2.2% due to declining commodity prices. Economists predict a slowdown in GDP growth, with some forecasting a 2.5% growth rate, forcing the RBA to keep interest rates at 1.5% until late 2019.

site_title: China's widening trade surplus remains a red flag for Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is threatening to stop trade with any country doing business with North Korea, amid escalating tensions with China over its massive trade surplus. China's trade surplus with the US grew to $48.5 billion in August, swelling the gap to $143.5 billion in the first seven months of the year. Despite China's pledge to import more from the US, the trade deficit remains a major concern for Trump, who is seeking to increase pressure on China to help rein in North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Fake Brazilian warzone 'photographer' duped BBC and others
summary: A Brazilian individual posing as war photographer Eduardo Martins duped BBC and other news outlets with fake photos and videos from the Middle East and Africa. Martins' Instagram account, which had 120,000 followers, was later found to be a scam, with photos edited to evade plagiarism detection software. None of Martins' supposed work was confirmed by the UN or Brazilian journalists, and his true identity remains unknown. The scam, which lasted several years, was exposed after Martins contacted a BBC journalist, leading to the disappearance of his Instagram account.

site_title: Australia state raises gold royalty, other mining fees to repair budget
summary: Western Australia's state government has raised gold royalty payments to 3.75% from 2.5% per ounce to repair its budget, generating an additional A$392 million over four years. The move, aimed at addressing a budget deficit of A$3.04 billion in 2017, is expected to impact gold miners, who claim they cannot afford the increased costs. The new royalty rate is triggered by a gold price above A$1,200 per ounce, and other mining sectors face added costs, including a 17% increase in annual dues for the Pilbara Ports Authority.

site_title: Merkel vows to press on with rallies despite jeers
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to continue her election campaign rallies despite jeers and whistles from protesters, particularly from far-right groups. At rallies in eastern states, demonstrators chanted slogans and made the Nazi salute, but Merkel said she would not be deterred. She aims to show "civil courage" and stand up against hate, despite polls showing her conservative alliance leading by 15 percentage points. Merkel's decision to open Germany's borders to refugees in 2015 has also been a divisive issue.

site_title: Australia shares end flat as BHP, Woolworths drag; NZ slightly up
summary: Australia's shares ended flat, closing 0.17 points higher at 5,689.90, despite early gains due to receding tensions on the Korean peninsula. BHP and Woolworths dragged the market down, with Woolworths' shares falling 1.8% due to a disappointing retail sales report. The consumer staples sector also saw a 0.3% decline. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.18% due to gains in consumer and healthcare shares.

site_title: All new Jaguar Land Rover cars to have electric option from 2020
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to offer electric or hybrid options for all new cars from 2020, accelerating its efforts to electrify its model range. The company aims to release a range of powertrain options, including fully electric, plug-in hybrid, and mild hybrid vehicles. This move comes as demand for low-emissions models rises, with the UK set to ban new petrol and diesel car sales by 2040. Jaguar Land Rover will build its first electric model, the I-PACE, in Austria, and is also exploring new technologies such as autonomous and connected cars.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia holds key rate as growth is solid
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3% as expected, maintaining an accommodative monetary policy stance. The central bank expects solid economic growth driven by domestic demand, improving incomes, and infrastructure projects. Annual headline inflation eased to 3.2% in July, a fourth consecutive month of slowing growth. The decision follows the central bank's 25 basis point rate cut in July 2016, which was in response to the Brexit vote.

site_title: Barry Callebaut strengthens US gourmet business
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut has acquired the ingredients division of US firm Gertrude Hawk Chocolates for an undisclosed sum. The move aims to strengthen Barry Callebaut's gourmet and specialties business, which saw a 11.6% sales volume rise in the first nine months of the company's fiscal year. The acquisition, expected to close in October, will expand Barry Callebaut's product portfolio and offer an even wider range of products and services. The deal is seen as a strategic fit, according to analysts, and is expected to boost the company's growth.

site_title: Sterling steadies above US$1.30, eyes on ECB
summary: Sterling steadied above $1.30, but remains near 11-month lows, with traders citing resistance to further gains against the US dollar. The pound dipped 0.1% against the euro and dollar, with offers to sell sterling around $1.31-$1.32 likely to cap further gains. The European Central Bank's policy statement and post-meeting news conference on Thursday may influence sterling's value, with expectations of a possible cut in monetary stimulus driving gains for the euro.

site_title: UK's Euromoney to consider options for market intelligence unit
summary: UK's Euromoney Institutional Investor is considering strategic options for its Global Markets Intelligence division, which provides market intelligence and has customers in China, India, and Eastern Europe. The division reported $52.7 million in revenue in 2016. Euromoney has received unsolicited interest from potential buyers and engaged advisers to assess its options. The decision comes as the company reviews its assets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise as US suspends discussions of FTA termination
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.1% to a one-week high on Thursday as the US suspended plans to end its free trade pact with Seoul, improving investor sentiment. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,346.19 points. The won strengthened 0.5% to 1,1129.4 to the dollar. Despite the rally, North Korea risks remain, with South Korea deploying additional anti-missile defenses.

site_title: Saudi King to visit White House in 2018
summary: King Salman of Saudi Arabia will visit the White House in early 2018 for talks with President Donald Trump. The two leaders discussed advancing shared goals such as strengthening security and prosperity in the Middle East, with an agreement made for the visit.

images.alt_text: King Salman of Saudi Arabia will make an official visit to Washington early next year for talks with President Donald Trump, the White House said Wednesday.

site_title: Asia: Markets up as Trump debt deal diverts from North Korea
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as US President Donald Trump agreed to a deal to raise the US debt ceiling, providing relief after a North Korea-fueled sell-off this week. Trump's insistence on a diplomatic solution and his call for military action not being his "first choice" eased tensions, boosting markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Seoul. However, concerns remain about North Korea's nuclear program, and analysts warn that the situation could deteriorate. The dollar held gains against the yen, while the Canadian dollar surged after the central bank announced a surprise interest rate hike.

site_title: Australia shares up on Wall Street lift, energy sector; NZ steady
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, driven by a lift on Wall Street and a rally in the energy sector. The benchmark index recovered from the previous day's loss, boosted by news of US President Donald Trump agreeing to extend the US debt limit. Global miner Rio Tinto jumped after increasing its coal reserve estimate, also supporting the market. Receding tensions on the Korean peninsula contributed to the gain.

site_title: Apple, LG said to discuss OLED deal for supplies starting 2019
summary: Apple is unlikely to surpass Samsung as a significant supplier of OLED screens for iPhones until 2019, according to people familiar with the matter. LG Display, a long-time supplier of liquid crystal displays, is targeting full-fledged shipments of OLED screens in 2019, with limited shipments possible by the end of 2018. Apple has been seeking alternative suppliers due to Samsung's dominance in OLED technology, which has been used in its own phones and sold to Apple rivals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks snap three-day losing streak as automakers rise
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index snapped a three-day losing streak, gaining 0.20% to close at 19,396.52. The rise was driven by a weakening yen, which boosted exporters, including Toyota and Nissan. The broader Topix index also rose 0.39%. The gains come despite ongoing US trade tensions and uncertainty, with investors maintaining a positive outlook.

site_title: Singapore social music startup BandLab buys UK livestreaming service Chew.tv
summary: Singapore-based social music startup BandLab Technologies has acquired UK livestreaming service Chew.tv, rebranded as "Chew by BandLab". Chew.tv will integrate its livestreaming technology into BandLab's platform and apps for its 2 million users, supporting DJs in bringing live performances online. The acquisition aims to digitally support creators and musicians, a key aspect of BandLab's flagship digital product, a social music platform.

site_title: Australia court dismisses challenge to gay marriage postal vote
summary: Australia's High Court dismissed two challenges to a same-sex marriage postal vote, allowing a national survey on legalizing such unions to proceed. The decision came days before ballot papers were due to be sent to 15 million people. The challenges argued that the government exceeded its powers in funding the ballot without parliamentary approval. The postal vote is a voluntary survey, and the High Court's decision paves the way for Australians to weigh in on the issue.

site_title: India's army chief says China 'testing limits' after stand-off
summary: India's army chief, General Bipin Rawat, has warned that China is "testing India's limits" after their recent border stand-off, stating that his country must be prepared for war. Rawat accused China of gradually taking over territory through "salami slicing" and warned that tensions could escalate into an all-out war. He also expressed concern that Pakistan, an ally of China, may take advantage of the situation. This comes after India and China withdrew troops from a disputed border region last month.

site_title: Fed leadership questions aside, policy outlook getting clearer
summary: The US Federal Reserve is moving forward with its plan to shrink its $4.5 trillion balance sheet, with a policy decision set for September 20, following a deal to extend the debt ceiling by three months. This move may make current Fed policymakers more comfortable with implementing the plan, which was already in place. Meanwhile, uncertainty surrounding Fed leadership, including Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer's departure, is expected to continue. The Fed's next policy decision will be its last under Fischer's leadership, marking the end of an era.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.44 points to 1,773.92 on Thursday, with volume reaching 62.38 million lots worth RM17.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 126 to 35.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.39% at the open on Thursday, following losses at the start of the week due to the North Korean nuclear crisis. The Hang Seng Index opened at 27,722.36. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index inched down 0.05%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. The rally is attributed to investors regaining confidence, despite ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: mm2 Asia unit, Chinese media firms to jointly invest US$25m to produce films
summary: A unit of mm2 Asia Ltd will jointly invest US$25 million with two Chinese media companies, New Culture Media Hong Kong Ltd and 9i Film & Television Media Co Ltd, to co-produce five films and multiple online films over the next three years. This partnership aims to capitalize on the growing popularity of online films in China.

site_title: Changi Garden to be put up for collective sale by tender with S$196m asking price
summary: The freehold property Changi Garden is up for collective sale through public tender with an asking price of S$196 million. The property, developed in the late 1970s and early 1980s, comprises 60 apartments, 12 penthouses, and 12 shops. The tender will offer gross sale proceeds ranging from S$1.69 million to S$5.5 million.

site_title: AXA policyholders' data breached after cyber attack
summary: AXA Insurance confirmed a cyber attack compromised the personal data of 5,400 past and present policyholders on a health portal, exposing email addresses, mobile numbers, and policy numbers. However, AXA stated that no other sensitive data, such as names, identification numbers, addresses, or financial details, was breached. The insurer apologized for the breach and assured that measures are being taken to prevent future incidents.

site_title: Trump strikes shock budget deal with Democrats
summary: President Donald Trump has agreed to a budget deal with Democrats, easing US borrowing limits and avoiding a government shutdown until December 15. The deal provides billions in funding for Hurricane Harvey recovery and is seen as a positive step forward by Democrats, but Republicans are critical, fearing it will embolden Democrats ahead of the 2018 mid-term elections. Trump's decision has strained relations with Republican leaders, who had pushed for a long-term debt ceiling extension.

site_title: Malaysia decision guide: central bank in inflation sweet spot
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, is in a favorable position with economic growth gaining momentum, inflation moderating, and the ringgit poised for its first annual gain in five years. After four quarters of expansion, the overnight policy rate is expected to remain at 3% following a recent survey of 21 economists. The economy has expanded faster than predicted, driven by a global trade recovery and resilient domestic demand, while inflation has eased from an eight-year high in March. The central bank has left borrowing costs unchanged since a surprise reduction in July last year.

site_title: Draghi kicks off the QE exit debate he has long sought to avoid
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi kicked off a debate on the future path of stimulus, marking the start of discussions on winding down asset purchases. The ECB has been concerned about low inflation and market turmoil, but Draghi acknowledged the need to begin dialing down quantitative easing while providing gradual assurances. The decision-making process is expected to continue until the October meeting, with economists predicting no change in interest rates but focusing on altered forward guidance.

site_title: Donald Sutherland to receive honorary Oscar
summary: Canadian actor Donald Sutherland, 82, will receive an honorary Oscar for his six-decade film career, which includes his breakout role in "The Dirty Dozen" (1967). Sutherland is a two-time Golden Globe winner with over 140 film credits. He will be honored at the Academy's 9th Annual Governors Awards in November alongside writer-director Charles Burnett, cinematographer Owen Roizman, and filmmaker Agnes Varda.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2 Asia, Ipco, Citic Envirotech
summary: mm2 Asia Ltd signed a memorandum of understanding with New Culture Media Hong Kong Ltd and 9i Film & Television Media Co Ltd. Ipco International Limited reported a net loss for the fiscal first quarter due to translation effects. Citic Envirotech Ltd took a 60% stake in Citic Environment Technology Development Co Ltd for S$78.3 million, resulting in a 2.05% decline in its shares.

site_title: Keppel O&M, Pavilion Gas tie up with PLN on small scale LNG in west Indonesia
summary: Keppel O&M and Pavilion Gas have partnered with Indonesia's state-owned electricity provider PLN to distribute liquefied natural gas (LNG) to remote islands in west Indonesia. The plan involves delivering LNG using small vessels to floating and onshore terminals, where it will be regasified and used to generate electricity at PLN's power plants. A Heads of Agreement was signed on Thursday at the Singapore-Indonesia Leaders' Retreat in Singapore. The partnership aims to enhance energy cooperation between Indonesia and Singapore, with small-scale LNG playing a key role in Singapore's regional LNG storage and distribution hub.

site_title: HDB pumps in S$10.7m in R&D collaboration with 2 local universities
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has invested S$10.7 million in research and development collaborations with Nanyang Technological University and Singapore University of Technology and Design. The three-year agreements focus on leveraging big data and smart technology to enhance construction productivity and safety. The collaborations include developing a smart integrated construction system and a "New Urban Kampung" research programme to create housing solutions tailored to residents' evolving needs. Minister Lawrence Wong officiated the agreements at the International Housing Forum on sustainable urban development.

site_title: Fed's Fischer resigns, leaving Trump earlier chance to shape central bank
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer is resigning in mid-October, potentially allowing President Donald Trump to reshape the central bank's direction. Fischer cited personal reasons for his departure, which leaves the Fed's seven-person board with as few as three members. The move intensifies Trump's urgency to overhaul US monetary policy, particularly with Fed Chair Janet Yellen's term set to expire in February. Fischer's departure may lower the likelihood of another Fed interest rate increase this year, and his departure could have significant implications for the Fed's future leadership.

site_title: Kim and Kanye expecting third baby via surrogate: US media
summary: Kim Kardashian and Kanye West are expecting their third child via a surrogate, according to US media. The couple, married since 2014, have a son and a daughter, and given Kardashian's past health scares, they opted for surrogacy. Kardashian, 36, had been searching for a surrogate for months before finding the perfect candidate. The baby is due at the end of January.

site_title: Vitamin World to file for bankruptcy protection
summary: Vitamin World, a vitamin and supplement retailer, plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy to exit costly lease agreements for some of its stores. The company, which has about 345 stores, will file for bankruptcy as soon as this month. CEO Michael Madden cited the need to restructure the company's real estate portfolio after struggling to negotiate with landlords. The move comes amid pressure from e-commerce and declining sales of specialty retailers, with shares of Vitamin World's competitors falling over 60% in the past year.

site_title: US airlines brace themselves, passengers for Hurricane Irma
summary: US airlines, including American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and JetBlue, have adjusted flight schedules and made cancellations ahead of Hurricane Irma's expected landfall in Florida. Airlines have implemented fare caps, with JetBlue and American offering $99 and $399 fares, respectively, for residents trying to evacuate the storm's path. Senators have called for an investigation into potential price-gouging schemes. Meanwhile, Canadian carriers and cruise lines have also taken measures to assist passengers affected by the storm.

site_title: China's military practises for "surprise attack" over sea near Korea
summary: China's air force conducted exercises near the Korean peninsula to defend against a "surprise attack" coming over the sea, simulating real battle scenarios. The drills, which included the use of certain unidentified weapons, were part of an annual plan to boost troops' capabilities and took place near the Bohai Sea. The exercises come amid rising tensions over North Korea's nuclear tests and the potential deployment of US aircraft carriers and strategic bombers to the region. China has expressed anger at a US anti-missile defense system in South Korea.

site_title: Ageing populations will drag on growth in Asia: IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns that ageing populations in key Asian economies, including China, Japan, South Korea, and Thailand, will drag on growth, with Japan forecast to become the first "ultra-aged" country by 2025. The IMF estimates these countries could face lower annual GDP growth by up to a percentage point. Lagarde urges policymakers to boost women's participation in the workforce, particularly in China and Japan, where closing the gender gap could raise GDP by 9-27%. The IMF also warns that parts of Asia risk becoming old before becoming rich due to low birth rates and declining working-age populations.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rebound as US shelves talk of scuttling trade deal
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded 1.1% on Thursday, breaking a five-day losing streak, after the White House suspended internal discussions about terminating the US trade agreement with Seoul. The announcement overshadowed concerns about the US anti-missile Thaad system deployment amid North Korea's provocations. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose to 2,345.63 points, boosting the won.

site_title: Russia-linked Facebook accounts stoked US divisions
summary: Facebook has found hundreds of Russia-linked fake accounts spent approximately $100,000 on ads inflaming US political tensions ahead of and following the 2016 presidential election. The accounts, which may have been part of an orchestrated campaign, ran ads promoting fake or misleading news and driving traffic to such pages. Facebook shut down the accounts, which were affiliated with each other and likely operated out of Russia, and reported the findings to US authorities.

site_title: The king is dead, long live the new 'Narcos' drug lords
summary: The Netflix series Narcos shifts its focus to the notorious Cali Cartel in season three, following the death of Pablo Escobar. The Cali Cartel, known as "los caballeros" or the gentlemen, is a multi-billion dollar organization that controls up to 90% of the world's cocaine supply. Led by Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, the cartel runs its business like a Fortune 500 company, making alliances and bribes to maintain power. The show explores the cartel's unique leadership structure and their approach to drug trafficking, which is more corporate and secretive than Escobar's public campaign of violence.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us said to hires advisers to help restructure debt
summary: Toys 'R' Us hires lawyers at Kirkland & Ellis to help restructure its US$400 million in debt due next year, amid struggles to compete with Amazon and discount chains. The company has also retained Lazard Ltd to refinance debt. A restructuring could help the retailer prepare for the holiday season, but bankruptcy remains a possibility. Toys 'R' Us has sufficient liquidity for 2017, but its private equity owners loaded the retailer with debt in a US$7.5 billion buyout over a decade ago.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 9.47 points to 3,241.94, driven by a US stocks rebound and President Donald Trump's support for a debt limit extension. The most actively traded counter was Accrelist, with 3 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 29, while other regional markets, including Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi, also rose.

site_title: Ready-to-use home-made explosives found in Paris suburb
summary: Homemade explosives ready for use were found in an unoccupied flat in Villejuif, a Paris suburb, on Wednesday. Two men were arrested nearby. The explosives, identified as TATP, are commonly used by the Islamic State group, which has targeted France in recent years. The discovery was made by judicial sources, and the motive behind the explosives is still unclear.

site_title: Fed sees limited wage pressures as labour market remains tight
summary: The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report showed modest economic growth in the US, with labour markets remaining tight despite moderate employment growth and limited wage pressures. Consumer spending, capital expenditures, and manufacturing all increased, but the auto industry emerged as a possible source of weakness. The report found subdued inflation, with the Fed's preferred measure at 1.4% and prices rising modestly across the country.

site_title: Oil up after Harvey fallout; Irma heads toward Florida
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday due to strong refining margins and reopened US Gulf Coast refineries following Hurricane Harvey. However, traders remain cautious about Hurricane Irma, which is heading towards Florida, and another tropical storm Jose, which strengthened into a hurricane and could impact demand. The oil price increase is a relief after Harvey's impact led to sharp drops, but the threat of Irma and Jose remains a concern for fuel shortages.

site_title: South Korea deploys US anti-missile launchers amid clashes with protesters
summary: South Korea deployed the remaining four US anti-missile launchers of the Thaad system to protect against North Korea's threats. The deployment was met with clashes between protesters and police in a village near the golf course, resulting in 38 injuries. The move is opposed by China, which believes the system's radar could be used to look into its territory and disrupt regional security. The deployment is seen as necessary due to North Korea's recent nuclear tests and missile launches, with the US seeking UN sanctions against the country.

site_title: May's Brexit battle returns to parliament
summary: British lawmakers will begin debating a landmark bill to end Britain's membership of the European Union, with Prime Minister Theresa May gearing up for a major battle. The bill, known as the "Great Repeal Bill," would repeal the European Communities Act and convert 12,000 existing EU regulations into British law, providing legal continuity to prevent a "cliff-edge" when Britain leaves the EU in March 2019. However, opposition parties have vowed to fight the bill, calling it a "power grab" that would give the government sweeping powers to amend laws without proper scrutiny.

site_title: US pushes oil embargo on North Korea, takes aim at Kim Jong Un
summary: The US has asked the UN to impose an oil embargo on North Korea and freeze the assets of leader Kim Jong Un, amid Pyongyang's sixth and largest nuclear test. The proposed resolution would also ban textile exports, restrict guest worker payments, and scrap joint ventures with North Korea. China and Russia are opposed to the measures, citing concerns over humanitarian crises and potential instability. The US and China agreed to strengthen coordination and take further action towards denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but details of the plan remain unclear.

site_title: Tennis: Talk like a man! Federer not 'boyfriend' material, says Nadal
summary: Rafael Nadal calmed speculation about a possible romantic relationship with Roger Federer by jokingly stating he didn't want to be seen as Federer's "boyfriend". Nadal expressed respect for Federer, calling him a "great ambassador for tennis" and admiring his sportsmanship and values. The two tennis legends have a long history of rivalry and mutual respect, and Nadal hopes to keep their relationship focused on the court rather than their personal lives.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as lower yen lifts exporters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, breaking a three-day losing streak, due to a weaker yen lifting exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.46% to 19,447.96, and the Topix index gained 0.47% to 1,599.47. The move was seen as a positive response to the slightly weaker yen, which makes Japanese exports more competitive.

site_title: Fresh interest in autos helps German shares outshine European market
summary: German shares rose to 10-day highs on Wednesday, driven by a rally in auto stocks, with the German blue chip index gaining 0.8% and Europe's auto index rising 1.7%. Upbeat broker notes and expectations of emission cuts boosted shares in Volkswagen, Daimler, and Fiat Chrysler, which rose 3.2%, 4.3%, and 4.3% respectively. Investors also saw a positive outlook from efforts to avert diesel bans and potential US car replacements.

site_title: United will not face fines after passenger dragging incident: US official
summary: The US government has decided not to fine United Continental Holdings Inc after a 69-year-old man was dragged from a flight in April. The Transportation Department notified United in a letter, stating it did not comply with government rules on overselling seats. The decision was criticized by a passenger rights group. The incident, which went viral, involved David Dao being dragged from a United aircraft at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport after he refused to give up his seat. United has not commented on the decision.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific back in the black for Q1 on strong sales in Asia
summary: Del Monte Pacific Ltd reported a net profit of US$740,000 in its first quarter, reversing a net loss of US$7.0 million in the previous year, driven by strong sales in Asia. Revenue edged up 1.4% to US$473.8 million, with the S&W business in Asia contributing to the growth. The company expects to be profitable for the 2018 financial year on a recurring basis and will explore e-commerce opportunities. Despite lower sales in the US, the group's loss per share narrowed to 0.13 US cents.

site_title: Banks look to step up employee surveillance after latest scandal
summary: Banks are exploring the use of technology to monitor retail-banking salespeople and loan officers after the Wells Fargo & Co scandal, which involved employees opening 3.5 million bogus accounts. IBM's Watson AI program, trained to collect information and detect suspicious patterns, is being tested by several major US banks to help uncover potential misconduct. The system can analyze employee emails, transaction records, and performance data to identify trends and alert executives to potential issues, with the goal of enhancing regulatory compliance and protecting customers.

site_title: Saudi Arabia seeks Islamic tourism boost in nation's economic reform
summary: Saudi Arabia is seeking to boost its Islamic tourism industry as part of its economic reform programme, aiming to diversify the economy away from oil. The country plans to relax pilgrimage visa restrictions and increase tourism infrastructure, including hotels, museums, and historical sites, to attract more pilgrims. Officials aim to increase umrah and haj pilgrims to 15 million and 5 million respectively by 2020, and 30 million by 2030. However, critics argue that the high costs and limited accessibility of tourism options will deter many pilgrims, particularly those from modest means.

site_title: Gender debate in UK spills into children's clothing
summary: British retailer John Lewis has removed gender-specific labels from its children's clothing, introducing unisex babywear instead. The move aims to overcome stereotypes and provide greater choice to customers. The change has sparked a debate, with some parents and critics accusing the store of succumbing to "political correctness" and others praising the move for promoting inclusiveness. The retailer's head of children's wear stated that the goal is to provide a more neutral and varied shopping experience for parents and children.

site_title: Few signs of progress in ongoing Nafta talks
summary: US, Canada, and Mexico's second round of NAFTA renegotiation talks concluded with little major progress, despite optimistic statements from officials. The talks will continue on September 23 in Ottawa, with the US pushing for changes to the "rules of origin" and dispute settlement system. Canada and Mexico remain committed to finding a deal, but concerns over wages in Mexico and right-to-work laws in the US may hinder progress. The talks are likely to be driven by US President Trump's politics and whims, raising questions about the feasibility of rewriting NAFTA this year.

site_title: Malaysia's July exports up 31%, led again by manufactured goods
summary: Malaysia's exports increased by 31% in July to RM79 billion, driven by a surge in manufactured goods, particularly electrical and electronic products. The trade surplus reached RM8 billion, with exports to Asean and China rising by double digits. The country's trade with major partners expanded by 22%, with imports increasing by 22% to RM70.6 billion. The robust export performance boosted Malaysia's GDP growth to 5.7% for the first half, but the retail sector remains sluggish.

site_title: The Korean cauldron creates dilemmas for the US
summary: US President Donald Trump's stance on North Korea's sixth nuclear bomb detonation has raised concerns about the future of the US military alliance with South Korea. Despite reiterating his commitment to defending the South Korean ally, Trump has threatened to withdraw the US from its free-trade agreement with Seoul, sparking criticism from Washington's foreign-policy establishment. This move reflects a shift in Trump's views, which diverge from the traditional narrative of the US as the leader of the West, and instead align with those of many Americans who are skeptical of US involvement in global economic and security arrangements.

site_title: High Court grants TT International's moratorium application
summary: TT International, a consumer electronics retailer, has been granted a moratorium by the High Court until February 11, 2018, temporarily protecting it from creditors. The moratorium order restrains creditors from taking further action against the company, including appointing a receiver or manager over its properties. The company had requested voluntary suspension of trading on August 4.

site_title: Samsung's Lee replaces lawyer ahead of appeal
summary: Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee has replaced his lawyer ahead of an appeal against a five-year jail term for bribery and other charges. The change comes as Lee prepares to challenge the conviction, which was handed down in February for bribing then-President Park Geun Hye to secure control of the conglomerate. Lee's new lawyer, Lee In Jae, is a more senior representative at law firm Bae, Kim & Lee LLC, aimed at "reinforcing" the executive's legal team.

site_title: Europe court backs employee fired over private messages
summary: The European Court of Human Rights has ruled in favor of a Romanian man, Bogdan Mihai Barbulescu, who was fired for sending private chat messages in the office. The court found that his employer's snooping on his private messages infringed on his right to respect for his private life and correspondence. The ruling, backed by 11 votes to six, sets a precedent for employees' right to privacy in the workplace, and its implications will be felt in the 47 countries that have ratified the European Convention on Human Rights.

site_title: Singapore economy expected to grow by 3.1% in Q3: economists
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by 3.1% in the third quarter of 2017, according to a poll of economists by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The full-year forecast remains at 2.5% growth, with non-oil domestic exports projected to grow 7.4% and manufacturing at 6.6%. Analysts, however, caution that manufacturing strength may not be sustainable. Unemployment rate is expected to remain at 2.2% at year-end.

site_title: Reits, banks hit in weak session
summary: The Straits Times Index dropped 18.79 points to 3,232.47 on Wednesday, following a weak Wall Street session due to concerns over North Korea and the US debt ceiling. A sell-off in real estate investment trusts (Reits) saw 18 of the top 20 actives close lower, resulting in a 0.83% drop in the FTSE FT Reit index. Market watchers attributed the Reit sell-off to proposed rights issues by Cache Logistics Trust and Manulife US Reit, citing market uncertainty over this year's cash raising by Reits.

site_title: US dollar tumbles versus loonie after Bank of Canada raises rates
summary: The US dollar fell 1.9% against the Canadian dollar to a multiyear low of C$1.2140, after the Bank of Canada raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 1%, putting Canada ahead of the curve. This move countered expectations and boosted the Canadian dollar. The US dollar also rose against the yen, likely due to President Trump's agreement to pass a debt limit extension.

site_title: Buildings too antiquated to use, too grand to demolish
summary: A US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) building, the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers, has been left to crumble after being deemed too antiquated to renovate and too grand to demolish. Despite being sealed for 28 years, the building has been leased to a private developer to transform into 80 apartments for homeless veterans. However, a nearby historic theatre, Ward Memorial Hall, remains empty and is slated for demolition, highlighting the challenges of preserving VA properties. The VA has 430 vacant buildings, with many over 90 years old, costing the department at least $7 million annually to maintain.

site_title: Florida's tech scene may give the West Coast hub a run for its money
summary: Florida's tech scene is gaining momentum, with venture capital investments more than doubling in the past 5 years to a record $1.7 billion. The state is attracting top talent and investors, with companies like Magic Leap, JetSmarter, and Chewy setting up shop in Miami and Fort Lauderdale. While Silicon Valley remains a hub, Florida's advantages, including affordable office space and a low cost of living, are drawing entrepreneurs and investors. Magic Leap's founder, Rony Abovitz, is leading the charge, and the region may be on the verge of a breakthrough.

site_title: Keep quarterly reporting; better still, give even more updates via social media
summary: A letter to the editor argues against removing quarterly reporting requirements for listed companies in Singapore. The writer suggests tweaking the current method of market capitalization thresholds and allowing shareholders to decide on the frequency of reports. They emphasize the importance of quarterly reports for investors, citing the Council on Corporate Disclosure and Governance's review and affirmation of the requirement a decade ago. The writer believes that leveraging social media for regular updates is a more feasible solution than removing quarterly reporting, which would be detrimental to retail investors and the attractiveness of the Singapore market.

site_title: HK to launch 'starter homes' for those priced out of private housing
summary: Hong Kong's newly-elected leader Carrie Lam announced a "Starter Homes" programme, aimed at providing affordable flats to middle-income residents priced out of private housing. The programme will offer subsidised sale flats with simple designs and interiors, priced according to the land's affordability, to those earning above the current Home Ownership Scheme's ceiling of HK$52,000 per month. The initiative is seen as a temporary solution to Hong Kong's housing crisis, with experts warning that the scheme's long-term viability is uncertain and may not meet the expectations of middle-income buyers.

site_title: Naiise story about designs
summary: Naiise, a Singapore-based online platform for design products, has expanded to 1,067 brands, including 800 local designers. Founded by Dennis Tay in 2013, the company started with an initial investment of S$3,000 and has grown to S$5 million in revenue. Naiise now has five physical stores in Singapore and recently expanded to Malaysia, offering a wide range of original and uniquely designed products for everyday use.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ETC proposes acquiring 87% stake in Uni Global Power for US$11.9 million. Mercator Lines faces winding-up application due to lack of justification for extension. CITIC Envirotech takes 60% stake in Citic Environment in Guangdong Province for S$78.3 million. Hotel Properties Limited acquires land in Republic of Palau for US$8.5 million. IPCO International expects net loss for fiscal first quarter due to translation effects. OCBC appoints Tan Teck Long as incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Boeing, Airbus voice doubts over US$23b supplier merger
summary: Boeing and Airbus have expressed concerns over a proposed US$23 billion merger between United Technologies and Rockwell Collins, citing potential distractions to key suppliers and disruptions to their own business operations. The planemakers, which hold significant influence over supplier contracts, have warned they would take action to protect their interests if the deal is deemed to harm their customers and industry. United Technologies shares plummeted by the most in two years, and credit ratings companies have downgraded the manufacturer's rating due to the uncertainty surrounding the deal.

images.alt_text: United Technologies will hold calls with customers to discuss the merits of the deal, says chief executive Greg Hayes.

site_title: Will the research conundrum ever be resolved?
summary: Rowsley Holdings, a diversified real estate company controlled by billionaire Peter Lim, has seen its shares actively traded despite not having any broking research coverage. Similar cases of companies like Cordlife Group, a healthcare firm, and Jiutian Chemical, a chemical company, have also been overlooked. The lack of research coverage is attributed to brokers' limited resources and the need to prioritize coverage of more liquid stocks. The Singapore Exchange and Monetary Authority have attempted to address this issue through funding schemes, but the problem persists due to suppressed trading volumes and thin broking margins.

site_title: Triyards sounds warning on going-concern status, cites loan repayment issues
summary: Tiriards Holdings, a Singapore-based marine, shipping, and oil & gas company, has warned of potential going-concern status due to loan repayment issues. The company faces difficulties in accessing new liquidity and has been unable to deliver vessels to clients within specified delivery periods. It has received demand letters from lenders for overdue loan instalments totaling US$0.8 million, and negotiations are underway to establish new delivery timelines. Triyards has engaged a financial adviser to develop a restructuring plan, citing an aggregate loan amount of US$6.9 million and potential cross-defaults.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Nissan takes electric vehicle battle to Tesla with longer-range Leaf
summary: Nissan has launched a revamped version of its Leaf electric vehicle (EV) with a longer range of approximately 241 kilometers on a single charge, competing with Tesla's Model 3. The new Leaf features a sporty facelift, automated functions, and a starting price of $39,157. However, analysts argue that the limited range remains a barrier to mass market adoption, with industry experts suggesting a range of 400 km or more at a price of $30,000 is needed to drive significant EV sales.

site_title: Getting the world's crisis funds to work closer together
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and regional financing arrangements (RFAs) are collaborating to combat financial crises. The first research seminar of regional institutions contributing to fighting financial crises is taking place in Singapore, focusing on cooperation between RFAs and the IMF to limit crisis effects. Eight RFAs worldwide, including the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralisation (CMIM) and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), are working together to enhance surveillance, crisis resolution, and early warning systems. The seminar aims to foster collaboration, share lessons from past crises, and address moral hazard risks.

site_title: MSCI chief: world of passive investing won't last forever
summary: MSCI's CEO, Henry Fernandez, believes the world of passive investing won't last forever, as conditions that favor it, such as bull markets and low costs, are not permanent. Passive management works best when there's a focus on cost management and one is fully invested. Active management will show its value when the economy improves and monetary policy recedes, and asset returns are higher. Despite this, MSCI is well-positioned, with steady revenue growth and increasing demand for its factor and ESG indices. The firm is investing heavily in digital platforms and analytics to provide easy access to financial data, potentially increasing its revenues exponentially.

site_title: Brexit threatens subsidies for UK's landed gentry and the Queen
summary: The UK's decision to leave the European Union may threaten subsidies for the country's landed gentry, including Queen Elizabeth II, who receives over $675,000 in EU farm subsidies annually for her Sandringham estate. The subsidies, part of the Common Agricultural Policy, are set to change once Britain is out of the bloc, with the British Parliament inheriting the issue. Critics argue that the subsidies favor large landowners, while supporters argue that the subsidies support livelihoods and the environment. The British government has promised to retain current subsidies until 2022, but hints at future changes.

images.alt_text: The queen's idyllic 8,000-hectare estate at Sandringham is among the huge holdings supported by the annual payouts, receiving more than US$675,000 in European farm subsidies last year.

site_title: The rich used to say 'no' to getting richer
summary: Fifty years ago, top executives like George Romney turned down bonuses due to high tax rates, citing the "temptations of success" could distract from important matters. The top marginal tax rate was 91%, with 90 cents of every extra dollar going to the IRS. Since then, the tax rate has dropped to 39.6%, contributing to soaring inequality and a culture of high-end wealth. Critics argue that the current tax rate is too low and that a higher rate could help reduce inequality, while others argue that it would stifle entrepreneurship.

images.alt_text: (From left) US House Speaker Paul Ryan, President Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell at a meeting with members of Congress regarding tax reform on Sept 5.

site_title: Pressure mounts on ISDA committee to end Noble's credit default swap impasse
summary: Pressure mounts on the International Swaps & Derivatives Association (ISDA) panel to decide on Noble Group Ltd's credit default swap (CDS) impasse, which could impact investors' confidence in the determinations committee's ability to make decisions. The ISDA committee was scheduled to meet to reconsider whether Noble triggered a credit event when it arranged a 120-day loan facility extension in June. A decision not to have enough information could further erode confidence in the committee, with market watchers citing the importance of clarity in CDS definitions for maintaining market stability.

site_title: Facebook 'in talks to offer princely sum for music rights'
summary: Facebook is reportedly in talks to offer major record labels and music publishers hundreds of millions of dollars to obtain the rights to include songs in videos uploaded to its platform. The deal aims to resolve the issue of infringing music in user-generated content, which currently requires rights-holders to request removal of videos. The move is seen as a priority for Facebook, which is launching its Watch video hub and expects video to drive its business for the next few years.

site_title: S'pore makes strides in advanced manufacturing
summary: Singapore has established itself as a hub for advanced manufacturing, with multinational companies like Dyson investing in research and development centers. The city-state's drive for innovation and skilled workforce enables it to transform its extensive manufacturing footprint, punching above its weight. Singapore's strategic initiatives, including partnerships with companies and start-ups, educational institutions, and government programs, support the growth of advanced manufacturing. The country aims to become an exporter of ideas and solutions, leveraging its capabilities to create new regional and global businesses, and sustain competitiveness over the medium to long term.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering, a Singaporean defense and aerospace company, is recommended to buy with a target price of S$4.07. The company's defensive business model, driven by growth in the aerospace and electronics segments, is expected to deliver 10% earnings growth in 2018-2019. This is supported by rising demand for passenger-to-freighter conversions and Smart Nation initiatives. With limited capital expenditure requirements, ST Engineering is poised to increase its dividend payout in 2019, making it a strong dividend-paying blue-chip counter.

site_title: Western Digital offers to exit Toshiba chip bid for better joint venture terms
summary: Western Digital Corp has offered to drop out of a consortium bidding for Toshiba's flash memory chip business to strengthen its joint venture position, potentially helping Toshiba seal the deal. The move comes as the two companies struggle to agree on Western Digital's stake in the business. A consortium offering around $23.6 billion for the chip business had stalled due to disagreements over the US firm's stake. Toshiba's board was set to meet to discuss the deal, with Western Digital seeking to invest jointly in a new production line.

site_title: Corporate chiefs lend their support
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 8th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2017, focusing on "Purpose, Values & Culture - How Does it Drive Governance?" from September 18-22, 2017. The event features a Statement of Support by 64 companies to uphold good corporate governance standards, with CEOs from various organizations expressing their commitment to accountability and transparency. These companies believe that good governance is essential for long-term success and sustainability, and will continue to prioritize this aspect in their operations.

site_title: Ink-stained reunion after years of digital upheaval in journalism
summary: The Chicago Tribune's parent company, Tronc, has acquired the New York Daily News after nearly 30 years of ownership by the Tribune Co. The Daily News was founded in 1919 and has undergone significant changes since its last ownership by the Tribune Co. in 1991. The acquisition marks a return to the company's roots, but some question how the new ownership will impact the paper's future.

site_title: Russia plans gem reform to compete with India
summary: Russia aims to boost the competitiveness of its diamond industry by encouraging its largest diamond miner, Alrosa, to offer more favorable terms to local cutters. The plan involves selling around 10% of its gems domestically, allowing cutters to choose specific stones and return the rest. The government also plans to ease controls on importing and exporting stones and introduce regulations to make the market more transparent. This move aims to counter India's dominance in the diamond market, where 90% of the world's diamonds are processed.

site_title: Months of dry runs wind down at Changi's T4 ahead of Oct 31 debut
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 is set to debut on October 31, following months of dry runs to fine-tune operations. The terminal, equipped with new technologies and systems, will initially be served by Cathay Pacific. The airport has conducted over 100 trials involving 2,500 staff and 1,500 volunteers to ensure a smooth transition. Self-service options, including facial-recognition technology and centralized security screening, are expected to reduce manpower needs by up to 20%. The terminal's handling capacity will increase to 16 million passengers per year, adding to Changi's total capacity of 82 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US services sector growth recovers slightly in August
summary: The US services sector experienced a slight recovery in August, with the non-manufacturing index rising 1.4 points to 55.3%, indicating growth. This marked 92 consecutive months of expansion, with 15 of 17 services industries reporting growth. However, farmers and the transportation sector reported contraction due to low dairy and cattle prices. Despite this, the majority of respondents remain optimistic about business conditions, with the employment index rising to 57.9% and business activity reaching 57.5%.

site_title: One-stop centre to help S'pore startups ace it abroad
summary: The ACE International Centre (ACEIC) has been launched in Singapore to support local and global startups in expanding internationally. The one-stop centre will provide resources, advice, and access to overseas markets for local startups, while also helping global startups find investment, tech, and business opportunities in Singapore. The centre is a collaboration between the Action Community for Entrepreneurship (ACE), the government, and international organizations. With over 4,300 tech startups in Singapore, ACEIC aims to leverage the country's vibrant ecosystem to drive international growth.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia slapped with class-action suit
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia is facing potentially Australia's biggest class-action lawsuit over a money-laundering scandal, which has already damaged its share price and exposed it to billions of dollars in fines. The lawsuit, funded by litigation financier IMF Bentham Ltd, accuses the bank of making false statements and failing to disclose breaches of anti-money laundering rules. The scandal has led to a board shakeup, with three non-executive directors set to leave, and investors are concerned it could hurt earnings growth and attract foreign regulators.

site_title: Hurricane Irma leaves Caribbean islands flooded and in darkness as it heads for Florida
summary: Hurricane Irma, a Category 5 storm, churned across the Caribbean, leaving islands flooded and in darkness. The storm's eye moved towards St. Martin, east of Puerto Rico, and may hit Florida on Saturday. Over 1,000 people in Antigua sought shelter, and the island's population was without power. The storm caused widespread damage and threatened life-threatening wind, storm surge, and rainfall hazards in several islands, including Puerto Rico, the US and British Virgin Islands, and the Dominican Republic. The US National Hurricane Center warned of catastrophic conditions, and authorities in Florida ordered evacuations and closed public schools.

site_title: Retrofitting a Long Island lighthouse for a second act
summary: A group plans to turn the county-owned Cedar Island Lighthouse in Suffolk County, New York, into a two-room bed-and-breakfast. The 1868 lighthouse, once a beacon for whaling ships, was decommissioned in 1934 and suffered a fire, leaving it in a state of disrepair. Suffolk County Legislature approved $500,000 for renovations, and the Friends of the Cedar Island Lighthouse are working to raise more money. The project aims to preserve the historic structure, which could become the first lighthouse in New York state to offer overnight accommodations.

site_title: Hurricane Irma batters Caribbean as Florida braces for weekend landfall
summary: Hurricane Irma, a Category 5 storm with winds of 185 miles per hour, is battering the Caribbean, particularly the northern islands, as it approaches a possible Florida landfall over the weekend. The storm has caused widespread damage and power outages in Puerto Rico, the US and French Virgin Islands, and other affected territories. The National Hurricane Center has issued hurricane warnings for several islands, including Florida, where residents are being urged to evacuate low-lying areas. US President Donald Trump has approved emergency declarations and mobilized federal disaster relief efforts.

site_title: Australia's economy strengthens after weak start to year
summary: Australia's economy has strengthened, with second-quarter growth at 0.8% and an annual rate of 1.8%, following a sluggish start to the year. Household spending rose 0.7% and government expenditure 1.2%, while exports increased 2.7%. The Australian dollar fell slightly after the data release, with investors disappointed by the slightly softer GDP reading. The economy has shown signs of recovery, with a strengthening jobs market and improved business conditions, but wages growth still needs to strengthen further to boost consumption levels.

site_title: CapitaLand boosts presence in Indonesia
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property developer, is investing $74.3 million in Indonesia's serviced residence market through its wholly-owned business unit, Ascott. The investment includes the acquisition of a 192-unit serviced residence in Jakarta and a contract to manage a 230-unit property in Bali. This addition brings Ascott's portfolio in Indonesia to nearly 600 units, making it the largest serviced residence operator in the country. CapitaLand sees Indonesia as a growth market due to its steady economic growth, urbanization, and increasing domestic consumption.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Singapore CEO Ronald Tay sees sound fundamentals in Indonesia's real estate market

site_title: In taxi slugfest, commuters gain, but mind the far bigger endgame
summary: A potential alliance between ComfortDelGro and Uber, and a partnership between Grab and non-ComfortDelGro taxi companies, could benefit commuters as ride-hailing firms continue to disrupt the taxi market. The entry of ride-hailing apps has led to lower prices, subsidized by venture capitalists, and has stimulated demand for private transport. Regulators should encourage competition benefiting consumers, while businesses must innovate to avoid disruption. The ultimate goal is to ensure that drivers can make a living while public transport services continue to improve.

site_title: HP Enterprise revenue gains 2.5% after company slims down
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) reported a 2.5% increase in revenue to $8.2 billion in its fiscal third quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company attributed the growth to stronger demand for servers and storage gear, which aid in data centers. HPE's adjusted profit rose to 30 cents per share, marking the first time in five quarters that the company beat projections. The company's efforts to slim down and focus on core products have paid off, alleviating investor concerns about the company's viability.

site_title: Number two at US Federal Reserve to step down
summary: US Federal Reserve vice chairman Stanley Fischer will retire on October 13, creating a third vacancy for President Donald Trump to fill. Fischer, 73, is stepping down two and a half years before his mandate expires. This move comes as the Fed faces pressure to address economic concerns, with some speculating that Trump may nominate a new vice chairman to oversee monetary policy. Fischer's departure marks a significant change in the Fed's leadership, with implications for the US economy and monetary policy.

site_title: Britain eyeing curbs on EU migration, leaked document shows
summary: Britain is considering measures to restrict EU immigration to only high-skilled workers, according to a leaked government document. The plans aim to address concerns about the impact of large EU migrant flows on the country, which were cited as a reason for the Brexit vote. Opposition lawmakers have criticized the plans as "plainly cruel," while some companies have described them as "alarming."

site_title: Church buys Elite Building in collective sale
summary: The Tabernacle Church and Missions Ltd has purchased the Elite Building in a collective sale for S$52 million, working out to S$1,242 per square foot based on the existing 41,866 sq ft gross floor area.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US home refinancing activity hits 11-week high
summary: US home refinancing activity surged to an 11-week high in September, driven by declining home borrowing costs to a 9-month low of 4.06% for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages. This revival in refinancing activity reversed a decline in loan demand, as lower borrowing costs revived homeowners' interest in refinancing existing loans. The Mortgage Bankers Association reported a 5.1% increase in refinancing activity, the strongest since June 16, as geopolitical tensions and tax reform uncertainty contributed to lower bond yields.

site_title: Taxify takes on Uber in competitive London taxi-hailing market
summary: Taxify, an Estonian startup, has launched its services in London, entering the city's competitive taxi-hailing market. The company has partnered with 3,000 private hire taxi drivers and offers lower fares and higher driver profits compared to Uber, which charges a 20-25% commission. Taxify's founder, Markus Villig, claims the company will be cheaper than Uber and accepts cash payments, setting it up for a potential challenge to the ride-hailing giant in London and beyond.

site_title: GSO's Bennett Goodman builds US$95b debt engine
summary: Bennett Goodman, co-founder of GSO Capital Partners, a US$95 billion private credit firm, is building a "debt engine" by lending directly to often-risky companies, bypassing traditional banks and capital markets. The firm has raised US$100 billion in the past year, with GSO and similar firms collectively having US$595 billion at their disposal. Experts warn of intensifying risks, including shrinking yields and loosening protections for investors, as the market becomes increasingly competitive. Goodman is prepared to own businesses through bankruptcy and sell later if needed, capitalizing on a fragmented market where private equity firms need US$1 trillion in loans.

images.alt_text: At GSO, Mr Goodman (above) is prepared to own a business through bankruptcy and sell later if needed. He weighs up a company's sources of liquidity, the value of its assets, who might buy them and at what price.

site_title: Dollar steadies ahead of central bank meetings
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of central bank meetings, particularly the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday. The euro has surged 14% against the dollar since the start of the year, driven by investors' expectations of the ECB's stimulus program winding down. Investors will be watching for ECB President Mario Draghi's response to the euro's strength, which could impact policy tightening plans. The euro remained flat at US$1.1924, while the dollar recovered to trade flat against the yen despite earlier weakness.

site_title: Renovated Berlin opera house finally opens - temporarily
summary: The Staatsoper opera house in Berlin has finally reopened after seven years of renovation, with a temporary reopening planned until December 7. The renovation, which cost 400 million euros, included a new computer-controlled stage and a 115m underground tunnel connecting the rehearsal centre to the main stage. The season begins on September 30 with a concert and a new production of Schumann's Faust, conducted by Daniel Barenboim. Performances will be suspended for two months to allow technicians to master the new equipment, before reopening permanently with a concert featuring works by Mendelssohn-Bartholdy and Pierre Boulez.

site_title: Big Oil says it still loves the North Sea despite asset sales
summary: Big Oil companies, including BP and Royal Dutch Shell, have expressed confidence in the UK North Sea oil industry, despite asset sales and declining production. The region's 40-year-old industry is facing a long slide into decline, but companies see opportunities to cut costs and generate profit with new technology. Shell CEO Ben van Beurden said the North Sea "still needs to earn its right to grow," while BP CEO Bob Dudley highlighted the discovery of new resources in the Shetland Islands. Despite reduced investment, the North Sea is set for its biggest year of startups in a decade.

site_title: Missing generals in list of delegates gives Xi room to pick army leaders
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is poised to fill as many as seven seats on the 11-member Central Military Commission, following the exclusion of two generals, General Fang Fenghui and General Zhang Yang, from the upcoming Communist Party congress. The absence signals the generals have been taken out of consideration, amid disciplinary probes. Xi's military overhaul aims to create a U.S.-style joint command structure and cement his control over the 2 million-member People's Liberation Army, with the party congress set to begin on October 18.

site_title: Investors on edge after 7.5% fall in August US airlines index
summary: US airline investors are concerned after a 7.5% decline in the August US airlines index, wiping out approximately $10 billion in market value. The decline is attributed to a spreading price war among carriers and markets. This is the worst monthly stock performance in a year, adding to investors' concerns.

site_title: HDB widens use of prefab to hit building productivity targets
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore announced plans to increase construction productivity by 25% between 2010 and 2020 by using prefabricated bathroom units in new flats by 2019. These prefabricated units will be pre-assembled off-site and transported to the work site for installation. This initiative aims to boost productivity and improve efficiency in HDB's construction projects.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker, banks and Reits hit
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 18.79 points to 3,232.47 on Wednesday, weighed down by a 0.83% decline in the FTSE FT Reit index. The Reit selloff followed a proposed rights issue by Cache Logistics Trust and Manulife US Reit. Market watchers attribute the decline to concerns about cash-raising by Reits this year.

site_title: Ipco warns of net loss for fiscal Q1
summary: IPCO International Limited is expected to report a net loss for the fiscal first quarter ended July 31, primarily due to the translation effect of its overseas subsidiaries' operations. The group will disclose further details of its financial performance on September 14.

site_title: Small car COE premium slumps nearly S$7,000
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars fell in the third consecutive bidding exercise, with Category A (small cars) decreasing by S$6,899 or 16% to S$36,001. Category B (cars above 1,600cc/130hp) dropped S$2,000 to S$49,000, while Category E (open category) fell S$1,995 to S$48,005. In contrast, Category C (goods vehicles) and Category D (motorcycles) increased by S$998 and S$1,890, respectively.

site_title: Car COE premiums down again but dealers expect rebound
summary: Singapore's passenger car certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums fell for the third consecutive bidding exercise, with the small car premium dropping S$6,899 to S$36,001. However, dealers expect a rebound due to changes in emission standards and a potential shortage of COEs. The new Euro 6 emissions standard, which came into effect on September 1, is expected to lead to higher premiums, particularly for models that lose CEVS rebates under the Vehicle Emissions Scheme (VES) on January 1, 2018.

site_title: Mercator Lines to be wound up
summary: Mercator Lines, under judicial management, has filed an application to wind up the company, with a hearing date set for September 8. The judicial manager has explored potential investors to transfer the company's listing status or restructure the company, but no extension has been justified. Mercator Lines was placed under judicial management in January 2017 after an application by creditor HSH Nordbank.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Ma'aden asks banks to refinance nearly US$3b of debt -sources
summary: Saudi Arabian Mining Co (Ma'aden) has asked banks to submit proposals for a US$2.88 billion loan to refinance existing debt. The facility, if successful, would be the largest corporate loan from Saudi Arabia since 2015. Ma'aden is raising the financing for its Ma'aden Aluminium, an integrated aluminium facility, with a deadline for proposals by the end of September. The loan would be denominated in US dollars and Saudi riyals, with tenors of seven and 10 years. The move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy beyond oil exports.

site_title: Heeton-led consortium begins first phase of regeneration scheme in Leeds
summary: A consortium led by Heeton Holdings has begun the first phase of a regeneration scheme in Leeds, transforming a 2.45-acre site at Bridge Street into a sustainable urban destination. The project, set to open in 2019, will feature a 192-room Hampton by Hilton hotel, along with meeting rooms, a gym, bar, and restaurant. The consortium, comprising Heeton, KSH Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and Ryobi Kiso Holdings, aims to create a sustainable urban destination in the heart of Leeds.

site_title: Roadmap to vibrant ecosystem for Singapore's wholesale trade sector
summary: Singapore has launched its Wholesale Trade Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to create a vibrant ecosystem for its wholesale trade sector. The initiative aims to create 10,000 new jobs by 2020, enhance global growth and productivity, and achieve a real value-add compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.3-3.5% between 2016 and 2020. The ITM includes digital marketplaces, training programs, and partnerships with industry players and trade associations to support the sector's digitalization and transformation.

site_title: Boeing raises 20-year China plane forecast on travel boom
summary: Boeing has raised its 20-year forecast for aircraft demand in China, predicting 7,240 new planes valued at nearly $1.1 trillion through 2036. This upward revision comes despite rising trade tensions and a volatile geopolitical environment. Boeing attributes the increase to China's expanding middle class, economic growth, and a recovering air-cargo market, supporting a more optimistic forecast. Narrow-body jets will make up 75% of total deliveries, driven by full-service and discount carriers expanding routes for leisure and business travel.

site_title: HPL subsidiary to buy land to build luxury hotel in Republic of Palau
summary: HPL Properties Limited's subsidiary, HPL Properties (Pacific Ocean) Pte Ltd, has incorporated Leisure Development Koror Inc to acquire US$8.5 million worth of land in the Republic of Palau for a luxury hotel development. The acquisition will be funded by internal funds and is not expected to impact the group's net earnings per share and net tangible assets per share. HPL owns 70% of HPLPPO, with Como Holdings Pte Ltd holding 30%.

site_title: The costs of not protecting personal data
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act 2012 has been in force for nearly three years, yet many organisations fail to protect personal data adequately. This can lead to significant costs and losses for companies. Practising good personal data protection is crucial, similar to protecting other organisational assets. Individuals also need to be aware of the risks of excessive data collection and be mindful of how their information is used. Strong data protection practices are essential for organisations to avoid financial losses and maintain trust with customers.

site_title: Falling car exports help nudge July US trade gap higher
