site_title: Falling pace of supply disrupts US petroleum pipeline system
summary: The US petroleum pipeline system has been disrupted by a falling pace of supply, with at least two major pipelines, Colonial and Explorer, shutting lines to Tulsa and Chicago due to damaged refineries from Hurricane Harvey. The Colonial Pipeline, a top transporter of petrol for the northeast, has closed part of its line after supply fell from damaged refineries. The US government has released one million barrels of oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, and pipeline operators are working to assess damage and restart services, with some hoping that restarting refineries will help revive the regional fuel supply.

site_title: How low-cost US airlines clip the wings of their big rivals
summary: US low-cost airlines, such as Spirit and Frontier, continue to moderate ticket costs despite mergers reducing competition. By offering cheap prices, they stimulate new demand and take passengers from major carriers. This trend, known as the "Southwest effect," has been observed since 1993. Low-cost carriers push down fares, with Southwest serving a market with nonstop flights resulting in a $45 lower average one-way fare. Major carriers like United and American have responded by introducing "basic economy" fares to compete with low-cost airlines.

site_title: Zest for AI applications swelling Nvidia's market value
summary: Nvidia's market value has surged due to its expanding applications of artificial intelligence (AI) technology, particularly in healthcare, drones, robots, and virtual reality. The company's graphics processing units (GPUs) can handle complex AI tasks such as image and facial recognition, and its stock market value has increased by over seven-fold in the past two years, reaching nearly $100 billion. Nvidia's CEO, Jen-Hsun Huang, has led the company's push into AI applications, repurposing existing GPUs to create a technology platform that has become popular among programmers and companies.

site_title: South Korea launch missile exercise after North Korea nuke test: Yonhap
summary: South Korea launched a ballistic missile exercise in response to North Korea's sixth nuclear test, simulating an attack on the North's nuclear site in the East Sea. The exercise involved the Hyunmoo ballistic missile and F-15K fighter jets, with targets equivalent to the North's Punggye-ri nuclear test site. US President Donald Trump criticized South Korea, stating that their talk of appeasement with North Korea will not work, and warned that the US could launch a "massive military response" to threats from North Korea.

site_title: Air pollution casts shadow on India's solar success
summary: India's solar energy ambitions are being undermined by air pollution, which is sapping power generation by more than 25% due to smog and dust. This amounts to roughly 3,900 megawatts of lost energy, equivalent to six times the capacity of its largest solar farm. The pollution is particularly problematic in northern India, where fine airborne particles from human activity contribute to dire air quality. Experts warn that this issue will only compound as India realizes its grand solar ambitions, with potential losses estimated in the billions of dollars.

site_title: Keppel Land on the hunt for new chief
summary: Keppel Land is seeking a new CEO after Ang Wee Gee's resignation on Dec 31, 2017. Current Keppel Corporation CEO Loh Chin Hua will assume executive chairman role starting Jan 1, 2018, while Louis Lim, 45, will become chief operating officer. Lim joined Keppel Corporation in 2016, previously working at Bain & Company. Ang Wee Gee, who led Keppel Land for over 26 years, is leaving to pursue other interests, praising the company's strong management team.

site_title: As bike-sharing brings out bad manners, China questions its moral values
summary: China's bike-sharing boom has exposed deep-seated issues of morality and decorum, as over 16 million shared bicycles flood the country's traffic-clogged cities. Vandalism, theft, and misbehavior have become rampant, with some bike-share companies shutting down due to the problem. Authorities have confiscated tens of thousands of bicycles and imposed parking restrictions, while residents and security guards express frustration with the blight of bikes piling up in neighborhoods. The debate has sparked discussions about China's concept of "suzhi" or inner quality, with some attributing the country's moral decay to its growing dependence on technology and lack of trust in strangers.

site_title: Owners driven by fears of hike in GLS supply
summary: Singapore owners are rushing to launch collective sale tenders due to fears of a potential hike in GLS supply from January 2018, which may increase competition for en bloc sales. Owners believe higher land prices make en bloc sales more viable. Developers prefer state tenders, which are hassle-free and faster to launch, but owners are taking action to secure a sale before January. Experts attribute the owners' enthusiasm to the rapid increase in land prices, which have risen significantly in recent months, creating a new opportunity for en bloc sales.

site_title: Paul Newman's rare Rolex has auction watchers all wound up
summary: Paul Newman's rare 1968 Rolex Daytona watch is set to be auctioned off at Phillips in New York on October 26, with estimates suggesting it could sell for $10 million. The watch, which Newman gave away to a friend in 1984, was previously unknown to the public and has gained significant attention among watch collectors and enthusiasts. Newman's daughter, Nell, said her father thought of the watch as a "tool" and didn't have a strong attachment to it, but its value has been increasing due to its association with the famous actor.

site_title: Hamilton takes F1 lead from Vettel
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Italian Grand Prix, taking the lead in the Formula One world championship for the first time in a year. He led teammate Valtteri Bottas to a one-two finish, finishing 36.3 seconds ahead of Vettel. Hamilton is now three points clear of Vettel with seven races remaining, and Mercedes are 62 points clear of Ferrari in the constructors' standings.

site_title: Keppel Land on the hunt for new chief
summary: Keppel Land's CEO, Ang Wee Gee, will leave the company on December 31, 2017, after 26 years of service. Loh Chin Hua, CEO of Keppel Corporation, will assume the role of executive chairman of Keppel Land starting January 1, 2018. The company is evaluating candidates for the CEO position. Louis Lim, a 45-year-old director at Keppel Corporation, will become the new chief operating officer of Keppel Land on January 1.

site_title: Reining in cypherpunks and the wild token ride
summary: Regulators in Singapore and the US are stepping in with advisories and warnings as cryptoanarchy leads to a surge in initial coin offerings (ICOs), raising concerns over the lack of transparency and investor protection. ICOs, which raise public funds for digital tokens, are often likened to Kickstarter campaigns and can be sold as securities, subject to regulations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has clarified that many digital tokens are in effect securities, requiring issuers to issue prospectuses. Regulators warn of price volatility, lack of investor protection, and the risk of scams, urging issuers to follow existing rules and guidelines.

site_title: Manufacturing is a bright spot in a subdued US jobs report
summary: US manufacturing added jobs at the fastest pace in over four years, with 156,000 new positions, as the economy created a total of 156,000 jobs in August. The rebound in factories, which lost over two million jobs in the recession, has recovered more than one million positions since 2010. The hiring reflects increased demand for big trucks, and manufacturers have indeed stepped up the pace of hiring this year. The unemployment rate edged up to 4.4%, while wages barely grew, with the national average hourly wage rising by just 0.1%.

site_title: Time to scale peaks beyond SEA Games
summary: Singapore's Southeast Asian Games overall showing was impressive, with a best-ever "away" medal haul of 57 golds, securing fourth place on the 11-team table. However, the country's athletes failed to live up to expectations in many sports, with some teams collecting only bronze medals. The government should focus on supporting high-performing athletes, rather than lavishing praise on those who underperformed, in order to help Singapore scale the peaks beyond the SEA Games.

site_title: Prosecco causes tooth decay? Claim by UK dentists angers Italians
summary: UK dentists claim that Prosecco causes chronic tooth decay, sparking outrage among Italians. The claim was made in headlines warning that the bubbly North Italian wine "could be rotting your teeth". The Italian government was particularly incensed by the statement, with many viewing it as a storm in a wine glass. No scientific evidence supports the claim, and the incident has highlighted cultural differences between the two nations.

site_title: When office meetings leave the office behind
summary: Entrepreneurs are taking unconventional approaches to boost employee creativity and productivity, ditching traditional office settings for outdoor activities like walking meetings, surfing talks, and salt room discussions. Companies like ProductionGlue and automotiveMastermind are finding that these unstructured, team-based activities increase collaboration, innovation, and focus. Experts say that these holistic changes can lead to increased motivation and performance, as employees are more engaged and connected to their work and colleagues.

site_title: Future of US-South Korea trade accord hangs in balance
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering terminating the US-South Korea free-trade agreement (KORUS FTA), which was signed in 2012. The decision comes amid rising tensions with North Korea over Pyongyang's missile tests. Trump's administration had begun talks to revise the deal, but negotiations failed to agree on a way forward. National Security Adviser HR McMaster and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis are reportedly against withdrawing the US from the pact, citing concerns about the potential impact on diplomatic relations with South Korea.

site_title: It's always best to stay invested in the index
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen a 5-day rally ahead of the release of GDP data, with investors shrugging off weak economic data and focusing on expected fiscal stimulus and potential Fed rate cuts. Despite market headwinds, including a tense North Korean situation and a potential US government shutdown, Wall Street remains close to all-time highs. Investors are advised to stick to index stocks, as they provide liquidity and stability in a market with a narrowing of liquidity into a two-tier formation.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to spin off parts unit; plans future sale of luxury car ops
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) plans to spin off its parts unit, including Magneti Marelli SpA, as part of efforts to eliminate 4.2 billion euros in debt by the end of 2018. The move is part of CEO Sergio Marchionne's plan to separate non-core assets and focus on luxury car operations, valued at up to 7 billion euros. While Marchionne has ruled out separating Alfa Romeo and Maserati, the companies could potentially become standalone entities after his departure in 2019.

site_title: Hogwarts School off to flying start in new digital experience
summary: Harry Potter fans can now experience Hogwarts School digitally through the Pottermore website. The immersive experience allows users to fly through the castle, forbidden forest, and quidditch pitch, marking the first time fans can explore the wizarding school at their own pace. The feature was launched on September 1, coinciding with the start of Harry Potter's first year at Hogwarts, and is available for free. This digital experience builds on the success of Harry Potter books and films, which have sold over 400 million copies worldwide and grossed $7 billion at the box office.

site_title: Viet developer rolls out plans for cars designed and made in Vietnam
summary: Vietnam's largest real-estate company, Vingroup JSC, plans to invest up to $3.5 billion in a car manufacturing and R&D complex, aiming to launch its first car in 24 months. The move is part of the country's goal to design and produce cars for its 90 million motorbike and scooter riders.

site_title: Alphabet completes restructuring with new firm
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, has completed its restructuring with the formation of a new holding company, XXVI Holdings Inc. This entity will own the equity of each Alphabet company, including Google, and legally separate Google from other units such as Waymo and Verily. The restructuring allows Alphabet to operate independently and limit the exposure of potential challenges between businesses. Google is also changing to a limited liability company (LLC), which is better suited for a single investor and no public disclosure obligations. The change aims to improve efficiency and transparency for the companies.

site_title: Cargoes diverted as Latin America competes for fuel in Harvey's wake
summary: Hurricane Harvey crippled the US Gulf of Mexico refining hub, diverting millions of barrels of fuel to Latin America to compensate for the shortage. The US lost 4.4 million barrels per day of refining capacity, leading to a surge in fuel prices. Latin American countries, including Mexico, Brazil, and Venezuela, are competing for fuel imports, with buyers rerouting cargoes from the US to Europe and Asia. Supply lines are expected to be disrupted for weeks, and prices may rise in the affected regions.

site_title: New Silkroutes looks like it's on recovery route
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a diversified oil and gas trader, appears to be on a recovery route. The company's underlying shares are trading at a new low of S$0.395, and its warrants have a conversion premium of 11.4% with 17 months to expiry. Despite a smaller net loss in FY2017, the company's revenue increased eight times to US$433 million. This suggests the company may have turned the corner and is poised for solid growth, making its warrants an attractive investment option.

site_title: Otkritie bank's bailout likely to be biggest in Russia's history
summary: Otkritie bank, Russia's largest private bank, is receiving a $6.9 billion bailout, making it the biggest in Russia's history. The Central Bank of Russia is providing the funds through money printing and capital injection to cover the bank's shortfall. The bank's ambitious expansion and deposit withdrawals led to a $6.9 billion hole in its balance sheet. A temporary administration team is reviewing the bank's books, and the Central Bank plans to take a 75% stake in the bank, with the possibility of increasing it to 100% if the bank's capital turns negative.

site_title: Call to slap property tax on China homes to curb prices
summary: China's central bank official, Xu Zhong, has urged the government to implement a property tax nationwide to regulate the sector, citing it as a major source of financial risk. Xu, head of the People's Bank of China's research bureau, suggested strict controls over property markets in major cities to curb price gains. He also proposed relying on market-based reforms to improve land supply and reducing local governments' reliance on land sales for revenue. The goal is to develop a long-term mechanism to support the healthy development of China's property market, which has experienced several cycles of overheating and regulatory clampdowns.

site_title: GSH Corp, UMS and Tai Sin file director buys
summary: Key changes in director interests and substantial shareholder stakes were reported by 55 SGX-listed companies between Aug 25 and Aug 31. The ratio of director acquisitions to disposals was 10 to one, while substantial shareholders filed for acquisitions almost four to one. Companies like UMS Holdings, Tai Sin Electric, and GSH Corp saw significant changes, with UMS Holdings chairman Andy Luong and Tai Sin Electric non-executive director Bobby Lim Chye Huat acquiring shares, while GSH Corp executive chairman Sam Goi increased his stake. Share buybacks also occurred, with UMS Holdings reducing its total consideration to S$6.4 million.

site_title: Ghost cities haunt stability dream in far west China
summary: China's far western Xinjiang region, home to the ancient Silk Road city of Kashgar, struggles to achieve economic development despite massive government stimulus. A "pairing assistance" programme, which pairs wealthy cities with Xinjiang, has stalled, with several projects abandoned or unfinished. The region's per capita GDP has expanded at a slower pace than the rest of the country, and local officials report difficulties attracting businesses due to strict security measures and lack of investment in local needs. Experts attribute the failure to the programme to fears of violence deterring investment and the region's strict controls on personal and religious freedoms.

site_title: En bloc surge has legs if pricing stays realistic
summary: Singapore's en bloc sale market is experiencing a surge, with 8 collective sales transacted at S$3.48 billion this year, surpassing 2016's total. Analysts predict this trend will last until the end of next year, driven by stable economic growth and improved private home sales. However, rising owner expectations and potential factors like a housing glut or government supply increases could end the market's momentum.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US stocks weather the storm to hit new highs
summary: US stocks rose last week, reaching new highs despite Hurricane Harvey's devastating impact on Houston, with traders betting on a "Goldilocks" scenario of strong growth without high inflation. The storm's damage is estimated to be over $100 billion, with private and public property affected. However, jobs data showed a moderate increase of 156,000 employees, giving the Federal Reserve wiggle room on interest rate plans. Analysts expect the economy to recover, with a tax-cut package and strong consumer confidence on the horizon, despite the looming threat of Tropical Storm Irma.

site_title: Wells Fargo deal in doubt as scandal deepens
summary: Wells Fargo's US$142 million class action settlement with customers may be jeopardized as the bank admits to opening 1.4 million potentially unauthorized accounts, 67% higher than its previous estimate. The external review found 3.5 million bogus accounts, with the new review covering a longer period. The bank's revised estimate raises questions about the extent of the scam, prompting lawyers to prepare written objections to the settlement. The bank's CEO claims the data quality prevents a detailed investigation into earlier years, but plaintiffs' lawyers are left wondering what records might reveal.

site_title: No to durians, but 'yes' to high-tech farming
summary: Excelpoint Technology, a Singapore-listed electronics company, is considering venturing into agriculture, particularly vertical farming, due to declining margins in its electronics components distribution business. Founder Albert Phuay sees opportunities in IoT applications and investing in new technologies to stay ahead. The company has grown revenue at a compound rate of 14% per year from 2012 to 2016, and is exploring acquisitions and frontier markets in Asia. Phuay attributes his success to people and family support, but has no immediate plans to retire, instead planning to remain a mentor to the company.

site_title: In for a scary taxi ride
summary: ComfortDelGro's core cab business is under threat from the rise of ride-hailing giants Grab and Uber, which could lead to a decline in revenue and operating profits. The company's taxi fleet has dropped 1-2% per month, resulting in a potential loss of S$100 million in revenue and S$10 million in operating profit. If the decline continues, ComfortDelGro's taxi operating profit could drop by S$15 million to S$30 million per year. The company's share price may also be impacted, with a potential 30-cent drop in value.

images.alt_text: Every time I feel like buying a car, I stop and ask myself: Would I rather blow S$100,000 on a Honda, or plonk that money in ComfortDelGro stock?

site_title: China's Legend buys Luxembourg's BIL bank for US$1.8b in European expansion
summary: China's Legend Holdings acquired a 90% stake in Luxembourg's Banque Internationale a Luxembourg (BIL) for 1.48 billion euros (S$2.39 billion), marking the largest European deposit-taking bank takeover by a Chinese firm. BIL's management team will remain in place, and the Luxembourg government will retain a 10% stake. The deal is part of Legend's European expansion efforts.

site_title: Apple shifts responsibility for Siri to operating system chief
summary: Apple has transferred responsibility for its voice assistant, Siri, from content chief Eddy Cue to operating systems chief Craig Federighi. The shift aims to embed Siri more deeply into Apple's core systems amid rising competition from Google and Amazon. Apple made the change by updating its executive biography pages. The move comes ahead of the release of the HomePod, a voice-activated speaker featuring Siri, which will compete with Amazon's Echo devices and Google's voice assistant. This change is part of Apple's efforts to strengthen its presence in the voice assistant market.

site_title: Junket king of Macau plans to invest billions in Japan, Vietnam
summary: Suncity Group, a Macau-based junket operator, plans to expand into the Japanese and Vietnamese markets, investing billions of dollars to transform itself into an overseas casino operator. The company, which controls half of Macau's junket business, aims to own stakes in casinos and bid on contracts to manage others' casinos. Suncity has partnered with local companies in Vietnam to build a $4 billion integrated resort and is actively working to obtain a license to build a potential $10 billion resort in Japan. The company expects to grow its business in Macau and diversify its footprint.

images.alt_text: Suncity's Andrew Lo expects his Macau business to grow for the next six months to a year because of improving conditions in the Chinese economy and real-estate market.

site_title: Trump's Houston trip will serve as empathy test
summary: US President Donald Trump's upcoming trip to Houston is seen as an opportunity for him to showcase a more empathetic side as he responds to the devastating effects of Hurricane Harvey. Trump will meet with flood survivors and volunteers, a move that could help him connect with Americans critical of his presidency. The trip comes as 1 million people have been displaced and up to 50 are feared dead in the disaster, with 59% of the public disapproving of Trump's performance as president.

site_title: Another blow from Harvey: Houston home prices, rents likely to rise
summary: Houston home prices and rents are expected to rise due to the city's historic flood, with tens of thousands of homes destroyed and uncertain flood insurance costs. The limited supply of available properties will drive up prices and rents in high-and-dry neighborhoods, as displaced buyers and renters compete for available properties. According to Nela Richardson, chief economist for Redfin, this pattern is similar to what occurred in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.

site_title: Natural Cool Holdings' managing director assists with investigation
summary: Natural Cool Holdings' managing director, Wong Leon Keat, assisted in an investigation into certain share trading activities prior to 2017, which is a personal matter and does not affect the company's business activities. The board stated that the investigation will not impact the company's operations and will announce any material developments.

site_title: Singapore aims to halve workplace fatality rate before 2028: PM Lee
summary: Singapore aims to reduce its workplace fatality rate by half to under one per 100,000 employed individuals by 2028, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The country has already seen a significant decline, from 5 per 100,000 in 2004 to 1.9 per 100,000 in 2016. This goal marks a new target for the nation, emphasizing its commitment to workplace safety.

site_title: Martin Schulz, luckless challenger 'shadow-boxing' Merkel
summary: Martin Schulz, the Social Democratic Party's candidate for German chancellor, is facing a tough challenge in his bid to defeat incumbent Angela Merkel. Despite a surge in popularity after his announcement, Schulz's campaign has stalled, with Merkel leading by 49-26% in a recent poll. Schulz's struggles include a lack of momentum, criticisms of his inability to challenge Merkel's refugee policy, and accusations of throwing in the towel too soon. Schulz's unenviable position as a "shadow-boxer" challenging Merkel has raised questions about his ability to win the election.

site_title: US, South Korea agree to revise missile treaty in face of North Korean threats
summary: US President Donald Trump and South Korean President Moon Jae-In agreed to revise a joint missile treaty, allowing South Korea to develop more advanced ballistic missiles to counter North Korea's nuclear and missile threats. The treaty revision aims to boost South Korea's defenses. Trump also gave conceptual approval for the purchase of US military hardware by South Korea, valued at millions of dollars. The move is seen as a response to North Korea's defiant stance on its missile and nuclear programs.

site_title: Houston home prices may rise, post-Harvey
summary: Houston home prices may rise sharply after Hurricane Harvey, with displaced buyers and renters competing for a limited number of properties. The city's flood insurance costs are uncertain, and the supply of homes is expected to drop sharply, with an estimated 242,000 homes in or near flooded areas. This could lead to a 48% increase in home prices, similar to the post-Hurricane Katrina experience in New Orleans. Affordability has long been a key factor in Houston's economic growth, and the disaster may exacerbate the shortage of entry- and mid-level homes, making for an extremely tight market.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Trump to keep migrant amnesty
summary: Pressure mounts on President Donald Trump not to end an amnesty for people brought to the US illegally as children, with business leaders urging compassion and top Republicans urging him to step back from a campaign pledge to axe the program. The CEOs of major US firms, including Amazon and General Motors, warned of the moral and economic impact of forcing almost 800,000 people back into the legal shadows. Top Congressional Republican Paul Ryan and his lawmakers also pressed Trump to reconsider.

site_title: Bullish correction on horizon for US dollar in near term
summary: The US dollar is expected to experience a bullish correction in the near term, according to a recent analysis. The Dollar Index (DXY) has been in a declining trend since January 2017, but a recent selloff has taken the index to a critical support area at 92.00, where a large deal of support can be found. The Relative Strength Index (RSI) suggests an oversold condition, indicating an imminent near-term correction. A rebound is expected, with the DXY potentially testing the 94.00-94.60 resistance area, but the long-term secular downtrend remains in place.

site_title: Neymar moves into sprawling mansion near PSG training ground
summary: Neymar, Paris Saint-Germain's Brazilian star, has moved into a 1,000-square-metre mansion in Bougival, Paris, near the team's training ground. The property, built in the 1950s, features 5,000 square metres of grounds, an indoor pool, and has never been on the market. Neymar, 25, became the world's most expensive footballer with a 222-million-euro transfer to PSG last month, meeting the buyout clause in his contract.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova advances into US Open last 16, Cilic ousted
summary: Maria Sharapova advanced to the US Open last 16, overpowering Sofia Kenin 7-5, 6-2. Sharapova, a former world number one, broke Kenin with a forehand winner after 66 minutes to take the set. Sharapova will face Anastasija Sevastova in the next round. Meanwhile, Marin Cilic was ousted by Diego Schwartzman, and Canadian teen Denis Shapovalov also reached the last 16, becoming the youngest man to do so since 1989.

site_title: Empress-ive
summary: The Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall, Singapore's oldest performing arts venue, was gazetted as a national monument in 1992. Built in 1905 as the Victoria Memorial Hall, it has played a significant role in Singapore's history, hosting various events, including a hospital during WWII, war criminal trials, and the launch of Singapore's first TV service. The building underwent renovations in 1979 and was renamed the Victoria Concert Hall, becoming the home of the Singapore Symphony Orchestra. It has since undergone further renovations, reopening in 2014.

site_title: Canadian university loses C$12m to phishing scam
summary: A Canadian university, MacEwan University in Edmonton, Alberta, lost nearly C$12 million to a phishing scam targeting staff. Hackers posed as a construction company, sending emails to employees advising of banking changes, and the university transferred funds into the hackers' accounts. The scam was discovered when the construction firm called to ask for payment. Authorities froze C$11.4 million of the funds, but C$400,000 remains unaccounted for, making it one of the largest phishing scams in Canada, attributed to human error.

site_title: Second man held over French girl's wedding disappearance
summary: French investigators have arrested a second man in connection with the disappearance of 9-year-old Maelys de Araujo during a wedding in the Alps. The 34-year-old man, a friend of the first suspect, was arrested over "contradictions" in his statement to police. The search for Maelys, who was last seen on Sunday, has entered its sixth day with over 1,000 people registering to participate in a massive search on Saturday. Investigators suspect she was kidnapped and are examining mobile phone evidence, photos, and videos taken on the night of her disappearance.

site_title: Honda reaches US$605m settlement over defective airbags
summary: Honda has reached a $605 million settlement in a US lawsuit over defective airbags in millions of cars on American roads. The settlement, filed in the US District Court in Miami, will replace the defective airbags from bankrupt Takata and compensate car owners up to $500 plus expenses. Multiple Honda models, including Civic, Accord, and CR-V, are affected, linked to 16 deaths and scores of injuries worldwide. The deal is the latest in a series of settlements among Japanese carmakers, including Nissan, Toyota, BMW, Mazda, and Subaru.

site_title: Delight as Serena Williams 'welcomes baby girl'
summary: Tennis superstar Serena Williams gave birth to a baby girl, weighing 6 pounds and 13 ounces, on Friday in West Palm Beach, Florida. Fellow professionals, celebrities, and fans expressed delight at the news. Williams, who is engaged to Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian, had previously announced her pregnancy in April and vowed to return to competitive tennis in January to defend her Australian Open title.

site_title: US manufacturing activity accelerates in August: ISM
summary: US manufacturing activity accelerated in August, reaching its fastest pace in six years, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM). The ISM purchasing managers survey showed a 2.5-point increase to 58.8, driven by gains in output, employment, and inventories. However, Hurricane Harvey's impact is expected to be felt in coming months, with supply chains stretched and labor shortages continuing. The hurricane is likely to affect the top exporting state, Texas, which contains 10% of US manufacturing GDP.

site_title: Search goes on for Harvey survivors, Trump requests aid
summary: US President Donald Trump requested $7.85 billion in federal disaster relief for Hurricane Harvey survivors, as rescuers searched flooded neighborhoods in southeastern Texas. The storm displaced over 1 million people, with 50 feared dead, and paralyzed Houston, Beaumont, and other cities. Trump's request comes as the Trump administration plans to submit aid funding requests in stages as more information about the storm's impact becomes known.

site_title: Utah nurse claims police assault after she refused patient blood sample
summary: A Utah nurse, Alex Wubbels, was assaulted by a police officer after she refused to provide a blood sample from an unconscious patient without a warrant or consent. The incident occurred on July 26, 2017, and was caught on body-worn camera footage. Prosecutors in Utah are considering criminal charges against the officer, who has been suspended from blood-collecting duties. The nurse followed hospital policy, which states that blood samples can only be taken with a warrant, patient consent, or under arrest. The nurse's lawyer claims she acted within the law, and the hospital has created a new policy to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to undertake rights issue to partly fund property acquisition
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife Reit) will undertake a rights issue of over 299 million new units at US$0.695 per unit to raise approximately US$208 million to fund the acquisition of a 30-storey office building in Jersey City, New Jersey, for US$313.2 million. The acquisition will be funded through debt financing and proceeds from the rights issue, with a discount of 28% to the closing price of US$0.965 per unit. The property, located on the Hudson River waterfront, has a net lettable area of over 730,000 square feet and is 93.1% leased with a weighted lease expiry of 5.7 years.

site_title: Windows 10 update set for October release
summary: Microsoft announced a major update to its Windows operating system, Windows 10 "Fall Creators Update", set for a global release on October 17. The update will include features such as gaming, security, accessibility, and immersive experiences made possible by Windows Mixed Reality headsets. The headsets, priced as low as $299, will not require cameras to track user movements. The update will be available as a free upgrade for a year after its release, and will be built into a wide array of devices for the year-end holiday shopping season.

site_title: Results boost European shares, Indivior plunge puts pressure on UK mid caps
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by gains in industrials and media stocks, while pharma firm Indivior plummeted 36% after a US court ruling. The FTSE 100 rose 0.1%, despite pressure from the slump in Indivior's shares, which weighed on the FTSE 250. Analysts attributed the market's resilience to low interest rates and limited options for investors.

site_title: Rites of passage
summary: Singapore's funeral industry has evolved with changing attitudes and new services. Direct Funeral Services (DFS) and Ang Chin Moh have introduced innovative elements, such as iPad apps and eco-friendly caskets, to improve the experience for grieving families. DFS has tripled its revenue and now handles 100-120 cases a month, while Ang Chin Moh has professionalized its staff and introduced a uniform for all employees. The industry is also becoming more diverse, with younger people and women joining the field. Funeral directors emphasize the importance of compassion and care, and some companies, like Ang Chin Moh, sponsor training and education for their staff.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges up as rate-hike bets in check after jobs data
summary: US stocks edged up on Friday as a weak jobs report kept expectations for a rate hike in check. The Labor Department reported 156,000 jobs added in August, below forecasts of 180,000. Despite this, traders still bet on a 39% chance of a rate hike in December. The Dow rose 0.18%, the S&P 500 gained 0.20%, and the Nasdaq added 0.1% as the market looked to supportive economic data for growth. Energy and materials sectors led gains, while utilities lagged.

site_title: US gasoline in first slide since Harvey, oil under pressure
summary: US gasoline prices slid 2% on the first day since Hurricane Harvey struck the US oil industry, as refineries restarted operations and oil prices remained under pressure. Gasoline futures fell to a 2-year low above $2 a gallon, while Brent crude for November settled 11 cents lower at $52.75 a barrel. Refineries in Texas began restarting operations, and the US government authorized an additional release of 3.5 million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Analysts expect prices to see-saw until the market gets a clearer outlook for the refinery industry.

site_title: Kevin Lee
summary: Kevin Lee, founder of Invisible Photographer Asia, has been instrumental in promoting Asian photography and visual arts for seven years. He runs IPA, which collaborates with various organizations to showcase emerging photographers and artists in the region. Lee, a Singaporean, believes the city-state's comfort and complacency can breed a lack of creative risk-taking. He is concerned about the "sunset industry" of photography, where the value of images has decreased due to accessibility of tools and the rise of digital media. Lee advises young aspiring photographers to prioritize their passion and artistic vision over financial considerations, as a stable income can stifle creativity.

site_title: Mighty mini
summary: KitchenAid has released its new Mini Stand Mixer, 20% smaller and 25% lighter than its Classic model, with a 3.5-quart capacity suitable for up to five dozen cookies or a loaf of bread. This is the first downsizing of the Stand Mixer since 1962, catering to modern home-owners with limited counter space. The Mini Stand Mixer is available in four colors and priced at S$649, offering a compact and efficient mixing solution for small batches.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US dollar rises, US jobs data not expected to derail Fed
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of major rivals on Friday, reversing losses after US jobs data was seen as decent enough to support another interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this year. Nonfarm payrolls increased by 156,000, below expectations, but the unemployment rate remained at 4.4% and wage growth was tepid. The US dollar index was last up 0.1% at 92.801, indicating the possibility of a December interest rate hike is still on the table.

site_title: German cut
summary: Braun Büffel has launched limited edition leather accessories for men and women to celebrate its 130th anniversary. The Johann and Katharina collections are inspired by archival designs and made in Germany by handcrafted artisans. Master artisan Udo Quint will be in Singapore for a session on leather craftsmanship, offering a complimentary personalization service. A portion of the proceeds will go to charity, with Braun Büffel matching dollar-for-dollar donations.

site_title: The wolf is at the door, and it's here to teach you something
summary: A unique executive coaching course in Austria's Wolf Science Center teaches business executives and senior managers to develop "leadership presence" and "communicate on a primal level" by interacting with timber wolves. Participants learn to let go of ego and status, mirroring the wolves' indifference to human hierarchy. The one-day course, costing 650 euros, involves group discussions and encounters with wolves, aiming to sharpen participants' senses and improve their ability to read people's behavior.

site_title: 156,000 jobs added in August; figure falls below expectations
summary: The US economy added 156,000 jobs in August, falling below expectations of 200,000. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.4% and average hourly wages rose 3 cents to $26.39, up 2.5% from last year. Despite missing expectations, the job growth is considered sufficient for the Federal Reserve to announce a plan to trim its bond portfolio. The Labor Department attributed Hurricane Harvey's impact to the payrolls, with economists predicting potential disruption to September payrolls.

site_title: History theatre
summary: Visual artist Robert Zhao's exhibition, The Nature Museum, showcases photographs, sculptures, and historical documents on Singapore's natural history. The exhibition features fabricated documents that blur the line between reality and fantasy. Zhao will give guided tours and lecture performances on select dates. The Nature Museum runs from September 1 to 9, with tickets available through Sistic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Get crafty
summary: Singapore's Craft SG 2017, a craft beer festival, will take place next weekend at Clarke Quay. The event will feature drinks from local distributors and brands, as well as food and entertainment at selected establishments. Ticket prices range from S$20 to S$150, including one complimentary welcome beer for all-day entry. The festival will provide an opportunity for beer enthusiasts to sample a variety of craft beers and enjoy the local food scene.

site_title: Between the two Ds of US markets
summary: US stocks, particularly the Dow, have defied expectations of a decline due to political chaos, with investors citing the Dollar Index as a better indicator of market sentiment. Despite technical analysis suggesting a potential Dow crash, the Dow has remained strong, with a long-term technical upside target of 23,700 and multiple support levels. The US dollar has also weakened, reaching a long-term support level near $0.93, which could lead to a rebound rally and retest of resistance levels.

site_title: How an angry candy man revolutionised the modern sushi industry
summary: Kisaku Suzuki, founder of Suzumo Machinery Co, revolutionized the modern sushi industry with the creation of the world's first sushi robot in the 1970s. Initially met with resistance from sushi chefs, the robot was later deemed usable, and Suzumo's machines now account for 70% of the market for sushi equipment at restaurants. The invention led to the popularization of kaiten sushi, a US$6 billion industry in Japan, and brought affordable sushi to the masses, changing the way people experience Japanese cuisine.

site_title: Trump to host Sept 18 meeting of world leaders on UN reform
summary: US President Donald Trump will host a meeting of world leaders on September 18 to discuss UN reform, with countries invited to attend if they sign a US-drafted 10-point declaration supporting UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres' reform efforts. The event, held at UN headquarters, will feature Trump, Guterres, and US Ambassador Nikki Haley. The declaration aims to reduce mandate duplication and redundancy within the UN system, with the US reviewing UN peacekeeping missions to cut costs. The meeting follows Ethiopia's planned Security Council meeting on peacekeeping reform on September 20.

site_title: The New Wave of Cool
summary: Three luxury fashion houses, Ermenegildo Zegna, Berluti, and Calvin Klein, have appointed new creative directors to shake up their menswear scenes. Alessandro Sartori returns to Ermenegildo Zegna to introduce a more relaxed take on traditional suits, Haider Ackermann takes the helm at Berluti to infuse the brand with a bohemian edge, and Raf Simons leads Calvin Klein with a focus on Americana and emotional connections. The new creative forces aim to appeal to younger generations while maintaining their respective brands' luxury codes.

site_title: Modern tragedy
summary: Avant-garde theatre director Ong Keng Sen is ending his tenure as head of the Singapore International Festival of Arts with a contemporary update of the ancient Greek tragedy "Trojan Women" in collaboration with the National Theatre of Korea, Anh Sook-sun, and Jung Jae-Il. The minimalist changgeuk opera will be performed in Korean with English subtitles from September 7-9 at the Victoria Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: A Mid~Autumn Night's Dream
summary: Several hotels and restaurants in Singapore are offering limited-edition mooncakes for the Mid-Autumn Festival. Shang Palace at the Shangri-La Hotel Singapore offers three gift sets, including the Mini Snow Skin Eight Treasures, Mini Eight Treasures, and Four Treasures. Fairmont Singapore's velvety snowskin mooncakes feature a new Golden Caramel Crunch flavor. Pan Pacific Singapore offers seven baked mooncakes, including new flavors such as Pandan Paste with Single Yolk and Caramel with White Lotus Paste Single Yolk. Tung Lok Group's Mochi Snowskin Mooncakes feature unique flavors like brown sugar mochi with red bean and yam. Mandarin Orchard Singapore offers Japanese-inspired mooncakes, while TWG Tea's tea-infused mooncakes pair well with their Lotus Jade Tea. Bakerzin offers eight distinct collections, including bold and classic flavors. Other hotels and restaurants, such as Singapore Marriott Tang Plaza Hotel and Peony Jade, also offer unique mooncake offerings.

site_title: This airline has some Florida real estate it wants to sell you
summary: Allegiant Travel Co plans to develop a 22-acre resort compound in Port Charlotte, Florida, with a 75-room hotel, 720 condominiums, and amenities like a private-resort swimming pool. The company aims to diversify its revenue by managing other leisure-destination hotels and developing F&B brands. Allegiant will fund the project with pre-sale deposits and expects owners' fees to cover operating costs. However, some investors are concerned that the venture could be costly and distracting, and that real estate is a different business with different cycles and competition.

site_title: In Vancouver, property pays better than stocks or bonds
summary: Vancouver's housing market continues to defy control, with new-home prices gaining 5% in the past three months, the largest increase since 1990. Despite government measures, including a 15% tax on foreign buyers, prices remain high, with the typical detached house valued at a record $1.6 million. Canadians and foreign investors alike are driving up prices, with the city's residents seeing their cumulative take-home income more than double in value. Experts warn that a tipping point may be near, where prices become unsustainable and prices plummet.

site_title: Why own an office when you can share it?
summary: Co-working spaces are gaining popularity in Hong Kong due to high office rents and changing attitudes towards flexibility at the workplace. In the first half of 2017, co-working operators added 222,000 sq ft of new office space, growing the stock by 30%. The trend is expected to continue, with 52% of respondents in the Asia Pacific saying they currently use third-party space, and this is expected to grow to 64% over the next three years. Companies such as HSBC and Compass Offices are already using co-working spaces, citing benefits of cost-effectiveness, operational flexibility, and improved work-life balance.

site_title: Ipoh - sleepy foodie stopover wakes up to new potential
summary: Ipoh, Malaysia, is gaining attention as a business hub due to its low labor and rental costs, growing talent pool, and family-centric culture. The city's location between Kuala Lumpur and Penang makes it an attractive destination for investors. Startups are drawn to Ipoh's affordable environment, with entrepreneurs citing the city's quiet work ethic and low stress levels as ideal for creativity and focus. The Perak government has initiatives to develop talent in the arts scene, and a loan scheme is available for start-ups. Ipoh's potential in food technology and its intellectual capital are also being explored, with some entrepreneurs envisioning a new wave of business opportunities in the city.

site_title: Picture perfect
summary: Casio Singapore is releasing a limited edition EXILIM EX-TR80 pearl white camera and a Swarovski clutch bag, available for pre-order at S$1,299 until Sept 3. The exclusive set, available in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, features a 360-degree swivel, Make-up Mode, wider screen display, and LED lighting for enhanced selfies. Only 100 sets are available.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Aren't you a little young to be running a VC fund?
summary: A 27-year-old, Andre de Haes, co-founded Backed VC, a London-based venture capital fund, raising 30 million euros. He and his 29-year-old business partner argue that youth gives them insight into what startups resonate with their age group. However, some founders fear an over-reliance on millennial investors' intuition, citing frustrations with inexperienced venture capitalists. This trend highlights the growing influence of young investors in European venture capital, sparking debate about the balance between youth's intuition and established know-how.

images.alt_text: Younger investors say the benefits of youth more than make up for the frustrations that may accompany their lack of expertise.

site_title: Audi track day
summary: The Audi Driving Experience centre in Neuburg an der Donau, Germany, offers a unique combination of driving training and luxury amenities. Professional instructors, including racing and rally drivers, lead on-road and off-road driving modules in various Audi models, showcasing the carmaker's handling, dynamic, and off-road capabilities. The centre features a range of tracks, including a 55% gradient off-road course, a "see-saw" and half-pipe, and a handling course with Audi's R8 LMS cars. The facility also boasts a restaurant and a panoramic view of the tracks.

site_title: Cake it till you make it
summary: A writer recounts the unexpected reaction of out-of-town guests at her wedding, who were shocked by a faux, five-tier cake provided by the venue, while local guests were unfazed. An informal poll on social media revealed that many Western cultures view fake cakes as taboo, while some countries like Malaysia, Sri Lanka, and Turkey have normalized the use of dummy cakes. The writer notes that the perception of wedding cakes varies across cultures, with symbolism and tradition playing a significant role in their significance.

site_title: Honourable mention
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Luxury watch brands have unveiled new timepieces to pay tribute to their inspirations. Omega's Aqua Terra range has evolved with a new teak pattern dial and Master Chronometer certification, while IWC's Aquatimer Special Edition celebrates its 35-year history with a 14.5mm-thick deep-sea diver. Hublot has partnered Ferrari to create the Techframe Ferrari 70 years Tourbillon Chronograph, featuring cutting-edge innovations. Casio's MRG-G2000HT features traditional Japanese craft techniques, including tsuiki metal hammering. Each timepiece is limited in production, with only 500 of the Casio model available for sale worldwide.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: From Cinderella to Hillary Clinton
summary: A new book, "Good Night Stories for Rebel Girls," celebrates 100 strong, real women who defy traditional feminine roles, such as being a princess, but instead pursuing careers like a trombonist or astronomer. The book, which was crowdfunded on Kickstarter, aims to empower young girls with the message that they can be whatever they choose to be. The stories feature women from various backgrounds and fields, showcasing their achievements and encouraging readers to be their own unique selves. The book serves as a counter-narrative to traditional sexist tropes and promotes female empowerment.

site_title: Taxman taps apps to make filing returns less taxing
summary: IRAS, Singapore's tax authority, has developed digital solutions to make tax filing easier for taxpayers. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has launched three apps: TinkerTax for small businesses, TallyGo for self-employed individuals, and FreeBoh, an online jobs marketplace. IRAS has also created an API Marketplace to facilitate co-creation with software developers. The goal is to reduce the complexity of tax filing and make it more accessible to taxpayers, with a focus on innovation and digital transformation.

site_title: BlackRock finds more risk assets at insurers than in '08
summary: BlackRock analyzed the US$5 trillion in US investments held by over 500 insurance companies, finding that if markets were to crash hard again, insurers' stockpiles would drop by 11% on average. This is significantly steeper than their mark-to-market losses during the 2008 crisis. Insurers have diversified their portfolios, owning stocks, high-yield debt, and alternative assets, which may provide a benefit in a downturn. However, some insurers are still taking on significant risks, and regulators are allowing firms to hold illiquid investments to improve returns.

site_title: Emas Offshore signs agreements with potential white knight investors
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, has begun restructuring proceedings and entered into a binding term sheet with potential third-party investors. The company aims to restructure its financial obligations.

site_title: China and Brazil sign agreements on football, nuclear power
summary: China and Brazil signed 14 agreements, including on football and nuclear power, during President Xi Jinping's meeting with Brazilian President Michel Temer in Beijing. The agreements aim to deepen cooperation between the two countries, with China seeking overseas markets for its excess industrial production capacity. Brazil's economy is slowly recovering after two years of recession, and the two leaders praised their relationship as "prosperous and affectionate." The agreements also mark a significant boost to trade between the two countries, with China becoming Brazil's top export market for beef.

site_title: Movie mania
summary: Singapore's first South Asian International Film Festival is underway, showcasing features, shorts, and documentaries by South Asian industry experts. The festival features panel discussions, master classes, and networking events. It concludes with a gala on September 9, including an awards ceremony, concert, and appearances by industry personalities like Manoj Bajpayee, who serves as the festival's mentor.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Purpose, values, culture - how do they drive governance?
summary: A recent Black Sun global research study found that 89% of executives believe companies must shift beyond profit to wider value creation. The pursuit of purpose will define companies that survive and thrive in the future, with a clear purpose linked to culture. The number of FTSE100 companies communicating their purpose has almost doubled to 60% this year. Encouraging holistic reporting models and incorporating purpose into business strategy are seen as key to driving long-term thinking and cultural change. The study emphasizes the importance of boards overseeing strategy to achieve a company's purpose, reflecting the values and culture of the company.

site_title: Social services builder
summary: Benedict Cheong, CEO of Temasek Foundation International, reflects on building a philanthropic organization from scratch. The foundation, established in 2007, has spent $180 million on 348 programs in 22 countries, benefiting 35,000 people. Cheong's approach focuses on "humanware" or institutional improvements, working with local partners and content partners from Singapore institutions. The foundation's programs aim to train leaders and create a cascading effect in host communities. Cheong, who has experience in the police force and as CEO of the National Council of Social Service, emphasizes the importance of flexibility, relevance, and resonance with host communities, and the need for stewardship in using resources towards the organization's mission.

site_title: Noble sells JV stake to Australian associate for US$1m in shares plus future royalty
summary: NOBLE Group sold its 50% stake in Coalridge Limited to Aspire Mining for US$1 million in shares and options, plus a future royalty. Noble's shareholding in Aspire rose to 18.2% from 9.54%. The consideration includes 66.67 million new Aspire shares and options, with a book value of A$1.80 million. Aspire also issued shares and options to Noble Resources International Pte Ltd, Noble's subsidiary. The sale comes amid Noble's financing constraints, with several traders and analysts leaving the company.

site_title: Noble Group sells stake in JV to Australia-listed associate Aspire
summary: NOBLE Group has sold its 50% stake in joint venture Coalridge Limited to Aspire Mining for US$1 million, receiving Aspire shares and options, plus a future royalty. Coalridge is a copper and gold exploration firm with several projects in Mongolia. The sale was made by Noble's indirect wholly owned subsidiary, Logarta Limited, in an exchange filing.

site_title: Singapore, Japan investing more in each other
summary: Singapore and Japan have increased investments in each other. In the first half of 2017, Japanese companies invested US$2.8 billion in Singapore, while Singapore-based companies invested US$3.3 billion in Japan. This marks a surge in direct investments between the two countries, driven by Singapore's foreign investment-friendly policies. The trend appears to continue, with Japanese firms now pumping US$2.8 billion into Singapore.

site_title: The hot dog finally has its day in Britain
summary: The UK is finally embracing its long-overdue hot dog day, with top chefs competing in a hot dog challenge hosted by Bubbledogs restaurant. Demand for hot dogs is growing significantly, with Kerry Foods reporting double-digit growth and selling over 20 million hot dogs annually. The trend contrasts with stagnant sausage sales, and even celebrity chefs like Jamie Oliver and Shake Shack's Mark Rosati are getting in on the action. While some Brits remain skeptical, others, like Richard Turner and Jonny Lake, see the hot dog's time in the spotlight has finally arrived.

site_title: SEA Games gold medal a silver lining for Singapore golf
summary: Singapore's golf team wins a gold medal at the SEA Games 2017 after 28 years, marking a triumph for the Singapore Golf Association (SGA) amidst a decline in the sport. The team's victory is seen as a launchpad to revitalize golf in the island, following a drop in playing population due to club and course closures and uncertainty about lease extensions. The SGA hopes the gold medal will change the face of golf in Singapore and attract new players.

site_title: Self-storage firm Beam, cashes in on vacant industrial space
summary: Beam Space, a Singapore-based self-storage firm, is capitalizing on the market's oversupply of industrial space to lease space at attractive rentals. With 1.2 million square meters of vacant warehouse space as of Q2 2017, Beam can generate 5-7 times returns at current rents. The company has installed security measures and offers flexible contract periods, making it more affordable than traditional self-storage companies. Beam aims to triple its current floor plate in six months and has attracted e-commerce and corporate customers.

site_title: Upping the steaks
summary: Singapore-based chefs will host a six-hands barbecue cookout at The Summerhouse on Sept 8, featuring unique cuts of Tajima wagyu from Australia. The BBQ Feast in the Garden will run from 6pm to 10pm, priced at S$140++ for a six-course menu. Local chefs Christopher Millar, Florian Ridder, and Alejandro Saravia will prepare dishes such as oyster blade, intercostal, and silverside.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Saab offers to build Gripen jets in India with billionaire Adani
summary: Saab AB has offered to build its Gripen warplanes in India with billionaire Gautam Adani's conglomerate as a partner, aiming to win a potential US$25 billion contract to supply fighter jets to the country's air force. The collaboration would involve design, development, and production of the aircraft, along with other high-tech products. This move comes as India's government seeks to reduce dependence on imports and create a "Make in India" defense ecosystem, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi planning to spend US$250 billion on defense hardware by 2025.

site_title: A week of missiles, hurricanes and floods
summary: A week of intense natural disasters, including a North Korean missile launch, hurricanes, and floods, left over 1,000 people dead and 24 million affected in South Asia. The disasters, including Hurricane Harvey in Texas, are linked to climate change, with warmer sea surfaces and air holding more moisture leading to heavy rainfall. The global impact is staggering, with estimated damages of over $30 billion, and the world is being forced to rethink its preparedness in the face of natural disasters.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Blackstone may cash out from this tropical island paradise
summary: Blackstone Group LP may sell its stake in Trans Maldivian Airways Pvt, a seaplane operator in the Maldives, after receiving takeover interest. The company, which owns one of the world's largest seaplane fleets, could be valued at at least $1 billion. Private equity firms and strategic buyers have shown interest, with China's Zongshen Group previously seeking a stake in the airline. The Maldives, a tropical island chain, attracted 1.29 million tourists in 2016, with mainland Chinese tourists accounting for 25% of arrivals. Blackstone's decision has not been finalized.

site_title: Mug shots: facial recognition nabs crooks at China beer fest
summary: Chinese police used facial recognition technology to catch 25 wanted individuals at a beer festival in Qingdao, arresting them in under one second. The system, which has a 98.1 accuracy rate, identified suspects at four entrances to the festival. The technology is also being used in other areas, such as identifying jaywalkers, predicting customer orders at KFC, and foiling toilet paper thieves in a Beijing park. The use of facial recognition in China has expanded beyond law enforcement, with the technology being integrated into various public services.

site_title: SunMoon appoints new chairman, will convene EGM to reinstate mandate for interested person transaction
summary: SunMoon Food Company has appointed James Prideaux as its new chairman and lead independent director, replacing Gary Loh Hock Chuan. Prideaux, a UK-based chartered accountant, will also attend training programs. The company is planning to convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval to reinstate its 2017 interested person transaction mandate, which lapsed due to its failure to renew it. The mandate allows SunMoon to carry out transactions with Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co, its largest shareholder with a 55.7% stake.

site_title: China's factory growth rises, but services growth slows
summary: China's manufacturing sector continued to grow in August, with both official and private purchasing managers' indexes (PMIs) exceeding expectations. The official PMI rose to 51.7, while the private Caixin reading reached a six-month high of 51.6. Analysts attribute the sector's resilience to previous loose monetary policies, government-funded infrastructure projects, and solid external demand. However, the services sector, which accounts for over half of China's economy, slowed down, with the official non-manufacturing PMI falling to 53.4. Moody's has raised its growth forecasts for China, South Korea, and Japan due to the global PMI outperformance.

site_title: British fashion retailer New Look seeks change of leadership to revive fortunes
summary: British fashion retailer New Look is seeking a change in leadership amid declining sales and increased competition from online retailers. Former CEO Anders Kristiansen has left the company, and Danny Barrasso, managing director for UK and Ireland, has been appointed as interim CEO. The company's board is searching for a permanent CEO to address the decline in revenue, which fell 4.4% in the 13 weeks to June 24. New Look aims to revive its fortunes by cutting costs and delivering a better product proposition, with the help of a new chief creative director, Paula Dumont López.

site_title: MST Golf opens superstore at Suntec City
summary: MST Golf has opened a 5,000 square foot superstore at Suntec City Tower 1, offering a comprehensive range of golf equipment and accessories from major brands. The store features a Golf Tech Shop with technical facilities for custom fitting, putter fitting, and club repair. Managing director Loh Ah Joo, nicknamed "the godfather of Singapore golf," aims to provide a positive energy boost to the sport, which has faced recent challenges. The store's launch comes after the opening of Golftec Singapore and the launch of new Titleist products.

site_title: SunMoon Food appoints new chairman, convenes EGM to reinstate mandate for interested person transaction
summary: SunMoon Food Company has appointed James Prideaux, a 54-year-old chartered accountant, as its new chairman, replacing Gary Loh Hock Chuan. Prideaux, who previously led Dole Asia Limited, will also serve as lead independent director. The company is also appointing Ms Ng Bie Tjin as an independent non-executive director. SunMoon Food will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval to reinstate its 2017 Interested Person Transaction (IPT) General Mandate, which had lapsed due to an oversight during its annual general meeting.

site_title: Online vigilantes go mainstream after Charlottesville
summary: Online vigilantes have taken to the mainstream after a white supremacist march in Charlottesville, Virginia, in response to "doxxing" - obtaining and posting private documents about individuals deemed hateful or racist. A protest in San Francisco's Castro neighborhood featured chants of "Dox a Nazi all day, every day." This phenomenon has emerged from subculture websites such as 4Chan and Reddit, where "doxxing" was once considered a cruel attack. The mainstreaming of online vigilantism has led to increased online harassment and labeling of individuals deemed hateful or racist, often resulting in job loss and social ostracism.

site_title: BOJ's break from battling the yield curve may soon end
summary: The Bank of Japan may soon resume its efforts to battle the rising 10-year bond yield, as global yields have fallen and central banks are expected to announce balance-sheet reduction plans. The Federal Reserve's plans and the European Central Bank's decision on tapering are expected to trigger a sell-off in stocks and bonds, causing Japanese bond yields to rise toward 0.1%. This could end the Bank of Japan's recent break from aggressively buying bonds to keep yields low.

site_title: Harvey's floods hang on in Texas, complicating rescue efforts
summary: Hurricane Harvey, which made landfall in Texas a week ago, continues to impact the state, with over 1 million people displaced and 44 feared dead from flooding. The storm has paralyzed Houston, swelled river levels to record highs, and knocked out the drinking water supply in Beaumont. A new storm, Irma, is strengthening in the Atlantic and is forecast to hit Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, and Haiti. The economic cost of Harvey is estimated to be between $51 billion and $75 billion, with widespread damage to the energy hub of Houston.

site_title: Design around the world
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Design festivals are taking place around the world, offering a platform for emerging and established designers to showcase their work. The London Design Festival runs from September 16-24, featuring eight Design Districts with distinct events and activities. Other festivals include the Something Good design festival in Bristol, Paris Design Week, and the Seattle Design Festival. The events will feature installations, workshops, and talks on creativity and design. They aim to inspire and engage the public, with a focus on sustainability and positive change. Visitors can explore various cities and experience the latest design trends and innovations.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US adds 156,000 jobs in August, unemployment rises to 4.4%
summary: The US added 156,000 jobs in August, a slowdown from expected levels, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.4% as it returned to June's level. Despite this, private employment rose by 165,000, driven by gains in the services sector, while manufacturing employment increased by 36,000. However, a 9,000-job contraction in the government workforce weighed on the total. The news may be unwelcome in the White House, where President Donald Trump has taken credit for reinvigorating the American economy and added 25 million jobs over the next decade.

site_title: US CEOs urge Trump to keep Daca 'dreamers' program in letter
summary: US CEOs, including Apple's Tim Cook and General Motors' Mary Barra, signed a letter urging President Donald Trump not to scrap the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, also known as "Dreamers", which protects young people brought to the country illegally from deportation. The White House is reviewing the program, which was adopted by former President Barack Obama. The CEOs' letter expresses concern over the potential deportation of these individuals, who were brought to the US as children and have grown up in the country.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after jobs data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday after job growth data showed a slower-than-expected increase in August and anemic wage growth, potentially making the Federal Reserve cautious about raising interest rates this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 35.26 points, the S&P 500 gained 4.77 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 14.93 points, all to new highs.

site_title: China Merchants Group is said to explore offshore rig deals
summary: State-owned China Merchants Group is exploring acquisitions of offshore rig operators, including Seadrill and Shelf Drilling, amid a collapse in oil-industry spending. Deliberations are at an early stage, and no formal offers have been made. China Merchants may opt for asset purchases rather than full takeovers. The move is part of a broader strategy to expand its energy sector presence.

site_title: China money rates rise as central bank drains cash, tight conditions likely to persist
summary: China's primary money rates rose for the second consecutive week as the central bank drained funds to tighten conditions. The seven-day repo rate increased to 2.9402%, up 0.99 basis points from the previous day. However, fiscal expenditure helped prevent excessively tight conditions. The central bank also banned the issuance of short-term debt to control banking system risk, suggesting a relatively tight environment may persist.

site_title: May faces questions on economic crime review as SFO awaits fate
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces questions on the progress of a review of Britain's economic crime agencies, which could lead to the dismantling of the Serious Fraud Office. Despite the review's incompletion, May had pledged to subsume the SFO into the National Crime Agency, drawing criticism from the legal community. The agencies under scrutiny include the SFO, NCA, and others, with a decision on their future to be made by ministers. The Treasury Committee has called for an update on the review, and May's spokesman said officials would deliver internal advice by the end of summer.

site_title: Eurozone yields rise as ECB's Nowotny plays down euro effect
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose across the board on Friday, reversing earlier falls, after ECB policymaker Ewald Nowotny played down the euro's impact on the ECB's stimulus withdrawal plan. Nowotny stated he wouldn't over-interpret the euro's sharp rise against the US dollar. The euro's strength had previously worried a growing number of policymakers at the European Central Bank.

site_title: China says Xi transcends West as a diplomatic "pioneer"
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has been hailed as a diplomatic pioneer whose ideology has transcended Western international relations theory, according to Foreign Minister Wang Yi. Xi has promoted China's Belt and Road infrastructure plan, positioning the country as a pillar of globalization. China has also expanded its global military reach, opening its first overseas base in Djibouti and taking a more assertive stance in maritime disputes. This assertive foreign policy has marked a significant shift under Xi's leadership.

site_title: Former Abterra head of trading returns to firm
summary: Abterra has appointed Liu Zhiyang as an executive director and head of trading, effective September 1. Liu, 42, previously served as Abterra's head of trading from February to October 2014 and is now returning to the firm.

site_title: UK manufacturing unexpectedly accelerates to four-month high
summary: The UK manufacturing sector expanded at its strongest pace in four months in August, driven by export orders and domestic demand. The Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 56.9 from 55.3 in July, exceeding economists' forecasts. Companies reported a strong intake of new orders, boosted by the weaker pound, and purchase-price gains accelerated for the first time in seven months. The manufacturing sector accounts for about 10% of the UK economy, and the data suggests it may support ongoing economic growth, leading some policymakers to call for an interest-rate increase to keep inflation in check.

site_title: Yahoo's first CEO and his wife are selling their mini-utopia for US$19.4m
summary: Tim Koogle, Yahoo's first CEO, and his wife Pam Scott are selling their California home for US$19.4 million, nearly double the original purchase price of US$8 million in 2003. The 5,440 sq ft mid-century modern house features four bedrooms, four and a half baths, and was once the site of the "Salawn Series," a gathering of intellectuals and celebrities, including Elon Musk and Alice Waters. The couple also developed an organic farm on the property, which now produces more than two-dozen fruit trees and various vegetables. The decision to sell comes after the couple downsized their extensive real estate portfolio, citing a desire for simplification.

site_title: Emas Offshore finds potential white knight investors
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, has started restructuring proceedings and entered into a binding term sheet with potential third-party investors to substantially deleverage its balance sheet. The company has also applied to the Singapore High Court to seek a moratorium on winding up its entities, which could provide stability for its day-to-day operations. The board believes the moratorium will enable the group to continue with the support of its key trade suppliers, but there is no certainty that definitive agreements with the white knight investors will be entered into.

site_title: US regulatory council votes to remove AIG's systemically risky label
summary: The US Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) voted to remove American International Group (AIG) from stricter government oversight, ending the era of stricter regulation for the insurance giant. AIG, which received a $182 billion government bailout during the 2007-2009 financial crisis, shed billions of dollars in assets and no longer poses a risk to financial stability. The decision reflects a changing tone towards financial regulation under President Donald Trump.

site_title: Anbang Life unit's premium income tumbles 99.6% after crackdown
summary: Anbang Life's life insurance unit saw a 99.6% decline in premium income in July due to an industrywide crackdown on short-term investment-type products. The unit's premium income fell to 48.8 million yuan, and sales of such products dropped 94.4% to 686.3 million yuan. This decline comes amid government scrutiny and domestic restrictions, including a rating cut by Dagong Global Credit Rating, and is linked to the detention of Chairman Wu Xiaohui in June.

site_title: Tencent Music is said to seek pre-IPO funds at US$10b value
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group, a streaming app operator controlled by China's largest social network operator, is seeking $10 billion in pre-IPO funding. The company plans to sell 3% of its shares to strategic partners, including record labels, to secure streaming rights in China's competitive music market. Tencent Music has deals with major record labels and operates apps with 600 million monthly active users, generating revenue through subscription, advertising, and content licensing. The company is expected to go public, but declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Microsoft chasing European startups for future cloud business
summary: Microsoft is launching a new Berlin-based accelerator program to support European startups, focusing on cloud computing, AI, and other emerging technologies. The four-month program will provide $500,000 in Azure credits, access to investors, sales teams, and technical experts. Ten startups, including Tellmeplus, have been selected for the program, which aims to win over future business for Microsoft's cloud platform. The move is part of Microsoft's efforts to be more accessible to startups, following increased competition from rivals like Google and Amazon.

site_title: Japan opposition picks former FM as new leader
summary: Japan's main opposition party, the Democratic Party, elected Seiji Maehara, a former foreign minister, as its new leader, marking the third change in 12 months. Maehara defeated Yukio Edano, a former top government spokesman, in the election. This move comes after the party swept to power in 2009, ousting the long-dominant conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

site_title: A Baltic surprise
summary: Latvia, a small Baltic state, is a hidden gem with a rich history, multicultural presence, and stunning tourist attractions. The country celebrates its centenary as an independent state in 2018 and boasts a unique identity shaped by its complex past with Germany, Russia, and Poland. Riga, the capital, is a must-visit, featuring the historic Old Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, with cobblestone streets and medieval architecture. The city also showcases modernist Soviet architecture and Art Nouveau buildings. Latvia's natural beauty, with over 40% forest cover and pristine national parks, attracts outdoor enthusiasts. The country has a thriving design scene, with local brands and artisans offering unique products. Modern Latvian cuisine is influenced by Nordic neighbors and focuses on seasonality and farm-to-table cooking. With a strong sense of community and a growing economy, Latvia is an under-the-radar destination that deserves more attention.
